webTitle: NHS dentistry is second-rate, patients told

fields.headline: NHS dentistry is second-rate, patients told
fields.standfirst:
Observer crusade hits home as profession admits that official line of 'equal treatment for all' is a myth

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's dentists have admitted for the first time that the work they do for NHS patients is second rate.
fields.body:
Britain's dentists have admitted for the first time that the work they do for NHS patients is second rate.

The British Dental Association has confessed that it has been conning the public by insisting NHS dentistry is on a par with private work. From now on NHS dentists will tell patients that the crowns, root canals, dentures and other treatments paid for by the state are not as good as they should be. They will say cheap, poor-quality materials are used and that too little time is allowed for them to do a decent job.

The association's change of heart was prompted by The Observer's Rip-Off Dentists campaign, which revealed that 90 per cent of NHS root canals are inadequate and 80 per cent of its crowns do not fit. The chairman of the BDA's general dental services committee, Anthony Kravitz, said yesterday: 'We cannot produce the quality we should be doing on the NHS.'

In a recent speech to dentists, Kravitz highlighted ways that government cutbacks are destroying the quality of NHS dentistry, and said: 'Do we tell the public about this? No, we pretend that the NHS is still looking after its patients properly. Our present strategy of stating that dentists who continue working fully in the [NHS] are providing the population with high-quality care is making our position increasingly untenable. Patients deserve better.'

Kravitz said that since the speech he has been deluged with messages of support from dentists relieved they can now tell the truth about the quality of the work. They have been desperately frustrated that the NHS is paying so little it is impossible to do a decent job, and that the Government is refusing to raise - and in many cases has lowered - the fees paid. Including labour, costs of materials and overheads, NHS practitioners are paid just £6.15 for a full check-up, £6.55 for a filling and £6.05 to extract a tooth. NHS fees pay only for 20 minutes' work on a root canal, when it should take an hour-and-a-half, they say. Overall the NHS spends only £30 per person per year on dentistry. Kravitz said this meant:

 NHS patients are not given crowns made of the precious metals used elsewhere in Europe. The cheaper UK materials are more likely to break off and may poison the patient;

 Root canals are done with old materials and equipment, and are less likely to be successful in the long term;

 Patients usually get plastic dentures on the NHS, not metal ones costing £10 more;

High-dosage X-rays are given because NHS dentists are given no money for low-dosage digital equipment, now the norm on the Continent;

 Sterilisation of instruments is not up to modern standards because NHS dentists have no cash for the latest vacuum sterilisation equipment.

Kravitz said: 'It's time the public realised that, despite the Government reassurances, quality in NHS dentistry is going down.'

All this will be a devastating blow to the Government's attempt to ensure NHS dentistry is available for everyone. Already many dentists have stopped offering NHS services because they want to earn more and do high-quality work. Now even more NHS dentists will tell patients they should go private.

'Dentists are going to be more blunt with patients - telling them they can have a non-precious metal crown, but "I wouldn't have it in my mouth",' said Kravitz.

Bill Courtney, chief executive of the Dental Laboratories' Association, whose members make crowns and dentures, confirmed: 'NHS work is inferior to private work. If it's for an NHS patient, dentists pay less, cheaper materials are used and less time is spent.'

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said: 'We are putting together a dental strategy that will guarantee high quality services.'

webTitle: Blairs move to block Leo picture

fields.headline: Blairs move to block Leo picture
fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: A group of schoolchildren were at the centre of a privacy row last night over photographs taken of sleeping baby Leo Blair at his first public engagement.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
A group of schoolchildren were at the centre of a privacy row last night over photographs taken of sleeping baby Leo Blair at his first public engagement.

Cherie Blair had brought her five-week-old son to show him to pupils at an award ceremony in her husband's constituency after they clamoured to see him. After a snapshot captured by the children's teacher was sent to a local newspaper Downing Street immediately issued a stern warning to the press against reprinting it. The move demonstrates the Blairs' determination to protect their four children from public exposure, but it risks being seen as an over-reaction to what the children's headteacher described last night as a 'perfectly innocent activity'.

A Downing Street spokesman said the Blairs had not consented to publication. 'They do not want to get into a position where they have to seek to prevent members of the public taking pictures that may end up in newspapers. The Prime Minister and Mrs Blair have always been grateful for the way the vast majority of newspapers have respected their children's right to privacy but they think it is right, given the follow-up inquiries the publicity has generated, to issue this reminder and point out once more the Press Complaints Commission guidelines on children.'

Downing Street later softened its line, saying it was 'understandable' that the Northern Echo had published the photo, but that the Blairs were anxious to avoid a market developing for snatched baby pictures. A spokesman said: 'It certainly wasn't done maliciously. There is a certain grey area when you have ordinary members of the public or children taking pictures. But what we are trying to avoid is pictures of the Prime Minister's baby ending up on all the front pages. Otherwise in future it could become hard to go out anywhere with the baby or indeed any of the other children.'

The editor of the Northern Echo, which published the picture after it was sent in with a bundle of reports on school activities, expressed his surprise at the move. 'As far as I was concerned it was a harmless bit of fun,' said Peter Barron. 'We thought it was funny that children from a local school had scooped the world's media by getting this picture. At no stage have we sought to breach the privacy of the Blairs or make any capital gain out of the picture.'

When Cherie arrived at the Durham County Cricket Club in Chester-le-Street for the ceremony, she left the baby outside with a minder. But as she chatted with pupils afterwards, they asked where he was, and she fetched the sleeping baby in his cot. Teacher Andria Farnon took the photograph as one of her pupils, 14-year-old Michelle Bennett, chatted to Mrs Blair.

The picture was submitted to the paper on Friday, a week after the event, as part of a regular round-up of schools' activities. When Northern Echo journalists spotted Leo in shot, they quickly realised they had a scoop. After the pictures were syndicated to national newspapers on publication yesterday, Downing Street swiftly intervened.

The school's headteacher, Brian Jones, stressed that the school had never sought to make money. 'It was an entirely innocent activity on the part of the pupils, and we decided to send the photos to the Northern Echo for the school report page. We did not think for a moment it would cause any problems.'

webTitle: Police win powers to shut down 'thug bars'

fields.headline: Police win powers to shut down 'thug bars'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Police are to be given sweeping new powers to close down 'hooligan pubs' which have a history of violence under plans to be unveiled by the Prime Minister.
fields.body:
Police are to be given sweeping new powers to close down 'hooligan pubs' which have a history of violence under plans to be unveiled by the Prime Minister.

Tony Blair will argue at a crime summit tomorrow that pub and club owners have to take more responsibility for customers who cause fights and criminal damage after a night of drink and drugs.

He will suggest that senior police officers be given powers to close down pubs and clubs immediately for 24 hours if they are violence hot-spots.

If a pub cannot show that it has taken steps to clean up its act, the police could extend the order for another 24 hours before going to the licensing authority and asking for the place to be closed down.

Blair's attack on late-night violence which blights towns and cities across Britain is the latest move by the Prime Minister to seize the initiative on crime. He is concerned that figures showing an increase in violent crime will damage the Government. An internal memo circulating in Downing Street says that crime is one of the key issues facing the Government, which fears missing its own performance targets. The announcement comes after a day of criticism for Blair, who was accused of announcing crime policies 'on the hoof'.

Tony Butler, the chief constable of Gloucestershire police, said that the Prime Minister should have consulted the police over his announcement that drunken louts should be given £100 on-the-spot fines by police. 'This is something which has just been announced out of the blue,' Butler said.

Civil liberties groups have also raised concerns that police will be given too much discretion over who should be fined and the Association of Chief Police Officers said it had its doubts about how the policy could be implemented.

But Downing Street insisted yesterday that Blair was simply raising important debating issues and that he wanted to hear all opinions.

This move follows on research done by the medical school of the University of Wales in Cardiff, where nurses were questioned about where casualties in hospital accident and emergency departments came from. A list of pubs which topped the violence league were then 'named and shamed' by the local police. The pilot scheme could now be extended nationwide, a move which the Government hopes will cut city centre crime.

Professor Jonathan Shepherd, who led the research, is emerging as one of the key players in the Government's drive to cut alcohol-related crime. He has been invited to the summit where he will tell Blair and police chiefs from the five largest police authorities about his research on alcohol and violence.

Shepherd, who is the director of the Violence Research Group and is highly regarded by the Home Office, advised pubs to introduce specially toughened glasses after his research revealed the horrific number of incidents of 'glassing' where people are attacked by thugs with smashed bottles and glasses.

Blair also wants to look at other areas where crime figures are rising. Incidents of domestic violence and racially motivated crime are all increasing. He will also ask about tackling mobile phone crime, which is one of the fastest growth areas, particularly the theft of phones used by children.

kamal.ahmed@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Nail bomber trapped by fake penpal

fields.headline: Nail bomber trapped by fake penpal
fields.standfirst:
To the tabloid press he is the man who conned and betrayed Britain's most notorious killers. To David Copeland, he was known as Patsy...
London nail bomber: special report
fields.trailText: Lovely Belinda Cannon, a curvy blonde with 'shining blue eyes', a 'perfect' wide smile and a bright, bubbly personality, couldn't help it. She had fallen madly in love with the Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe. She sent a torrent of letters, each signed off with 'big juicy hugs', to his secure ward in Broadmoor Hospital. Sutcliffe replied with equal enthusiasm, detailing what he would love to do if only he and Belinda could be alone together.
fields.body:
Lovely Belinda Cannon, a curvy blonde with 'shining blue eyes', a 'perfect' wide smile and a bright, bubbly personality, couldn't help it. She had fallen madly in love with the Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe. She sent a torrent of letters, each signed off with 'big juicy hugs', to his secure ward in Broadmoor Hospital. Sutcliffe replied with equal enthusiasm, detailing what he would love to do if only he and Belinda could be alone together.

Following the trial of London nail bomber David Copeland, another Broadmoor love story has emerged. The Old Bailey heard how Copeland fell in love with lonely secretary Patsy Scanlon who began writing to him shortly after his arrest. The letters continued for a year, slowly becoming more intimate. Copeland wrote that he dreamed about her wearing sexy clothing and could not wait for her to visit him in Broadmoor hospital. 'You're the only girl I write to so you have no need to be jealous.'

Copeland and Sutcliffe were, in fact, writing to the same person - a burly nightclub bouncer known as Bernard O'Mahoney who has been described as the 'Judas of Fleet Street'. Since the late Eighties when he struck up a friendship with Ronnie Kray, O'Mahoney has written to people involved in high profile criminal cases - sometimes posing as a woman, sometimes not - in order to sell stories to tabloid newspapers.

Copeland's replies filled two pages of yesterday's Mirror and earned O'Mahoney tens of thousands of pounds. They were also a key element in the bomber's court case as the prosecution used them as evidence of his state of mind.

In the case of Sutcliffe, O'Mahoney was less fortunate. He sent a woman friend, posing as Belinda, to the Sunday People with copies of the letters and a demand for £34,000. She broke down and confessed that the whole thing was a scam.

Undeterred, O'Mahoney began writing letters, using the alias of Patrick, to Richard Blenkey who was awaiting trial for the murder of a seven-year-old boy. In the course of a year, Blenkey wrote back 36 times, eventually confessing to the murder. O'Mahoney took the letter straight to the News of the World where once more it proved to be a key element in the subsequent conviction.

But O'Mahoney's trade is less concerned with guilt or innocence than with the amount of money he can make from a story. His biggest scoop came soon after the opening of the perfect tabloid murder trial. Michelle Taylor was said to have been consumed with jealousy when her boyfriend, John Shaughnessy, married a 21-year-old bank clerk named Alison. An uneasy affair continued between the two until in June 1991 Michelle and her younger sister Lisa allegedly ambushed Alison and stabbed her 54 times, leaving her dead in the hallway of her flat in Battersea, south London.

O'Mahoney wrote letters full of sympathy, certain that the sisters could never have committed such a crime. They were found guilty and as soon as the trial was finished the News of the World ran a scoop with the headline 'Alison's killer hated being love rat's tart'. It quoted a 'letter to a pal' in which Michelle Taylor described how she had come to hate her former boyfriend.

Michelle was distraught but O'Mahoney denied he was responsible. 'I would never harm you Michelle,' he wrote. He even offered to sign an undertaking that he would never betray their confidence. He then began campaigning for their release which was eventually secured by the Court of Appeal after it was agreed that the tabloid press had unfairly influenced the jury. Immediately the News of the World ran a story about the celebrations inside the Taylor home, even though their reporters had never stepped foot there.

O'Mahoney began an affair with Michelle, leaving his long-term girlfriend. When the pair broke up, O'Mahoney turned, claiming that Michelle had secretly confessed the murder to him and was guilty after all.

O'Mahoney also featured prominently in the case of Ecstasy victim Leah Betts. He had worked as a nightclub bouncer at Raquels where the pill that killed Leah was purchased. With the help of the News of the World he attempted to secure secretly taped confessions from some of those said to have supplied the drugs.

The revelations about O'Mahoney's involvement in the Copeland trial come as questions continue to be asked about how much police knew of Copeland's plans to plant a bomb in Soho. It was this third device, in the mainly gay Admiral Duncan pub in Old Compton Street, that was the most devastating of all, leaving three dead and 76 injured.

Copeland entered the pub at 5.45pm. He ordered a coke but seemed uneasy and kept looking at his watch and up and down the bar. A man standing nearby went over and asked Copeland if he was waiting for someone. 'I'm just waiting for my boyfriend,' came the reply. Copeland then asked where the nearest bank was and, having looking at his watch, left just after 6pm. The man offered to look after Copeland's drink, and the bomber accepted.

It was soon afterwards that the bag was first noticed. The assistant manager was called over and asked customers standing alongside, including pregnant Andrea Dykes, 27, and friends John Light, 32, and Nik Moore, 31, if the bag belonged to them. They said no. As he tried to read the writing on the bag, it exploded, killing Dykes, Light and Moore.

It subsequently emerged that police had visited a number of gay pubs in Old Compton Street the night before the blast, including the Admiral Duncan, warning them to be vigilant about unattended bags. Gay groups say police did not warn pubs in other gay areas such as Vauxhall or Earl's Court.

Sources within MI5 were said to have warned members of the gay community that they believed the bomber was targeting a gay venue three days before the Admiral Duncan explosion, but that this was not considered to be the most likely target by the Met's anti-terrorist squad. MI5 is known to have infiltrated groups such as Combat 18 and the National Socialist Movement of which Copeland was a member and chief organiser for the Hampshire area.

Copeland's worst outrage was to be his last. Police tracked him down through a series of leads, including calls from members of the public who recognised him from CCTV footage released following the Brixton bombing.

Police had also received a faxed list of names of people they suspected of being associated with right-wing organisations from a member of an anti-fascist group. Copeland's name was also faxed, although his name did not appear among those associated with those organisations.

In the early hours of the following day officers arrested Copeland at his home in Cove, Hampshire, following one of the biggest investigations ever held. Copeland immediately admitted he had caused the explosions. Suggestions that was known to security services before have been denied by police.

Police tracked him down through a series of leads, including calls from members of the public who recognised him from CCTV footage released following the Brixton bombing. Police had also received a faxed list of names of people they suspected of being associated with right-wing organisations from a member of an anti-fascist group. Copeland's name was also faxed, although his name did not appear among those associated with those organisations. In the early hours of the following day officers arrested Copeland at his home in Cove, Hampshire, following one of the biggest investigations ever held. Copeland immediately admitted he had caused the explosions. Suggestions that was known to security services before have been denied by police. Email Tony Thompson

webTitle: Foolproof 'dual keys' used to seal IRA arsenals

fields.headline: Foolproof 'dual keys' used to seal IRA arsenals
fields.standfirst:
Inspectors use system pioneered in Central American peace process to secure arms in south-west Ireland

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA arms dumps inspected by the ANC's Cyril Ramaphosa and former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari have been secured in the same way as bank deposit boxes.
fields.body:
The IRA arms dumps inspected by the ANC's Cyril Ramaphosa and former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari have been secured in the same way as bank deposit boxes.

Ramaphosa and Ahtisaari are understood to hold one of two keys to a dual-lock system, which ensures the arsenals cannot be opened unilaterally by the IRA.

Informed sources in Dublin claim this is the mechanism, which the two international inspectors said in their terse statement last Monday enabled them to check if IRA dumps were interfered with. The dumps could only be opened if both IRA quartermasters and the two inspectors were present with their dual-key system.

The dual-key system was used successfully by the UN in El Salvador at the end of the civil war in the early 1990s. UN inspectors held one of two keys that had to be turned simultaneously to open arms caches belonging to the left-wing FMLN guerrilla movement, which agreed to disarm following a ceasefire in the Central American country. Tonnes of weapons and explosives belonging to the FMLN were locked in secure dumps as part of peace negotiations between the Marxist guerrillas and the pro-American government in San Salvador.

'The dual key system is a bit like a bank deposit box,' a senior Irish source told The Observer. 'The customer owns one key; the bank manager has the other. The only way the box can be opened is if either customer and bank manager or employees are present with both keys having to be turned at the same time. It worked in El Salvador and it's our view Ramaphosa and Ahtisaari probably used the same system in Ireland.'

He said it was 'very unlikely' that the device hinted at by Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson was some kind of electronic tracking system.

'Ramaphosa would have needed a satellite to check the device to see if dumps were tampered with,' the Irish source said. 'But once you bring in satellite surveillance that introduces a third party into the inspection process, something the Provos would never have bought into.'

Few details have been released about the two inspectors' historic trip to southwest Ireland to check on IRA arms dumps. However, The Observer has established that Ramaphosa and Ahtisaari travelled to Ireland in a private jet rather than on a scheduled flight, thus avoiding publicity at airports in either Dublin or Cork.

It is not known if the jet belonged to Ramaphosa, who does have access because of his personal wealth to a number of private jets in South Africa. It is understood they were then taken from a private airfield in a blacked-out van to the dumps somewhere along Ireland's western seaboard.

Republican sources say the IRA man who masterminded their secret trip was Martin Ferris, a convicted gunrunner and key ally of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness. The journey took place around 22 to 23 June and lasted more than 24 hours.

Ramaphosa and Ahtisaari's brief report appears to have satisfied David Trimble and his allies in the Ulster Unionist Party. Ken Maginnis MP, the UUP's security spokesman and former major in the Ulster Defence Regiment, said he was satisfied that the dumps were secure.

'From what I have been told I am happy,' Maginnis said. 'I trust both men, they have an international reputation, which they would not put at risk just to help the IRA. Martti Ahtisaari in particular would not compromise himself just to help out a terrorist organisation. I am also content from what I have heard from the International Decommissioning Body. They have told me that the IRA has re- entered talks with them. It's a slow process but things are going in the right direction.'

If mainstream Ulster unionists are content, sceptical and dissident republicans are disillusioned that the IRA has opened up arms dumps to outsiders.

Tommy Gorman, a former IRA internee from West Belfast and co-founder of the Republican Writers Group, said an inspected dump was a compromised dump.

'This is decommissioning no matter what the Sinn Fein leadership tells its members on the ground. Once you open up a dump to outsiders it's difficult to see how it can be ever be used again. The penny hasn't dropped yet among most of the republican base though,' Gorman said.

Ruairi O'Bradaigh, the pres ident of Republican Sinn Fein, claimed that allowing the inspectors to check the dumps was a breach of the IRA's own rules, the so-called Green Book. O'Bradaigh pointed to the IRA's General Order No 11, which states that showing outsiders arms dumps and IRA arsenals is 'treachery punishable by death'.

Other republicans have attempted to portray the Pro visionals' historic move as a betrayal of long-standing principles. The Real IRA - the group that carried out the Omagh bombing - has been taunting former comrades in the South Armagh area over the arms inspections.

To underline their determination to maintain the 'armed struggle' the Real IRA blew up the Dublin to Belfast rail link near Newry on Friday.

Train services between the two capitals remain disrupted over the weekend. The organisation also staged roadblocks near the Jonesboro area last week with armed Real IRA men stopping cars, including those belonging to Sinn Fein supporters and members.

The two international inspectors are deeply respected both by mainstream republicans and unionists.

webTitle: Drugs tsar backs medicinal use of cannabis strains

fields.headline: Drugs tsar backs medicinal use of cannabis strains
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Cannibas could be legalised for medical use in as little as two years, drugs tsar Keith Hellawell has predicted. The former chief constable, who is Tony Blair's adviser on drugs, backed its availability on prescription after recent breakthroughs in research on the effects of marijuana.
fields.body:
Cannibas could be legalised for medical use in as little as two years, drugs tsar Keith Hellawell has predicted. The former chief constable, who is Tony Blair's adviser on drugs, backed its availability on prescription after recent breakthroughs in research on the effects of marijuana.

His words, which go well beyond Downing Street's strictly neutral public position, suggest the Government is moving closer to legalisation.

Crucially, scientists have now isolated two strains of the plant with very low levels of so-called THCs - substances which produce the 'high' - but strong levels of active ingredients thought to be medicinally beneficial. The resulting drug would be taken through an inhaler. Clinical trials on its safety and effectiveness will take another two to three years.

Hellawell told The Observer he was in favour of legalisation for medicinal use, adding: 'My view would be yes, if a derivative of cannabis can be shown to help, that we would encourage and support that.

'The two tests need to be that it is effective, and that it can be taken safely.'

However, he insisted that decriminalisation for general use was not on the agenda.

Although Mo Mowlam has publicly expressed support for legalisation for medical use and Home Secretary Jack Straw has said he is not opposed in principle, Downing Street has tried to keep a lid on the cannabis debate for fear of a backlash.

A Downing Street spokesman insisted yesterday: 'There are trials and that process is ongoing. We are entirely neutral, given there are trials going on.'

Legalisation for medical use would not allow patients to grow or smoke cannabis. The move would be warmly welcomed by campaigners arguing the seriously ill should not have to break the law to obtain relief.

The breakthrough by the company leading the trials, GW Pharmaceuticals, has been in finding varieties that would not make sufferers high - and so would not be attractive on the black market.

Meanwhile, Hellawell will produce a revamped drugs strategy at the end of this month, focusing on disrupting traffic in hard drugs such as heroin or cocaine by cutting off supply lines to international drug barons.

He has already established a secret intelligence unit based at the Cabinet Office, to trace the flow of money back from dealers and money launderers in Britain to suppliers abroad.

It will also try to curb black market trading in so-called 'precursor chemicals' - ingredients produced legitimately by Western factories, but used by illicit drugs labs to process raw materials such as the coca leaf or opium into street drugs.

fields.headline: Ken to shame sexist bosses
fields.standfirst:
London's Mayor targets business 'bigots' who fail to hire women
Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone will name and shame 'bigoted' private firms who do not hire enough women and ethnic minorities in a drive to root out workplace prejudice.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone will name and shame 'bigoted' private firms who do not hire enough women and ethnic minorities in a drive to root out workplace prejudice.

The Mayor of London believes black talent is wasted by big business and wants to expose those failing to tap it. His move on the eve of formally assuming his powers will alarm some in the City. But he said that if his new authority can ensure half its recruits are women and more than a quarter from ethnic minorities, so can others. 'We can take the policies we used in recruitment to private firms and say "a quarter of the community is black or Asian and you need employees, we can help".

'Then it is a question of naming and shaming the bigots. There is a huge reservoir of black and unemployed youth. A lot of these kids have incredible ability. If you give them a second chance they will jump at it.'

But Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors, attacked the plan: 'My initial reaction is that this is nothing to do with him. There are enough problems for firms with all the extra regulation coming through: to have this pushed upon you is the final straw. And speaking as a woman, I find it patronising.'

In a wide-ranging interview with The Observer, Livingstone also backed the effective decriminalisation of drugs such as cannabis and ecstasy for personal use, dismissing Tony Blair's war on drugs and urging a return to the state maintaining registered addicts on hard drugs.

However, Livingstone insisted he will not become a thorn in Downing Street's side: 'I'm totally immersed in my own job. It's Tony Blair's big mistake: thinking that I would be Mayor and I would cause him trouble. I'm up to my neck in work.'

After two uncharacteristically low-profile months, Livingstone's re-emergence into the limelight suggests some mellowing. Only days ago the one-time republican attended a lunch with the Queen Mother in full morning dress: he even shared a joke there with Baroness Thatcher. There have been amiable meetings with John Prescott, Jack Straw, Chris Smith, and David Blunkett, plus the Minister for London, Keith Hill. Even Blair phoned him after his victory. 'I told him how to win the next election,' Livingstone says cheekily.

So has Ken been housetrained? Amid the organised chaos of the Greater London Authority's temporary HQ, a redbrick former hotel near the Commons, he says he has relaxed about grabbing headlines because he finally has a proper job. 'The last 15 years of my life has been dedicated to how can I get my name in the newspapers. Now I'm actually running things.'

What he most enjoys running is transport. John Prescott will, he says, underwrite the costs of introducing congestion charges for driving into central London from summer 2002, in return for his officials helping devise them. 'If it works, everyone will say it is a transforming thing and it will spread throughout the Western world, and if doesn't I won't get elected again.'

Other priorities include a recruitment campaign with the Metropolitan Police encouraging more Londoners to join. He was shocked to discover most officers come from outside the capital. But flashes of the old mischief are never far away. During the election campaign, he was accused of being 'soft on drugs' for saying small-time cannabis and ecstasy use should effectively be de-penalised, and that Blair's war on drugs was failing.

'What I said was you shouldn't be bothering to arrest the girl with one E tablet in her handbag on the way to a rave,' he now says. 'If you went back to the situation where, if you are an addict, you register with a GP, you don't have to knock over an old lady for the money, half of all the crime in London would disappear.'

Arguments like these do not help his chances of working his passage back into the Labour Party, which he passionately wants to do. The first test of the relationship is July's Treasury spending review, in which he is seeking extra funds: he says it will determine 'if it's going to be trench warfare' with the Chancellor, Gordon Brown.

webTitle: Complain and we'll sue you, doctors threaten

fields.headline: Complain and we'll sue you, doctors threaten
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Beleaguered doctors are threatening to sue complaining patients for defamation. The threat of prosecution, being used by dozens of doctors, as well as midwives, dentists and opticians, is an attempt to hit back at the rising tide of complaints.
fields.body:
Beleaguered doctors are threatening to sue complaining patients for defamation. The threat of prosecution, being used by dozens of doctors, as well as midwives, dentists and opticians, is an attempt to hit back at the rising tide of complaints.

Patient watchdogs warn that the strategy threatens to undermine the Government's attempts to improve standards in the NHS and make medical professionals more accountable to the public.

Many patients, who may not be able to afford to defend themselves in a legal action and do not qualify for legal aid, have been forced to withdraw complaints, while others have ended up with legal costs of thousands of pounds.

By contrast, doctors can have their legal fees paid by medical insurance companies. In some hospitals, officials who handle NHS complaints are now warning patients not to lodge one or they will face legal action.

The findings have emerged from a survey by the Association of Community Health Councils, after it had been deluged with calls from patients asking for legal advice. It found that in more than 20 per cent of health authorities, doctors have threatened to sue patients for libel or slander for daring to complain.

Donna Covey, of the Association of Community Health Councils, said: 'We are appalled that, no matter how unjustified the healthcare professional thinks the complaint is, they use this sort of threatening behaviour to stop the complaint going ahead.'

The survey found dozens of cases where patients had withdrawn complaints, even though they are protected by 'legal privilege' which means the doctor has to prove malice to win. But the mere threat of legal action - and the costs involved - was warned many patients off:

 One patient complained about her doctor, who phoned her at home, saying he would sue her for defamation of character. She withdrew.

 One GP said he would sue a patient for defamation unless certain statements in the complaint were removed or amended. The complaint ultimately succeeded.

 A midwife sued a patient for defamation, but dropped the action before the case was heard. The complainant was left with a large legal bill.

 One Community Health Council relayed details of complaints to a hospital about one of its members of staff, who then threatened the CHC with legal action.

One extreme case was in Medway, Kent, where a GP - already suspended by the General Medical Council but still practising - had threatened three patients with legal action, landing one with £7,000 in costs. The patient, Diana Bryans, lodged a complaint against the doctor for misdiagnosis. The doctor took out an injunction against her and her husband Richard, accusing them of criminal damage to the practice.

'He really tried to intimidate me because I made a complaint to the health authority, and he slung all the mud back. He accused us of malicious damage and death threats,' said Bryans. The couple were arrested and ended up with four court appearances. The doctor was represented by a solicitor paid for by his medical defence company. They were acquitted.

The doctor wrote to another patient who complained, likening them to the serial killer Fred West, saying they were mad and insisting they had stolen money from the surgery.

The Medical Defence Union, which insures most doctors in Britain, said it was unaware of the problem.

Spokeswoman Mary-Lou Nesbitt said: 'I would like to see the proof of this - we deal in facts only. Have you checked your facts? I am unaware we have ever funded a doctor for this.'

Gerard Panting of the Medical Protection Society, the second largest medical defence organisation in the UK, said: 'We would not fund a doctor to do this. Litigating against complainants is a nonsense, and is not what the complaints procedure is about.'

webTitle: Dolly firm put woman's gene into sheep

fields.headline: Dolly firm put woman's gene into sheep
fields.standfirst: The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: The British firm that cloned Dolly the sheep has inserted the DNA of a Danish woman into thousands of New Zealand sheep without her knowledge.
fields.byline: by Antony Barnett, public affairs editor
fields.body:
The British firm that cloned Dolly the sheep has inserted the DNA of a Danish woman into thousands of New Zealand sheep without her knowledge.

PPL Therapeutics is refusing to disclose her name, but it has admitted the DNA probably came from a blood sample she gave in a clinic in the Eighties when she was 22. She has never been told what her DNA has been used for.

The company hopes to make profits by extracting a protein from the genetically modified sheep's milk which it claims might help cure diseases such as cystic fibrosis.

But the disclosure that a firm could use the woman's DNA without her knowledge, in the week that the human genome was unravelled, has led to calls for tighter controls on the biotech industry.

Dr Sue Mayer, director of GeneWatch, said: 'People give blood and organs thinking they will be shared freely with other people. They are given as a gift. Certainly most donors do not think their DNA will be patented, inserted into animals or bacteria and used to boost the profits of some company. Many people would find this morally objectionable.'

The Department of Health has admitted that DNA taken from blood or tissue banks in Britain can also be used by universities and biotech companies for genetic experiments as long as the donor is unidentified.

Professor Sandy McCall-Smith, vice-chairman of the Government's Human Genetics Commission, said: 'There need to be very clear guidelines on how human DNA is stored and used by industry.'

The Medical Research Council is reviewing its guidelines governing how human tissue can be used for experiments and McCall-Smith backed plans to ensure that donors have full knowledge of what their body parts, including their DNA, will be used for.

PPL denied it has acted improperly. Research director Alan Colman said: 'I would be proud if it was my DNA being used. The samples were taken in the Eighties when there were few guidelines. PPL was forced to reveal the source of the human DNA they had inserted into the sheep, after rumours began circulating in New Zealand that the DNA had come from the local Maori community.

Many in the local Maori community have been opposed to the flocks of genetically modified sheep which they find culturally offensive, believing that the 'bridge between human and non-human species should not be crossed'.

The local Raukawa tribe has insisted that if the project is abandoned at some point in the future, a ritual cleansing ceremony of the area should take place.

The sheep have been modified with copies of human genes from the Danish woman to produce the human protein alpha-1-antitrypsin (hAAT). PPL says this protein, which is extracted from the ewes' milk, could theoretically be used to treat acute respiratory problems and cystic fibrosis.

webTitle: BBC drops Peter Cook's drunk chat

fields.headline: BBC drops Peter Cook's drunk chat
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: He liked to talk. But the words of Peter Cook - bon viveur, wit and raconteur - were dropped last week from a BBC radio show after the long-suffering wife of the late star took legal action.
fields.body:
He liked to talk. But the words of Peter Cook - bon viveur, wit and raconteur - were dropped last week from a BBC radio show after the long-suffering wife of the late star took legal action.

As chief shareholder in the satirical magazine Private Eye, Cook was strongly against the courts being involved in issues of free speech. But five years after his death, the BBC has been forced to scrap plans to broadcast three programmes based on tapes of the comedian in conversation with a friend.

The BBC backed down after Cook's widow Lin took the production company making the series to court, claiming she had a copyright claim on the tapes.

It was the latest blow to Cook's neighbour and confidante George Weiss, who has been trying to have the tapes he made aired since Cook died of liver failure in January1995.

Now Weiss has thrown down the gauntlet to Mrs Cook. He says he will put short extracts of the tapes on a Rainbow Dream Ticket CD to raise money for his Rainbow Party political activities.

'It is an open challenge for Lin to sue and I would love to end up in court with her,' he said. 'She is behaving unreasonably about the whole thing.

'The supreme irony is that Pete always said he would never bring a legal action against anyone.'

The two have been embroiled in a wrangle over the tapes - 100 hours of rambling, often drunken, chats recorded by Weiss when Cook visited his London home - since Weiss revealed their existence in 1995.

He believes the tapes will help fans to understand the comedian as he really was, but Lin believes they are private conversations not for public consumption and does not want them broadcast.

Julie Dawson, of the independent London production company Wise Buddha, said BBC lawyers would not take the risk of going ahead with the programmes.

'We were commissioned to make the programmes by Radio 4. There is certainly nothing contentious in the content of the tapes themselves, but it seems the copyright issue is contentious. Mr Weiss said he had 100 per cent copyright then it turned out that was disputed. We went to court but the BBC decided not to broadcast.'

Lin has a reputation as a difficult woman and seems to have fallen out with most of Cook's relatives. Supporters claim she suffers from the 'Yoko Ono syndrome', when a wife is reviled by jealous fans of her husband. But she seems to bear no grudge against Weiss personally. 'Lin still pops the odd fiver through my letterbox to help me out because she knows I've got no money,' he said.

The relations between her and the Eye have always been strained since it was initially assumed she would take over Cook's controlling stake of 66 per cent. Rumours circulated that the Eye's happily laid-back environment would be subject to new, stricter management techniques.

When Lin, a Chinese-Malaysian, brought her brother Vin, a Geneva-based accountant, into the magazine's offices, editor Ian Hislop hung out a white flag and a sign in Chinese to welcome her.

She was also reported to be unhappy to find a jazz band rehearsing in the magazine's offices when she first visited after her husband's death.

fields.headline: Climbdown on e-snooping Bill
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Lobbying from internet pressure groups has forced the Government to step back from proposals forcing encryption keyholders to provide information to the security forces.
fields.body:
Lobbying from internet pressure groups has forced the Government to step back from proposals forcing encryption keyholders to provide information to the security forces.

A raft of amendments is expected to the highly controversial Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill which is currently passing through Parliament. Legal experts predict there will be more embarrassing climbdowns for the Government in the next few weeks.

However the Government shows no sign of backing down from the main principles of the Bill which will give the security forces unprecedented access to emails.

One of the main concerns of civil rights campaigners has been that the Bill would shift the burden of proof from the prosecution to the individual. Individuals would be compelled to hand over encryption keys to the security forces. But those who had lost the keys, or couldn't remember them, would have to explain why they no longer held them, to the satisfaction of a court. This, campaigners argue, is against current UK law and European human rights legislation.

The Bill is currently being scrutinised in the House of Lords and is due to reach the committee stage this week. The amended Bill will put the burden of proof on the prosecution to show that a keyholder is able to comply with an order to hand over a key but has refused to do so.

The Observer has also learnt that the Government intends to redraft the section of the Bill compelling a particular individual to hand over the encryption key. There had been fears that employees of companies could be bullied into refusing to release the key. Under a redrafted section of the Bill, the plan is now to serve notice on a company's directors rather than an employee.

All Internet Service Providers will still have devices fitted which allow the security forces to monitor people's email traffic. However, in what appears to be another climbdown, the security forces will have to obtain warrants from the Home Office before accessing emails.

Yaman Akdeniz, director of the pressure group Cyber-Rights & Cyber-Liberties, said: 'The IRA is no longer a problem. The Cold War is over. There are no real security threats. Just who are they targeting?'

webTitle: BBC to tell us the old, old Jackanory

fields.headline: BBC to tell us the old, old Jackanory
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: It made Mrs Pepperpot and Grimble TV stars and for 25 years was Britain's most popular children's television show. When it was axed four years ago adults and children complained that the BBC had abandoned story-telling. Now Jackanory is back.
fields.body:
It made Mrs Pepperpot and Grimble TV stars and for 25 years was Britain's most popular children's television show. When it was axed four years ago adults and children complained that the BBC had abandoned story-telling. Now Jackanory is back.

The BBC has signed up Anna Friel, Nick Moran, Sadie Frost, Ray Winstone, Marianne Jean-Baptiste, Kelly Macdonald and Sam Morton to read 15-minute-long stories which will be screened later this year. Among the tales are new works by Sean Hughes and stories by Jeffrey Archer and Diran Adebayo.

Greg Dyke, the BBC director-general, gave the programme the go-ahead after criticism that the art of story-telling was dying. 'We thought the email and text-messaging generation would be pretty good at spinning a yarn, so Greg told programme-makers to go away and prove it,' one BBC insider said.

Some of Britain's hottest young actors clamoured to appear. Stuart Murphy, head of programming for BBC Choice which will screen the stories, told The Observer: 'Like many of us they still remember watching Jackanory with the smell of baking cakes wafting in from the kitchen. Storytelling is such a British art and they wanted to be a part of the new programme.'

The rush to take part proved that 26 to 34-year-olds 'are not the sort of illiterate beer-drinkers who need two pints of lager before they can tell a tale that some people think they are,' Murphy added. 'They like telling stories. Anyone who does not know how to do it with a beginning, a middle, a tease, and an end is held in low regard.'

Most of the stories are horror stories and the series, being filmed at Hampton Court House, is designed to appeal more to adults than to children. Sean Hughes' story is called Sleep Tight and describes a son's revenge against his oppressive father. Diran Adebayo's The Unknown Chef stars Cathy Tyson, who has appeared in Mona Lisa. Jeffrey Archer's short story is Never Stop on the Motorway .

'We wanted to put the spook into Jackanory and pump it up with A-list celebs,' Murphy said. 'It has a firecracker effect. The programme will go much faster than the Jackanory everyone remembers from when they were in nappies'. Each 15-minute instalment will be screened in September.

The new chapter in the history of BBC storytelling will be welcomed by the thousands of parents who wrote to the BBC to complain when Jackanory was axed. The programme went on the air in December 1965.

At first, few actors wanted to clutch a book on the trademark cane chair. But it was a hit with children and by 1990 more than 650 stories had been read by some of Britain's leading actors, including Peter Sellers, Joanna Lumley, Denholm Elliott, Arthur Lowe, Kenneth Williams, Alan Bennett, Maggie Smith, Bernard Cribbins, Judi Dench, and Paul Merton. Prince Charles even agreed to read his tale of the Old Man of Lochnagar .

But as the popularity of music videos and soap operas grew, the programme's audience fell. In 1994 it was moved to Sunday morning before being dropped.

fields.headline: 'Snakehead' link to death fall reporter
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: He lived for his job. Tenacious, diligent and hard-working, Simon Macklin made his name as an award-winning reporter on the  South China Morning Post in Hong Kong before taking up the prestigious post as the paper's London correspondent. Popular with colleagues, neighbours and never short of friends or admirers, Macklin seemed to have it all.
fields.body:
He lived for his job. Tenacious, diligent and hard-working, Simon Macklin made his name as an award-winning reporter on the South China Morning Post in Hong Kong before taking up the prestigious post as the paper's London correspondent. Popular with colleagues, neighbours and never short of friends or admirers, Macklin seemed to have it all.

But last week his body was found on the pavement outside his London flat. His fourth-storey living-room window was left wide open.

His death sparked immediate mutterings that dark forces had been at work. He had spent the previous week investigating the tragic deaths of the 58 Chinese men and women found sealed in a refrigerated lorry in Dover. Macklin had written stories detailing the background of the notorious 'snakehead' gangs behind the people-smuggling business, about the fact that MI6 now planned to infiltrate the gangs and about the possible suspects involved in the Dover case.

There was talk of him working on a special investigation into Chinese organised crime and that he had received death threats from the gangs, who told him to stop his probing. Did he jump or was he pushed?

Macklin was no stranger to front-line investigative journalism, a path which makes enemies. Soon after completing his University of London degree, he was the toast of the Hong Kong press in his first job. In the early Nineties, he wrote a series of fearless articles exposing inhuman conditions among Vietnamese in refugee camps.

His startling features and news stories provoked such a powerful public response that the authorities were shamed into changing their policy towards the 'boat people'. The articles won Macklin the Hong Kong Journalist of the Year award as well as first prize in the best feature story category. He became the paper's chief reporter and spent six years as its news editor before returning to Britain two years ago.

He settled in quickly and wrote on a broad range of subjects: politics, entertainment, sport, he turned his hand to everything. The investigative edge was as sharp as ever and Macklin's reports of the Dover deaths proved it.

In Britain, the story dominated the front pages of both tabloids and broadsheets for days and stirred up a hornets' nest of emotions. In China, the reaction was more extreme. The luxury home of a snakehead gang leader close to a village where the dead immigrants were said to have lived was surrounded by 70 angry relatives who hurled rocks and stones.

Later that same day a journalist and photographer from Macklin's South China Morning Post were threatened by locals after being accused of theft.

The villagers attempted to bundle them into a taxi to take them off to teach them a lesson, but government officials intervened.

By last week the Dover deaths were overtaken by other events and Macklin wrote a number of other stories. At 9pm last Tuesday he filed a piece about a visiting politician and then spoke enthusiastically to his neighbours about Euro 2000 and his bet on France vs Portugal.

Despite the fact that the main door to his flat could only be opened by those inside the block 'buzzing' people, security-conscious Macklin locked his front door and attached the chain. Nothing more was heard until his body was found at 1am.

Police first suspected he had committed suicide, although the Post's editor, Robert Keatley, said there was no evidence of depression in the star reporter.

'If anything, colleagues have said that he was happier, even more up, than he had been for some time. He even had a new girlfriend.'

Colin Kerr, deputy editor of the Post at the time when Macklin joined the paper, was equally dismissive of the idea that Macklin had taken his own life: "He was a dedicated journo in the old style. He worked hard, was always the last to leave the office and lived his life with a passion for news and for this paper.'

In fact, Macklin was set to lose his cherished London job within two weeks. A reorganisation of the paper meant that the job of UK correspondent would no longer exist. He had chosen to remain in Britain and find a new job rather than return to Hong Kong.

'We had told him two months ago and his job was due to end in mid-July,' said Keatley. 'He did not seem depressed about it at all. He was a very good writer and I don't think he would have had any difficulty finding another job.'

With no note left behind and no evidence of previous depression, his family believe that Macklin's death was simply an the result of an accident, a theory which they trust will be borne out by the forthcoming inquest.

Friends said that he often read papers and magazines with his feet dangling out of the window. Somehow or other, they think, he may have slipped.

Others are less sure.

webTitle: Labour still on course for a landslide

fields.headline: Labour still on course for a landslide
fields.standfirst:
Peter Kellner launches a new monthly analysis of the polls with the news that Blair is heading for a big win next year

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Despite recent wobbles, Labour holds an 11-point lead and is on course for a big victory next year, unless Britain's economy hits trouble. These are the main findings of a new form of analysis of polls and political trends that  The Observer will be reporting each month from now until the general election.
fields.body:
Despite recent wobbles, Labour holds an 11-point lead and is on course for a big victory next year, unless Britain's economy hits trouble. These are the main findings of a new form of analysis of polls and political trends that The Observer will be reporting each month from now until the general election.

The analysis, commissioned by YouGov, the new e-democracy website, employs the latest computer modelling techniques to analyse polling data and then project the likely trends in party support over the next 18 months. It shows that as long as the economy remains on an even keel, Labour should win the next election comfortably, with a contest next May likely to produce a bigger majority than one in October 2001.

The Tories' best hope of denying Labour outright victory would be for the economy to nosedive this winter, and for Tony Blair to delay the election until the autumn of next year, or later. In those circumstances, the Tories could move into a three-point lead in October 2001. Because of the vagaries of Britain's election system, Labour would almost certainly still have more seats than the Tories, but would fall 10-20 seats short of the 329 they need for an overall majority.

This analysis is the work of Professor David Sanders of Essex University and myself and we have modestly christened our progeny the 'Kellner-Sanders Index'.

It combines the results of the latest published polls - by Gallup for the Telegraph , ICM for the Guardian and Mori for the Times . However, instead of providing a simple poll-of-polls average, our index adjusts the data to take account of the different methods used by the three companies, and the lessons of the last two general elections.

As the chart shows, Labour enjoyed a six-month honeymoon in 1997, when its lead averaged 30 per cent, before slipping to 15-20 points this spring. But this May, Labour's lead fell sharply to 10 points, recovering fractionally in June to 11. On these figures, Blair would be returned with a likely majority of 167.

However, there is not going to be an election this summer. The key question is: what will happen to party loyalties over the next 12-18 months?

Since the mid-Eighties, Sanders has pioneered the development of computer models for forecasting general elections. The key to his forecast is consumer confidence. The more optimistic voters are about their own prospects, the more favourably they tend to view the government of the day; the more pessimistic they are, the better the chances for the opposition. Consumer confidence, in turn, is driven by a number of influences, of which the most important is interest rates.

Other factors are also built into Sanders's model - including the observation that governing parties tend to incur 'costs of ruling'. In other words, over the course of a parliament, and all else being equal, support for ruling parties tends to drift slowly down.

Political forecasts can be blown off course by unforeseen events - and by exceptionally good, or inept, election campaigning. Our projections are best viewed as the likely underlying state of the parties in the absence of such shocks.

The central forecast assumes that interest rates stay roughly where they are today, and that consumer confidence remains broadly constant. If the economy goes wrong during the next 12 months, and consumer confidence slides so that pessimists eventually outnumber optimists by 30 per cent, then Sanders's model predicts that the Conservatives would move into the lead by the autumn of 2001.

This projection highlights one of the dilemmas that the Prime Minister could face. If Labour's lead is down to four or five points by next spring, Blair might well be tempted to abandon any thoughts of a May election, and hope for Labour's fortunes to pick up. But those are precisely the circumstances in which delay could be fatal.

If the economy does stumble, Labour would do better to take the risk of holding a May election. On a uniform swing, the Labour lead would still leave Blair with a majority of 40-50.

fields.headline: Outrage as Iran jails Jewish 'spies'
fields.standfirst:
Accused are spared execution as court caves in to criticism

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Ten of 13 Iranian Jews on trial for spying for Israel were convicted yesterday, receiving sentences of four to 13 years, provoking Western condemnation.
fields.body:
Ten of 13 Iranian Jews on trial for spying for Israel were convicted yesterday, receiving sentences of four to 13 years, provoking Western condemnation.

That no defendant received the death penalty, the maximum punishment for espionage under Iranian law, was a major victory for defence lawyers and a sign that Iran's Revolutionary Court caved in to international criticism.

Compared with other recent sentences, those against the Jews were light. A revolutionary court, for example, sentenced a university student to death for being photographed carrying a bloody T-shirt during pro-democracy demonstrations last July. The photograph was printed around the world.

Iran's supreme leader later reduced the sentence to 15 years in prison. The court seems to have defied hardline clerics who demanded execution for the Jews.

'We are happy with today's events because at least our clients and their families are sure there will be no death sentence,' said lead defence lawyer Esmail Nasseri. 'It was a small victory for us that we have passed this hurdle.'

Despite the lenient sentences, attacks against Iran intensified, as global Jewish groups and Western leaders condemned the verdict.

US ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, called it 'ridiculous'.

'This was a kangaroo proceeding. The fact that 10 were convicted is a tragedy for them and for all people who hoped to see Iran emerge into a more open society.'

A senior official of the World Jewish Congress said the convictions were 'vile' and 'uncivilised'. 'The continued persecution of the Iranian Jewish community and the outrageous pseudo-judicial process which upheld the spurious allegations of espionage against 10 of the accused has proved that Iran remains a pariah state,' said Lord Janner, a Labour member of the House of Lords and vice-president of the World Jewish Congress.

Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on Wednesday cancelled a visit to Iran, scheduled to begin on Tuesday, possibly out of fear that the sentences would be harsh. Both sides denied the Jewish case was the reason for the cancellation, but few in Iran believe this explanation.

Authorities in the southern Fars province, where the trial began on 13 April, maintained the Jews had been spying for 15 years. Officials said the mastermind of the ring, allegedly no longer in Iran, instructed the spies to collect classified information about local military installations, which was passed to Mossad.

Hamid 'Danny' Tefileen, sentenced yesterday to 13 years in jail, held wild parties where alcohol was traded for information, said Hossein Ali Amiri, the judiciary chief of Fars province. There was also a plan to pollute the water supply in Shiraz, the southern town that is home to most of the defendants.

The spies were said to have been aided by nine Iranian Muslims. Two of the Muslims were sentenced to two years yesterday and two acquitted.

Officials had refused until May to divulge evidence against the Jews, even though the suspects were in jail for more than a year. This secrecy left Iran vulnerable to accusations that the case was a 'show trial'.

The trial was held in secret behind closed doors. Before it began, some suspects confessed on Iranian television. While the confessions cannot be used as evidence, the public admissions were considered by Iran's critics to be a violation of the suspects' rights.

Some relatives of the Jewish defendants wept when they learned of the verdict. 'I want him to be released now, I want him to come hone,' said the mother of Ramin Nematizadeh, an army conscript accused of spying from his barracks. He was sentenced to four years in prison.

fields.headline: Nader the invader stalks Gore
fields.standfirst:
After 40 years as a radical campaigner, Ralph Nader is running for president on the Green ticket and stealing crucial votes, reports Ed Vulliamy in New York

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The man with the mournful mien and the quiet power is back - apparently more powerful than ever.
fields.body:
The man with the mournful mien and the quiet power is back - apparently more powerful than ever.

Ralph Nader is listed by Life magazine as one of the 100 most influential people of the twentieth century, which is more than can be said of the other candidates in the presidential election.

He has been in politics for 40 years, and - without broadcasting a single commercial - is a more familiar political brand name than either George Bush or Al Gore.

This is the first real Nader campaign. Without trying at all he took a mere 1 per cent in 1996. This time, he is on a hectic and relentless campaign trail (using commercial airlines) and set to bring in $5 million to pay for it.

Of course Nader is not going to win the presidency, but that is not the issue. The issue, over the past few remarkable days in the career of a remarkable man, is his impact on the one who does.

Nader - adopted last week by the Green Party - is running behind at 7 per cent in what is otherwise a close tie, with the candidate whose votes he will plunder, Gore, trailing Bush by a whisker.

In the make-or-break state of California, Nader has shot up to 10 per cent - enough to steal that crucial political fiefdom from Gore, who had assumed it was his for the taking.

And last week, America was treated to the extraordinary spectacle of the candidate for whom tree-huggers and animal rights nuts will vote in effect being endorsed by the famously muscular leader of the world's biggest and most macho trade union, Jimmy Hoffa's International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

The equally well-cut muscle of the Auto Workers union seems ready to follow suit with another monkey-wrench embrace. The prospect that he will now have to do battle with Nader for the industrial blue collar vote is a terrifying one for Gore, who had to fight hard to win the AFL-CIO (America's TUC) nomination last autumn in his primary scuffle against Bill Bradley.

Nader can be many things to many people - and in an America that is increasingly fragmented this is his strength more than ever before.

The mathematics of the Nader campaign are complex, but starkly alarming for Gore. So much so that workers on the Bush campaign tell The Observer that they are actively working behind Nader in some areas.

One plan - with Nader unlikely to make the 15 per cent needed to star in the final television debates - is to force Gore into a four-candidate TV debate comprising Nader and right-winger Pat Buchanan of the Reform Party, knowing that the brilliance of Nader's debating would be targeted at Gore, and disastrous to him.

Nader's strong showing in California, the Democrats' Convention state this year, is the main concern.

Another worry is Oregon, where Nader is picking up 8 per cent - thereby giving him the chance of converting the entire Pacific coastline from part of the safe Democratic base into a fierce battlefield.

In the Midwest, Nader will also upset the cart. In Minnesota, where his activists are targeting supporters of the maverick governor Jesse 'The Body' Ventura, no Republican candidate has won the presidential votes since 1982. Bush and Gore are now neck-and-neck, with Nader cruising at a balance-holding 7 per cent.

The percentages do not, however, tell the whole story. In measuring the floating voter, pollsters also count the 'favourable' and 'unfavourable' figures for each candidate.

In Ohio, for instance, 43 per cent have a favourable view of Nader, while only 19 per cent have an unfavourable one. Gore, who needs to win there, is favoured by 42 per cent, but has an 'unfavoured' rating of 45 per cent.

Nader is liked, admired and popular even among those who may not vote for him.

The politics of the candidacy are more mercurial than the maths. They have certainly changed.

Mop-headed but smartly dressed, Nader arrived with his gawkish walk at a bean feast of hi-tech and new-tech dotcommery in New York recently - the place in which he would seem entirely out of place.

But no, as his audience of adoring geeks made clear. In his long career as troublesome priest to corporate America, none of his campaigns bore such dramatic fruit as that against the Microsoft monopoly. It was not the US Department of Justice who began the siege laid against Bill Gates, it was Nader who insisted that the government sanction Gates.

His most celebrated previous success was against the car industry - when he led a tireless consumer campaign against scant attention to the safety of cars, markedly at General Motors in Flint and Detroit - with startling results, including the recalling of tens of thousands of cars and a tightening of safety specifications.

Taking a break to talk to The Observer - from working the conference floor urging computer users to boycott Microsoft - Nader explained that his political objectives are not about the environment, but about corporate power, universal medical care, income inequality, and campaign finance reform.

Nader had never been a revolutionary against, rather a watchdog on, the capitalist system.

In the Sixties, while the radicals wanted to tear the system down, Nader was one of the Junior Chamber of Commerce's outstanding young men of 1966, lobbying Congress to pass the Wholesale Meat Act and the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act.

His hallmarks were environmental pollution, health and safety at work and product safety.

Now he is more radical. The core of the new pitch is not to regard corporate power as something to be checked and balanced, but as a 'monster' which is going to take over our political government in Washington'.

'More and more corporations are raising our kids,' he says; 'companies are marketing to children from the age of two. What's wrong with a society that allows its most precious resource to be exploited?

'If there was a child molester in the neighbourhood, would it be enough to tell parents to lock the doors?'

On corporate power, he says, the only difference between Gore and Bush is 'the velocity with which their knees hit the floor when the corporations come knocking on the door... Both parties are subordinating themselves to global corporations which are without any allegiance to this country'. Gore, he says, is 'a coward'. The goal is to 'build a new progressive party that says to the Democratic party, if you don't shape up, you're going to ship out'.

Nader's strategy is, as he says, to 'bring thousands of people into the progressive political community' that already exists around him - 'that's a win,' says Nader, and a popular viewpoint too.

fields.headline: Playing the imitation game
fields.standfirst:
For Gore v Bush, see Blair v Hague

The US elections: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: American influence now pervades British politics. New Labour's political strategy and policy programme overtly mimics Clinton's, while William Hague is monitoring how George W. Bush mounts his candidacy for President. The news from the States, at least from the liberal-Left's point of view, is increasingly sober, with important implications for Mr Blair.
fields.body:
American influence now pervades British politics. New Labour's political strategy and policy programme overtly mimics Clinton's, while William Hague is monitoring how George W. Bush mounts his candidacy for President. The news from the States, at least from the liberal-Left's point of view, is increasingly sober, with important implications for Mr Blair.

Last week, Bush took a 12-point lead in the polls over Gore and, awash with cash, is set to repeat Clinton's strategy in 1996 of crowding out his opponent's advertising time over the summer with wall-to-wall adverts, so helping to harden a lead that becomes difficult to overturn in the autumn. Bush has also been aided by allegations of impropriety in Gore's fund-raising efforts in 1996, so that Gore has been on the defensive.

Gore, like Blair and Brown, is a cautious politician. He has hoped to continue with the New Democrat/New Labour strategy of appeasing the Right and Centre while offering a minimalist programme to his core supporters on the grounds they have nowhere else to go. His attacks on Bush rarely carry conviction because he does not want to lose the tag of being business- and middle-class friendly. His pitch is little more than 'Don't rock the boat', while respecting the conservative hegemony.

Bush has been able to assume the mantle of being the true conservative while trying to extend his appeal to parts of the old Democrat coalition by insisting on his 'compassion'. It may be phoney, but because his philosophy is, in effect, unopposed, he can appear plausible. Gore, meanwhile, is struggling to hold his own disaffected supporters together. In short, Gore's cautious pragmatism is in danger of appealing to neither Right nor Left. If the choice is between two compassionate conservatives, better vote for the real thing.

There are already signs of these trends asserting themselves in Britain. New Labour's political base is fragile and the policy of appeasing the Right while trashing progressives is beginning to give the Tories a new confidence, while disheartening Labour's base. The Tories are a long way from appearing to be or even wanting to be compassionate, but Hague and Portillo are watching Bush carefully. If he sustains his lead, we may soon be hearing a lot more Tory compassion than we ever expected. In which case, Mr Blair may have to sound like a Labour politician again.
