fields.headline: This cruel lottery
fields.standfirst:
Family courts must be more open

More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: Britain has the highest divorce rate in Europe, but its legal arrangements for dealing with family breakdown are a lottery. As we report today, parental access and contact with children hangs too frequently on advocacy and the prejudices of individual judges and welfare officers rather than the merits of each case.
fields.body:
Britain has the highest divorce rate in Europe, but its legal arrangements for dealing with family breakdown are a lottery. As we report today, parental access and contact with children hangs too frequently on advocacy and the prejudices of individual judges and welfare officers rather than the merits of each case.

The system was never designed to handle the current volume of work or complexity of family arrangements. The needs and fears of parents have tended to take precedence over the needs of children, especially for regular contact with estranged and separated parents. Sometimes this has meant fathers getting very limited access; on other occasions, that violent men have been granted damaging access notwithstanding their record.

From next April probation officers, guardians ad litem, court welfare officers and family courts will all be part of the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (CAFCAs). The hope is that this will see the reduction of anomalies in court welfare reports, which together with the recent House of Lords ruling on contact with violent fathers will offer a more codified and reasonable framework for parental access.

However, as our report underlines, fears persist that the lack of training of court welfare officers and judges means that without more disclosure and regulation quixotic judgments over contact will remain. Although we understand the argument for confidentiality, there is a need to re-establish public confidence that judgments are underpinned by a coherent nationally agreed philosophy - which means that we need to know what the judgments are through their disclosure. There is also a case for establishing some normal level of contact for the 'non-resident' parent as the base for access, but which can be varied as circumstances warrant. What cannot be allowed to continue is the current lottery - bad for children and parents alike.
fields.bodyText: Britain has the highest divorce rate in Europe, but its legal arrangements for dealing with family breakdown are a lottery. As we report today, parental access and contact with children hangs too frequently on advocacy and the prejudices of individual judges and welfare officers rather than the merits of each case. The system was never designed to handle the current volume of work or complexity of family arrangements. The needs and fears of parents have tended to take precedence over the needs of children, especially for regular contact with estranged and separated parents. Sometimes this has meant fathers getting very limited access; on other occasions, that violent men have been granted damaging access notwithstanding their record. From next April probation officers, guardians ad litem, court welfare officers and family courts will all be part of the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (CAFCAs). The hope is that this will see the reduction of anomalies in court welfare reports, which together with the recent House of Lords ruling on contact with violent fathers will offer a more codified and reasonable framework for parental access. However, as our report underlines, fears persist that the lack of training of court welfare officers and judges means that without more disclosure and regulation quixotic judgments over contact will remain. Although we understand the argument for confidentiality, there is a need to re-establish public confidence that judgments are underpinned by a coherent nationally agreed philosophy - which means that we need to know what the judgments are through their disclosure. There is also a case for establishing some normal level of contact for the 'non-resident' parent as the base for access, but which can be varied as circumstances warrant. What cannot be allowed to continue is the current lottery - bad for children and parents alike.

fields.headline: Don't mention the C-word
fields.standfirst:
Cones Syndrome afflicts politicians when they are in a panic to be seen doing something, but can't think of anything sensible to do

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Cones Syndrome afflicts politicians when they are in a panic to be seen doing something, but can't think of anything sensible to do
fields.body:
On to the wall of the Prime Minister's study should be hammered a neon orange hazard warning sign painted in six foot letters shouting: Beware Traffic Cones. Many say that John Major was finished by Black Wednesday, but it is equally arguable that his premiership descended into terminal risibility when the desperate quest to bring meaning to his Government culminated in the great unveiling of the Cones Hotline.

Alarmingly, Cones Syndrome now appears to have infected Tony Blair. Flourishing his big new idea to give powers to the police to impose on-the-spot-fines on 'hooligans', he tells us that faced with this threat 'a thug might think twice about throwing traffic cones around your street'. Welcome to the Cones Constabulary.

When he meets chief constables at Number 10 tomorrow, perhaps Mr Blair will have worked out the tariff he expects their officers to apply to those caught engaging in cone abuse. Is it to be a verbal caution for one cone and a £100 fine for two cones? Three cones - and it's life.

Cones Syndrome afflicts politicians when they are in a panic to be seen doing something, but can't think of anything sensible to do. The Government has been in a blue funk about crime since January, when recorded offences started going up for the first time in six years. The polls show the Tories pulling ahead of New Labour on Laura Norder. William Hague's call for vigilante justice had them cheering in the saloon bars of Essexland. The next set of crime figures are not going to look good. Panic, panic, panic.

So first we learn from a tale spun to the Sun that 'tough-talking Tony is to declare war on thugs and order judges to lock up thousands more violent criminals'. This is the usual tabloid vehicle when Tough Tony is given an outing, though it's a reasonable assumption that thugs - those of them who are literate - are much more likely to favour the Sun for their reading matter than, say, the Guardian .

Then, the Prime Minister flies to Germany to address the subject of global ethics. Into the middle of what is otherwise a thoughtful and interesting speech, he inserts this half-baked, lame-brained notion which hasn't been properly studied by the Home Office or discussed with the police.

Grabbing after another crackdown headline, the Prime Minister suggests that trouble-making drunks could be collared and 'taken to a cashpoint' to pay up their fine. Assuming, that is, they have a hundred quid in their account. Assuming also that these drunken yobbos are sufficiently co-operative and sober enough to remember their pin code.

As a general principle, summary justice, which turns police officers into prosecutor, judge, jury and tax collector, is not a terribly wise idea. But the one exception I might make to this rule is to introduce on-the-spot fines for politicians caught knee-jerking in public places.

Britain does have a crime problem, as does just about every country in the world. When the pubs chuck out on Friday and Saturday nights, many town and city centres become threatening places. Britain's squad came home from Holland and Belgium as the champion hooligans of Europe. Too many estates are terrorised by gangs. Too many lives are blighted by anti-social behaviour. That does not amount to making Britain the crime capital of the planet.

Organised crime is much more corruptly embedded in France and Italy. Racial violence is nastier in Germany. The present frenzy about crime has been further fuelled by the wide coverage of a ludicrous CBS report claiming that Britain is a more violent society than America. A citizen of the United States, home of the electric chair and land of the incarcerated, is seven times more likely to be murdered.

It's unsurprising that William Hague and Ann Widdecombe should seek to spread alarm that we are drowning in an unprecedented tidal wave of lawlessness. They are Opposition politicians looking for any truncheon with which to clout the Government. What is strange, and self-injuring, is the behaviour of Tony Blair and Jack Straw. Their contributions to racking up public anxiety about crime can only hurt the Government.

New Labour once had a very serviceable strategy, encapsulated in the sound-bite which was minted by Gordon Brown for Tony Blair: 'Tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime.' The second half of that formula, always as important as the first, seems to have been entirely neglected.

Though the Government is addressing some of the 'causes', all of the Home Secretary's rhetoric has been concentrated on simplistic toughness. He has introduced no less than five different pieces of criminal justice legislation in three years, each one designed to cultivate the character of Hard Jack.

There's been good progress in shortening the time it takes to get young offenders from arrest to court. But his nuisance orders and curfews - unhappy precedents for the Prime Minister's badly conceived gimmick - are not being used. The tougher-than-the-rest rhetoric piled up by the Home Secretary leaves him acutely embarrassable whenever there is a rise, whether it be a blip or a trend, in the crime figures.

Hard Jack has trapped himself in a caricature of ersatz working-class populism which has left New Labour without a plausible strategy or a convincing story to tell about crime and punishment. It is the Home Secretary's perverse boast that on his watch there are 4,500 more people in prison. The Prime Minister suggests that even this is too soft for Number 10. Tough Tony lets it be known that he wants the judges to ladle out gallons more porridge. Between them, they sound as if they will not be happy until half the country is in jail and the remainder of the population is employed as warders.

Messrs Blair and Straw, being lawyers by training, should know a bit about evidence. The rise in crime has almost certainly nothing to do with lenient sentencing. The 'prison works' doctrine adopted by Michael 'Something of the Night' Howard and then continued by Jack 'Something of the Right' Straw has encouraged judges to mete out longer stretches for crimes of violence. Crime is mainly going up because of a rise in the number of those most likely to commit it - young men between the ages of 14 and 25.

What the best research has always shown is that it is not ever-longer sentences that most deters criminals, but the prospect of getting nicked. The Prime Minister and the Home Secretary have surely also seen all the evidence that says the best way to prevent re-offending is not the length of sentencing but the use of prison for educating and rehabilitating criminals. Every over-crowded jail, apart from being a powder keg waiting to blow up under the Home Secretary, is a prison where there is less prospect of civilising its inmates. Every new prison leaves less money available for more police officers.

The Prime Minister and the Home Secretary, both intelligent and decent men, know this. On the quiet, when they think the right-wing tabloids aren't watching, the Government has even been doing some sensible things. But they have become imprisoned by inane get-toughery and self-defeating crackdownism.

I doubt it has any effect on young thugs. What it surely does do is wind up public terror about crime. This is not just a bad way of governing, it's a lousy form of politics. How on earth does it assist the popularity of the Government to feed the fear that Britain is plunging into a dark age of lawlessness?

I thought they might have learnt a lesson from inflaming the scare that Britain was being swamped with asylum-seekers. Whenever New Labour lurches to the right, the Conservatives will lunge even further. This an auction they can never win. Anything that Tough Tony and Hard Jack do, Vigilante Hague and Leg-Irons Widdecombe can do even worse.

fields.headline: Fears of a clone
fields.standfirst:
Worries about designer babies and other selective breeding in the wake of the genome project are overblown. Our defences against misuse of the human map are mistrust and democracy

The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Worries about designer babies and other selective breeding in the wake of the genome project are overblown. Our defences against misuse of the human map are mistrust and democracy
fields.body:
Let's start with a test. Think of your least favourite group of humans - not individuals, mind you, but a group. It could be thug children from peripheral estates who smashed your car open. It could be militant white supremacists or people with black skins. It doesn't matter - just any group you can't stand. And the question is: suppose you could blink right now and obliterate them forever, wipe them off the human chart from July 2000 onwards, would you blink?

Now let us move on. The world changed last month. It was a curious triumph, because scientists in rival teams have only mapped 97 per cent of the human genome, fully sequenced some 85 per cent of it and finished less than a fifth. But because of a deal between the Human Genome Project, funded by taxpayers in the United States and Britain, and the buccaneer Craig Venter, hoping to sequence the human genome with private money and patent some of the results, the great event was declared to have happened.

Why quibble? The public scientists and their political masters, Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, were not upstaged by Mr Venter, who is widely expected to win part of a Nobel Prize; the analysis of the genome will be over soon enough.

What everyone agreed was that this cracking of the human code was Big. It was bigger than the invention of the wheel. (And the wheel, you may recall, was Big. At the time, it was pretty much the biggest thing going.) This, though, was the recipe for all of us. Clinton called it 'the most wondrous map ever produced by mankind'. Even the cool heads at New Scientist concluded that: 'Monday, 26 June, will be remembered as the day when humankind learned, in a sense, what it is to be human.'

It is certainly a moment to take stock. The genome achievement can be compared with other, infinitely slower advances, such as books, several thousand years old, and electric-driven computers, several decades old, without which the reading of the code could not have happened. Now we have the massive information stack of the genome, the secrets of our hundred trillion cells turned inside out, it's interesting that we react by making these older achievements into metaphors; so the genome is the 'book' of human life, the 'computer programme' for humanity.

A book is the best of the metaphors. In his book, Genome, science writer Matt Ridley argues that it is more than a metaphor, it's literally true: 'A book is a piece of digital information, written in linear, one-dimensional and one-directional form and defined by a code that transliterates a small alphabet of signs into a large lexicon of meanings through the order of their groupings. So is a genome.' This one, he says, has 23 chapters, called chromosomes, each of them containing several thousand stories, called genes, and so on.

But, ingenious and passionate though this is, common sense insists that 'book', like recipe or computer programme, is a metaphor. A book has an outside intelligence as reader, whereas the genome is read, or has been, only by itself, endlessly reproducing, making tiny alterations. If it's a book, it is a auto-book, the ultimate, solipsistic autobiography. If it's a recipe, please imagine the cook. What strange being, with this coded information to hand, in which steaming environmental kitchen, could produce a human as we know we are humans? Come on.

Nor does it follow that this is a time when humankind has learned, in any sense, what it is to be human. We have spent millennia developing that, through ethics, art, philosophy, religion, music, politics and none of that is cancelled by the reading out of the mind-dazingly huge and complex sequence of our chemical bases (adenine, cytosine, guanine and thymine, combined a billion times).

To be human is to be the inheritor and transmitter of a biological, political, cultural and literary fate of endless beauty, danger and subtlety. To say that reading the genome changes one's view of this is as if I turned to my five-year-old daughter, congratulated her on her recent grasp of the alphabet and asked her to explain some puzzles in the emotional register of Shakespeare's late romances. In fact, it's worse than that. Since the sequencing is far from over, it would be like asking her the question while she was still confused about the shapes of b, q, u and p.

What has changed is not the alphabet, or a confusing new 'book'. It is the arrival of the manipulator-reader, us, the constant explorer now in new territory, navigating deep inside our own system. Exactly, say the critics; it is like the arrival of the Spanish in America, bringing their lust for gold, their diseases and their crude firepower. Watch out, diversity. Beware, people with genetic abnor malities. And the rest of us, prepare for the disastrous victories of the law of unintended consequences.

I think the political story of humanity offers more scope for optimism. The racist and totalitarian ideas driven out with such violence in the last century, and the greater squeamishness that has come with a more informed, educated and democratic culture, suggest that we may be able to cope with this increase in understanding and dexterity without disaster. We may, instead, be on the edge of a new and greener economy, in which wealth is created by extraordinary nimbleness in life sciences and less by moving lumps of metal around on the Earth's surface, burning carbon and exploiting crude Newtonian laws. The age of physics gives way to the age of biochemistry.

The first practical change all this brings will be uncontentious - the shrewdly-directed cancer treatments, the pills to cut obesity, the better identification of risks to our individual health and survival. As with earlier advances in health care, there will be second-order controversies - it will help the rich first and draw out lucky lives even longer. Overall, though, people are no likelier to protest against the arrival of genomics in medicine than at the advent of penicillin or open-heart surgery.

What, though, of the prospect of the wiping out of socially unpopular or genetically different groups and the creation of 'designer people', more handsome, intelligent and social than most of us today? That's the really scary stuff, isn't it?

Up to a point. Designer, or designed, people are here already. When an abnormally intelligent and well-favoured woman seeks and mates with a clever, hunky male to produce offensively attractive and sharp children, what are they making but designer babies? The basic principles of selection have been applied to people as well as to apple trees since time immemorial. But it will prob ably go further if already rich people can buy expensive genetic treatments to cut out the chance of a son who, sadly, turns out to look exactly like Great-Uncle Jeff, the family warthog, alcoholic and train-spotter.

Let them try. It will be far harder than they think, thanks to the huge complexity of genetic outcomes, never mind the massive laws of chance that have resulted in every one of us having the fantastic, surreal luck to be alive, and not a dried sperm or wasted egg, or, indeed, a nematode worm or the banana, with whom we share so much genetic material. If selective breeding really worked, we would presumably have already produced a superclass of wise and enlightened rulers. As it is, the cream of the cream have given us the contents of the Dome and the banalities of the current US presidential race. Far from the 'purified' races dreamed of by politicians in the early twentieth century (and not just Hitler; Churchill and most socialist thinkers were keen eugenicists, too), humanity is mingling more than ever.

The panic of Edwardian England and Twenties America or Sweden about the 'feeble minded' and miscegenation seems as outdated as spats or Gothic architecture. Look around today and you see that purity is out. We have discovered, to use Louis MacNeice's words, that 'World is crazier and more of it than we think,/ Incorrigibly plural.'

Or have we simply become sneakier about our language? In non-Catholic countries, the destruction of Down's syndrome embryos and therefore of large numbers of lives of people who would have been happy - indeed abnormally happy - has been going on for decades. The difference, however, is that this change comes from individuals, not politicians. We may admire the parents and carers of people with genetic abnormalities but, given the chance, most choose not be those parents. The idea of a state-sponsored drive against the fertility of any group has, by contrast, become unthinkable.

Our strongest defence against the misuse of these discoveries is simply our democratic culture. We have learned the hard way to mistrust the state, the great misuser of science in the century just past (Chernobyl, forcible sterilisation, anthrax bombs) and we are learning to use boycotts and protests to rebuke private companies today when they push new technologies too hard and too fast. The hard questions thrown up by the genome breakthrough are not scientific ones at all. They are old-fashioned ethical and democratic ones. If you are scared by all this, then you are scared of yourself.

I end with the opening question: could you, the reader, imagine wiping out any group, however irritating or offensive? Would you, if you could? Could you imagine any government advocating such a thing and getting away with it?

My guess is that the new genetics will bring wonderful medicines and very small shifts in the human stock, not the new eugenics or any of the nightmares based on crude and discredited thinking from a century ago. If, on the other hand, you began this piece with a spasm of furious blinking, then I am entirely wrong and the uncovering of the human genome has been a disaster.

In non-Catholic countries, the destruction of Down's syndrome embryos and therefore of large numbers of lives of people who would have been happy - indeed abnormally happy - has been going on for decades. The difference, however, is that this change comes from individuals, not politicians. We may admire the parents and carers of people with genetic abnormalities but, given the chance, most choose not be those parents. The idea of a state-sponsored drive against the fertility of any group has, by contrast, become unthinkable. Our strongest defence against the misuse of these discoveries is simply our democratic culture. We have learned the hard way to mistrust the state, the great misuser of science in the century just past (Chernobyl, forcible sterilisation, anthrax bombs) and we are learning to use boycotts and protests to rebuke private companies today when they push new technologies too hard and too fast. The hard questions thrown up by the genome breakthrough are not scientific ones at all. They are old-fashioned ethical and democratic ones. If you are scared by all this, then you are scared of yourself. I end with the opening question: could you, the reader, imagine wiping out any group, however irritating or offensive? Would you, if you could? Could you imagine any government advocating such a thing and getting away with it? My guess is that the new genetics will bring wonderful medicines and very small shifts in the human stock, not the new eugenics or any of the nightmares based on crude and discredited thinking from a century ago. If, on the other hand, you began this piece with a spasm of furious blinking, then I am entirely wrong and the uncovering of the human genome has been a disaster.

fields.headline: Blair's blackest art
fields.standfirst:
Ken Follett was an ardent supporter of the Prime Minister, but now is sickened by the briefings he uses against colleagues. In this blistering attack, he calls for the PM to turn his back on spin

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Follett was an ardent supporter of the Prime Minister, but now is sickened by the briefings he uses against colleagues. In this blistering attack, he calls for the PM to turn his back on spin
fields.body:
People can't choose how they go down in history. Most of us know nothing about King Alfred except that he burnt some cakes. How will Tony Blair be remembered? Possibly as the Prime Minister who made malicious gossip an everyday tool of modern British government.

I'm talking about 'briefing', the practice of vilifying your colleagues in off-the-record conversations with journalists. It's the media equivalent of the poison-pen letter - an anonymous attack by someone who is scared of honest confrontation.

Tony Blair did not invent it, of course. The technique was used by Margaret Thatcher's press officer, Bernard Ingham, and at about the same time was eagerly adopted by Peter Mandelson, then Labour's head of communications.

On a recent Channel 4 programme about the rubbishing of Mo Mowlam, there was a revealing interview with Roy Hattersley. With the bemused indignation of an elderly vicar who has accidentally tuned in to a sex film on Channel 5, he told how he had been 'briefed' while writing a profile of a Minister. (He did not name the man, but it must have been David Clark.) A Downing Street press officer had told him, off the record, that David - appointed, of course by the Prime Minister - was no good.

It happens every week. Last Sunday we were told that Downing Street was 'dumping on' Health Minister Tessa Jowell after an initiative on anorexia misfired. A recent Evening Standard piece told us that Chief Whip Ann Taylor was 'dispensable'.

Downing Street staffers say this kind of treachery has always gone on, but it's not true. Before the Eighties, it would have been highly unusual for a Prime Minister, or his messengers, to calumniate members of his own government to the press. Everyone was shocked when Ingham said that John Biffen was 'semi-detached'.

Neither John Major nor John Smith indulged in this shameful practice. Major's 'bastards' outburst expressed the fury of a decent man surrounded by traitors. Smith froze Mandelson out.

Nor does it go on in other countries. Reading the Washington Post or the New York Times, you never see articles denigrating Clinton appointees on White House authority.

The Prime Minister doesn't seem to have noticed how often it goes wrong. His attempt to blacken Mo's reputation backfired spectacularly. Her popularity has remained high while his plummeted. And so many senior Labour figures have been savaged by this technique that it is no wonder the public is becoming sceptical about the Government as a whole.

But what really bothers me is the morality of it. Not to put too fine a point on it, the whole business stinks. If you are displeased with a colleague, you should look him or her in the eye and say so. That's the behaviour my parents' generation called 'manly'. It's what we expect from leaders.

The people who do the briefing, who whisper the words of poison into the ears of journalists, are of no consequence. They are the rent boys of politics, and we shudder with disgust when they brush past us in the lobby. But what is truly disgusting is the desire for their services.

The polite fiction that the Prime Minister's advisors are responsible is absurd. Control-freak Tony doesn't let Alastair Campbell and Peter Mandelson go around saying anything they like. They do what the boss tells them. Peter isn't the Prince of Darkness, though he may be Lady Macbeth.

In the July edition of Saga magazine, Mo continues the pretence: 'Somebody is not happy with me - I don't think it's Tony Blair - but somebody wants to do me down.' She seems confident the Prime Minster won't be insulted by the implication that members of his Cabinet are stabbing one another in the back, assisted by people in his own press office, and he's too weak to put a stop to it. But of course Mo doesn't believe this, nor does anyone else.

Does the Prime Minister actually say to his staff: 'Go out there and stick the knives into Mo Mowlam?' Or does he hide behind euphemisms, like Henry II saying: 'Who will rid me of this meddlesome priest?' Does it matter? One way or another, he's responsible. He can't pos sibly be so stupid as not to know what is being done in his name.

Corrections are issued occasionally, when a mistake has been made and the wrong person crucified. If Tony Blair does not repudiate what has been said, we can be confident that he is behind it. When we are told that Gordon Brown is psychologically unstable, Mo has failed to recover from her illness, Harriet Harman is thick, Jack Cunningham is lazy, or Neil Kinnock needs to have his ego boosted by being photographed with celebrities, we know the identity of the 'source' from whom the story comes. It's the Prime Minister.

When this Government stumbles, it is usually over the rock of a moral question: Bernie Ecclestone, arms to Indonesia, Pinochet, Mike Tyson, Mandelson's mort gage. The latest example is the Regulation of Investigatory Practices (RIP) Bill, with its breathtaking insouciance toward civil liberties. (Home Office Minister Charles Clarke last week promised a rethink.)

In private conversations, Tony says issues don't matter to the average voter, only to the tiny minority who read the Guardian and send money to Amnesty. He's half right. These are not bread-and-butter questions. But people expect a Prime Minister to give a moral lead.

Tony's sure touch deserts him when he faces a decision that cannot be based on expediency. He tries to resolve the matter like a lawyer, checking what the rules say. He seems not to possess the inner core of strong convictions that would enable him to make a confident choice in a morally complex issue.

The effect has been tragic. The Government came to power like a knight in shining armour. People really believed New Labour would rule in a different way. They wanted a change from the feebleness and sleaze of the last years of the Conservatives. And the Government's achievements have been real. The economy is healthy, the promised reform of our education system is proceeding at a cracking pace, the health service is slowly being forced to modernise, and in dozens of ways, from gun control to reform of Parliamentary hours, the country is being catapulted into the twenty-first century.

But we have taken the road of expediency too often. Decisions such as the shockingly rapid return of Peter Mandelson to the Cabinet gave the impression that we are as soft on sleaze as was John Major, allowing the cynics in the pubs to repeat the shabby cliché that politicians are all the same.

High office is merciless in the way it reveals character. Slowly but relentlessly, Tony Blair's shortcomings are undermining him. The process has the tragic momentum of a Shakespeare play. One by one, the people with the strength to tell him when he is wrong are being dumped. A Minister was chatting recently about having warned the Prime Minister against foisting Alun Michael on the Welsh party: 'Tony didn't speak to me for a year,' he said. Meanwhile, advisors who play on Tony's weaknesses grown ever more powerful.

But the process is not irreversible. Tony can stop briefing in an instant. He simply has to give the word.

A good time to start might be the next reshuffle. The last was preceded, not so much by leaks, but by floods of vituperative briefings in which half the Cabinet were declared to be useless. This time, Tony should resist the temptation to prepare the way with mean-spirited gossip. He could announce that no 'Downing Street sources' or 'senior Cabinet members' will be commenting in advance. He could tell Alastair and Peter to keep their mouths shut, on pain of being sacked themselves. And he could energetically repudiate any reports that do appear.

It would be a signal that he is turning over a new leaf. It would give him back the moral high ground that he commanded three years ago. And it might mark the point at which his popularity begins to rise again. With a general election expected in about a year, it won't be a moment too soon.

webTitle: Rover's unsung saviour revs up towards top job

fields.headline: Rover's unsung saviour revs up towards top job
fields.standfirst:
Key union official Tony Woodley backs mediation, not militancy, to save car jobs, he tells Joanna Walters
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Key union official Tony Woodley backs mediation, not militancy, to save car jobs, he tells Joanna Walters
fields.body:
Tony Woodley lives by the car. But he almost died by it when he was run over as a child on Merseyside, and he still has the scar on his face to prove it.

The emotional wounds inflicted on this key union negotiator by BMW dumping its 'English Patient', Rover, are, however, much deeper, even if they are less visible.

Many say the fact that Rover still exists at all has a lot to do with Woodley's pugnacious campaigning and shrewd string-pulling after BMW threw in the towel.

He forced reluctant German bosses and British Ministers to talk, and made the vital telephone call that persuaded former Rover chief John Towers to lead the Phoenix rescue consortium, giving it the credibility it needed. Crucially, unlike others, he refused to give up on the tens of thousands of workers facing oblivion.

He was already being spoken of as a future general secretary of the Transport & General Workers' Union, to succeed Bill Morris. Now he is also regarded as the unsung hero of Rover's salvation, despite the company's precarious future and the surprise sale of Land Rover to Ford.

In promoting deal-making and negotiation more often than strikes, Woodley sees himself as 'a modern union man with traditional values', saving jobs more by mediation than by militancy.

Sitting in his tiny office high above the roaring traffic of Holborn, central London, last week, he reflected: 'BMW put their money where their mouth was in great measure, pouring billions into Rover. My only regret is that they did not have the honesty to come to us earlier and say, "We cannot carry on". Then we could have kept the company together under the ownership of another manufacturer.'

He was 'shocked, gutted and seriously angry' when, despite repeated oral and written assurances about Rover's long-term future, BMW panicked in March and decided to break it up.

Woodley was on an emergency mission to Munich, trying to get BMW to save the UK company, when he saw television pictures of Jon Moulton, boss of the venture capital group Alchemy which had just made a deal to snap up Rover. He believed immediately that his members had been thrown on the mercy of an asset-stripper.

The rival Phoenix bid was drawn together over the next few weeks in the face of deep media scepticism, equivocal Government support and zero early financial backing. The bad news for Phoenix persisted even when the Alchemy deal collapsed, after Moulton had reportedly demanded improved terms from BMW late in the negotiation. Rover looked doomed.

Woodley recalled: 'I never gave up. I phoned John Towers at 11 o'clock at night and told him I had to go back to Munich in two days' time with a credible leader for the Phoenix bid in order to get BMW to take it seriously.'

After a sleepless night, Towers rang to say he could 'do without this' - but that Woodley could 'count him in'.

'The rest is history,' the union man said last week.

There is no summer relaxation for him, however. Ford has announced the end of carmaking at Dagenham, reneging on a promise made to the union three years ago and putting itself on course for industrial action.

Nissan says its next Micra model may not come to the Sunderland plant which makes the present car. This is a single-union plant with AEEU membership, so not in Woodley's patch, but the issue has added to the sense of crisis in the UK car industry as firms shop abroad for parts and production to avoid the effects of the pound's strength.

Only last week, Vauxhall said no final decision had been taken on whether the next Astra will be built at its Ellesmere Port factory on Merseyside, where Woodley began his car industry career in the footsteps of his father, who was its union convener.

One industry source said: 'I just don't know how he keeps battling against the crises.'

Woodley said he never forgets his roots or his responsibilities to members trying to pay their mortgages - and he loves his job.

He returns to his Merseyside home each weekend in his British-built Vauxhall Vectra. He joked that he's ordered a Rover 75 and has been waiting for it since January. He lives with his wife Janet and 10-year-old son, Christopher.

Woodley was born into a working class family in Wallasey. He failed his 11-plus, left his local secondary modern at 15 with no qualifications and joined the merchant navy.

'I believe our primary school teachers looked at us, decided who would be able to afford a grammar school uniform and gave them extra attention. The system failed people like me.'

Sailor Woodley travelled all over the Far East with the Ocean Steam Ship Company, and found much of the legacy of inequality left by the British Empire 'shameful'.

The 'shocking squalor, child prostitution and desperation people went through just to earn bread' had a profound effect on the teenager.

At 18 he returned to land and a shopfloor job at Ellesmere Port, turning out Vauxhall Vivas in the short bursts of production that punctuated the 'daily and nightly' disputes of the car industry in the late Sixties and early Seventies.

Like his father, he quickly became a shop steward. Militancy in UK industry was blunted first by Margaret Thatcher, then by the arrival of the Japanese car manufacturers and the Nineties realism of trading flexibility for job security.

Woodley has not only embraced change, he has been a catalyst for it.

He is now seen as the rising star of the T&G. But he has taken chances by selling to workers so many unpopular management deals that some feared it would jeopardise his career. Some call it risky; others use the word visionary. Woodley calls it leadership. His style is blunt, often acerbic, always focused.

Industry expert Professor Garel Rhys of Cardiff University Business School said: 'He has built a good reputation as a bit of a firebrand into that of an individual who recognises that the only people who can guarantee a job are the motorists who buy cars.

'Poor industrial relations must be avoided. He has grasped the implications of the global economy and built trust with managements, while never forgetting where he came from and the hopes and fears of ordinary members.'

Rhys predicts that, barring something 'nasty' happening in UK manufacturing that undermines Woodley's work, he will be a candidate to lead the union when Morris retires. He described Woodley as one of the most realistic of the 'younger breed' of trade union movers and shakers.

Woodley himself recalled, among dozens of events that have shaped his outlook, the time 15 years ago when he was lobbying the boss of General Motors, Vauxhall's US owner, to invest more in the group's UK factories.

He said: 'At one point the guy turned to me and said "Tony Woodley, you have missed the point. We are not in the business of making cars, we are in the business of making money."

'As a sprog from a two-up, two-down with no carpets in Wallasey, I realised I was in the big league.'

fields.headline: Gentlemen still prefer blondes
fields.trailText: Sometimes I think you could put a long blonde wig and a Wonderbra on a rolled up rug, spray it with perfume, dab on some lipstick, leave it by the side of the road and men would still gather around it, as if hypnotised, pointing, and intoning robotically: 'SEXY! SEXY!'
fields.body:
Sometimes I think you could put a long blonde wig and a Wonderbra on a rolled up rug, spray it with perfume, dab on some lipstick, leave it by the side of the road and men would still gather around it, as if hypnotised, pointing, and intoning robotically: 'SEXY! SEXY!' This isn't your usual bolt of brunette jealousy, it's sheer bewilderment, and - yes, I have to admit it - a certain grudging respect, for the sheer persistence, the unflagging solidarity, of men regarding the issue of optimum female loveliness.

Decades of feminism have passed, huge mountains of literature have built up devoted to the evils of objectification and, only this week, Marks & Spencers announced that the average female form is a generous size 14. Elsewhere, big efforts are being made to convince young girls to accept that feminine beauty comes in all different shapes, hues and sizes. It's just a pity they don't make similar efforts convincing the guys. For, still, men seem absolutely determined to stick to their guns about this tall, slim blonde thing. You can try to talk them out of it until you're blue in the face, but in your heart of hearts, you know you might as well try to talk a ravenous monkey out of its next banana.

Of course, men like other types of women, too, but after the zenith of 'the tall, slim blonde thing', it's as if all the colours on the palette of female beauty run together to form a small pool of semi-attractive everywoman 'She'll do' sludge. In this way, men are like proud Philistines in an art gallery: 'I don't know much about the diverse beauty of the female form, but I know what I like.' What women have to accept is that these guys are not just pretending to wind you up or to get you back for publicly drooling over the Portuguese football team, a lot of them actually do prefer tall, slim blondes. It's a painful thing to take on board - this 'meaning it' thing - but it's really the only way one could even begin to understand the phenomenon of Russian tennis babe, Anna Kournikova. The latest comely manifestation of that ageless blueprint of male desire - 'the tall, slim blonde thing'.

I have nothing against tall, slim gorgeous blondes - my daughter is one. Unlike a lot of people, I've even got a few positive things to say about Ms Kournikova. She's fit, she has a modicum of talent (which is a modicum more than most British players), and she's given reporters something a bit more interesting to talk about than the high price of strawberries at Wimbledon. Kournikova's chief crime seems to be that, even more than Chris Evert and Gabriela Sabatini, she has succeeded in heterosexualising the sub-Sapphic ghetto of women's tennis. So much so, that when the 20-year-old first arrived at Wimbledon, linesmen were ordered not to stare at her legs. Presumably, they are permitted to ogle the posters plastered outside the grounds, depicting Kournikova smouldering in a Berlei sports bra that's about as sexy as a giant corn plaster. 'Only Balls Should Bounce', the poster's tag-line drones (Should have been: 'Hello Ball-Boys!'). Berlei paid Kournikova £3m for this. She made £7m in sponsorships last year. A 14th of that figure in actual winnings.

Sure, it's unfair that the merely pretty are more highly rewarded than the supremely talented, but welcome to Planet Reality. One could even argue that a woman's beauty is her own business, and if she manages to turn it into a hugely lucrative cottage industry ( pace Liz Hurley) then all the better. In Kournikova's case, there is the added amusement factor that she's such an arrogant piece of work. While so many girls her age waste their best years grovelling for male validation, here's a Kournikova quote on guys: 'I'm like the most expensive exotic item on a gourmet menu. People can look then wonder about the taste and the sensuous delights of such a dish but when it comes down to it they simply can't afford such an expensive luxury.' Quick, fetch a doctor! This young woman is suffering from high self-esteem.

Sadly, not many men seem to share Kournikova's 'gourmet' opinion of herself - of the ones I asked, at the most, they seemed to view her as an OK visual sex snack. The most common, rather Pavlovian response was: 'Oh her - blonde, yeah, nice.' To these men, Kournikova was just the latest tall, slim blonde to fall off the tall, slim blonde conveyor belt. Her gimmick, the thing that makes her seem taller, slimmer and blonder than the rest, the thing that makes her millions, is the fact she plays tennis. Without the tennis, it seems doubtful that Kournikova's prettiness, and scowly demeanour, would have got her very far in the modelling and acting worlds she professes to be interested in. That's why Kournikova should milk her situation all she can. In this unfair world, it's rather a good joke that an averagely talented blonde tennis player should make millions simply by reminding the world of a tacky Athena poster.

webTitle: Blair was warned of car crisis

fields.headline: Blair was warned of car crisis
fields.standfirst:
Report handed to PM before BMW debacle | Five factories still on secret 'at risk' list
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The Government was secretly warned that five British car plants were in serious jeopardy - with the potential loss of tens of thousands jobs - in a document passed to Prime Minister Tony Blair weeks before BMW rocked the industry by dumping Rover, The Observer has learned.
fields.body:
The Government was secretly warned that five British car plants were in serious jeopardy - with the potential loss of tens of thousands jobs - in a document passed to Prime Minister Tony Blair weeks before BMW rocked the industry by dumping Rover, The Observer has learned.

The warning was reiterated this weekend as union bosses and industry execu tives expressed their exasperation with government inaction.

Blair was sent a confidential union report at the beginning of March warning that the entire UK motor industry was under threat.

Although the identity of the plants has not been revealed, industry experts believe that in addition to Ford's Dagenham factory and Rover's Longbridge base, Vauxhall's plant at Luton, BMW's former Rover plant at Cowley and Nissan's Sunder land factory are the ones most likely to feature on an 'at risk' list.

Tony Woodley, national motor industry negotiator for the Transport & General Workers Union, wrote the report at a time when Longbridge was not considered one of Britain's more vulnerable plants. Since then, Longbridge has joined the others on the 'at risk' list as the Phoenix consortium that bought the carmaker from BMW battles to secure its future.

Woodley told The Observer this weekend that all five were still under threat as consolidation in the European industry gathered pace and the pound remained overvalued against the euro.

He would not reveal which factories he had named in his report to Blair, called 'The British Car Industry: What Future?', nor would he confirm experts' predictions.

Last week, Vauxhall chief Nick Reilly told a parliamentary committee that no final decision had yet been taken on whether it would build the next Astra at its Ellesmere Port factory on Merseyside; this sparked alarm among the workforce.

And Nissan president Carlos Ghosn last week reiterated The Observer's story on 14 May that the high pound could cost Sunderland the £150 million investment required to build the next Micra - putting a question mark over the plant's long-term future.

Ghosn is expected to meet Blair and trade secretary Stephen Byers in the coming weeks to warn of the threat to UK jobs of the Government's non-interventionist stance on the car industry and its delay on joining the euro.

But similar protests by a delegation of the UK's most senior car industry chiefs to Downing Street in April fell on deaf ears.

Woodley said: 'If manufacturing matters, the Government has got to intervene in the industry. It is about aid, it is about interest rates, currency policy, influencing senior industry executives... Whatever - it has got to do what is necessary. I warned Blair before the Rover thing even blew, and we are starting to see the fall-out across the industry.'

Woodley said the Government appeared to have 'just accepted' that Ford will cease building cars at Dagenham next year, arguing the state 'cannot interfere with companies doing their business'.

But he said such a stance put all motor manufacturing in the UK in jeopardy.

fields.headline: Canvassing support
fields.trailText: What luck! Apparently all the teachers at the school have gone off for a couple of hard-earned 'inset' days. Still, never mind, it's only the hottest day since records of having to drive around town running pointless errands with the children all in the back complaining their heads off began.
fields.body:
What luck! Apparently all the teachers at the school have gone off for a couple of hard-earned 'inset' days, which have been invented by the Department of Education to make room for national curriculum workshops aimed at improving sunbathing and shopping skills while at the same time offering harassed male parents the unexpected opportunity to see what it's like to juggle four children, burn toast, clean the downstairs toilet, detox the rabbit hutch, buy a tent, take the eldest for a haircut and get 57 varieties of earache while their wives are suddenly unavoidably out at work. Still, never mind, it's only the hottest day since records of having to drive around town running pointless errands with them all in the back complaining their heads off began.

I drop the eldest at the barber's, which has the immediate effect of reducing emissions of greenhouse gases in the car by 50 per cent, while the rest of us pop down to M&S for bread, milk and a game of hunt-the-three-year-old, who I eventually find running amok in ladieswear much to the amusement of absolutely no one but himself. 'Come on,' I say wearily, 'put the bra down.' We eventually lure him out with a selection of M&S cakes and return to pick up the newly shorn one, who emerges in buoyant mood having been chatting to his role-model teen snipper about the attractions of snowboarding, drugs and football hooliganism, and we set off with some enthusiasm for the outdoor discount leisure and camping emporium, which according to my wife's hand-encrypted instructions is located off a country lane somewhere in the middle of nowhere as indicated by a sign in a cowfield. Admittedly we do have to stop at a garage on the way to hose down the toddler who has thrown up and is now mired in reconstituted chocolate doughnut, but at last we find the place, optimally positioned for passing trade three miles up a dirt track in a corrugated former milking shed behind a scrap merchants, used car-part specialist and other miscellaneous grime-recycling enterprises.

'We're looking for a tent?' I say to the woman who comes sweating out of the darkness with a mouth full of ill-concealed sausage roll. 'Ad a ook in a compound?' she blurts, helpfully indicating the direction to take by spraying gobbets of mechanically recovered meat product towards what at this distance looks like a refugee camp, albeit one with striped awnings, barbecue areas and chemical toilets. So we wander round the displays in the shimmering heat, the children tripping over ropes and pegs, me fainting at the prices.

'Hey, cool - can we have this one, Dad!' shouts the six-year-old, disappearing into a 17-room canvas villa with gas central heating, Smeg fridge, conference facilities and gold zips.

'I think this is more us,' I murmur, lifting the storm flap of a second-hand £20 desert-camouflage ridge tent with two skeletons in it from El Alamein.

In the end we settle for one of those igloo jobs, which is just big enough for three boys wanting to camp out in the garden but, alas, just too small for a male adult to join them under any circumstances.

'It's very easy to put up,' says the woman.

'Ha, ha,' I laugh. 'Isn't that what they said about the Leaning Tower of Pisa?'

'Ha, ha,' she laughs, snatching the money out of my hands.

We zoom home in a state of high excitement, and we are soon out the back, them squabbling over whose job it is to lose what vital woggle out of which bag of bits while I try to fathom the 'international' instruction sheet, which consists of a) an illustration of what our tent looks like now, and c) an illustration of what our tent could look like if I was Lord Baden-Powell. There is no b).

'I mean, how are you supposed to tell which way round it goes?' I cry. 'What are all these sticks for? Why are there no peg holes?' I spread it this way and that, crawling in and out of the door, knotting all the wrong tags and clips together until heat exhaustion takes its toll and the three-year-old puts it up while I'm in the kitchen looking for the paracetemol.

'Hey, great job,' I say, helping them to stuff the tent with their quilts and teddies. 'I wish I could be in there with you tonight.'

The seven-year-old looks alarmed. 'But Mum said you would be...'

webTitle: Key Labour backer turns on 'cowardly' Blair

fields.headline: Key Labour backer turns on 'cowardly' Blair
fields.standfirst:
Blair's blackest art, by Ken Follett



New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A key architect of the New Labour project who has raised millions of pounds for the party launched an astonishing attack last night on Tony Blair, accusing him of being immoral, cowardly and a control freak.
fields.body:
A key architect of the New Labour project who has raised millions of pounds for the party launched an astonishing attack last night on Tony Blair, accusing him of being immoral, cowardly and a control freak.

Ken Follett, the millionaire author whose wife Barbara is the Labour MP for Stevenage, said Blair would be remembered as the Prime Minister who had made 'malicious gossip an everyday tool of modern British government'.

Breaking his silence for the first time about his views on Blair, Follett said that, far from leading an ethical Government, Blair presided over an administration which depended on vilifying people in secret briefings.

His attack puts the issue of spin and the Government's message once again at the centre of the political debate. He said the Prime Minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, and the Northern Ireland Secretary, Peter Mandelson, were not brave enough to air their criticisms of colleagues publicly. He described spin doctors as the 'rent boys' of politics.

Writing in today's Observer , Follett said the secret briefings were the 'equivalent of the poison-pen letter - an anonymous attack by someone who is scared of honest confrontation'. He added: 'What really bothers me is the morality of it. Not to put too fine a point on it, the whole business stinks. If you are displeased with a colleague, you should look him or her in the eye and say so. It's what we expect from leaders.'

Follett's attack, which follows criticism of the Government by Labour backbenchers and the former general secretary of the party, Lord Sawyer, is particularly wounding as the author was once a close friend of Blair.

In the Nineties Follett raised millions of pounds for the party as head of the 1,000 Club, an elite group who each donated £1,000 a year.

He has been credited with being one of the driving forces behind the modernisation of Labour. His wife advised its MPs on dressing well, and the couple earned themselves the sobriquet 'leaders of the luvvie brigade'.

He fell out with the Prime Minister, however, after photographers were tipped off about a party at his house to which Blair, then leader of the Opposition, and his wife were invited.

'Tony's sure touch deserts him when he faces a decision that cannot be based on expediency,' Follett said.

'He tries to resolve the matter like a lawyer, checking what the rules say. He seems not to possess the inner core of strong convictions that would enable him to make a confident choice in a morally complex issue.'

Follett said efforts to under mine the former Northern Ireland Secretary, Mo Mowlam, had been counterproductive.

'Attempts to blacken Mo's reputation backfired spectacularly. Her popularity has remained high. And so many senior Labour figures have been savaged by this technique that it is no wonder the public is becoming sceptical about the Government as a whole.'

Downing Street has always said it was not behind brief ings against Mowlam after stories appeared suggesting that she was struggling to recover from a brain tumour. Campbell has also publicly given her Mowlam his full support. But the author said of the role of Labour's spin doctors: 'The people who do the briefing, who whisper the words of poison into the ears of journalists, are of no consequence. They are the rent boys of politics.'

He said that Blair should put a stop to all secret briefings and get on with selling the Government's message.

'The polite fiction that the Prime Minister's advisers are responsible is absurd. Control-freak Tony doesn't let Alastair Campbell and Peter Mandelson go around saying anything they like. They do what the boss tells them.

'High office is merciless in the way it reveals character. Slowly but relentlessly, Tony Blair's shortcomings are undermining him.'

The Labour Party last night poured scorn on Follet's attack. 'It is sad to see people who purport to be on the Left peddling the propaganda of the Right,' a spokesman said.

'The lurid, over-the-top language of Ken Follett's remarks show why he is better known for his fiction than for his judgment.

'He joins the ranks of the disappointed and disgruntled who opt for the easy voice of opposition and the ready market to attack a Government taking the tough decisions needed to take Britain into the future.

'As for his attack on Alastair Campbell it was Alastair Campbell who put Government briefings on the record.'

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: A plastic carrot for vegetarians
fields.body:
A plastic carrot for vegetarians

If you are one of the country's four million vegetarians, you now have your own credit card - the Vegetarian Society card, offered by People's Bank in conjunction with the Vegetarian Society.

People earning over £18,000 can qualify for the Platinum card - offering a minimum credit limit of £3,000 and a rate of 5.9 per cent for the first six months, rising to 16.9 per cent thereafter.

Lower earners get the standard card - with an introductory six-month rate of 7.9 per cent, rising to 17.9 per cent. People's Bank makes a donation of £10 to the Vegetarian Society for each card taken out and gives 35p for each £100 spent on the card.

But veggies will be very altruistic if they end up paying interest on their purchases: lower rates can be found elsewhere.

Virtual tax

The Inland Revenue hopes that its email filing system for tax returns will be ready to operate tomorrow. It has been testing its software over the weekend and hopes that taxpayers will be able to complete the process without hiccup. There is a £10 discount off their tax bill for people who file this way. See www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk

Free guide

The Observer's sister publication, Money Observer, is giving away a supplement, Your Guide to Sharedealing, with its July issue, available in newsagents or by subscription (for £31.97 for 12 issues on 0870 870 1324). The guide is also available separately: send a cheque or postal order for £1.75 (including p&p) to Share dealing supplement, Money Observer, 75 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 3JY.

Come clean

A new government hotline encouraging people in the black market to come clean will turn its focus to tax cheats this month.

The line, Tax and Benefits Confidential, was launched last month with an advertising campaign aimed at stopping the practice of signing on and doing paid work at the same time.

But now the campaign will also be aimed at drawing in more upmarket tax evaders. The hotline - on 0845 608 6000 - can be called on a 'no names' basis, and the Treasury promises that 'no attempt will be made to trace the calls'.

Advisers can give rough calculations of tax and National Insurance liabilities.

Risky business

A free factsheet on evaluating risk is available from the Association of Investment Trust Companies on (020) 7431 5222.

It ranks different sectors from the most risky (emerging markets) to the least risky (UK income growth).

New pension

HSBC Bank is offering a pension that complies with the Government's criteria for stakeholder pensions. The HSBC Personal Pension scheme has a 1 per cent annual management charge and no charges for fund switches or monthly policy fees, and no bid-offer spread.

There is no minimum term, and investors can contribute as little as £20 on a regular or one-off basis. And when stakeholder schemes are launched in April next year, investors will be able to transfer the proceeds from their HSBC Personal Pension scheme into any other stakeholder scheme without penalty.

HSBC is also reducing charges and abolishing monthly policy fees for existing personal pension customers. Call 0800 520 420.

What's that?

Can you follow your bank statement? Do you understand why cheques take so long to clear? Have any idea what a bank draft is? The British Bankers' Association has compiled a series of factsheets covering all those questions you need to ask but have been too embarrassed to raise. For a free copy of BankFacts, call 020 7216 8801 or visit www.bba.org.uk

Amnesty gets ethical

Amnesty International has launched a free pack, Pensions: Protecting your future...and theirs?, aimed at people who want their pension fund trustees to take an ethical investment stance.

From tomorrow , pension fund trustees will be required by law to state the extent - if any - to which they take social, environmental and ethical considerations into account in their investment policy. Amnesty is encouraging pension scheme members to press trustees to consider human rights and other ethical issues in their management of the pension funds.

 Packs are available from Becky Hess on (020) 7814 6267 or email bhess@amnesty.org.uk

fields.headline: Two cheers for Labour
fields.standfirst: Three years after winning power, Blair's team gets a surprisinly upbeat vote from the personal finance experts. Neasa MacErlean reports
fields.trailText: Three years after winning power, Blair's team gets a surprisinly upbeat vote from the personal finance experts. Neasa MacErlean reports
fields.body:
Three years into its term of office, the Labour government is starting to be judged by results. Attention has so far focused on the highly charged issues of health and education - but how does the record stand when it comes to our own individual finances? Last week's announcement of the planned Universal Bank, to be run through post offices, is an indication that money issues are high on the current political agenda.

The Observer spoke to experts in this field and found the response to be far more positive than the day-to-day hum of New Labour criticism.

'At least this Government is recognising there is such a thing as poverty - which the previous Government did not,' says Geoff Fimister of the Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG). In 1979, one in 10 children was estimated to be living in poverty - a proportion which has risen to one in three now. But within the next year Chancellor Gordon Brown hopes to cut that proportion to one in four (3.2 million children) through Child Benefit increases and other rises.

'The Labour Government has tended to focus on those with the lowest incomes,' says Andrew Dilnot of the Institute of Fiscal Studies (IFS). Calculations by the IFS show that Brown's four budgets so far have been more redistributive than one might expect from a party which seems to aim itself at the middle ground of Middle England. The poorest 10 per cent of the population are nearly 9 per cent better off as a result of the budgets, says the IFS (www.ifs.org.uk) Meanwhile, the richest 30 per cent experienced a fall in post-tax income, once all the reforms are considered.

And everyone benefits from Labour's handling of the economy. 'You'd have to say that Brown is doing very well,' says Mike Warburton, head of tax at accountant Grant Thornton. 'He's avoided the recession, inflation is on target, interest rates are reasonably stable and not too high, growth is in an acceptable target range, unemployment is at a 20-year low and, although the pound is high, it's not too bad in relation to non-European currencies.'

Bharti Patel, director of the Low Pay Unit, gives the Government 'two cheers' on several of its initiatives, including parental leave and the minimum wage. Like many commentators she seems to feel that although much needs to be done, the Government has not done badly in three years.

There are also serious failures, of course. The New Deal is in trouble. The Government has dragged its heels on the difficult issue of long-term care. It has found some issues far more difficult to handle (Individual Savings Accounts and credit unions, for instance) than in the days when it could make pious statements from the safety of the Opposition benches. It has put several issues in the 'too difficult' pile. Why else would a political party based on collectivism allow large parts of the building society movement to throw away their mutual status?

Labour's future plans are now starting to take shape. The results of the comprehensive spending review - outlining areas of spending and retrenchment - will soon be unveiled. And on Friday Labour's national policy forum meets in Exeter to start discussing the manifesto for the next election.

There are calls from Old Labour representatives for a higher minimum wage and basic state pension. This could well be the scene of clashes between the forces of Old and New Labour.

In the meantime, we look at major areas of government activity over the past three years.

Taxation

Labour has kept to its manifesto pledge that there would be no increase in the basic or top rates of income tax; in fact, it cut the basic rate to 22p in April this year. But the cut in the basic rate is widely seen as a gimmick by commentators: if Brown had wanted to target the poor more efficiently, he would have raised the tax threshold higher. He has also boxed clever to keep to the manifesto pledge - taking tax benefits away in other forms, such as the loss of the dividend tax credit.

Warburton says: 'He has allowed himself to get far too fiddly. Most people don't understand the tax system any more.'

Welfare benefits

The party got itself a bad reputation among Old Labour when it stuck to Conservative spending plans in the first two years: it cut the benefits paid to single parents and went further and attacked disability benefits.

But although that reputation does linger, the reality may not be quite as bad. Fimister of the CPAG does not make the fierce attack on the Government that some might have expected of him: 'The Government has improved some disability benefits and cut others.'

Despite the intentions of Labour's first Minister for Welfare Reform, Frank Field, to move away from means-testing, the Government is going in the opposite direction. So, although the incomes of the bottom 10 per cent of the population have improved 8.8 per cent as a result of budget measures, the IFS concludes that poor people with some savings could be losing out, while their counterparts with no extra money will be doing better.

Home ownership

Interest rates for the country's 11 million homeowners have stayed relatively low: base rates ranging between 5 and 7.5 per cent. Although the Chancellor passed responsibility for rate-setting to the Bank of England, he takes the praise for the low-inflation, low-interest-rate climate. But if there is another 1991-style recession, the National Association of Citizen's Advice Bureaux believes more people could be repossessed because of a tougher stance by lenders, particularly mutuals which converted to banks.

Labour has done nothing to stop the move from mutuality - and could indirectly take some of the blame. Labour also plans to make home ownership more risky - by extending from nine to 14 months the period in which unemployed or sick homeowners are unable to get Income Support for their mortgage payments.

Individual savings accounts

The major criticism of Isas is, perhaps, that they do not fulfil Labour's once laudable aims of helping the poor to save - although the Pep and Isa Managers Association says that 'many new savers have been attracted' to Isas. About £28 billion was invested in 9 million maxi and mini accounts in the first Isa year, which ended in April. Isas are clearly reaching more people than Peps. In 1998/99, the last Pep year, about £16bn was invested in five million plans.

Pensions

To some degree, Labour's pension policy has already been a success. Its stakeholder pension, due to start in April 2001, is dragging down charges on personal pensions to the 1 per cent a year maximum allowed under the stakeholder scheme. But Labour stopped short of the step that must surely come one day - compulsion. There is also a danger that employers will be less keen to offer their own schemes (which they would contribute to) than stakeholder schemes (where they do not have to contribute).

The removal of the tax credit on dividends hits all our pension plans hard. But, on the plus side, the introduction of the 'minimum income guarantee' for pensioners gave a leg-up on income levels to the poorest pensioners claiming welfare benefits.

Despite pensioners' fury over the 75p rise on their basic pension, the country's 11 million senior citizens have not, says Dilnot of the IFS, done badly under Labour: 'It has allocated a reasonable amount of money to pensioners, but in different ways - winter warmers, free TV licence and so on - instead of putting it straight into their benefit.'

Pensions policy is an important issue for Labour, explicitly mentioned in the seventh of 10 pledges (the ones drawn up by Tony Blair in his back garden) about their aims in this Government: 'We will help build strong families and strong communities, and lay the foundations of a modern welfare state in pensions and community care.'

Long-term care

Homilies about treating the elderly with respect are the background noise you hear whenever Health Ministers make an appearance. But apart from this nice thought, little has happened in the way of action on the results of the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care for the Elderly. However, a white paper is due on this subject this month. With life expectancies extending, the bill for long-term care is potentially enormous.

A generous critic of the Government would congratulate them for starting to tackle a difficult subject. But they will inevitably be attacked for not going further.

Banking

Labour has taken a non-interventionist policy on some of the huge issues which are transforming banking - bank branch closures and the demutualisation of building societies and insurance companies, for instance. On cash withdrawal charges, they relied on Don Cruickshank to suggest compromises in his recent report on banking. Infuriated by Labour's lack of action, many people in rural areas may take their grudges about having to travel 10 miles to a bank into the voting booth when the election comes.

Working parents

Along with 'New Deal', the words 'Working Families Tax Credit' are thought to be engraved on Brown's heart. Far more generous than the benefit it replaced (Family Credit), WFTC is providing an average of £24 a week extra to working parents. But it is still 'too early' to judge its success definitively, says Patel of the Low Pay Unit. In the interim, she gives it 'two cheers' - the third being lost because of the way the interaction with Housing Benefit reduces the extra cash for many parents to just £10 a week. Another measure to help working parents is the new arrangement for 'parental leave'. Although this is currently unpaid, campaigners are hoping that paid leave will become a manifesto pledge. Very strong hints have come from Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers that he is considering this.

New Deal

Brown's flagship £4bn programme to help the unemployed find a new skill and a new job could have set the model for the rest of the world - if only it worked. 'New Deal is not looking good,' says Patel of the Low Pay Unit. 'Within the scheme, it has proved fairly hard to place the long-term unemployed in work - particularly people from ethnic minorities. And it may be that there is some institutionalised racism in the scheme.'

Only about a fifth of New Deal entrants are thought to keep the jobs they are offered. The Conservatives recently proposed scrapping the New Deal scheme for lone parents - without suffering any sort of backlash.

Minimum wage

More than 1.5 million people are thought to have seen their hourly wage go up after the introduction in April 1999 of the minimum wage (£3.70 an hour for people aged 22 and over; and £3.20 an hour for 18-to-21-year-olds). The Low Pay Unit gives two cheers to the minimum wage - arguing that the rate should be linked to a benchmark such as half of male median earnings, currently £4.94 an hour. The Unit believes that more than 1.5 million may have benefited - although some employers may have taken away some of the extra money by ruses such as reducing paid holiday.

In general, workers' rights have improved enormously through a raft of measures, including the right to four weeks' paid holiday a year; the equal treatment of part-timers with full-time workers; and the right to claim unfair dismissal (and therefore to get financial compensation) after one year, rather than two. Some of these measures have been forced on the Government by the EU and the European Court of Justice, but Labour has, perhaps, adopted them a little more enthusiastically than the Tories would.
