fields.headline: The greatest grump
fields.standfirst: Philip French pays tribute to Hollywood's ultimate nonconformist
fields.trailText: Philip French pays tribute to Hollywood's ultimate nonconformist
fields.body:
Walter Matthau, who has just died at the age of 79, was born in New York to Russian Jewish immigrants as Walter Matasschanskayasky, the name used for his guest appearance as a comic drunk in the 1974 disaster movie Earthquake. By that time the gravelly voice and the lugubrious bloodhound face were famous the world over and Matthau was a major star.

Success had come slowly. As a teenager on the Lower East Side he'd peddled soft drinks and played walk-on roles in the local Yiddish theatre, but it wasn't until after wartime service as a radioman-airgunner in the Army Air Corps that he studied acting with a grant under the GI Bill and became a professional actor. In the theatre and cinema he became a supporting actor, playing sardonic observers of the social scene, usually as a heavy or the hero's friend.

In his first movie, The Kentuckian (1953), he was the villain who drew Burt Lancaster into a duel of whips and in Michael Curtiz's King Creole (1958) he was the New Orleans gang boss making life difficult for Elvis Presley.

Between those two parts he had more sympathetic roles as the kindly neighbour of deranged teacher James Mason in Nicholas Ray's Bigger Than Life (1956) and as the liberal TV director who helps expose the fascistic anti-hero in Elia Kazan's A Face in the Crowd (1957). The title seemed to describe his career. He seemed destined to become one of those character actors like William Demarest and Sidney Greenstreet who are in constant demand, helping to populate Hollywood's special world, yet never taking centre stage. Then things changed in America as the studios declined, the conformity of the Eisenhower years gave way to the Kennedy era.

Matthau's supporting roles got bigger and stronger and allowed him to bounce off the smooth stars he worked with. As the decent sherriff in Lonely Are The Brave (1962), he stole the show from Kirk Douglas, and as the smooth villain in Stanley Donen's Charade the following year he had better lines than Cary Grant.

In Fail Safe he was a cold warrior, urging a pre-emptive strike on the President, Henry Fonda, and in Mirage he was a crafty New York private eye who gets bumped off by the military-industrial establishment for assisting Gregory Peck.

His biggest theatrical success came in 1965 under Mike Nichols' direction as Oscar, the selfish, slobbish sportswriter in Neil Simon's The Odd Couple , playing opposite a then much more celebrated comic actor, Art Carney, as the prissy Felix. I remember the excitement of seeing this production on Broadway and experiencing the confident arrival of a star, someone who commanded the theatre through comic misanthropy, scorned sentimentality and did nothing to ingratiate himself with anyone, either on stage or in the audience. He combined the bull-like feroc ity of Wallace Beery with the rebarbative humour of W.C. Fields. He was immediately signed up by Billy Wilder, who saw in him a man after his own cold heart and cast him as the ambulance-chasing shyster who lures his decent brother-in-law Jack Lemmon, into a legal scam in The Fortune Cookie (1966). The pair were as perfectly matched as Laurel and Hardy. The next year they appeared together again in the film version of The Odd Couple and made a further half-dozen pictures in tandem including the two Grumpy Old Men comedies of the Nineties. None was as good as those first two, and the best of them - Wilder's 1974 version of The Front Page - was not the classic that on paper it should have been.

Neil Simon had written The Odd Couple with Matthau in mind, and over the years Simon scripts gave him characteristic parts, the finest perhaps starring with George Burns as the vaudeville duo who can't stand each other in The Sunshine Boys . He worked beautifully with the nonagenarian Burns, and was usually at his best when locked in friendly or not so friendly combat with his dramatic or comic equals. He was marvellous with the feisty Carol Burnett in Pete 'n' Tillie, and as a techy priest in the rarely seen Italian comedy The Little Devil he brought out the best in Roberto Begnini as a devil sent to torment him.

He could, when called upon, play more or less straight, as he did in one of his best pictures as the ruthless crop-dusting pilot and part-time bank robber who tangles with the Mob in Don Siegel's Charley Varrick (1973).

During the last 25 years of his career the lines on the face got ever deeper and the voice became a dangerous growl. The roles, however, became increasingly stereotyped, a predictable succession of comic curmudgeons, whose hearts of gold we were invited to infer, and increasingly often to inspect. Yet he never gave up the sense of being his own man or the opponent of whatever seemed to be the establishment of the moment. In First Monday in October (1981) he played a liberal judge facing up to a right-wing woman appointed to the court. He was excellent in another courtroom drama, The Incident (1989), as an elderly lawyer who defies a xenophobic small-town community during World War II by undertaking the defence of a German PoW charged with murder.

His final appearance was as the isolated, dying father of sisters Diane Keaton, Lisa Kudrow and Meg Ryan in Hanging Up . Though sick and demented he goes to his grave rejecting all gestures of sympathy, turning everyone against him, but with a joke on his lips.

It was a bad film, but a courageous part for a sick, 78-year-old actor to accept. Matthau was bracingly funny, acerbic, and very special - as Charley Varrick advertised himself: 'The last of the independents'.

1920 - Born Walter Matasschanskayasky in New York's Lower East Side on 1 October, 1920, the son of Jewish-Russian immigrants. He had one brother, Henry. His father left home when Walter was three. First job before the war: organising basketball and gymnastics for the street-kids of the Depression for $23 a week.

World War II - Matthau enlisted in the Army Air Corps and served as radio cryptographer in a heavy bomber unit in Europe, earning six battle stars and a fistful of money from poker winnings. During the war, he met Captain James Stewart in England.
1945 - After attending Columbia School of Journalism, in 1945 he enrolled in the dramatic workshop at New York's New School. His first Broadway role came at the age of 28 when he was hired as understudy for the role of an 83-year-old English bishop in Anne of the Thousand Days.

Ex-wife - Grace Johnson.
Children - David and Jenny (with Johnson), Charles.
fields.bodyText: Walter Matthau, who has just died at the age of 79, was born in New York to Russian Jewish immigrants as Walter Matasschanskayasky, the name used for his guest appearance as a comic drunk in the 1974 disaster movie Earthquake. By that time the gravelly voice and the lugubrious bloodhound face were famous the world over and Matthau was a major star. Success had come slowly. As a teenager on the Lower East Side he'd peddled soft drinks and played walk-on roles in the local Yiddish theatre, but it wasn't until after wartime service as a radioman-airgunner in the Army Air Corps that he studied acting with a grant under the GI Bill and became a professional actor. In the theatre and cinema he became a supporting actor, playing sardonic observers of the social scene, usually as a heavy or the hero's friend. In his first movie, The Kentuckian (1953), he was the villain who drew Burt Lancaster into a duel of whips and in Michael Curtiz's King Creole (1958) he was the New Orleans gang boss making life difficult for Elvis Presley. Between those two parts he had more sympathetic roles as the kindly neighbour of deranged teacher James Mason in Nicholas Ray's Bigger Than Life (1956) and as the liberal TV director who helps expose the fascistic anti-hero in Elia Kazan's A Face in the Crowd (1957). The title seemed to describe his career. He seemed destined to become one of those character actors like William Demarest and Sidney Greenstreet who are in constant demand, helping to populate Hollywood's special world, yet never taking centre stage. Then things changed in America as the studios declined, the conformity of the Eisenhower years gave way to the Kennedy era. Matthau's supporting roles got bigger and stronger and allowed him to bounce off the smooth stars he worked with. As the decent sherriff in Lonely Are The Brave (1962), he stole the show from Kirk Douglas, and as the smooth villain in Stanley Donen's Charade the following year he had better lines than Cary Grant. He combined the bull-like feroc ity of Wallace Beery with the rebarbative humour of W.C. Fields. webTitle: Come off it, we all love Harry Potter

fields.headline: Come off it, we all love Harry Potter
fields.standfirst: Anthony Holden's criticism last week hit a nerve. We have had one of our biggest post-bags ever
fields.trailText: Anthony Holden's criticism last week hit a nerve. We have had one of our biggest post-bags ever
fields.body:
Is Beatrix Potter awful, too?
Could Anthony Holden advise me as to the worrying behaviour of my two-year-old daughter. She continues to get great joy from my reading unchallenging books such as the Harry Potter series, not to mention the incredible fantasy that is Beatrix Potter. Whoever heard of talking animals! Perhaps I have left it too late to introduce her to Chekov. K Marshall
Evesham
Worcestershire

You're rubbish
Look Anthony Holden I think your story about Harry Potter is rubbish! Although I may be only 10, I still count and there are plenty of others who do not agree with you. Holden says: 'As Harry approaches puberty, he will no doubt turn into a spotty little wizard who eventually gets the girl.' I disagree. Although he may become a teenager, I think he would never be such a thing. The books are about the fact that Harry is a wizard in this strange new world, not whether or not he gets a girl.

I disagree with the part where he says that you can predict exactly what is going to happen. You are an adult who is probably getting paid to write and as a child I would say that because you are an adult, and the book was written for children, you would not understand the magic that children feel when reading the books. All my friends find Harry Potter exceptionally good and for your own good I advise you to stop publishing things that criticise Harry Potter books, or you will be in trouble from a dozen more readers writing you letters like this one.
Joy Elsmore
Wokingham, Berks

My son reads now
In an age where the number of non-literary distractions seems almost overwhelming, JK Rowling has accomplished the feat of creating excitement about written stories, getting them discussed in the playground. She turned my eldest son into an avid reader.
Julian Page
Darlington, County Durham

They're original
I suppose it was only a matter of time before someone had to deflate JK Rowling's popularity. As a former English teacher, I can't say I have noticed her 'pedestrian ungrammatical style'. More to the point, have we to hear again the old argument about a story set in a boarding school being alien to day pupils? Surely there is attraction to something that is different from everyday reality!

It is also good for children to read stories that are thrilling, heroic, full of surprises and where good unashamedly triumphs over evil. He should also remember that however splendid Seamus Heaney's Beowulf is, it is a translation. The Harry Potter books are, with all their faults, original works.
E Barraclough
Leeds

Sour grapes
One wonders whether Anthony Holden's diatribe against the Harry Potter books was born of jealousy? He wonders why people do not prefer the writings of Seamus Heaney, David Cairns or 'even my own action-packed life of Shakespeare'.

As a newly qualified librarian, I do not feel that it is my role to dictate children's tastes to them. My own nine-year-old daughter commends Rowling's work as 'a humorous adventure which I can't put down'.

Holden criticises the élitism of Hogwarts boarding school. But don't stories such as Beowulf rely on privileged and élite characters such as kings, queens, knights and heroes?

I sense a feeling of sour grapes among Mr Holden and his Old Boys' Network of literary chums which is no doubt influenced by Ms Rowling's social background. She just does not fit in with the Oxbridge, male-dominated world of literature, and so much the better.
Phyllis Mutua
Edgware
Middlesex

Sheer envy
Why should reading be 'for the brain'? Isn't it acceptable to pick up a book to read and enjoy? Comparisons are odious - why can't one enjoy JK Rowling and Jacqueline Wilson. The Illustrated Mum is superb but that doesn't make Prisoner of Azkeban any less enjoyable. That an author who writes so extensively about the royals (hardly great literature) should whinge about 'a pedestrian, ungrammatical prose style' is beyond me.

I would suggest that it is the success that Ms Rowling is enjoying that sticks in his craw. Nothing upsets our journalists more than success - it's so un-British!
Jane Alexander
London SE3

Such fantasy
Anthony Holden suggests that young people should be reading more realistic things: 'Reading [Harry Potter books] is an activity marginally less testing than watching Neighbours. And that, at least, is vaguely about real life,' he claims. But he also said that 'I had looked forward to enjoying a magical ride through some thrillingly original fantasy world.' This is a contradiction.

Is he really trying to say that children should be watching Neighbours rather than be in bed reading, even if it is Harry Potter?

I personally love fantasy books and one reason for that is that they allow me to forget all my worries. If people enjoy fantasy then that's fine by me if it is enjoyable for them.
Hannah Tucker (year 7)
London E8

Get facts straight
I have just read Anthony Holden's article about Harry Potter and it made me very annoyed.

What is so wrong with Harry Potter that we are not to rejoice? Children are enjoying reading a perfectly good book so what is so awful? I found it quite funny how he compared the advertising and hype surrounding Harry Potter to that of the Wonderbra. They are completely different things.

Children are not as stupid as he thinks. We can tell the difference between a good book and real life. I feel that JK Rowling has brought joy to millions.

As for her using her initials, well it worked didn't it? I have met JK Rowling and she is very nice. I think Mr Holden should get his facts straight.
Catherine Somerville (11)
Edinburgh

A dog called Fluffy has my vote
Any book that has as a guard to the entrance to a secret tunnel, a three-headed dog, the name of which is revealed, several chapters later, to be Fluffy, gets my vote!

And how would parents get their young (and often, not so young) children to behave at all without the constant threat that 'there'll be no Harry Potter tonight'? Poor Mr Holden if he cannot see the excitement, magic and the sheer fun in the Harry Potter series. But then, if he thinks Neighbours is about real life (even vaguely), and that 'the infantilisation of adult culture' counts as an example of flowing prose, there is really very little hope for him.
Brian Everitt
London SE19

What a whinger
Harry Potter may not be about real life but children wouldn't want to always be reading about things that happen every day. Jacqueline Wilson's book are exciting as well, so why shouldn't children have both?

I picked up a few new words from Mr Holden's article but I also learned some from Harry Potter which can only be a good thing. Do you think Mr Holden is just whingeing because Harry Potter books are selling better than his? I am really looking forward to the new book and I hope Mr Holden enjoys it too.
Eve Garrett (aged 9)
Black Bourton
Oxon

For children only
I'm sorry that the Harry Potter books haven't cast a spell over Anthony Holden, but the truth of the matter is that they are not written for his age group, but for mine.

Although they may not be on a par with Alice in Wonderland, Treasure Island or Peter Pan, they are witty, enjoyable and imaginative ('Charm Your Own Cheese!'). He complains about marketing, However, the books were first sold by word of mouth, not advertising. Whatever Anthony Holden says, it won't stop us from enjoying the series.
Tom Lazenby (aged 10)
London E8

... and the one who thinks Holden is right
This morning I read with relief the crushing indictment of Harry Potter by Anthony Holden. The effect that reading these books is having both on adults and on children concerns me. Rowling's success may be attributed to her ability to provide mystery and excitement in a world where they are now rarely noticed.

Unfortunately, she shows an increasing fascination and attraction to evil and black magic. Rarely ever writing with delight about anything beautiful or positive, she seems to love describing the horrible Dementors in every detail.

In fact the only positive character in the whole series is the wise Professor Dumbledore, quietly in control of every situation, but whom we hardly ever see.

This obsession with evil can only have a negative effect on our children's minds. Come back CS Lewis's The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe and show us the wonder, magic and beauty of life again.
Fiona Campbell
London N6

webTitle: Now it's summer all year round

fields.headline: Now it's summer all year round
fields.standfirst: Forget 'beach' novels. Real people take heavyweight books on holiday. Now publishers have caught up
fields.trailText: Forget 'beach' novels. Real people take heavyweight books on holiday. Now publishers have caught up.
fields.body:
Summer reading happens all year round these days. It has got better, become Chick Lit (there is a ruder name) and moved into what used to be called the 'mainstream'.

No one would think of calling the new Bridget Jones 'summer reading', nor yet Amy Jenkins's Honeymoon . These books get all the resources and attention - the big launch (not always in the summer even), the bus-side ad campaign, the author interviews - given to major titles. Because that is what they are.

You used to know where you were with summer reading. It arrived in the bookshops in late June, as brightly coloured as a bird of paradise and twice as bold. Plot-led (usually a helter skelter search for Mr Right and the perfect pair of shoes), these were books that announced themselves as off-duty reading, the kind of thing to while away a long wait at the airport. If anyone caught you with one, you made a little face and said that you'd found it lying around the hotel and were planning to ditch it the moment you'd finished. And mostly that was true.

By September there were big, important new books to grab your attention, and the fact that you'd just spent two weeks reading something with raised silver letters on the cover was as quaint a memory as the lingering scent of Ambre Solaire on your towels. Summer books were part of a thudding rhythm, arriving each year like cruise wear or strawberries.

The publishing industry had a calendar as fixed as the Church of England. There was the heavy stuff in early autumn, the Booker maybes which had to slip in by the end of October in order to qualify for that year's competition (make them wait 12 months and there was a danger no one would remember). Then in June came the beach reads - romance and shoes for women, giant sharks and Mafiosi for men.

Easter was a mini- autumn, a reprise of the main September themes, with good literary fiction and biographies which weren't necessarily looking to a big prize. Then there was Christmas, when bookshops turned into penny bazaars flogging TV tie-ins, puzzle-book annuals, things about Victorians and odd boxed sets of minor classics that no one could possibly intend to read.

All this was annoying if you liked books and wanted to read them all the time, regardless of whether there was an 'r' in the month. August was particularly depressing, with last year's hardbacks vanished from the bookshop shelves, and a bored, desultory feeling among the staff, as if everyone was marking time until something more interesting happened. It was a bit like hanging round a provincial Debenhams, listlessly rummaging through sale tubs of shop-soiled bras, waiting for the winter coats to come in stock.

What made these coercive patterns so irritating was that they bore no relation to how people live and read. Far from being the time to slip on intellectual mufti, summer is the time when many of us finally have time to brain up. Formal obligations - to evening classes, sales conferences, PTA meetings - are over and there's a kind of a social and intellectual lull begging to be spiced up with something tricky and engaging. Likewise autumn, with its back-to-school busyness, is not always the best time to plough through the new heavyweight hardbacks, lining up menacingly like so much extra homework.

Real people are just as likely to read Bridget Jones in February and sweat through a Booker Prize winner on the beach. And, anyway, in an increasingly chopped-up world, even the idea of seasons seems increasingly meaningless. Bank holidays don't exist properly unless you happen to work in a bank. People opt to go into the office over Christmas and then disappear on holiday in January. Old timers in the publishing industry will tell you that the reason big books never used to be launched in August was that the reviewers were all away, stretched out in a hammock in rural France. These days any critic without children is much more likely to be propping up a wine bar in EC1, desperate for someone to give him or her something to do.

So it is a relief that the publishing industry has finally caught up with the rhythms of the real year. Publishers are increasingly taking their cue from Amazon and the late-opening Waterstone's and responding to the fact that reading goes on all the time.

HarperCollins is publishing several important biographies in July, including Claire Harman's Fanny Burney, A Biography and Richard Holmes's Sidetracks, and Sceptre and Hodder & Stoughton are running right through August with literary fiction and heavyweight biography: Kit's Law by Donna Morrissey, Fred and Edie by Jill Dawson plus a new life of Patrick O'Brian by Dean King. Amy Jenkins's Honeymoon, on the other hand, got an Easter launch from the same company. And the final, incontrovertible proof that everything has gone topsy-turvy: A.S. Byatt's impossibly tricky The Biographer's Tale came out in June, the same day as Jane Green's girly Bookends .

There's self-interest at work here, naturally. With more and more books being churned out, the schedules are over-crowded. Publishers have endless meetings to ensure that their lead titles don't clash with each other and with those of their main rivals. As a result, the annual publishing schedule has become finely tuned.

January, for instance, has emerged as a good launching pad for serious novels and non-fiction. Where once it was seen as a dead, hungover kind of month, now it has been recognised for what it is - an energetic, ambitious time for people just released from a fortnight of family Scrabble who are desperate to get back to their real lives.

Amid all this fun of full-on reading there is the tiniest sense of loss. All that hanging around listlessly in August did, after all, create a huge appetite for the new arrivals in September. Buying a paperback of something you hadn't been able to afford in hardback was more exciting if you'd been made to wait two years, instead of the increasingly common eight months. And the arrival of popular women's fiction in June did at least signal that summer was here, even if it was raining outside.

It's a bit like buying vegetables in the supermarket. Now that you can get satsumas, new potatoes, avocados and leeks all year round, it's taken away the anticipation and inventiveness of cooking. And it never quite tastes the same, either.

Then there was Christmas, when bookshops turned into penny bazaars flogging TV tie-ins, puzzle-book annuals, things about Victorians and odd boxed sets of minor classics that no one could possibly intend to read. All this was annoying if you liked books and wanted to read them all the time, regardless of whether there was an 'r' in the month. August was particularly depressing, with last year's hardbacks vanished from the bookshop shelves, and a bored, desultory feeling among the staff, as if everyone was marking time until something more interesting happened. It was a bit like hanging round a provincial Debenhams, listlessly rummaging through sale tubs of shop-soiled bras, waiting for the winter coats to come in stock. What made these coercive patterns so irritating was that they bore no relation to how people live and read. Far from being the time to slip on intellectual mufti, summer is the time when many of us finally have time to brain up. Formal obligations - to evening classes, sales conferences, PTA meetings - are over and there's a kind of a social and intellectual lull begging to be spiced up with something tricky and engaging. Likewise autumn, with its back-to-school busyness, is not always the best time to plough through the new heavyweight hardbacks, lining up menacingly like so much extra homework. Real people are just as likely to read Bridget Jones in February and sweat through a Booker Prize winner on the beach. And, anyway, in an increasingly chopped-up world, even the idea of seasons seems increasingly meaningless. Bank holidays don't exist properly unless you happen to work in a bank. People opt to go into the office over Christmas and then disappear on holiday in January. Old timers in the publishing industry will tell you that the reason big books never used to be launched in August was that the reviewers were all away, stretched out in a hammock in rural France. These days any critic without children is much more likely to be propping up a wine bar in EC1, desperate for someone to give him or her something to do. So it is a relief that the publishing industry has finally caught up with the rhythms of the real year. Publishers are increasingly taking their cue from Amazon and the late-opening Waterstone's and responding to the fact that reading goes on all the time. HarperCollins is publishing several important biographies in July, including Claire Harman's Fanny Burney, A Biography and Richard Holmes's Sidetracks, and Sceptre and Hodder & Stoughton are running right through August with literary fiction and heavyweight biography: Kit's Law by Donna Morrissey, Fred and Edie by Jill Dawson plus a new life of Patrick O'Brian by Dean King. Amy Jenkins's Honeymoon, on the other hand, got an Easter launch from the same company. And the final, incontrovertible proof that everything has gone topsy-turvy: A.S. Byatt's impossibly tricky The Biographer's Tale came out in June, the same day as Jane Green's girly Bookends . There's self-interest at work here, naturally. With more and more books being churned out, the schedules are over-crowded. Publishers have endless meetings to ensure that their lead titles don't clash with each other and with those of their main rivals. As a result, the annual publishing schedule has become finely tuned. January, for instance, has emerged as a good launching pad for serious novels and non-fiction. Where once it was seen as a dead, hungover kind of month, now it has been recognised for what it is - an energetic, ambitious time for people just released from a fortnight of family Scrabble who are desperate to get back to their real lives. Amid all this fun of full-on reading there is the tiniest sense of loss. All that hanging around listlessly in August did, after all, create a huge appetite for the new arrivals in September. Buying a paperback of something you hadn't been able to afford in hardback was more exciting if you'd been made to wait two years, instead of the increasingly common eight months. And the arrival of popular women's fiction in June did at least signal that summer was here, even if it was raining outside. It's a bit like buying vegetables in the supermarket. Now that you can get satsumas, new potatoes, avocados and leeks all year round, it's taken away the anticipation and inventiveness of cooking. And it never quite tastes the same, either.

fields.headline: Audiobooks for the summer
fields.trailText: Rachel Redford enjoys an abridged version of Michael Frayn's Headlong, plus Classic Love Stories 2, The Old Wive's Tale, Grasshopper and The History of the Theatre
fields.body:
Headlong (2hrs 15 mins, BBC Radio 4 Books £8.99) by Michael Frayn is read in an abridged version by Martin Jarvis. Art historian Martin Clay thinks he has stumbled on the discovery of the century. His boorish neighbour, Tony, shows him some old family pictures and one of them, Martin is sure, is a lost painting from Bruegel's Seasons cycle. We know that everything will end in tears, but Martin's Machiavellian plotting to acquire the missing masterpiece, and his hideous entanglement with Tony's philistine wife, is hugely enjoyable.

Jarvis's rendering of dialogue produces uncannily real men and women and deftly exploits the comedy Abridgement loses much of the sparkling, intellectual detective work which made the book so satisfying, and consequently the comic contrast between the serious scholarship and the farcical pursuit of the picture isn't so sharp. Nevertheless it's enormous fun.

If you're looking for holiday romance, why not try Classic Love Stories 2 (3hrs, CSA Telltapes £8.99) which is beautifully read by husband and wife Joanna David and Edward Fox. Georgie Porgie in Kipling's story of the same name lives happily with a cheroot-smoking Burmese 'wife' whom he has named Georgina - until he feels it time to return to his 'own kind' to marry an English rose. Georgina's final realisation that her 'god' is not going to return as promised is indelibly poignant Edward Fox's leisurely, days-of-Empire delivery sharpens the edge of Kipling's bitter social comment.

Holidays give you time to catch up with the classics - and the audiobook allows you to do it with your eyes shut. Wherever you are, you will be transported by David Haig reading Arnold Bennett's The Old Wive's Tale (24hrs 15 mins, Cover to Cover £59.99; direct mail (01672) 562255) Haig's gentle Staffordshire accent takes you to nineteenth-century Bursley where Constance and Sophia are imprisoned in the draper's shop while their father lies upstairs, ruined by a stroke.

Those 'terrific bosoms' of mother and aunt swathed in cocoons of crepe! Poor Maggie slaving in the subterranean kitchen for 22 years and not even invited to her master's funeral! No wonder Sophia ran away with her 'commercial', the shady Gerald Scales, never to see her mother again.

A new Barbara Vine is always sure to intrigue. In Grasshopper (5hrs 30 mins, Penguin £12.99) Clodagh & Silver, two drifters drawn to one another by their rejection of conventionality, nightly roam the rooftops of Maida Vale. Peering through lighted windows into other people's lives, they become involved in an increasingly dangerous scenario. Frances Barber's seductive voice suits the fey, otherworldliness of the characters.

Finally, why not treat yourself to 2,500 years of theatre from ancient Greece to modern musicals without stirring from the beach mat? In writing The History of the Theatre (5hrs 11mins, Naxos cassette £11.99; CD £16.99) David Timson hoped, like Thomas Middleton, to 'both make you sad and tickle ye'. With Derek Jacobi's narration supported by nearly 60 excerpts performed by a full cast, he certainly succeeds.

Buy Classic Love Stories 2 at BOL

Buy The History of the Theatre at BOL

fields.headline: Readers, I met you...
fields.standfirst: Thousands of people buy  Nicci Gerrard's books. Now it's her turn to find out who they are
fields.trailText: Thousands of people buy Nicci Gerrard's books. Now it's her turn to find out who they are
fields.body:
'What colour is the hero's hair?'... 'That reminds me of something that once happened to me'... 'Will she be happy afterward?'... 'If I was her'... 'If she was me'...

Critics are not ideal readers. They are necessarily watchful, alert and maybe cold. They do not submerge themselves into a book and relinquish themselves to it, but appraise it, dispassionate. They note its faults and its merits and judge its syntax. They read carefully (if they're doing their job properly). They don't forget themselves. Sometimes - or this is what Martin Amis says, anyway - they feel competitive with the author they are reviewing, which colours their judgment. They rarely allow themselves to fall in love with the characters - or, if they fall in love, cannot say so. That's not what they are for. It's not for a critic to behave like one of those 'Janeites' (the often-mocked members of the Jane Austen fan club) who gather to talk about what dress Elizabeth was wearing when Darcy proposes the second time, or what food was served at the picnic in Emma , and doesn't it serve Ann's sisters and father right, and isn't Fanny a dreadful prig. Critics, for whom reading is a profession, can make the reader feel inferior - as if they are not reading in the 'proper' way, or as if there are some books that are mildly embarrassing to love.

Sometimes I read as a critic; more often I read as a reader. They are different experiences. In one, I am available for seduction; in the other, not. Sometimes critics review the novels I write with my husband, Sean French, under the name Nicci French (and sometimes this is pleasurable, and sometimes not). But a couple of weeks ago, Sean and I were invited to attend a reading group that was to discuss our last novel, Killing Me Softly - this group was made up by representatives of organised reading groups from all over the country. We went nervously, not sure what to expect - after all, we've heard the Radio Four Book Club, in which authors can get rough treatment.

It's one thing to be criticised by a critic, quite another by a reader. You can disagree with a critic, say to yourself that they didn't get it, that they're mistaken, that they've read the book wrongly or rancorously, argue the case point by point - in other words, try to defend yourself against pain or humiliation. But if a reader says that they just don't like your book, well then, they just don't like it. It's like someone not liking you . You can't persuade them they're wrong and that you're very nice. For most readers, a book is like a person, and reading is like a relationship. You don't fall in love because you're told you should.

Reading groups have become suddenly and extraordinarily popular. There are more than 50,000 people in reading groups in the UK (and this is nothing compared to the numbers in America, which have been further boosted by the Oprah Winfrey monthly book-club segment, which always shoots a selected title into the bestseller list). They take place in libraries, bookshops, workplaces, day care centres, homes for the elderly, pubs, restaurants, and above all in the home. They are largely subterranean organisations - by invitation only. More than two-thirds of those who attend are women; more than 80 per cent of the works under discussion are fiction. There are favourite titles (Captain Corelli's Mandolin) but more than three-quarters of the books are one-offs, not chosen by other groups, and they are as often classics (the Book of Job, Aeschylus, Mrs Gaskell...) as contemporary. Often the books are unusual, difficult, unfamiliar. Sometimes there's food. Very often there's drink. Friendships are formed. People argue and giggle. Very often, the discussion drifts away from the book, to the readers. The novel can be a springboard for emotional conversations - reckless subjects within the safe structure of a reading group.

I guess there were about 30 or 40 people there. Most were women. All had read our book Killing Me Softly (though a couple hadn't quite reached the end). We sat in a circle - and to start with the chairs on either side of us were left empty, as if we were teachers. Sean and I talked about the book - a psychological thriller about the thin and shifting line between love and madness, passion and danger. We described how we wrote together, how we wanted the novel to be character-driven as well as plot-driven - and at first it was a bit like being interviewed, except there were 30 interviewers and they were all smiling at us and our words weren't going to be used in evidence.

Then gradually something happened. We were shunted gently away from the centre of the discussion, which became enthusiastic and digressive, rather than respectful and linear, and in which everyone was equal. Who found the novel erotic? Should Alice (the narrator) have behaved the way she did? Would they do the same? Had any of them done that - thrown away their old life for the sake of a stranger? Did they disapprove of her? What was love anyway? Was it something close to friendship or something close to danger? Should you trust a stranger? Who'd ever climbed a mountain? Were her eyes grey, were his eyes blue, how would the story continue after the final paragraph?

It was a conversation about a book, and a conversation about life. Often it's easier to have a conversation about life when it starts off as one about a book. Some people sneer at reading groups and patronisingly caricature those who belong to them. But this is how we often read: our lives and the life of the book merge. Nabokov - a great critic and ardent reader - said that in the end the litmus test of a novel is whether it sends that shiver down the spine.

Here we are, in an age of electronic urgency, where time runs away from us and days flicker by on fast-forward - and 50,000 people are meeting once a month to talk about a book that they sat down and read. A democratic community of readers; literature as a pleasure available to everyone - who would argue with that?

fields.headline: India's summer
fields.standfirst: India Knight wrote a column for The Observer. Then her husband left her. Now she's written a roman à clef, and Minnie Driver wants to play her in the movie...
fields.trailText: India Knight wrote a column for The Observer. Then her husband left her. Now she's written a roman à clef, and Minnie Driver wants to play her in the movie...
fields.body:
Yummy yummy, I predict much wolfing of India Knight's My Life on a Plate (Penguin, £5.99) this summer. It's one of those light-as-air soufflés that could well turn into a great meaty stockpot for the publishers. It has already been sold in eight countries, and now two Hollywood film companies are fighting to buy it. So we are talking big money, which is appropriate for India who is a big hungry girl.

Attentive Observer readers will spot similarities between My Life on a Plate and the column India wrote for Life magazine in l998. If you remember, or rather if you don't, that column began with India, happily married with two small children, chattering cheerfully about her friends and family. But suddenly things took a darker turn and on 21 June l998 she announced: 'Stop me if this sounds at all familiar, but my husband is leaving me.' It did sound familiar because precisely the same thing had happened to the previous columnist, Kathryn Flett, now TV critic. Kathryn went on to write a moving book about it, The Heart-Shaped Bullet. India rallied quickly and consoled herself by writing a funny novel. The idea of a funny novel about divorce might sound heartless; I can only say - read My Life on a Plate and see.

I went to visit India at home, and wow! She lives in grim, grey Dalston but the greyness ends as soon as you enter her front door - the house is pink and mauve and scarlet and turquoise, with rows of fabulous shoes instead of ornaments. India shimmies forth in a pink party dress - 'I dressed for YOU!' - and says immediately that she is not allowed to tell me about the two film companies bidding for her book because she is sworn to secrecy. But before I can even murmur, 'Oh go on', she is trumpeting, 'Miramax and Minnie Driver! Minnie Driver wants to play ME!' It seems that Minnie Driver has her own production company and wants My Life on a Plate to be her first production. This means that Minnie has now supplanted Madonna in India's affections. India wanted to quote some Madonna lyrics in her novel, but she would have had to pay the Material Girl £l0,000 for permission. So Madonna is toast.

India Knight defies any easy categorisation, which is part of her charm. She is fiercely intelligent, but obsessed with lipstick and face cream; she is alarmingly posh, but lives in Dalston; she seems very confident most of the time but then has awful wobbles of nerves - especially about this book. She is, as her name suggests, Eurasian but hardly your Andrew Neil-type Asian babe because she is a strapping size l6 with a Wagnerian chest and a noisy habit of 'honking' - her word - at any jokes including her own. Despite the honking, she can be positively Lady Bracknellish at times. Some poor benighted customs officer once had the temerity to stop India and her mother and ask to search their baggage - they responded by suing HM Customs and Excise for false imprisonment and 'slander by conduct'.

Actually, she isn't India Knight at all - her real name is something hideous and Belgian but she changed it by deed poll at 13. She chose India because her mother is - not Indian actually, but Pakistani - and Knight because it was the name of her then stepfather. Her early life is so complicated it would never be believed in a novel. She was born in Brussels in l965, and her first language was French. Her mother, Begum Sabiha, had fled from an arranged marriage in Pakistan to university in the States, and then to Brussels, where she met India's father - 'a rather louche rakish playboy figure' - at a dinner party and he proposed that evening. She said yes and India was born the next year (when Sabiha was just l8), but the marriage was short-lived.

Sabiha stayed in Brussels working as a translator while India was looked after by her paternal grandparents. Then Sabiha met Andrew Knight, who was the Economist 's man in Brussels, and later its editor. India recalls her mother coming back from lunch at the Ritz one day and saying 'Look!' and showing her an engagement ring, and saying they were moving to London. India was sorry to leave her grandparents but thrilled to leave Belgium. 'Belgium is stultifying, stupefying, so even aged nine I quite fancied the idea of getting out.'

She spoke no English so went to the French Lycée but was expelled at l3 for truancy and shoplifting. She and her friend would spend the morning at the Natural History Museum looking at dinosaurs, then wander down to Harrods for a little light shoplifting. Eventually a classmate snitched, and India was summoned to a great family conference with her father, stepfather and mother all asking why she did it. 'I said, "Oh I was bored", and then I thought: This is really very feeble, I must come up with an excuse so I invented this whole existential angst.'

She was bundled off to boarding school, Wycombe Abbey, which of course she found bizarre. She made good friends, but never got used to the cold dormitories and only being allowed to have seven things on the top of your dressing table. She was expelled eventually for smoking pot, but managed to win an exhibition to Cambridge to read modern languages.

All this time she made regular duty visits to her father in Belgium, but he acquired a new wife whom she found 'absurd - and unfortunately I began to see him as absurd'. Anyway she had transferred her affection to her stepfather, Andrew Knight, and to her two half-sisters. So it was a terrible shock when he and her mother split up when she was 25. Her mother went on to marry the architect Norman Foster, but the marriage only lasted four years. India remains on good terms with Knight - he took her on a family holiday to Mustique recently - but in her novel there is a poignant scene where the stepfather talks of his 'first grandson', ignoring her two sons.

Her real father is now in his eighties, 'completely gaga', living in a home in the Ardennes. India is his only child. 'It's a nightmare! I wish he had other children. I'm going to have to arrange the funeral, talk at it, and I barely knew him.'

After such a disrupted childhood, and then the 'loss' of her stepfather, she was desperately keen to get settled and rushed into marriage very young, at 25. 'I wanted to have my own home, I wanted to be married for ever - I took my wedding vows incredibly seriously.' She met her husband, Jeremy Langmead, when they were colleagues on the short-lived Mirabella magazine, and they had an office flirtation which turned into love on a Moroccan holiday. She became pregnant almost immediately and they had a full white wedding, with Sir Norman Foster giving her away. But in retrospect she thinks it all happened too quickly and Jeremy perhaps felt trapped.

And they were soon embroiled in money troubles - India admits she is a disaster with money - buying an expensive house in Islington practically next door to the Blairs, and then having to sell after six months when they couldn't keep up the mortgage payments.

Despite this, the marriage was good for several years, but then not, and My Life on a Plate covers its dying days. Here we get on to difficult ground. Most novelists have the get-out that their characters are invented so of course it isn't their marriage they're writing about. But it's more complicated in India's case because her novel is based on her column, which was not fiction. And as she is quite clearly 'Clara' in the novel, it seems natural to assume that Jeremy Langmead is Robert, the husband, who frankly seems a cold fish.

India says piously, 'The husband in the book isn't Jeremy, and he is crueller than Jeremy.' So it's all right to call him a cold fish? 'Arguably completely frigid, yes.' But why doesn't he ever explain what he's thinking? 'Jeremy is witty and charming, but quite closed. Originally it was intriguing. I mean I'm all surface, my family are all surface, everybody shouts at each other. And he was the opposite of that, and I thought it was wonderful, all this elegant English reserve.'

But because the husband in the novel is so mysterious and reserved, we never understand why he suddenly decides to walk out of the marriage. There is no other person involved - nor was there in real life, India insists. The rumour was that Jeremy Langmead was bisexual all along and left her for a man, but she says that is absolutely not true. 'He was faith ful throughout our marriage, we had a very vigorous and happy sex life, we have two children, and what he's done since_ Well, ask him.' [I did but he wouldn't play - or rather, he did play - he said he was just off to watch some lapdancers at Stringfellow's.]

But, as she says, marriages do just peter out, for no particular reason, and that's what she wanted to show in the novel: 'If something's not horrible but it's barely satisfactory and you're kind of chugging along, neither of you having a very nice time, then - I'm trying to suggest in the book - maybe you should call it a day. You don't need a crisis, you don't need to find your husband in bed with someone, you don't need to be betrayed in some horrific way - things can just peter out. And it's not the end of the world, is what I wanted to say.'

Anyway, she and Jeremy remain friends. She showed him chunks of My Life on a Plate as she wrote it, and 'he was fine about it. He said it made him sad. He told my mother it was like a map of where things went wrong and he was seeing the map properly for the first time. But he also honked which was the main idea!'

In the novel, Clara soon finds consolation in the shape of a ballet dancer called Dunphy. In real life, India's consolation is the novelist Andrew O'Hagan. They meet every day and she thinks they will eventually live together, and have children. But, she reminds me, she is not yet divorced, and 'it's a bit too modern for me to have children while married to someone else.'

She has already signed up for novel number two, in which Clara will be living with Dunphy. She still writes a newspaper column but her ambition now is to be a full-time novelist because 'It's a really great way of earning money! fields.bodyText: Yummy yummy, I predict much wolfing of India Knight's My Life on a Plate (Penguin, £5.99) this summer. It's one of those light-as-air soufflés that could well turn into a great meaty stockpot for the publishers. It has already been sold in eight countries, and now two Hollywood film companies are fighting to buy it. So we are talking big money, which is appropriate for India who is a big hungry girl. Attentive Observer readers will spot similarities between My Life on a Plate and the column India wrote for Life magazine in l998. If you remember, or rather if you don't, that column began with India, happily married with two small children, chattering cheerfully about her friends and family. But suddenly things took a darker turn and on 21 June l998 she announced: 'Stop me if this sounds at all familiar, but my husband is leaving me.' It did sound familiar because precisely the same thing had happened to the previous columnist, Kathryn Flett, now TV critic. Kathryn went on to write a moving book about it, The Heart-Shaped Bullet. India rallied quickly and consoled herself by writing a funny novel. The idea of a funny novel about divorce might sound heartless; I can only say - read My Life on a Plate and see. I went to visit India at home, and wow! She lives in grim, grey Dalston but the greyness ends as soon as you enter her front door - the house is pink and mauve and scarlet and turquoise, with rows of fabulous shoes instead of ornaments. India shimmies forth in a pink party dress - 'I dressed for YOU!' - and says immediately that she is not allowed to tell me about the two film companies bidding for her book because she is sworn to secrecy. But before I can even murmur, 'Oh go on', she is trumpeting, 'Miramax and Minnie Driver! Minnie Driver wants to play ME!' It seems that Minnie Driver has her own production company and wants My Life on a Plate to be her first production. This means that Minnie has now supplanted Madonna in India's affections. India wanted to quote some Madonna lyrics in her novel, but she would have had to pay the Material Girl £l0,000 for permission. So Madonna is toast. India Knight defies any easy categorisation, which is part of her charm. She is fiercely intelligent, but obsessed with lipstick and face cream; she is alarmingly posh, but lives in Dalston; she seems very confident most of the time but then has awful wobbles of nerves - especially about this book. She is, as her name suggests, Eurasian but hardly your Andrew Neil-type Asian babe because she is a strapping size l6 with a Wagnerian chest and a noisy habit of 'honking' - her word - at any jokes including her own. Despite the honking, she can be positively Lady Bracknellish at times. Some poor benighted customs officer once had the temerity to stop India and her mother and ask to search their baggage - they responded by suing HM Customs and Excise for false imprisonment and 'slander by conduct'. Actually, she isn't India Knight at all - her real name is something hideous and Belgian but she changed it by deed poll at 13. She chose India because her mother is - not Indian actually, but Pakistani - and Knight because it was the name of her then stepfather. Her early life is so complicated it would never be believed in a novel. She was born in Brussels in l965, and her first language was French. Her mother, Begum Sabiha, had fled from an arranged marriage in Pakistan to university in the States, and then to Brussels, where she met India's father - 'a rather louche rakish playboy figure' - at a dinner party and he proposed that evening. She said yes and India was born the next year (when Sabiha was just l8), but the marriage was short-lived. Sabiha stayed in Brussels working as a translator while India was looked after by her paternal grandparents. Then Sabiha met Andrew Knight, who was the Economist 's man in Brussels, and later its editor. India recalls her mother coming back from lunch at the Ritz one day and saying 'Look!' and showing her an engagement ring, and saying they were moving to London. India was sorry to leave her grandparents but thrilled to leave Belgium. 'Belgium is stultifying, stupefying, so even aged nine I quite fancied the idea of getting out.' She spoke no English so went to the French Lycée but was expelled at l3 for truancy and shoplifting. She and her friend would spend the morning at the Natural History Museum looking at dinosaurs, then wander down to Harrods for a little light shoplifting. Eventually a classmate snitched, and India was summoned to a great family conference with her father, stepfather and mother all asking why she did it. 'I said, "Oh I was bored", and then I thought: This is really very feeble, I must come up with an excuse so I invented this whole existential angst.' She was bundled off to boarding school, Wycombe Abbey, which of course she found bizarre. She made good friends, but never got used to the cold dormitories and only being allowed to have seven things on the top of your dressing table. She was expelled eventually for smoking pot, but managed to win an exhibition to Cambridge to read modern languages. All this time she made regular duty visits to her father in Belgium, but he acquired a new wife whom she found 'absurd - and unfortunately I began to see him as absurd'. Anyway she had transferred her affection to her stepfather, Andrew Knight, and to her two half-sisters. So it was a terrible shock when he and her mother split up when she was 25. Her mother went on to marry the architect Norman Foster, but the marriage only lasted four years. India remains on good terms with Knight - he took her on a family holiday to Mustique recently - but in her novel there is a poignant scene where the stepfather talks of his 'first grandson', ignoring her two sons. Her real father is now in his eighties, 'completely gaga', living in a home in the Ardennes. India is his only child. 'It's a nightmare! I wish he had other children. I'm going to have to arrange the funeral, talk at it, and I barely knew him.' After such a disrupted childhood, and then the 'loss' of her stepfather, she was desperately keen to get settled and rushed into marriage very young, at 25. 'I wanted to have my own home, I wanted to be married for ever - I took my wedding vows incredibly seriously.' She met her husband, Jeremy Langmead, when they were colleagues on the short-lived Mirabella magazine, and they had an office flirtation which turned into love on a Moroccan holiday. She became pregnant almost immediately and they had a full white wedding, with Sir Norman Foster giving her away. But in retrospect she thinks it all happened too quickly and Jeremy perhaps felt trapped. And they were soon embroiled in money troubles - India admits she is a disaster with money - buying an expensive house in Islington practically next door to the Blairs, and then having to sell after six months when they couldn't keep up the mortgage payments. Despite this, the marriage was good for several years, but then not, and My Life on a Plate covers its dying days. Here we get on to difficult ground. Most novelists have the get-out that their characters are invented so of course it isn't their marriage they're writing about. But it's more complicated in India's case because her novel is based on her column, which was not fiction. And as she is quite clearly 'Clara' in the novel, it seems natural to assume that Jeremy Langmead is Robert, the husband, who frankly seems a cold fish. India says piously, 'The husband in the book isn't Jeremy, and he is crueller than Jeremy.' So it's all right to call him a cold fish? 'Arguably completely frigid, yes.' But why doesn't he ever explain what he's thinking? 'Jeremy is witty and charming, but quite closed. Originally it was intriguing. I mean I'm all surface, my family are all surface, everybody shouts at each other. And he was the opposite of that, and I thought it was wonderful, all this elegant English reserve.' But because the husband in the novel is so mysterious and reserved, we never understand why he suddenly decides to walk out of the marriage. There is no other person involved - nor was there in real life, India insists. The rumour was that Jeremy Langmead was bisexual all along and left her for a man, but she says that is absolutely not true. 'He was faith ful throughout our marriage, we had a very vigorous and happy sex life, we have two children, and what he's done since_ Well, ask him.' [I did but he wouldn't play - or rather, he did play - he said he was just off to watch some lapdancers at Stringfellow's.] But, as she says, marriages do just peter out, for no particular reason, and that's what she wanted to show in the novel: 'If something's not horrible but it's barely satisfactory and you're kind of chugging along, neither of you having a very nice time, then - I'm trying to suggest in the book - maybe you should call it a day. And it's not the end of the world, is what I wanted to say.' Anyway, she and Jeremy remain friends. She showed him chunks of My Life on a Plate as she wrote it, and 'he was fine about it. He said it made him sad. He told my mother it was like a map of where things went wrong and he was seeing the map properly for the first time. But he also honked which was the main idea!' In the novel, Clara soon finds consolation in the shape of a ballet dancer called Dunphy. In real life, India's consolation is the novelist Andrew O'Hagan. They meet every day and she thinks they will eventually live together, and have children. But, she reminds me, she is not yet divorced, and 'it's a bit too modern for me to have children while married to someone else.' She has already signed up for novel number two, in which Clara will be living with Dunphy. She still writes a newspaper column but her ambition now is to be a full-time novelist because 'It's a really great way of earning money! You write the book, and that's quite fun, sitting at the computer in your pyjamas honking. And then other countries buy it and film people come along and give you money and it is completely bliss.'

webTitle: Book giants teeter on the brink

fields.headline: Book giants teeter on the brink
fields.standfirst:
The big stores are under assault. Authors and their own staff attack them for dumbing down while internet retailers are undercutting them. Sarah Ryle reports

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The big stores are under assault. Authors and their own staff attack them for dumbing down while internet retailers are undercutting them. Sarah Ryle reports
fields.body:
It is not exactly Stop the City, but the demonstrators picketing Waterstone's in Manchester are as serious about their cause as any urban warrior.

At stake, as they see it through their gold-rimmed spectacles, is the very core of civilisation: the future of literature. Their hero is the sensible-shoed, sacked manager of Britain's leading bookseller's Deansgate store.

Robert Topping, a 43-year-old with an alarming look of Harry Potter about him, is appealing against dismissal for refusing to reduce stock levels and increase focus on bestsellers. He is one of five managers who have dug their heels in. 'They don't have confidence in books,' says Topping of his former bosses. 'They don't have people who read books, who love books.'

The enemy is Waterstone's managing director David Kneale, nicknamed 'The Mekon' by Private Eye. Topping accuses Kneale (whose last job was running Boots) of the low crime - at least in the book world - of 'analytical business procedures'.

Will Self, the bad-boy novelist who pitched the debate into the public eye on Radio 4, says the policy will lead to 'cultural impoverishment' and 'wall-to-wall pulp'. He is not alone in this view. Michael Frayn says he was grateful for the loyalty of managers such as Topping when his novels, before the Booker-nominated Headlong , sold 'modestly'. 'I have done readings in Manchester as I imagine most authors have. I think that most of the big book stores are well-run and have a huge range of books. But people like the personal view and the strength is in the manager knowing his customers and his books.'

He says he makes a point of buying books from a tiny, independent shop around the corner.

Fay Weldon - who buys her books from Amazon.com or Waterstone's in Hampstead - says it was inevitable that independents would suffer once the Net Book Agreement was abolished. 'Books Etc opened a new store near us and within five weeks the existing book shop went out of business. Books are rather a funny stock to have. They take up a lot of space. They have to shift them quickly and there are so many of them. You can see why this is happening.

'People think that if you remove controls, everything gets better and cheaper but that only happens in the short term. They drive out competition as they did in the music industry and then put prices back up.'

Nicci Gerrard, co-author of Beneath the Skin as Nicci French, fears harsh economics will kill off diversity. 'It is all about market forces and pure capitalism. The little things should be able to flourish. It is all about the Harry Potter environment in which the winner takes all. It is a terrible thing for readers and for writers.'

There is a deep irony in the corduroy-wearing protesters: here is Waterstone's, sweeper-away of small, independent stores, in trouble itself. And it is not only Waterstone's. The giant book chains and internet retailers have been accused of squeezing small local bookshops out of business.

The book trade is being forced to face harsh facts. Kneale says fewer people go into bookshops than did so two years ago. Half of the titles Waterstone's buys from a choice of 2,000 new books every week never sell a single copy. According to Trevor Goul-Wheeker, managing director of mid-market high-street rival, Hammicks, 60 per cent of the population never visits a book store at all.

But demonstrations? Who would have thought it until now? Certainly not the wider public, who read about huge advances paid to almost anybody from students at posh public schools to ex-journalists from Leeds and mockney-lad chefs. Harry Potter racks up more than a million orders even before the name of his latest adventure is announced. Helen Fielding is feted in Hollywood for creating the sad, self-obsessed but very ordinary Bridget Jones.

The public could be forgiven for thinking the world of books is second only to the Premiership when it comes to soaraway, cash-fuelled success for those with the talent to make the first team.

But this business is no beautiful game. It is more like a big, fat duck: apparently cutting serenely through calm water, the book trade is paddling furiously under the surface to stay afloat.

The row at Waterstone's has for the first time given the wider public a glimpse of what those in the industry have known for some time: the good old days when publishers milked retailers, retailers milked the consumer and everybody had a high old time are over.

UK book sales in 1990 were £2.1 billion. In 1999, sales were, at most, £1.9bn. From the attack on Waterstone's to the less widely registered but just as damaging admissions by the chain's owner, HMV Media, that all is not well on the financial front, the customer is suddenly aware that for all the big, new book store space, something is definitely wrong.

David Kneale admits as much. He reels off reasons for the chain's recent decline in profits. These include, predictably, the advent of the internet and the demise of the Net Book Agreement which has led to heavy discounting of the most profitable titles.

The rest of the industry, however, seems to think the problem begins and ends with Waterstone's. Publishers whinge that the one-time friend of the literati has sold out to the masses. Agents say (or, rather, whisper) that the poor authors have nowhere to go and are being bullied by publishers who slash fees to give retailers tempting discounts.

'When I walk into a bookshop I feel like packing up and going home,' says Jo Frank of AP Watt. 'It is extraordinary that publishers publish so many titles. So many of the books just look the same. It is a wonder how anything ever sells.'

Kneale says they are all being foul to Waterstone's because it is still the market leader, despite its flimsy balance sheet, and because the entire universe as they knew it has been stood on its head.

'The market is undergoing significant structural and technological change and Waterstone's has to change as well. Customers want different things now.'

The publishers had it easy for a long time. They sold large numbers of advance copies because retailers, unable to predict all but the most obvious bestsellers, did not want to run out of books and wait for new print runs. Improved technology means retailers are no longer so worried about restocking. They have better systems for returning books that sell badly.

But there are other issues. As Alan Giles, chief executive of HMV Media, moaned this year: 'It tells you something about the quality of the book market, when the Who Wants to be a Millionaire quiz book flies off the shelves.' And people now expect to see these popular hits at anything up to 50 per cent off.

Kneale admits to reducing the quantity of individual titles, but insists Waterstone's is extending the quality by extending the range, helped by a £6m investment in new systems which enable it to spot the 50 per cent of new titles that never sell a single copy. They are not ditched entirely, he says, but are cut back to one copy instead of several.

'We are no longer a dumping ground for publishers,' he exclaims, adding: 'That will really endear me to all those people who don't like Waterstone's already.'

The retailers shoulder some of the blame. They have over-stretched themselves by building mega-stores with football-pitch scale floorspaces at a time when footfall is down. Those people who are entering these palaces have different expectations to their counterparts in the Eighties when Waterstone's gained hero status for stocking 30,000 titles.

In those days, customers accepted a wait of up to three weeks for any but the best-known titles. And they did not expect a bargain. Nowadays, Waterstone's stocks 80,000 titles and WH Smith (which sold Waterstone's two years ago) stocks 30,000.

Neither can keep abreast of the internet. Amazon, for all its share-price slump, can still beat the lot when it comes to price and accessibility. Only a virtual bookstore can stock a sizeable fraction of the 1.2 million books in print at any one time.

David Young, chief executive of publishers Little,Brown, says the net has totally transformed the book landscape. There is no arguing with that. Stephen King published an e-book, Riding the Bullet , and at $2 a hit made a small fortune within weeks.

Big businesses are deemed beautiful and the larger chains have merged to stay viable in books as they have in banking. The net also means price transparency: it means Harry Potter at £8 instead of nearly £15 in the shops.

Imagine this 10 years ago: retailers discounting brand new, popular stock by up to 50 per cent instead of the books that were difficult to shift off the shelves. Odd, isn't it? It is more than odd. It is positively ridiculous, says Young. The consumer has never had it so good, he proclaims.

There are still voices struggling to trumpet brightness above the gloom, including the Bookseller, whose news editor Danuta Kean says: 'I would be concerned to see anything in writing that said the book market has hit the floor.' Well, yes, possibly. But she admits that back lists are not doing well and that there are too many big shops with too much floor space to sustain a sluggish market.

The industry hides behind the complexity of performance figures upon which nobody will agree. Whoever you believe, the growing consensus is that there is simply too much floorspace given over to books in this country. There are too many titles for a limited reading public to sustain.

Kean patiently explains that books are not like any other kind of retail market. They cannot be compared with clothes or shoes.

Forgive those of us looking into the new mega-bookshops-cum-bars from the outside if we don't quite appreciate the nice differences. In a modern marketplace with no fixed prices and ever-efficient technology, any trade that celebrates sales of 100,000 units as a triumph looks a little bit shaky.

The painful truth is that books are a business as well as an art form and, until they can get a Lottery grant, the retailers are going to do more and more to incur the wrath of Topping and his band of well-read supporters.

A tale of two bookshops

Waterstone's

203 Piccadilly

London W1

Tel: 020 7581 2400

Opened Nearly 10 months ago.

Shop size The biggest book shop in Europe, 67,000 square feet.

Turnover Can't say as hasn't been running for a full year. But, 'in terms of the good, the bad and the ugly - very good. Record-shattering,' says general manager Lisa Milton.

Stock Approximately 1.4 million books, about 240,000-260,000 titles.

Staff Including cleaners, about 220. Around 150 booksellers.

Salary £10,500-£13,500. Company and performance-related bonuses.

Staff qualifications 'Most are graduates. But don't have to be.' Most are very well read.

Bestselling book Last week, Bridget Jones . This week, expected to be the new Harry Potter.

Most obscure title A 50-volume set on Sikhism at £2,000. One sold so far.

Metropolitan Books

64 Exmouth Market

London EC1

Tel: 0207 278 6900

Opened 19 months ago.

Shop size 420 square feet.

Turnover 'Too soon to say', just over £100,000 a year.

Stock About 36,000 books, about 4,000 titles. Anything can be ordered.

Staff Owner Phil Griffiths is currently the only member of staff.

Average salary £5,400 per year - 'Fifty thousand next year!' Is it worth it? 'For quality of life, definitely. Financially, probably not.'

Staff qualifications 'Someone who loves reading and ideally had experience in bookselling.'

Bestselling book Last week, A Fish Caught in Time by Samantha Weinberg. Last month: River Cafe Green.

Most obscure book in stock 'Probably A Fish Caught in Time.'
