The only person who has ever sued him was 'one of our insane mayors', a man he dubbed Mayor Loco. 'I didn't accuse the guy of any crime or attribute to him any nasty diseases, just kept calling him Mayor Loco. It later turned out that the election he won was stolen - a whole bunch of dead people had voted for him, so he was kicked out. The lawsuit against me did not allege any liability. It just said that after he'd been kicked out for rigging elections and no one would hire him because they knew him as Mayor Loco. Our response was that we would be happy to have psychiatrists look at him - this was a guy who used to turn up at the newspaper office ranting in his bathrobe - and clearly he didn't fancy that.'

'Some days, I really enjoy writing the column,' he says, 'and some days it's the purest form of torture. I still agonise over every miserable adjective. When you get fired up and you have something to write about, like during the Elian Gonzalez case, then you just have to go nuts, because you're speaking for a lot of people who're pulling their hair out.'

But there are other moments when he considers packing it in. Hiaasen is 47 now; he was first married when he was 17 ('We were crazy about each other and it seemed like the right thing to do). He has a son from that marriage, Scott, 29, who is also a journalist, and from his second marriage he has a nine-year-old stepson, Ryan and a baby, Quinn, born at the beginning of this year. His daughter-in-law is expecting twins. 'So I'm going to be a grandfather and a father in the same year. I'm waiting for the call from Jerry Springer.

'There's certainly a temptation when you reach a certain age just to chill out and look out only for the people you care about. Now I've got a little one in the house it would be nice occasionally not to have to deal with crazies on your answering machine or the odd threat in the mail or whatever. Of course, after the Gonzales stuff, I got a bunch of letters saying I was anti-Hispanic and a racist and a Castro sympathiser. And, of course, I could not resist sending these people back letters saying, "Please keep it quiet but I've been working for the communists for years". And signed them Carl "Che" Hiaasen.'

But he doesn't see much hope of himself mellowing out - 'I know I'd be miserable doing that'; if anything he thinks he'll get madder as he gets older. He points to a passage in Sick Puppy which he says is about as close to his philosophy as anything in his books. It comes from Skink, a recurrent alter-ego, an ex-governor gone native in the Everglades: 'People like us are doomed to be angry, and to stay angry, because that's the only way things get changed.'

Before I leave, Hiaasen, the most laid-back angry man I have met, shows me around his garage. Around the walls are half-a-dozen tanks containing pet reptiles. He has a frog that eats mice, a wedding gift from his lawyer: 'It has canines but it's kind of slow,' he says. 'Sometimes, the mouse survives in there for a day before he catches up with it.'

He takes out a couple of snakes from other tanks. One, which can apparently pretend to be a rattler, is five feet long. Does it bite? I ask. 'They have razor-sharp teeth, but you won't see them until they're embedded in you,' he says. 'Then you have problems.'

With Hiaasen around, a lot of Florida's legislators and businessmen, you imagine, know exactly that feeling.

Hiaasen on Hiaasen

Tourist Season

'This involved the kidnapping of the Orange Bowl queen which was, no doubt, a submerged teenage fantasy of mine. '

Double Whammy

'Sex, murder and corruption on the professional bass-fishing circuit. This was territory I had pretty much to myself. I couldn't see much danger of Updike or Norman Mailer going in that direction.'

Lucky You

'A good old-fashioned tale of greed and the Florida state lottery. '

Skintight

'I thought I had invented the most repellent plastic surgeon ever but he has since been eclipsed. The other day, we had a guy arrested: a bodybuilder had come in asking for pectoral implants and this guy used breast implants instead. He woke up with a boob on each shoulder.'

Native Tongue

'Any time you can have a villain romanced to death by a dolphin and manage to convince your editors that it's an important component of your novel, you're doing something right.'

Strip Tease

'The book was about how you can always count on men to behave badly.'

Sick Puppy

'I enjoy the idea of beating a litterbug senseless, because that's a death-penalty issue. Haul them off and straight into the electric chair. No question.'

 Sick Puppy is published by Macmillan at £16.99.

webTitle: The loneliness of the low-grade stripper

fields.headline: The loneliness of the low-grade stripper
fields.standfirst: George Saunders writes about the people who fall down the gap between aspiration and achievement in Pastoralia
fields.trailText: George Saunders writes about the people who fall down the gap between aspiration and achievement in Pastoralia
fields.body:
Pastoralia
George Saunders
Bloomsbury £9.99, pp188
Buy it at BOL

George Saunders writes in the voice of the misfit; the kind of misfit who embodies America's deepest fears - failure, embarrassment, loneliness. His first story collection, CivilWarLand in Bad Decline, earned him a place in the New Yorker 's pantheon of Twenty Best American Fiction Writers Under Forty, and his second, Pastoralia, confirms his talent, honed and refined here with a greater linguistic virtuosity and a greater degree of sympathy and tenderness for his pitiful, hopeless characters.

These stories belong in a recognisable tradition of American fiction; there is an unavoidable association with the surreal, self-conscious stories of David Foster Wallace, for example, and Saunders has also been likened to Vonnegut, Heller and Pynchon.

But his writing also provokes an unlikely comparison with Alan Bennett's Talking Heads; Saunders has the same ability to recreate precisely the idiom of the small people, those who live their lives on the fringe, unnoticed and unvalued by the society around them. His narratives often read like monologues, articulating the frustrations and stunted feelings of characters as diverse as a low-grade male stripper, a pudgy 10-year-old bullied by his contemporaries, or a would-be novelist with adjectival overkill.

By just inverting a preposition or deftly dropping in a well-observed malapropism, Saunders makes these characters lurch into Technicolor life in all their Jerry Springer awfulness, and he can fix a character or a scene in a sentence: 'Min and Jade are feeding their babies while watching How My Child Died Violently', or 'Vicki had a face that looked as if it had been smashed against a steering wheel in a crash and then carefully reworked until it somewhat resembled her previous face.'

His characters are parodies, certainly, but not caricatures; they are artful, exaggerated and often cruelly funny portraits, but they remain utterly credible, even when their circumstances slide into the distinctly weird. Of Morse in 'The Falls', Saunders writes: 'His childhood dreams had been so bright, he had hoped for so much, it couldn't be true that he was a nobody, although, on the other hand, what kind of a somebody spends the best years of his life swearing at a photocopier?' It could be an epitaph for all Saunders's characters who fall down the gap between aspiration and achievement.

In 'Winky' we meet Yanicky, a small, balding man who solders 'triangular things' and attends a self-help course to enable him to get rid of his mad, embarrassing but devoted and loving sister. 'The Barber's Unhappiness' features a lonely, sexually frustrated middle-aged man who meets a pretty but fat young woman and wonders if the promise of intimacy is greater than their distaste for each other's physical inadequacies. In the title story, the narrator earns his living playing a caveman in a Neanderthal theme park and defending his slack partner, Janet, from the wrath of their manager, until he is forced to choose between loyalty and self-interest.

But ultimately there exists, in all these sorry, sidelined lives, an unsentimental suggestion of redemption, a moment of human contact that lifts people briefly out of their solipsism and self-absorbed fears, and it is this humanity that offsets the humour and makes Saunders's writing so much more than just clever satire.

'The Barber's Unhappiness' features a lonely, sexually frustrated middle-aged man who meets a pretty but fat young woman and wonders if the promise of intimacy is greater than their distaste for each other's physical inadequacies. In the title story, the narrator earns his living playing a caveman in a Neanderthal theme park and defending his slack partner, Janet, from the wrath of their manager, until he is forced to choose between loyalty and self-interest. But ultimately there exists, in all these sorry, sidelined lives, an unsentimental suggestion of redemption, a moment of human contact that lifts people briefly out of their solipsism and self-absorbed fears, and it is this humanity that offsets the humour and makes Saunders's writing so much more than just clever satire.

webTitle: That Hamlet is full of clichés...

fields.headline: That Hamlet is full of clichés...
fields.standfirst: John Updike jumps triumphantly through all the hoops in his prequel to Hamlet, Gertrude and Claudius
fields.trailText: John Updike jumps triumphantly through all the hoops in his prequel to Hamlet, Gertrude and Claudius
fields.body:
Gertrude and Claudius
John Updike
Hamish Hamilton £16.99, pp212
Buy it at BOL

Rewriting Hamlet involves the literary equivalent of an old-fashioned fairground game where you have to manoeuvre a wire loop along a contorted curve of the same material, without actually making contact and ringing the bell of disqualification. Getting too far away from the original and coming too close spell failure equally. But in his magnificently wily Gertrude and Claudius, John Updike is confident enough of the independent status of his fiction to risk, and even court, those chimes that would normally be disastrous.

So his Polonius uses the phrase 'neither a borrower nor a lender be' as if it was already a cliché, rather than a formula which Shakespeare sent on its way into the dictionaries of quotations. In fact, the original text is so supercharged with potency that a simple phrase - 'out of joint', say, or 'you protest too much' - or sometimes a single word - 'arras' or 'angel' - can trigger the tinkle of associations.

Updike actively enjoys nagging the reading brain with paraphrases only a stage further removed from canonical passages: Gertrude's maid comes up with 'There's a shape in things, fiddle and fuss however we will at the edges', and Hamlet's father tries in vain to formulate his own sense of something rotten in the state of Denmark, 'a local situation so elusively slack and malodorous'.

This lack of inhibiting awe as regards the original flows from the knowledge that the Hamlet we know is not 'original' but itself a reworking - if not of a play from the 1580s (perhaps by Thomas Kyd), then certainly of a legend in the Historica Danica of Saxo Grammaticus, written in Latin in the twelfth century and first printed in 1514. The names in Part I of Gertrude and Claudius - Gerutha and Feng for the principals, Horwendil for the king - are taken from this source. The Lord Chamberlain, the Polonius figure, is more recognisable by being characterised as 'prudent, fussy and sententious' than from the name of 'Corambus'.

For Part II, the names mutate to correspond with those in a French adaptation of Saxo from 1576: Geruthe, Fengon, Horvendile, Corambis. Only for Part III, which takes the story into Shakespeare's first act, do the names assume their familiar forms. Updike has done some historical research, which is smoothly incorporated into the narrative, except for a lapse into exposition about the workings of the Danish succession. A king needed to be elected by four provincial 'things', assemblies of freedmen, which is how (not that people ask) Claudius rather than the young Prince could legally ascend the throne whose vacancy he had brought about.

Updike acknowledges the impact on his version of a dissident reading of the play - G. Wilson Knight's - as summarised by William Kerrigan: 'Claudius seems a capable king, Gertrude a noble queen, Ophelia a treasure of sweetness, Polonius a tedious but not evil counsellor, Laertes a generic young man. Hamlet pulls them all into death.'

Without the introduction of new material, though, a retelling of the story on this basis would be closer to a contradiction of the play than an enriching variation. What Updike invents to give Feng/Fengon/Claudius a depth of character beyond his brother's is a decade of foreign wandering as, in the most literal sense, a 'free lance'. His long absence from Denmark is both a renunciation of desire for Gertrude (and the political turmoil it might bring) and a test of it. His wanderings constitute a romantic ordeal.

Claudius quotes the Provençal troubadours in his wooing - he is a courtly lover whose approach is the opposite of his blunt brother's. He brings back to the North a knowledge of the Mediterranean, even of Islam. Updike so arranges things that Claudius can more than rival young Hamlet in breadth of experience, in subtlety and lifelong underdog status, to the point of seeing him as a kindred spirit - 'witty, large-minded and many-sided'.

To fortify the tent he has pitched in the heart of monumental Elsinore, Updike makes use of some rather insistent patternings of his own (so that, for instance, each part of the book begins with the sentence 'The King was irate'). As the story approaches its end, it must necessarily surrender to Shakespeare's imagination, and the invention becomes, on occasion, almost camp - Polonius's wordiness growing caricatural.

Enough has been written about Hamlet's Oedipus complex without Claudius anticipating the Freudian critics when he says to Gertrude: 'You are too much woman for him, my dear. too warm for his comfort. He fled into coldness, idealising his father and taking up German philosophy. He loves you, as I do, as any man with eyes and a heart must. He and I share something else: we were overshadowed by the same man, a man hollow but for his appetite for reputation.'

Despite the odd tonal wobble, Gertrude and Claudius is more than a high-toned example of that despised genre, the prequel. Updike is the supreme fantasist of sensation. There are no limits to his ability to conjure up vividness of detail. Memorable here are the passages about falconry, the itemising of Gertrude's dressing table, and the astounding sentence, unforced though a page and a half long, evoking the dull radiance of her marriage in its happiest days.

fields.headline: It's a royal knockout!
fields.standfirst: Christopher Wilson tells the story of a bizarre ménage-à-trois in Dancing with the Devil
fields.trailText: Christopher Wilson tells the story of a bizarre ménage-à-trois in Dancing with the Devil
fields.body:
Dancing with the Devil: The Windsors and Jimmy Donahue
Christopher Wilson
HarperCollins £16.99, pp270
Buy it at BOL

Whatever republican thoughts are inspired by the centenary bonanza for the Queen Mother, you can be quite sure that few could rival the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in regal disdain.

According to this spicy rendering of one of the many sad, shameful footnotes in the life of former king Edward VII, the Windsors routinely referred to her as 'that fat Scotch cook' and 'the Loch Ness monster'. When she appeared on television, the Duke would yodel: 'Here comes the Blimp', while the Duchess, not to be outdone, described her nemesis as 'that 14-carat beauty' and 'the monster of Glamis'.

It's well known that royalty attracts a dismal, often homosexual, cast of toadies, timeservers, creeps, and arse-lickers, but the Windsors' court-in-exile was, as Christopher Wilson expertly demonstrates in this gruesomely fascinating tale, one of the queerest and nastiest entourages in recent memory.

The Duke was a pathetic figure. In the Bahamas, where he found some comfort, it was said he 'used to be First Lord of the Admiralty, but now he's third mate on an American tramp'. After much sleuthing Wilson shows that once Wallis Simpson failed to get her hands on the crown, she became more interested in the seedy by-ways of Anglo-American demi-monde.

In this stinking rich, and utterly futile, world of playboys and wastrels, no one was more charming, better connected, and apparently more talented than the captivatingly youthful figure of Jimmy Donahue. A scion of the Woolworth family, he was notorious within the East coast establishment for his outrageous homosexuality.

And yet, according to Wilson, the moment Donahue and the Duchess met, there was a coup de foudre, despite a 19-year age-gap. Jimmy and the Duchess plummeted into a relationship based on sexual practices inappropriate for a Sunday newspaper. The cuckolded Duke had no idea how to deal with an infidelity so flagrant that even the gossip columns of the day did not flinch from coded references to the liaison. 'The Duke is a very sad person these days,' wrote the Mirror's Walter Winchell.

According to observers, he seemed mesmerised by the audacity of Donahue's attentions. The Duchess, for her part, was equally outrageous, and would adorn her bedroom door with 'Keep Out' and 'Don't Come in Here'. This bizarre ménage-à-trois became a fixture on the international circuit, but behind the scenes the infatuated Duchess was tiring. She underwent surgery for cancer of the womb in 1951. It became clear that her passion was waning.

'To think,' said the Duchess, during one of her bouts of remorse, 'that I gave up a king for a queen.' After four embarrassing years, it was the Duke, finally, who snapped. 'We've had enough of you, Jimmy. Get out!' he said, to the drunken playboy. In the end, it was the Duchess who pronounced the coolest verdict on her situation. 'You have no idea,' she told a friend, 'how hard it is to live out a great romance.'

The interest and appeal of Wilson's book is that it shows how, decades before Fergie's well-publicised dalliance with jet-setting Eurotrash, the older generation was up to the same game. Wilson is also good on the details of hotels, automobiles and haute couture. It is no more than a footnote, but Hello! readers will love it.

fields.headline: Upside-down view of down under
fields.standfirst: Michael Davie and Bill Bryson get funny peculiar ideas about Australia
fields.trailText: Michael Davie and Bill Bryson get funny peculiar ideas about Australia
fields.body:
Anglo-Australian Attitudes
Michael Davie
Secker & Warburg £17.99, pp250
Buy it at BOL

Down Under
Bill Bryson
Doubleday £16.99, pp319
Buy it at BOL

Australia is topical at the moment, with the centenary of federation about to be celebrated, the Olympics soon to open in Sydney and an imminent official visit to Britain by John Howard, the Prime Minister. Both Australia's economy and its culture are buoyant and there is a sense of boom time.

It is not surprising that publishers are cashing in by producing a plethora of books on all aspects of Australian life and history. Anglo-Australian Attitudes by Michael Davie, a former Observer journalist, is a discursive set of essays on the history of the vexed relationship between Australians and what they are no longer allowed to think of as their mother country. Davie - conspicuously knowledgeable about the countries' common history - writes as an Englishman who prefers Australia and cannot understand why Australians cling to any British traditions.

Davie starts with the issue of class, claiming that it is a myth that Australia is classless. It had never crossed my mind that Australia might consider itself classless, since, like east coast America, it has preserved the institutions of birth, education and privilege rather more intact than Magdalen College, Oxford. He then has a chapter on attitudes to Gallipoli - clearly a formative moment in making Australians think badly of Britain since it was generally assumed that Churchill had sent large numbers of Australian troops needlessly to their deaths as cannon fodder. What emerges is another side to Gallipoli, a side carefully excised from official accounts in order not to offend Australian sensibilities.

A chapter on the role of the governor-general misses the point of the arguments surrounding the referendum over whether or not Australia should be a republic, which involved a recognition of the potential problem of a Prime Minister having no limits to his or her authority - an issue about which one might find British sympathisers.

At the book's heart are a pair of chapters on why it might be regarded as legitimate for Australians to think ill of Britain. The first was the scandal over the Australian test matches in 1933 when the captain, Douglas Jardine, insisted that his players adopted bodyline bowling which, if not illegal, was certainly regarded as profoundly unsporting. Jardine was assumed to be a typical Englishman - arrogant, hypocritical and pretending to be a good sportsman when actually he was not. In fact, he comes across as extremely unusual, a shit of the first order, of which presumably there are examples in Australia and Britain.

The second, mid-century event that confirmed Australians in their views of the perfidy of Albion was when Churchill failed to send effective help to Australia when it was faced by Japanese invasion. But as Davie effectively demonstrates, there was an element of self-delusion about the might of the British Empire if Australians thought that Britain would happily send off its fleet to the South Pacific when still faced by German invasion of its own shores.

Cumulatively, the book makes you wonder why anyone in Australia should be remotely sympathetic towards Britain. The reality, of course, is different from this one-sided book. For example, the current exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery of photographs by Polly Borland of Australians in Britain includes in the catalogue a wealth of information about why Australians were keen to leave Australia in the 1960s and 1970s. They regarded Britain as more liberal, more willing to countenance an avant-garde. This attitude of admiration for some of the better aspects of Britain cannot simply be dismissed as cultural cringe.

Bill Bryson has also written an account of his travels round Australia which borders on the parodic. Bryson has made, I presume, an immense amount of money writing an everyman's account of his travels. The formula is always the same, consisting of a little bit of background information conveyed in the most casual way possible and then an anecdotal account of what went wrong. His first book in the genre, The Lost Continent, was deservedly successful. But as he writes more and more of these books on the basis of less and less travel, the humour wears thin.

The reality is that Bryson is now famous in his own right; when he goes to some godforsaken hole in the Australian outback, he is met by the chief of the local bureau of tourism. When he is attacked by jellyfish in the ocean at Manly, he is accompanied by a staff photographer from the Sydney Morning Herald .

You feel that, from the moment he gets out of bed in the morning to the moment he goes to sleep, he is hoping that something funny will happen. The result is deeply tedious.

fields.headline: Heat and bust
fields.standfirst: From the Louisiana swamps to Greece, it's murder
fields.trailText: From the Louisiana swamps to Greece, it's murder - Peter Guttridge rounds up the latest releases
fields.body:
Purple Cane Road
James Lee Burke
Orion £12.99, pp341
Buy it at BOL

The Big Blowdown
George Pelecanos
Serpent's Tail £10, pp313

Strange Police
Reg Gadney
Faber & Faber £9.99, pp346
Buy it at BOL

Windchill Summer
Norris Church Mailer
Fourth Estate £9.99, pp395
Buy it at BOL

The Louisiana swamps probably aren't the first place you'd think to park your imagination while lying in a holiday hammock, but James Lee Burke, one of America's finest writers, evokes their beauty in his fiction as tellingly as he examines the ugliness and violence just below the surface of the American Dream.

Purple Cane Road is the eleventh novel to feature Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux and it is a thrilling piece of fiction, at once exciting and elegiac. In it Robicheaux has to come to terms with the sad, sordid past of his own mother, Mae, whom he scarcely knew. He discovers that she was a prostitute, murdered one stormy night on the edge of a bayou on Purple Cane Road, drowned in a muddy puddle by two cops working for the Mob.

Robicheaux's painful search for his mother's killers brings him into contact with an intriguing bunch of characters. They include Belmont Pugh, a preacher who has progressed from door-to-door salesman to state governor, and the chilling Johnny Remeta, a seemingly unstoppable hit man with a high IQ and psychotic personality. Burke's Cajun cop, a Vietnam veteran, is a detective in the classic US mould: a flawed knight errant, a tragic hero, battling injustice and his own demons. (Like his creator, Robicheaux is a recovering alcoholic.) Burke has said he sees him as closest to Everyman in the medieval morality play, a man of courage and humility who tries to give a voice to the weak and the powerless.

As with virtually all Burke's other novels, Purple Cane Road is for Robicheaux a journey into the past. Influenced by Flannery O'Connor, William Faulkner and his own 'Gethsemane experience' which enabled him to give up drink, Burke creates characters in spiritual crisis. In the course of his search for his mother's killers, Robicheaux sees that if he can come to terms with his and his family's troubled past, he might at last find some form of redemption.

Burke's writing can only be measured in superlatives. Nobody else in the mystery genre is doing what he is doing - as a descriptive writer alone he is without equal. In Purple Cane Road he writes with a depth of feeling that is rare in the mystery genre. I defy anyone to read the final page without shedding a tear.

George Pelecanos is hot but he's not exactly sunny. However, The Big Blowdown is a perfect summer read for its pace, its plotting and its sheer page-turning narrative drive. Although the last to be published here, it's the first of Pelecanos's acclaimed DC Quartet and in my view it's the best. Big is a pretty prosaic adjective, but use it in the title of a crime novel and it somehow gives the result mythic qualities, from Chandler's The Big Sleep through to Ellroy's The Big Nowhere. And the Fifties B movies that used it? Films such as The Big Heat, The Big Combo and The Big Steal came almost to define pulp crime fiction.

However, Pelecanos's title is more than a nod to his hard-boiled precursors - with The Big Blowdown he has actually written one of those Fifties noir thrillers and there are mythic qualities aplenty. Not that the novel is simply a retro gimmick or even straightforward pulp. Pelecanos has a larger story to tell: that of the immigrant experience in multi-ethnic inner-city Washington from the Thirties through to the Fifties.

The novel starts with a bunch of boys growing up in poverty in the Thirties, then focuses on one of them - Pete Karras - who goes off to war and comes back a hero. He and his Italian friend Joe Recevo, fond of snappy clothes and easy living, go for the easy money - debt-collecting for the local mob boss. Karras is too lenient with his fellow immigrants, so the mob boss decides to teach him a vicious lesson. Three years later, Karras finds that his criminal past impinges on new friendships and that there must come a final and bloody reckoning.

Pelecanos has enormous strengths as a crime writer. He can't write a dull sentence, his dialogue has great rhythm, his action scenes are ferociously effective. But more than that, he has a powerful social conscience and The Big Blowdown, as with his other novels, deals with themes of friendship, social injustice, ethnic co-existence and the possibility that ordinary people, if they have courage enough, can triumph over the corrupt and the lawless.

Reg Gadney is another writer with a strong sense of pace and narrative drive. After a slightly bitty start he demonstrates these qualities to the full in Strange Police, the fourth outing for former customs agent Alan Rosslyn. In it Rosslyn is in Greece doing minor surveillance work when his client, Cleo Ipsilanti, is murdered.

Since he was also her lover, he becomes the prime suspect. Hurriedly smuggled out of Greece by the British intelligence service, he discovers back in London that Ipsilanti was involved in a well-planned operation to steal the Elgin Marbles and return them to Athens. And the curious thing is, certain members of the security forces seem to be in on it.

One of the pleasures of the novel is the thought Gadney has obviously given to the plan to steal the Marbles. It's so detailed, you come to think it might well work in actuality. He also peoples Strange Police with an assortment of vivid characters, from the single-minded, devious intelligence officer Marion Shaw, who effortlessly manipulates Rosslyn, to the villainous Constantine Dragos, who has a vicious metal claw in place of a hand.

If that sounds James Bond-like, there are occasional reminders of those kinds of straight-ahead adventures here, just as there are of Le Carré, in the petty wrangles and squabbles that Gadney writes about between and within security services. But Gadney owes nothing to other authors, especially in the quality of the writing and the enthusiastic way he tells his exciting story.

Hearing that Norris Church Mailer is Norman Mailer's wife might make you wary of her first novel, Windchill Summer. But this is no vanity project published for its marketing possibilities. Mrs Mailer can write and this is an impressive, ambitious debut in which she successfully marries a thriller to a - probably autobiographical - coming-of-age novel.

It's the long hot summer of 1969 in Sweet Valley, Arkansas. It's the summer of the moon landing and anti-Vietnam war demonstrations. The main narrator, Cherry, and Baby, her Filipino best friend, are working sticky, sweaty nights at the pickle plant. Another friend, Carlene, is pulled from the bottom of the lake, murdered.

Over the following days and weeks Cherry, brought up strictly in the Holiness Church, begins to question all her old certainties as she discovers that everyone around her seems to have dark secrets, even those whom she thinks she knows best. Confidently plotted, the novel's initial easy pace builds to a strong climax when the Vietnam war is brought brutally back home.
fields.bodyText: Purple Cane Road James Lee Burke Orion £12.99, pp341 Buy it at BOL The Big Blowdown George Pelecanos Serpent's Tail £10, pp313 Strange Police Reg Gadney Faber & Faber £9.99, pp346 Buy it at BOL Windchill Summer Norris Church Mailer Fourth Estate £9.99, pp395 Buy it at BOL The Louisiana swamps probably aren't the first place you'd think to park your imagination while lying in a holiday hammock, but James Lee Burke, one of America's finest writers, evokes their beauty in his fiction as tellingly as he examines the ugliness and violence just below the surface of the American Dream. Purple Cane Road is the eleventh novel to feature Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux and it is a thrilling piece of fiction, at once exciting and elegiac. In it Robicheaux has to come to terms with the sad, sordid past of his own mother, Mae, whom he scarcely knew. He discovers that she was a prostitute, murdered one stormy night on the edge of a bayou on Purple Cane Road, drowned in a muddy puddle by two cops working for the Mob. Robicheaux's painful search for his mother's killers brings him into contact with an intriguing bunch of characters. They include Belmont Pugh, a preacher who has progressed from door-to-door salesman to state governor, and the chilling Johnny Remeta, a seemingly unstoppable hit man with a high IQ and psychotic personality. Burke's Cajun cop, a Vietnam veteran, is a detective in the classic US mould: a flawed knight errant, a tragic hero, battling injustice and his own demons. (Like his creator, Robicheaux is a recovering alcoholic.) Burke has said he sees him as closest to Everyman in the medieval morality play, a man of courage and humility who tries to give a voice to the weak and the powerless. As with virtually all Burke's other novels, Purple Cane Road is for Robicheaux a journey into the past. Influenced by Flannery O'Connor, William Faulkner and his own 'Gethsemane experience' which enabled him to give up drink, Burke creates characters in spiritual crisis. Big is a pretty prosaic adjective, but use it in the title of a crime novel and it somehow gives the result mythic qualities, from Chandler's The Big Sleep through to Ellroy's The Big Nowhere. And the Fifties B movies that used it? Films such as The Big Heat, The Big Combo and The Big Steal came almost to define pulp crime fiction. He and his Italian friend Joe Recevo, fond of snappy clothes and easy living, go for the easy money - debt-collecting for the local mob boss. Karras is too lenient with his fellow immigrants, so the mob boss decides to teach him a vicious lesson. Three years later, Karras finds that his criminal past impinges on new friendships and that there must come a final and bloody reckoning. Pelecanos has enormous strengths as a crime writer. webTitle: Pride marches on amid tears for bomb

fields.headline: Pride marches on amid tears for bomb
fields.standfirst: 'It's OK to be gay, but what next?'  Peter Tatchell, Comment
fields.trailText: Mothers and fathers with children just wanted to watch from the sidelines. But for one group yesterday's Mardi Gras gay festival in London was a time for tears.
fields.body:
Some came to wave banners and placards. Others saw it as an excuse to dress up in spandex and sequins and dance to Steps. Mothers and fathers with children just wanted to watch from the sidelines. But for one group yesterday's Mardi Gras gay festival in London was a time for tears.

At the head of the march of almost 100,000 gay men and lesbians, veterans of the 30-year-old Gay Liberation Front wept as they danced from Hyde Park to Finsbury Park for Europe's biggest gay celebration. 'We started Gay Pride three decades ago because we wanted to feel proud. Looking around today we do. It's very emotional,' said Andrew Lumsden, 58.

Yesterday's blend of flower-power counter-culture, revolutionary politics and camp theatricality was a far cry from the clandestine protests of the Sixties and Seventies. 'At the beginning it was just 100 of us sneaking into Hyde Park for a picnic. We all knew we could be arrested, beaten up or worse. Now look at it. It is a new century and a different world,' Lumsden said.

Campaigners, entertainers and 'gay families' yesterday declared Britain had changed for good.

'I am old enough to remember the days when you could be arrested for simply being gay,' said Jeremy Douglas, 53. 'Today we should pause, take a good look around, and celebrate that we have come so far.'

Dozens of floats and open-top buses crawled down Piccadilly towards Trafalgar Square, watched by enthusiastic crowds and bemused tourists peering from hotel windows. Leather-clad moustachioed traffic policemen smiled nervously as marchers teased: 'Two-Four-Six-Eight. Is that policeman really straight?'

'Gorgeous, eh?' said Sarah Grimes, 51, who first started going to Gay Pride when she was a teenager. 'I remember when you did not dare look at a policeman in case he arrested you. It makes me cry to think how much we have achieved.'

Watching from the pavement, a group of Essex pensioners on a day trip to the summer sales agreed. 'I quite like dressing up, too, you know,' said Phyllis James from Billericay.

As crowds danced to Kylie Minogue in Finsbury Park, some warned that the growing tolerance did not mean the fight against discrimination was over.

'Sure Mardi Gras is less political, less revolutionary these days,' said Femi Otitoju, 42, from Brixton.

'But most people here know someone who lost their job because they came out. Section 28 is still law.'

Outside the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho Evan Thomas agreed. 'Everyone's happy but don't forget there are people out there like David Copeland (the nail bomber sentenced to life imprisonment on Friday for killing three people in a bomb attack) and the age of consent argument is not over.'

webTitle: New wave of HIV hauntsgay capital

fields.headline: New wave of HIV hauntsgay capital
fields.trailText: The long-feared new wave of HIV infection has arrived in San Francisco, the city that first alerted the world to the epidemic 20 years ago.
fields.body:
The long-feared new wave of HIV infection has arrived in San Francisco, the city that first alerted the world to the epidemic 20 years ago.

News that the city now has the same infection levels as sub-Saharan Africa has sparked fears across America and Europe that years of safe-sex education are being undermined by complacency.

It is the first reported rise in infection rate in any US city since the HIV epidemic started being brought under control.

San Francisco public health officials estimate that the number of new HIV infections - which can lead to Aids - has doubled in the past year to 900. 'This is a harbinger of what is going to happen all over the country. What happens in the HIV epidemic usually happens here first,' warned Tom Coates, director of the University of California at San Francisco Aids Research Institute.

Anonymous testing at clinics across San Francisco - where high-risk groups serve as an early warning system - show the proportion of HIV positive cases has nearly tripled in three years, from 1.3 per cent in 1997 to 3.7 per cent in 1999. 'We are very concerned, very worried. These are sub-Saharan African levels of transmissions' said Dr Willi McFarland, the city's Department of Public Health Epidemiologist.

Aids workers said that there was no evidence the new wave of infection had hit the UK, but that the figures served as a warning against unsafe sex. 'It's worrying. We've got to make sure we stay ahead of the game. It shows that in an epidemic like HIV, you can't afford to take your eye off the ball,' said Derek Bodell, head of the National Aids Trust, 'We've got to be aware of the risks of complacency, or it can all go pear-shaped.'

In both the US and the UK, there are increasing signs that those at risk are reverting to unsafe practices, lulled into a false sense of security by powerful drugs and - until now - falling infection rates.

In Britain, the number of recorded infections rose last year to 2,500, the highest for a decade, although researchers insist that was caused by more people coming forward for testing, rather than the actual rate of infection rising.

However, Aids prevention workers worry that people are letting down their guard, with all the early-warning signals all pointing the wrong way:

 The number of gay men having unprotected anal intercourse has risen, according to research just completed by the Terrence Higgins Trust - although more men know the HIV status of their partner.

 Hepatitis infection rates among injecting drug users have risen, suggesting there is more sharing of needles.

 Gonorrhoea cases rose by 26 per cent in men and 30 per cent in women last year - and jumped by more than 50 per cent in young men, suggesting fewer people practise safe sex.

The rise in infections in San Francisco was preceded by similar signs of less than safe sex in high-risk groups.

Marie Ennis, assistant director of the Terrence Higgins Trust said: 'HIV doesn't have the profile it once had, so people don't think it's as relevant as it once was.

'People are getting complacent because they are not getting enough information.'

fields.headline: Sticky times for the 'Teflon Taoiseach'
fields.trailText: 'Maybe when it goes over eight-and-a-half million you stop getting shocked.'
fields.body:
'Maybe when it goes over eight-and-a-half million you stop getting shocked.'

The words are those of Bertie Ahern, giving evidence last week to the Moriarty Tribunal, which is investigating allegations of corruption in political life.

The Taoiseach was referring to revelations that one of his predecessors, Charles Haughey, had received £8.5 million from property developers and other captains of industry between l979 and 1996. Ahern was appearing to answer questions about these contributions, and to refute allegations that his Fianna Fail Party had failed to provide the inquiry with vital documents which would have enabled it to identify a number of the anonymous donors.

Even his bitter critics agree that, as national leader, there must be a presumption that Ahern is telling the truth when he claims to be ignorant of what went on during the Haughey era.

But the 'Teflon Taoiseach' is losing his look of non-stick innocence. The Irish public has not lost its capacity to be shocked. On the contrary, all the signs are that it is becoming increasingly incensed at the seemingly unending saga of low standards in high places.

This has been a terrible 10 ten for Ahern and his party. It started with a by-election in North Tipperary, where its vote collapsed by 15 points. The contest was won by an independent left-wing candidate, Seamus Healy, whose victory has been interpreted as an expression of anger over political corruption.

This was compounded by a High Court ruling that the trial of Haughey, on charges of obstructing a previous public inquiry set up to look into his affairs, should be postponed indefinitely. The main reason for Judge Kevin Haugh's decision was that remarks by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mary Harney, severely prejudiced the former leader's chances of a fair hearing.

Harney left Fianna Fail because of her implacable opposition to Haughey's leadership. The fact that her comments have enabled him to escape trial, at least for now, has caused glee to her former colleagues. But the possibility that the old Houdini of Irish politics could now walk free, taking his millions with him, has contributed to public cynicism about all politicians.

The week ended with a rancorous six-and-a-half hour debate in the Dail on a vote of no confidence in Ahern's coalition. The government survived by 84 votes to 80, but there is a growing feeling that its days are numbered. The Dail has now gone into recess for the summer, but the tribunals looking into political sleaze will continue to hold public hearings. Dublin is buzzing with rumours about who and what will crawl out of the woodwork next.

Until recently, Ahern managed, very skilfully, to distance himself from the Haughey era. He set up tribunals to look into the sins of the past and promised that Fianna Fail would co-operate with them. Haughey once described Ahern as 'the most devious and most cunning' politician he had known and the description is now much quoted.

As long as Ahern could maintain that the style of government associated with Haughey was a thing of the past, his position remained relatively secure.

But a recent decision to appoint a former Supreme Court judge to a lucrative post in Europe has fuelled suspicions that cronyism and worse is still alive at the highest levels of Fianna Fail. Hugh O'Flaherty was forced to resign from his Supreme Court post last year after his intervention in a drink-driving case was deemed to have damaged the administration of justice.

Just a year later he was nominated to a job carrying a salary of £147,000 at the European Investment Bank. The fact that the appointment was defended by both Ahern and Harney, on the grounds that O'Flaherty 'deserved a second chance', did nothing to assuage public anger. The Irish Times asked whether Haughey too could expect a job representing Ireland on the world stage.

Relieved Parliamentary Deputies have now departed for the summer. But, to paraphrase Gerry Adams, this government's problems haven't gone away, you know. Ahern and Harney hang together for now because they know that the only alternative is to hang separately. But few people now believe their partnership can last beyond the autumn.

fields.headline: Jail 'ignored suicide warning'
fields.standfirst: Family furious as they learn that Isobel's killer was not watched in his cell after trying to cutting his wrists
fields.trailText: Prison authorities had been warned to keep a close eye on the killer of British student Isabel Peake before he was found dead in his Portuguese prison cell, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: by Eduardo Gonçalves  Lisbon and Tracy McVeigh
fields.body:
Prison authorities had been warned to keep a close eye on the killer of British student Isabel Peake before he was found dead in his Portuguese prison cell, it emerged yesterday.

Three hours before the 21-year-old Algerian asphyxiated himself by setting light to his mattress, he had been treated for self-inflicted cuts on his wrists. Guards were watching football on television when he died.

The disclosures have shocked and angered families of his three victims. Sid Ahmed Rezala had been in the Lisbon jail awaiting extradition to France for trial.

The report of the duty doctor who treated the cuts on his wrist shows that the prison director was immediately warned that Rezala was likely to make another attempt on his life.

But the guards did not look in again on the self-styled 'Train Killer', who was slowly dying in the smoke. There was immediate speculation that the prison officers had their attentions instead on the Euro 2000 football semi-final between France and Portugal on television at the time.

The battered body of Isabel Peake, a 20-year-old Birmingham University student, was found beside a railway line near Chabenet in central France last October. She had been on her way home after an exchange visit.

On Thursday, her distraught parents said they were shocked by Rezala's suicide. It did not soften the blow of their daughter's death, they added. Curtains were kept drawn at their Staffordshire home as Brian and Annie Peake prepared a statement which was read out by their lawyer.

'We need time to consider the implications. We will not be making any further state ments at this stage and ask for our privacy to be respected.'

Yesterday the family's MP, Bill Cash, said: 'This entire tragedy is absolutely saturated by blunders, a roll call of unmitigated bungling. This will only add to the suffering of Mr and Mrs Peake and their family. They have been unable to see their daughter's killer brought to justice.'

When the guards eventually broke in to Rezala's cell on Wednesday - he had blocked the cell door with his bedframe - he was already unconscious.

Gilbert Collard, lawyer for the parents of Corinne Caillaux, 36, stabbed to death on an express train, announced that he intends to sue France and Portugal for allowing Rezala to escape justice.

'Rezala will now never be declared guilty of the crimes he committed', he said.

Rezala had claimed that 'blinding light flashes' made him hurl Isabel to her death from a train. He said he was high on drink and drugs, and added: 'There was nothing I could do. When that happens you aren't even aware of all the blood you spill. I got her and chased her and threw her off the train.'

Rezala confessed to Figaro magazine from jail. He said he had chatted to Isabel as she waited at Limoges station to catch a train on her way home to Stoke-on-Trent.

Rezala said: 'She was a gentle girl who didn't deserve to die. Isabel was very sweet. We got on well. She was supposed to be going back to England to see her boyfriend.'

French police took nearly a week to identify Isabel's body, by which time the killer's trail was cold and Rezala struck again before his arrest in Lisbon.

He also admitted murder ing Caillaux and his ex-girlfriend, Emilie Bazin, 20.

Rezala's own lawyer, Alain Richard, called the suicide a scandal. 'His death must have been slow. In spite of the smell, the smoke, nobody noticed a thing,' he said.

French newspapers claimed that guards were watching the dramatic climax of the semi-final match between France and Portugal which started at around the time that Rezala was last seen by doctors. He died just after 11pm, after a controversial hand-ball penalty incident involving Portugal's Everton defender Abel Xavier.\

Rezala was said to have been growing increasingly disturbed as extradition to France loomed, showing signs of 'extreme despair and anxiety'.

Celso Manata, the prison director, said he was under constant watch.

webTitle: Junk email senders face large fines

fields.headline: Junk email senders face large fines
fields.trailText: Senders of junk email face prosecution and unlimited fines if they continue to bombard computer inboxes with unsolicited offers of products and services. Complaints about 'spam', as it is called, have soared in recent months as users are bombarded with everything from opportunities to enter competitions to hyperlinks for downloading hardcore pornography.
fields.body:
Senders of junk email face prosecution and unlimited fines if they continue to bombard computer inboxes with unsolicited offers of products and services. Complaints about 'spam', as it is called, have soared in recent months as users are bombarded with everything from opportunities to enter competitions to hyperlinks for downloading hardcore pornography.

Now, the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner has said it will get tough. The Data Protection Act, which came into power this year, made it illegal to buy email addresses for the purpose of sending 'spam' without the addressee's consent.

But hundreds of firms are flouting the law, illegally buying up lists of email addresses. Scores of sites on the internet offer 'spammers' the chance to buy millions of email addresses for as little as £20 for 100,000. One seller, who asks for cash to be paid into an unnamed account in Sweden, charges $395 for one million names.

'It's very much an underground thing. Go on the web and type 'spam' into a search engine and you'll get hundreds of companies offering to sell you lists,' said Jonathan Hobday, managing director of email security firm Netsiren.

The Data Protection Act of 1998 became law in March and created a new classification of what constitutes 'personal' data. This includes personal email addresses. The law applies equally to firms operating in the UK and overseas firms sending 'spam' to the UK. 'Most people are not aware their email address is now classed as personal data,' Hobday said.

Since the Act was introduced, the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner, which looks into 'spamming' issues, has recorded a three-fold rise in complaints. However, a spokesman declined to give the actual number of complaints. 'We don't give them out as a matter of policy because we feel they are just the tip of the iceberg,' he said.

The commissioner has the power to serve an enforcement notice on any firm found 'spamming' individuals without their express consent. If the firm fails to obey the notice, the Data Protection Commissioner can take legal action that carries the penalty of unlimited fines.

One problem is that people receiving emails might click to accept future information about a particular product or service, not realising this means they are giving approval for their email address to be sold on to other parties.

Much of the 'spam' originates from Russia and Eastern Europe, making it difficult for the authorities to take legal action. The Australian and US authorities are both lax about clamping down on the problem.

Rogue 'spamming' is becoming so acute that the Data Protection Commissioner is examining plans to compel companies to include an 'opt out' on any emails they send. This would mean the recipient had the chance to click on a box to register that he or she would prefer not to receive further information. Many companies already include an 'opt-out' possibility.

'Where individuals provide information and it is used for direct marketing purposes, organisations should provide an opt-out box. It may become mandatory,' the spokesman for the Data Protection Commissioner said.

An alternative suggestion is to introduce 'consent lists', which are becoming increasingly popular in the US. This allows users to register to receive information on particular products and services, allowing them to receive unsolicited emails targeted at specific interests.

fields.headline: Mother hanged after sons die
fields.trailText: Detectives last night said they were baffled by the tragic death of a young Northamptonshire mother, who apparently killed her two young sons before hanging herself on Friday.
fields.body:
Detectives last night said they were baffled by the tragic death of a young Northamptonshire mother, who apparently killed her two young sons before hanging herself on Friday.

The bodies of Lewis Jackson, aged two, and his brother Oren, six, were discovered in their mother's bed, with mother Claire Jackson, 28, hanging from a ligature attached to the door. As they sorted through family possessions, police confirmed they were not looking for anyone else in connection with the deaths.

Police broke into the two-bedroom flat at 11.15pm on Friday after a relative called to say they were unable to contact the family.

Jackson was discovered hanging from a plastic covered metal cable attached to the bedroom door but post-mortem examinations of the children failed to establish the cause of death. Further tests will be carried out this week.

Although the two boys have different fathers, both were close to Lewis's father who lived locally. Oren's father, from whom Jackson was also estranged, serves in the Royal Navy and is due to return from a foreign assignment today.

Detective Superintendent Chris Cross, who is leading the inquiry, said the deaths had devastated the family and shocked the neighbourhood.

'Outwardly everything seemed normal. Claire had celebrated her birthday last Sunday and the boys had bought her presents,' he said.

'At this early stage there is no indication of any third party being involved in the death of Ms Jackson. The premises were secure until entry was forced by the police and there was no sign of a disturbance.'

Detective Inspector Larry Ennis said: 'The depth of emotion here is very real and the family are, obviously, in a state of absolute shock.

'She seems to have been devoted to her children. This is a terrible case and whatever we discover the motive to have been won't detract from that.'

fields.headline: £10m trail to World Cup flop
fields.standfirst: They said England's bid to host football's biggest tournament in 2006 was within reach. They spent millions trying to secure votes. But they never stood a chance, reports  Denis Campbell
fields.trailText: It was meant to be English football's finest hour since Alf Ramsey's red-shirted heroes won the 1966 World Cup at Wembley. A mixture of big names, magnificent modern stadiums and nostalgia about England's special status as the inventor of soccer would ensure the 2006 tournament came 'home' to where the game began.
fields.body:
It was meant to be English football's finest hour since Alf Ramsey's red-shirted heroes won the 1966 World Cup at Wembley. A mixture of big names, magnificent modern stadiums and nostalgia about England's special status as the inventor of soccer would ensure the 2006 tournament came 'home' to where the game began.

Four years on, humiliation awaits. England may get as few as two, and possibly only one, of the 24 votes of football's rulers who will decide in Zurich on Thursday which nation will host the prestigious and money-spinning 2006 finals. South Africa will probably win, with Germany second, while England could trail in last behind no-hopers Morocco and Brazil.

This weekend, as Fifa, the sport's governing body, released a report by its inspectors which placed England's bid below those of Germany and South Africa, the inquest has already started about where it all went wrong. Critics claim 2006 campaigners optimistically ignored England's diminished influence in world football. Crucially, the bid team - run by the Football Association - stands accused of offering 'over the top' hospitality to soccer's movers and shakers in an increasingly desperate bid for favour.

Senior politicians and even Prince Charles were pressed into service to help England's cause, while lavish functions were put on to impress voters in some of England's most sumptuous surroundings, including Highgrove, Lan caster House and the Natural History Museum.

In a prelude to the looming storm of recrimination after this week's decision in Zurich, Prime Minister Tony Blair is already distancing himself from the bid he once backed so enthusiastically.

It is unclear why £10 million was spent on a bid which was apparently doomed from the start. 'Ten million quid to win just two votes is a nonsense, a complete and scandalous waste of money,' said one football insider. 'We would have been better taking the money and offering each of the Fifa 24 a big, fat brown envelope of cash instead.'

Demands are growing for an explanation of how England managed to spend £7m more than South Africa, and twice as much as arch-rivals Germany, and still lose. Questions will be asked in Parliament once the full scale of England's failure becomes clear.

'If it transpires that a lot of money has been spent without yielding anything we will be highlighting the cost of the bid, once we know the outcome of the voting,' said John Greenway MP, the Conservatives' spokesman on sport. 'If we don't get 2006, one can look into all the elements of what it cost and where it went wrong. We have some concerns there.'

The Observer can reveal that Kate Hoey, the Sports Minister, has written to FA chief executive Adam Crozier suggesting they open up the 2006 bid books in order to avoid suspicion. In her letter of 20 June, Hoey wrote: 'I am conscious that whatever the result on 6 July there will be keen interest in the amount spent on the World Cup bid by the FA in 1999 and 2000. Publication of these sums clearly identified in the [FA's] 1999 annual report in advance of any questions would prevent mischief-makers seeking to portray the FA as having something to hide.'

But the 2006 campaign refuses to divulge spending details, though £3m of their £10m budget is Lottery funding from Sport England. The FA claims it is 'a private organisation spending money donated by other private organisations' and has no duty to reveal where the money went. Its financial affairs are kept secret.

They include details of payments to Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst - both heroes of England's victory in 1966 - for their efforts as global ambassadors for the 2006 bid. Both covered thousands of miles globetrotting to try winning friends and influencing football people.

FA sources claim that Charlton received around £250,000 for his work and was paid £3,000 for each of many overseas lobbying trips he took. Hurst is thought to have received a similar amount. Both men took time away from their business activities to help the bid.

The accounts also reveal how much was spent on, for example, the four-day 'lobbying exercise' put on by the 2006 team in May 1999. Sixteen of the Fifa 24 and their wives enjoyed lunch with Prince Charles, drinks at Downing Street, West End shows and a boat-trip on the Thames before attending the FA Cup Final.

Fifa inspectors were ferried round England in military helicopters as they assessed stadiums.

Sport England said its £3m went on salaries, costs and promotional literature and not on such travel or hospitality.

Sir Bob Scott, a veteran of two Manchester bids to stage the Olympics, said England's team had got its tactics wrong, were too optimistic about their chances and too naive in the intrigue inherent in bidding for big sports events.

'Bidding for the Olympics or the World Cup is a world where everybody is polite and nice, and everybody says your bid is brilliant and that you'd be a very worthy host. But later, when voting for someone becomes real rather than just a promise, they find a reason not to vote for you.

'No football delegate from Asia or Latin America is going to be anything except extremely polite...and praise the England bid. But behind the scenes, any genuine, honest consideration of England's likely vote was that it was nothing like as solid as the England team was claiming it was. Some public statements by the bid team have been a bit short on realism.'

A senior football figure said England were 'foolish' to even enter the 2006 race given the FA's previous 'gentleman's agreement' with Germany to back them for 2006 if Germany helped the FA secure Euro 96, which they did. 'There was a deal to back each other's bid, but the FA reneged on it. That went down very badly with leaders of European football, most of whom are backing Germany and are furious with England for splitting the European vote.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Lorry driver held after three are killed in M6 pile-up
fields.body:
Lorry driver held after three are killed in M6 pile-up

A lorry driver was arrested by Leicester police after a pile-up on the M6 near Shawell which left three men dead. The accident involved 11 vehicles and closed the motorway for eight hours.

Bookies win Euro 2000

Bookies say Euro 2000 will become the biggest betting event in the history of sport with more than £100 million wagered. William Hill quoted France as 8/15 favourite with Italy at 11/8 for today's final.

David and Frederick Barclay

On 18 June 2000, in 'End awards of court', John Sweeney wrote that David and Frederick Barclay are 'not paying tax'. We did not intend to suggest that they do not pay any tax at all, rather that they pay less tax because they are not UK residents.

However, David and Frederick Barclay have made very substantial charitable donations to UK causes over the last 20 years. They have advised us that they pay personal tax in the UK every year and that as Monaco residents they also pay substantial sums in tax to the French Treasury.

David and Frederick Barclay have asked us to make clear that the English and French proceedings brought against John Sweeney were not simply about privacy, but included a serious libel allegation in relation to the Crown Agents affair. We apologise to David and Frederick Barclay for not including this information.

Sex frees hamster

Mechanics spent four days trying to extract a hamster from a Liverpool doctor's Mercedes, by stripping the car. They finally lured it out with a female hamster.

Casualty toes

Ambulance crews in Hampshire failing to meet performance targets blamed 'ridiculous' requests, such as help to cut toenails.

Lottery draw

The winning numbers are 11 16 22 39 42 48, bonus 38. The Thunderball numbers are 16, 17, 24, 31, 9, Thunderball 4.

Dome looks up

The Millennium Dome attracted 40,000 more visitors in June than in May.

Killed in chase

Police hunted two men after a policeman died in a chase near Port Talbot.

webTitle: Fat is key to good sex, says DNA man

fields.headline: Fat is key to good sex, says DNA man
fields.standfirst: A Nobel scientist claims thin people are miserable, writes  Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: One of the world's most revered scientists has developed a theory that fat people are happier than thin ones. James Watson, the Nobel prize-winning geneticist who was jointly responsible for discovering the structure of DNA, believes that plumper women are also likely to enjoy a better sex life than their thin counterparts.
fields.body:
One of the world's most revered scientists has developed a theory that fat people are happier than thin ones. James Watson, the Nobel prize-winning geneticist who was jointly responsible for discovering the structure of DNA, believes that plumper women are also likely to enjoy a better sex life than their thin counterparts.

Dr Watson, who directed the successful human genome project, has moved into the controversial science of body image.

He told an audience at University College London that his research suggested extra pounds had the biological effect of making a woman well-rounded in character and better in bed.

'Thinness is never associated with sexuality,' said Watson, 72, an American. Posh Spice and Calista Flockhart might smile for the photographers, he claimed, but beneath their sleek exteriors lurked miserable thin souls.

His study of chemicals in the body has led him to conclude that extra fat has the effect of boosting endorphins - the natural mood-enhancing chemical - and a hormone linked to sexual desire.

In thin people, he said, the opposite effect was observed: less fat led to the brain receiving fewer endorphins.

Watson's theory, which applies equally to men, is that in the past man would have spent his life constantly looking for food. The reward for the hard work would be eating and gaining weight. Hence if you are thin you may be constantly looking for the next meal.

Watson concludes that in evolutionary terms 'thin equals discontent. Content people have weight on them. That is why we hire thin people because they are discontent and will work harder. Heavier people are more mellow and less successful.' Thin people, on the other hand, are so driven by the need to find that elusive happiness that they become overachievers. So worldly success may well come more easily to the slender. 'Kate Moss is probably the most famous thin person in the world and she's looking particularly sad. Who has ever heard of a happy supermodel?' asked Watson.

'Why is the association with these people and drugs so strong? It may not be a moral weakness but in fact a thin person trying to find happiness in artificial opiates?'

Watson's comments will be welcomed by those who want to push body image higher up the political agenda. Last month Minister for Women Tessa Jowell came in for a barrage of criticism when she declared a Downing Street war on the 'superwaifs'.

But Watson's interest is purely scientific. He stumbled on what he calls his latest 'obsession' chatting to a taxi driver in New York who told him of an Arizona scientist who, trying to create a self-tanning drug, had injected himself with a hormone which gave him an eight-and-a-half-hour erection.

The hormone was MSH, linked to sexual desire and also to sunlight. 'It was one hormone which had always bored me before,' said Watson. His interest excited, he began to look at MSH and discovered it was closely linked to two other chemicals in the body: endorphins, the feel-good chemical, and leptin. Leptin is made in fat tissue, the more fat, the more leptin. MSH is affected by leptin and is connected to sexual desire.

'The heavier you are the more leptin and possibly the more MSH,' said Watson, who intends to continue his research from his base at Cold Spring Harbour Laboratories on Long Island.

'My guess is that your mood is controlled by endorphins and you make more of these when you are fat, hence nobody has ever drawn Santa Claus thin - thin people are discontented.'

Since MSH can also be affected by sun, happiness could depend on either being in the sun or being fat.

'The people who are the hottest sexually are fat white people who are burning in the sun,' he said. 'I now really look at fat couples in a totally different way,' he said. 'When you see two thin people together you know they've got problems.' Hence Watson recommends that curvy women match with larger-proportioned partners for the best sex life.

He also credits the drop in crime rates in his native America to the rise in obesity there. Watson hopes to publish a paper on the subject by the end of the year.

fields.headline: T-rays take over from X-rays
fields.trailText: Detectors that can exploit T-rays - electromagnetic pulses generated at a rate of a trillion a second - may soon be used to pinpoint cocaine smugglers and discover tumours in cancer patients.
fields.body:
Detectors that can exploit T-rays - electromagnetic pulses generated at a rate of a trillion a second - may soon be used to pinpoint cocaine smugglers and discover tumours in cancer patients.

Physicists from Europe, the US and Japan reported on terahertz technology last week - and revealed that detectors based on it could be installed in airports and hospitals within three years.

At a meeting in Toulouse organised by Nato, delegates said they had already used terahertz, or T-rays, to spot breast cancer cells and to pinpoint illegal drugs.

'Terahertz radiation is safe, so we should be able to use it in a wide variety of settings,' said Professor Martyn Chamberlain, of Leeds University's Institute of Microwaves and Photonics. 'In addition, T-rays not only give you an idea of the shape of a hidden object, they also let you know what it is made of - and that is extremely important.'

Military officials believe T-rays could pinpoint the chemical constituents of anti-personnel mines, and spot terrorists carrying explosives into airports. Doctors are interested in T-rays because they are less damaging to living tissue than X-rays.

Terahertz radiation is slightly more energetic than that of microwave ovens, and slightly less energetic than the infra-red light emitted by TV remote controls.

Generating pulses in this region of the electromagnetic spectrum is hard and has only recently been achieved with newly developed infra-red lasers. When these are directed on to special sheets of semi-conductor material, they emit terahertz pulses.

'Creating T-rays is still a relatively crude business but we are now making good progress,' said Chamberlain.

When terahertz radiation strikes a target, it sets its constituent molecules vibrating and rotating in ways that define the substance. Semtex molecules vibrate differently from cocaine molecules, for example. These vibrations alter the T-beam as it bounces off the target so it becomes possible to detect the presence of Semtex, or cocaine, from the T-ray reflections.

Scientists are designing devices that can exploit the power of T-ray detection. One project aims to build T-ray portals at airports. Passengers would be flooded with terahertz radiation and, from the reflections, it could be determined whether they are carrying explosives or drugs.

In hospitals, T-ray devices could spot chemical differences in the organs of individuals with a particular cancer.

'There has been a sudden rush of interest in this field, with major companies such as Toshiba investing heavily,' said Chamberlain. 'British industry is also beginning to show interest - though not in a big way yet. Hopefully they will soon see the vast potential of terahertz technology.'

fields.headline: Abortion militants to attack England
fields.trailText: An extremist group is set to bring the militant tactics of American anti-abortionists to England later this month.
fields.body:
An extremist group is set to bring the militant tactics of American anti-abortionists to England later this month.

The Christian activists, called Precious Life, will launch their trademark intimidation and leafleting at schools, abortion clinics and family planning centres in London and Liverpool.

Led by Scottish father-of-three and former Orangeman Jim Dowson, the far-right group is expanding from its base in Scotland to open a new office in Liverpool and is planning a third in London.

Dowson told The Observer he hoped to publish on the internet names and addresses of nurses working in 'death mills'. 'We want to let the whole of Britain know who they are, these men and women with knives in their hands. We are exposing abortion for what it is. It's vile - similar to paedophilia.'

Family planning agencies, women's rights campaigners and nurses' unions have been meeting to discuss the threat.

'We are incredibly worried at any threat to picket anywhere where women go for help and advice,' said Sarah Colbourne of the National Abortion Campaign. 'Neither nurses or doctors or vulnerable women deserve to be bullied like that.'

The group has staged noisy demonstrations at Scottish hospitals, centres and politicians' homes, handing graphic leaflets showing aborted foetuses to children. Scottish Health Minister Susan Deacon has threatened them with legal action.

Precious Life claims 1,200 members. Its steering committee is anonymous apart from 20-year-old student nurse Anne-Marie Willis, who recently emerged as the female face of the group, and former sales manager Dowson, who refers constantly to babies 'having their heads ripped off'.

'It's taken 10 years for the American pro-life movement to get as successful as it is so we know we have a way to go,' he said. We do not advocate violence. We want to mobilise Christians and the evangelical movement. We're starting in Liverpool because we have a lot of activists there.'

Precious Life grew out of Ireland's Youth Defence movement, linked with militant anti-abortion groups in the US, who have burnt down 12 clinics and killed four doctors since 1994.

Other UK pro-lifers, including the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, distance themselves from Youth Defence, which claims to have the support of the Pope.

In 1995, Youth Defence leaders Naimh Nic Mhathuna and John Heaney had a private audience with the Pope and claimed he told them Ireland 'was under attack' by pro-abortionists and to 'continue in your apostolate and be courageous'.

Next month Youth Defence hosts a pro-life conference in Rome where US Christian Defence Coalition leader Patrick Mahoney will speak.

Mahoney is infamous for trying to give President Clinton a 15-week aborted foetus during the Paula Jones scandal. His group pickets abortion clinics every day, bringing their children to remind patients of 'God's little image bearers'.

'Pat Mahoney has a keen interest in our group,' said Justin Barrett of Youth Defence in Dublin. 'A few years ago he funded a campaign for us but the vast majority of our funding comes from our donors in Ireland, although we have quite a few in Britain too. We wrote to them when Jim Dowson set up the Scottish branch and asked them to help.'

Last year the Scottish Catholic Herald newspaper donated payment for a Precious Life advert to charity after learning that Dowson was once an Orange Lodge member and had supported loyalist Michael Stone, who shot mourners at an IRA funeral. Belfast's Ulster Pregnancy Advisory Association closed after Precious Life picketed the home of one of its workers chanting 'murderer'.

'For days after, children were cycling up and down my road saying that babies were being murdered here,' the woman said. Not long after, the centre was firebombed.

Dowson denies that the demonstration contributed to the attack and told The Observer the office was torched because of sectarian violence. The centre was one of only two in Belfast willing to advise women about contraception and abortion.

NHS abortions are not available to women in Northern Ireland, who instead travel to England, having had to raise around £500 to finance the journey and the operation.

'That is not a situation we would ever want to see in mainland Britain,' said Juliette Hillier of the Brooks Advisory Clinics, who condemned Precious Life's 'misleading and highly emotive' literature.

fields.headline: Undergraduate finally gets laid
fields.trailText: Josh Cohen is used to playing second fiddle. For four-and-a-half months, he has padded out his part as understudy for Benjamin in The Graduate with roles including wedding guest, porter and pool player - all useful ways of distracting himself from the nightly vigil of watching from the wings as the lead character failed to fall sick and allow him his moment in the limelight.
fields.body:
Josh Cohen is used to playing second fiddle. For four-and-a-half months, he has padded out his part as understudy for Benjamin in The Graduate with roles including wedding guest, porter and pool player - all useful ways of distracting himself from the nightly vigil of watching from the wings as the lead character failed to fall sick and allow him his moment in the limelight.

Before that, he played a minor part in Rent, the American musical based on Puccini's La Bohème, and became inured to standing back while fans rushed to greet more famous members of the cast.

'Was it galling to find myself physically elbowed to one side while another cast member from Rent was showered with praise and glory?' he pondered. 'No. I've always had confidence that my time would come. I knew that one day I'd make it big.'

And make it big he has. From drama college to West End in less than two years, 26-year-old Cohen is currently the envy of every man twice his age and a good number of his contemporaries too. This is the milksop, still wet behind the ears, who will be seduced by a naked Jerry Hall once a day for six and a half months from later this month, and twice on Thursdays and Saturdays. But Cohen is beginning to realise that, despite the lead role, the Gielgud Theatre's central London location and the flurry of media attention, he has yet again been eclipsed and condemned to a role as sidekick and underling. And this time there is no hope that the show's star elect will drop out and propel him onto centre stage.

'Yes, it's extraordinary to have Mick Jagger playing my under study in private tutorials with Jerry and yes, it's also quite amazing to be the one being seduced by her night after night when she's banned him from her bed,' he said. 'But I still can't help feeling a little aggrieved when I give interviews to people and they immediately start asking me about the two of them.'

He has good reason to be frustrated: in the past month there have been 107 articles written about Jerry Hall and her accession to The Graduate, 14 of which gave brief mention to the fact that Cohen might also have a small role in the play.

'It's not really like she's stolen my thunder,' he insisted. 'I'm fully aware that without her there would be no thunder, but it's not nice to feel like a filter that people pass through simply to get something else. There was one American journalist in particular who, once he realised that I wasn't going to talk about either Jerry or Mick, simply had nothing more to say to me. We just sat there and looked at each other in silence.'

Cohen dismissed recent criticisms over Hall's appointment to the role so far played by Kathleen Turner. 'It's nonsense to say that Jerry was just brought in as a marketing gimmick,' he said. 'She has to prove herself now, it's true, but so do we all.'

For now, however, Cohen is concentrating hard on his main task: staying calm in the face of a nightly ravishing from a naked Hall. 'I'm sure I'll get used to it, he said. 'After eight times, it'll probably seem commonplace and after 30 times, perhaps it'll even be a little boring.' He paused. 'Perhaps.'
