webTitle: 'It makes more sense to forget I ever had a child'

fields.headline: 'It makes more sense to forget I ever had a child'
fields.standfirst: For three months The Observer has been investigating the emotional fall-out of family breakdown. We have found a shocking culture producing routine misery on a vast scale for both children and parents. We have discovered wide-ranging inadequacies in the legal system: ill-trained professionals, badly prepared judges, and decision-making that is often a lottery. Part one of a three-part series by Dina Rabinovitch
fields.trailText: 'I was told it'd be a very informal meeting - that we'd have our heads bashed together and be told to grow up.' This is Edward, an investment consultant and father of four who is getting divorced. He is talking about a directions (or conciliation) hearing in the family law courts - an initial session in front of a judge.
fields.body:
'I was told it'd be a very informal meeting - that we'd have our heads bashed together and be told to grow up.' This is Edward, an investment consultant and father of four who is getting divorced. He is talking about a directions (or conciliation) hearing in the family law courts - an initial session in front of a judge.

The judge opened the proceedings by asking Edward why he was asking for residence. 'I said, "I'm not, the children live with me",' he recalls. 'She then looked very embarrassed, grabbed her notes and started frantically reading.'

The judge then told Edward she wanted to resolve the dispute that day. 'When I pointed out that my barrister said that wasn't the purpose of a directions hearing, she said "this is my court".'

Welcome to the world of family law, a world of uninformed decision-making, impatient judges and rigid court orders. In family law, judges have the widest discretion and are least restrained by precedent.

The thinking is that there can only be loose guidelines within family law, no strict rules, to allow for the 'uniqueness' of each family. But this results in a 'complete lottery', says one barrister specialising in family law. 'With family cases - and this is different from any other area of law - the judge is given this excuse to be inconsistent, quite maverick in approach, or even outrageous.'

What's more, this is a system which decides that the best people to carry out the central role of assessing parents and their children, the Court Welfare Officers, are professionals from the criminal probation service.

'People would come in on a Friday afternoon from working with criminal offenders, and start work as court welfare officers on a Monday morning,' says Alan Sealey, who last year resigned his position as chair of the Association of CWOs. He describes the service he left as 'a hell of a mess - haphazard and there's no training'.

'The Court Welfare Officer didn't seem to me to be a person who understood children at all,' says Dave, a builder, who was recently granted sole residence of his three-year-old son. 'She didn't seem interested in [his son] John, except about how much contact he had with his mum. In her report she wrote that "there weren't many pictures of mum around the house".' She might have wondered just how many people decorate their homes with photographs of their ex? (The amount of time a CWO will spend with a child varies enormously; there might be repeated visits or none at all.)

Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, claims that fundamental changes to the system are imminent.

From April 2001, CWOs will be the responsibility of a new department, the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (CAFCAs). But these 'fundamental' changes seem to amount to nothing more than a new home. (And nobody in the service seems to have noticed that the name seems, unfortunately - if aptly - to be a variant of Kafka.)

What's more, according to Mr Justice Wall, a senior High Court judge 'with all the administration involved we'll be lucky to have CAFCAs set up with a roof, let alone any fundamental changes'.

Those parents who do manage to gain an audience with a judge will face further problems. The standard divorce, money and contact cases coming to court, which are increasing in number, though divorce rates appear to have levelled off, will be heard by part-time judges and judges drawn from the county courts (traditionally known as the 'cut-price' or 'poor man's courts').

So what is going on in the family courts? Are they governed by a disdain for parenting, coupled with a particular suspicion of involved parents? Or perhaps still at work is the influence of a culture - the same one that sends its supposed elite off to boarding school - that does not understand children.

How else to explain the stories I was hearing all the time? Stories of judges ignoring women's concerns about domestic violence; stories of the fathers every year who kill their children during their post-divorce contact period. Stories of fathers given an hour a fortnight to spend with their children, post-divorce, causing damage that only those who have been separated from a child can understand.

I began taking an interest in family law following my own and friends' divorces, witnessing the reckless decisions I saw being taken about families' lives. At first, I couldn't believe what I was seeing. Some of the characters within family courts seem to come straight from the pages of Charles Dickens. Only in the family courts could one hear, as I did last month, the phrase 'in these very modern times in which we live, where some couples cohabit without marrying', uttered by a barrister.

Those going through the system are often rendered passive by it. They can see the problems but don't want their whole lives affected, so they choose to 'get on with things' rather than fight back. Or worse, they do fight back, and become manic, angered by the intricate injustices which, in turn, might result in them being seen as the problem.

Sarah Heatley's story (see the parent's story below) might offer an extreme case study. But every day routine misery is visited upon parents and children. Over the past few months, The Observer has been exploring the system, spending time watching these daily traumas unfold.

The mother, Iris, comes through the plate-glass doors of the family courts building first. She talks about what she thinks will happen that day at court. Her former partner, Dan, has sued for joint residence of their two children. Iris wants sole residence.

Iris imagines she will be ushered into a court room with a judge. She doesn't really see the day ahead anymore clearly than that. She knows she is paying 'around £600' for a barrister to be in court with her that day, whom she has not yet met.

There are tables in recesses along the corridor, off which the individual courts lead. The solicitor shepherds Iris to one of these tables, and the barrister arrives. Within the hour, Iris's solicitor, who has the most knowledge of her circumstances, leaves so as to save her client the hourly cost of her services and in order to get on with her own heavy workload.

Dan turns up, with a solicitor but no barrister. They sit at another table further down the corridor. The hearing is scheduled for 11am, in half-an-hour's time. A clerk comes out and says the judge is running a bit late. Iris's barrister reads her papers and says she will talk to Dan's solicitor, to see what can be negotiated.

The hearing in front of the judge never happens. The mother's barrister and the father's solicitor begin a whole day of back-and-forth, table-hopping negotiations, like over-active hosts at a gala dinner. This controlled frenzy is repeated all along the corridor, and indeed the other floors of this family court building, each time set in relief against the bleached-out faces of the mothers and fathers immobile at their separate tables.

None of the professionals - the solicitors, barristers, court welfare officers or indeed the judge - are surprised that the hearing does not take place. It is common practice for a hearing date and time to be fixed, but all the professionals involved come to the court premises with the knowledge that a discussion will take place in the corridors, rather than everybody going into court to put their case before a judge.

A 'settlement' is thus forced out of the parties under the worst possible circumstances - the threat of that great indeterminate, the judge, actually deciding the case. It is not a healthy environment in which to make important decisions about one's children. But it is very difficult, unless one is practising in this field, to get a clear picture of how it operates.

So much of what is going on in the family courts is secret. Family hearings are most often held 'in chambers', i.e. in private, and not reported. This is for obvious, but not insurmountable, reasons, and it means that much of what goes on is not investigated, or indeed challenged. And in fact, such is the pressure of family work that, around the country, any judge with spare time is pressed into service. On the one hand, lawmakers are talking about the need for an ever more specialised family court. But, in reality, the pressure of work means that pretty much any judge who wants to can obtain what's called a 'family ticket' - the right to sit as a family judge.

So parents expose their families to the mercy of whichever judge hears their case. Training, background, what a judge may have read most recently, will all be crucial to the outcome of the case.

Family judges have so much work ('10 cases on your desk each morning'), it can be hard for anything bar the most blaring of messages to reach them.

Last week a circuit judge, a perfectly kind and gentle person, told me: 'Quite often, you see a man, he tells you that "when we were married, she drove me mad, and I whacked her. I've never laid a hand on the kids, though, and I wouldn't." I must say, I find that quite compelling.'

If family court hearings were open, bad practice could be exposed much earlier. We would also all have at least the chance of a clearer idea of what constitutes family law and what fashions are being followed at any time.

According to Lord Justice Thorpe, in the early 1990s the Lord Chancellor's Department carried out a consultation about whether family justice should come out from behind closed doors, but the outcome itself was never published - a muffling of the secrecy inquiry worthy of a Blackadder script. But while the political shenanigans continue, parents - and children - carry on suffering.

A father fighting right now for overnight contact with his three-year-old daughter (and there are no allegations of damaging behaviour of any kind), told me: 'I've been pursuing this for two years now; last year I almost gave up - I thought it would make more sense all round for me to cut off contact completely and just forget I ever had a child.'

The child's story

Now 12, Jasmine was seven years old when her parents separated.

She did not see her father at all for a period of 10 months, following a court welfare service report recommending restricted contact.

She talks about being interviewed by a court welfare officer. After litigating for four years, her father established steady contact.

'It was a bit weird really - I was pulled out of my class, out of lessons to go to see him (the CWO). I didn't know what it was about the first time.

'He came to see me in school about three times, I think. He was stupid. He had these pebbles and he said one pebble was my sister, one was me, one my dad, and one my mum. Then he'd move my sister's pebble over to my dad, and mine over to my mum. It was rubbish. He'd say, do you want to live with your dad? You don't really know what to answer.

'I was about seven or eight then, I think, and I just said, "I dunno" or, "with my mum" or something.

'Things are good now, I see my dad quite a lot (alternate weekends, and Wednesday evenings), so I don't have to miss him that much.

'When the welfare officer asked me, I just picked my mum. I didn't know what to choose. I remember I felt like I was stuck, I got confused.'

The parent's story

In 1993 Sarah Heatley's ex-husband killed their two children, Jack and Nina, and then committed suicide, on his first unsupervised contact with them.

Sarah now has a four-year-old son, George. She was back in the courts this January, over contact with his father, Jan.

'Jan has shared care of his two older sons by a previous relationship. He always said he wasn't concerned with George, that it complicated things with his older boys.

'He would have George every Saturday for three hours. I didn't think it was worth staying in Sheffield for that, so I took a job in Colchester, with better pay.

'Jan applied for overnight contact with George. I said I wasn't happy with Jan's safety standards. The night I met him it was in a pub, and he'd left his 10-year-old son at home. But the case welfare officer (CWO) and judge recommended overnight contact.

'I felt that they thought, here is a hysterical woman, tread carefully. The CWO said to me, "I'm afraid we sometimes sanction contact, even when the circumstances are not ideal." I was told that I had to oblige, that it was in George's interests.

'In 1997, a television programme took me to meet the judge and the CWO who'd been involved with Nina's and Jack's custody. The CWO expressed no remorse or regrets - he just wanted to vindicate himself on film.

'When I told him I didn't want their father to have unsupervised contact, he'd said: "There's nothing to be anxious about."

'After the camera was switched off, the judge took me to one side and gave me his heartfelt sympathies. He hadn't known about Nina and Jack, until the TV people contacted him.

'He then told me he'd found out that my dad had written to him about it all, but his secretary had fielded the letter from him - to protect him.'

The barrister's story

'You go into court never knowing the outcome, or even knowing whether stuff that's been agreed by both counsel outside the court will be ratified by the judge. I can think of so many cases that just seem totally bizarre in outcome. For example, I once represented a father of four children. The mother had left, and was gone for two or three years, during which time the father cared for the children.

'Then mum reappeared and the father made an application for custody. We had numerous witnesses testifying to his good care of the children.

'The mother's counsel relied on the fact that she was the mother, but also the fact that she was white and the father black.

'The mother's counsel presented to the judge a report by an American academic, based on a survey, which said that black men by virtue of their race are unable to love their children.

'It was absolutely appalling, but the judge was listening to it all. I'm black, and I was spluttering throughout. The mother's counsel also played on the fact (and this is a ploy I've used myself) that the daughter would need a woman in her life as she approached puberty, and how dangerous it'd be to have a man look after her.

'Residence was awarded to the mother. We were appalled, because we knew she wouldn't be able to cope and would leave the children again. The mother's counsel in that case is now sitting as a family court judge herself.

'In a welfare case about a three-year-old girl, she was able to read, and the report said that therefore she couldn't be living in normal circumstances because normal three-year-olds can't read.

'The welfare report said mum should be taught how to interact more normally with her child.

'Our system is flawed in resolving family disputes and how we treat children. '

The process

When parents are unable to agree on residence and contact for their children, this is what should happen next.

Stage 1: One side makes an application under the Children Act

Stage 2: First appointment at court, usually called a conciliation appointment in front of a district judge, to discuss the issues. If agreement is reached, the district judge can make an order in the terms agreed. If there is no agreement, the district judge sets a timetable - gives 'directions', so this is also called a direction hearing - for the final hearing.

Stage 3: Full hearing, with witness statements and Court Welfare Officer's report.

Some of the names in this article have been changed.

Next week: The real power inside the system: the most senior judges speak, as never before, on the problems with family law.

webTitle: US sprays poison in drugs war

fields.headline: US sprays poison in drugs war
fields.standfirst: Colombia aid includes plan to target coca fields with GM herbicide which kills other crops and threatens humans
fields.trailText: A torrent of potentially lethal herbicide is set to be unleashed across great swaths of Colombia as part of a new US aid package which was finally approved by Congress last week.
fields.body:
A torrent of potentially lethal herbicide is set to be unleashed across great swaths of Colombia as part of a new US aid package which was finally approved by Congress last week.

A hidden and undebated condition of the $1.6 billion package - meant to finance the Colombian government's fight against the now overlapping forces of guerrilla rebels and narco-cartels - is a plan for military aircraft to spray the country's coca-growing areas.

The scheme echoes the infamous defoliation of Vietnam because the plan involves a mycoherbicide called Fusarium EN-4. The Fusarium fungus is the root for many of the chemical weapons developed by the US, the Soviet Union, Britain, Israel, France and Iraq.

Mycotoxicologist Jeremy Bigwood - working with a fellowship grant to carry out research into Fusarium derivatives used in biological warfare - told The Observer that the use of the fungus in Colombia would damage crops other than cocaine, and develop mutations that could lethally affect humans with immune deficiencies.

Fusarium works by infecting crops with a soil-borne mould which secretes toxins into their roots, which then putrefy and dissolve the plants' cells, killing them or - worse still - affecting the animals or humans who feed off them. During the late 1980s, a mystery epidemic of Fusarium suddenly attacked a coca-growing area of Peru. Bigwood was working as a photo-journalist and teamed up with a Latin American expert, Sharon Stevenson, to publish an article in the Miami Herald detailing extensive damage to other crops than coca in the Peruvian valley.

Ruined peasants said they had seen helicopters spraying a brownish smoke across the fields, but it remains a mystery whether the Fusarium epidemic was an experiment by the US and Peruvian authorities, as Bigwood and Stevenson suspected.

Fusarium next emerged in 1999 when Colonel Jim McDonough - a former colleague of White House drug czar General Barry McCaffrey, now in charge of the present Colombian operation - was hired by Governor Jeb Bush to run the Florida anti-drug office. He proposed to spray the fungus's EN-4 strain on the state's copious marijuana crops. His adviser in the scheme was Dr David Sands, now a professor at the University of Montana in Bozeman, who had extracted the strain for the US Department of Agriculture.

The plan was scotched when the head of Florida's Department of Environmental Protection, Dr David Struhs, wrote a letter to the colonel dated 6 April 1999, saying that the 'mutagenicity' of the fungus 'was by far the most disturbing factor in attempting to use a Fusarium species as a herbicide. It is difficult if not impossible to control the spread of the Fusarium species,' he wrote. 'The mutated fungi can cause disease in a large number of crops including tomatoes, peppers, flowers, corn and vines'. He added that the mutated genus could stay in the ground for 40 years.

During research for his lecture, Bigwood traced Sands to Colombia where he was an executive with Agricultural and Biological Control, a company which markets the fungus. He visited scientists to tell them about EN-4, and - according to the same scientists' accounts to Bigwood - instructed them not to talk to the press.

The government's 'fumigation' of coca-growing areas of Colombia had been continuing for some time on a small scale, with Indians in the high Andean villages complaining of nausea, rashes and stomach problems after the spray-planes had swooped over. They have also damaged legitimate crops, thereby undermining government efforts to support farmers who have renounced poppy and coca growing.

The agent used in these cases was Glyphosate, marketed by the Monsanto company (famous for GM foods) as 'Roundup'. Monsanto had been forced by a court case in New York to withdraw claims that the product was 'safe, non-toxic and harmless'.

The limited spraying programme did nothing to curb the mass production of either cocaine or heroin. Official sources fear even if the forthcoming programme were to wipe out a third of the drug, that would send the price of the remaining two-thirds 'through the ceiling'.

US government researchers, says Bigwood, initially insisted that the EN-4 strain was 'species specific', designed to attack only the Erythroxylum genus in a coca plant. But, he says, there are 200 other plant species within that genus which do not contain coca and could therefore be affected and destroyed. Even this does not fully define the threat to other crops because, says Bigwood, 'it mutates into another organism, capable of attacking another plant. The protagonists of Fusarium can then hide behind the fact that when it attacks something else, it has become something else.'

Bigwood's greatest concern is with the potential effect not on other crops than coca, but on humans. Among the Colombian scientists who met with Sands was Eduardo Posada, president of the Colombian Centre for International Physics, who found Fusarium to be 'highly toxic'. His data found that that the mortality rate among hospital patients who were immune-deficient and in-fected by the fungus was 76 per cent.

'To apply a mycoherbicide from the air that has been associated with a 76 per cent kill rate of hospitalised human patients would be tantamount to biological warfare', he said.

The limited spraying programme did nothing to curb the mass production of either cocaine or heroin. Official sources fear even if the forthcoming programme were to wipe out a third of the drug, that would send the price of the remaining two-thirds 'through the ceiling'. US government researchers, says Bigwood, initially insisted that the EN-4 strain was 'species specific', designed to attack only the Erythroxylum genus in a coca plant. But, he says, there are 200 other plant species within that genus which do not contain coca and could therefore be affected and destroyed. Even this does not fully define the threat to other crops because, says Bigwood, 'it mutates into another organism, capable of attacking another plant. The protagonists of Fusarium can then hide behind the fact that when it attacks something else, it has become something else.' Bigwood's greatest concern is with the potential effect not on other crops than coca, but on humans. Among the Colombian scientists who met with Sands was Eduardo Posada, president of the Colombian Centre for International Physics, who found Fusarium to be 'highly toxic'. His data found that that the mortality rate among hospital patients who were immune-deficient and in-fected by the fungus was 76 per cent. 'To apply a mycoherbicide from the air that has been associated with a 76 per cent kill rate of hospitalised human patients would be tantamount to biological warfare', he said.

webTitle: Loudspeakers blamed as eight die at festival

fields.headline: Loudspeakers blamed as eight die at festival
fields.trailText: Faulty loudspeakers that caused fans to rush closer to the stage to hear the music may have led to eight deaths at the Roskilde Festival near Copenhagen on Friday night, Danish police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Faulty loudspeakers that caused fans to rush closer to the stage to hear the music may have led to eight deaths at the Roskilde Festival near Copenhagen on Friday night, Danish police said yesterday.

The disaster occurred shortly before midnight on Friday at one of Europe's oldest and most popular musical festivals. As fans moved closer to the foot of the stage during a set by US rock group Pearl Jam, eight were trampled underfoot.

Victims included a Dutch man aged 23, a German aged 26, a 22-year-old Swede and a Dane of 17. Twenty-six fans received medical attention.

'Things were really great and we wanted to move up forwards,' said festival-goer Lasse Aagard yesterday . The group's singer, Eddie Vedder repeatedly ask the crowd of 50,000 to move back and stopped the show when they failed to respond.

It had rained steadily at the festival site throughout Friday and the ground around the seven stages was muddy. As Pearl Jam continued their set, still pointing at the crush of bodies near the stage, the victims, all men, slipped and were trampled to death, police said.

'At one point, some 15 spectators collapsed en masse in front of the rostrum and people behind them began uncontrollably tumbling over them,' added one witness. 'It was obvious what was going to happen.'

'Everybody at the festival is deeply concerned and wishes to express their sympathy to the relatives,' said festival spokesman Leif Skov yester day. 'The festival is expected to continue to its Sunday conclusion with the deepest respect for the perished. Life is stronger than death.'

This year's festival features 170 performers, including Lou Reed, Oasis, Willie Nelson and the Pet Shop Boys. First held in 1971, Roskilde was launched as a European equivalent of Woodstock. It is staged annually on a farm 25 miles west of Copenhagen. The four-day festival has in recent years attracted over 100,000 fans, but attendance this weekend, provoked by safety concerns, was limited to 90,000.

Increased security and stage management over the years have failed to stop the death toll at high-profile festivals. Last year, 52 people were killed in a stampede after a rock concert in Minsk, Belarus.

Yesterday, in a nationally televised interview, Danish Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen expressed sorrow for the deaths. 'It was a terrible and tragic accident. It is very difficult to put words on the fact that so many young people have lost their lives in such sinister circumstances.'

In a statement released yesterday, Pearl Jam said: 'This is so painful. I think we are all waiting for someone to wake us and say it was just a horrible nightmare. There are absolutely no words to express our anguish.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Egyptian professor accused of 'harming national unity'
fields.body:
Egyptian professor accused of 'harming national unity'

Cairo police have arrested Saad Eddin Ibrahim, professor of sociology at the American University in Cairo and a champion of human rights in Egypt, accusing him of publishing reports harming national unity.

Infected milk makes 5,000 ill

About 5,000 people in western Japan have fallen ill after drinking low fat milk. Authorites suspect an infected valve at a plant.

700 swim the Baltic channel

700 people finished the annual Stralsund channel swim in the Baltic within the 45-minute limit.

Law enrobed

Beijing judges will wear robes or suits instead of uniforms to increase respect for the law.

Refugee ferry still missing

The Indonesian navy sent ships and planes to a remote island in the Moluccas to check whether a missing ferry carrying at least 500 Christians fleeing sectarian violence was seized by Muslim fighters, but found no proof of this.

Chechen rebels ambush troops

Russian soldiers suffered fresh losses in a rebel ambush in breakaway Chechnya when at least nine were killed and seven wounded in a village south-east of the regional capital Grozny.

$4.5bn poker empire folds

The last game of video poker was played in South Carolina as a statewide ban on a $4.5 billion industry took effect.

Flood deaths

Sixty people died when a bus was swept away by floods in central Ethiopia.

fields.headline: Burger rebel faces token penalty
fields.trailText: Prosecutors yesterday demanded a token week in jail for José Bové, the French activist on trial in the small southern town of Millau for wrecking a McDonald's restaurant last year in protest against 'globalisation'.
fields.body:
Prosecutors yesterday demanded a token week in jail for José Bové, the French activist on trial in the small southern town of Millau for wrecking a McDonald's restaurant last year in protest against 'globalisation'.

The trial, which started on Friday, has turned into a two-day carnival with an estimated 45,000 revellers at a free rock concert last night. Fifteen thousand stayed to support the 'Millau Ten' as Bové and his nine co-defendants are known.

The trial was set to finish yesterday evening, with judgment expected some time later this summer.

Bové's defence has been that the attack on McDonald's, which allegedly caused £70,000 of damage, was legitimate civil disobedience. He has called several of the biggest celebrities of modern protest movements as witnesses to help argue his case.

The courtroom has been used to debate global trade, Americanisation, malbouffe (junk food) and their effect on small peasant farmers.

Though many people clearly come to Millau for fun, the town was bedecked with banners supporting Bové.

'Merde à McDonald's' read one banner. 'Down with junk food,' said another. Many were wearing T-shirts proclaiming 'the world is not for sale' - the title of Bové's best-selling book. On the back of them is: 'And nor am I'.

The local speciality Roquefort cheese was the catalyst for 47-year-old Bové's attack on McDonald's. Last year the US imposed a 100 per cent tax on imports of the cheese in response to the Europe's refusal to allow sale of US hormonally enhanced beef.

Bové raises sheep for Roquefort and saw the ban as symbolic of big businesses' assault on small farmers.

The original attack on McDonald's was hardly reported, but Bové's subsequent imprisonment for 23 days after refusing to pay bail made him a national hero.

Lionel Jospin, the French Prime Minister, has paid tribute to him and Jacques Chirac, the President, has been filmed reading Bozé's book. French newspapers this weekend lauded the 'Astérix of McDonald's, St Bové' and 'the Robin Hood of Larzac'.

Though likely to spend only one week in prison if the judge sentences according to the prosecutors' wishes, Bové remains stubbornly defiant. 'The only thing possible is acquittal,' he said.

fields.headline: Scientists denounce Mbeki's 'Aids error'
fields.trailText: More than 5,000 of the world's leading scientists, doctors, research directors and Nobel Prize-winners have signed an open declaration affirming that HIV is the 'clear-cut' and 'unambiguous' cause of Aids.
fields.body:
More than 5,000 of the world's leading scientists, doctors, research directors and Nobel Prize-winners have signed an open declaration affirming that HIV is the 'clear-cut' and 'unambiguous' cause of Aids.

The mass signing - unprecedented in medical history and organised by more than 50 national groups - is intended to establish the research community's implacable opposition to the views of South African President Thabo Mbeki.

Mbeki recently gave contentious support to a small group of dissident scientists who claim there is no link between the virus and the disease now ravaging southern Africa. A special scientific committee, set up by Mbeki, is due to meet tomorrow to try to find common ground between the two sides.

However, the mass signing of the declaration, to be published in the magazine Nature on Thursday, will render this task insurmountable and will set the scene for a controversial opening of the thirteenth International Aids Conference in Durban next Sunday.

Signatories of the Durban Declaration include Nobel Prize-winners such as Aaron Klug, Max Perutz and Caesar Milstein, as well as James Watson, co-discoverer of the structure of DNA. Directors of the US National Academy of Sciences, the Royal Society in London, the Pasteur Institute in Paris and the National Institute of Virology in South Africa have also put their names to the document.

'The evidence that Aids is caused by HIV is clear-cut, exhaustive and unambiguous, meeting the highest standards of science,' states the declaration. 'The data fulfil exactly the same criteria as for other viral diseases, such as polio, measles and smallpox. It is unfortunate that a few vocal people continue to deny the evidence. This position will cost countless lives.'

This uncompromising stance threatens to bring emotions to near boiling point at the Durban conference, the world's principal forum for discussing developments in HIV research. Scientists are already horrified by news of Aids' dramatic spread in Africa's southern regions.

Last week the United Nations revealed that 34.3 million people now carry HIV in their blood, and 24.5 million of them live in southern Africa. In 1999, 2.8 million people died as a consequence of that infection. The vast majority were Africans.

However, the disease's spread has been anything but uniform through the continent. 'In Central Africa, HIV infections were about 5 per cent 15 years ago,' said Aids researcher Professor Robin Weiss, of University College London. 'Now the rate has reached about 7-8 per cent.

'By contrast, in 1985 southern Africa had HIV infection rates of less than 1 per cent. Now they have leapt to between 30 and 40 per cent.'

Scientists cannot yet explain these disparate infection rates, though some sug gest secondary factors - infections with parasites, for example - may be involved. Others, such as Weiss, believe the problem lies in the nature of HIV itself.

'This virus comes in many different strains and will occupy many different niches,' he said. 'It is simply very, very opportunistic - which makes its behaviour very hard to predict.'

Aids now rivals malaria as the world's greatest infectious killer. However, unlike malaria, which mainly kills children, Aids mostly claims the lives of young adults, wrecking families and national economies deprived of workers.

'The Aids timebomb has already gone off in southern Africa,' said Weiss. 'The next region to be affected will probably be the Indian sub-continent where HIV rates have already reached several million.'

Although scientists have developed drugs to halt the spread of HIV, such medicines are too expensive for developing nations. New ways to combat Aids in the Third World are urgently needed, and had been expected to form the basis of the Durban conference.

However, widespread dismay has been caused by Mbeki's recent support for Aids dissidents such as US researcher Peter Duisberg, whom he said were being treated like religious heretics. Most analysts saw this as evidence that the President was in denial about HIV. A principal aim of the declaration will be to stiffen the resolve of Mbeki and other politicians to accept the grim truth of the Aids threat.

The declaration concludes: 'Science will one day triumph over Aids, just as it did over smallpox. Until then, reason, solidarity, political will and courage must be our partners.'

webTitle: Virgins fight the killer that shames

fields.headline: Virgins fight the killer that shames
fields.trailText: Rose 'Ma' Zungu runs a virginity-testing centre in the land of the Zulus, long a bloody corner of South Africa and most recently the scene of a regional civil war accompanying the transfer of power to the nation's black majority.
fields.body:
Rose 'Ma' Zungu runs a virginity-testing centre in the land of the Zulus, long a bloody corner of South Africa and most recently the scene of a regional civil war accompanying the transfer of power to the nation's black majority.

Now a new assassin, Aids - whose name is never spoken - stalks the killing fields of the warrior tribe who style themselves the 'heavenly people'. One attempt to defend them is Ma Zungu's curious trade.

Once a month, on a Friday night, between 20 and 30 girls assemble in the shed opposite Ma Zungu's house in the township of Lamontville, dancing and singing. They sleep in the shed overnight and are wakened after sunrise to line up for the tests.

Afterwards comes the presentation of the prized virginity certificates. The girls agree that 'we are fed up with boys only interested in taking our virginity and then going on to the next one'.

Virginity 'is like gold dust,' says one, to murmurs of assent. Being a virgin is cool, says another. It's about feminism and being in control. Nobody men tions the assassin's name. The undertakers of KwaZulu-Natal Province, which includes Durban, are busy over the weekend, as they were during that civil war. But now nobody sings fighting songs in praise of the fallen. The silence of shame attends their corpses. Even in the anger of the graveside nobody utters the assassin's name.

Ma Zungu had a daughter who was at the virgin-testing. Phumzile had taken part until last year, when she was 25, and told her mother: 'Ma, I can look after myself now...'

She was pitifully thin. Ma Zungu said: 'I don't think she's well.' Last week, back home in Johannesburg, Ma Zungu told me that Phumzile was now dead, and - over the telephone - I at last heard the assassin named.

Her daughter was the second of Ma Zungu's three children to die the same way. Her son, Mandlenkosi, died two years ago. Her eldest son, Khamsanqa ('Lucky'), graduated last month from New York's Julliard school of music after training as an opera singer. It is a reminder that theirs is still the land of heavenly voices, even if the Zulu dead are no longer honoured in song.

webTitle: Trusts that are far too cosy for comfort

fields.headline: Trusts that are far too cosy for comfort
fields.trailText: Heather Connon Your investments
fields.body:
Watch out, watch out, the arbitrageurs are about. For investment trust managers, the attention of an arbitrageur is likely to be unwelcome. But for shareholders, it could do more for the value of their investments than any industry awareness campaign.

So far, the arbitrageurs - investors who take stakes in trusts to force changes that will increase the value of the investments - have declared their hand in only a few situations. A New York firm called Millennium Partners last week succeeded in forcing the recontruction of International Biotechnology Trust (IBT), run by Rothschild Asset Management, and Regent Europe is asking Govett Emerging Markets to find ways to give shareholders some cash back.

There could soon be more action - Templeton Emerging Markets is being talked of as a target. Despite the 'its' campaign to promote investment trusts, discounts - the difference between share price and the value of the assets in the trust - are now over 15 per cent. A new vulture trust - the Value Catalyst Fund - is being launched to target underperforming trusts.

There are simply too many trusts, and most are too small to attract investors' attention. Managers tell small firms that they need to get bigger or get out of the stock market, but when it comes to their own trusts, the message is ignored.

To be fair, many trusts specialise in niche areas which fall out of fashion - smaller European compa nies for example - and their discounts rise and fall accordingly. But a well managed trust will be popular in good times or bad.

In a normal world, poor trusts would be taken over or wound up. But the investment trust world is still characterised by cosy relationships and self-interest. Millennium Partners, for example, makes a number of accusations about the activities of IBT's managers.

'I am amazed at how old-fashioned the sector is,' said one fund manager who specialises in trusts. 'It is like the City was 20 years ago.'

The longer the cosy world operates, the more ineffective the 'its' campaign will be. Aimed at the retail investor, 'its' will be of most benefit to the big international trusts and the general growth funds like Foreign & Colonial or Fleming Claverhouse.

Small investors would never be encouraged to put their money into very specialist trusts: the risks are too high. But their poor performance will continue to blight the sector's image.

webTitle: Pokemon craze prepares girls to become tycoons

fields.headline: Pokemon craze prepares girls to become tycoons
fields.trailText: The future of Britain's boardrooms is being shaped in its playgrounds: girls, not boys, will be the new wheeler-dealers. More girls than boys are now buying Pokémon cards to trade.
fields.body:
The future of Britain's boardrooms is being shaped in its playgrounds: girls, not boys, will be the new wheeler-dealers. More girls than boys are now buying Pokémon cards to trade.

The Pokémon craze demands negotiating skills as children as young as six bid for their favourite characters from the world's most famous cartoon and computer game.

Some boys have resorted to mugging to obtain the most popular cards, while others have hit the headlines for the cash that changes hands. But supermarket chain Tesco says in the past two months sales to girls are up by 28 per cent, overtaking those to boys.

'Young girls are moving away from traditional girls' toys such as dolls into areas once seen as male preserves,' said buyer Robert Hookway. With two women on its board of 15, Tesco is asking manufacturers to make more toys to appeal to both boys and girls.

A survey of 5,000 women for Top Santé magazine shows women rate themselves higher than men at everything from communicating to creativity. Women make up 45 per cent of the workforce and hold 20 per cent of the directorships. Yet they account for 40 per cent of new business ventures, suggesting an entrepreneurial spirit the Pokémon craze has tapped in to.

The Pokémon craze demands negotiating skills as children as young as six bid for their favourite characters from the world's most famous cartoon and computer game. Some boys have resorted to mugging to obtain the most popular cards, while others have hit the headlines for the cash that changes hands. But supermarket chain Tesco says in the past two months sales to girls are up by 28 per cent, overtaking those to boys. 'Young girls are moving away from traditional girls' toys such as dolls into areas once seen as male preserves,' said buyer Robert Hookway. With two women on its board of 15, Tesco is asking manufacturers to make more toys to appeal to both boys and girls. A survey of 5,000 women for Top Santé magazine shows women rate themselves higher than men at everything from communicating to creativity. Women make up 45 per cent of the workforce and hold 20 per cent of the directorships. Yet they account for 40 per cent of new business ventures, suggesting an entrepreneurial spirit the Pokémon craze has tapped in to.

webTitle: Berlin holds an orgy but no one has sex

fields.headline: Berlin holds an orgy but no one has sex
fields.trailText: It has become Berlin's biggest tourist attraction, a drug-fuelled celebration of hedonism that fills the city centre with one-and-a-half million half-naked young people and a throbbing techno beat.
fields.body:
It has become Berlin's biggest tourist attraction, a drug-fuelled celebration of hedonism that fills the city centre with one-and-a-half million half-naked young people and a throbbing techno beat.

But Germany's leading sex expert has condemned the annual Love Parade - to be held for the twelfth time next Saturday, with an offshoot event in Britain - as a festival of human loneliness that has nothing to do with love - or sex.

Professor Volkmar Sigusch, who heads the Institute for Sexual Research in Frankfurt, believes that, unlike previous generations, few of the beautiful revellers who parade themselves in Berlin have any interest in one another. 'When people show themselves off like this at the Love Parade it has a primarily self-regarding character. It is meant to satisfy the person himself. It is not love or even sex between two people that is in the foreground but self-love,' he said.

The Love Parade started as a birthday party for a Berlin DJ, Dr Motte, in 1989, when it was attended by only 150 people. It has grown each year and is now the biggest dance party in the world. Berlin police say the city's drug dealers prepare for the event months in advance and the factories making ecstasy and amphetamines across the border in Poland have been working overtime in recent weeks.

Motte outraged Germany's Jews five years ago when he suggested that, half a century after the Holocaust, they should 'put on a new record and stop whingeing'. He apologised two years later and has kept clear of political issues ever since.

Sigusch maintains that, despite their image of themselves as fun-loving individualists, the ravers are meek, highly disciplined members of society. 'The Love Parade is a curious construction. The old sexuality experienced by previous generations was hysterical when it took place in public. What had been powerfully suppressed broke out equally powerfully. The new sexuality follows a perverse mode,' he said.

Sociologists who attend the Love Parade to observe its participants have reported to Sigusch that, despite the drugs, music and naked flesh, very few ravers end up having sex. He believes this reflects a worldwide trend among young people who are losing interest in sex altogether. 'A large number of people can now admit they simply don't enjoy sex. Just like there are people who never watch television, never read a book, never travel. We must learn to understand this.'

Dance music fans who are unhappy with the way the Love Parade has developed are staging their own, alternative party in Berlin - called, appropriately enough, the Fuck Parade. But they have not stopped Motte turning his party into a global brand - Vienna staged its own Love Parade yesterday and Leeds will have its own version to coincide with Berlin's this Saturday.

Motte says: 'My vision is to establish a Love Parade day throughout the world and to let so many people dance that the morphogenetic field around the earth will be so full that world peace will reign through dancing.'

Denis Staunton writes for the 'Irish Times'

webTitle: Spain at war over its past

fields.headline: Spain at war over its past
fields.standfirst: Schools accused of ignoring national history in rush to teach regional issues
fields.trailText: Spain, wrote the great Victorian traveller Richard Ford, is 'a bundle of local units tied together by a rope of sand'. And 150 years later Spaniards are still arguing over what holds and shapes the nation, most recently in a furious debate over teaching history.
fields.body:
Spain, wrote the great Victorian traveller Richard Ford, is 'a bundle of local units tied together by a rope of sand'. And 150 years later Spaniards are still arguing over what holds and shapes the nation, most recently in a furious debate over teaching history.

A report issued last week by the Royal Academy of History complains that the subject is so localised that in some areas children lack any sense of a common past. In the green and Celtic corner of Galicia, for example, textbooks devote only 22 lines to the Second Republic, the Civil War and the Franco dictatorship, yet use 22 pages to detail changes in Galicia over the period.

The heaviest guns are reserved for the Basque country where historians accuse the ikastolas , or Basque-language schools, of fomenting racism: 'The history taught is partial and tendentious, inspired by nationalist ideas that encourage racism and the exclusion of common ties.'

British historian Raymond Carr says: 'The establishment of a balance between the demands of central government in Madrid and a resistant provincialism helps to map the course of Spanish history.' But the telling of this history has long been a weapon in the political arsenal. During the dictatorship a single historical 'truth' was disseminated, of an imperial Spain, undivided; local languages, such as Basque and Catalan, were banned, as were local histories.

The 1978 constitution recognised a 'nation of nations', granted autonomy to 17 regions and with it the right to set up to 45 per cent of the local curriculum. Therefore, textbooks destined for Madrid or Santiago de Compostela or Barcelona are issued in separate editions. 'The word "Spain" has been practically wiped out, and instead the phrase "territorial limits" is used,' complained Gonzalo Anes, director of the academy. 'The role of politicians should be to learn, and not to take it upon themselves to write history.'

The immediate uproar sparked by his report came mostly from nationalist politicians who described it as an attack on the regions in line with a recent hardening of the government's position towards Basque nationalists, in particular.

The ikastolas waved aloft EU-prize-winning text-books to illustrate their academic credentials. Catalans wondered why the report was written without the input of a couple of eminent Catalan academicians. Sergi Pamiès, a prominent Catalan writer, said: 'This is an old argument - part of Spain's inability to understand its many nations. It can show up in laws, in the economy, in the way some resources are distributed. This ghost still walks: not wanting to admit that this is a multi-national country.'

He added: 'I know that when my children study history they will be told lies, so it doesn't make any difference if it's a nationalist lie or a Spanish lie - what hurts is that they do it with my taxes.'

Alberto Letona, who runs a cultural foundation in Bilbao, said learning about Basque history does not preclude learning about Spanish or European history. 'Under Franco there was no polemic, because we learnt a history that was simply one story, but with the advent of democracy it has become more complicated because each area wanted to reflect its own interests,' says Letona, a supporter of the ikastolas .

'With a bit of common sense it could be solved,' says Pamiès. 'But then we wouldn't be living in Spain' - a country of gloriously varied regions.

fields.headline: Neighbourhood watch
fields.standfirst: Sharing your postcode with celebrities is no guarantee of higher prices, writes  Anne Caborn
fields.trailText: Sharing your postcode with celebrities is no guarantee of higher prices, writes Anne Caborn
fields.body:
Living in close proximity to a well-known author or famous actor may add a certain frisson to visiting the corner shop. But does having a famous neighbour add to the saleability, or even the value, of your home?

On the plus side, famous neighbours with high purchasing power are indicative of a well heeled, or at least upwardly mobile, residential area. But celebs are often accompanied by groupies, or even stalkers, which raises all sorts of security issues.

'Nick Rhodes owned a house in Gilston Road, SW10, when Duran Duran were at the height of their fame,' said David Forbes of central London estate agent Chesterfields, which boasts a long list of celebrity clients. 'He was constantly being staked out by groupies. His neighbours became increasingly fed up with kids camping on the pavements and the press asking questions.'

Paul Bonett of estate agent Bonetts in Brighton gives the example of former Chilean ruler General Pinochet, who was considering living on a private estate in West Sussex around the time his extradition was being debated. 'There was near panic among the neighbours,' he says.

Traditionally an actors' retreat, Brighton's slightly down-at-heel image has taken on a fresh lustre as a new breed of celebrities has moved in. The old guard would have been typified by minor aristocrats, or actors such as Laurence, later Lord, Olivier. These days people are more impressed by the fact that they may rub shoulders - or, perhaps, Sainsbury's trolleys - with Zoë Ball and Fat Boy Slim.

Selling a home with celebrity status may spice up the estate agents' particulars, but it is no substitute for a sound roof and a stable damp course. 'Lord Olivier's former home was on the market some time ago at a price well in excess of the market and I don't think they achieved it,' says Bonett. 'If people are looking to buy a property, they have their financial wits about them.'

Chesterfields' Forbes cites a flat in Coleherne Court, SW5, which the Princess of Wales shared when she was still Diana Spencer. 'It was later bought by a developer who was hoping someone would pay a premium. This was not the case at all, and after some time he ended up selling it at its market value.'

What might make a difference, in Forbes' opinion, is if the celebrity used the services of a well known interior designer or architect.

A smattering of celebrity neighbours, particular in modern, central developments, may stand testament to good building security. If nothing else, this will keep the fans and photographers out.

'Our developments offer a high level of security,' says Angela South, sales and marketing director for Nicholson Estates. 'I don't think other purchasers worry because there are celebrities in the development. In fact, prices are more likely to increase if people believe there are celebrities living there.'

Nicholson was responsible for Century Buildings in Manchester and the company is currently creating 'b central' in Birmingham. Prospective purchasers include corporate high fliers, at least one politician and a number of footballers - from Manchester United in the case of Century Buildings and from Aston Villa at b central.

But developers such as Nicholson Estates and hip London firm Metropolis draw a veil of secrecy over who has actually bought where, for fear of frightening away celebrity clients. You may only know you live next door to a famous face when your eyes meet over the morning milk bottles.

'It's our company policy to be very discreet about famous names,' says David Green, head of sales at Metropolis. When a member of All Saints decided to buy in the company's north- west London school house conversion, the news leaked out and she pulled out of the deal.

'Security is a big thing for a number of celebrities, and life can be difficult if suddenly the world and his wife know where they live,' says Green. Individuals who find they are selling to a celebrity should take note and eschew dinner party hubris.

But the 'added value' a famous face brings to a neighbourhood may be fleeting. Some celebrities are notoriously fickle and may move out as quickly as they move in - assuming they move in at all. Just over two years ago, the Earls Terrace development in Kensington, London, where asking prices start at around £4 million, became the centre of attention when Madonna was photographed being shown round by John Hunter of developer Northacre.

'It was a media frenzy and hard to deny, as both our heads were visible as we entered one of the houses,' he said. 'Although she did not buy, she in fact came back a few months later to rent.' Madonna then went on to purchase a house in Tregunter Road on the Chelsea and Fulham borders. But she sold that property without ever moving in.

Selling your home to a fabulously rich celebrity can be a strange process.

'Very often celebrities are represented by their minders, a house hunter, or an accountant, which can make negotiations quite difficult,' says Peter Rickenberg, managing director of Leslie Marsh & Co, which has offices in Notting Hill and Ladbroke Grove.

But this rarely puts vendors off. 'The only time they feel uncomfortable is if the lead singer or drummer of some rock band wants to move in; they may feel a bit guilty on behalf of the friends and neighbours they leave behind.'

You too can join the blue plaque set
English Heritage, which runs the commemorative blue plaque scheme marking the former homes of famous and historical figures, admits that possession of a plaque does tend to find its way onto the estate agents' blurb.

The scheme is now extending outside London, with plaques being planned for properties in Portsmouth, Southampton, Liverpool and Birmingham. The scheme receives around 100 suggestions for plaques each year. If you think a blue plaque may add cachet to your property when you sell, keep in mind that only a few survive the vetting and research process. This takes about two years, and proposed candidates must have been dead for 20 years.

Less onerous but just as rewarding can be a local investigation, if you have reason to believe your home has a famous association. Older neighbours and historical societies can provide a wealth of information, as can your local library and planning department.

The Land Registry is not obliged to provide information about the previous occupants of your home, but it may do so for a small fee. You need to contact the relevant district registry in writing, stating why you want the information. Keep in mind that not all properties are registered.

webTitle: Now we are defined by designer tat

fields.headline: Now we are defined by designer tat
fields.trailText: Dr Martin Stephen (News, last week) is to be commended not only for his sounding the alarm about the intellectual decline of Britain, but also for pointing out the glaring absurdity of governments, over the past 15 years, which have declared the importance of higher education to Britain's future, yet done everything possible to impede access.
fields.body:
Dr Martin Stephen (News, last week) is to be commended not only for his sounding the alarm about the intellectual decline of Britain, but also for pointing out the glaring absurdity of governments, over the past 15 years, which have declared the importance of higher education to Britain's future, yet done everything possible to impede access.

Higher education should be underwritten by the state. If no benefits accrue from it, then why are we doing it anyway? Or has it become simply a way of keeping young people off the dole queue for just a few more years?

Professor Reynolds of Exeter is right when he says that previous generations had their heroes, but has the cult of the celebrity ever been so predatory? Dr Richard Hoggart puts his finger on it when he speaks of the 'enormous industry devoted to making young people buy...'

This is at the heart of the matter; we have produced a generation of uncritical minds who can be conned into buying any old tat providing it has a fashionable label. If it is endorsed by a grossly overpaid celebrity, so much the better.Young people are taught to see their identity in terms of what they buy, not what they are; this is the legacy of Thatcherism.

Professor Reynolds says that people are reading more books; but what are they reading? Barbara Cartland? How many people have been watching the repeat of Jacob Bronowski's Ascent of Man; and how many watch Neighbours? What hope is there for a country where the biggest-selling newspaper is the Sun?
Chris Waller
Bristol

Dr Martin Stephens attacks the philistine English culture which he feels values celebrity above learning in a away unknown in other countries, including Scotland, where, he states, education is seen as a way out of poverty and where there has always been a respect for learning.

Many of us in Wales can empathise with the Scots. Throughout the nineteenth century nonconformity grew and the resultant chapel-based communities with their concomitant 'British' elementary school system spawned an erudite proletariat in which literacy flourished.

The Sunday schools also contributed greatly to standards of literacy and that helped in the establishment of the University of Wales in the Eighties. The one remaining void was filled by the establishment of a network of secondary schools as the result of the Welsh Intermediate Education Act of 1888. This Act was exclusive to Wales.

In the twentieth century scholarship continued to flourish, especially in the parts of Wales that remained primarily Welsh speaking.
Gareth Williams
Wrexham

fields.headline: Nice girls do get pregnant
fields.trailText: I was shocked to read Margaret Cook's crass comments about adoption (Review, last week). I am adopted myself and I found Dr Cook's musings lurched between saccharine romance (the elderly relative who believed herself the ancestor of a Scottish laird) and the downright offensive.
fields.body:
I was shocked to read Margaret Cook's crass comments about adoption (Review, last week). I am adopted myself and I found Dr Cook's musings lurched between saccharine romance (the elderly relative who believed herself the ancestor of a Scottish laird) and the downright offensive.

Well, I've got news for Dr Cook. 'Nice girls' get pregnant too and, as a compelling Channel 4 series in 1996 showed, are far more likely to experience the 'shame' or family pressure that might push them into putting up their child for adoption than the 'serial murderers, child molesters, drug pushers/criminals' of the doctor's imagination.

What the reader who wrote in needed was practical advice (numbers of helplines etc) - such as that supplied by HT of London. What the reader did not need was Mills and Boon sensationalism.
Cathy Shrank
Aberdeen

fields.headline: Number's up

fields.body:
Oliver Morgan (Business, last week) defined atomic numbers as the number of protons plus neutrons in an atomic nucleus, but this is the mass number. The atomic number, unique to each element, is the number of protons in the nucleus.

Also, the half-life is the time for half the atoms to disintegrate: the products may or may not be stable.
John Scutt
University College
London WC1

Beside the sea

Well, fancy that! Seagulls have set up colonies in Whitby and Bridlington, according to last week's Observer. Amazing! It has obviously escaped the attention of your journalists that Whitby and Bridlington are at the seaside.
John Forder
Dent
Cumbria

Mendes speaks

Once more, for the record: I can categorically state that I have never made any comment publicly, or indeed privately, about Jerry Hall, or about nudity on stage.

My remarks (which were made to a small gathering at the Covent Garden Community Association) were entirely to do with ensuring that the best British stage actors were protected from being occasionally elbowed aside by foreign stars. The rest was journalistic invention.
Sam Mendes
Donmar Warehouse
London WC2

fields.headline: Virgin points
fields.trailText: Nick Cohen in his article 'Branding Branson is a Dangerous Game' made a number of elementary errors in the comments that he published concerning Virgin Atlantic and myself:
fields.body:
Nick Cohen in his article 'Branding Branson is a Dangerous Game' made a number of elementary errors in the comments that he published concerning Virgin Atlantic and myself:

1. Virgin Atlantic does not and never has harshly treated any drivers. Virgin Atlantic does not employ any drivers. The limousine service which employs the drivers for Upper Class passengers is operated by an entirely independent third party who provide similar services to other major airlines operating from both Heathrow and Gatwick.

2. My motive for being involved in the bid to run the National Lottery has always been entirely clear and it is quite simply to ensure that the greatest amount of money raised by the National Lottery goes to good causes. The People's Lottery has absolutely no connection whatsoever with the Virgin Group of Companies, as was implied by Nick Cohen, and nor will they benefit in any way from the award of the lottery licence to The People's Lottery.
Sir Richard Branson
London W8

fields.headline: Zizou top
fields.standfirst: If his team wins the European championship tonight, this immigrant’s son from a Marseille housing estate is set to be his country’s national hero - for a second time in two years. Yet he’s more than just a footballing icon. His is the face of a new, multi-cultural France.

fields.body:
There is a poster currently decorating the walls of many European towns, particularly in France, that shows a rather grey and grim council-type flat. The legend across the image, which promotes Adidas, says simply: 'Everybody comes from somewhere'. The undesirable apartment in the photo was once inhabited by Zinedine Yazid Zidane, or 'Zizou' as he is known in Italy and France, very possibly the finest football player on the planet.

Today Zidane, already a world champion, will attempt to lead France to victory in the final of the European Championship. Having turned 28 just over a week ago, the French midfielder is in his prime and is firmly in the process of establishing his name alongside other world all-time greats such as Puskas, Pele, Cruyff, Platini and Maradona.

A sportsman of uncharacteristic humility, Zidane tends to be embarrassed by those sorts of comparisons. Although hugely ambitious, his drive to get ahead has been tempered by a strong awareness of where he's come from. The bleak poster home was located in La Castellane, a run-down suburb in the Arab quarter of Marseilles, where Zidane lived with his Algerian parents, Smail and Malika, and their three other French-born sons, Jamel, Farid and Nourredine, and sister, Lila. Zidane moved his parents to a sumptuous villa soon after becoming wealthy. Of his father, he once said: 'He has been my guide in life. He has worked hard for very little return, but for him life is still about human relationships rather than money.'

Often described as a no-go area, owing to the fear it inspires in the town's more conservative citizens, La Castellane is really a no-leave district. There are few opportunities for its largely North African-origin population to get out and make their mark. Which is why Zidane enjoys unparalleled cult status in the high-rise blocks that surround the old Mediterranean port.

The footballer acknowledged the support a while back by paying for the clubhouse for a local football side, the Association des Jeunes de la Nouvelle Vague. If his constituency is La Castellane, his rule nevertheless extends right across France. The two goals he scored in the 1998 World Cup final against Brazil guaranteed him a special place in the hearts of his countrymen. That game - in which, to the disgust of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front, France fielded a team from various ethnic backgrounds - also served to usher in a sense of a new multi-cultural France. And at its creative centre was Zidane, the son of an Algerian supermarket worker. After the match, his image was projected on to the Arc de Triomphe with the message: 'Merci Zizou.'

But it nearly didn't happen like that. Zidane was sent off in the qualifying rounds of France 98 for stamping on the captain of the Saudi Arabian team. Doubters immediately turned to that old saw about being able to take the boy out of the ghetto but not the ghetto out of the boy.

It was a curious criticism because very often Zidane had been accused of appearing too cold and controlled. In fact, Zidane has long possessed an unlikely combination of street-toughness and a Zen-like calm. Jean Varraud, the Cannes scout who first spotted Zizou playing for his boys club, Septemes, recalls the promising teenager quietly walking across the pitch to head-butt an opponent.

'I immediately saw this boy would become a great player,' recalls Varraud. 'He had an exceptional speed of foot that I've never seen before or since. Also he had this warrior side that you find in kids from underprivileged neighbourhoods. He was hungry.'

One story has it that a director at Cannes was furious with Varraud for bringing the 16-year-old Zidane to the club. 'What are you thinking of?' he is supposed to have asked. 'Putting an Arab in the team? Are you mad?' But it was another Cannes director, Jean-Claude Elineau, who invited the youngster to leave the dormitory he shared with 20 other trainees and to come and stay with him and his family. Zidane later said that it was living with the Elineaus that he 'found equilibrium'.

In school, according to his mother, he had been 'a bit distracted'. He practised judo and messed around on a skateboard but football was always his obsession. He used to watch games on TV and felt a magical exhilaration. 'I had an impression of another world, a world of dreams. I couldn't imagine one day it would be mine.'

At Cannes he met his wife, Véronique, a dancer. Together now for more than 10 years, they have two boys, Enzo and Luca, names that have not entirely pleased the more militant Muslims among the player's hometown fans (Zidane see himself as a Muslim but does not practise the faith).

A French sports journalist who remembers Zidane at Cannes describes him then as being 'very lean but with more hair'. A tall, well-built man today, with noble poise and handsomely genial features, Zidane is no friend of the over-head camera. From above, you can see the monkish bald patch that adds years to the already mature-looking man on view from the pitch. In an age of saturation marketing and total image, Zidane's alopecia may possibly have meant that he is lagging behind in the superstar stakes in comparison to, say, the tonsorially blessed (if shaven) David Beckham.

Not that he would be concerned with such matters. Rather he sees himself, in the words of one French journalist who knows him, as a 'craftsman of football'. Certainly, while learning his trade at Cannes, he would not even have hallucinated thoughts of fame and riches. He was overjoyed to receive a £500 bonus on making his first-team debut one month short of his seventeenth birthday in 1989. He immediately sent the money to his parents. A year later he was given a red Renault Clio by the Cannes president and doubtless confusing it for a sports car, spent his leisure hours cruising up and down the Croisette.

From Cannes he was transferred to Bordeaux in 1992 and made his debut for France two years later. He scored twice in that game and went on to be voted the young French player of the year. In 1996 it was time to move again, but this time abroad to Italy.

Leaving aside its sunny climate and glorious belle époque architecture, Marseilles is in many ways reminiscent of English port towns like Liverpool or Newcastle. It has the same kind of provincial independence and bullish identity. So when the young man from La Castellane went to join Juventus in the Alpine city of Turin, he took a friend from home with him.

The Geordie Paul Gascoigne did a similar thing when he left England for Lazio in Rome. The difference being that Zidane's friend was a sensible chap called Malek, while Gazza was accompanied by the perpetually thirsty Jimmy Five Bellies. It was one of many smart decisions that has enabled Zidane, who was endowed with similar skills to Gascoigne, to go on to become peerless while the Englishman has remained but one of a number of gifted players who never fulfilled their potential.

Again, it was not an easy path for Zidane. When he joined up with Juve, he had just finished playing for France in Euro 96, a tournament that was for him a bitter personal disappointment, not least because he was carrying an injury. Having seen Zidane's lacklustre performances, Gianni Agnelli, the legendary president of Juve, expressed the idea that perhaps he had granted funds (what turned out to be a bargain £3.5 million) for the wrong player. But Michel Platini, the sublime French midfield artist who played for Juve in the Eighties, was quick to reassure Agnelli that he had not made a mistake, as would soon become apparent.

Zidane has won two Serie A titles with Juventus as well as losing twice in the final of the European Champions League Cup. His team-mate, the irrepressible Dutchman, Edgar Davids, has said of Zizou: 'He is the footballer I admire most.'

At the 1998 World Cup, Cesare Maldini, the manager of the Italian team, said: 'I would give up five players to have Zizou in my squad.' Footballers throughout the game seem to respect Zidane because while he is an individual who can do just about anything with a ball, he is also an out-and-out team player and one who does not freeze on the big occasion. In 1998 he was voted European and World Footballer of the Year. And he has improved since then. Zidane attributes much of his progress to playing in Italy. He singles out the influence of Piero Ventrone, the Juventus fitness trainer, for dramatically increasing his explosive power (the use of body-building drugs has put Juve under scrutiny by the football authorities in recent years).

Yet there are signs that he may leave Italy soon. His wife is said not to like Turin and there has been talk of a move to Spain or even back to France. 'My heart beats for Olympic Marseille,' he has said, referring to the club he supported as a boy.

But with the way he has played for France in the past few weeks, it's unlikely that Juve would let him go or that Marseilles could afford him. He seems to have everything. An immense strength is allied to the most delicate touch. Looking at his upper body you would never guess at the swift subtlety expressed below the knees. He can run with the ball but is also able to make pinpoint long and short passes without breaking stride. And he scores unforgettable goals.

The whole package has left him indispensable to France. 'If he is not there,' said Aime Jacquet, the French manager during the World Cup, 'the team is not the same.'

One of the ways that it is not the same is that it also tends not to include Zidane's great friend Christophe Dugarry. According to observers of the French national side, Zidane's influence rivals that of Didier Deschamps, the captain, and it said that if they do not rate a player, he does not make it into the team. Equally, many feel that Dugarry would not have made it into the World Cup squad in 98 without the bond he has formed with Zidane.

Coming into the tournament, some wondered if Zidane, who admits to an almost poetic sensitivity, might have been adversely affected by the manner in which Juve needlessly lost the Italian championship on the last day. He returned to Marseilles for a while to recharge his batteries and to attempt to forget the Italian campaign. 'I tried to make myself feel better by telling myself that soccer is just a sport,' he said. 'However, this technique did not work.'

Unusually for a professional footballer, Zidane is still boyishly in love with the game. Following a Juventus fixture on Sunday afternoons the whole team goes to a restaurant in Turin to unwind together. In Italy the the evening match is televised. As the rest of the players chat, Zidane will sit staring at the TV, the kid from La Castellane entranced by a game that no one else can play as well as him.

Zinedine Yazid Zidane

AKA: Zizou

DoB: 23 June 1972 (Marseille)

Family: Married to Véronique (two sons - Enzo, 6, and Luca, 3)

Clubs: Cannes, Bordeaux, Juventus

Honours: Italian league champion (1997, 1998); European Super Cup (1997); Intercontinental Cup (1997); World Cup (1998)

Internationals: 55 (15 goals)

fields.headline: God and politics
fields.trailText: You ask 'why this new concern with religion' by Blair and Hague (Focus, last week)?  A key to the answer is this: politicians appeal to God and religious gurus not only as a mirror for their prejudices (and delusions of grandeur) but on the same basis that they try to justify their policies by appeals to common sense, democracy, freedom, human nature, economic efficiency, truth, reason etc.
fields.body:
You ask 'why this new concern with religion' by Blair and Hague (Focus, last week)? A key to the answer is this: politicians appeal to God and religious gurus not only as a mirror for their prejudices (and delusions of grandeur) but on the same basis that they try to justify their policies by appeals to common sense, democracy, freedom, human nature, economic efficiency, truth, reason etc.

In so doing, they show neither care nor recognition that the meaning of these terms are always philosophically/intellectually contested, and are revisable (in the light of new experience and better reasoning). Shamelessly, whether their own conception is backed by sound thinking doesn't worry them - since they know such appeals will win the majority votes of an electorate unschooled in discerning better from worse views.

Indeed, to paraphrase HL Mencken, no one under capitalism goes short of approval by under-estimating human possibilities and intelligence.
David Rodway
London SW10

Blair's bombs

What part of Tony Blair's much-vaunted Christianity ordained his dropping of bombs on Serbia last summer, and the sanctions that are killing children in Iraq now?
CV Jones
Sutton
