webTitle: Lord Lucan's last secret goes to the grave among gorillas

fields.headline: Lord Lucan's last secret goes to the grave among gorillas
fields.trailText: The death of John Aspinall means that we have lost the last, best chance of finding out what happened to Lord Lucan after he murdered his children's nanny, Sandra Rivett, in November 1974. Because Lucan was never found and there was no trial, the events of that night remain murky. But I have always believed that John Aspinall unwittingly admitted to me that he'd seen Lord Lucan after the murder - possibly for some considerable time after the murder.
fields.body:
The death of John Aspinall means that we have lost the last, best chance of finding out what happened to Lord Lucan after he murdered his children's nanny, Sandra Rivett, in November 1974. Because Lucan was never found and there was no trial, the events of that night remain murky. But I have always believed that John Aspinall unwittingly admitted to me that he'd seen Lord Lucan after the murder - possibly for some considerable time after the murder.

Aspinall and Lucan were friends - in fact Lucan was a regular at Aspinall's Clermont Club and had dinner there on the fatal night. Lucan then supposedly went back to his old house in Belgravia, intending to murder his estranged wife so that he could get custody of the children, but - in the darkness of the basement - murdered the nanny by mistake. His car was later found abandoned at Newhaven, and Lucan apparently vanished off the face of the earth - or down to the bottom of the English Channel as his friends maintained.

Aspinall, Sir James Goldsmith, and the whole Lucan circle were consistent in saying that they believed Lucan died that night by his own hand. Aspinall's version to me in an interview for the Independent on Sunday in l990 was the usual: 'He was very skilled at motor-boat racing, and I think he had a boat there at Newhaven, where his car was found, and I think he jumped into one of his little motor boats, went out to sea, put a big weight round his body and jumped overboard. And scuttled the boat. That's what happened.'

However, I believe that, in the course of that same interview, Aspinall let his guard drop for a moment and unwittingly gave the lie to his own story. It was an unusual interview - mainly because it started with Aspinall being almost killed by his own elephants. I'd driven down to Howletts with the photographer and the photographer was worried about the fading light (it was midwinter) and said could we do the photographs immediately?

So Aspinall led us out to the elephant enclosure where he wanted to be photographed - even though the keeper warned him that one of the old cows, Masa, was behaving oddly. Aspinall went straight over to Masa and petted her and posed between her legs - then she suddenly knocked him to the ground and started rolling him around like a football.

Every time he tried to get to his feet, Masa or one of the other elephants would knock him down again and bat him between them. This went on for eight or 10 minutes, until the keepers eventually managed to distract the elephants long enough for him to escape. He was bleeding profusely from cuts to his knees and face - he was 64 and had already suffered two strokes - and severely shaken. We drove him back to the house. His wife wanted to call the doctor but of course he would not allow it: he insisted he would do the interview as soon as he'd been bandaged.

And then I asked about Lord Lucan. Aspinall was annoyed, perhaps even rather hurt - 'You're like every other journalist: all you want to talk about is Lucan.' But anyway, then we did talk about Lucan and he gave the usual suicide version quoted above. But I was banging on about how could he call someone a friend when he was a murderer - didn't this alter his feelings about Lucan at all? And then he made what I believe was his crucial slip.

He said: 'Well, I always think that if someone who has been a great friend is then in a terrible position, you rather feel more warmly towards him because that's when you're needed. fields.headline: Migrant workers like 'slaves'
fields.trailText: The Dover immigrant tragedy has overshadowed another not entirely unrelated horror story: the revelation that illegal migrant workers are being employed under the gang labour system in exploitative conditions to supply vegetables to some major supermarket chains.
fields.body:
The Dover immigrant tragedy has overshadowed another not entirely unrelated horror story: the revelation that illegal migrant workers are being employed under the gang labour system in exploitative conditions to supply vegetables to some major supermarket chains.

The trafficking of people is not merely criminal profiteering in the evasion of immigration controls, it is effectively a rebirth of the slave trade since many illicit migrant workers are employed in exploitative conditions and for obvious reasons are unlikely to complain.

The problem requires more than the review of the rules on asylum seekers that Nick Hardwick advocates. It also requires the enforcement of employment legislation, particularly minimum wage and health and safety regulations so that migrant workers are not exploited or used as a pool of cheap labour if immigration rules are relaxed to tackle labour shortages.
Andrew Hudson
London E10

fields.headline: Be fat, be happy
fields.standfirst: And be a good citizen, too
fields.trailText: James Dewey Watson doesn't paddle in the shallow end of scientific endeavour. In 1953, he shared in the celebrated discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA. Now, fresh from successfully nursing through the human genome project, he may have stumbled on an even greater discovery - the secret of what makes people happy.
fields.body:
James Dewey Watson doesn't paddle in the shallow end of scientific endeavour. In 1953, he shared in the celebrated discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA. Now, fresh from successfully nursing through the human genome project, he may have stumbled on an even greater discovery - the secret of what makes people happy.

It turns out not to be fame or fortune - we knew that - or the pay-off for a secure childhood or even the collective ecstasy experienced by football supporters when the final whistle blows on a win for their side. Neither can we achieve it through religious devotion, artistic endeavour or as the earthly reward for being considerate to others. The answer is banally simple: the fatter you are, the more happy-making chemicals you store in your body and, an added bonus, the sexier you feel.

So far, his arguments lack the rigour of his earlier genetic work, but Watson claims that America's falling crime rate is linked to the rise in obesity and that Calista Flockhart has a miserable, thin soul. He hopes to provide a full proof later in the year. Meanwhile, citizens made miserable by worries about rising crime and negative images of fatness can take immediate action. Get stuck into that Sunday roast and bring down the UK crime rate.

webTitle: Money to make the world go around

fields.headline: Money to make the world go around
fields.standfirst: How can I plan for the future when I am overseas, Lizzie Williams asks  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: How can I plan for the future when I am overseas, Lizzie Williams asks Helen Pridham
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Lizzie Williams
Age: 31
Lives in: Cape Town, South Africa
Occupation: Hotel manager
Earns: £3,600
Mortgage: £65,000
Debts: Credit card £2,000, outstanding service charge £1,400
Investments: With-profits endowment, 200 Halifax shares
Pension: Has made no payment to personal pension since 1995
Aims: To sort out her UK financial affairs

Lizzie Williams left the UK to go travelling in March 1995 and never returned - at least not to live. She now works in South Africa as a hotel manager and that is where she intends to stay for the foreseeable future.

She is currently back in London for a couple of months to sort out her financial affairs and sell her flat, which is on the market. She has had the property in Bethnal Green in London since 1988, when she bought it for £65,000 with a 100 per cent endowment mortgage.

She is hoping the flat will fetch between £115,000 and £120,000. After paying off her mortgage, fees and her debts, she would like to invest the remainder here before she leaves.

She is prepared to tie up the money for five years but then wants it to be accessible in case she decides to return to the UK and wants to buy another property.

She is not sure what her options are as a non-taxpayer and is looking for an investment that she can leave here without having to manage it.

She would also like to have some money available in a bank account, say £2,500-£5,000, in case she decides to continue her travels.

After selling her property, she is wondering what to do about her mortgage endowment policy with Legal & General. She is prepared to keep up the £78 per month premium payments for the full term, but is not sure whether it is worthwhile now that she has seen the bad press endowments have been receiving.

She also has a personal pension with Legal & General, which was started when she opted out of Serps in 1988. Her National Insurance contribution rebates were paid into the plan until she left the UK in 1995. She is curious to know what has happened to this plan.

She is also concerned about making more provision for her retirement since she has no pension scheme in South Africa.

She says: 'I have been advised that I cannot start a pension here [UK] as a non-taxpayer. Is this correct?'

She is interested in her tax status generally, and would like to know what would happen if she returned to the UK to work.

She says: 'I don't expect to be eligible for any [tax] rebate for my last year of work in 1995 as it was so long ago, but would like to know where I stand, considering I quite literally disappeared.'

Her only other remaining financial interest in the UK is 200 Halifax shares which she wonders whether to keep.

In South Africa her wages are more than adequate to maintain her standard of living and her accommodation and bills are paid for.

Adviser 1: Tony Shah
Providing Lizzie has not entered the UK on visits of more than 183 days in a tax year or 90 days on average, she will be regarded as non-resident for tax purposes and does not need to pay UK tax on assets held abroad. As she left the UK five years ago, she will be able to sell her UK property without paying capital gains tax.

The net proceeds from the sale of the flat should be invested offshore so she can benefit from the funds growing free of tax. There are many offshore investments available from UK institutions, but she needs to consider several factors, such as the term of the investment.

Her attitude to risk is another consideration. Does she want to invest in cautious funds that can reduce volatility but also limit returns, such as with-profits funds, or is she prepared to invest in stock markets?

When Lizzie returns to the UK, she will become liable for UK tax again on a worldwide basis. So if she wants to use the proceeds of her investment bond for home purchase, she should make sure she sells it beforehand rather than waiting until the tax year in which she returns.

She should keep her Legal & General endowment going as the surrender value will be poor.

It is true that she cannot take out a UK pension while living away, and nor can she do much with her Serps pension. She will need to sort all that out on her return.

 Tony Shah works for financial adviser Towry Law.

Advisor 2: Robert Rackcliffe
For the money Lizzie raises from the sale of her flat, we would normally consider offshore investments, where interest can be paid gross without deduction of tax.

There are a number of excellent offshore investment bonds designed to run for at least four or five years but which allow the investor to withdraw up to 80 per cent of capital without penalty. This should provide Lizzie with the access she needs should she return to the UK and want to buy another property.

As an investment bond does not produce any interest, it would not need to be declared for income tax purposes in South Africa. Another advantage of an offshore bond is that it can be considered similar to an offshore pension fund. If Lizzie returned to the UK, she would have the option of taking withdrawals from the investment as income.

If Lizzie invested £40,000 in an offshore investment bond, she could place the balance, say £5,000, in an offshore high-interest current account.

Her existing pension with Legal & General should remain invested to provide benefits at Lizzie's normal retirement age. We would recommend that she continue with her endowment policy, as 25-year maturing policies are still yielding excellent returns and surrender values are generally poor mid-term.

 Robert Rackliffe works for financial adviser Jackson Battern .

 Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Robbed on a jet, but my claim crashed

fields.headline: Robbed on a jet, but my claim crashed
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
Returning home from a safari in Kenya, we found that a mini-disc player worth £220 had been stolen from our luggage while it was in the airline's care. But the company told me that carriers are exempt from liability for bags in aircraft holds.

A claim on our travel insurance with Royal & Sun Alliance was rejected as our baggage was 'not in our control' when the theft took place. With the holiday booking, I had free insurance from Inter Group, which said we were not covered for 'theft of money or valuables while left in the luggage in the custody of the carriers'.

Can it be true that, when we hand over our luggage to the airlines, we are totally at their mercy?
AH London

 Under the Warsaw Convention, airlines are respon sible for your luggage, but the liability is so minimal that it is not worth fighting for your rights for a lightweight article unless you want to make a point of principle. The maximum airlines have to pay is some £13 for every kilo the items weigh, and often they try to argue their way out of even that tiny liability.

Your other two policies highlight the significance of small print. Inter Group says your claim failed because you had put a valuable item into the hold, and it would have paid up if a more ordinary item had been taken.

Royal & Sun Alliance says its policy excludes valuables when they are outside your control because they are out of your sight. If something exceedingly valuable was stolen, even from an overhead locker, it would be regarded as outside your control.

You can claim under the personal possession or all-risks section of your house policy because it insures your belongings while they are away from home. Oddly, Royal & Sun Alliance's all-risks cover treats valuables in the hold as though they are still within your control.

Windfall advice: Rotten apple?
I had a Standard Life with-profits policy which matured last November. I reinvested £10,000 of the proceeds with the same company on the advice of my independent financial adviser. This was done with the possibility of Standard Life becoming a public company and there being a windfall.

The new investment is a Capital Investment Bond. Not having received voting forms on the proposed conversion, I rang Standard Life only to find that I do not have voting rights, nor do I qualify for a windfall.

My adviser tells me no alternative Standard Life investment was available through him. Is he responsible for having given this bad advice?
MV Ambleside

 Although rumours had been circulating, Standard Life's first public statement about the vote, which threw out demutalisation last week, was not issued until 9 February. When you reinvested, your adviser should have explained his reasons for choosing that particular investment. If he did quote possible demutualisation, he has fallen down on the job because unit-linked investments do not qualify for windfalls and he should know that.

His excuse that you could not buy any other Standard Life product through him is nonsense. Anyway if, for any reason, he could not sell you the product he believed best, he should have said so.

If demutualisation was discussed when you reinvested, you should contact someone more senior in the company, clearly stating that you want to make a formal complaint.

Tax on joint cash: How to pay less
My partner and I have several joint savings accounts. I pay basic-rate tax and she pays at the 10 per cent rate, reclaiming tax overpaid on the interest. The Inland Revenue suggests that half the interest on joint accounts is deemed to belong to my partner, but I feel sure I have read that assets, and interest, can be split other than 50/50 where this is tax- efficient. Is this right? RS Oldham

 The Revenue assumes all joint accounts are split equally, and you cannot ask to be taxed in unequal shares just to avoid tax while continuing to own half each.

But you can decide to own the money in unbalanced proportions. Tell your tax office in writing how much belongs to each, and you will be taxed accordingly.

Bank blunder: A fair offer?
Abbey National has admitted making a mistake on my mortgage repayments and offered what it calls an 'amicable' settlement. When interest rates went up in 1988, the bank failed to increase my payments. Instead, without informing me, it extended the loan by 10 years, to beyond my retirement. They are offering £2,405 in return. Is this fair? MW Purley

 The bank claims that over 12 years you underpaid £5,976, on which you could have earned £1,595 interest in a savings account.

But this ignores the fact that you did not know you were underpaying, so had no reason to put the money aside.

Abbey National says it has calculated the compensation according to the Banking Ombudsman's formula. But this is just the first offer, and it does not prevent you checking with the ombudsman whether he thinks it is fair. Telephone 020 7404 9944. You do not need to pay a solicitor to contact an ombudsman on your behalf.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: The danger of too much knowledge

fields.headline: The danger of too much knowledge
fields.trailText: The mapping of the human genome has been greeted as a milestone in man's knowledge of himself. Unfortunately, it could also be a milestone in insurance companies' knowledge of their customers.
fields.body:
The mapping of the human genome has been greeted as a milestone in man's knowledge of himself. Unfortunately, it could also be a milestone in insurance companies' knowledge of their customers.

In time, scientists believe their new understanding of the genetic code will enable them to cure and prevent diseases. But in the meantime, insurers will be able to use the information to identify which applicants are most likely to develop a serious or life threatening illness. Although insurers are not allowed to ask applicants to undergo genetic tests, they are permitted to ask for the results of any tests applicants may already have had for seven conditions, including familial Alzheimer's disease, Huntingdon's and hereditary breast cancer.

The Association of British Insurers claims that applicants who test positive will not necessarily be turned down. However, the Lancet reported earlier this year that women at risk of developing breast cancer had refused genetic testing for fear of being refused insurance. And last week a high-profile firm of independent financial advisers recommended that anyone requiring life insurance buy it now before it is too late.

The ABI argues that its members have to assess the risk of insuring a person using all available information. But so much information is on hand now that insurers have moved away from the original idea of insurance to cherry-picking those who present least risk.

Standard Life and Virgin Direct have said they will not take the results of any genetic tests into account. Lets hope other insurers are wise enough to follow.

webTitle: Tories bank on Labour's lost love

fields.headline: Tories bank on Labour's lost love
fields.trailText: You do not have to be a member of the Conservative party to agree with some of their policies. Someone in the party is doing a nice line in spotting weaknesses in Government measures and then suggesting a popular alternative.
fields.body:
You do not have to be a member of the Conservative party to agree with some of their policies. Someone in the party is doing a nice line in spotting weaknesses in Government measures and then suggesting a popular alternative.

Giving pensioners a handsome increase rather than spreading the cash on free TV licences and winter fuel payments brought one recent publicity coup. They also plan to reform IR35 - the new tax regime under which many self-employed people now find themselves taxed as employees.

Another area is the Tory plan on annuities. 'The Conservative Party is committed to scrapping this 75-year rule on taking office,' said shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo last month.

In a move that Labour may be tempted to copy, the Conservatives would end the current rule under which pensioners with private pension funds have to convert the money into annuities by their 75th birthday. Under the new proposal, they could keep the fund invested as long as they wanted. This could be a popular measure with better-off pensioners - particularly now that annuity rates are low.

The Tories are coming out with new bits of policy almost every week. Last week, it was the suggestion that owners of private medical insurance plans should get tax relief. At the same time, the party is working on its new manifesto, which is due to be put to the party conference in Bournemouth in early October.

The manifesto will almost undoubtedly include the new policy declarations, which have come mainly from Portillo and shadow Social Security secretary David 'Two Brains' Willetts.

Willetts was behind the announcements on the proposed rises in the basic state pension. He is also trying to strengthen the Tories' appeal to women - announcing, for example, that the Working Families Tax Credit would be paid to the carer, rather than the earner.

Highly controversial, however, is the plan to 'require lone parents of secondary-school-age children to be actively seeking work'. The Tories would be very tough on some benefit claimants. For claimants who need money for emergencies and capital costs, such as new shoes or new cookers, spending would be cut by about a sixth.

The Tories also guarantee that 'at the end of the Parliament, the next Conservative government will take a smaller share of the nation's income in tax than at the beginning'.

fields.headline: Liberal Democrats steal opposition thunder
fields.trailText: In the rather unlikely event that they win the next election, the Liberal Democrats would put an extra penny on tax to go towards education, set a 50 per cent tax rate on earnings over £100,000 and introduce a compulsory second pension.
fields.body:
In the rather unlikely event that they win the next election, the Liberal Democrats would put an extra penny on tax to go towards education, set a 50 per cent tax rate on earnings over £100,000 and introduce a compulsory second pension.

These policies are likely to form the basis of their manifesto when it is debated and adopted at the party conference in September.

With their 47 MPs, the Liberal Democrats have sometimes made a better job of opposition over the past three years than the Conservatives.

This year they produced an alternative budget, 'putting hospitals, schools and pensions before tax cuts', according to leader Charles Kennedy. Many of their proposals have a green tinge - their plan to abolish road tax for the most efficient cars, for instance, and the proposal to 'create 10,000 extra affordable homes to rent each year, paid for by ending the 50 per cent council tax discount on second homes'.

This proposal is now being considered by the Government - an indication of the most likely role that the Liberal Democrats will play, influencing policy rather than implementing it.

But this manifesto could be particularly important. If, as many suspect, Labour returns to power with a reduced majority, the Lib Dems could find themselves closer to the fulcrum of power.

Despite their rather limited resources, they have won respect for their ability to challenge Labour policy and actions in many areas. So, for example, the Liberal Democrats have attacked 'greedy and socially irresponsible' banks for closing down branches, and have called on the Government to take stronger action against Barclays and others. And it is their social security spokesman, Steve Webb, who continues to highlight the issue of child poverty. He backs the 50 per cent tax rate as a way to channel more help to poor families.

webTitle: Universal bank with benefits for those on the fringe

fields.headline: Universal bank with benefits for those on the fringe
fields.trailText: The announcement last week of the planned Universal Bank - run by the country's 18,000 post offices - is a serious step towards helping people on the social and financial fringes of society. An estimated 3.5 million adults with no bank account should be able to open accounts here.
fields.body:
The announcement last week of the planned Universal Bank - run by the country's 18,000 post offices - is a serious step towards helping people on the social and financial fringes of society. An estimated 3.5 million adults with no bank account should be able to open accounts here.

But the Post Office has yet to discover what funding and assistance it will get from Government and private banks. It expects to have a pilot scheme in place 'this time next year'.

The account will be basic - money in and out. It hopes to let customers set up direct debits, which should enable them to save money on certain bills. But since there will be no overdraft facilities the bank will not make any payments that causes the account to go into the red.

It also hopes to offer a cashpoint card, and may offer a cheque book but, again, will not honour cheques that cause the customer to get into debt.

But there is still a long way to go on tackling social exclusion. Many benefits claimants are excluded by the way the system works: offices often insist on dealing by telephone, but it can take fully 25 attempts to get beyond the engaged tone.

webTitle: Vote-hungry parties queue up to woo the Preston Pensioner

fields.headline: Vote-hungry parties queue up to woo the Preston Pensioner
fields.trailText: In 1992, the election was said to have been won for the Tories by the votes of Basildon Man - the Home Counties male who got an attack of nerves at the prospect of Neil Kinnock running the country.
fields.body:
In 1992, the election was said to have been won for the Tories by the votes of Basildon Man - the Home Counties male who got an attack of nerves at the prospect of Neil Kinnock running the country.

In 1997, Worcester Woman is said to have done the trick for Labour. In 2001 or 2002, it could be the Preston Pensioner - as 'grey power' takes hold and 11 million retired people cast their votes according to the policies on offer, rather than sticking to old voting habits. One in five voters is now a pensioner - a big enough proportion to affect the next election.

The main three parties are now courting the Preston Pensioner. Labour has realised that it made a major error by announcing an increase in the basic state pension of just 75p a week. The Tories latched onto this issue, winning headlines through their plan to give pensioner households rises of between £5.50 and £10.

Liberal Democrat Shadow Chancellor Matthew Taylor also made his contribution: 'Instead of a miserly 75p a week, we would add at least £2 to every state pension, rising to £5 for over-75s and £6.75 for over-80s.' As it happens, the Government was also looking at rises which could amount to £5 per person when you include the inflation uprating and an extra £2-£3 which the Chancellor had said may be added on to the basic state pension.

Confused by who exactly is saying what and whether they are saying different things or all really promising the same? Don't worry. You will be even more confused by the time the election comes along. On this one issue, they are making very similar pledges.

The next policy landmark is when the Government unveils its white paper on long-term care for the elderly. The parties cannot afford a bad impression on this emotive subject with an election due within 22 months.

fields.headline: Don't say I told you...
fields.standfirst: Jay Rayner spreads the word on Shropshire's best-kept secret
fields.trailText: Jay Rayner spreads the word on Shropshire's best-kept secret
fields.body:
There is a tendency among London-based critics to go about discovering things outside the capital which, like tribes in the Amazon, are hardly crying out for the attention. Indigenous tribes don't need to be discovered because they already know they are there. Likewise, a restaurant out in the wilds may be a rare find to the critic, but its hardly news to the locals. For them the only thing a good write up does is make it harder to get a table.

All of which is by way of an apology to the good people of Shropshire. Because, if there is any justice at all, people should flock from far and wide to the Hundred House in the village of Norton. It is tucked away in the decidedly unmanicured Severn Valley which, on the hottest day of the year, took on a curious resemblance to the Lot region of France. That similarity continued inside the pub itself, a rambling building dating partly from the 14th century. Then again it may have been the heat; sunshine does curious things to the English.

The first indication of the kind of place this is sits in the middle of each table: a bowl of fresh herbs - sage and lemon balm, mint and rosemary and dill - awaits you, alongside a message inviting you to add whatever you like to your meal. This is more a declaration of intent by the Phillips family, whose place this is, than anything else. The foliage comes from an extra-ordinary herb garden out the back, tended by Sylvia Phillips, and every dish is filled with so much of the stuff by the chef, her son Stuart, that you hardly need muck about with it yourself. It does, however, make a point: that this is a restaurant where sourcing of ingredients matter.

On Sunday lunchtimes there is a set-price menu which is a complete steal at £16.95 for three courses and £13.95 for two - particularly as portions are so generous that a third course is more a challenge than an option. A starter of melon, cherries and mint with orange and lemon sorbet was just the thing for a hot day. It was sweet and sharp and refreshing and the ballast of fresh mint gave it an aromatic lift.

A Greek salad may look incongruous out in Shropshire, but it is no more so than in London. It was a fine assembly of feta, cucumber, olives and olive oil and came with a great crusty chunk of foccacia to soak up the slick of juices. My marinière of clams and mussels - all from Loch Fynne - also passed muster. It was heavily spiked with fresh chives and dill and the liquor was an expert brew of wine and cream and garlic. Solid slices of a freshly baked and seed bread were quickly dispatched in soaking it up. Granted, these aren't hugely original dishes but they were well executed

For my main course I chose the confit of Hereford duck legs with a tomato and chorizo salad on a white-bean purée. This is clearly a bit of a multi-lingual dish: the meat from nearby, confited in the French style with the chorizo from Spain. Still, the combination of bold flavours worked, thanks to the calming presence of the beans. But what was most striking was the size of it: it was enormous, added to by frankly redundant side dishes groaning with vegetables. Perhaps this is the Hundred House reminding you that, at heart, it is still a pub and in pubs main courses come with lots of vegetables. Side dishes piled up around us promised only massive amounts of left-overs. They also provided the one weak point: a couple of platefuls of over-salted mash.

That said, the dishes they were meant to accompany were a huge pleasure. Carefully poached shoulder of lamb came with a delicate caper cream sauce. Roast loin of pork came with a tangy lemon-and-apricot stuffing and perfectly crispy crackling. For pudding we three shared a couple of strawberry and peach pavlovas, more because they were there than because we needed them - nobody 'needs' a pavlova.

The bill for three without wine - it was too hot - came to just £51. The carte is more expensive, but even with a bottle chosen from the sensibly priced list it would be hard to break the £70 mark. Afterwards, we walked through the aisles of Sylvia's remarkable herb garden and sniffed the air heavy with the perfume of the lunch just eaten. Frankly, it doesn't get much better than that.

 The Hundred House Hotel, Bridgnorth Road, Norton, near Shifnal, Telford, Shropshire (01952 730 353). Sunday lunch, including wine and service, costs around £55. Jay Rayner can be contacted at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Five of the best...
fields.standfirst: ... places to dig up perfect potatoes. By Sue Webster
fields.trailText: ... places to dig up perfect potatoes. By Sue Webster
fields.body:
People are surprisingly passionate about potatoes. The merest mention of them to my (American) hairdresser brought forth a eulogy, not for the Idaho potato, which is famous in its homeland and even forms the logo of a posh restaurant in north London (Idaho, 13 North Hill, London N6, 020 8341 6633), but for the Ukon Gold. And while the Idaho is so firmly wedded to its native soil that it refuses to produce anything of substance elsewhere, the Ukon Gold is occasionally available in this country.

Alan Wilson, agronomist for Waitrose and author of The Story of the Potato , grows them in his garden. 'It's a beautiful, round, yellow, buttery potato,' he says. So when will they be for sale in his own supermarket? This is a good question, apparently, and one which may have a positive outcome if enough people ask for it at a two-day public potato event to be held in conjunction with the HDRA - The Organic Association on 7 and 8 October (at Ryton Organic Gardens, Coventry, 01203 303 517). To be fair, Waitrose has pioneered the commercialisation of old-fashioned, threatened potato varieties, without which they would face de-listing from the UK and European seed catalogues. Right now in its stores you should be able to buy Kestrel, Duke of York, Carlingford and Red King Edward, which is a variety successfully rescued by the campaign.

If it's a talking point that you're looking for, then Sainsbury's will offer the Blue Congo potato from Finland in October (when all maincrop, as opposed to new or early potato varieties, become available). It is said to make a 'lovely purple mash', which will probably appeal to customers already hooked on Terra blue potato crisps.

Would it be cynical to wonder whether blue crisps are the ones always left over at parties? No matter, for there is one issue that is infinitely more important than novel varieties. The conventional potato, harmless as it may seem, is doused with an average of seven applications of fungicide, two applications of herbicide and three applications of insecticide before it reaches a saleable stage of development. Most of the residue ends up under the skin, which is enough to make you think three times before ordering those yummy potato skins with sour cream.

Jane Edwards of Newfarm Organics, Soulby Lane, Wrangle, Boston (01205 870 500) is one of many organic potato growers which maintains that customers remark on the improved flavour of tubers grown in this way. Though Newfarm supplies a range of vegetables to organic wholesalers, and several box schemes, locals drive up to the farm in the autumn to pick up whole sacks (25kg) of the potatoes for £8 to £10. Of course, the varieties cultivated are chosen for their resistance to slugs and disease - the red-skinned Desiree and the white Sante, for example. 'Those Pink Fir Apples are wonderful,' Edwards says of the knobbly root favoured by the chattering classes, 'but they're such higgledy-piggledy little things, they need lifting by hand and they're so difficult to wash'.

Admittedly, part of the wonder of farm-bought potatoes is their freshness. To find a retailer in your area, consult The Organic Directory 2000-2001 (£7.95, co-published by Green Books and The Soil Association; orderline 01803 863 260).

Finally, don't forget the sweet potato, which is what Columbus originally discovered in the West Indies, rather than the white potato, as many people assume. At the new Portrait Restaurant in the National Portrait Gallery, St Martin's Place, London W1 (020 7312 2490), chef Kerwin Browne transforms this largely disdained vegetable by mixing it with pineapple, coriander and chopped chillies, then macerating it while warm in a reduction of lime juice, sugar and chilli. It is served as a potato salad with scallops, but is such a wake-up call to your taste buds that I could eat a plateful on its own.

Admittedly, part of the wonder of farm-bought potatoes is their freshness. To find a retailer in your area, consult The Organic Directory 2000-2001 (£7.95, co-published by Green Books and The Soil Association; orderline 01803 863 260). Finally, don't forget the sweet potato, which is what Columbus originally discovered in the West Indies, rather than the white potato, as many people assume. At the new Portrait Restaurant in the National Portrait Gallery, St Martin's Place, London W1 (020 7312 2490), chef Kerwin Browne transforms this largely disdained vegetable by mixing it with pineapple, coriander and chopped chillies, then macerating it while warm in a reduction of lime juice, sugar and chilli. It is served as a potato salad with scallops, but is such a wake-up call to your taste buds that I could eat a plateful on its own.

fields.headline: Second opinion
fields.standfirst: Are suntan lotions effective at protecting us from skin cancer?
fields.trailText: Are suntan lotions effective at protecting us from skin cancer?
fields.body:
NO
Professor Philippe Anoutier of the European Institute of Oncology

While sunscreens are useful for outdoor activities, such as gardening or walking around, they are not for people who actually sunbathe with the intention of tanning themselves. In fact, we believe that wearing a suntan lotion can mean you run a higher risk of contracting skin cancer because it makes people feel safer than they are. Although creams definitely offer a delay in getting sunburn, our research shows that using a lotion encourages people to spend far more time in the sun - at least an extra 30 minutes a day, which is more than enough to significantly increase your risk of getting a melanoma. We concluded that if you want to get a suntan, then it is probably best not to use a sunscreen. That way you develop your natural defences without any chemical interference between your own skin and the radiation that is coming from the sun, and you will find out how much sun your type of skin can take before it burns. There is research which suggests that chemical filters in the lotions are damaging to the skin and can destroy the skin's natural defences against sunlight. But remember that we need a certain amount of sunlight to give the body vitamin D.

YES
Dr Julia Newton Bishop, Imperial Cancer Research Fund scientist and consultant dermatologist in Leeds

Anything which helps keep dangerous cancer-inducing sun off the skin has to be a good thing. Of course there are issues with the way suncreams are used, but we can't afford to discourage people from using what is a valuable tool in protecting them from skin damage and cancer. In an ideal world, you would stay out of the sun between 11am and 3pm, when it is highest in the sky. You would also wear protective clothing to keep the rays from your skin. But as you cannot always stay out of the sun in the course of a normal life, I think it is sensible, if not essential, for people to use sunscreens.

Years ago, people used low-SPF sunscreens to get a tan. Those creams were mostly of a chemical base which would only protect from UVB rays, which meant that you still got UVA rays. This led to the argument that, while using a sunscreen does stop you from burning, it also tends to make you stay out in the sun longer and get even higher doses of UVA. This is no longer the case: most modern sunscreens protect us from UVA and UVB rays - and are effective. So choose the right sunscreen, and apply and reapply it evenly.

fields.headline: Beat generation
fields.standfirst: It dominates the charts and outsells Steps. It's garage music, and it's everywhere from the suburbs to the city streets. Miranda Sawyer on how an underground scene exploded into Britain's richest cultural movement.
fields.trailText: It dominates the charts and outsells Steps. It's garage music, and it's everywhere from the suburbs to the city streets. Miranda Sawyer on how an underground scene exploded into Britain's richest cultural movement.
fields.body:
Saturday night, Sunday morning. It's 1.30am and we're weaving off London's Old Kent Road, down dark, lonely side streets, past abandoned warehouses, over shattered glass. We round a corner and - watch out! - almost smack into a Mercedes SLK doing a three-point turn. We wait, then slope slowly on down the street, past a scene unimaginable from only a couple of roads away, a scene familiar and gratifying to anyone who's ever been to a nightclub on the basis of a scrawled address, the hallelujah welcome sign that says you've made it. Well: you've found it.

People. Hundreds and hundreds of people. Groups of girls clack past, screeching into mobiles, showing off, looking for friends. Boys spill up from round the corner, neatly dressed and coiffed, to eye the enormous queue - three people wide, 200 yards long - that hems the blank brick wall of the club, before pitching up at its end. Some march to the front of the line, but are swiftly disaffected of their delusions of superior status by the bouncers, who aren't so much heavy-handed as just heavy. Still, a spot of sweet talk and we queue-hop. Through a metal detector, on to a clothes-bag-and-body-search that would shame Heathrow, and in. Three vast rooms, each progressively darker, both in lighting and sounds. The darkest is the most popular: we arrive just in time for the PA from Colour Girl, who performs her latest single, 'Joyrider'. Once she's off, the DJ slams on some moodier, harder music. The crowd goes bananas.

It's fantastic to see. A group of perfectly turned out, seemingly aloof young men, who'd been standing around as though training for cool school, suddenly and simultaneously throw some joyful, eye-popping moves. They continue to do so for as long as the DJ plays the tunes they like: often not very long, given his habit of letting each track last all of a minute and a half. Low-attention-span clubbing. On the stage, a gaggle of lads argy-bargy as to who gets to chat over the records.

There are more girls in the other rooms. And what girls they are. Of all shapes, ages, colours, they are united in their rejection of unnecessary clothing. The skimpiest of skirts and hankiest of tops are uniform, as are glamour heels. Their hair is twisted into works of art. In many clubs, this could lead to snooty attitudes towards other women: here, the toilets chatter with compliments - 'Lookin' good, girl!' The good humour stands in contrast to the hassle getting in. The friendliness of the clubbers goes against long-held assumptions about this area of south-east London and, in particular, about the kind of people that are into the skippy drums, cut-up vocals and hard basslines of the music now known as UK garage.

You might not think you know about UK garage, but you do. It's what pours from every car, thumps out of every window, clogs up the compilation racks in Our Price and HMV. It packs out Under-18 nights and goes on student-union tours. It's what you hear when you flip across your radio on a Saturday night. It's 'Re-Rewind', 'Sweet Like Chocolate', 'Little Bit Of Luck', 'Never Gonna Let You Go', 'Girls Like Us', 'Thong Song', 'Buggin". It beats Steps into third place in the Top 20, after Craig David's 'Fill Me In' and Sweet Female Attitude's 'Flowers'. It's all those pop songs with those light 'n' frisky drums.

Forget Ibiza Uncovered and, these days, Overexposed . Take a summer trip to Cyprus instead, to the once sleepy town of Ayia Napa. You'll meet Radio 1 there, and MTV. Or talk to the punters at Twice As Nice, the packed-to-the-rafters Sunday night UK garage club held at central London's The End. Ask Sarah, who's 32, a dressed-to-the-99s sales accountant who sometimes spends £200 on going out over the weekend. She used to go to 'field raves' in the early 90s, but then didn't bother clubbing until UK garage became big.

'Yeah, it made me start going out again,' she says. 'I like the vibe, I like the music. I love soul, too, but soul to me isn't for coming out. But with garage, I can dance to it and that's the main attraction. I like the people, too, because a lot of the girls are nice, they're trendy. And there's no attitude at all. Everyone comes out to enjoy themselves. They don't stand around, you know, just looking bored.'

'Everyone's coming out for this atmosphere now,' says Vanessa, who's 21 and works in advertising. 'It's nice to be in a club and to see loads of different people, new people every week. It shows that it's alive.'

Keep talking and you'll find out that - blimey! - even the boys are positive. Peter, who's a security guard at the Old Bailey, is happy to explain the appeal. 'I like the vibe, the people, the music, the chicks,' he grins. 'The chicks are more sophisticated, sexy. It's not like any other club... I met my wife here a year ago. I was a little bit tipsy and she came up to me and rescued me and took me home. When we have kids, I'll get my mum to look after them and we'll both come to Twice as Nice.'

But it's not just the clubbers who are enjoying themselves. UK garage has started to give the British music industry the shake-up it's needed for the past five years. Dave Norton is a PR for Four Liberty Records, an Eastender whose first musical influences were Chuck Berry and Little Richard (he's 43). He is over the moon about UK garage. 'I'm someone who's always been totally in love with black music,' he enthuses. 'Through the 70s, with James Brown, through the 80s with the jazz funk and soul, into the 90s... UK garage is a continuation of this wonderful legacy. Plus, it's British, it's our version.

There's so many influences that have been added into the stew. If you look at current American black music, essentially it's just a version of early soul and disco. With UK garage, there are those influences, but there's also dancehall reggae, drum and bass, even hardcore in there, too. It's a broad church and it's bringing everyone in. If you held up a mirror to what's going on culturally in the UK today, then UK garage would look back at you. It's going to dominate the charts.'

Or meet Nigel Blunt, who manages Oracabessa, a Birmingham-based record label set up by Ali Campbell from UB40. Nigel's a laidback man whose CV includes band, label and club management from as far back as the New Romantic era. Nigel is not usually moved to over-enthusiasm, but even he's bubbling. 'You can press 1,000 copies of your single, get it rinsing in a disco, and within weeks it can be dropping on national radio, if The Dreem Teem pick up on it,' he grins. 'The music scene has never had so few rules. It's like the Wild West out there, I tell you. The last time I saw excitement like this was punk. It's just black people this time.'

Sensational prospects for a music that began so humbly. Here's the story. In 1993, in a grotty south London pub called the Elephant and Castle, a clever promoter called Timmy Ram Jam decided to try and catch the late-night clubbers stumbling out of the Ministry of Sound. He started his club at 6am. Now-established UK garage DJs like Matt Jam Lamont and Mickey Simms played tuneful American house music: but, crucially, played the records a bit too fast. This was for two reasons. First: British crowds - for some long-acknowledged but inexplicable reason - have always liked their music faster-tempoed than Americans. Second: the clubbers had been up all night. The DJs wanted to keep them awake.

From there, the club moved to the big- ger, but no more salubrious, Frog and Nightgown on the Old Kent Road, then the Arches in Southwark, and finally, to the Colliseum at Vauxhall. It picked up DJs, MCs, pirate radio coverage and plenty of punters along the way. Twice As Nice every Sunday night at the Colliseum started in 1997. Within weeks, it had legendary status, boasting DJs such as EZ (now on Kiss FM) and The Dreem Teem - producers and DJs Spoony, Timmi Magic and Mikee B, now on Radio 1.

I went to Twice As Nice in 1998. It was rammed. There were so many people spilling out of the club on to the road that they literally stopped the traffic. Inside, the atmosphere was uplifting and full of energy: plenty of posing, but even more dancing, breaking loose, proper night-of-your-lifetime clubbing. Everything about the club seemed completely new to me. It had its own sound: skippy drums, boot-shuddering bass and uplifting vocals. It had its own look: dressy, exclusive, designer-labelled - the boys in head-to-toe Moschino and Versace, the girls likewise, though not so warmly wrapped. It had its own tipple: champagne. Far from wanting to drop a pill and veg out, the new crew wanted to keep their cool, dance well, look great. And it had its own ambience: it was racially mixed (very unusual in clubland) and inclusively friendly (unusual in an underground club). It was inevitable that the press would pick up on it.

Unfortunately, when it did, it got things slightly wrong. The media concentrated on the champagne-BMW-designer-label lifestyle, as opposed to the music. Then, because the flourishing club scene didn't immediately translate into chart-hit records, the press turned away, talking flash-in-the-pan, leaving those involved in the scene smarting and irritated.

Richard Benson was one of the first journalists outside the music press to champion the UK garage scene. He says: 'Everyone who went to garage clubs three or four years ago could see what was happening, because the music made sense there,' he says, 'but it took a long time to replicate the excitement of the clubs on vinyl. The Next Big Thing was actually jumping up and down and asking for support for years, but the media chose to ignore or misrepresent it.'

In those years, when UK garage was filling the clubs, but not being played on mainstream radio, the role of pirate radio was fundamental. Benson visited Ice FM, one of London's most popular pirates, which broadcasted from ex-fireman Ricky D's kitchen. He recalls Technics decks on the worktops, memos to DJs Blu-tacked on the fridge, empty champagne bottles in one corner, boxes of 12in vinyl singles in all the others, and, sitting on the windowsill, the 'horn'. The horn, like a 6in mini-loudhailer, is a cheap piece of broadcasting equipment that beams the music to a transmitter atop another block of flats.

The pirates broke and still break those independent label records that suddenly and rudely gate-crash the top 10. They pick up on tracks that go down well in clubs, and the listeners tape the shows, then take the tapes to record shops to get the vinyl. Between 1997 and 2000, with the mainstream media so shy of the culture, the pirates cleaned up: their number in London alone has almost quadrupled since 1996.

Four years on, and the UK garage hits are coming thick and fast. DJs Mark Hill and Pete Devereux, alias Artful Dodger, who gave us 'Re-Rewind' (which launched teen- age lover-crooner Craig David), 'Movin' Too Fast', and now 'Woman Trouble' have already sold in excess of 1 million records. Producers such as Truesteppers, Wookie and Zed Bias are in ouch-that's- hot demand. And, after a couple of years in which most vocals seemed to be supplied by American r'n'b artists (producers would take the a cappella version of a single by Whitney Houston, Brandy, Destiny's Child and do a bootleg remix), British vocalists are coming through.

We all know about 'making love on a Tuesday, Wednesday, etc, etc' Craig David; now there's Alan Shearer-in-a-suit Robbie Craig, Stockport bargirls Sweet Female Attitude, potential pop queen Colour Girl, even Neneh Cherry, whose career got a shot in the arm with The Dreem Teem's remix of Buddy X. And it's not just British performers who are benefiting from UK garage's Midas touch. Oracabessa is mining a rich seam of talent from Jamaica, and has already had hits with Mr Vegas's 'Heads High' and B15 Projects' 'Girls Like Us'.

UK garage, because it was given time to develop at its own pace, away from press glare and major label cherry-picking, is now throwing up more talent than any other pop genre. 'I think the reason why UK garage works is that you can throw in anything, it'll go in the mix,' says writer and singer Colour Girl, real name Becky, an Essex girl with a two-year-old son. 'A screaming diva vocal, something haunting, like Wookie, or Witchidam, for the reggae.'

Colour Girl herself came from house music, but now finds UK garage more fulfilling. 'I don't often feel proud about being British, but I do with UK garage. For years, we were left behind by America. They had the best hip-hop, r'n'b, soul, house music. Now we've come up with our own unique music. Let's just hope it's got enough legs to trot over the Atlantic and kick some arse.'

Writer-singers like Colour Girl, Craig David and the amazingly soulful Robbie Craig are to be f ted in an industry that has relied for many years on boy/girl/combination-bands that sing, dance, look pretty, but don't pen tunes. UK garage producers can write, too. Artful Dodger are classically trained. Another who looks as though he could become a star - though not, perhaps, in the hold-the-front-page mould - is 27-year-old polite-as-you-like Wookie. Wookie (real name Jason Chue: Chue-Chewbacca-Wookie-geddit?) has an LP coming out later this year: 'There'll be tracks of the same speed as UK garage, but the mood will be lower, you wouldn't play them out.' He's self-taught - he wrote all his first tunes on a £1,100 keyboard - and part of Jazzie B's Soul II Soul crew. (They met six years ago when Wookie was renting a flat from Jazzie's barber.) Wookie's already remixed Gabrielle, Whitney Houston, Brandy, Angie Stone and is an example of what The Dreem Teem's Timmi Magic calls the 'depth' of the UK garage scene. 'It isn't just bedroom producers,' says Timmi. 'There are legitimate songwriters, like Wookie, and K Warren, Dubaholics, TJ Cases_ they're another reason why this scene will last. They can write.'

Sunday afternoon at Radio 1. The Dreem Teem have just come off air from their 10am-1pm show. All three have been up all night DJing at clubs, and now, though their stint is over, they can't stop. They have to discuss and approve a TV ad for their mix LP (part of the INcredible series), and go through what will happen for a telly programme to be made around their Ayia Napa trip. They'll be there, with Radio 1, on 21-23 July. They munch chocolate bars and crisps to keep up their energy.

The Dreem Teem are possibly the most well known DJs of the UK garage scene, mostly because of their Radio 1 show. (Other DJs, like EZ and Artful Dodger, have prime-time Kiss slots, but Kiss only broadcasts in London.) They met in 1996 through working on the same pirate radio station: Spoony played US garage; Timmi Magic came from acid house; Mikee B was into drum and bass and hardcore - et voilà, the essential ingredients of UK garage. Since then, they've become a respected production team as well as building on their club and radio DJing.

The Dreem Teem came to Radio 1 via shows on Kiss and on Galaxy, a station which broadcasts almost everywhere in the UK, except London - thus disproving the UK garage 'is a London thing' theory. They're very different characters: Timmi, who oversees their production work, is the most naturally lively and jokey; Mikee is laid-back and only contributes to conversations when he has to; Spoony is the spokesman, a man who can argue his corner and who is keen to represent UK garage in what he feels is its correct light.

'When people write about the house scene, they don't write about sweaty people with their tops off any more,' he points out. 'So why do they always write about the champagne and the suits? It's too easy. For the record, only one of us three has a BMW. And one of us doesn't even drink champagne.'

The Dreem Teem believe that UK garage will stick around because it's strong in so many areas. It has a healthy clubscene that's now spread nationally, a thriving and long-established pirate radio stage; plus, now, mainstream chart hits, mainstream radio play, and telly-friendly Ayia Napa for those who want a holiday. All backed up by talented writers, producers, singers and MCs: 'MCs are our rappers,' says Timmi. 'Instead of Mel C featuring Left Eye, soon it'll be Baby Spice featuring PSG.'

Friday afternoon at Uptown Records on D'Arblay Street in London's Soho. The basement is mobbed: there are queues at the desk and at the turntables at the back of the shop, where customers can try out the wares. Check that the record they're listening to is the one they want. 'We get a lot of people coming in and singing to us,' smiles 28-year-old Huckleberry Finn, who's in charge of the underground music section. 'People play tapes down the phone of stuff they've heard on pirates. I've had kids come up and go: You got the song with the bass? I'm going: Well, is it a soft bass? A hard bass? Does it go woooooooh?'

Huckleberry has an ear for hits: he bought in the very first white-label copies of 'Flowers', 'Little Bit Of Luck', 'Buggin", 'Girls Like Us'. He tells me that the next track to look out for will be 'Can I Get Your Number' by Obi: 'That's my top tip.' His tips have started to pay off: several major record labels are sniffing about, offering him A&R consultancy deals, because 'they miss so much they shouldn't. There's a lot of homegrown talent that's going unspotted.'

Huckleberry, like The Dreem Teem, came up through the pirates, via soul, rave and hardcore. And, like The Dreem Teem, he's concerned with spreading the message: in his case, worldwide, developing contacts with Japan, America, Switzerland. 'The whole scene happened naturally,' he says. 'It was an accident, there was no bandwagon to be jumped on. We all know each other and we plodded along, doing our thing, helping each other out, you know - you do a mix for me and I'll do one for you - there's been no money involved.'

But now, of course, there is. And it alters things. 'There's no extra people involved,' says Huckleberry. 'It's not like we're finding new fans under the carpet. They're coming into our scene from other ones, like we did. So, if that scene is trance, or house, and if over the last year you've lost 15 per cent of your trance or house fans to UK garage, then that's a problem for some people.'

He means the long-established, multi-millionaire house and trance DJs that still dominate Radio 1's prime Friday and Saturday night slots. Pete Tong, Judge Jules, Danny Rampling: they all came out of the acid house scene of the late 80s and they are unlikely to give up their top-boy positions easily. One wonders why The Dreem Teem aren't given an early night Friday slot, where they could break out of the daytime playlist and DJ as they did on Kiss or Galaxy or just be free to play their own choice of records.

It seems that 2000 could be UK garage's year. Admittedly, there are many people who can't stand the skippety drums and mucked-up vocals, but to stand in the way of a genuinely multiracial, thoroughly friendly, utterly new-sounding, exciting, innovative, fresh British music is just plain churlish. Its variations are vast, from the Jamaican connection with Oracabessa to the pop- tastic 'Flowers' girls; from the sweet nu soul vocals of Lain, who sings with Wookie, through the sample gimmick of 'I Don't Smoke Da Reefer' (taken from comedian Marcus Brigstocke, not Jim Davidson, as has been reported) all the way to the growl of MC Neat. It's the soundtrack to the suburbs, the beat of the street. It's aiming for America and it's as mainstream as we want it to be. And just how mainstream is that? Well: Posh Spice, bless her, is studio-bound for her first solo LP. Her first single, 'Out Of Your Mind', is a duet with Dane from Another Level, produced by those 'Buggin" Truesteppers. Come in, Judge Jules, your time is up.
