UK garage is a continuation of this wonderful legacy. Plus, it's British, it's our version. There's so many influences that have been added into the stew. If you look at current American black music, essentially it's just a version of early soul and disco. With UK garage, there are those influences, but there's also dancehall reggae, drum and bass, even hardcore in there, too. It's a broad church and it's bringing everyone in. If you held up a mirror to what's going on culturally in the UK today, then UK garage would look back at you. It's going to dominate the charts.' Or meet Nigel Blunt, who manages Oracabessa, a Birmingham-based record label set up by Ali Campbell from UB40. Nigel's a laidback man whose CV includes band, label and club management from as far back as the New Romantic era. Nigel is not usually moved to over-enthusiasm, but even he's bubbling. 'You can press 1,000 copies of your single, get it rinsing in a disco, and within weeks it can be dropping on national radio, if The Dreem Teem pick up on it,' he grins. 'The music scene has never had so few rules. It's like the Wild West out there, I tell you. The last time I saw excitement like this was punk. It's just black people this time.' Sensational prospects for a music that began so humbly. Here's the story. In 1993, in a grotty south London pub called the Elephant and Castle, a clever promoter called Timmy Ram Jam decided to try and catch the late-night clubbers stumbling out of the Ministry of Sound. He started his club at 6am. Now-established UK garage DJs like Matt Jam Lamont and Mickey Simms played tuneful American house music: but, crucially, played the records a bit too fast. This was for two reasons. First: British crowds - for some long-acknowledged but inexplicable reason - have always liked their music faster-tempoed than Americans. Second: the clubbers had been up all night. The DJs wanted to keep them awake. From there, the club moved to the big- ger, but no more salubrious, Frog and Nightgown on the Old Kent Road, then the Arches in Southwark, and finally, to the Colliseum at Vauxhall. It picked up DJs, MCs, pirate radio coverage and plenty of punters along the way. Twice As Nice every Sunday night at the Colliseum started in 1997. Within weeks, it had legendary status, boasting DJs such as EZ (now on Kiss FM) and The Dreem Teem - producers and DJs Spoony, Timmi Magic and Mikee B, now on Radio 1. I went to Twice As Nice in 1998. It was rammed. There were so many people spilling out of the club on to the road that they literally stopped the traffic. Inside, the atmosphere was uplifting and full of energy: plenty of posing, but even more dancing, breaking loose, proper night-of-your-lifetime clubbing. Everything about the club seemed completely new to me. It had its own sound: skippy drums, boot-shuddering bass and uplifting vocals. It had its own look: dressy, exclusive, designer-labelled - the boys in head-to-toe Moschino and Versace, the girls likewise, though not so warmly wrapped. It had its own tipple: champagne. Far from wanting to drop a pill and veg out, the new crew wanted to keep their cool, dance well, look great. And it had its own ambience: it was racially mixed (very unusual in clubland) and inclusively friendly (unusual in an underground club). It was inevitable that the press would pick up on it. Unfortunately, when it did, it got things slightly wrong. The media concentrated on the champagne-BMW-designer-label lifestyle, as opposed to the music. Then, because the flourishing club scene didn't immediately translate into chart-hit records, the press turned away, talking flash-in-the-pan, leaving those involved in the scene smarting and irritated. Richard Benson was one of the first journalists outside the music press to champion the UK garage scene. He says: 'Everyone who went to garage clubs three or four years ago could see what was happening, because the music made sense there,' he says, 'but it took a long time to replicate the excitement of the clubs on vinyl. The Next Big Thing was actually jumping up and down and asking for support for years, but the media chose to ignore or misrepresent it.' In those years, when UK garage was filling the clubs, but not being played on mainstream radio, the role of pirate radio was fundamental. Benson visited Ice FM, one of London's most popular pirates, which broadcasted from ex-fireman Ricky D's kitchen. He recalls Technics decks on the worktops, memos to DJs Blu-tacked on the fridge, empty champagne bottles in one corner, boxes of 12in vinyl singles in all the others, and, sitting on the windowsill, the 'horn'. The horn, like a 6in mini-loudhailer, is a cheap piece of broadcasting equipment that beams the music to a transmitter atop another block of flats. The pirates broke and still break those independent label records that suddenly and rudely gate-crash the top 10. They pick up on tracks that go down well in clubs, and the listeners tape the shows, then take the tapes to record shops to get the vinyl. Between 1997 and 2000, with the mainstream media so shy of the culture, the pirates cleaned up: their number in London alone has almost quadrupled since 1996. Four years on, and the UK garage hits are coming thick and fast. DJs Mark Hill and Pete Devereux, alias Artful Dodger, who gave us 'Re-Rewind' (which launched teen- age lover-crooner Craig David), 'Movin' Too Fast', and now 'Woman Trouble' have already sold in excess of 1 million records. Producers such as Truesteppers, Wookie and Zed Bias are in ouch-that's- hot demand. And, after a couple of years in which most vocals seemed to be supplied by American r'n'b artists (producers would take the a cappella version of a single by Whitney Houston, Brandy, Destiny's Child and do a bootleg remix), British vocalists are coming through. We all know about 'making love on a Tuesday, Wednesday, etc, etc' Craig David; now there's Alan Shearer-in-a-suit Robbie Craig, Stockport bargirls Sweet Female Attitude, potential pop queen Colour Girl, even Neneh Cherry, whose career got a shot in the arm with The Dreem Teem's remix of Buddy X. And it's not just British performers who are benefiting from UK garage's Midas touch. Oracabessa is mining a rich seam of talent from Jamaica, and has already had hits with Mr Vegas's 'Heads High' and B15 Projects' 'Girls Like Us'. UK garage, because it was given time to develop at its own pace, away from press glare and major label cherry-picking, is now throwing up more talent than any other pop genre. 'I think the reason why UK garage works is that you can throw in anything, it'll go in the mix,' says writer and singer Colour Girl, real name Becky, an Essex girl with a two-year-old son. 'A screaming diva vocal, something haunting, like Wookie, or Witchidam, for the reggae.' Colour Girl herself came from house music, but now finds UK garage more fulfilling. 'I don't often feel proud about being British, but I do with UK garage. For years, we were left behind by America. They had the best hip-hop, r'n'b, soul, house music. Now we've come up with our own unique music. Let's just hope it's got enough legs to trot over the Atlantic and kick some arse.' Writer-singers like Colour Girl, Craig David and the amazingly soulful Robbie Craig are to be f ted in an industry that has relied for many years on boy/girl/combination-bands that sing, dance, look pretty, but don't pen tunes. UK garage producers can write, too. Artful Dodger are classically trained. Another who looks as though he could become a star - though not, perhaps, in the hold-the-front-page mould - is 27-year-old polite-as-you-like Wookie. Wookie (real name Jason Chue: Chue-Chewbacca-Wookie-geddit?) has an LP coming out later this year: 'There'll be tracks of the same speed as UK garage, but the mood will be lower, you wouldn't play them out.' He's self-taught - he wrote all his first tunes on a £1,100 keyboard - and part of Jazzie B's Soul II Soul crew. (They met six years ago when Wookie was renting a flat from Jazzie's barber.) Wookie's already remixed Gabrielle, Whitney Houston, Brandy, Angie Stone and is an example of what The Dreem Teem's Timmi Magic calls the 'depth' of the UK garage scene. 'It isn't just bedroom producers,' says Timmi. 'There are legitimate songwriters, like Wookie, and K Warren, Dubaholics, TJ Cases_ they're another reason why this scene will last. They can write.' Sunday afternoon at Radio 1. The Dreem Teem have just come off air from their 10am-1pm show. All three have been up all night DJing at clubs, and now, though their stint is over, they can't stop. They have to discuss and approve a TV ad for their mix LP (part of the INcredible series), and go through what will happen for a telly programme to be made around their Ayia Napa trip. They'll be there, with Radio 1, on 21-23 July. They munch chocolate bars and crisps to keep up their energy. The Dreem Teem are possibly the most well known DJs of the UK garage scene, mostly because of their Radio 1 show. (Other DJs, like EZ and Artful Dodger, have prime-time Kiss slots, but Kiss only broadcasts in London.) They met in 1996 through working on the same pirate radio station: Spoony played US garage; Timmi Magic came from acid house; Mikee B was into drum and bass and hardcore - et voilà, the essential ingredients of UK garage. Since then, they've become a respected production team as well as building on their club and radio DJing. The Dreem Teem came to Radio 1 via shows on Kiss and on Galaxy, a station which broadcasts almost everywhere in the UK, except London - thus disproving the UK garage 'is a London thing' theory. They're very different characters: Timmi, who oversees their production work, is the most naturally lively and jokey; Mikee is laid-back and only contributes to conversations when he has to; Spoony is the spokesman, a man who can argue his corner and who is keen to represent UK garage in what he feels is its correct light. 'When people write about the house scene, they don't write about sweaty people with their tops off any more,' he points out. 'So why do they always write about the champagne and the suits? It's too easy. For the record, only one of us three has a BMW. And one of us doesn't even drink champagne.' The Dreem Teem believe that UK garage will stick around because it's strong in so many areas. It has a healthy clubscene that's now spread nationally, a thriving and long-established pirate radio stage; plus, now, mainstream chart hits, mainstream radio play, and telly-friendly Ayia Napa for those who want a holiday. All backed up by talented writers, producers, singers and MCs: 'MCs are our rappers,' says Timmi. 'Instead of Mel C featuring Left Eye, soon it'll be Baby Spice featuring PSG.' Friday afternoon at Uptown Records on D'Arblay Street in London's Soho. The basement is mobbed: there are queues at the desk and at the turntables at the back of the shop, where customers can try out the wares. Check that the record they're listening to is the one they want. 'We get a lot of people coming in and singing to us,' smiles 28-year-old Huckleberry Finn, who's in charge of the underground music section. 'People play tapes down the phone of stuff they've heard on pirates. I've had kids come up and go: You got the song with the bass? I'm going: Well, is it a soft bass? A hard bass? Does it go woooooooh?' Huckleberry has an ear for hits: he bought in the very first white-label copies of 'Flowers', 'Little Bit Of Luck', 'Buggin", 'Girls Like Us'. He tells me that the next track to look out for will be 'Can I Get Your Number' by Obi: 'That's my top tip.' His tips have started to pay off: several major record labels are sniffing about, offering him A&R consultancy deals, because 'they miss so much they shouldn't. There's a lot of homegrown talent that's going unspotted.' Huckleberry, like The Dreem Teem, came up through the pirates, via soul, rave and hardcore. And, like The Dreem Teem, he's concerned with spreading the message: in his case, worldwide, developing contacts with Japan, America, Switzerland. 'The whole scene happened naturally,' he says. 'It was an accident, there was no bandwagon to be jumped on. We all know each other and we plodded along, doing our thing, helping each other out, you know - you do a mix for me and I'll do one for you - there's been no money involved.' But now, of course, there is. And it alters things. 'There's no extra people involved,' says Huckleberry. 'It's not like we're finding new fans under the carpet. They're coming into our scene from other ones, like we did. So, if that scene is trance, or house, and if over the last year you've lost 15 per cent of your trance or house fans to UK garage, then that's a problem for some people.' He means the long-established, multi-millionaire house and trance DJs that still dominate Radio 1's prime Friday and Saturday night slots. Pete Tong, Judge Jules, Danny Rampling: they all came out of the acid house scene of the late 80s and they are unlikely to give up their top-boy positions easily. One wonders why The Dreem Teem aren't given an early night Friday slot, where they could break out of the daytime playlist and DJ as they did on Kiss or Galaxy or just be free to play their own choice of records. It seems that 2000 could be UK garage's year. Admittedly, there are many people who can't stand the skippety drums and mucked-up vocals, but to stand in the way of a genuinely multiracial, thoroughly friendly, utterly new-sounding, exciting, innovative, fresh British music is just plain churlish. Its variations are vast, from the Jamaican connection with Oracabessa to the pop- tastic 'Flowers' girls; from the sweet nu soul vocals of Lain, who sings with Wookie, through the sample gimmick of 'I Don't Smoke Da Reefer' (taken from comedian Marcus Brigstocke, not Jim Davidson, as has been reported) all the way to the growl of MC Neat. It's the soundtrack to the suburbs, the beat of the street. It's aiming for America and it's as mainstream as we want it to be. And just how mainstream is that? Well: Posh Spice, bless her, is studio-bound for her first solo LP. Her first single, 'Out Of Your Mind', is a duet with Dane from Another Level, produced by those 'Buggin" Truesteppers. Come in, Judge Jules, your time is up.

webTitle: Who wants to be a millionaire?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a millionaire?
fields.standfirst: The new prophets of the motivational circuit preach an old-fashioned gospel of self-advancement, personal development and... making lists. Sanjiv Bhattacharya feels the power
fields.trailText: The new prophets of the motivational circuit preach an old-fashioned gospel of self-advancement, personal development and... making lists. Sanjiv Bhattacharya feels the power.
fields.body:
The streets are clogged in San Jose today with hopes and dreams in suits and jeans all creeping towards the arena for a piece of that off-the-shelf success stuff. The kind peddled by gurus with five-digit speech fees whose audio-cassette programmes appear in airport bookshops, titles like Maximum Achievement , Unleash the Power Within and Million Dollar Habits . They claim to possess the secrets of boundless wealth, lifelong happiness and trim thighs, all of which are apparently available to everyone all the time. Which explains why 15,000 hungry punters have log-jammed the traffic around the SJ Convention Center in time for the 8am kick-off. 'Results 2000,' flashes the electric billboard. 'Create An Extraordinary Quality Of Life.'

Results is a big deal in a huge business, a kind of all-star motivational circus featuring such giants of the genre as Anthony Robbins and Brian Tracy - authors of the above-cited blockbusters - and speaker-circuit celebrities like Gulf War general Norman Schwarzkopf, Larry King (live by satellite) and Danny Glover of Lethal Weapon fame. Results takes its feel-good romp around the US, greeting audiences of 10,000 and more with the news that you, yes you, can make your dreams come true if only you make lists, believe in yourself and buy the six-tape programme after the show. And at every venue, grown adults with MBAs, even plcs, have jumped around like teenagers to teenage music, hugged their neighbours and scribbled down copious notes before plundering their savings at the product stalls to the rear. Worth well more than $100m a year, the success industry well deserves its name.

'I WANT YOU ALL TO COMMIT TO AN OUTSTANDING LEVEL OF EXCELLENCE!' It is 10am and Tony Robbins, the 6ft 7in undisputed heavyweight champion of the circuit, adopts the Atlas pose on stage - shoulders back, beaming teethy smile, as big as a house and with hands like shovels, he looks like a cross between Arnie and Jaws from the James Bond movies. He tells us we are unique and we can do anything as long as we achieve a 'peak state', so in a thunder-clap roar he commands us to dance to his 'peak state' tune - a 20-second snatch of the Dutch duo 2 Unlimited, whose 'Get Ready for This' is rivalled only by Snap's 'I've Got the Power' in the motivational hit parade. And everyone, all 15,000 of us, dances. Robbins has fireworks, he stamps, he claps, he beats his huge chest - he is the booming behemoth of the success business.

Robbins is a showman, harnessing the same mass-manipulation machinery as television evangelists, and rock bands. The sceptic shrinks from this disturbing conjunction of charismatic speakers, life-changing agendas, emotion-whipped crowds and 'all major credit cards accepted'.

But Robbins couldn't care less about sceptics - he meets all ironic barbs head on and smashes through them with the sheer force of his will. Like a latter-day Marvel hero, Captain American Dream, he embodies his can-do philosophy. He's a self-made centillionaire who could snap you like a twig, but all he wants is for you to live a life as fulfilled as his. He makes upwards of $125,000 per gig, and his clients include Bill Clinton, Andre Agassi and, at one time, Princess Diana.

However, there's more to the success industry than titanic Tony. In his wake marches a legion of lesser gurus, each carving a lucrative niche, one of the most successful of whom is Brian Tracy, who performed his first public (not corporate) gig in the UK this May, in Manchester.

Against the virile, chest-beating Robbins, Tracy is a neutered shell - he has none of the charisma or brio one expects of a motivational guru. While Robbins charges about on stage bellowing about RPMs - 'RESULTS-FOCUSED, PURPOSE-DRIVEN MASSIVE-ACTION-PLANS' - Tracy is to be found calmly sipping his third black coffee in the sumptuous Hyatt hotel down the road, a few hours before his performance. A stiff, grey man of 56 in a sombre suit who speaks softly and smiles awkwardly through imperfect teeth, he cuts a desperately ordinary figure.

'Most people say I'm the highest-content speaker and writer in the personal-development business worldwide,' he says. 'I've published three books, there's a fourth coming out, I've got offers on the table for two more and outlines for 20 others. And my books are good. They are judged by the people who read them as the best books ever written in their field in history in any language. And I've been published in a dozen languages. I've eight books in German, and this year I will be the best-published personal-success author in German history.'

The self-aggrandisement is interminable, unprompted and without apology. As befits the author of The Science of Self-Confidence , modesty isn't a Tracy tenet. Post-boast, I ask him if dispensing life's great answers all day makes it hard to be humble. His features harden. 'Look, you couldn't possibly be successful in a profession that requires performance unless you have an ego.' More coffee. 'Egoless people just aren't successful.'

Tracy is in many ways a more intriguing figure than Robbins, for he relies on nothing but content - perhaps his favourite word. While a superficial observer might attribute Robbins' popularity to his charm, his size, the music and lewd references to erections - or 'Mr Happy', as he calls it - Tracy offers no excuses. Stony, dour and defensive in person, he has nonetheless succeeded in a field that, at first, doesn't seem to suit him, armed only with his precious material and a steely resolve. And like many modern gurus, he made his fortune teaching others to make theirs.

Tracy began life as a salesman, rising diligently through the ranks selling everything from cars to real estate, until one day 20 years ago, he unearthed the holy grail of consumer society - that what people really want isn't this house or that car, but the ability to buy any damn house or car they want. Albert Einstein once said that 'too many of us look upon Americans as dollar chasers - this is a cruel libel, even if it is reiterated thoughtlessly by the Americans themselves'. And no more so than here in the bars and restaurants of San Jose - not the romantic San Jose to which Dionne Warwick once asked directions, but the blocky, functional hub of northern California's Silicon Valley - where venture capitalists repeatedly ask e-entrepreneurs the same questions: what's the market, how big is it, will it last? Well, Tracy's market is guaranteed and limitless - everyone who wants to be successful at anything.

'When I started in this field, I used to speak to tiny audiences - seven people, then 12 - and I lost $100 each time. But you know, anything worth doing is worth doing poorly at first. Never be afraid of failure. If you want to succeed, you must double your rate of failure.' Singing the virtues of graft and perseverance, he inflated his speech fees over 20 years to the current $25,000, and that's irrespective of the audience - public or corporate, large or small. In a typical year, he'll speak, say, 120 times, which makes a cool $3m before counting the $15m annual sales of his book and audio programmes, bestsellers like The Psychology of Selling and Breaking The Success Barrier .

'You know why they like me in Germany?' he says. 'Because I'm not a glad-hander. My material is very practical; it doesn't try to fool you. You know, recently the editors of my latest book tried to shorten it and they couldn't. These are some of the finest editors in New York City. You know what they said? There was too much content.'

This magical 'content' that promises to double or triple your income in 90 days - with emotional, spiritual and physical fulfillment tossed into the bargain - is nothing new. There have been no new discoveries or scientific breakthroughs, despite the industry's wildest exaggerations. Rather, motivational literature remains characterised by the oldest material going - vintage truisms of the bumper-sticker kind, such as 'Failing to plan is planning to fail' or the particularly helpful 'Time management is the key - try to find faster ways of doing things.' The bibliography of Tracy's latest oeuvre, Maximum Achievement , contains the likes of Kahlil Gibran, Emerson, Epictetus, Plato, Winston Churchill, Longfellow and Roosevelt, all of whom the author quotes liberally to bolster such home-grown aphorisms as: 'If you change your thinking, you change your life.' The effect is a kind of cliché soup - every word is undeniably true in both the deepest and the corniest ways; most of it is common to most self-respecting gurus and ultimately too hackneyed to be of interest. Who was it that said stealing from one is plagiarism but stealing from many is research?

Tracy bristles, brushes away the hovering waitress and bites his lip. 'It's not plagiarism or stealing, it's eclecticism. It's like elements of the periodic table: there are millions of ways of combining those elements to make compounds, some of which will be strong and powerful and useful, others of which will not. It is how these elements are combined that counts. Recipes are another example_' And architecture is another, and music. Having detected a cynic, he rises admirably to the challenge with an instant volley of cheesy analogies, each one meticulously explained. Tracy is as quick with a cornball story or quickfire quote as a stand-up comic putting down a heckler.

'What I have done is gone back through history,' he explains patiently, 'to the early philosophers like Pythagoras and Socrates, and found out what those formulae for success are. It's very simple. You see, Tony's approach is just feel - don't worry about specifics, just go with the flow, make a lot of noise and sing and dance_ But you know, you can make people happy until they get to the parking lot and then, like cigarette smoke, it's gone. I say: these are the specific things you should do. These are the numbers.'

Yes, but is life really so straightforward? Don't these 'numbers' reduce life's rich tapestry to bullet points? Didn't Mark Twain dismiss the success industry with his own formula - ignorance and confidence? And anyway, the greatest minds in humanity have perished pondering such things, so what makes a salesman from San Diego so damned smug? Tracy breaks a difficult smile and raises his voice as a politician might.

'There's a condescending attitude towards the US in England,' he says. 'You think you know it all. But you see, America is made up of the people who left seeking opportunity, and Europe is made up of those who stayed, seeking security and creating a huge bureaucracy with some of the worst corruption in the Western world. Look at France. And in England you have this union movement that's just so... What you fail to grasp is the difference between the active and passive voice, I discovered this the other day. You can either say, "All this prosperity isn't helping the poor" - passive. Or "Poor people aren't taking advantage of all this prosperity" - active. The first is "I'm a victim", the second is "I'm in control, I'm in charge of my life". All this talk about wealth distribution is pure socialist claptrap - wealth is created, not distributed. And how are you going to create wealth if you only work 30 hours per week - that's the main trouble with poor people, they don't work enough hours! How can you British be so wrong-headed as to deny the fact that these principles work! It's the same mentality as those outrageously incompetent officers in the First World War who sent their men to the slaughter and sat back in their chteaux drinking wine and smoking cigars...' And so on.

Despite Tracy's protestations, however, the success industry is making headway in the UK - we even have a home-grown guru circuit. It's a punier proposition to the American scene, to be sure, playing to hundreds rather than thousands, but nonetheless, it's a start. David Hughes of Nightingale Conant, which publishes all of Tracy's material - alongside Robbins, Deepak Chopra, all the big guns - recognises the British wariness of the motivational business. But he feels it's merely a style thing.

'Personal improvement is a growing industry, in the UK,' he says. 'Our sales have doubled in the last three years, only we don't like to bow down to the guru so much. Take Tony Robbins - in the US, they like a big, glossy hero picture, but here we had to reduce the picture on the packaging and market it according to its content. In fact, Brian Tracy's style is more appropriate, in a way, to the English market.'

Paul McKenna, the TV hypnotist, is one of Hughes's biggest sellers in the UK. He believes that our traditional scepticism is a double-edged sword because, in fact, much of this goal-setting, list-making stuff is good for you. 'It's a bit of a cliché, but the world is changing. Communication has hugely speeded up technological development, and the brain has become the most important resource. So the motto must be 'Improve thy brain', except no one ever taught us how at school.' The key, inevitably, is hypnosis. 'We have much better psychological technology now,' he explains. 'That Freudian nonsense about taking you back to the root of your trauma is thankfully losing ground. It's like if someone comes to you with a broken leg, would you keep throwing them down the stairs until they feel better? While they can take six months to treat a simple phobia for example, I take half an hour.'

In the stark concrete green room to the left of the stage, Brian Tracy quietly runs over his speech notes one last time. On the TV screen in the corner, Tracy's warm-up, a former tax attorney called Sanford ('Sandy') Botkin, hams his way through what you can and can't claim if you're self-employed. Just outside the door, Robbins is doing 'live shots' for a local TV outfit - despite having slept only two hours last night, and spent the morning roaring and stamping, Robbins manages to cram his every window with media interviews. Then the door bursts open.

'Hi Brian!' It's Jan, the chirrupy event organiser, with a microphone headset and a clipboard. She stands fanning herself and beaming. 'Have you felt the energy in there? Isn't it aaahsome? Wow, I'm like toadally buzzing on the energy!'

Before Tracy takes the stage, Robbins does him the service of geeing up the crowd - he bounds out to that 2 Unlimited tune for what seems like the 20th time today to hurl Results 2000 T-shirts into the crowd as a guitarist might plectrums. Everyone flocks to the falling bundles, pushing and grabbing and cheering. Then Brian comes on, a grey and gestureless man with an overhead projector, and the music dies. Row upon row of salesmen and women produce notepads and red Biros. He asks them: 'Who's the most important person in the room?' And everyone shouts 'Me!' That's about as fun as it gets.

For most of his set, Tracy rattles through the magic of goal-setting. But for the last quarter, he simply sells his wares shopping-channel style, one product at a time, spinning pitches of superlatives and unconfirmable statistics, even kissing the cassette-boxes before moving on, most of which were graced with his own image. It's a remarkable and shameless performance, considering his $500 a minute fee, and not one that endears him to the wearying punters.

Certainly behind the till at the hot-dog stall where Tracy appears on a screen beside the soft-drinks machine, the cashier cannot fathom his style. 'Why's he have to kiss it like that?' she asks no one in particular. 'He's kissing every one, what's the matter with him?'

You can feel the relief when Danny Glover totters onto the stage, yelling, 'Would y'all give it up for Brian Tracy!'

While Glover relates his battle with dyslexia as a child, Tracy marches back to the Green Room once more to gather his things and rush off to the airport - no sense in hanging around, there's work to be done. He meets an orgy of mutual congratulation. Fellow gurus compliment him on an illuminating speech, members of the audience sneak in to shake his hand and thank him profusely for tripling their incomes. And I'm seized by the realisation that in this room, I am the only sceptic and the only non- millionaire. Perhaps life really is built on simple truths, truths of which I have long lost sight in my stubborn scepticism - perhaps irony is a British malaise after all. And loath as I am to succumb to these empires of aphorism and advertorial, I well know the dull sting of underachievement, the gnawing guilt of not turning my 'shoulds' into 'musts'.

So I ask him: Mr Tracy, what can you do for me, a humble journalist? Can I triple my income, too?

'Of course you can,' he says, sensing a convert. 'But you must be specific about your goals.'

Er, I want to be a better journalist, make more money, er_

'Right. Well, a journalist is really a subject entrepreneur. You must first see what the market wants and then you'll make money. We're living in a boom period right now, so people are interested in positive articles. So end all of your articles with some practical tips, and you'll get syndicated, believe me. I've got it - why not write a series of articles about self-made millionaires in the UK? Call it 'You Can Do It - Success in the UK'. Keep interviewing self-made millionaires about how they achieved their success, and when you've interviewed a hundred, you've got a book!'

But Brian, you're asking me to become a success guru, not a journalist.

Catalina Di Novo, 29
'Actually this is my first time at an event like this. I'm a model. Hopefully I'll be in business by the end of the year. And yes, I'm definitely going to buy some motivation tapes.'

'I've never attended a Robbins event before, and I have to say, it's fantastic - it's unbelievable, actually. Almost better than a touchdown at a 49ers game. Great place to do some networking, too. And I've decided today to really make a plan and move into financial services full time. I'll double or quadruple my income before the year's out, definitely. No doubt at all. If other people can do it, so can I.'

'I'm, like, the No.2 salesman for Cutco cutlery, which is the biggest cutlery company in California. And I'm still at school, so you know, I'm real good. fields.bodyText: The streets are clogged in San Jose today with hopes and dreams in suits and jeans all creeping towards the arena for a piece of that off-the-shelf success stuff. The kind peddled by gurus with five-digit speech fees whose audio-cassette programmes appear in airport bookshops, titles like Maximum Achievement , Unleash the Power Within and Million Dollar Habits . They claim to possess the secrets of boundless wealth, lifelong happiness and trim thighs, all of which are apparently available to everyone all the time. Which explains why 15,000 hungry punters have log-jammed the traffic around the SJ Convention Center in time for the 8am kick-off. 'Results 2000,' flashes the electric billboard. 'Create An Extraordinary Quality Of Life.' Results is a big deal in a huge business, a kind of all-star motivational circus featuring such giants of the genre as Anthony Robbins and Brian Tracy - authors of the above-cited blockbusters - and speaker-circuit celebrities like Gulf War general Norman Schwarzkopf, Larry King (live by satellite) and Danny Glover of Lethal Weapon fame. Results takes its feel-good romp around the US, greeting audiences of 10,000 and more with the news that you, yes you, can make your dreams come true if only you make lists, believe in yourself and buy the six-tape programme after the show. And at every venue, grown adults with MBAs, even plcs, have jumped around like teenagers to teenage music, hugged their neighbours and scribbled down copious notes before plundering their savings at the product stalls to the rear. Worth well more than $100m a year, the success industry well deserves its name. 'I WANT YOU ALL TO COMMIT TO AN OUTSTANDING LEVEL OF EXCELLENCE!' It is 10am and Tony Robbins, the 6ft 7in undisputed heavyweight champion of the circuit, adopts the Atlas pose on stage - shoulders back, beaming teethy smile, as big as a house and with hands like shovels, he looks like a cross between Arnie and Jaws from the James Bond movies. He tells us we are unique and we can do anything as long as we achieve a 'peak state', so in a thunder-clap roar he commands us to dance to his 'peak state' tune - a 20-second snatch of the Dutch duo 2 Unlimited, whose 'Get Ready for This' is rivalled only by Snap's 'I've Got the Power' in the motivational hit parade. And everyone, all 15,000 of us, dances. Robbins has fireworks, he stamps, he claps, he beats his huge chest - he is the booming behemoth of the success business. Robbins is a showman, harnessing the same mass-manipulation machinery as television evangelists, and rock bands. The sceptic shrinks from this disturbing conjunction of charismatic speakers, life-changing agendas, emotion-whipped crowds and 'all major credit cards accepted'. But Robbins couldn't care less about sceptics - he meets all ironic barbs head on and smashes through them with the sheer force of his will. Like a latter-day Marvel hero, Captain American Dream, he embodies his can-do philosophy. He's a self-made centillionaire who could snap you like a twig, but all he wants is for you to live a life as fulfilled as his. He makes upwards of $125,000 per gig, and his clients include Bill Clinton, Andre Agassi and, at one time, Princess Diana. However, there's more to the success industry than titanic Tony. In his wake marches a legion of lesser gurus, each carving a lucrative niche, one of the most successful of whom is Brian Tracy, who performed his first public (not corporate) gig in the UK this May, in Manchester. Against the virile, chest-beating Robbins, Tracy is a neutered shell - he has none of the charisma or brio one expects of a motivational guru. While Robbins charges about on stage bellowing about RPMs - 'RESULTS-FOCUSED, PURPOSE-DRIVEN MASSIVE-ACTION-PLANS' - Tracy is to be found calmly sipping his third black coffee in the sumptuous Hyatt hotel down the road, a few hours before his performance. A stiff, grey man of 56 in a sombre suit who speaks softly and smiles awkwardly through imperfect teeth, he cuts a desperately ordinary figure. 'Most people say I'm the highest-content speaker and writer in the personal-development business worldwide,' he says. 'I've published three books, there's a fourth coming out, I've got offers on the table for two more and outlines for 20 others. And my books are good. They are judged by the people who read them as the best books ever written in their field in history in any language. And I've been published in a dozen languages. I've eight books in German, and this year I will be the best-published personal-success author in German history.' The self-aggrandisement is interminable, unprompted and without apology. As befits the author of The Science of Self-Confidence , modesty isn't a Tracy tenet. Post-boast, I ask him if dispensing life's great answers all day makes it hard to be humble. His features harden. 'Look, you couldn't possibly be successful in a profession that requires performance unless you have an ego.' More coffee. 'Egoless people just aren't successful.' Tracy is in many ways a more intriguing figure than Robbins, for he relies on nothing but content - perhaps his favourite word. While a superficial observer might attribute Robbins' popularity to his charm, his size, the music and lewd references to erections - or 'Mr Happy', as he calls it - Tracy offers no excuses. Stony, dour and defensive in person, he has nonetheless succeeded in a field that, at first, doesn't seem to suit him, armed only with his precious material and a steely resolve. And like many modern gurus, he made his fortune teaching others to make theirs. Tracy began life as a salesman, rising diligently through the ranks selling everything from cars to real estate, until one day 20 years ago, he unearthed the holy grail of consumer society - that what people really want isn't this house or that car, but the ability to buy any damn house or car they want. Albert Einstein once said that 'too many of us look upon Americans as dollar chasers - this is a cruel libel, even if it is reiterated thoughtlessly by the Americans themselves'. And no more so than here in the bars and restaurants of San Jose - not the romantic San Jose to which Dionne Warwick once asked directions, but the blocky, functional hub of northern California's Silicon Valley - where venture capitalists repeatedly ask e-entrepreneurs the same questions: what's the market, how big is it, will it last? Well, Tracy's market is guaranteed and limitless - everyone who wants to be successful at anything. 'When I started in this field, I used to speak to tiny audiences - seven people, then 12 - and I lost $100 each time. But you know, anything worth doing is worth doing poorly at first. Never be afraid of failure. If you want to succeed, you must double your rate of failure.' Singing the virtues of graft and perseverance, he inflated his speech fees over 20 years to the current $25,000, and that's irrespective of the audience - public or corporate, large or small. In a typical year, he'll speak, say, 120 times, which makes a cool $3m before counting the $15m annual sales of his book and audio programmes, bestsellers like The Psychology of Selling and Breaking The Success Barrier . 'You know why they like me in Germany?' he says. 'Because I'm not a glad-hander. My material is very practical; it doesn't try to fool you. You know, recently the editors of my latest book tried to shorten it and they couldn't. These are some of the finest editors in New York City. You know what they said? There was too much content.' This magical 'content' that promises to double or triple your income in 90 days - with emotional, spiritual and physical fulfillment tossed into the bargain - is nothing new. There have been no new discoveries or scientific breakthroughs, despite the industry's wildest exaggerations. Rather, motivational literature remains characterised by the oldest material going - vintage truisms of the bumper-sticker kind, such as 'Failing to plan is planning to fail' or the particularly helpful 'Time management is the key - try to find faster ways of doing things.' The bibliography of Tracy's latest oeuvre, Maximum Achievement , contains the likes of Kahlil Gibran, Emerson, Epictetus, Plato, Winston Churchill, Longfellow and Roosevelt, all of whom the author quotes liberally to bolster such home-grown aphorisms as: 'If you change your thinking, you change your life.' The effect is a kind of cliché soup - every word is undeniably true in both the deepest and the corniest ways; most of it is common to most self-respecting gurus and ultimately too hackneyed to be of interest. Who was it that said stealing from one is plagiarism but stealing from many is research? Tracy bristles, brushes away the hovering waitress and bites his lip. 'It's not plagiarism or stealing, it's eclecticism. It's like elements of the periodic table: there are millions of ways of combining those elements to make compounds, some of which will be strong and powerful and useful, others of which will not. It is how these elements are combined that counts. Recipes are another example_' And architecture is another, and music. Having detected a cynic, he rises admirably to the challenge with an instant volley of cheesy analogies, each one meticulously explained. Tracy is as quick with a cornball story or quickfire quote as a stand-up comic putting down a heckler. 'What I have done is gone back through history,' he explains patiently, 'to the early philosophers like Pythagoras and Socrates, and found out what those formulae for success are. It's very simple. You see, Tony's approach is just feel - don't worry about specifics, just go with the flow, make a lot of noise and sing and dance_ But you know, you can make people happy until they get to the parking lot and then, like cigarette smoke, it's gone. I say: these are the specific things you should do. These are the numbers.' Yes, but is life really so straightforward? Don't these 'numbers' reduce life's rich tapestry to bullet points? Didn't Mark Twain dismiss the success industry with his own formula - ignorance and confidence? And anyway, the greatest minds in humanity have perished pondering such things, so what makes a salesman from San Diego so damned smug? Tracy breaks a difficult smile and raises his voice as a politician might. 'There's a condescending attitude towards the US in England,' he says. 'You think you know it all. But you see, America is made up of the people who left seeking opportunity, and Europe is made up of those who stayed, seeking security and creating a huge bureaucracy with some of the worst corruption in the Western world. Look at France. And in England you have this union movement that's just so... What you fail to grasp is the difference between the active and passive voice, I discovered this the other day. You can either say, "All this prosperity isn't helping the poor" - passive. Or "Poor people aren't taking advantage of all this prosperity" - active. The first is "I'm a victim", the second is "I'm in control, I'm in charge of my life". All this talk about wealth distribution is pure socialist claptrap - wealth is created, not distributed. And how are you going to create wealth if you only work 30 hours per week - that's the main trouble with poor people, they don't work enough hours! How can you British be so wrong-headed as to deny the fact that these principles work! It's the same mentality as those outrageously incompetent officers in the First World War who sent their men to the slaughter and sat back in their chteaux drinking wine and smoking cigars...' And so on. Despite Tracy's protestations, however, the success industry is making headway in the UK - we even have a home-grown guru circuit. It's a punier proposition to the American scene, to be sure, playing to hundreds rather than thousands, but nonetheless, it's a start. David Hughes of Nightingale Conant, which publishes all of Tracy's material - alongside Robbins, Deepak Chopra, all the big guns - recognises the British wariness of the motivational business. But he feels it's merely a style thing. 'Personal improvement is a growing industry, in the UK,' he says. 'Our sales have doubled in the last three years, only we don't like to bow down to the guru so much. Take Tony Robbins - in the US, they like a big, glossy hero picture, but here we had to reduce the picture on the packaging and market it according to its content. In fact, Brian Tracy's style is more appropriate, in a way, to the English market.' Paul McKenna, the TV hypnotist, is one of Hughes's biggest sellers in the UK. He believes that our traditional scepticism is a double-edged sword because, in fact, much of this goal-setting, list-making stuff is good for you. 'It's a bit of a cliché, but the world is changing. Communication has hugely speeded up technological development, and the brain has become the most important resource. So the motto must be 'Improve thy brain', except no one ever taught us how at school.' The key, inevitably, is hypnosis. 'We have much better psychological technology now,' he explains. 'That Freudian nonsense about taking you back to the root of your trauma is thankfully losing ground. It's like if someone comes to you with a broken leg, would you keep throwing them down the stairs until they feel better? While they can take six months to treat a simple phobia for example, I take half an hour.' In the stark concrete green room to the left of the stage, Brian Tracy quietly runs over his speech notes one last time. On the TV screen in the corner, Tracy's warm-up, a former tax attorney called Sanford ('Sandy') Botkin, hams his way through what you can and can't claim if you're self-employed. Just outside the door, Robbins is doing 'live shots' for a local TV outfit - despite having slept only two hours last night, and spent the morning roaring and stamping, Robbins manages to cram his every window with media interviews. Then the door bursts open. 'Hi Brian!' It's Jan, the chirrupy event organiser, with a microphone headset and a clipboard. She stands fanning herself and beaming. 'Have you felt the energy in there? Isn't it aaahsome? Wow, I'm like toadally buzzing on the energy!' Before Tracy takes the stage, Robbins does him the service of geeing up the crowd - he bounds out to that 2 Unlimited tune for what seems like the 20th time today to hurl Results 2000 T-shirts into the crowd as a guitarist might plectrums. Everyone flocks to the falling bundles, pushing and grabbing and cheering. Then Brian comes on, a grey and gestureless man with an overhead projector, and the music dies. Row upon row of salesmen and women produce notepads and red Biros. He asks them: 'Who's the most important person in the room?' And everyone shouts 'Me!' That's about as fun as it gets. For most of his set, Tracy rattles through the magic of goal-setting. But for the last quarter, he simply sells his wares shopping-channel style, one product at a time, spinning pitches of superlatives and unconfirmable statistics, even kissing the cassette-boxes before moving on, most of which were graced with his own image. It's a remarkable and shameless performance, considering his $500 a minute fee, and not one that endears him to the wearying punters. Certainly behind the till at the hot-dog stall where Tracy appears on a screen beside the soft-drinks machine, the cashier cannot fathom his style. 'Why's he have to kiss it like that?' she asks no one in particular. 'He's kissing every one, what's the matter with him?' You can feel the relief when Danny Glover totters onto the stage, yelling, 'Would y'all give it up for Brian Tracy!' While Glover relates his battle with dyslexia as a child, Tracy marches back to the Green Room once more to gather his things and rush off to the airport - no sense in hanging around, there's work to be done. He meets an orgy of mutual congratulation. Fellow gurus compliment him on an illuminating speech, members of the audience sneak in to shake his hand and thank him profusely for tripling their incomes. And I'm seized by the realisation that in this room, I am the only sceptic and the only non- millionaire. Perhaps life really is built on simple truths, truths of which I have long lost sight in my stubborn scepticism - perhaps irony is a British malaise after all. And loath as I am to succumb to these empires of aphorism and advertorial, I well know the dull sting of underachievement, the gnawing guilt of not turning my 'shoulds' into 'musts'. So I ask him: Mr Tracy, what can you do for me, a humble journalist? Can I triple my income, too? 'Of course you can,' he says, sensing a convert. 'But you must be specific about your goals.' Er, I want to be a better journalist, make more money, er_ 'Right. Well, a journalist is really a subject entrepreneur. You must first see what the market wants and then you'll make money. We're living in a boom period right now, so people are interested in positive articles. So end all of your articles with some practical tips, and you'll get syndicated, believe me. I've got it - why not write a series of articles about self-made millionaires in the UK? Call it 'You Can Do It - Success in the UK'. Keep interviewing self-made millionaires about how they achieved their success, and when you've interviewed a hundred, you've got a book!' But Brian, you're asking me to become a success guru, not a journalist. 'It's what people want to read,' he adds, climbing into his limousine. 'And you must expect to be turned down a hundred times.' fields.headline: Wide awake club
fields.standfirst: Tesco's at 2am, the gym at 3am and then the all night café... it may be convenient, but it's not good for you. Dr Luisa Dillner stays up late
fields.trailText: Tesco's at 2am, the gym at 3am and then the all night café... it may be convenient, but it's not good for you. Dr Luisa Dillner stays up late.
fields.body:
It's 2am. The time when only clubbers and nursing mothers should still be up. But pull back your curtains and you might be surprised by the number of lights on in your street. Night-time is no longer ring-fenced for sleep. It has become the new daytime, offering us the chance to catch up on everything we didn't manage to cram in during what used to be our waking hours. Now, instead of sleeping, we can check our bank balances by phone, buy groceries, surf the net for cheap flights or swop our slippers for training shoes and go to the gym.

Such flexibility, however, has a price. Our bodies are run by circadian rhythms, a prehistoric internal clock that regulates when we feel sleepy or awake, our body temperature, hormone secretion and level of alertness. It makes our brains and bodies active during the day and recuperate through the night. So robust is this clock - based in cells in the hypothalamus in the brain (3cm behind the eyes) - that even two weeks on a night shift without a break will not destroy its intrinsic rhythm, and when scientists keep human volunteers in isolation, without cues of what time it is in the day, they still show daily cycles of temperature changes, sleep and wakefulness, and hormone release. Continually working against our body's natural rhythm is likely to cause ourselves both physical and psychological damage and, research shows, may actually increase our risk of depression, stomach ulcers and heart disease.

At the sleep unit in Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, consultant Tom Mackey believes that our normal circadian rhythms are increasingly being completely distorted. 'More and more of us are being pressured into doing things at odd hours. There's more flexitime at work, but this can mean people taking work home and staying up doing it long after the children have gone to bed. This is going to have an impact on quality and length of sleep. If people don't go to bed at a reasonable time, say around 11pm, and have between six and eight hours of sleep, they will build up a sleep debt that will make them unable to concentrate and liable to swings in temper and depression. You need sleep for rest and repair; in sleep you lay down the memories of experiences you've had during the day. You need to process them. If you bombard your mind with information for too long, then everything gets disorganised - you become unable to manage daytime activities.' Many people repay their week's sleep debt at weekends, but such blocks of extra sleep may not be as good as the natural way of sleeping. 'You can't replicate the normal sleeping act,' warns Mackey.

The circadian rhythms that run the sleep/wake cycle are as old as evolution itself. In his laboratory in Northwest University in Illinois, Phil Lowrey has studied the genetic basis of circadian rhythms in various organisms. 'You see circadian rhythms in single-celled bacteria, all the way up the evolutionary ladder to humans. It is important for all living things to have a biological timing system. There are many similarities between the genes in humans that are responsible for circadian rhythms and those which are responsible in flies.' Just as the way glucose is stored and released in the body is similar in all species, because it works well, so it is with circadian rhythms. Once nature has a prototype that works, everyone gets it. Much of Lowrey's work has been done on hamsters, largely nocturnal creatures, whose circadian rhythms get them up just before dusk and make them sleepy before dawn, so they can avoid predators and hunt down food.

Our circadian rhythms were developed in the opposite direction. 'Our prehistoric ancestors would have needed their clock to get them out hunting during the day and probably in bed around 6pm to 8pm to avoid predators,' says Lowrey. 'Our night vision is not as good as that of nocturnal animals - our natural rhythm was to sleep as the sun went down. The invention of the electric light obviously changed that.'

Like most biological systems, circadian rhythms are not made to measure. Our internal clock runs a bit longer than 24 hours, hence its Latin name, circadian, which means almost a day. Each day, the cells in the hypothalamus readjust their timing in response to environmental cues such as the amount of daylight. This doesn't happen immediately, hence jet lag when we fly across time zones. It can take one day per time zone to make a full recovery. If the clock was unable to self-regulate as the seasons changed, the poor hamster would suddenly find itself waking up in broad daylight between the paws of a predator.

That humans tend to vary in their circadian rhythms has been known for centuries. Benjamin Franklin's maxim 'Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise' recognised that some people are born to be larks (to get up and go to bed early) while others are owls (late risers and late to bed). Larks are 'morning people' - productive and communicative from the time their eyes open - while owls are grouchy and groggy until midday. Franklin's maxim has, however, largely been disproved by researchers. A paper in the British Medical Journal in 1998 based on nearly 1,300 people found that far from being the poorer bird, owls tended to be richer and were more likely to have their own cars than larks. There was no real difference in death rates between the two. According to Dr Chris Martyn, one of the authors of the paper, the idea of industrious, prosperous larks probably dates from before artificial light, when people needed to get up early to make the most of daylight. 'I'm an owl by nature, so I was pleased with our findings because I was fed up with larks claiming moral superiority for getting up early. '

Other research nevertheless suggests that owls may pay a price - health problems - because they tend to go to sleep at less regular times. While the temperature of the body should fall at night (and does whether or not we are asleep, reaching its lowest at around 4am), it falls more in larks than in owls. 'Larks go to bed at a more appropriate time for their body clock,' says Dr James Waterhouse, lecturer in the Research Institute of Sport and Exercise Science at John Moores University in Liverpool. 'Owls probably pay for less regular hours by having a greater incidence of low mood and sub-clinical depression.'

Phil Lowry's Northwest laboratory has moved even closer to uncovering the havoc that a disturbed clock can have on the body. Last month, the lab published a paper in Science describing the first genetic mutation in the biological clock of a hamster, which is similar to a human's. The mutation switched the hamster's circadian cycle from 24 hours to 20. 'Humans may have similar problems with their circadian rhythms that could be responsible for sleep problems,' says Lowrey. 'The result is that some people want to go to sleep earlier but can't until 3am. While others can't stay awake after 5pm. These are all new areas of research, but if humans continue to push themselves, to override our natural body clocks so we can do what we want, when we want, then there will be health consequences.'

Much of the damage that can be done by disrupting the biological clock has been seen in shift workers. The fatigue and disorientation following night shifts is similar to that of jet lag. As with jet lag, the body adjusts over time, but the wake-and-sleep cycle never seems to be totally reversed. As more of us push back our circadian clocks, going to bed later and later, the effects on our bodies will be similar to those of shift workers. Peter Colquhoun, a retired chronopsychologist who studied shift work in his Medical Research Council laboratory in Cambridge for many years, believes that more accidents happen at night, when workers are less alert. He studied people working continuous night shifts who were responsible for various monitoring devices in the military. 'They only managed a partial adjustment of their circadian rhythms - instead of having a trough in their temperature at 4am or 5am, their temperature flattened out over the day and night. Similarly, their fall in alertness at 4am flattened out. People sleep less on night shifts and have more psychosomatic illness. Our increasingly 24-hour society means more people are doing things at funny times - so more of the population is liable to make mistakes.'

Apart from psychosomatic illness, shift workers also get physically unwell. 'If you continue to be a night worker, then you have a high incidence of indigestion and of stomach ulcers - our bodies are better able to metabolise food we eat in the day,' says Dr Waterhouse. 'You will also have a higher incidence of cardiovascular disease. Night workers have adrenaline levels that are high in the middle of the night, so they are kept alert - this is stressful physiologically, and there's probably a medical cost involved in terms of cardiovascular disease.

'There is also evidence that working nights affects the immune system. It isn't equally competent over 24 hours, it's related to levels of the hormone cortisol. When a person is stressed, cortisol levels rise, the immune response is depressed and infections may be more likely. Night workers have an increased rate of sick leave.' The best thing for night workers to do is to change their lifestyle, keeping to their pattern of being awake at night and asleep during the day, even on days off. Otherwise their clocks can never even partially adjust.

Meanwhile, the move towards a 24-hour society gathers pace. Tesco started by opening four shops for 24 hours in 1996 - now it has 170 stores open day and night. 'It is in response to consumer demand,' says its spokesman, Russell Craig. 'People are more conscious of their leisure time. They don't want to shop as soon as they get home; they might want to see the children, eat supper and wander out to shop at midnight. We have a global economy. When it's night-time for us, it's daytime in the US - business goes on through the night. If you drive through any city, you'll see people in suits at 2am.'

Over a four-year period, there has been a 20 per cent rise in the number of people watching television between 3am and 6am. The foundation says that people increasingly want everything available to them 24 hours a day and forecasts that people will work longer hours, but outside the 9-to-5 model. 'If we interfere with them, the consequences will catch up with us.'

Night-time is no longer ring-fenced for sleep. It has become the new daytime, offering us the chance to catch up on everything we didn't manage to cram in during what used to be our waking hours. Now, instead of sleeping, we can check our bank balances by phone, buy groceries, surf the net for cheap flights or swop our slippers for training shoes and go to the gym. Such flexibility, however, has a price. Our bodies are run by circadian rhythms, a prehistoric internal clock that regulates when we feel sleepy or awake, our body temperature, hormone secretion and level of alertness. It makes our brains and bodies active during the day and recuperate through the night. So robust is this clock - based in cells in the hypothalamus in the brain (3cm behind the eyes) - that even two weeks on a night shift without a break will not destroy its intrinsic rhythm, and when scientists keep human volunteers in isolation, without cues of what time it is in the day, they still show daily cycles of temperature changes, sleep and wakefulness, and hormone release. Continually working against our body's natural rhythm is likely to cause ourselves both physical and psychological damage and, research shows, may actually increase our risk of depression, stomach ulcers and heart disease. At the sleep unit in Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, consultant Tom Mackey believes that our normal circadian rhythms are increasingly being completely distorted. 'More and more of us are being pressured into doing things at odd hours. There's more flexitime at work, but this can mean people taking work home and staying up doing it long after the children have gone to bed. This is going to have an impact on quality and length of sleep. If people don't go to bed at a reasonable time, say around 11pm, and have between six and eight hours of sleep, they will build up a sleep debt that will make them unable to concentrate and liable to swings in temper and depression. You need sleep for rest and repair; in sleep you lay down the memories of experiences you've had during the day. You need to process them. If you bombard your mind with information for too long, then everything gets disorganised - you become unable to manage daytime activities.' Many people repay their week's sleep debt at weekends, but such blocks of extra sleep may not be as good as the natural way of sleeping. 'You can't replicate the normal sleeping act,' warns Mackey. The circadian rhythms that run the sleep/wake cycle are as old as evolution itself. In his laboratory in Northwest University in Illinois, Phil Lowrey has studied the genetic basis of circadian rhythms in various organisms. 'You see circadian rhythms in single-celled bacteria, all the way up the evolutionary ladder to humans. It is important for all living things to have a biological timing system. There are many similarities between the genes in humans that are responsible for circadian rhythms and those which are responsible in flies.' Just as the way glucose is stored and released in the body is similar in all species, because it works well, so it is with circadian rhythms. Once nature has a prototype that works, everyone gets it. Much of Lowrey's work has been done on hamsters, largely nocturnal creatures, whose circadian rhythms get them up just before dusk and make them sleepy before dawn, so they can avoid predators and hunt down food. Our circadian rhythms were developed in the opposite direction. 'Our prehistoric ancestors would have needed their clock to get them out hunting during the day and probably in bed around 6pm to 8pm to avoid predators,' says Lowrey. 'Our night vision is not as good as that of nocturnal animals - our natural rhythm was to sleep as the sun went down. The invention of the electric light obviously changed that.' Like most biological systems, circadian rhythms are not made to measure. Our internal clock runs a bit longer than 24 hours, hence its Latin name, circadian, which means almost a day. Each day, the cells in the hypothalamus readjust their timing in response to environmental cues such as the amount of daylight. This doesn't happen immediately, hence jet lag when we fly across time zones. It can take one day per time zone to make a full recovery. If the clock was unable to self-regulate as the seasons changed, the poor hamster would suddenly find itself waking up in broad daylight between the paws of a predator. That humans tend to vary in their circadian rhythms has been known for centuries. Benjamin Franklin's maxim 'Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise' recognised that some people are born to be larks (to get up and go to bed early) while others are owls (late risers and late to bed). Larks are 'morning people' - productive and communicative from the time their eyes open - while owls are grouchy and groggy until midday. Franklin's maxim has, however, largely been disproved by researchers. A paper in the British Medical Journal in 1998 based on nearly 1,300 people found that far from being the poorer bird, owls tended to be richer and were more likely to have their own cars than larks. There was no real difference in death rates between the two. 'I'm an owl by nature, so I was pleased with our findings because I was fed up with larks claiming moral superiority for getting up early. ' Other research nevertheless suggests that owls may pay a price - health problems - because they tend to go to sleep at less regular times. While the temperature of the body should fall at night (and does whether or not we are asleep, reaching its lowest at around 4am), it falls more in larks than in owls. 'Larks go to bed at a more appropriate time for their body clock,' says Dr James Waterhouse, lecturer in the Research Institute of Sport and Exercise Science at John Moores University in Liverpool. 'Owls probably pay for less regular hours by having a greater incidence of low mood and sub-clinical depression.' Last month, the lab published a paper in Science describing the first genetic mutation in the biological clock of a hamster, which is similar to a human's. The mutation switched the hamster's circadian cycle from 24 hours to 20. 'Humans may have similar problems with their circadian rhythms that could be responsible for sleep problems,' says Lowrey. 'The result is that some people want to go to sleep earlier but can't until 3am. While others can't stay awake after 5pm. These are all new areas of research, but if humans continue to push themselves, to override our natural body clocks so we can do what we want, when we want, then there will be health consequences.' Much of the damage that can be done by disrupting the biological clock has been seen in shift workers. The fatigue and disorientation following night shifts is similar to that of jet lag. As with jet lag, the body adjusts over time, but the wake-and-sleep cycle never seems to be totally reversed. As more of us push back our circadian clocks, going to bed later and later, the effects on our bodies will be similar to those of shift workers. He studied people working continuous night shifts who were responsible for various monitoring devices in the military. 'They only managed a partial adjustment of their circadian rhythms - instead of having a trough in their temperature at 4am or 5am, their temperature flattened out over the day and night. Similarly, their fall in alertness at 4am flattened out. People sleep less on night shifts and have more psychosomatic illness. Our increasingly 24-hour society means more people are doing things at funny times - so more of the population is liable to make mistakes.' Apart from psychosomatic illness, shift workers also get physically unwell.
