fields.headline: Spell bound
fields.standfirst: Paul Daniels may have made a fortune and be happily married to The Lovely Debbie McGee, but he'll need all his magic powers to pull off his next trick... conjuring up a touring ballet company
fields.trailText: Paul Daniels may have made a fortune and be happily married to The Lovely Debbie McGee, but he'll need all his magic powers to pull off his next trick... conjuring up a touring ballet company
fields.body:
The lane that leads to Paul Daniels' house (his £1.5m minimalist Thames-side mansion, as Hello! has it) is pure Disney: a bucolic England of birdsong, wood smoke, drifts of roses on flint walls, rowing boats beached on stripy lawns. Paul and his wife, The Lovely Debbie McGee, are running a little late - they're bowling back from Bluewater, where he has been signing copies of his autobiography - so there's an opportunity to wander around inspecting everything before they get back: the wraparound view from their 60s glass box; the flowerbeds spilling over with peonies; the pleasure-cruisers pfutting past behind a screen of willows. Then a gold Mercedes two-seater is entering the drive, spraying gravel around in its wake, and Paul Daniels, who was once very famous for being a magician, is stepping out, tieless, in a crumpled blue suit. 'It's a tough life, isn't it?' he calls out breezily, and for a moment he reminds me of Alistair McGowan's spoof of Nigel Havers hosting OK! TV : you'll never have a house like this, you wouldn't know what to do with it anyway, this is how really rich people live.

Paul Daniels was never a cuddly entertainer. He always got up people's noses. A pint-sized telly colossus during the 80s, he bestrode a world of wide lapels and sequinned dollybirds and Seaside Specials and cheesy grins, without bothering to disguise a certain anti-populist bloody-mindedness. Though he married his magic with comedy banter learned from American one-liner books, you could not have mistaken him for a warm man. Unlike the Brucies and Tarbies, he never courted affection. He is, he says proudly, a wizzywig. 'Know what that is? WYSIWYG? What You See Is What You Get. I'm not precious. I'm me. I don't put on any airs and graces, which sometimes upsets people.'

The papers were always full of Paul Daniels. He refused to sign a petition supporting the rights of Aids sufferers to have children; he raised funds for the Tories; he boasted about the wealth he'd accumulated through shrewd investment; he stifled rivalry by never inviting younger 'patter' magicians to do guest spots on his shows; he remarked that, like Jesus, he too could walk on water. In addition, 'the mini magician' had a short fuse and, for a brief period, wore a wig that made a deep impression on Spitting Image puppeteers. In other words, he was the flip side of Tommy Cooper: technically accomplished with wand and saw, but seriously short on charm.

In 1995, when audience figures slumped, Alan Yentob pulled the string which released the trap door, at which point Daniels and Debbie, his assistant, suddenly vanished - pouff! - from the BBC schedules. Though he was indignant at the time about the way this was handled, he now insists he's well out of television. 'I never realised what a strain it was. I don't get uptight, I'm a cool guy. But when I found out I wasn't going to be doing any more series, I really went: "Phew."' In any case, television studios aren't the same now, being stuffed with 'nerds': people 'who've been to university and have degrees in media and communications_ who don't understand this peculiar emotion called theatre'.

You may think that magic is a dying art, having been hijacked by the tiger acts of Vegas and the subversive antics of Penn and Teller, but Daniels insists that his act is evergreen. 'I'm an oddity, you see. The rest of the world of magic looks at me with some amazement. They can't figure out how I can do a tiny trick with a cup and a ball in a 7,000-seater hall. But I do. And everybody laughs.' He may have called time on his annual Magic Show tour, but he has no plans to cut down on his other commitments. Lucrative cabaret for corporate events, after-dinner speaking, 'designing' effects for musicals and product launches: these things keep Mr and Mrs Daniels in cars, new DVD systems and Caribbean holidays. (He's a little cross that the BBC recently sent a docusoap crew to his favourite resort in Barbados. 'They gave it the tabloid treatment. And it really is much better than that. Why else would I have gone there for 20 years, you know? It's not as they depicted it at all. Who cares about life downstairs? Who goes down there, for Chrissake? You live in your room and the salons and the foyers. My God, my French is improving here.') He certainly feels no inclination to retire, or anything dull like that. No: he follows his mother's example. The other day, he noticed that she had a blackened fingernail. She explained she'd crushed it while lugging some paving slabs around the garden. She's 83.

'People imagine that if you're not on television, you're out of work and starving to death. The truth of the matter is, of course, that you can't make a living only out of television. Well, you can - does it sound bigtime? - at my level.'

Of course it sounds bigtime. Daniels has always tootled his horn at volume. Settling down on the patio, surveying his acres, his river view, a garage full of fine motors tucked away just out of sight, he's very Toadish indeed. When the sun has the temerity to pop behind a cloud, there is a discreet mechanical hum as the overhead canopy automatically furls itself away. 'When the sun goes in, it goes in,' he points out.

'It's magic!' I joke.

But Daniels is sternly literal. 'No! This' - gesturing - 'is an electronic world of wonder. Not quite finished yet. But fabulous, yes.'

The autobiography has the same boisterously immodest quality, in spades. Here are a few artless picture captions to give you a flavour: 'The Ferrari. My brother, Trevor, was pleased when he got to drive it on my wedding day'; 'No, it's not a trick photograph. I was trading in the Bentley on the left for the one on the right. Now there's posh!'; 'Enjoying the tranquillity of the garden at our previous house. It was once owned by Roger Moore of 007 fame.' Daniels enjoys the good things in life because, as he says, 'I've earned the damn things, and I can afford it.'

Whether he can afford his next and most mind-boggling trick remains to be seen. The Vanishing Elephant, the Magic Kettle That Poured Any Drink, the Houdini Water Torture Escape... all of these famous illusions pale in comparison to Daniels' forthcoming project: The Magician Who Launched A Ballet Company. The storehouses in North Lincolnshire that once accommodated all his magic paraphernalia - his guillotines and birdcages and decks of cards - are being emptied out and gutted, to be replaced with barres and mirrors. Debbie, a one-time soloist with the Iranian National Ballet, will be the company's artistic director, choreographer and costume designer. Her husband, who is investing heavily, will be 'building in the visual effects'. Poop-poop! It all sounds kitsch beyond belief.

Ballet Imaginaire's production of Coppelia opens in Lincoln in September, nine months to the day after Daniels first suggested it to Debbie, because 'nine months is a proper time for a birth. It's our baby, yes. It'll be the first really high-profile touring ballet because none of the others, without conceit, will have celebrity adjuncts, any add-ons. I'm an add-on! So it'll be fascinating.' With bullish certainty, he says he's not at all apprehensive about this new venture. 'I was in Molière - not Molière . Yes, Molière - a couple of years ago. I loved it. I've presented QED and Medical Express and all this stuff; I love doing things that I don't normally do, and it comes quite easily to me. It annoys people enormously.'

Debbie has dragged her husband along to plenty of ballets over the years, but he can't cite one performance that he particularly enjoyed. 'They stick in the mind for the wrong reasons. Every time I went to one of these things, I thought: "I wouldn't put this scenery behind a pantomime!" And, 'Aren't these costumes naff?" And, "Why are they doing that, Debbie?" No, I wasn't a great ballet fan beforehand. I come from a north-east industrial town where you were kind of brought up to believe that ballet dancers were ponces. It took years to realise that they were fitter than footballers.'

Debbie, daintily turned out in a pencil skirt, tan stilettoes and apricot shell top that matches her lipstick and the fruit juice she is carrying on a tray, comes tripping out of the house. At 42, she's 20 years younger than her husband, and superfeminine and supercoiffed in the way that only perfume-counter assistants seem to be nowadays. Friendly and utterly without guile, Debbie talks deferentially about 'Paul' and 'us', whereas her husband talks about 'me' and 'I'.

Spotting that she has a few slices of white bread to hand, the ducks come charging up the lawn. 'Where's your photographer now?' asks Daniels, raising his eyebrows (amateurs!). He cups his hands around his mouth and bellows, foghornlike: 'Eva! Eva! Eva! Eva!'

Perhaps I should go and find her.

'Well, it's a good shot,' says Daniels sagely. The photographer approaches at a gallop, and is reprimanded. 'You must move slowly, Eva, or the ducks get frightened.' Watching his wife having her picture taken with the ducks, his attention wanders away from our conversation. As she shreds the bread with perfectly manicured nails, he says, 'Debbie. That's a bit big . Are you all right? What's going on? Can you get rid of that plastic bird? Why don't you go on the grass?'

On the Paul Daniels website, this is how he sums himself up: 'Height: 5ft 5in. Favourite colour: blue. Favourite food: anything except cauliflower cheese sauce. Dislikes: inefficiency, idleness, centre-lane drivers, over-the-top use of traffic cones, war, violence and murder, especially when they come in the name of religion.'

Daniels was born 62 years ago in South Bank near Middlesbrough, where his father was the projectionist at the Hippodrome cinema. A conspicuously short child, he was a loner until the age of 11 when, convalescing at the home of a family friend in the Yorkshire countryside, he pulled an old book called How to Entertain at Parties out of the shelves. An 'excellent antidote' to his natural shyness, magic was also a way of deterring bullies. 'Magic does give you a sort of power. If you are a quiet, shy kid, there is an awareness that hey, yes, this is a bit special. And, therefore, even to yourself, you are elevated slightly.' After grammar school, he started to work for Eston Urban Borough Council as a junior clerk, rising to the position of internal auditor. He married a colleague at the council, had three sons, and started carving out a reputation on the Working Men's Club circuit after hours. In 1970, he made his TV debut on Opportunity Knocks (and came second, as the letter inviting him to appear on the programme had told him he would). Guest spots on variety shows followed. By the time he had his own series, his marriage had fallen apart. These were the 'mad years': a while back on a train journey, he scribbled a list of the women he'd slept with, and gave up around 300.

In 1979, he turned up at the rehearsal rooms in Shepherd's Bush to start work on his Great Yarmouth summer show. And there, perched on a wall, was the diminutive Debbie McGee. He was 40; she was 20. What did he first notice about her? 'She was easy to spot, she was the only one there. "Who's this old tart sitting on this wall?"'

His wife's smile does not falter. 'I was early,' she explains.

Debbie ('Height: 5ft 1in. Weight: 7st 3lb. Hobbies: tennis, piano, reading, clothes. Favourite colour: pale pink. Pet hates: smelly people') grew up in Surrey. She always adored showbiz ('I was just in love with the business of performing') and at 15 was accepted by the Royal Ballet School to study for its teaching diploma. After that 'I was actually offered places with a couple of big European ballet companies, but I decided to accept at the Iranian National Ballet. I was very mercenary because they were paying the most money - double what the Royal Ballet corps de ballet were.' So off she went to Iran, performing Swan Lake for the Shah while beady-eyed guards with machine-guns stood in the wings. The company was loaded, and so able to recruit retired ballerinas, such as Svetlana Beriosova (who gave Debbie private coaching when, after six weeks, she was made a soloist), and choreographers, such as Alvin Ailey. All the scenery - like most of the 150 dancers - was imported from Europe or the States. Small wonder, somehow, that the Revolution followed shortly afterwards.

Back in the UK, desperate for work and feeling that she'd lost 'the ballet bug', Debbie auditioned for a summer show. 'I needed a job, basically. I'd never even heard of Paul Daniels. Came home, rang a load of friends up. "I've got a job with this guy Paul Daniels, what does he do?" And when they told me, I thought: "Oh God no, I hate magic, I've signed a contract for four and a half months... in Great Yarmouth." I was dreading it.' She saw him acting the fool on Blankety Blank , stripping down to Superman underpants, and was not impressed. Later, she had a change of heart. When Mrs Merton famously asked her, 'What was it that first attracted you to the short, balding millionaire Paul Daniels?' she said he made her laugh. They were together intermittently for just under 10 years before he finally popped the question in 1987.

Paul says it was a very conscious decision to wait for so long before making an honest woman of Debbie. 'Now, if we'd got married when she was 20 and I was 40, the press would have shredded us. But, nevertheless, at 30, this is a woman who has made her mind up. This is not a passing fad or fancy, she is not a gold-digger and I am not an older-man-going-for-a-younger-bird. She was 30 years old. Perfect timing.'

Debbie: 'I had no idea that Paul was going to propose, but, by then, we were in a very steady, stable...'

Paul: 'No, we'd moved out of the stable, we were in the mansion by then.'

Debbie (doggedly): 'Before then we'd been together and apart, but by this stage we'd been together for two years, so I knew things were quite serious. But I wasn't really expecting_'

Paul: 'When was I ever serious?'

Debbie: 'Well, exactly. But I mean, you know, I couldn't think of the word. My vocabulary's a bit short.'

When I ask Paul for the key to the success of their relationship, there's a pause while he puts his head on one side and considers the question. 'Well. Um... I'm funny!' My eyes flick involuntarily to Debbie, bolt upright in her chair, ankles tidily crossed, a smile soldered to her face. 'We laugh all the time, don't we?' he continues, oblivious. 'We really are good friends, good laughers. Debbie does occasionally try to have a row with me. I'm not the tidiest fella in town, you know.'

Debbie: '99 per cent of the time we hardly ever have a cross word. We don't actually row.'

'Although,' interjects Paul, 'it is astonishing how often you are wrong.'

Debbie (an airhostess in turbulence): 'I'll agree to disagree on that.'

Later, she says that the nine years she spent in limbo, waiting for Daniels to settle down, were pretty painful. 'Oh yes, because I really wanted to be serious. He kept saying, "Go away, you're much too young for me, find somebody your own age." I got terribly hurt sometimes. I wanted us to be together. I didn't have any sense that it would work out in the end. I never thought he would actually take that extra step.'

Throughout this period, of course, the pair were working together constantly. Debbie swears that she never had a moment's regret about becoming a magician's assistant. 'I did meet someone who was at the Royal Ballet School the year before me, and she said, "Oh Deborah," - they didn't call me Debbie - "Did I see you jumping out of a box or something on a Royal Variety Performance ?" But I can't really understand it when people ask me what it feels like to have taken second best. I worked with Abba and Chris de Burgh, toured in Europe, did all this television work, lovely work, earning a lot more money than if I'd been working as a ballet dancer. I learned my craft and now I feel so relaxed on stage. Now I've got this opportunity to give all this knowledge I've got to other performers. I just feel lucky that I stopped dancing properly when I was about 24. I think I've saved my body.' It was Debbie's decision not to have children. Though Paul's oldest son from his first marriage has been in trouble with the police and nowadays has more contact with the tabloids than his dad ('TV Paul Daniels' son is a down and out!'), he and Debbie are close to the younger two.

This house on the river was bought a few years ago, when they wearied of their last home, which had seven bathrooms and a staff of five. They wanted a simpler life, with a view of moorhens and only the occasional visit from a cleaning lady. 'It was the ugliest property on the river, and now people go by and say: "Oooh, look at that,"' says Daniels, Toadishly. 'That's a great tip for investment, you know. Always buy the worst house on the best street.' Out went the hessian wallhangings (shreds of which you can still see in some far-flung corridors) and the old purple and orange Hygiena kitchens. In came spanking new cornicework and cream sofas as long as cruise ships. 'And we have a Linley look in the woodworking, do you see?' points out Daniels. 'Well, no, he didn't do it, but it's very derivative. I'm not sure who made it, but I suspect he works awfully close to Lord Linley. You'll notice that because of the line of the willows there, people can't really see us, right? In the winter, when the boat licences run out, the leaves fall off and the view expands. It's just pole position. Absolutely pole position.'

While the pair pose obligingly on their swing seat, I potter in the kitchen. The video collection includes La Fille Mal Gardée, Murder She Wrote and Emmanuelle . Next to the Smeg hob, two cookbooks are propped open on twin stands, at recipes for Fillet of Sole With Banana And Cream, and Tart Lemon Tart. For the first years of their marriage, Debbie was famous for never cooking the same meal twice in a year. She's a little less strict about that nowadays and today is adept at conjuring hash and curry out of leftovers. When the photos have been taken, she busily fixes up cups of tea and hands round a plate of almond slices and mini Bakewells while Daniels continues to reminisce. 'And I won all the comedy awards. There are boxes somewhere of awards and trophies and things. I'll sell 'em,' he says airily. 'I don't want to dust 'em. Ha ha ha! It was nice to get 'em, but...'

Debbie distributes napkins. 'I've unpacked quite a few in your office,' she says helpfully.

'I've wondered where all this rubbish is coming from,' roars her husband excitedly. 'It's you! Divorce! Scoop! Divorce!'

Debbie sees me off into the taxi. I watch her picking her way back across the gravel, heading for the plate-glass of the dining-room extension, and for some reason I am reminded of the Houdini Water Torture Escape. I hope Debbie knows that the padlock is a dummy. I hope she knows it's all done with false lids.

A pint-sized telly colossus during the 80s, he bestrode a world of wide lapels and sequinned dollybirds and Seaside Specials and cheesy grins, without bothering to disguise a certain anti-populist bloody-mindedness. Though he married his magic with comedy banter learned from American one-liner books, you could not have mistaken him for a warm man. Unlike the Brucies and Tarbies, he never courted affection. He is, he says proudly, a wizzywig. 'Know what that is? WYSIWYG? What You See Is What You Get. I'm not precious. I'm me. I don't put on any airs and graces, which sometimes upsets people.' The papers were always full of Paul Daniels. He refused to sign a petition supporting the rights of Aids sufferers to have children; he raised funds for the Tories; he boasted about the wealth he'd accumulated through shrewd investment; he stifled rivalry by never inviting younger 'patter' magicians to do guest spots on his shows; he remarked that, like Jesus, he too could walk on water. In addition, 'the mini magician' had a short fuse and, for a brief period, wore a wig that made a deep impression on Spitting Image puppeteers. In other words, he was the flip side of Tommy Cooper: technically accomplished with wand and saw, but seriously short on charm. In 1995, when audience figures slumped, Alan Yentob pulled the string which released the trap door, at which point Daniels and Debbie, his assistant, suddenly vanished - pouff! - from the BBC schedules. Though he was indignant at the time about the way this was handled, he now insists he's well out of television. 'I never realised what a strain it was. I don't get uptight, I'm a cool guy. But when I found out I wasn't going to be doing any more series, I really went: "Phew."' In any case, television studios aren't the same now, being stuffed with 'nerds': people 'who've been to university and have degrees in media and communications_ who don't understand this peculiar emotion called theatre'. You may think that magic is a dying art, having been hijacked by the tiger acts of Vegas and the subversive antics of Penn and Teller, but Daniels insists that his act is evergreen. 'I'm an oddity, you see. The rest of the world of magic looks at me with some amazement. They can't figure out how I can do a tiny trick with a cup and a ball in a 7,000-seater hall. But I do. And everybody laughs.' He may have called time on his annual Magic Show tour, but he has no plans to cut down on his other commitments. Lucrative cabaret for corporate events, after-dinner speaking, 'designing' effects for musicals and product launches: these things keep Mr and Mrs Daniels in cars, new DVD systems and Caribbean holidays. (He's a little cross that the BBC recently sent a docusoap crew to his favourite resort in Barbados. 'They gave it the tabloid treatment. And it really is much better than that. Why else would I have gone there for 20 years, you know? It's not as they depicted it at all. Who cares about life downstairs? Who goes down there, for Chrissake? You live in your room and the salons and the foyers. My God, my French is improving here.') He certainly feels no inclination to retire, or anything dull like that. No: he follows his mother's example. The other day, he noticed that she had a blackened fingernail. She explained she'd crushed it while lugging some paving slabs around the garden. She's 83. 'People imagine that if you're not on television, you're out of work and starving to death. The truth of the matter is, of course, that you can't make a living only out of television. Well, you can - does it sound bigtime? - at my level.' Of course it sounds bigtime. Daniels has always tootled his horn at volume. Settling down on the patio, surveying his acres, his river view, a garage full of fine motors tucked away just out of sight, he's very Toadish indeed. When the sun has the temerity to pop behind a cloud, there is a discreet mechanical hum as the overhead canopy automatically furls itself away. 'When the sun goes in, it goes in,' he points out. 'It's magic!' I joke. But Daniels is sternly literal. 'No! This' - gesturing - 'is an electronic world of wonder. Not quite finished yet. But fabulous, yes.' The autobiography has the same boisterously immodest quality, in spades. Here are a few artless picture captions to give you a flavour: 'The Ferrari. My brother, Trevor, was pleased when he got to drive it on my wedding day'; 'No, it's not a trick photograph. I was trading in the Bentley on the left for the one on the right. Now there's posh!'; 'Enjoying the tranquillity of the garden at our previous house. It was once owned by Roger Moore of 007 fame.' Daniels enjoys the good things in life because, as he says, 'I've earned the damn things, and I can afford it.' Whether he can afford his next and most mind-boggling trick remains to be seen. The Vanishing Elephant, the Magic Kettle That Poured Any Drink, the Houdini Water Torture Escape... all of these famous illusions pale in comparison to Daniels' forthcoming project: The Magician Who Launched A Ballet Company. The storehouses in North Lincolnshire that once accommodated all his magic paraphernalia - his guillotines and birdcages and decks of cards - are being emptied out and gutted, to be replaced with barres and mirrors. Debbie, a one-time soloist with the Iranian National Ballet, will be the company's artistic director, choreographer and costume designer. Her husband, who is investing heavily, will be 'building in the visual effects'. Poop-poop! It all sounds kitsch beyond belief. Ballet Imaginaire's production of Coppelia opens in Lincoln in September, nine months to the day after Daniels first suggested it to Debbie, because 'nine months is a proper time for a birth. It's our baby, yes. It'll be the first really high-profile touring ballet because none of the others, without conceit, will have celebrity adjuncts, any add-ons. I'm an add-on! So it'll be fascinating.' With bullish certainty, he says he's not at all apprehensive about this new venture. 'I was in Molière - not Molière . Yes, Molière - a couple of years ago. I loved it. I've presented QED and Medical Express and all this stuff; I love doing things that I don't normally do, and it comes quite easily to me. It annoys people enormously.' Debbie has dragged her husband along to plenty of ballets over the years, but he can't cite one performance that he particularly enjoyed. 'They stick in the mind for the wrong reasons. Every time I went to one of these things, I thought: "I wouldn't put this scenery behind a pantomime!" And, 'Aren't these costumes naff?" And, "Why are they doing that, Debbie?" No, I wasn't a great ballet fan beforehand. I come from a north-east industrial town where you were kind of brought up to believe that ballet dancers were ponces. It took years to realise that they were fitter than footballers.' Debbie, daintily turned out in a pencil skirt, tan stilettoes and apricot shell top that matches her lipstick and the fruit juice she is carrying on a tray, comes tripping out of the house. At 42, she's 20 years younger than her husband, and superfeminine and supercoiffed in the way that only perfume-counter assistants seem to be nowadays. Friendly and utterly without guile, Debbie talks deferentially about 'Paul' and 'us', whereas her husband talks about 'me' and 'I'. Spotting that she has a few slices of white bread to hand, the ducks come charging up the lawn. 'Where's your photographer now?' asks Daniels, raising his eyebrows (amateurs!). He cups his hands around his mouth and bellows, foghornlike: 'Eva! Eva! Eva! Eva!' Perhaps I should go and find her. 'Well, it's a good shot,' says Daniels sagely. The photographer approaches at a gallop, and is reprimanded. 'You must move slowly, Eva, or the ducks get frightened.' Watching his wife having her picture taken with the ducks, his attention wanders away from our conversation. As she shreds the bread with perfectly manicured nails, he says, 'Debbie. That's a bit big . Are you all right? What's going on? Can you get rid of that plastic bird? Why don't you go on the grass?' On the Paul Daniels website, this is how he sums himself up: 'Height: 5ft 5in. Favourite colour: blue. Favourite food: anything except cauliflower cheese sauce. Dislikes: inefficiency, idleness, centre-lane drivers, over-the-top use of traffic cones, war, violence and murder, especially when they come in the name of religion.' Daniels was born 62 years ago in South Bank near Middlesbrough, where his father was the projectionist at the Hippodrome cinema. A conspicuously short child, he was a loner until the age of 11 when, convalescing at the home of a family friend in the Yorkshire countryside, he pulled an old book called How to Entertain at Parties out of the shelves. An 'excellent antidote' to his natural shyness, magic was also a way of deterring bullies. 'Magic does give you a sort of power. If you are a quiet, shy kid, there is an awareness that hey, yes, this is a bit special. And, therefore, even to yourself, you are elevated slightly.' After grammar school, he started to work for Eston Urban Borough Council as a junior clerk, rising to the position of internal auditor. He married a colleague at the council, had three sons, and started carving out a reputation on the Working Men's Club circuit after hours. In 1970, he made his TV debut on Opportunity Knocks (and came second, as the letter inviting him to appear on the programme had told him he would). Guest spots on variety shows followed. By the time he had his own series, his marriage had fallen apart. These were the 'mad years': a while back on a train journey, he scribbled a list of the women he'd slept with, and gave up around 300. In 1979, he turned up at the rehearsal rooms in Shepherd's Bush to start work on his Great Yarmouth summer show. And there, perched on a wall, was the diminutive Debbie McGee. He was 40; she was 20. What did he first notice about her? 'She was easy to spot, she was the only one there. "Who's this old tart sitting on this wall?"' His wife's smile does not falter. 'I was early,' she explains. Debbie ('Height: 5ft 1in. Weight: 7st 3lb. Hobbies: tennis, piano, reading, clothes. Favourite colour: pale pink. Pet hates: smelly people') grew up in Surrey. She always adored showbiz ('I was just in love with the business of performing') and at 15 was accepted by the Royal Ballet School to study for its teaching diploma. After that 'I was actually offered places with a couple of big European ballet companies, but I decided to accept at the Iranian National Ballet. I was very mercenary because they were paying the most money - double what the Royal Ballet corps de ballet were.' So off she went to Iran, performing Swan Lake for the Shah while beady-eyed guards with machine-guns stood in the wings. The company was loaded, and so able to recruit retired ballerinas, such as Svetlana Beriosova (who gave Debbie private coaching when, after six weeks, she was made a soloist), and choreographers, such as Alvin Ailey. All the scenery - like most of the 150 dancers - was imported from Europe or the States. Small wonder, somehow, that the Revolution followed shortly afterwards. Back in the UK, desperate for work and feeling that she'd lost 'the ballet bug', Debbie auditioned for a summer show. 'I needed a job, basically. I'd never even heard of Paul Daniels. Came home, rang a load of friends up. "I've got a job with this guy Paul Daniels, what does he do?" And when they told me, I thought: "Oh God no, I hate magic, I've signed a contract for four and a half months... in Great Yarmouth." I was dreading it.' She saw him acting the fool on Blankety Blank , stripping down to Superman underpants, and was not impressed. Later, she had a change of heart. When Mrs Merton famously asked her, 'What was it that first attracted you to the short, balding millionaire Paul Daniels?' she said he made her laugh. They were together intermittently for just under 10 years before he finally popped the question in 1987. Paul says it was a very conscious decision to wait for so long before making an honest woman of Debbie. 'Now, if we'd got married when she was 20 and I was 40, the press would have shredded us. But, nevertheless, at 30, this is a woman who has made her mind up. This is not a passing fad or fancy, she is not a gold-digger and I am not an older-man-going-for-a-younger-bird. She was 30 years old. Perfect timing.' Debbie: 'I had no idea that Paul was going to propose, but, by then, we were in a very steady, stable...' Paul: 'No, we'd moved out of the stable, we were in the mansion by then.' Debbie (doggedly): 'Before then we'd been together and apart, but by this stage we'd been together for two years, so I knew things were quite serious. But I wasn't really expecting_' Paul: 'When was I ever serious?' Debbie: 'Well, exactly. But I mean, you know, I couldn't think of the word. My vocabulary's a bit short.' When I ask Paul for the key to the success of their relationship, there's a pause while he puts his head on one side and considers the question. 'Well. Um... I'm funny!' My eyes flick involuntarily to Debbie, bolt upright in her chair, ankles tidily crossed, a smile soldered to her face. 'We laugh all the time, don't we?' he continues, oblivious. 'We really are good friends, good laughers. Debbie does occasionally try to have a row with me. I'm not the tidiest fella in town, you know.' Debbie: '99 per cent of the time we hardly ever have a cross word. We don't actually row.' 'Although,' interjects Paul, 'it is astonishing how often you are wrong.' Debbie (an airhostess in turbulence): 'I'll agree to disagree on that.' Later, she says that the nine years she spent in limbo, waiting for Daniels to settle down, were pretty painful. 'Oh yes, because I really wanted to be serious. He kept saying, "Go away, you're much too young for me, find somebody your own age." I got terribly hurt sometimes. I wanted us to be together. I didn't have any sense that it would work out in the end. I never thought he would actually take that extra step.' Throughout this period, of course, the pair were working together constantly. Debbie swears that she never had a moment's regret about becoming a magician's assistant. 'I did meet someone who was at the Royal Ballet School the year before me, and she said, "Oh Deborah," - they didn't call me Debbie - "Did I see you jumping out of a box or something on a Royal Variety Performance ?" But I can't really understand it when people ask me what it feels like to have taken second best. I worked with Abba and Chris de Burgh, toured in Europe, did all this television work, lovely work, earning a lot more money than if I'd been working as a ballet dancer. I learned my craft and now I feel so relaxed on stage. Now I've got this opportunity to give all this knowledge I've got to other performers. I just feel lucky that I stopped dancing properly when I was about 24. I think I've saved my body.' It was Debbie's decision not to have children. Though Paul's oldest son from his first marriage has been in trouble with the police and nowadays has more contact with the tabloids than his dad ('TV Paul Daniels' son is a down and out!'), he and Debbie are close to the younger two. This house on the river was bought a few years ago, when they wearied of their last home, which had seven bathrooms and a staff of five. They wanted a simpler life, with a view of moorhens and only the occasional visit from a cleaning lady. 'It was the ugliest property on the river, and now people go by and say: "Oooh, look at that,"' says Daniels, Toadishly. 'That's a great tip for investment, you know. Always buy the worst house on the best street.' Out went the hessian wallhangings (shreds of which you can still see in some far-flung corridors) and the old purple and orange Hygiena kitchens. In came spanking new cornicework and cream sofas as long as cruise ships. 'And we have a Linley look in the woodworking, do you see?' points out Daniels. 'Well, no, he didn't do it, but it's very derivative. I'm not sure who made it, but I suspect he works awfully close to Lord Linley. You'll notice that because of the line of the willows there, people can't really see us, right? In the winter, when the boat licences run out, the leaves fall off and the view expands. It's just pole position. Absolutely pole position.' While the pair pose obligingly on their swing seat, I potter in the kitchen. The video collection includes La Fille Mal Gardée, Murder She Wrote and Emmanuelle . Next to the Smeg hob, two cookbooks are propped open on twin stands, at recipes for Fillet of Sole With Banana And Cream, and Tart Lemon Tart. For the first years of their marriage, Debbie was famous for never cooking the same meal twice in a year. She's a little less strict about that nowadays and today is adept at conjuring hash and curry out of leftovers. When the photos have been taken, she busily fixes up cups of tea and hands round a plate of almond slices and mini Bakewells while Daniels continues to reminisce. 'And I won all the comedy awards. There are boxes somewhere of awards and trophies and things. I'll sell 'em,' he says airily. 'I don't want to dust 'em. Ha ha ha! It was nice to get 'em, but...' Debbie distributes napkins. 'I've unpacked quite a few in your office,' she says helpfully. 'I've wondered where all this rubbish is coming from,' roars her husband excitedly. 'It's you! Divorce! Scoop! Divorce!' Debbie sees me off into the taxi. I watch her picking her way back across the gravel, heading for the plate-glass of the dining-room extension, and for some reason I am reminded of the Houdini Water Torture Escape. I hope Debbie knows that the padlock is a dummy. I hope she knows it's all done with false lids.

webTitle: The way we live now: Hate male

fields.headline: The way we live now: Hate male
fields.standfirst: Why British men hates their exes
fields.trailText: Why British men hates their exes
fields.body:
Carl Friedan has a bit of a thing about his ex-wife Betty, US author of the feminist blockbuster The Feminine Mystique . Not only is she 'the most violent person' he knows, with a 'streak of lunacy that permeates her personality' but - in 19 years of marriage - she never once gave him a blow job. We know all this because Carl Friedan has just told us so on a website (www.carlfriedan.com), mostly dedicated to dissing his ex-wife, which, he says, has been created in response to accusations made by her. Of course, he says, he's proud of her achievements, but that doesn't stop him voicing some frank caveats. 'It took a monster,' he explains, 'a driven, super-aggressive, egocentric, almost lunatic dynamo to rock the world the way [Betty] did. Unfortunately, she was that same person at home.'

Carl Friedan is 81 and has been divorced for 30 years. You'd think by now he'd have got over it. But no. He's got time on his hands, so why not spend it doing down the ex as nastily and publicly as possible? Forget gentlemanliness or, indeed, any idea of masculinity being associated with gentility. Men don't do that nowadays. The prevailing culture is one of emotional hooliganism, fuelled by the excuse of searing honesty. And what these men feel compelled to be most honest about are their feelings of hatred for the women they once loved. Cheerio bitch, you can almost hear them saying, as they publicly expose and vilify the ex.

Some would say it's the biter bit: men can be vile to women because women have been calling them irrelevant no-gooders for the past 30 years. Whatever, there's obviously a market for it. A trickle that started in the late-80s with the embittered Neil Lyndon has turned into a flood. Now we've got Hanif Kureishi's Intimacy , a thinly disguised novel considered a 'hate letter' to his ex-partner and mother of his twins, Tracey Scoffield. There's Joseph Stone's weekly Guardian column, ostensibly about co-parenting, but in which he takes gratuitous side-swipes at his ex-wife Dilys. There's Terence Conran who, in rage at third wife Caroline's £10.5m divorce settlement, publicly dismissed any contribution she might have made to the Conran empire; and US billionaire Ron Perelman who, in an ongoing battle over child custody, discredits and humiliates his ex-wife Patricia Duff at every turn.

Then there's Tim Lott, the dreaded Tim Lott. Women now quail at his name - all thanks to The Separation, a short non-fiction (or long whinge) about the breakdown of his marriage. In it, he dished the emotional dirt on ex-wife Sarina in a horribly self-serving manner, 'tearing away the veils' of privacy in the name of writing 'something worthwhile'. He might think this is great literature, but it reads as vendetta by exposure - and most of it is aimed at Sarina's private parts.

This catalogue of male meanness isn't meant to suggest that pain, rage and the revenge impulse are gender specific: it's patently clear that both sexes can behave appallingly when a relationship breaks down. But men do have an impressive capacity for the kind of monolithic thinking which instantly turns the once-loved into the eternally despised. Their impulse is to switch off and move on without recourse to rational thought. This is nowhere so explicit as in that recent episode of C4's shrink satire Frasier. Niles (Frasier's brother) secretly married his sexless, manipulative, controlling, plastic surgeon girlfriend. Only to run off 10 minutes later with Daphne, the warm, sexy, naive, life-affirming family helpmate. Hello gorgeous Eve, goodbye gruesome Lilith.

Though it's now culturally acceptable for men to diss their exes, the bigger question is why they feel the need. 'You may as well ask why men read car advertisements for a car they've already bought. There's nothing worse than thinking you've made the wrong decision,' says psychotherapist Adam Jukes. As founder of the London Men's Centre, and author of Why Men Hate Women (Free Association Books) and Men Who Batter Women (Routledge), he's something of an expert on the male psyche. He believes there's more to men's response than just sour grapes, and pins it down to one big difference between the sexes: their ability to handle levels of ambivalence about the one they love. They want to punish their partner because she's not the perfect person they thought she was. Like emotional toddlers, they believe that if they can't love wholly, then, boohoo, they'll hate, denigrate and discredit. (And, incidentally, make themselves feel a lot better in the process.)

Of course, not all men think like this. Many are emotionally mature enough to be adorable to their ex-wives. Just look at Neil Diamond: the £100m divorce settlement he gave his ex Marcia was symptomatic of a larger emotional generosity. After 25 years of marriage, their life together was not dismissed or distorted. As Diamond simply said: 'She's been through thick and thin with me and deserves half my fortune. I'm happy to give it to her.'

What a grown up. What emotional intelligence. And the good news for Mr Friedan, when he stops having quite so much fun, is that it's never too late to learn.

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ... The Peugeot Design Awards
fields.trailText: ... The Peugeot Design Awards
fields.body:
One of the best things about the exhibition featuring the finalists for this year's Peugeot Design Awards is that you can actually touch and play with the products. The show, at Oxo Tower Wharf on London's South Bank, has none of the snooty attitudes towards design that can be so alienating. If a toddler wants to use Hector Serrano's innovative and humorous La Senora Potato Light as a punch bag, then he's welcome to it. A lightbulb is encased in a brightly coloured latex sock which is filled with salt. As you squidge the salt around, the brightness of the light moves with it. It's quite addictive. And if you want to test out the hinges on Michael Sodeau's elegant and seductive birch-veneer, curved Wing Unit chest, with doors that open out like wings, you can open and close them as much as you like.

Other highlights include Carl Clerkin's Bucket Seat, recycled out of a bucket handle and a broomstick for the legs (you can buy it, too - for £45), Deborah Bowness's larger-than-life photo wallpaper, and Martin Avery's ingeniously engineered chest of drawers, which is built so that the drawers slide on a central mechanism (they don't need an outer case to slide in and out of).

Most of the finalists chose to redesign familiar household objects. There's the U cup, that slots into its saucer and can't be knocked over, and a pair of bowls, one with a little dipping saucer built into the side of it, and another with a slot to hold chopsticks. These are already in production, priced £22 and £14 respectively.

The Peugeot Design Awards is now in its third year and ise seen as the design equivalent of the Turner prize. A panel of judges, including Ron Arad, Andrew Purves of Purves & Purves and Elle Deco 's Toni Rodgers, will choose an overall winner, to be announced 12 July. There is also a people's poll, where you can vote for the design you'd like in your home.

 Peugeot Design Awards, until 30 July at the.gallery@oxo, Oxo Tower Wharf, Bargehouse Street, South Bank, London SE1 (020 7401 2255). From 7-31 August, the exhibition will be at Nexus Galleries, 61 Bread Street, Edinburgh (0131 477 4524)

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... festival
fields.trailText: ... festival
fields.body:
Anticipation is key. You can only see your favourite band for the first time once - and that's what the perfect festival should be all about. For me, it was seeing New Order at Reading in 1998 because they had always been my favourite band - 'Blue Monday' opened my heart to poetry, it was so honest and naked - but I'd never seen them live. For some reason, security wouldn't let me watch them from the side of the stage, even though Blur were going to headline the gig next year. So I had to go out front to watch, but it turned out to be the best thing - I was totally moved to tears. I cried and jumped up and down - there is nothing like knowing all the songs and being at a gig that you've waited and waited for. The more excited you get about it, the more you endow the festival with meaning.

Being with 50,000 people who all feel the same way is very emotional. When I went to see the Pixies at Reading in 1989, there were all sorts of people wearing the same clothes as me and they all knew the words to the songs, like I did. There were people lighting bonfires, people letting rip_ some fucker jumped on my tent and pissed all over the guy ropes. Letting it all hang out is essential though - just getting excited about hearing the songs and being off your head. Lacking sleep and being slightly drunk is the best way to appreciate music. Any perturbed state of mind is good - whether it's down to adolescence, being in love or whatever. Music is louder for the tired and the unhappy.

Go with a girl you fancy if you can get her to go, but it's better to go with a group of lads because it's just like football. The festival is only as good as the bands who play - there's nothing exciting about mud and tents.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... ballooning
fields.trailText: ... ballooning
fields.body:
The sounds of a summer evening in the country: birdsong, a breeze rustling through trees, and the soft 'pssshht' of a hot air balloon's burner. So how do you go about joining this sedate group of aviators? First you ought to familiarise yourself with the concept of floating at an altitude of 1,000ft, relying on nothing more than the wind, nylon, wicker and physics. The theory is simple. A propane-fuelled burner heats air inside a canopy (the 'envelope'). The air becomes less dense and therefore lighter, so it rises, along with anything attached to it.

Almost all balloonists join the British Balloon and Airship Club (£28 for new members). At first you will crew for established pilots and retrieve their balloons, but you should gradually earn the 16 hours at the controls necessary for your pilot's licence (£200), but you will be tested on aviation law, navigation, balloon systems, human performance and meteorology.

An entry-level balloon costs from £14,000. This covers the entire package of 80,000 cubic feet of envelope (and three kilometres of stitching), the burner, basket and fuel tanks (40 litres each). However, second-hand balloons can be picked up for about £8,000, including the essential trailer (supply your own 4WD). Envelopes have a lifespan of 500 hours, and replacements are about £4,000, but about half of this can be offset if you sell advertising space on it.

The average balloon flight lasts an hour and uses about £20 worth of propane, but this depends on wind speed and direction. Special Ordnance Survey maps should help you avoid power lines, urban areas and farmers who prefer not to have their livestock startled. You are legally allowed to land almost anywhere as long as you compensate for any damage, so don't forget insurance (£800 third party for a crew of four). In-flight refreshment might include champagne (£20), but the views are free.

If you literally have money to burn, something like the Breitling Orbiter will set you back more than £1 million. Alternatively, a one-person 'cloudhopper' - you sit in a sling with a cylinder on your back - is just £10,000, although many would rather a parachute (£890).

BBAC membership £28
Tuition (optional) £2,700/course
Licence £200
Balloon £14,000 (£8,000 second-hand)
Replacement envelope £4,000
Propane £20/hour
Insurance £800
Parachute £890
Total from £10,028

webTitle: Fast forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: Fast forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: This week: Carl André
fields.trailText: This week: Carl André
fields.body:
Wasn't he the one who... Yes, yes - the artist whose bricks sculpture (Equivalent VIII) caused outrage in middle England when it was purchased by the Tate for a rumoured £6,000 in 1972.

Brickbats? 'Brick-a-brac art!' screamed the Daily Mail . Today, Equivalent VIII has a permanent home at Tate Modern. And now the organisers of Andre's new show, from 7 July to 27 August at the Whitechapel Gallery (80 Whitechapel High Street, London E1; information line 020 7522 7878; gallery 020 7522 7888), must be hoping that their 'fresh reintroduction' to the master of minimalism will finally consign the bricks furore to art history.

Aren't they banging their heads against a brick wall? Not in the least. Britain's obsession with art continues unabated, and following the recent Jackson Pollock retrospective, the time is right for a major survey of another f ted American.

Hod times? Enough already. Recent cedar sculptures as well as 60 poems and 'typewriter drawings' will be shown alongside Andre's grid-like floor pieces. And the artist himself, now 64 and still going strong, has been on hand to help install them.

What if I trip over a sculpture? No worries, some of it was designed to be walked on - it's all part of the sensual experience of materials, apparently. Better leave the stilettoes at home, though.

But is it art? Not that old chestnut. Andre sees himself as part of a long lineage of artists that leads back through Brancusi to Turner. He may have his critics but his biggest fans, says Andre, are children: 'They don't ask, "Is it art" - they just go ahead and move and jump around, reacting directly to it. Which is essentially what I do in making the work.'

Nice work if you can get it... Quite. But it wasn't ever thus. Andre was in the army for a while, and worked on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Earlier, he helped his father, a marine draughtsman, to design and build a house.

A chip off the old block? Precisely.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Zen and the art of business cycle maintenance | Jagger for the Mirror
fields.body:
Zen and the art of business cycle maintenance
Lis Murdoch finally winged her way out of BSkyB last Thursday with a lavish leaving party at the highly fashionable Momo restaurant. Salvers of nibbles including pigeon samosas were handed out to TV's glitterati . (One hopes they were not filled with the spavined and mangy inhabitants of nearby Trafalgar Square or it'll be psittacosis all round.)

While the Prebbles and the Yentobs mixed happily - people not cocktails - Lis was given the traditional leaving present of a Harley Davidson. Very handy for popping down the shops when you're heavily pregnant. This follows a long tradition of News Corp executives being given large things that throb between their legs; first it was Sam Chisholm who, on his departure from Oz for the top job at Sky was given a Harley; Tony Ball, the current chief executive, was given a Ducati when he left Fox in the US; and David Chance, former BSkyB managing director, was, again, given a Harley.

How different then from the BBC, where recently departing big hitters - David Docherty and Patricia Hodgson - were given only Spacehoppers by Greg Dyke. Clearly big bike macho status symbols is the only language News Corp executives understand. But aren't they a bit heavy for the mantlepiece - and a bugger to dust?

Sunny Sky turns a little cloudy
We remember that David Bergg, the head of programming at Sky, described his ideal target for Sky One as 'the Sunny Delight family'. A couple of points here: first, Guardian columnist Julie Burchill recently described a photo of Will Self and his wife, Independent columnist Deborah Orr, as looking like 'the family in a Sunny Delight ad'; second, worries over the amount of sugar in the drink have meant a hefty hit on sales.

It could be that Sky One is in fact aimed at post-modern novelists - which would explain a lot of its output as 'irony' - but clearly Bergg will have to swap his drinks analogy if he wants his West Wing to be seen by the wholesome nucleus of middle England.

Let's spend some money together
Following his brush with the share-trading authorities and top brass at Trinity Mirror, editor Piers Morgan has solved his City editor problems by hiring Mick Jagger. In a surprise move, the grandad rocker will be lifting the lid on the Financial Services Act and getting on down to the occasional interim results presentation.

Jagger has strong views on the benefits of financial organisations remaining mutual where possible and will be actively campaigning on important business issues such as fat-cat pay rises and the 35-hour week. Apparently Morgan hired him because he was impressed by what people described as Jagger's 'great tips' - which sadly turned out to be 'great lips'.

In a hiring mix-up, Telegraph City reporter Suzy Jagger is to front the Rolling Stones' next tour as gyrating vocalist.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Jackie Hickling's lifelong fear of worms intensified after she had a stroke. But through introspection, picture books and a  glass box containing a worm, psychotherapist Paul Salkovskis has been helping her to get over her phobia
fields.trailText: Jackie Hickling's lifelong fear of worms intensified after she had a stroke. But through introspection, picture books and a glass box containing a worm, psychotherapist Paul Salkovskis has been helping her to get over her phobia
fields.body:
Jackie Hickling

I've always hated worms. Even hearing the word 'worm' made me feel sick. I couldn't go for a walk or a bike ride with my children in case I saw one, and if it rained, I couldn't leave the house for fear of them squirming on to the pavement.

One of my earliest memories is of being at junior school when the teacher decided she'd get me over this fear by having a wormery in the classroom. One of the boys decided to fill my lift-up desk with worms. I screamed the place down, I was hysterical - and it's gone on from there.

After I had a stroke during the birth of my fourth child, Johnny, it got much worse. It was bad enough losing control of my left side, let alone losing control of my head. When Johnny was a toddler he escaped out of the yard towards the lake, but as I tried to chase him I saw a worm on the grass and couldn't get past it, even though I could see Johnny heading for the water. Robin, my eldest daughter, grabbed him just in time.

So when I heard the BBC was looking for phobics to participate in a science programme, I rang them. They wired me up to see how I'd react to a kiddie's picture of a worm smiling, and my blood pressure dropped so low they thought I was going to have another stroke. Then they introduced me to Paul. I walked into the room at Warneford Hospital in Oxford and there was this large man with grass cuttings on his trousers where he'd been mowing the lawn earlier, and I thought: 'Mad professor.' I was sceptical. But he got me to analyse myself. A lot of doctors talk down to you, or expect you won't understand things, whereas Paul talks to you on the same level. He's open and lets you into his life, talks about his wife and children. So I began to trust him.

He got down to the point of why I was scared of worms, what I knew about them. He asked if, because of the stroke, I was scared of dying. I said no. Then I told him about this repetitive vision of being in a box with worms around me. He showed me pictures of worms in a book, which I took home to practise touching the paper. Later he gave me a glass box and he put a worm in it, and I had to hold it. Ooh.

Paul's increased the quality of my life tremendously. I feel he's the first doctor to actually do something to help me. I'm a lot more normal. I'm in and out of hospitals a lot, so the time I do have with the children is precious. I can now go to watch them playing football in the park, whatever. I still freeze when I see a worm - I have palpitations and my heart races, but only for a few seconds, and I walk around it. I don't think I could have trusted anyone other than Paul.

Paul Salkovskis
Jackie was terrified when we first met. I knew she'd had a stroke and wasn't in the best physical health. I first had to identify how it was affecting her and what she feared might happen. Jackie was trying really hard not to think too much about what she was afraid of, which was unusual. She was also having fragmentary images of a worm, coming downwards. I asked her if she would close her eyes and picture it, which she was reluctant to do. As she calmed down, it turned out this worm was one of many. She was lying in a coffin and there were worms all around her; she couldn't move or scream. The fear that seemed to be driving this wasn't worms, per se, but being trapped in a coffin.

She'd had a stroke and become immobilised, unable to speak. My strong hunch was that she had a fear of worms, then had a stroke and started envisaging what could happen, and a locked-in syndrome developed. One of the things that we teach people to do is to stay in control, but Jackie could only use one hand. So to have a worm wriggling around was much harder to control, which meant treatment took longer. I also didn't want to put her blood pressure up because she'd had a stroke, so I had to balance out her anxiety with the need to keep things moving.

Gradually, I got her used to having worms in her hand, then going out into the grass and getting used to the worms you can't see. One of the things about fears is that the thing we can't see is often more frightening than that which you can.

My aim with Jackie was to get completely rid of the fear. For 71 per cent of people we see, a year after treatment there is no residual problem. With the other 29 per cent, it isn't that they aren't improved, it's just that they need a bit more of the same. For Jackie, there was an intermediate end, which was walking on grass and dealing with the restrictions in her life.

She's still got some fear and needs further treatment.

You have to bear in mind the importance of helping people to feel understood, and I give that the highest priority. If you don't believe in them, and you think it's pathetic, you'll be a lousy therapist. One of the things I'm aware of with someone like Jackie is that they're often very self-critical, thinking they are neurotic, weak and anxious. In fact, the exact opposite is true. You have to think about what it means to be courageous: it's to feel afraid and to do what you have to do anyway. Jackie was enormously brave and strong.

 Jackie's story will be part of Phobia , a BBC1 series starting on12 July at 7.30pm

webTitle: No mercy on dotcom death row

fields.headline: No mercy on dotcom death row
fields.standfirst:
A large number of e-tailers are condemned to die... and it will be established retailers who are pressing 'execute', says Jamie Doward
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A large number of e-tailers are condemned to die... and it will be established retailers who are pressing 'execute', says Jamie Doward
fields.body:
When asked a couple of years ago what he thought of dotcom companies, IBM head Lou Gerstner described them as 'the fireflies before the storm'. Few observers today are as poetic, but numerous internet sites with names like fucked.com now chronicle the death throes of the e-tail sector, gleefully reporting the demise of the start-ups.

The gallows humour is not confined to net-heads bitter about the way the web has been exploited by commercial interests. Even analysts are calling e-tail companies 'radioactive'.

The depression that has swept the sector has even taken its toll on mighty Amazon, the internet's most visible e-tailer, which has seen its value crash from more than $30 billion to less than half that. Some analysts have expressed fears that the company will run out of cash by September, a claim hotly disputed by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos. Although the company had less than $100m in cash in the bank earlier this year, Amazon points out it has 10 times this in 'marketable securities' which can quickly be transformed into the folding stuff, thus funding future investment.

Amazon argues that it has been spending so much is because it has been building up a distribution network so as to be able to deliver as efficiently as possible - a move that will ensure customer loyalty and allow it to move into other areas and, hence, turn a profit.

But even Steve Frazier, Amazon UK's managing director, describes the firm as 'controversial'. 'It's not a stock that should be the major holding in your portfolio,' he says. ' Observer readers shouldn't take all their money out of their Isas and invest in Amazon. We've racked up some pretty big operating losses, but we understand we've got to make some pretty big profits in the future.'

The irony is that, despite its slump in value and the volatility of its stock, Amazon has a better chance of becoming a major player in the e-tail sector than virtually any other 'pure' internet company. The distribution network will create a barrier to entry which rivals will find it difficult to emulate and will give Amazon much greater control over inventory. Also, the Amazon brand is very powerful, and the company's management is regarded as strong.

Indeed, a recent report by influential Merrill Lynch analyst Henry Blodget has likened the position Amazon is in to the 'gawky adolescence' period of AOL in 1996, when commentators suggested it would never make money. Bezos himself asks investors to think ahead 10 years, rather than focusing on the short term. Small wonder. The predictions made for growth in the e-tail sector are huge. Gartner Group, for instance, estimates e-tail sales in the US at nearly $30bn this year, up 75 per cent on last year's figure. By 2004 the sector will account for 7 per cent of retail sales.

But while predictions for future growth are soaring, the value of the companies currently competing in the sector are crashing. In the US, a report from Goldman Sachs found that 10 publicly quoted e-tailers are burning money so quickly they will have to raise more in the coming months if they are not to go under. We have already seen online video distributor Reel.com collapse, while music e-tailer CDNow is in trouble. Others have had to find merger partners. Online grocery store Webvan recently bought HomeGrocer, and Pets.com has swallowed Petstore.

In the UK things look equally gloomy. A report by PricewaterhouseCoopers suggests that 25 of the 28 companies it studied are likely to run out of cash within 15 months because their operating costs are exceeding gross profits.

So who will fill the e-tail void caused by the dearth of the start-ups? 'We're about to see the revenge of the bricks,' said Andrew Peck of business consultancy The Smith Group.

David Pannell, consultant with Durlacher, agrees: 'Who will capture the growth in e-sales? The stock market is saying it will be established retailers, not the dotcoms.'

Consumers seem to share his view. A report out last week from BT suggested that even the strongest pure web players cannot compete a high street brand that has an online presence. The report found that 63 per cent of customers were inclined to trust whsmith.co.uk, against 59 per cent for Amazon. And some online brands are already losing their novelty value. Doug Wilson, a director with market analyst Datamonitor, says: 'If you shop at most online sites today it's the equivalent of going into a basic discount store. People in the offline world like to shop with retailers who offer customer service - such as Selfridge's, and are going to expect the equivalent online.'

Pressure on pure internet firms is likely to intensify dramatically in the coming months. The P500 report, a survey out this week by Online Research Agency, finds that although only 20 per cent of the UK's biggest firms currently have an e-commerce presence, by the end of this year half of them will be selling online. And the bricks- and-mortar firms have a significant advantage in the race to dominate the internet: money.

Tesco, for instance, now claims to be the biggest online grocer that delivers to your door. But each van Tesco uses to fulfil online purchase orders costs the retail giant nearly £1,000 a week, according to industry sources. 'The amount of money now being spent by the major corporations in comparison to start-ups is very similar, but in relative terms they haven't even begun to flex their muscles,' said Nick Rosen of Online Research.

Similarly, in the US, analysts at Forrester Research predict that companies such as Wal-Mart, Kmart and Toys 'R' Us, which have large inventories and huge customer bases, will emerge as major online players once the dust settles.

The events of last Christmas show how much pain the pure internet firms are likely to feel. According to a survey by internet analysis firm Media Metrix, nearly half of the 50 most visited sites during the holiday period had a strong bricks-and-mortar presence; only a handful of 'pure' websites made the list. Datamonitor's Wilson com ments: 'Internet companies have to spend a fortune building a brand, but Tesco doesn't have to spend much convincing people it's a grocer.'

One theory now in fashion is that many dotcoms will end up being swallowed by high street retailers looking for new business opportunities. 'Many will just get bought by established brands looking for a quick way to resolve their channel problems,' said Rosen at Online Research. 'For instance, a camera firm may not sell online because this would upset retailers who already sell its products, but acquiring an internet firm would get round this problem.'

This is not to say all pure e-tailers are doomed. 'There are going to be a lot of winners,' said Victor Basta, managing director of investment bank Broadview. 'Those companies that have established an online brand now will do well. If a company doesn't have a brand by now, it's too late.'

Some online firms will even be thankful for the cull. Basta adds: 'The money will be channelled to those firms which are seen as long-term successes. There will be less of a portfolio approach to investment.'

Nevertheless, the list of firms on dotcom death row is set to grow while the established retailers look for ways of commanding their turf.

Said Wilson: 'God tends to be on the side of the big battalions.'

webTitle: A thin argument for blaming broadcasters

fields.headline: A thin argument for blaming broadcasters
fields.trailText: Steve Barnett: On broadcast
fields.body:
For the past few months, my five-year-old daughter has been muttering darkly about being 'too fat'. Since she is not a regular viewer of Ally McBeal and doesn't, to my knowledge, intersperse her Postman Pat books with Marie Claire, it is difficult to know where this distorted self-image comes from. It has something to do with peer groups and playground chat, but I have no doubt somewhere in that complex mix of social conditioning lie the pervasive images of television, press and posters. no one knows whether a five-year-old's unthinking repetition becomes a 15-year-old's anorexia, but it is disturbing.

My reaction to the announcement by women's minister Tessa Jowell that television and magazines were to monitor how women's bodies were represented on TV was therefore rather different to the predictable hysteria of the tabloid press. The Daily Mail ' s front- page 'Lunacy of the TV weight watch police' was taken up by editorials condemning 'political correctness gone mad' ( Express ) and 'a total joke' ( Sun ).

It is slightly disappointing to discover that the study may not even happen: the Broadcasting Standards Commission has given no commitment to count fatties and thinnies on the box and is merely thinking, in the light of Jowell's 'body image summit', about whether such research is feasible and whether it wants to do it anyway.

What is fascinating about this furious reaction to an idea that may never happen is that the fury comes from the very same newspapers that tend to save their most savage bile for those who offend their rather precious standards of taste and decency. In recent weeks, Channel 5 in general and its chief executive David Elstein in particular have been the targets of malicious attacks simply because the channel dares to show some not very attractive dangly bits without a fig leaf. We see the same chorus of blinkered condemnation whenever some kind of violent atrocity can be tenuously linked to a TV programme or movie (never, of course, to something published in a newspaper). Anyone who's ever murdered their husband and buried his body under their patio would have been the model of law-abiding citizenship if only they hadn't succumbed to the temptation of watching Channel Four.

The reason for these outbursts of self-righteous fury lies in assumptions about TV's influence. Repeated use of four-letter words or scenes of nudity or mindless violence on TV are deemed at best to degrade viewers' delicate minds and at worst to persuade them that such behaviour should be mimicked in the real world at the earliest opportunity.

All this is unproven, unprovable and 95 per cent nonsense. Adults exposed to the now familiar 'strong language' that accompanies much contemporary drama are unlikely suddenly to expand their vocabulary when remonstrating with children or neighbours the following day. On the other hand, they are less likely to be surprised (or even offended) by the colourful language that often accompanies road rage or a post-soccer-match inquisition in the pub.

Similarly, watching an hour of Friday-night steamy heterosexual activity on Channel 5 is unlikely to send thousands of viewers off to copulate like rabbits all weekend. It may, however, remind those of us who may be having doubts (or memory loss) that sex can be quite pleasant.

Apply that model to TV violence, though, and I begin to side with the moralists. However much dramatic reality may demand it, there is always the nagging fear that graphic acts of violence on TV might somehow legitimise violent conduct among viewers who are that way inclined. But those who advance this argument must also accept the logical extension that other kinds of TV images - be it the negative portrayal of ethnic minorities or the constant parade of thin women who define female beauty - can also reinforce social norms which are undesirable.

Our obsession with taste and decency is not helped by the presence of two regulators expressly charged with looking after broadcasting's moral welfare. It scarcely matters how much thoughtful research the Independent Television Commission or the Broadcasting Standards Commission does on the role of broadcasting: as we saw this week with the publication of the BSC's annual report, the spotlight will always be on complaints about the f-word or Keith Chegwin's willy.

Perhaps the much-touted single regulator will provide an opportunity to change our research priorities. In the meantime, I hope the BSC does find a way to count fatties on the box.

S.Barnett@wmin.ac.uk

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Cookson | Chamberlin & Hill | Tarsus | ICM Computer Group
fields.body:
Keep an eye on Cookson, the industrial materials group, which embraces economies both old and new.

The shares have bounced of late following the market's switch back towards traditional stocks. But latest research suggests the stock is still trading at a 25 per cent discount to the group's 'sum of-the-parts valuation'.

Cookson's trouble is that it still suffers from the 'conglomerate' tag. Its better-known activities, in industrial ceramics and precious metals, are also seen as mature, despite being solid, reliable performers.

Nonetheless, Cookson now derives half its profits from electronics, chiefly the assembly and supply of chemicals and equipment for printed circuit boards. Unlocking the value of that business will, says broker Old Mutual (for merly Albert E Sharp), be exercising management as much as it did rival Johnson Matthey two years ago.

While a break-up à la Matthey may not immediately be on the cards, further disposals and refocusing should narrow the discount. At 220p, the shares are well below Old Mutual's 283p target price.

Iron in the soul
Think old 'old economy' stocks, and Midlands metal-bashers surely top the list. Walsall-based iron founder and light engineering outfit Chamberlin & Hill may not be getting invitations to e-commerce networking soirées. But over the past six years, its performance has been nothing if not consistent.

Profits have more than doubled, as have earnings. And there's every indication that steady growth will continue in the future.

Pity, then, the share price, which has tumbled this year as small companies such as this one remain out of fashion. It is, however, only a matter of time before the vogue for value trickles down to the likes of Chamberlin & Hill.

Such firms are clearly never going to set the world alight - but they do make it go round. And at 172p, trading on an earnings multiple of just 5 times, on a par with net assets and with no gearing, this metal-basher's shares offer considerable upside.

Ringing the changes
Tarsus, Neville Buch's new exhibitions company, is certainly ringing the changes to confront the challenge of the internet. Lately it has splashed out nearly £30 million on a couple of acquisitions, helped by a rights issue.

The first, Martex, brought 26 business-to-business trade websites, focusing on online trade directories and close relationships with trade associations. The second, Groupe MM, took it further into France in traditional trade exhibitions and magazines, plus an internet portal aimed at marketing managers.

Debt, consequently, is running high, but Tarsus is good at generating cash. The shares, 60 per cent owned by the management, are illiquid and have certainly been volatile. They are likely to remain so, but Buch, remember, made a packet building up and selling on Blenheim Exhibitions, and knows the business inside out.

At 340p, the stock is well below its 560p high, and in-house broker Charles Stanley's 462p target price.

Stubborn stance
If you'd followed the advice of Manchester broker Henry Cooke last week to buy shares in ICM Computer Group, you'll already be much the worse off. And serve you right. At 340p, the shares have tumbled from the 435p at which analyst Ray Burgum recommended buying ICM, one of the broker's clients.

The stance, notwithstanding a downbeat trading statement from ICM, is hardly surprising. Of 46 stocks covered by Henry Cooke this month, there's just one sell recommendation. As for ICM, the shares are likely to mark time in the short term. There are better prospects elsewhere.
