webTitle: A risky road to growth for Carphone Warehouse

fields.headline: A risky road to growth for Carphone Warehouse
fields.trailText: Heather Connon Throg Street
fields.body:
When a fast-growing company launches itself into a completely new business, it is always worth asking why. When that business is floating on the stock market at a valuation of between £1.4 billion and £1.8bn, the answer is doubly interesting.

It may be that Carphone Warehouse, the company in question, is adding the internet portal Mviva and Value Telecom mobile telephone service to its retail business because it cannot resist the profits available from these two services. But it could just as easily mean that Charles Dunstone and his team suspect the staggering growth rates enjoyed in the first 12 years of business cannot be sustained in the future and are casting around for other sources of growth.

Certainly, the business has done spectacularly. Turnover in the past three years alone has risen almost fourfold, while profits before tax have jumped from £13.9 million to £29.6m. The charts presented to analysts are designed to suggest growth will continue forever. Bar charts showing handset sales and mobile phone usage march across the page, increasing by 25 per cent or more each year. Sales of replacement handsets, for example, are expected to rise to 227 million by 2003, from 22 million last year, dwarfing the 83 million likely to be sold to new users.

These are forecasts, not facts, albeit based on research by experts. Many other businesses are betting their futures on predictions of an explosion in the use of mobiles for internet access and text messaging - just look at what Vodafone and the rest paid for their third-generation licences. And the valuations of handset manufacturers such as Nokia and Ericsson are predicated on punters regularly swapping their old-fashioned mobile phones for Wap-enabled ones in the latest design.

Carphone Warehouse has plenty of scope for growth even if these forecasts prove optimistic. It has 477 UK outlets, but could open more. It is building a network on the Continent, and branch openings - 60 in three months - will keep sales growing.

But, as everyone from Marks & Spencer to Boots can attest, building European networks is harder than it sounds. The risk is that it absorbs a lot of investment and never produces decent returns. Good returns have been Carphone Warehouse's hallmark. Gross margins in the retail business are more than 30 per cent. Operating margins have been falling, partly because of growth, and are now 4.9 per cent compared with 7.4 per cent two years ago. The company says it can return to the higher levels as expansion slows. But some analysts worry these may not be sustainable.

The phone manufacturers and network operators which are its suppliers will have been reading the prospectus too. It would not be surprising if, having studied the phenomenal growth Carphone Warehouse has enjoyed, they were thinking of ways to keep more of the profits for themselves, either by cutting subsidies or selling more directly. There is increasing competition elsewhere too. The fact that you can now get handsets from places such as Tesco and Woolworths underlines how close they are to a commodity product.

Conveniently, the prospectus lists all the other potential threats to business in a section called Investment considerations - and the six pages devoted to these should be essential reading for anyone considering applying for shares. These range from the possibility that Value Telecom and Mviva will distract management's attention from running the core retail business, to the threat that its reputation for impartial advice will be undermined by the fact that its salesmen will now be rewarded for pushing these two services.

But all companies, however risky, can be sold at a price. The question is, does Carphone Warehouse's valuation adequately reflect the risks? The only way to treat Mviva and Value Telecom is as costs, and their profits, if they do arrive, as a bonus. The mid price of 195p puts the valuation at £1.6bn, equal to more than 50 times forecast earnings. That is below Matalan, the other retail star of the stock market. But Matalan's suppliers are not likely to try to muscle in on its success, and it has more scope for growth in outlets.

Mobile mania means that the flotation is likely to be oversubscribed and could go to a premium. But buyers should be aware of the risks in the business. This is not a share which you can just buy and forget about.

Healthy prospect
Smith & Nephew never seems to live up to the promise of its products. It is the leading company in wound management - producing products such as synthetic skin for burns patients - and in arthroscopy techniques such as keyhole surgery. It is also one of the top companies in orthopaedic products, such as hip and knee replacements. All are fast-growing areas, with the potential for further acceleration. Yet S&N's sales growth has been pedestrian, and shares have lagged far behind the market over the past five years.

Last week's trio of announcements suggests that could finally change. It is selling its consumer products businesses - solid names including Simple, Lil-lets and Elastoplast, which distracted management from a single-minded focus on its core, more high-tech, areas. It is giving shareholders the £235m that is raising - plus an extra £180m from its own resources through a 37.14p special dividend - and consolidating its share capital. And it is changing its dividend policy to reflect its 'strategic growth aims'.

In layman's language, the immediate effect of that is a one-third cut in payout as it aims for dividends to be covered 2.5 times by earnings, rather than 1.3 to 1.7 times as in the past. The benefit to S&N, however, is that it frees up the £25m or so a year of cash that was needed to pay the dividend and can now be used to finance acquisitions.

fields.bodyText: When a fast-growing company launches itself into a completely new business, it is always worth asking why. When that business is floating on the stock market at a valuation of between £1.4 billion and £1.8bn, the answer is doubly interesting. It may be that Carphone Warehouse, the company in question, is adding the internet portal Mviva and Value Telecom mobile telephone service to its retail business because it cannot resist the profits available from these two services. But it could just as easily mean that Charles Dunstone and his team suspect the staggering growth rates enjoyed in the first 12 years of business cannot be sustained in the future and are casting around for other sources of growth. Certainly, the business has done spectacularly. Turnover in the past three years alone has risen almost fourfold, while profits before tax have jumped from £13.9 million to £29.6m. The charts presented to analysts are designed to suggest growth will continue forever. Bar charts showing handset sales and mobile phone usage march across the page, increasing by 25 per cent or more each year. Sales of replacement handsets, for example, are expected to rise to 227 million by 2003, from 22 million last year, dwarfing the 83 million likely to be sold to new users. These are forecasts, not facts, albeit based on research by experts. Many other businesses are betting their futures on predictions of an explosion in the use of mobiles for internet access and text messaging - just look at what Vodafone and the rest paid for their third-generation licences. And the valuations of handset manufacturers such as Nokia and Ericsson are predicated on punters regularly swapping their old-fashioned mobile phones for Wap-enabled ones in the latest design. Carphone Warehouse has plenty of scope for growth even if these forecasts prove optimistic. It has 477 UK outlets, but could open more. It is building a network on the Continent, and branch openings - 60 in three months - will keep sales growing. But, as everyone from Marks & Spencer to Boots can attest, building European networks is harder than it sounds. The risk is that it absorbs a lot of investment and never produces decent returns. Good returns have been Carphone Warehouse's hallmark. Gross margins in the retail business are more than 30 per cent. Operating margins have been falling, partly because of growth, and are now 4.9 per cent compared with 7.4 per cent two years ago. The phone manufacturers and network operators which are its suppliers will have been reading the prospectus too. It would not be surprising if, having studied the phenomenal growth Carphone Warehouse has enjoyed, they were thinking of ways to keep more of the profits for themselves, either by cutting subsidies or selling more directly. But all companies, however risky, can be sold at a price. The question is, does Carphone Warehouse's valuation adequately reflect the risks? The mid price of 195p puts the valuation at £1.6bn, equal to more than 50 times forecast earnings. That is below Matalan, the other retail star of the stock market. This is not a share which you can just buy and forget about. Healthy prospect Smith & Nephew never seems to live up to the promise of its products. fields.headline: The fall of Barnsley's superspiv
fields.standfirst: Paul Farrelly  charts the fortunes of Kevin Jones, Doncaster hairdresser turned pyramid scheme conman
fields.trailText: Paul Farrelly charts the fortunes of Kevin Jones, Doncaster hairdresser turned pyramid scheme conman
fields.body:
This is the story of Kevin Jones, Britain's king of pyramid selling. In a five-year reign in the Nineties, this slick Doncaster hairdresser-turned-serial superspiv fleeced more people through more illegal get-rich-quick schemes than any other con merchant in the UK before him.

His conviction in February - he and four co-conspirators were jailed for 20 years in all - marked the Department of Trade and Industry's biggest success to date in nailing fraudsters. But, because of strict reporting restrictions, the full story of the Yorkshire pharaoh's rise and fall can only now be told.

Dubbed 'the man with the golden tongue', Jones's tale of high living, fast cars and quick riches is a caution to fools easily parted from their money. It is also, the authorities hope, a warning to future fast-buck merchants aiming to take advantage of the greedy or just plain gullible.

Last week, the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) closed its file on the 41-year-old Yorkshire swindler. At Leicester Crown Court, it decided not to pursue one of the smaller pyramid-selling scams in which he was alleged to have been involved. In 1994 about 3,000 suckers lured by that particular get-rich-quick scheme - cynically promoted as Peace of Mind - together lost £1.3 million.

Ten days ago, Kevin Jones and his older brother, Russell, were also acquitted over their alleged role in the Ostrich Farming Corporation (OFC), which fleeced 2,800 people - including ITN newsreader Fiona Armstrong - of £22m in the most bizarre fast-buck scheme of the last decade.

OFC's two founders had already pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud and were jailed. Kevin Jones' acquittal was, nonetheless, another huge disappointment to the Serious Fraud Office, which brought the case. But what the ostrich jury did not know was that four months previously - following a dogged seven-year international pursuit by the DTI - Kevin Jones had already been locked up for five-and-a-half years over another scam which made headlines in the Nineties: Alchemy International.

'You have... cynically and dishonestly and systematically exploited on an extensive, indeed, near countrywide, scale, the trust and aspirations of a very large number of people,' Judge Hoffman said on sentencing Jones over the 'complex and elaborate' Alchemy swindle at Leeds Crown Court.

Snared by happy clappy seminars at top hotels, slick videos, sales patter and downright lies, scores of taxi drivers, cleaners, redundant miners and professional people flocked to Alchemy.

So high-profile was the scheme that it featured on BBC's That's Life and national television news. In all, 7,300 people were taken for a £3m ride over 18 months before the DTI finally shut Alchemy down in July 1994. The lure was the old pyramid trick - with a twist. Vast rewards were promised to investors who forked out up to £14,000 each and recruited other 'players' to join Alchemy's 'Golden Matrix'. Alternatively, for a mere £2,000 stake, simple 'spectators' would reap more than £30,000 in just two years. But as happens with most illegal money circulation schemes, Alchemy would have needed to recruit more people than live on the entire planet if it was to honour its pledges. The scheme was 'from first to last a dishonest one', Judge Hoffman remarked.

Not, of course, that Jones cared. The court heard how, on the day one school cleaner handed over an £18,500 inheritance, Jones used the cash as part payment for a £90,000 Bentley. In all, he boasted of making £350,000 out of Alchemy.

After years of perming hair and flogging videos, Alchemy marked Jones's arrival in the big time. He had in fact pinched the idea from another local pyramid pioneer, builder-turned-mystic Tom Leigh, whose Barnsley-based 'club', Frequency Programming World, was also shut down by the DTI in 1994.

By the time Alchemy fell apart, following a bust-up with co-founders over how to bank thousands of cheques, Jones had moved on. In 1993 he set up Tsar Computing, which traded for less than a year as Peace of Mind, before DTI investigators again moved in. Feeling the heat, Jones then skipped offshore to the Netherlands. There, in 1996, he launched a similar pyramid scam, Illuminati.

That scheme, he claimed to BBC North's Fools Gold documentary, traded in 38 countries, but not the UK. It was yet another lie. Through its UK arm, Lifestyle Services, Illuminati recruited at glitzy hotel parties before being wound up by the DTI in April 1997. By then, Jones was also involved in marketing large, flightless birds at OFC, whose founder, Brian Ketchell, had been with Alchemy. Kevin Jones allegedly made £2.1m from his involvement with OFC, the ostrich trial heard.

According to Dutch police sources, Jones also travelled to Tirana. There he met with Albanian officials before the government launched a raft of pyramid schemes, which nearly bankrupted the Balkan state and sparked huge riots in 1997. 'The joke here is that the economic collapse of that country was in no small part due to that visit,' one investigator told The Observer .

In late 1997, DTI officials were ready to start extradition proceedings to winkle Jones out of his Amsterdam exile. By then, however, police sources say, Illuminati's activities had stepped on the toes of Dutch organised crime and Jones had fled. 'There were a few heavies after him,' one source said. 'Basically they wanted to get hold of him and kill him.'

A tip-off from an angry Alchemy member led DTI investigators to the Costa del Sol. There Jones was understood to have stayed at the Spanish villa of a financial consultant who was flogging ostriches for OFC to British expatriates.

In May 1998 a warrant was finally issued for Jones's arrest. But by then, he had skipped again - back to familiar territory in Barnsley. And on 30 June 1998, after talks between the DTI and his solicitors, Jones gave himself up at Barnsley police station.

White-collar crime is treated leniently in Britain: with good behaviour, Jones is likely to emerge from Leicestershire's Stocken prison in November 2002.

When he comes out, the words of consumer affairs minister Kim Howells which accompanied his sentence will still be ringing in the ears of the thousands of punters who have lost life savings, redundancy money and inheritances: 'If an offer seems to good to be true, it usually is.'

fields.headline: Mobile phones run into static
fields.standfirst: Nokia's vision of the wireless future is expensive - and it's failing to convince the sceptics, writes  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Nokia's vision of the wireless future is expensive - and it's failing to convince the sceptics, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
The bods charged with delivering Nokia's wireless internet strategy could manage only the hastiest of interviews last week - in the back of a London taxi between Piccadilly Circus and Paddington Station.

Unfortunately, Ilkka Pukkila, director of Nokia's 3G marketing strategy, and Ukko Lappalainen, the company's 3G general manager, hadn't banked on the capital's atrocious traffic conditions and were thus running late for the interview. Admittedly, Nokia is a giant in the mobile communications market. But a hasty briefing in the back of a lurching black cab is probably not what the Finnish company has in mind when it comes to developing communications on the move.

When The Observer caught up with the pair, they had just finished a presentation to the City's finest in which they pushed the line that, honestly, the costs of rolling out the wireless internet of the future - also known as third-generation (3G) services - are not really going to be that expensive.

Unfortunately, fellow mobile giant Ericsson is not so optimistic. On Thursday the company's president, Kurt Hellstroem, warned that growth in the mobile market is likely to slow because of the costs of 3G licences. His comments focused investors' concerns on the wireless industry's massive capital requirements and sent the price of telecom shares plunging.

As the taxi weaved through thick London traffic, the two Nokia executives expressed incredulity that the city centre could be so jam-packed. 'It's because of all the telecom firms digging up the roads and laying thick cables,' the pair were informed.

In Nokia's world, of course, there would be no need for so many cables. Wireless base stations would act as substitutes for many of the inner city networks currently being laid across the UK to cope with the huge demand for new information services.

But the promised wireless revolution now seems to have hit a snag: how will it be financed? The key problem is that the industry is embarking on a roll-out of new technology which will transform mobile handsets into sophisticated devices capable of receiving and sending data wherever we are.

Revolution is something of a misnomer. Evolution is more the order of the day. This may look like semantic pedantry, but the fact that the mobile data explosion will roll out in stages has profound implications for the industry.

Already, consumers in the UK can buy Wap (Wireless Application Protocol) phones which allow them to download basic text services from the world wide web; soon, general packet radio services and, in the longer run, 3G technology, will be rolled out.

The problem is that each new technology requires huge investment. And this will come on top of the billions the mobile phone networks are now having to pay for the cost of 3G licences. Nokia estimates that it will take an incumbent mobile operator between five and seven years to claw back the costs of that 3G licence and of building a network in any particular country.

Analysts now talk of mobile phone operators having to spend more than £100 billion on licences and 3G technology if they want to build a global network. But other technologies are sucking up mobile operators' capital expenditure, such as Wap and GPRS.

Who is going to pay for all this new technology? You can almost hear investors stealing the best line from Jerry Maguire: 'Show us the money. Show us the money.'

Nokia suggests that 3G means operators can double their revenues and cut their costs in half. The latter can be done, apparently, because 3G networks will have 'scaleability' - that is, they will be able to adapt at little cost in the long run, thus bringing overall capital expenditure down.

Pukkila argues that there will be three key drivers behind the doubling of revenue growth: 'There will be services that are time-critical: you will be able to receive information in real time. There will be services that are person-sensitive: they know who you are and will arrange their services around you. And they will be location-sensitive: they know where you are. These factors will allow for the creation of premium services that will put some real value on the networks.'

Nokia believes consumers are prepared to pay for these services. 'People are already paying a little extra for banking over their mobile phone in Finland,' Lappalainen explained. Advertising and the application of the technology to other services - such as clever gizmos which help black cabs negotiate tricky driving conditions in central London - will also be big cash generators. The City has yet to be convinced.

As Alistair Scott, head of Asian Telecoms Research at Merrill Lynch, wrote in Asiacom , a business newsletter: 'There is a huge leap of faith needed by the financial community that the operators will sort this out.' He points out that in Asia, operators cashflows simply cannot finance Wap, GPRS and 3G.

The problem is not confined to Asia, however. Few, if any, operators really, know what is going to happen. Telecom Italia Mobile, for instance, recently shut down its strategic planning department because it couldn't see even six months into the future.

Removing the uncertainty surrounding the different wireless technologies will be crucial for the mobile networks. For example, nearly a third of the value of NTT DoCoMo, Japan's giant mobile phone company, is based on the potential of its data services.

But jumping on the technology bandwagon carries its own risks. BT Cellnet, has made much of the fact that it is the first UK operator to roll out GPRS services in the UK. But, to cut a long and complex story short, the handsets it is using work to a different GPRS standard from the version agreed by the industry, which limits their ability to use upgraded software packages in the future.

The operators themselves do admit that things could be better handled. One2One has spent huge amounts of time and money gearing up for GPRS, which it believes will be far more important than the introduction of Wap because it will allow the delivery of huge amounts of data and video services at speeds far faster than those on offer through today's conventional modems.

While Wap allows for the simplification of web pages so that they are easy to view on mobile phone screens, GPRS adds a completely new dynamic. The systems would work well together, but the industry has ended up launching two different sets of handsets at different times.

Craig Tillotson, One 2 One's strategic development director, says: 'The timing was unfortunate. The Wap browser model was ready before GPRS. In a perfect world everything would be ready at the same time.'

Given this uncertainty, questions must now be asked about who will pay for the new generations of handsets. Currently mobile phones are heavily subsidised by the operators because they 'locks' users into their networks for a year or two. But given the huge costs facing the networks, consumers will probably end up being asked to pay hundreds (instead of tens) of pounds for their phones. Nokia doesn't rule this scenario out. Pukkila said: 'It [the subsidisation of handsets] will not necessarily continue. It remains to be seen. It's very much up to the operators to decide.'

Some back-of-the-envelope calculations by Laurent-Pierre Baculard, a principal with management consultancy AT Kearney, suggest that if a 3G licence costs £5bn, an operator will probably need another £3bn to develop the network and a further £1bn to subsidise the costs of the new handsets.

And this is for 3G, which won't be available for another three years at least. Imagine how many more billions of pounds have to be factored in for the roll-out of Wap and GPRS until then.

Such financial fears plays into the hands of big operators such as Orange and Vodafone. 'They will have a different scale of purchase with the manufacturers. They will enjoy economies of scale by buying en masse from the manufacturers,' Baculard says.

These fears also mean that the operators will look to secure exclusive deals with content and service providers. This will see certain sites heavily promoted and easily accessible through particular mobile phone networks because the operators are receiving a kickback on any e-commerce transactions.

It all boils down to one question, according to Kee-hian Tan, vice-president of e-commerce with AT Kearney. 'One of the big uncertainties is how much people will use these new services. How much content will people pay for? If we can expect a shift to higher usage, with people spending more on access, it's possible to say handsets will be subsidised.' Big if.

Acronym buster

Wireless Application Protocol (WAP)

WAP phones are now available in the mass market (Nokia's 7110 phone and Ericsson's R320 handset). WAP is an industry-wide set of standards which allow mobile phones to download web pages.

General Packet Radio Service

Sometimes called '2.5 G'. This will allow users full internet access on the move. The system bundles data into 'packets' which can be sent far more quickly over mobile networks. The first versions of GPRS will be available later this year.

3G

Also called Universal Mobile Telecommunications System. This will allow video downloads and massive data transfer between mobile handsets. The first generation of GPRS phones also compatible with 3G networks will be launched in 2002. Full 3G services will not be available until the end of 2003.

But, to cut a long and complex story short, the handsets it is using work to a different GPRS standard from the version agreed by the industry, which limits their ability to use upgraded software packages in the future. The operators themselves do admit that things could be better handled. One2One has spent huge amounts of time and money gearing up for GPRS, which it believes will be far more important than the introduction of Wap because it will allow the delivery of huge amounts of data and video services at speeds far faster than those on offer through today's conventional modems. While Wap allows for the simplification of web pages so that they are easy to view on mobile phone screens, GPRS adds a completely new dynamic. The systems would work well together, but the industry has ended up launching two different sets of handsets at different times. Craig Tillotson, One 2 One's strategic development director, says: 'The timing was unfortunate. The Wap browser model was ready before GPRS. In a perfect world everything would be ready at the same time.' Given this uncertainty, questions must now be asked about who will pay for the new generations of handsets. Currently mobile phones are heavily subsidised by the operators because they 'locks' users into their networks for a year or two. But given the huge costs facing the networks, consumers will probably end up being asked to pay hundreds (instead of tens) of pounds for their phones. Nokia doesn't rule this scenario out. Pukkila said: 'It [the subsidisation of handsets] will not necessarily continue. It remains to be seen. It's very much up to the operators to decide.' Some back-of-the-envelope calculations by Laurent-Pierre Baculard, a principal with management consultancy AT Kearney, suggest that if a 3G licence costs £5bn, an operator will probably need another £3bn to develop the network and a further £1bn to subsidise the costs of the new handsets. And this is for 3G, which won't be available for another three years at least. Imagine how many more billions of pounds have to be factored in for the roll-out of Wap and GPRS until then. Such financial fears plays into the hands of big operators such as Orange and Vodafone. 'They will have a different scale of purchase with the manufacturers. They will enjoy economies of scale by buying en masse from the manufacturers,' Baculard says. These fears also mean that the operators will look to secure exclusive deals with content and service providers. This will see certain sites heavily promoted and easily accessible through particular mobile phone networks because the operators are receiving a kickback on any e-commerce transactions. It all boils down to one question, according to Kee-hian Tan, vice-president of e-commerce with AT Kearney. 'One of the big uncertainties is how much people will use these new services. How much content will people pay for? If we can expect a shift to higher usage, with people spending more on access, it's possible to say handsets will be subsidised.' Big if. Acronym buster Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) WAP phones are now available in the mass market (Nokia's 7110 phone and Ericsson's R320 handset). WAP is an industry-wide set of standards which allow mobile phones to download web pages. General Packet Radio Service Sometimes called '2.5 G'. This will allow users full internet access on the move. The system bundles data into 'packets' which can be sent far more quickly over mobile networks. The first versions of GPRS will be available later this year. 3G Also called Universal Mobile Telecommunications System. This will allow video downloads and massive data transfer between mobile handsets. The first generation of GPRS phones also compatible with 3G networks will be launched in 2002. Full 3G services will not be available until the end of 2003.

fields.headline: Is this the new Roddick?
fields.standfirst: Chantelle Gottgens hopes to cause a stir with organic coffee, says  Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: Chantelle Gottgens hopes to cause a stir with organic coffee, says Sarah Ryle
fields.body:
With Starbucks, Costas and Prets spreading plague-like through city centres (blink and you may miss the transformation of yet another shop front), it is an odd time for a small, independent coffee bar to enter the market.

But this is exactly what 34-year-old Chantelle Gottgens is doing. And, as the MBA student of the year at the London Business School (number eight in the world behind the big US schools), she should know what she's about. Gottgens has started Fresh, an all-organic coffee shop which aims to do for latte and muffins what Anita Roddick and the Body Shop did for lotions and make-up. It is a big ambition in a tricky market.

Less than a year after it opened, in a shop leased by the LBS, she is preparing a second outlet in Chiswick and planning a further eight branches for 2001.

Groups such as Whitbread (owner of the Costa chain) are not yet ready to embrace the organic 'niche', because they do not perceive enough demand to sustain extra cost and hassle. On the other hand, if anybody had said five years ago that people would be prepared to pay £1.60 for a coffee and a further £1.60 for a plain croissant every morning on the way to work, and that this would sustain an apparently unstoppable proliferation of shops cashing in, who would have believed it?

Gottgens, small and neat, fizzing enthusiasm, adopts the 'optimistic but not complacent' stance. 'There are three classic ways of looking at the niche market,' she says, being the good student that the LBS is so impressed by. 'One is that it simply means you have run out of customers; another is that you have to be a differentiator (like Starbucks); and the third is that you keep below the radar, not attracting the attention of the huge players, starting small and growing before they spot what you are doing. That's the way I like.'

With Iceland preparing to switch its entire own-brand vegetable range to organic but charge the same as it did for non-organic produce, it has to be true that demand for honest-to-goodness, additive-free food is no longer confined to the hairy-armpit, sandal-wearing brigade. According to the Soil Association, registered organic food processors increased from 500 at the end of 1997 to more than 800 by April 1999. They sold produce worth £300 million to retailers. Demand for organic food is rising by 40 per cent a year, and most big supermarkets offer at least 450 lines.

Gottgens is staggered by the premiums other retailers charge: 'I did a straightforward shopping-basket comparison at Sainsbury's with identical ordinary groceries, and the organic basket was 84 per cent more expensive. I have no intention of charging that kind of premium, but it shows what a buffer zone there is.'

She has her eye on more than coffee and muffins. Her South African background (she is the daughter of a Cape Town seafood importer) and a stint on an LBS placement at the University of California have convinced her that the UK does service badly and salads and juice worse.

She wants to create a whole new concept for food in, as Roddick did for cosmetics. This includes a dream of nutritional fast food for children - not such pie in the sky when you consider the incredible growth in demand for organic baby food.

Lizzie Vann, a woman with more claim to the 'new Roddick' tag than anybody, knows this well. Her brand Baby Organix now has a 9 per cent share of the baby food market, and her operating profit rose last year by 75 per cent to £265,000.

Gottgens believes that the boom can be at least partly attributed to a relatively buoyant economy: 'People have the money to have a conscience at the moment.'

There are imperatives, such as improving the supply chain. 'People in this business have a tendency to grow what they like when they like, or bake what they like if the spirit moves them. This can cause problems.'

fields.headline: Free trade gets a facelift
fields.standfirst: It is dubbed 'the Third Way for the Third World'.   Faisal Islam  reports from Paris on a soft new line on hard global development issues
fields.trailText: It is dubbed 'the Third Way for the Third World'. Faisal Islam reports from Paris on a soft new line on hard global development issues
fields.body:
There was no tear gas on the Champs-Elysées. Secret police and gendarmes patrolling concurrent World Bank and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development conferences in Paris were not as troubled as their counterparts in Seattle and Washington had been.

A handful of noisy anti-globalisation protesters outside the OECD's forum were placated by the words of a conference delegate from Friends of the Earth, which was consulted alongside other non-governmental organisations on new guidelines for multinationals. The final communiqué from Ministers of the 'rich man's club' was peppered with references to social inclusion, poverty reduction and sustainable development.

Across the city in Bercy, Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, and James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, argued for a more comprehensive approach to development that would encompass human rights, access to healthcare and education.

'[We should] think about development in the broadest possible sense, the one described by Amartya Sen, winner of the Nobel Prize in Economics, in one of his books, Development as Freedom ,' said the French prime minister.

Wolfensohn added: 'People are the ends of development. Were they measuring their lives in terms of GDP per capita?'

With one eye on last December's shenanigans in Seattle, the agents and proponents of this globalisation, are falling over themselves to present the softer side of economic liberalisation. They are putting into practice a lesson learnt from the IMF and World Bank handbook - that it is difficult to push through adjustment policies without the support of the local population.

Some of the global doubters will be reassured by talk of rethinking development policy, and a shift away from the Washington consensus - the IMF and World Bank-led focus on liberalisation, privatisation and trade specialisation. Concerns about Third World debt lay at the heart of the anti-globalisation protests.

The new approach is rooted in development concepts that go beyond the traditional debate on growth and equity. Economic development becomes more than growth in per capita income and is seen, instead, as the aggregate of human development. The talk is of 'pro-poor' growth, analysing macroeconomic statistics in conjunction with life expectancy, access to primary education, and healthcare. Policies that focus on these indicators are considered important as an end to the development process as well as a means of stimulating growth.

This subtle change of tack is being dubbed the 'Third Way for the Third World': a global free market system that is morally anchored by a watered-down version of equality of opportunity. Inequalities can be stomached so long as citizens and countries are provided with the capabilities - education, and healthcare - that allow them to compete in the market. The role of the state is essentially one that facilitates provision of these capabilities and of institutions that protect the working of the free market.

'Third Way for the Third World' does no justice to the approach. The study of the role of institutions and human indicators in development preceded New Labour by decades. Now, world leaders such as Jospin are showing a willingness to talk about it seriously. Indeed, Jospin talked about the need for a European approach to development which could be established if the EU took a unified approach - it accounts for a third of voting rights at the World Bank.

The relevance of new approaches to development stretches beyond the Third World. Globalisation means that the world can gainfully be considered one giant developing country. There are pockets of underdevelopment in industrialised nations. Likewise, there are islands of Silicon Valley-style dotcom wealth in the poorest countries - Bangalore, for example.

So a changing conception of development economics has global repercussions.

'It's not just the economics of development; it's the economics of the world,' said Wolfensohn at the World Bank conference.

Extrapolating elements of development theory to world level informs the need for institutions to facilitate and manage the workings of a global market. Robert Mundell, last year's Nobel prizewinner in economics, advocated a global currency. The Paris gatherings to talk about sustainable development were also about setting down the ground rules for globalisation.

Jospin called for the creation of a World Environment Organisation to manage protection of global public goods.

Four multilateral institutions: the World Bank, IMF, OECD and UN launched A Better World for All - a joint response to the challenges of social development - at the Geneva Social Summit last week. The release was rounded upon by NGOs for hijacking the agenda.

The NGOs criticised the document for putting all the onus for poverty alleviation on changes in developing countries, rather than on reform of the international financial system or of the structural adjustment policies agreed as a condition of lending programmes.

Indeed, talk of broader concepts of development has not filtered into policy changes. The French government may wish to lead a European approach to development, but its policy negotiators are keen to scupper agreements to untie aid. Structural adjustment policies have been scrapped; in their place are Poverty Reduction Strategy Papers (PRSPs), which have yet to yield substantially different policies.

They are based on applying the high principles and 'tough medicine' of neoclassical economics. NGOs and developing countries have noted that their record is mixed at best, and that industrialised nations are rather worse at applying free trade principles to themselves.

Last week the World Bank came under fire from pro-Tibetan groups for failing to publish a critical report on a controversial project, backed by a World Bank loan, that involves resettling 57,750 Chinese farmers on Tibetan land.

The World Bank has suffered splits on these issues. Ravi Kanbur, an eminent economist who wrote this year's draft World Development Report , last month resigned over differences with World Bank economists. Last year, the bank's former chief economist, Joseph Stiglitz, resigned, reportedly following US pressure.

Stiglitz was outspoken in his attacks on the Washington consensus. After stressing the importance of openness, accountability and democracy, he said, the international financial orthodoxy then strips away decision-making: 'It's nice to have votes, developing countries are told, but don't get involved in anything that affects your life. It's a very mixed message.'

Stiglitz pointed to India as a country that can work perfectly well without an independent central bank.

He cited the move in 1997 to make capital market liberalisation a central policy aim of the IMF as showing that 'ideology' was driving policy. There is no definitive evidence of its effect on growth.

A new weapon in the NGO arsenal is to take on the international institutions using their own terms. The most effective way to combat poverty in the developing world is to focus on agricultural incomes. Genuine free trade would open up the protected markets of industrialised nations. Similarly, the success of the new economy informs the need for investment in education.

Such policies of investment in human capital illustrate that comparative advantage is a dynamic process. Protection was afforded to today's industrialised nations during the development of their industries, yet free trade is a cornerstone of policy foisted upon the least developed countries.

Similarly, debt is portrayed as a tax on national income that diminishes incentives to produce. Suggestions were made that the IMF and World Bank apply market principles to its policy advice by taking an equity stake in countries carrying out the policies. The institution's advisers could also be paid in relation to achievement of human development objectives.

NGOs argue the Washington consensus was structured not as a means of development, but to open up markets for multinationals and to entrench power structures.

Such suspicions will persist until the international financial institutions take a leaf out of their own manual for development and become more transparent, accountable and democratic. Moves in that direction are afoot, but the proof of any change will be in the policies espoused in the PRSPs. Otherwise the experience of discontent in Seattle and Washington will have served only to improve their public relations.

In the meantime, police in Prague are taking advice from the Washington police department.

Global confidence-building

Ministers from the 29 OECD countries were involved in two initiatives to 'address the concerns of ordinary citizens about globalisation' as part of a 'consensual framework for a global economy'.

They issued a list of 35 tax havens outside the OECD and 47 preferential regimes within it that were identified as tax havens.

Ministers also reached agreement on new guidelines for multinationals.

The code includes recommendations on environmental and labour standards, covering measures to stop bribery and the use of forced and child labour.

Trade unions and NGOs were involved in the con sultation process, but the guidelines are not legally binding. The first code, published in 1976, proved ineffective.

Enforcement mechanisms have now been strengthened. Companies that violate the code can be referred to a country's National Contact Point - the Department of Trade and Industry in the UK - and 'named and shamed'. After a last-minute intervention by Mexico, worried about the effect on US investment, the OECD is not permitted to do this itself.

The carrot for multinationals, according to the OECD, is that the guidelines will promote competition in quality and standards.

fields.headline: Locks and likeability
fields.standfirst: Alan Davies may be endearingly bemused, but he's no John McEnroe
fields.trailText: Stand-Up With Alan Davies | A Many Splintered Thing | Wimbledon
fields.body:
Stand-Up With Alan Davies BBC1
A Many Splintered Thing BBC 1
Wimbledon BBC1 and 2
Glastonbury BBC1

During the programme Stand-Up With Alan Davies, a rather earnest, intense, off-duty and therefore not awfully funny Davies told it like it apparently is. 'My likeability gets remarked upon,' he sighed, in that slightly campy, nasal, Essex twang, ' but that's just the way I am.' He could probably have substituted 'hair' for 'likeability' but it still seemed a little odd to remark upon one's marketable asset with such cool detachment, not to mention a complete lack of irony.

This was Davies as a model or a racehorse - nice mane, strong fetlocks, lovely likeabilities. He started as a stand-up and morphed into an actor. Rather, I'd always thought he started as a stand-up, but it turns out he was really a luvvie all along. In Stand Up With _ he revealed that he'd applied to do drama at Warwick and was put off by an audition in which he had to pretend to walk through a blizzard, which he did in a very Alan Davies sort of way - scrunched-up eyes and screwed-down hairdo and a shrug.

None the less, as an actor Davies has done very well for someone who only seems to have on offer a few, subtly varying shades of Alan Davies, plus John McEnroe's hair, circa 1980. Indeed, he's done even better at being Alan Davies than Frank Skinner has at being Frank Skinner. There's the bemused Jonathan Creek, the bemused bloke in the building society ads, the perpetually bemused guest on various completely bemusing panel games, the wryly bemused stand-up interviewing his peers and, this week, the definitively bemused and irritatingly spelt, Russel - befuddled fulcrum of a lust triangle - in A Many Splintered Thing .

I bet Davies sometimes wakes up in the night sweating and waiting for the knock on the door: 'That's enough now, Mr Davies. Likeability and unlikely hair are, unfortunately, no longer quite enough to sustain your career and anyway, we're currently looking for somebody essentially likeable who also hints at psychosis, kind of a new Keith Allen but maybe with a ponytail. So, if you don't mind coming with me...'

A Many Splintered Thing is a comedy about adultery, which is probably what passes for a hip, modern romance at BBC Towers. Still, at least modern romance is a subject that writer/producer Geoff Deane knows a bit about - he's the one who wrote and sang the hits for the unforgettable 1980s band of the same name. Geoffrey is a real old new romantic, then, and you could spot some of his legendary charm in, for example, A Many Splintered Thing 's pay off-line: drunk man shouts: 'I may be married but at least I've got a cock!' through his lesbian mistress's letterbox before falling over in the gutter and being urinated on by a small passing dog.

No? Still not entirely convinced by the scene's edgily contemporary likeability? Well, admittedly it's not quite Cary Grant and Ros Russell, but this is presumably why Deane was smart enough to employ Mr Alan Congeniality-Davies to imbue the scene with instant likeability. But aside from being stylistically derivative (fantasy scenes, internal voiceovers, Frasier-style captions); despite, too, the premise of the cheekily-loveable yet under-achieving adulterer married, predictably, to a be-bobbed, power-dressed, she-bitch-in-heels but sleeping with a younger, blonder dippy-chick; and despite the fact that some of Deane's lines rely too heavily on Davies and the excellent Josie Lawrence.

If you enjoy oral sex after your watershed, A Many Splintered Thing is an (in)decently likeable adult comedy. Though none of Deane's oral sex is quite as funny as Davies's own failsafe recipe for the 'Blow-Job Slammer', shared with us during Stand Up With _ : Salt and lemon and _ well, I guess you have to tell it likeably , which is beyond me. Though I console myself by having much better hair than Davies - even since he chopped off his curls.

Twenty years ago, John McEnroe owned the prototype for Alan Davies's hair. And, if he didn't have Alan's marketable likeability, he had genius instead. Interestingly, he has now lost the hair, acquired likeability in spades and channelled his genius into new arenas. Since retiring from playing competitively, McEnroe has usually covered Wimbledon for, I think, NBC, so invariably each summer we'd be shown shots of a distant, suited-and-booted Mac in headphones, while David Mercer or Bill Threlfall said something like: 'And there's John McEnroe, of course - arguably one of the greatest grass-court players of the modern era, blah, blah...'

And I would stamp my little foot and shout: 'Not "arguably" anything!' Because McEnroe is one of only two stars I have blindly and devotedly hero-worshipped in a slobberingly uncool and fanlike way. Well, to be honest, there were three, if you include Red Rum.

But now, finally, McEnroe has been hired by the BBC to commentate on key men's matches and, from last Monday, it was immediately obvious that he was going to affect the coverage in the much the same way he affected the game - by being brilliant and irreverent, informed, intelligent, exasperated, inspired, anxious and always keeping his solid, reliable BBC commentary doubles partners on their metaphorical toes.

It is obvious, too, that whatever the Mercers and Threlfalls may have felt about him in the past, they all now adore him. As Holland were losing to Italy on Thursday night, Agassi tussled with Todd Martin, and Bill Threlfall admitted that he really doesn't approve of Mexican waves. McEnroe ribbed him: 'Come on, Bill, don't be old fashioned!' and Bill was forced to admit: 'I'm an old fashioned guy.' Not exactly a shock revelation, but still a whole lot more than we've learned about Mr Threlfall in the last 100 years of his commentating career.

Oh, it was sweet! Like little green and purple flowers blooming in the light, everybody wanted to open up to McEnroe, so each time he served up tidbits of important historical information (for example, the first time he played on Centre Court was as a qualifier against Jimmy Connors, who refused to acknowledge him in the locker room), or lobbed us practical tactical tips (if your opponent makes you feel nervous, try some topspin, because it's much tougher to hit flat balls consistently), you got Mercer reminiscing about umpiring the 1984 Connors-McEnroe final: 'The one mistake I made was that I said it was the third set when it was the second!' 'I find it hard to believe that was the only mistake, but we'll leave it at that,' said McEnroe - and I swear you could hear Mercer purr.

The BBC failing to secure £40 million worth of football highlights suits me fine - especially if it means there's enough in the kitty to keep McEnroe on the payroll. He's loving it, too, of course. 'I know I've arrived!' he said on Monday. 'First at the BBC, then at Buckingham Palace!' (he plays a charity exhibition there with Björn Borg today). Endearing? Likeable? Mac: 'Talking of tragedy, what was it with Great Britain's performance in the European Championships?'
Mer: 'Ah well, I speak as a Welshman, John, that was England . Not a great performance, was it!' (Lengthy silence while this geographical revelation sank in.)
Mac: 'Great Britain! That includes Scotland and Wales..?'
Mer: 'Yes, and Northern Ireland.'
Mac: 'Maybe that's the answer. You all band together!'
Mer: 'Lot of politics...'
Mac: 'Welcome to sports!'

This was hallucinatorily fabulous TV, and Bragg and Johnson should be given a Baddiel and Skinner-style show immediately. Indeed, it completely overshadowed the main event in which Bowie unfortunately decided to do a cocktail bossa nova version of my favourite song but, despite this, it was still a pretty good week for heroes. Indeed, all it lacked was a very soppy documentary about Red Rum.

webTitle: Vivendi set to defy Prescott over Connex

fields.headline: Vivendi set to defy Prescott over Connex
fields.trailText: French communications and utility giant Vivendi is set to clash head-on with the British Government if, as is widely predicted, its Connex rail arm loses the major London South Central franchise later this month.
fields.body:
French communications and utility giant Vivendi is set to clash head-on with the British Government if, as is widely predicted, its Connex rail arm loses the major London South Central franchise later this month.

It is understood that Vivendi will refuse to relinquish its contract and will insist on Connex running the service until the current franchise expires in 2003.

It would be likely to uphold only the bare minimum performance and customer service standards while continuing to make profits from the state-subsidised operation for the next three years. By 2003 the South Central franchise will have received a total of almost £400 million in subsidy.

Such defiance will put the company on a collision course with Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and his 'rail enforcer' Sir Alastair Morton.

But industry experts warned that the authorities could be powerless to force Connex off the route and even a legal challenge could prove useless.

Connex is competing for a renewed, longer South Central franchise of up to 20 years against rival GoVia, which is half-owned by listed rail and bus group Go-Ahead.

GoVia's track record on its Thameslink franchise is unimpressive, and its Thames Trains operation has been sharply criticised for underinvestment and poor driver training after one of its trains shot past a red signal and led to the Paddington rail crash last year.

But Vivendi's Connex is one of the most reviled of all the passenger rail operators, and industry observers predict that Morton's Strategic Rail Authority will want its scalp at an early stage of the passenger refranchising process.

South Central carries 100,000 passengers a day, mostly commuters between London, Surrey and Sussex.

It has been widely criticised by passengers for causing overcrowding by using shorter trains than its customers need, running more than a third of its rush hour trains late, cancelling services without providing information and dealing badly with customer complaints. But it has never been removed from the franchise because of the lax contractual conditions written during the original process of privatising the former British Rail.

But if Vivendi loses out and refuses to hand over the keys to GoVia it could run the trains for another three years.

Roger Ford, of the journal Modern Railways , said: 'This would be highly embarrassing for the Government and a blow to passengers.'

webTitle: Wellcome bids again to save jobs

fields.headline: Wellcome bids again to save jobs
fields.trailText: A last-ditch effort to safeguard thousands of British bio-technology jobs will be launched by the Wellcome Trust in the next two weeks as it reignites the controversial planning battle to expand its Hinxton Hall laboratories.
fields.body:
A last-ditch effort to safeguard thousands of British bio-technology jobs will be launched by the Wellcome Trust in the next two weeks as it reignites the controversial planning battle to expand its Hinxton Hall laboratories.

Wellcome, the world's biggest medical research charity, will submit a fresh planning application in August to house a 270,000sq ft centre for biotech start-ups and established companies connected to the Human Genome Project in south Cambridgeshire.

The charity was furious when, last August, Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott refused permission for a 430,000sq ft centre at Hinxton Hall in Cambridgeshire because he believed the site's countryside location would be harmed by traffic congestion. Wellcome threatened to build a new research centre abroad.

This weekend, sources advising Wellcome told The Observer that if its new application is rejected, the medical charity will leave Cambridge, taking thousands of leading-edge jobs with it.

'Options other than Cambridge are being considered,' the Wellcome source said. 'The way the trust is thinking is that this is absolutely the last chance for south Cambridgeshire.'

In a statement, Wellcome - which has assets of £11 billion thanks chiefly to its historical stake in pharmaceuticals giant Glaxo Wellcome - said: 'We're still in discussions with South Cambridgeshire council, and we will be making a further statement in the next two weeks.'

Prescott's ruling last year drove a coach and horses through the Government's policy of creating economic clusters of excellence. Cambridge is seen by the Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry as a centre for bio-technology businesses.

But Cambridgeshire is one of the UK's fastest-growing counties, and many locals believe its environment cannot sustain the number of businesses wishing to move there.

Last week Wellcome scientists in Cambridge played a major part in completing the first draft of the DNA blueprint. Scientists connected with the the Human Genome Project are now peeling off to create commercial applications using this data.

fields.headline: Sports ahead in online race
fields.trailText: The future of many dotcoms may be looking shaky at the moment, but at least one type of online firm seems to have a life expectancy that runs beyond the end of this year.
fields.body:
The future of many dotcoms may be looking shaky at the moment, but at least one type of online firm seems to have a life expectancy that runs beyond the end of this year.

Sports-related websites are set for massive revenue growth, according to a report out tomorrow. Analysts at Screen Digest, the media business and research company, say sports sites benefit from their ability to harvest multiple revenue streams, including e-commerce, advertising and sponsorship.

By 2005 it is predicted that global revenue from advertising on sports sites will reach $6.27 billion, a tenfold increase on last year's figure. Over the same period, the total amount of sports merchandise sold over the internet will increase from $186 million to $5.8 billion. Ticketing sales are set to jump from $60.5m to $2.9bn. The report also suggests the sites will benefit from other revenue streams, including pay-per-view services and online gambling - which some analysts predict will rise to more than $15bn this year.

Rachel Church, the report's author, said: 'It seems likely that a large amount of online revenue will be earned at the expense of more traditional retail and entertainment channels, including sports clubs themselves.'

She said that one of the rea sons sports sites are likely to do well is that their visitors tend to be more affluent than most internet users. A typical sports site user tends to be a university-educated male with an average income of between $40,000 and $60,000.

Last year, the official Wimbledon tennis site recorded 900 million hits in just 14 days. The Euro 2000 website has received more than 150 million hits per day.

webTitle: When the saints go dancing in

fields.headline: When the saints go dancing in
fields.standfirst: On a rare visit to London, Mark Morris's dancers perform the world premiere of a work by Gertrude Stein
fields.trailText: Mark Morris Dance Group | Royal Ballet
fields.body:
Mark Morris Dance Group, London Coliseum WC2

Royal Ballet, Linbury Theatre, Royal Opera House

Body fascism doesn't rule, even in ballet, as this congested summer season has shown. Dancers can be all shapes, sizes and ages: uniformly lean in the Kirov, variably muscular in the Royal Ballet or offer a pleasing mixture in the Mark Morris Dance Group.

Morris himself, now in his 40s and bigger than ever, returns to the stage in Dido and Aeneas . He takes the leading roles of Dido and the Sorceress; his Aeneas is grizzled Guillermo Resto, who has danced with Morris for 17 years. This may be the last chance to see Dido and L'Allegro , also in the two-week Coliseum season, for Morris intends to retire them, if not his performing self.

He needs large resources to stage these choral works, created in the Eighties when his company was resident at the Monnaie Theatre in Brussels. After his stint at successive Edinburgh Festivals, he has struck up a special relationship in London with the English National Opera, whose musicians are prepared to be sidelined while dancers take pride of place. The singers are stacked in boxes on either side of the stage, a stereophonic choir of angels.

Some are saints in a new Morris/ENO production of Virgil Thomson's Four Saints in Three Acts (1934), given its world premiere last Wednesday. It is a shorter version of the original 90-minute operatic spectacle, with a libretto by Gertrude Stein and choreography by Frederick Ashton. Ashton, on his first visit to New York, had been commissioned to move the singers and dancers, recruited from Harlem nightclubs and dance halls. Thomson wanted black performers, he said, 'because they alone possess the dignity and the poise _ that the proper interpretation of opera demands'.

Morris's dancers have those qualities, though he has somewhat underwritten their roles. He keeps the community of adepts' dancing simple and ecstatic: his villagers link up in chains and circles, break out into a Spanish jota or American hoedown. They look more Mexican than Spanish, in earth-coloured costumes by Elizabeth Kurtzmann. Hot red and ochre backdrops suggest a tropical semi-paradise where saints bloom like lilies.

Gertrude Stein proposed a pantheon of saints, including two Teresas. Morris limits himself to one Teresa and an Ignatius - Michelle Yard and John Heginbotham, young, rapt, uncontaminated by experience. They have a direct line to heaven, accessed via a garden swing. Heginbotham is a Holy Fool, leading his followers in a blissful round of 'pass the pigeon on the grass, alas, and the magpie in the sky' (carolled by baritone Gavin Carr). Yard's vocation we have to take on trust, waiting for her to reveal the god-given attributes that will take her to a place of grace.

Morris has not yet passed on to these youngsters how to carry a leading role. There are no supporting saints to help them out and the ensemble sags in between bouts of dancing. Watching the singers can be more rewarding, as they chant antiphonal stage instructions from their blue and gold eyries. A plainer setting might actually help unify the production, putting all the performers on an egalitarian footing.

Full-blown divadom flourishes in the North African climate of Dido. Morris hefts his huge arms to the skies like Isadora at her ripest, then gets down and dirty as the smirking Sorceress. Sarah Connolly voices her/his dual personality, welcoming death as Aeneas departs.

Resto's presence is so powerful that the stage is bereft without him. For the first time, I found the dancing chorus intrusive; an unaware innocence has been lost in this revival. Even Morris seems too knowing.

The Royal Opera House has become an altogether jollier place, with 146 children attending last Monday's matinée by the Kirov Ballet, while Royal Ballet fans mingled with newcomers below stairs in the 400-seater studio theatre. The Royal Ballet has still to discover how to programme its playpen. Should it offer friendly access to ballet for those hesitant about paying upstairs prices or new works that challenge? Its first programme was a messy compromise, re-deemed by Michael Corder's Masquerade . Neither new nor daring, it showcased first-rate dancers in a cornucopia of steps. Rather too many, but we needed diverting.

The second programme was more satisfying, mixing beginner choreographers with experienced ones. Both Poppy Ben David, still at the Royal Ballet School, and Vanessa Fenton, a new member of the company, showed considerable promise. Fenton's trio featured Alina Cojocaru, a meteor about to burst through the company's ranks; Ben David's Siren Song (to seductive music by 13-year-old Benjamin Marquise Gilmore from the Yehudi Menuhin School) was fresh and witty.

Then came two older, garrulous choreographers, Jacopo Godani and William Tuckett, splicing up the vocabularies of contemporary and classical dance. Tuckett's Death and the Maiden trio climaxed in a wild, whirling lift for Zenaida Yanowsky, manhandled by Jonathan Cope. Its extravagance was typical of the piece, which calmed unexpectedly in a coda in which the dancers at last acknowledged the musicians. No such luck in Godoni's Aeon's Run, to a computerised score by Diego Dall'Osto, which went on for aeons.

Godoni's costive combinations further bunched the muscles of its cast of eight. The intimacy of the studio theatre exposes just how many Royal Ballet dancers have bulges where the Kirov's don't. The cause is not just modern choreography - there is something wrong with the company's daily training, for incomers, even those as sleek as Cojocaru, start developing bulk they do not need.

Leaving the best till last, Christopher Wheeldon scored a hit with a suite, There Where She Loves, to songs by Chopin and Kurt Weill. Darcey Bussell looked lovely, pretending to be cross with possessive Cope; Jaimie Tapper delighted in her manly team of partners.

Wheeldon knows how to keep dancers still, as well as how to get them going. What he can't do is match Weill's understanding of rocky relationships. Women who love too much don't suffer as prettily as these ballet girls. Wheeldon could push them, and us, a lot further.

They look more Mexican than Spanish, in earth-coloured costumes by Elizabeth Kurtzmann. Hot red and ochre backdrops suggest a tropical semi-paradise where saints bloom like lilies. Gertrude Stein proposed a pantheon of saints, including two Teresas. Morris limits himself to one Teresa and an Ignatius - Michelle Yard and John Heginbotham, young, rapt, uncontaminated by experience. They have a direct line to heaven, accessed via a garden swing. Heginbotham is a Holy Fool, leading his followers in a blissful round of 'pass the pigeon on the grass, alas, and the magpie in the sky' (carolled by baritone Gavin Carr). Yard's vocation we have to take on trust, waiting for her to reveal the god-given attributes that will take her to a place of grace. Morris has not yet passed on to these youngsters how to carry a leading role. There are no supporting saints to help them out and the ensemble sags in between bouts of dancing. Watching the singers can be more rewarding, as they chant antiphonal stage instructions from their blue and gold eyries. A plainer setting might actually help unify the production, putting all the performers on an egalitarian footing. Full-blown divadom flourishes in the North African climate of Dido. Morris hefts his huge arms to the skies like Isadora at her ripest, then gets down and dirty as the smirking Sorceress. Sarah Connolly voices her/his dual personality, welcoming death as Aeneas departs. Resto's presence is so powerful that the stage is bereft without him. For the first time, I found the dancing chorus intrusive; an unaware innocence has been lost in this revival. Even Morris seems too knowing. The Royal Opera House has become an altogether jollier place, with 146 children attending last Monday's matinée by the Kirov Ballet, while Royal Ballet fans mingled with newcomers below stairs in the 400-seater studio theatre. The Royal Ballet has still to discover how to programme its playpen. Should it offer friendly access to ballet for those hesitant about paying upstairs prices or new works that challenge? Its first programme was a messy compromise, re-deemed by Michael Corder's Masquerade . Neither new nor daring, it showcased first-rate dancers in a cornucopia of steps. Rather too many, but we needed diverting. The second programme was more satisfying, mixing beginner choreographers with experienced ones. Both Poppy Ben David, still at the Royal Ballet School, and Vanessa Fenton, a new member of the company, showed considerable promise. Fenton's trio featured Alina Cojocaru, a meteor about to burst through the company's ranks; Ben David's Siren Song (to seductive music by 13-year-old Benjamin Marquise Gilmore from the Yehudi Menuhin School) was fresh and witty. Then came two older, garrulous choreographers, Jacopo Godani and William Tuckett, splicing up the vocabularies of contemporary and classical dance. Tuckett's Death and the Maiden trio climaxed in a wild, whirling lift for Zenaida Yanowsky, manhandled by Jonathan Cope. Its extravagance was typical of the piece, which calmed unexpectedly in a coda in which the dancers at last acknowledged the musicians. No such luck in Godoni's Aeon's Run, to a computerised score by Diego Dall'Osto, which went on for aeons. Godoni's costive combinations further bunched the muscles of its cast of eight. The intimacy of the studio theatre exposes just how many Royal Ballet dancers have bulges where the Kirov's don't. The cause is not just modern choreography - there is something wrong with the company's daily training, for incomers, even those as sleek as Cojocaru, start developing bulk they do not need. Leaving the best till last, Christopher Wheeldon scored a hit with a suite, There Where She Loves, to songs by Chopin and Kurt Weill. Darcey Bussell looked lovely, pretending to be cross with possessive Cope; Jaimie Tapper delighted in her manly team of partners. Wheeldon knows how to keep dancers still, as well as how to get them going. What he can't do is match Weill's understanding of rocky relationships. Women who love too much don't suffer as prettily as these ballet girls. Wheeldon could push them, and us, a lot further.

fields.headline: The light fantastic
fields.standfirst: Freed from their frames and hung in natural light, Turner's sublime paintings will make sun-worshippers of us all
fields.trailText: The Sun is God: J.M.W. Turner | Douglas Gordon
fields.body:
The Sun is God: J.M.W. Turner, Tate Liverpool to 1 October

Douglas Gordon, Tate Liverpool to 1 October

People were easily shocked by Turner. Short, stubby, bow-legged and unkempt, he looked, they said, like a coachman or a tenant farmer. Constable called him uncouth. Delacroix was appalled by his clumpy footwear. Turner owned a pub in Wapping, drank with stevedores and, even when he was supremely famous, could be spotted scoffing shrimps with the daytrippers on the Margate steamer. When he died, fellow Academicians were horrified to learn that he had a secret life with an illiterate woman in Chelsea, where his nickname on the streets was Admiral Puggy Booth - after his supposed profession.

As in life, so in art: some people thought Turner's later work didn't look remotely like painting. 'Tinted steam,' sneered Constable; others suggested soapsuds, custard or whitewash. 'Pictures of nothing, and very like' was Hazlitt's famous barb; which, turned on its head by modern critics, makes Turner a pioneer of abstract art. To his contemporaries, these veils and vortices of light were the empty ramblings of Admiral Booth; to the twentieth century, they made him Turner Our Contemporary. Not the least achievement of this tremendous show is to reveal his light, as it were, in both lights: to present him as simultaneously ancient and modern.

The method is simple. Fifty paintings from the last decade of Turner's life have been removed from their frames and hung, somewhat lower than usual, in entirely natural light. You see them as they might have been seen in the 1840s, specifically in Turner's own studio. Yet you also see them as startlingly live and direct, liberated from the antique frames, security glass and Soane-pink walls that force them back in time at the Clore Gallery in London. The contrast is there in every work: intensely vital images, still quick with the maker's mark, painted on the frail and aged canvas now exposed round the edge of each stretcher.

The absence of artificial lighting has a radical effect on these pictures. Some look dramatically darker. The Angel Standing in the Sun is no longer so radiantly blond: the sun burns with the dark ferocity you might expect in a vision of the apocalypse. Others appear magically brighter: Turner's translucent dawn over Lake Lucerne seems to rival the gallery's own sunlight. As that light changes throughout the day, its passage is reflected in the paintings: a sea that looks as still as a field of mown hay begins to ruffle and shiver, icy skies thaw and glow, dying rays come up like wild fire. This isn't just some trick of the light, it is inherent in Turner's painting: all those millions of coloured touches add up to an ever-changing play of light - generally frozen in the steady glare of electric bulbs.

In these conditions, you literally see more of Turner. He has been described as an action painter; like Jackson Pollock in Hans Namuth's film, Turner made a spectacle of himself in the act of painting. He would arrive at the Royal Academy with the bare rudiments of a picture, then work it up in a storm of brushwork. The effect was so rapid that his enemies thought Turner must be excavating some buried image from the canvas. Up close and personal at the Tate, you can discern his movements everywhere - the spatters of wet oil, clinging like droplets to an earlier crust of pigment, the quick sweeps that barely graze the canvas, the deep score of his thumbnail furrowing through the paint.

This doesn't tell you how he did it - especially in those late watercolours that materialise in waves of tinted light - but it does give a sense of Turner's fearless innovation. The surface of 'Disaster at Sea' is a mayhem of paint: glutinous as bubble gum, stiff as lunar rock, molten as the wax Turner was mixing with his oils. The black clouds are literally bursting with claggy matter, showered on the shipwrecked figures below who are, by contrast, as cursory and trivial as the putty on a stately home ceiling. Forget the fatality, it is the elemental upheaval that obsesses Turner - and, of course, the hint of sun that makes the darkness visible.

Turner is routinely pegged as a sun-worshipper, lying on his back as a boy in Covent Garden to experience the widest angle of rays, traipsing all over Europe to observe the solar effect on foreign landscapes. As its title indicates, the sun is the central fact of every picture in this show. But seen together - they've never been shown as a concerted group before - these paintings amount to a far more complex affair with sunlight.

In late Turner, the sun transforms matter into energy, turning the substantial world into a mirage. All the local details listed in his titles simply vanish into the ether: there are no dolphins, blazing wrecks or distant coastlines. In Hurrah! For the Whaler Erebus! Another Fish! , the ship and its catch are dissolving in a flood of irradiated light. The Two Figures on a Beach from 1845 are just ghostly afterthoughts in a radical sunscape. In the end, the only reality in Turner's art is the constant phenomenon of the sun.

Some people regard these pictures as oblique self-portraits; instead, Turner seems to be escaping from himself, from all those heroes and ships and classical allegories that infest his official works. The more he stares at the sun, the more unconstrained his painting, as if he wanted to breach the picture frame altogether and let in a world of light. It's probably best to see this show on a clear day, when the sun returns the favour and you don't have to squint to see every trace of Turner's genius. Otherwise, Tate Liverpool has shown him to perfection. Never quite abstract - there is always some faint horizon that returns them to earth - these last images are closer to the sublime than anything in English painting.

'The Sun is God' is the inspiration of Mark Francis, late of the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. Sad to say, he is also responsible for inviting the Turner Prize winner Douglas Gordon to produce a parallel show. Gordon has installed a sunny yellow lightbox in a maze and painted some nerdish wordplay on the title of Turner's show round the doorway between the two exhibitions. Thankfully, that's as far as he goes.

Gordon is also showing Hitchcock's Dead on Arrival on a triptych of screens at three fractionally different speeds. Once your eyes adjust to this mild déjà vu , there is the pleasure of watching the movie and listening to the wonderful soup of soundtracks. There are further word associations, a morbid peepshow that blinks on and off, and one of Gordon's own films in which a hand repeatedly slaps the camera so that it, too, seems to blink on and off. Metaphysics is generally held to be Gordon's forté, but there's no evidence of subtle thought in this show. Without the powerful prop of Hitchcock, Douglas Gordon falls flat.
