fields.headline: A country punk kin
fields.standfirst: Booze, betrayal and yodelling: Hank Williams III is just like his grandpa - except for the tattoos and thrash metal
fields.trailText: Hank Williams III
fields.body:
'Welcome to the schizophrenic world of Hank III,' says Shelton Hank Williams by way of introducing the second part of his stage act. He's spent the previous 90 minutes playing a beautifully judged country set, his astringent but melodic voice delivering a mixture of old favourites such as Johnny Cash's 'Cocaine Blues', new songs by himself and others, blues, rockabilly, and a clutch of tear-jerkers by his famous grandfather, Hank Williams.

He's warned us what's coming, but it's still a shock when Williams sets aside his battered straw stetson and he and a band featuring fiddle and stand-up bass blast into a set of full-on thrash metal delivered at ear-damaging volume, with the lazy southern twang of his vocals replaced by a manic jabber. It is, he tells me later, his way of 'letting people know who I am, and the kind of music I was raised on - Black Sabbath and Nirvana. And this way, no one can say I'm cashing in, because no matter how good a country artist I might one day become, people will always say I'm riding on other people's coat-tails.'

The coat-tails in question are the most famous in country music. Almost half a century after his death at the age of 29, Hank Williams remains the undisputed king of country, a Fifties legend as tragic and potent as Monroe or Dean, with a life and songbook steeped in betrayal, booze and Bible-belt religion. Williams's melancholy canon, packed with standards such as 'Your Cheating Heart' and 'Lovesick Blues', is much covered even now.

For the divorced wife and three-year-old son he left behind, Williams's legacy proved something of a poisoned chalice. Hank Jr, cynically groomed by his mother, Audrey, to impersonate his famous father, eventually rebelled, and became reborn as one of Seventies Nashville's hell-raising 'outlaws' alongside Waylon Jennings, Kris Kristofferson and Willie Nelson. He survived a barbiturate overdose, a near-fatal mountaineering accident and a severe cocaine addiction before securing his own entry into the country hall of fame.

The family baggage carried by Hank III is, you sense, somewhat weightier than that borne by rock sprogs like Rolan Bolan, Zak Starr or Simon Collins. Sporting a Sid'n'Nancy T-shirt beneath his battered rodeo shirt, a pair of worn-out cowboy boots held together by duck tape, and a colourful set of tattoos, his lanky frame and gaunt good looks eerily recall those of his grandpop - hell, he even has Hank the first's fluting vocals and steer-calling yodel down pat. Small wonder that a portion of his audience consists of 'a lot of older people who come just to hear me sing those three Hank Williams songs'.

Shelton's parents divorced when he was three, and prickly relations with his father (whom he didn't see again until he was eight), helped direct his musical interests towards punk and metal. Then, three years ago, while playing drums with a Nashville punk band, he was served a paternity suit on stage, the result of 'a one-night stand who had waited three years to tell me I had a kid'. That his passing fling was the daughter of a policeman didn't help; Hank III was landed with a $28,000 back bill and ongoing payments of $600 a month.

Instructed by the judge to find a job paying more than the $50 a gig he was earning, the 24-year-old Shelton decided to cash in on the family name. 'I went knocking on managers' doors saying, "I'm Hank Williams the Third, are you interested in getting behind me?"' The result was a ghoulish album, Three Hanks: Men With Broken Hearts , on which he and his father sang along with the disembodied voice of Hank the first, a project he now disowns.

Then something odd happened - Shelton Hank Williams discovered country music afresh. He'd grown up with albums by George Jones and Merle Haggard lying around the house, now he tapped into young songwriters like Wayne Hancock (with whom is now friends) and Dale Watson; men steeped in the gritty, emotional lineage of his granddad rather than the slick, pop-country sound of modern Nashville, which Shelton had intended to exploit.

Shelton's recently released debut, Risin' Outlaw , allies him firmly with Hancock, Watson and others for whom the spiritual home of modern country is not Nashville but Austin, Texas. It's a likeable but patchily impressive debut, featuring only three Williams originals, for which he blames his record company. He has, he says, pitched them a score of songs which they turned down as being 'too country' and therefore unlikely to score the all-important radio exposure.

When Hank Williams's grandson is rebuffed for being 'too country', something is surely amiss in the state of Tennessee, and Shelton is scathing about a Nashville establishment apparently interested only in hunks in hats and babes in boots who can deliver mainstream success. 'Nashville has become stale and formulaic,' he says. 'The musicians got outsmarted by the lawyers and businessmen. Every year they throw 40 acts against the wall and see which ones stick. In fact, it's become a sports town more than a music town -they'd rather have football stars on the Grand Ole Opry than singers.' As an example, he points to Chad Brock, an ex-wrestler who currently occupies the number one spot with a cutesy piece of fluff called 'Yes', about which Shelton is vitriolic.

The shift in attitude from cash-in cowboy to authentic artist helps explain why Shelton has taken up the 'outlaw' tag, though he's keen to distance himself from his father's generation. 'In the Seventies outlaws meant hanging out with Hell's Angels and shooting up dope. For me and Wayne [Hancock] and for unsigned Nashville bands like Greg Garing and the Hot Town Tigers, it's a musical definition, about making music for ourselves and our fans. We don't care about becoming Entertainer of the Year.'

His outspokenness, and a freely admitted taste for booze and pot, haven't helped his standing with a Nashville ruling caste still steeped in the puritan values of the 1940s, and which like to promote its wares as a wholesome alternative to the evils of rock and rap. 'They have this thing called media school to help you evade difficult questions, which I have turned down six times. I'm here to speak what I feel, not to be a puppet for a record company.'

Shelton's relations with his record company, Curb - run by a former Republican governor of California, Mike Curb - reached a bizarre nadir when it joined forces with his parents, manager and ex-girlfriend to persuade their wayward charge to enter rehab to wean him off liquor and weed. After a break-up with his girlfriend, Hank Three was showing signs of emulating the self-destructive habits of Hanks One and Two. 'They were concerned about my emotional health - I was heartbroken and depressed,' he admits, though the suggestion that his father helped him enter rehab brings a pained expression. 'That was a scam,' he says. 'He's never around, then when everything is going to shit, here's Hank Junior to the rescue!

'What happened was that Hank Junior and Waylon [Jennings] came in and said, "We just don't want you to get as crazy as we did". I said, well, I'm not snorting pounds of coke like you guys did, I'm just smoking pot and drinking alcohol - big fuckin' deal. On the day I went in I told my girlfriend I'd do it to win her back. I wrote her 20 letters, never got one in return, realised it was all a game and walked out.'

Since then, says Hank III, he's calmed down. He has his career plan in place, with a new country album due to be recorded this summer back to back with a thrash metal album titled This Ain't Country . His future, though, is in the music of his grandfather. 'Pop country will eventually choke itself to death, then the old stuff will come back,' he predicts. Who better to revive it than Hank Williams III?

 Hank Williams III plays the Reading and Leeds festivals on 26 and 27 August

webTitle: Scott Walker's Meltdown review – a crisp selection

fields.headline: Scott Walker's Meltdown review – a crisp selection
fields.standfirst: Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText: Scott Walker’s Meltdown review – a crisp selection
fields.body:
The second Sunday of Meltdown, directed this year by ‘reclusive pop genius’ Scott Walker, got off to a good start with this message over the PA system: ‘Please take your seats now for the unmissable and unannounceable first half of the evening.’ What this meant was: ‘Please take your seats now for Fuckhead.’ People piled in: it’s not every day you get to see German sonic terrorists who play in the nude.

Spotlights circled to a soundtrack of fighter planes and fingernails on blackboard, then four men in white vests and underpants jogged around, spraying perfume and tossing pillow feathers. It was a while before they got to goose-stepping with their electric guitars. Finally Fuckhead began to pull off each other’s undies.

They weren’t even the main support act. Jarvis Cocker had to follow that with his artsy ensemble A Touch of Glass featuring a glass harmonica – a big, jangly 18th-century thing you stroke and pedal. Standing cross-legged behind a mini keyboard, Jarvis dabbled his way into a soothingly ambient 20-minute soundscape, performed his niggling theme song (‘My body may die but my heart will keep loving you baby, oohhh’) for Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased), and departed with Scott Walker’s ‘On Your Own Again’. From the back of the hall, someone shouted out: ‘Well done! Well done!’ Not so reclusive, then?

The main attraction was Smog, led by lo-fi guru Bill Callahan, a reluctant stage presence in boyish denim, singing desolate lyrics in a lugubrious voice bordering on the Leonard Cohen. Dwarfed by a big-screen close-up of his pupil contracting and dilating like a goldfish mouth, Callahan stole just one look at the audience, and sang: ‘There are some terrible gossips in this town/ With jaws like vices and eyes like drains.’ His band backed him with three-note undertows or kicked in for upbeat numbers such as ‘Dress Sexy At My Funeral’. At best he was pure Ivor Cutler: ‘I take the prisoners swimming/ They have the times of their lives/ I love to watch them floating on their backs/ Unburdened and relaxed.’

On Tuesday night it was Jim O’Rourke – guitarist, singer-songwriter, producer (of Smog, among others) – who pulled in a capacity crowd at the QEH despite being double-booked with Asian Dub Foundation next door. The Chicago renaissance man has just wrongfooted followers of the avant-garde with Eureka, a big fat slice of beautiful Americana. A dishevelled figure to the back of the stage, he presided over a bravura feast of mordant lyrics, sweet arrangements and spacey improvised ramblings with a slick seven-piece band (great cornet) who sat around on stage reading Time Out while O’Rourke and guitar encored with the cheerful ‘Halfway to a Threeway’ (a song about wheelchairs and brain death).

Once again, barriers melted – all except one. Meltdown seems to be a male thing. In eight years only one woman (Laurie Anderson) has directed. Has anybody asked the equally great and reclusive Kate Bush?

• Meltdown ends tonight with Blur

webTitle: It's got love, lust and guilt. So why did we have to wait 150 years for it?

fields.headline: It's got love, lust and guilt. So why did we have to wait 150 years for it?
fields.trailText: Genoveva/Il Mondo della Luna | Ion
fields.body:
Genoveva/Il Mondo della Luna Garsington, Oxfordshire

Ion Almeida, London N1

The three-arched Italianate loggia and statuary, usually so handsome a backdrop to the stone terrace of Garsington's stage, had been wrapped and hidden in yards of stressed, bloodied tarpaulin - a brutish echo of Christo's shrouded Reich stag and a shock, no doubt, to the ghost of Ottoline Morrell, whose Bloomsbury spirit still pervades the captivating house and garden which once were hers. This bracing, abstract evocation of eighth-century Brabant provided the setting for Schumann's only opera, Genoveva, a rousing psycho- drama of German romanticism which explores love, lust and guilt in the Dark Ages. Apparently last staged in this country by students in 1893, this operatic ugly duckling has had to wait for the enterprise of one inquisitive opera lover, Leonard Ingrams, for a modern, professional production.

Of course it helps to have an opera festival in your own garden, but one of the more serious pleasures of Garsington has always been the rehabilitation of spurned, ditched or disowned repertoire. This involves risk. Without doubt, many members of his deluxe audience would prefer a popular warhorse to an arcane oddity; the man in front who spent much of the first half studying the palm of his hand until his wife nudged him was certainly one. Everyone else was agog. Exactly a century and a half after it was written, Genoveva , dismissed by Wagner and others as dramatically limp, musically confused, operatically inconsequential, has at last had a chance to show its happily abundant glories. Indeed, the work is a revelation, a stepping stone from Weber - whose Euryanthe , like Beethoven's Fidelio , is ever in aural evidence - to the mature Wagner, as well as throwing new light on Schumann's songs and symphonies. The cast, led by a stunning Susannah Glanville, is first-class, Aidan Lang's production (designed by Ashley Martin-Davis) clear-eyed and thoughtful, and the orchestral playing, under the perceptive direction of Elgar Howarth, supple and energetic.

The plot centres on the newly-wed young Genoveva (a good German wife) who is distraught at the departure of her husband, Siegfried, to fight the Moors. Golo, a loyal knight, stays behind to act as her protector but instead attempts to seduce her. After agonies and tribulations, a sorceress, a murder and a magic mirror, the mistrustful husband and innocent wife are finally reunited. In one of the versions of the story (by Friedrich Hebbel) from which the composer made his libretto, the villain Golo gouged his eyes out with a hunting knife. Schumann's interests are more subtle. He shuns melodrama and instead elicits sympathy for the knight, superbly played by Nigel Robson despite some loss of voice in the last act. Golo's agonised struggle between desire and honour is at the heart of the drama.

The violence and near-rape which Genoveva suffers has chilling conviction. Not for Schumann the heavy-handed signalling of emotion so loved of opera composers in the mid-nineteenth century (when Meyerbeer's theatrically gluttonous Le Prophete enjoyed huge popularity). Despite the spirited horn calls and bright, scurrying string figures, his orchestration is on a higher level of complexity and expressiveness. No wonder such music was misunderstood. Opera North follows suit with a new production in the autumn. They must work hard to match the quality at Garsington.

One of the highlights of the festival's more makeshift early years, before the smart apron tent and nice seats arrived, was a performance of Il Mondo della Luna during which a seasonal deluge forced the production manager to hold up the canvas awning with a broom, water gushing down every few minutes on to the water-logged moonscape, while the singers sang bravely on. This year's welcome revival of Haydn's satire to Goldoni's libretto, not wholly convincing as opera but full of glorious music, escaped such hazards, though illness marred the start of the run. But Jonathan Veira soon recovered vocal strength and comic form as the self-important merchant Buonafede, duped by a bogus astronomer into thinking he is on the moon. Nerys Jones as the maid was outstanding. Jane Glover, a conductor busily engaged abroad and too rarely seen here, brought the score to life with customary acumen and was rewarded with vivacious playing by the orchestra.

It is too early to judge Param Vir's unfinished Ion, co-commissioned for this year's Aldeburgh and Almeida festivals. Larger in scale and scope than his acclaimed double bill of four years ago, this opera after Euripides to a sometimes maladroit text by David Lan has had to be presented as a work-in-progress with a linking narration (delivered by Janet Suzman). Disappointing though this is, it offers Param Vir (b1952) a valuable chance to review the opera's effectiveness so far. Despite lush and vivid orchestration and some ravishing five-part writing for women's voices, the work as yet feels static. The story turns on a confusion of identity between a lost child (Ion) and a found parent, his mother Creusa. In theory it's the very stuff on which opera thrives and Rita Cullis was enthralling as Creusa. As yet these elements refuse to bond as drama. We await the next stage.

The death of Sir William Glock at the age of 92 leaves a sad gap for all who benefit from his legacy as director of the Proms in the 1960s. He pioneered the sort of challenging mix of old and new which remains an inspiration for programme-makers today. As chief music critic of The Observer , he was famously sacked in 1945 for praising the modernist rantings, as they were deemed, of Stravinsky and Bartók, as well as the outlandish efforts of his British contemporaries (notably Tippett and Britten). Others may bemoan the diminished coverage of classical music in the broadsheets today. But what editor in these more liberal days would sack a critic for championing the neglected and the new? Don't answer that.

fields.headline: Blessed are the bleak...
fields.standfirst: Sarah Kane's 4.48 Psychosis is a declaration of suicide - it's also beguiling and arresting
fields.trailText: 4.48 Psychosis | Orpheus Descending | Much Ado About Nothing
fields.body:
4.48 Psychosis, Royal Court, London SW1

Orpheus Descending, Donmar, London WC2

Much Ado About Nothing, Regent's Park, London NW1

It's just over a year since Sarah Kane killed herself at the age of 28. It's five years since her first play, Blasted , was given a widespread critical lashing, and turned into a box-office success. Headlined by the Daily Mail as a 'Disgusting Feast of Filth', the play has since been produced in Austria, France, Italy, Serbia and Australia. When Kane died, a minute's silence was observed on German radio.

In Blasted eyeballs were eaten; in Cleansed tongues and limbs were freely lopped off. Kane didn't, she said, see the point of the off-stage violence of Greek drama: 'Why pay £10 to not see it? Why not stay at home?' The gory explicitness which helped to make her drama notorious is entirely lacking from her posthumous play now premiered at the Royal Court Upstairs. But 4.48 Psychosis is no less disturbing for that.

This is Kane's most nakedly autobiographical work: it's a study of the clinical depression from which she suffered, and it's a declaration of suicide - '4.48' is the time chosen by a character to kill herself. It is dazzlingly well staged by Kane's long-time director James Macdonald and the designer Jeremy Herbert; it is tightly, raptly acted by Daniel Evans, Jo McInnes and Madeleine Potter.

Three figures sprawl on a sparse set in front of a huge, slanted mirror. They argue among themselves - sometimes as if each were a facet of a single person. They also play the parts of doctor and patient. They are always at odds with each other and with themselves: on the stage, they may seem to lounge, but in the mirror, tilting towards the audience, they look like insects trapped on a flypaper or people spreadeagled at a fairground wall of death. A girl lolls back on a table with apparent ease, but her reflec tion makes her look as if she's spread out for sacrifice.

This is the monochrome world of the depressive. Occasionally a great sizzling sound breaks out and the mirror is covered in a fuzz of light, as if a television has gone barmy. At one point, shadows of unseen people walk across the stage. The silhouettes of windows are projected; views of London streets are glimpsed - but you know these are windows that can never be opened. Which makes the ending of the play the more compelling. 'Please open the curtains,' are its last words. As they are said, the cast leaves the stage and opens the shutters of the windows in the auditorium.

When Sarah Kane was alive, one of the charges against her was that she was merely setting out to shock - though shock may seem less of a threat to the theatre than boredom. 4.48 Psychosis makes it clear that all Kane's plays have been howls from the heart. It is her most beguiling work: it's hard not to like a dramatist who describes a dream in which a doctor 'gave me eight minutes to live. I'd been sitting in the fucking waiting room half an hour.' It is also the most obviously direct and modest. There is no attempt to paint a tumultuous inner landscape on to the outer world. There is no attempt to suggest a colourful literary madness: it is a picture of the real thing. It's fragmentary: sometimes arresting and individual; sometimes leaden, with the dull repetitiveness of the person who has lost her energy; and it's sometimes apocalyptic. Kane - who was a born-again Christian until she was 17 - never lost the rhythm and iconography of her religion.

There's a thin line in Tennessee Williams's work between tosh and transcendence. It's a line which Nicholas Hytner's fine production of Orpheus Descending, seen by me at a Donmar preview, cunningly observes. A subtle, ever-changing performance by Helen Mirren lets humour into the hot house and in doing so banishes some of Williams's absurdities.

The play needs this touch, for there are many moments here which are the stuff of an ad for Southern Comfort. Bobbing around in the background is a cluster of female grotesques - salacious and disapproving. There's a rent-a-voodoo figure who is wheeled on to wail at significant moments. And there's a heavy-handed overlay of myth: boy with guitar goes into the depths of the South, where he revivifies a woman whom he ends up losing.

Mirren takes the central part of the fed-up creature of Italian descent, orphaned when her father is burnt to death by a local posse because he traded with blacks. She has been left by the love of her life for a richer woman, and shackled to death in the shape of a brutal, ailing husband.

Mirren has spent a lifetime on the stage being gorgeous - not merely physically, but vocally. Ever since as a teenager she played Cleopatra - wheeling her arms around her in despair at Antony's death, swishing her golden hair like a whip - she's been sumptuous and expansive. Confronted with Williams's operatic lushness, she might have been expected to go in for floridity. She does the opposite.

In the intimate space of the Donmar, not helped by Bob Crowley's dull design, she creates not simply one but a series of characters. She arrives - shrivelling well - buttoned into her black coat as tightly as Mary Poppins, with a set face and tight voice and just an occasional compulsive Mediterranean fling of the arm to suggest future steaminess. She crawls up a spiral staircase as painfully as if she were a pensioner. When she bursts into fecundity, she makes a total surprise of what might be thought the normal Mirren mode.

The architects Haworth Tompkins are transforming the theatres of London. The practice has carved a magical space out of the Gainsborough Studios and re-made the Royal Court. Haworth Tompkins have also released the Open Air Theatre in Regent's Park from its muddle of car park and lavatories, opening the space in front of the theatre and hanging a scatter of lights like berries high up on what looks like netting. The place has become a nest dropped into the middle of the park.

And in it some golden eggs are being laid. The theatre has sensibly retained Alan Strachan as one of its directors. Now Rachel Kavanaugh has cleverly translated Much Ado About Nothing to a postwar genteel, demob-happy England. The cry of love rings out from the tennis court; the toffs are in uniform; the often arduous comic relief afforded by Dogberry and his mates is re-imagined as Dad's Army , with Ian Talbot particularly effective as a bouncy-toed, barking Mainwaring figure. Tom Mannion is a striking, unaffected Benedick - he almost makes you believe this is a character who cares.

webTitle: Vivacious, flashy and cheerful. Those Colourists were typical Scots

fields.headline: Vivacious, flashy and cheerful. Those Colourists were typical Scots
fields.standfirst: Andrew Marr's great-grandfather burnt a Hunter portrait. Hindsight suggests this was a mistake
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr's great-grandfather burnt a Hunter portrait. Hindsight suggests this was a mistake
fields.body:
To what has been a dreary little summer, the Royal Academy's Scottish Colourists' exhibition brings, at first glance, uncomplicated joy - bright light in the grey, the flash and glitter of vivid reds, golds and greens through the rain. And that, really, is what Samuel Peploe, Francis Cadell, Leslie Hunter and John Duncan Fergusson did for Scotland before and after the First World War. They were light-bringers: hugely influenced by French post-impressionism, they gave northern art a shock from which, thankfully, it has never quite recovered.

Their work is expensive now and held in high regard. In America, it is studied by art PhD students. But this, remarkably, is their first major exhibition in London, certainly since the group collapsed in the 1930s. You only need to compare the best Cadells, Peploes and Hunters to the far limper, greyer versions of post-impressionism from the Bloomsbury set from the same period to see what London has been missing.

They seem to be everything that Scots are reputedly not - vivacious, flashy, cheerful, exhibitionist. Later generations of Scottish painters got the message, to the point where it became degraded: even now, the annual Royal Scottish Academy show in Edinburgh still throws up rip-off McMatisses and lurid tartan Cezannes just for pleasure, a concept learnt from the Colourists.

But the original four were serious, and often inspirational painters, highly regarded by their French contemporaries. None of the four exist outside their society. Despite the often bright colours, there is also a ripple of melancholy in the RA rooms, since the four represent what is now a lost country - the confident, outward-looking and wealthy middle-class Scotland, born of Empire and destroyed by war and the Depression. It was the Scotland whose 'Glasgow Boy' painters had been f ted in France and the US, whose architecture was exemplified by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, whose City fathers bought Van Gogh and Dali at a time when these painters were generally ridiculed, which was undergoing the full spate of a literary renaissance, and which was briefly rich in enlightened, vigorous patrons. It was a country whose flash and glitter can be glimpsed in Cadell's Edinburgh interiors and big-hat ladies.

Then came the war and the Depression. Private patrons, who had encouraged the artists and bought their work, went bust or found themselves short of cash. Even Peploe's prices plunged. The raffish, good-living Cadell, who had insisted on fighting through the First World War as a private soldier, albeit in a specially tailored uniform, was reduced to appealing for money from a fund 'for the Relief of Decayed Scottish Artists'. All but Fergusson, who lived until 1961, were dead by the end of the Thirties. Because their market had been largely in Scotland, their international reputation went into a steep decline.

Something of the ambiguous relationship between the Colourists and their country is caught by Leslie Hunter, a cousin of my great-grandmother. Compared to the others, Hunter is variously described as shadowy, neurotic and his life 'the most erratic to follow': in the blown-up pic tures which introduce this exhibition, he stares at the photographer with a swollen, slightly vacant look, sandwiched between a pork-pie hat and a thick tweed suit. His family, like many, had reacted to bad times by emigrating and he started his career in California, mixing with the likes of Jack LondonSadly he lost all his work in the San Francisco earthquake of 1906.

Hunter was a serious alcoholic. It was obvious that he would have problems with my great-grandfather, who was a fierce teetotaller and, as Lord Provost of Glasgow, the epitome of respectable Scottish society. There were terrible rows when Hunter came to beg for money for paints, and to dry out. Hunter, whose later work has been compared to Matisse and Van Gogh, did a large portrait of Anne Cameron, my great-grandmother, but then fell back off the wagon. My great-grandfather took the painting into the garden and burnt it. Anne, more appreciative of Hunter's genius, defiantly hung one of his still-lifes in the house: it was allowed to remain only because her husband never recognised the artist. Hunter died soon afterwards, as tormented as ever. While he was doing his great houseboat paintings on Loch Lomond he was seen in violent rages, throwing unsatisfactory canvases into the water.

There were never enough patrons to boost the Glasgow artists. The big American and Russian patrons never looked north, and four of the most talented painters Scotland produced died poor andrelatively unhonoured.

How large do they bulk now? They could never have done what they did without the influence of, first, Manet and Whistler and, later, Cezanne and Matisse - but then, a similar story applies to scores of major twentieth-cen tury painters. The truth is, they only really make sense when we think of them as European painters, not Scottish or British ones. They stand, very easily, alongside the other second generation groups, provoked by the Paris of the 1900s - Germany's Blue Riders, Italy's Futurists, the Canadian Group of Seven. In France, they are the equal of Marquet and Camoin, Utrillo, Delaunay, Soutine - pretty high, by any standards, if not the cloud-piercers every child learns about. And sometimes higher still: compare Hunter's Provençal landscape, shown in this exhibition, to a Matisse landscape from the Twenties, or Peploe's still lives to the limper work done by Vlaminck and Derain during the same period.

Above all, though, if you don't know the four Colourists, go to the Royal Academy and enjoy them for themselves. They hang in the private collections of prominent Tories, and the Lord Chancellor; if you walk from the Downing Street entrance to Tony Blair's office, you pass a row of them. They are, in short, almost fashionable, for the first time since everyone wore hats. Cadell, 'decaying' Scottish artist, would be grimly amused. And Hunter, remembering the paintings destroyed by earthquake, fire and water, would raise a shaky glass.

 The Scottish Colourists 1900-1930 is at the Royal Academy, London SW1 until 24 Sept

fields.headline: Hanging on the telephone
fields.standfirst: David Haig has turned his experience as a Samaritan into a harrowing new play, writes  Kate Kellaway
fields.trailText: David Haig has turned his experience as a Samaritan into a harrowing new play, writes Kate Kellaway
fields.body:
I am trying to imagine what it would be like to ring the Samaritans and get David Haig on the end of the line. He would be nice; of that there is no doubt. A good listener. A diverting talker, if that was what was wanted. But his highly developed sense of the absurd... he would probably have to sit on that. What else could he do with it?

Haig worked for the Samaritans for five years during the Eighties, combining this with a flourishing career as an actor. And now he has written The Good Samaritan. On the page, it is entertaining (absurdity comes into its own) yet sobering, too. It is the story of a good samaritan who becomes the person in need of help, the one who has fallen by the wayside.

I first met Haig 12 years ago. He had just won an Olivier award as best actor for his part in Timberlake Wertenbaker's Our Country's Good . I liked him immediately and remember being slightly dazed by his big house, filled with small children, in south-east London. He seemed abnormally settled for an actor, a young, responsible paterfamilias.

He is 43 now, plumper, glossier but seemingly not a day older. He has a bucolic face - lightly tanned at present - and a moustache, which I suppose to be only a temporary adornment, cultivated for his next role as Teddy Platt, lord of the manor, in Alan Ayckbourn's House and Garden at the National, which is where I meet Haig during a rehearsal break. I note that the twinkle in his eye is just as I remember it. His charm, as an estate agent might say, is unspoilt.

Haig has been extraordinarily productive in the last decade as an actor, a playwright and a parent. As an actor, he has been, to name a few roles, in Ben Elton's Gasping (just finished); Inspector Grimm in the BBC's The Thin Blue Line and a discomfitingly likeable paedophile in Alan Bennett's Talking Heads. And in Terry Johnson's Dead Funny, Haig was exactly that.

His first play, My Boy Jack (1997), about the relationship between Rudyard Kipling and his son, transferred to the West End and is now being developed as a film. He also has a further film script and a third play in the pipeline. And as if all this were not enough, he has five children: Alice,15, Caroline,12, Freddy, eight, Harry, six, and Connie,10 months. He ought, I observe, to have the good grace to look a little bit tired.

Where was he based as a Samaritan? 'I used to work in the crypt of a church in the City. It was very atmospheric; each of the crypt's arches contained a telephone booth.' His training was rigorous. The Samaritans 'brutally excise' a percentage of volunteers and many 'rule themselves out' once they realise that they must not be 'judgmental about anything'.

He found the work 'harrowing'. It was essential, he explains, to find a 'disengagement' in order not to be swamped by other people's misery and yet at the same time - and it was this he found most difficult - to keep with each new caller 'the illusion of spontaneity and freshness alive'.

He is quick to spot the similarities between being a Samaritan and an actor. The weariness of having to sound fresh sounds exactly like that encountered by actors in long-running West End hits. The similarity is also about 'enforced intimacy'. You become close to fellow actors who, once the play is over, you may never see again.

Being an actor helped with the writing of the play: 'You get used to a boredom threshold. You often have to bolster a scene that has passed its sell-by date. So I am puritanical about keeping dialogue taut.'

Sometimes, indeed, the dialogues are not only taut but entirely one-sided - one of the Samaritans is stressed by silent callers. How common are such calls? 'When I showed the script to the Samaritans, they pointed out that I had the figure of silent calls too low - 38 per cent of calls are silent.'

In the play, Haig describes a call from a 17-year-old who is killing himself with a drug overdose. The Samaritan has to respect the boy's wish not to be saved. The woman talking to him has to provide a kind of spoken lullaby and is desolate afterwards.

A debate arises about whether the Samaritans are right not to trace calls when lives are at stake. 'Two or three times', Haig had to talk to people in their death-throes. But unlike the character in his play, he agrees with the Samaritans' 'central principle' of not betraying the trust of callers in any way.

Has he ever called a helpline himself? 'Yes, but I am not going to tell you about it.' He says he could imagine calling the Samaritans when he was in New York acting in Yasmina Reza's Art . He felt 'profoundly isolated and depressed'.

Appropriately enough, it was during this time that he started to work on The Good Samaritan . He did not enjoy the writing, even though the result appears so effortless. 'I suppose it was because it was examining such uncomfortable recesses.'

'Uncomfortable recesses' is an understatement, for Haig includes in the play a scene in which a woman describes giving birth to a stillborn baby. A few years ago, Haig and his wife had a stillborn daughter, whom they named Grace.

Although the scene is fictionalised and the woman is 'nothing like my wife', it is a kind of memorial to Grace and also a 'buried tribute' to his wife who, like the character in the play, had to experience giving birth to a dead baby, 'utterly alone' with no midwife to help her while he ran frantically down the hospital corridors looking for help. It would be pat to suggest that the scene is a kind of therapy; if anything, it is a protest.

Haig tells me that he and and his wife have improvised a 'domestic Zen' garden in Grace's memory, consisting of gravel, bamboo and bonsai. 'It is very peaceful, even if its little water feature is a bit blocked up at the moment,' he says.

There is nothing pious about Haig, though there have been times when it might have helped to believe in God - 'My younger sister died when she was only 22.' She died unexpectedly, of a brain haemorrhage, and the experience has left him with a tendency to be always braced for the worst. Sometimes, his children ask him about heaven and he tries to be 'fluffy' about it. He hopes he can get away with this until their corrective 'cynicism' sets in.

With such a big family, he not only hopes to go on acting, he 'needs' the work, he says. But he is 'profoundly happy that writing comes into the equation'. What dreams does he have for future roles? He would love to play Iago one day, he says.

In the meantime, he is more than happy to settle for Ayckbourn who, in House and Garden , takes theatrical virtuosity to extremes, running two plays in two theatres simultaneously, with the same cast commuting to and fro between auditoria. Haig describes Ayckbourn as 'when on form, the greatest comic writer around'. And he relishes the character he plays, who he describes as 'angry, stupid, endearing and very funny'.

When he was in his teens, Haig was thrown out of his public school, Rugby, because of a persistent inability to adhere to minor school rules. The letter home read: 'He must completely reform his character and appearance.' This sounds like career advice to me. Haig has been doing exactly as he was told ever since, on stage at least. In every way, his former headmaster should be proud of him.

 The Good Samaritan opens on 6 July at Hampstead Theatre (020 7722 9301)

webTitle: And you thought Christopher Walken couldn't get any nastier

fields.headline: And you thought Christopher Walken couldn't get any nastier
fields.standfirst: America's creepiest actor plays up for Britain's wildest director, while yet another of the Friends makes a feeble flop
fields.trailText: America's creepiest actor plays up for Britain's wildest director, while yet another of the Friends makes a feeble flop.
fields.body:
Donald Cammell's Wild Side (112 mins, 18) Directed by Donald Cammell; starring Christopher Walken, Anne Heche, Joan Chen, Steven Bauer

Beyond the Mat (103 mins, 15) Directed by Barry Blaustein; starring Terry Funk, Jake Roberts, Mick Foley

Kikujiro (122 mins, 12) Directed by Takeshi Kitano; starring Beat Takeshi, Yusuke Sekiguchi

The Best Man (121 mins, 15) Directed by Malcolm D. Lee; starring Taye Diggs, Nia Long, Morris Chestnut

Three to Tango (99 mins, 15) Directed by Damon Santostefano; starring Matthew Perry, Neve Campbell, Dylan McDermott

Like William Burroughs, British film-maker Donald Cammell was the scion of an immensely rich family (the Cammell Laird shipbuilders) who reacted violently against his respectable background. Both lived outrageously unconventional lives of drugs, orgies and diabolical dabbling, and produced extravagant, deliberately provocative works concerned, often mystically, with bisexuality and the perverted exercise of power. Unlike Burroughs, who killed his wife, Cammell killed himself, dying in Hollywood in 1996 at the age of 62.

Cammell's first film, Performance , co-directed with Nicolas Roeg, is one of the most remarkable to emerge from a British studio and encapsulates the culture of Swinging London at its most seductively corrupt. He was forced by Warner Brothers to re-edit it drastically and he only completed three more pictures - the SF curiosity Demon Seed (Julie Christie impregnated by a computer), the mystic thriller White of the Eye (serial killer loose in the Arizona desert) and Wild Side , which was chopped up by its producers and sent straight to cable TV in 1995. It was the contemptuous treatment of this last film that proved the last straw, as it were, for Cammell, but he was still hoping to regain control of it when he shot himself. Now his editor and friend, Frank Mazzola, with the help of Channel 4 and Tartan Films, has restored the director's cut, and it is being shown under the somewhat tautologous title of Donald Cammell's Wild Side. It could as easily be called 'Christopher Walken on the Wild Side', for in that most volatile of American actors Cammell found a perfect exponent of his dangerous art. Walken plays an out-of-control financial crook, Bruno, the world's biggest money launderer, on whom the federal authorities have planted a psychotic undercover agent, Tony (Steven Bauer), as his chauffeur. A beautiful Los Angeles banker, Alex Lee (Anne Heche), is moonlighting as a $1,000-a-night call-girl to pay off her mortgage. She services the sexually voracious Bruno, is raped by Tony and then blackmailed by the Feds. Walken sends his Chinese wife Virginia (Joan Chen) to Alex's bank as part of a gigantic scam and the two women fall passionately in love.

The film is from start to finish absolutely crazy, full of baroque dialogue and over-the-top performances. On one level it's a power game between an unlikely unhinged quartet, on another it's an orgy in serial form. It is often queasily risible, as when the financier prepares to bugger his chauffeur in front of Alex to demonstrate his superiority, and makes the intended victim roll the condom on for him as he smokes a cigar. Yet like all Cammell's work, Wild Side is oddly compelling - riveting in the sense that you feel nailed to a post as you watch it. The editing is disconcerting, the interiors claustrophobic, and Cammell uses to considerable emblematic effect the township of Long Beach, where the immaculate three-funnelled Queen Mary is isolated in an industrial seaside wasteland. In a curious reference back to the London of the 1960s, the heroine's nasty boss is called Rachman, presumably after the property racketeer involved in the Profumo scandal.

Wrestling has produced writers as diverse as Brian Glover, Steve Tesich and John Irving, but it's never been taken seriously the way boxing is and there's little in Beyond the Mat, a documentary by Saturday Night Live writer Barry W. Blaustein, to persuade us otherwise. As conducted by the multi-million-dollar World Wrestling Federation and its small-time rivals, professional wrestling is a branch of showbiz and the circus. But however commercialised and phoney the sport, its participants get badly hurt (it's almost as dangerous as rodeo-riding) and strive to retain their self-respect. Most retire penniless and crippled; a few never give up; one of them, Jesse Ventura, made it to the Governor's mansion in Minnesota. Blaustein, a fan since childhood, follows them around, watching them perform, hearing their confused life stories, meet ing their sad families. There is fascinating material here, but it's one of those personal documentaries where 'personal' often seems a synonym for rambling and self-indulgent.

With Kikujiro, writer-director-actor Takeshi 'Beat' Kitano turns aside from his usual stylised gangster films to make a gentle road movie that resembles a Wallace Beery picture of the 1930s. He plays a dim, lumbering petty criminal sent by his wife to escort a nine-year-old lad, who's been living a latch-key life with his grandma, in search of the mother he hasn't seen for years. Along the way they meet a variety of violent, kindly, eccentric folk and the result is amusing, whimsical, sad and overlong. The little boy is delightful.

From America come two mediocre comedies by first-time directors. Marginally the better is The Best Man, produced by Spike Lee and directed by his cousin Malcolm D. Lee, and centring on the effect a forthcoming roman à clef has on the wedding of a macho football star. The novel, written by his best man, reveals that the bride-to-be had been the author's lover. It's a slow, clumsy picture and the final scenes are excruciatingly sentimental. But the characters, all well-off African-American professionals in their late twenties, are staggeringly handsome and beautiful.

Damon Santostefano's Three to Tango is the latest feeble vehicle for one of the stars of Friends, in this case the pudgy, unprepossessing Matthew Perry who plays a struggling Chicago architect mistakenly thought to be gay by a rich business tycoon and assigned to spy on the man's mistress (Neve Campbell). The plotting is crude, and apart from the homosexual jokes there are running gags about vomiting and the size of black men's penises. It's all as tasteless and long drawn-out as a three-day-old piece of chewing gum used for a skipping rope.

Lee; starring Taye Diggs, Nia Long, Morris Chestnut Three to Tango (99 mins, 15) Directed by Damon Santostefano; starring Matthew Perry, Neve Campbell, Dylan McDermott Like William Burroughs, British film-maker Donald Cammell was the scion of an immensely rich family (the Cammell Laird shipbuilders) who reacted violently against his respectable background. Both lived outrageously unconventional lives of drugs, orgies and diabolical dabbling, and produced extravagant, deliberately provocative works concerned, often mystically, with bisexuality and the perverted exercise of power. Unlike Burroughs, who killed his wife, Cammell killed himself, dying in Hollywood in 1996 at the age of 62. Cammell's first film, Performance , co-directed with Nicolas Roeg, is one of the most remarkable to emerge from a British studio and encapsulates the culture of Swinging London at its most seductively corrupt. He was forced by Warner Brothers to re-edit it drastically and he only completed three more pictures - the SF curiosity Demon Seed (Julie Christie impregnated by a computer), the mystic thriller White of the Eye (serial killer loose in the Arizona desert) and Wild Side , which was chopped up by its producers and sent straight to cable TV in 1995. It was the contemptuous treatment of this last film that proved the last straw, as it were, for Cammell, but he was still hoping to regain control of it when he shot himself. Now his editor and friend, Frank Mazzola, with the help of Channel 4 and Tartan Films, has restored the director's cut, and it is being shown under the somewhat tautologous title of Donald Cammell's Wild Side. Walken plays an out-of-control financial crook, Bruno, the world's biggest money launderer, on whom the federal authorities have planted a psychotic undercover agent, Tony (Steven Bauer), as his chauffeur. A beautiful Los Angeles banker, Alex Lee (Anne Heche), is moonlighting as a $1,000-a-night call-girl to pay off her mortgage. She services the sexually voracious Bruno, is raped by Tony and then blackmailed by the Feds. Walken sends his Chinese wife Virginia (Joan Chen) to Alex's bank as part of a gigantic scam and the two women fall passionately in love. The film is from start to finish absolutely crazy, full of baroque dialogue and over-the-top performances. On one level it's a power game between an unlikely unhinged quartet, on another it's an orgy in serial form. It is often queasily risible, as when the financier prepares to bugger his chauffeur in front of Alex to demonstrate his superiority, and makes the intended victim roll the condom on for him as he smokes a cigar. Yet like all Cammell's work, Wild Side is oddly compelling - riveting in the sense that you feel nailed to a post as you watch it. The editing is disconcerting, the interiors claustrophobic, and Cammell uses to considerable emblematic effect the township of Long Beach, where the immaculate three-funnelled Queen Mary is isolated in an industrial seaside wasteland. In a curious reference back to the London of the 1960s, the heroine's nasty boss is called Rachman, presumably after the property racketeer involved in the Profumo scandal. Wrestling has produced writers as diverse as Brian Glover, Steve Tesich and John Irving, but it's never been taken seriously the way boxing is and there's little in Beyond the Mat, a documentary by Saturday Night Live writer Barry W. fields.headline: We'll meet a hen...
fields.standfirst: Nick Park's latest feat of clay is a hand-crafted gem. Movies like this are as rare as, well, hens' teeth
fields.trailText: Nick Park's latest feat of clay is a hand-crafted gem. Movies like this are as rare as, well, hens' teeth
fields.body:
Chicken Run (83 mins, U) Directed by Peter Lord and Nick Park; featuring the voices of Mel Gibson, Julia Sawalha, Miranda Richardson, Jane Horrocks

Most aspects of the cinema have been the subject of books by scholars or buffs in the past 30 years. But possibly the oddest is Cluck!, a wondrously erudite, tongue-in-cheek study of chickens on the screen, written in 1980 by Jon-Stephen Fink and Mieke van der Linden. The authors' rating system of chicken-stars went from one (Elementary Incident, e.g. Patton) to four (Awesome Consequence, e.g. The Gold Rush, Freaks), and if they are preparing a new edition they will have little hesitation in putting Chicken Run into the top category.

This fine family entertainment is the first feature-length film from Aardman, the animation studio based in Bristol that has been dazzling us for 20 years with its feats of clay. This one is co-directed by Peter Lord, co-founder of Aardman, and Nick Park, the creator of Wallace and Gromit and winner of Oscars for Creature Comforts, The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave, which opened nearly five years ago and was loosely inspired by Brief Encounter. Chicken Run is a very close parody of the prisoner-of-war camp genre, especially The Great Escape. In this case, however, the PoWs are Plasticine chickens and the camp is a farm in Yorkshire surrounded by barbed wire, policed by vicious guard dogs and run by the ferocious Mrs Tweedy (Miranda Richardson) whose jack-booted resemblance to Irma Grise of Belsen infamy is slightly mitigated by her dim husband who looks like Wallace's black-sheep brother. In contrast to the not dissimilar Babe, there are no decent humans here.

The camp's escape officer is Ginger (voiced by Julia Sawalha in the manner of her imperturbable Saffie in Absolutely Fabulous) and the movie begins with a lively montage of ingenious escape attempts. Between each of them Ginger is thrown into the coal-bin cooler where, like Steve McQueen in The Great Escape, she bounces a baseball. The movie takes on a darker shade when a hen is executed by Mrs Tweedy for failing to lay eggs (we see the shadow of the falling axe), and it threatens to become positively black when the Tweedies decide to switch from producing eggs to manufacturing chicken pies, thus turning the farm into an extermination camp.

But Park and his associates know that while swans can be tragic, hens can only be comic. So they endeavour to make us care about their poultry, but avoid easy pathos and seek to keep sentimentality at bay.

This isn't an allegory in the tradition of The Parliament of Fowls or Animal Farm, and there are no uplifting, heartrending songs in the Disney manner. The only musical interlude is a jive session the hens have with Rocky, a flying Rhode Island rooster from the States (Mel Gibson) who has escaped from a circus and landed in the camp. Rocky provides a foil for Fowler (Benjamin Whitrow), the ageing cock-of-the-walk nostalgically obsessed with his days in the RAF, and some love interest for Ginger.

More important, Ginger gets him to start a flying school for a mass escape by air. This hilariously disastrous enterprise is observed by a pair of black-marketeer rats (Timothy Spall, Phil Daniels) who mock the hens' antics with lines such as 'Birds of a feather flop together' and 'Poultry in motion'. In fact, except for refraining from references to getting laid, there is not a single chicken joke or pun that goes unused, and I now even feel bad about writing 'e.g.'.

Flying the coop using your own wings would have been the inspirational way out, but the Aardman people wisely reject it. Instead they opt for a flying machine of the sort built in Colditz and run up by the stranded survivors in Flight of the Phoenix. This gives Park the chance to create another eccentric contraption of a Heath-Robinson or Roland Emmett sort.

Stalag Luft III would have had trouble containing inmates who could transform a string of fairylights into a flarepath and use the ratchets of a deck-chair to create a take-off ramp. Naturally Mac, the camp's resident engineer, is, like Star Trek 's Scotty, from north of the border.

The film flags slightly from time to time, but for most of the way it is prodigally and prodigiously inventive, both visually and verbally. For me, coming to Chicken Run after such smoothly brilliant computer-generated Hollywood films as Toy Story, Antz and A Bug's Life was like sitting down to a home-cooked Sunday dinner of beef, Yorkshire pudding and home-grown potatoes after weeks of beautifully packaged meals from the microwave.

We know that every second of the film involves hours of painstaking physical work moving and adjusting the figures and sets. But even if you didn't know about the laborious process of clay animation, you would recognise the virtuosity and sense something lovingly hand-crafted in Chicken Run.

fields.headline: It's reel up north
fields.standfirst: Do US audiences identify more with Britain's regions?
fields.trailText: Do US audiences identify more with Britain's regions?
fields.body:
If you're a movie producer intent on having an American hit with a British film, here's a handy hint. Set it in Accrington. Or Penrith. In fact, the further north the better. Chicken Run, a distinctly low-tech animated tale of Yorkshire poultry on the lam is currently wowing audiences across the United States (though tales of American youth adopting the argot Austin Powers-style,calling each other 'git face' and replacing gangsta rap with On Ilkley Moor Baht'at are, thankfully, exaggerated).

It's only one in a string of films set in northern Britain that have delighted American audiences. Back in 1983 Local Hero set its whimsical action in an isolated Scottish fishing village, while the more memorable portions of An American Werewolf In London were set not in the nation's capital but on the Yorkshire Moors.

More recently The Full Monty delivered stripping unemployed Sheffield steelworkers to delighted American audiences. Brassed Off introduced colliery brass bands to appreciative Yanks and even East Is East, a story about a chip-shop owning Pakistani family in Seventies Salford, enjoyed a little US success.

And there are a slew in the pipeline with good transatlantic prospects. Purely Belter , a Newcastle tale of a pair of kids and football garnered rave reviews from industry bible Variety when it premiered in Cannes and There's Only One Jimmy Grimble, a feel-good football (or no doubt in the US, 'soccer') story set in Manchester looks promising.

So what is it about Britain's nether regions that wows American audiences?

Perhaps it's that inner-city audiences in Chicago or Detroit have more in common with unemployed steel workers or extended working-class families struggling with everyday life than they have with the inhabitants of Notting Hill (and even that smash hit had an imported slice of regionalism in the Welsh shape of Rhys Ifans). Or maybe even they have got sick of the entirety of British culture on celluloid being represented by stock footage of a red number 38 bus negotiating Piccadilly Circus.

Whatever the reason, the cappuccino-swilling British film executives of Soho may want to look to Hollywood as a setting for their next British blockbuster. Hollywood, Birmingham, that is.

webTitle: Brazilian film dances to a new rhythm

fields.headline: Brazilian film dances to a new rhythm
fields.standfirst: An exciting new wave of Brazilian cinema fusing verve and social realism - inspired by 'patron saint' Walter Salles - is coming here. Report by Daniel Whitaker
fields.trailText: An exciting new wave of Brazilian cinema fusing verve and social realism - inspired by 'patron saint' Walter Salles - is coming here. Report by Daniel Whitaker
fields.body:
The film industry, that well-spring of cynicism, is not the most obvious place to go looking for salvation. But Walter Salles, director of the much feted Central Station and an emblematic figure within the Brazilian film industry, is an optimistic man.

'What we all look for is the possibility to rewrite in one way or another our own story,' says Salles, speaking from his Videofilmes studio in Rio de Janeiro. You hope his words of new beginnings might be true about life. They are certainly true of Brazil's film industry, triumphantly back on the world scene after a long hiatus.

There's a hot rash of Brazilian films screening across London in various festivals over the coming months. In this veritable cine-carneval Salles's work will be among films testifying to the power and breadth of what has been shot in Brazil - most of which has been cruelly denied to audiences in this country. Love stories of the wealthy, like Baretto's seductive Ipanema-set Bossa Nova , or of the poor, like veteran director Carlos Diegues's tragic Orfeu , will be shown alongside tense tales of the southern badlands, like Beto Brant's acclaimed debut Belly Up . There are takes on what it means to be black (Macunaima), or of Japanese (Gaijin) or Italian (O Quadrilho) origin in perhaps the world's most successful melting pot. And also a generous helping from the Cinema Novo of the 1960s, when Brazilian directors kept pace with Italian neo-realists like Fellini.

This month sees the National Film Theatre showing 24 Brazilian films while the Barbican runs another dozen, all from the 1990s. Then, in September, the indefatigable Eva Tarr will launch her 11th annual Latin American Film Festival, first at her Metro cinema in W1 then around the UK, again with a focus on Brazil. 'You leave a Brazilian film feeling alive,' says Tarr.

Away from the screen, an unprecedented wave of Brazilian rhythms, photography, theatre and dance will also serve as background throughout the summer. The excuse is the country's 500th birthday, which has seen big Brazilian companies overjoyed to score PR points by sponsoring international cultural tours. Back in South America's largest country, some of the reflection is darker, focusing on a society that produces the world's largest gap between rich and poor and enough real-life violence that no local director feels the urge to glamorise it as Western gangster chic.

But while their country's enormous problems are treated with unfailing realism, Brazilian films do emanate a steady faith in the prospect of redemption. Salles sees it as the idealism of youth in a nation still preoccupied with discovering its identity: 'How can you be cynical in a moment like this?'

And he sees film as a means to change things, even though 'the targets are not so easily identifiable' as they were in the clear-cut military dictatorship years of the 1970s and 80s. 'The day I start to believe that there are no inter-relations between art and society, I will stop making films,' he declares.

Salles is not alone. Brazilian films, whatever their overt theme, do tend to focus on changing the way people see each other. John King, author of a forthcoming book on Latin American cinema, Magical Reels, and one of the organisers of the NFT series, points out how the focus has shifted from the overtly political message of Cinema Novo to a more psychological and complex approach today. Yet still most films from Brazil are moral fables, saccharine-free.

Here in Britain the idea of moral progress through film (especially subtitled ones!) sounds fatally worthy, and dull to watch, especially to the distributors and TV execs who control what is on offer to us on any given evening. They have proved that Hollywood, celebrities, a steady ratcheting-up of violence and only the most pre-tested plot formulas can be converted into steady cash.

Yet history shows audience tastes are mobile, while many people do seem to want something more from their movies. And the thing about most of these current Brazilian directors is that they do have a way with cinema: a 'way' in that even though budgets are small and subtitles do need reading, your emotional engagement is turned on like a switch and then held. Inventive disrespect for genres is combined with characterisations and narratives that pull you in. The likes of Barreto, Salles and Lima make it all seem so easy on the screen, just as Pelé did on the football field. Film is a serious business to Brazilians - and they are seriously good at it.

The directors are helped by strong, occasionally breathtaking, cinematography - witness the work of Affonso Beatto in Orfeu or Pedro Farkas in the haunting Oyster and the Wind , unfortunately absent from the Barbican series. A lot of Brazilian camerawork is influenced by years when their film industry hibernated and wages were earned, just as by our own Ridley Scott, in advertising. This overlap is still alive - Salles's own studio still earns some handy money that way.

It's with these companion qualities that intelligent cinema becomes a pleasure. That sense of leaving the cinema feeling quite different about something, even if it takes a few days to define what, can happen easily with good Brazilian films (though with Helena Solberg's biopic Carmen Miranda - Bananas is my Business I think you just need to love samba and fruit-topped hats). In this they share something with current output from China and Iran, but perhaps a narrower cultural gulf means less is lost to European viewers in translation.

But where does this faith come from? The 'young country' argument doesn't fully convince. US culture is more youthful, yet most Hollywood pictures are cynical in how they treat their audiences. Perhaps a more likely reason is the innate religiosity of Brazilian culture, whether those roots are Amerindian, African, Catholic or (as with several directors) Jewish. Belief just seems to make more sense in Brazil, whether you are between the Sugar Loaf mountain and Atlantic breakers or on the edge of the world's last major rainforest.

Some sort of providence did seem to guide the making of Central Station . Salles says: 'We looked for the boy who could play Josué's role for a whole year, and interviewed over 1,500 children.' Yet Vinicius de Oliveira, the nine-year-old actor whose relationship with Fernanda Montenegro is the backbone of the film, found Salles. Vinicius was shining shoes at the airport and was guided to Salles's footwear as a likely prospect. 'He chose me before I could choose him.'

Even before Central Station , the 'second chance' theme was prominent in Salles's oeuvre. In Socorro Nobre he presents the true story of how a 36-year term female prisoner began a relationship with a Polish-Jewish sculptor who carves wood he finds in the Amazonian jungle (giving those branches their own second chance in life). In the suspenseful Midnight a prisoner is allowed to escape on millennium eve on condition he carry out a murder. Most famously, the Oscar-nominated and magical Central Station gave us Montenegro at her best as the epitome of a cynical character given an opportunity for self-reform.

Brazilian cinema itself is going through a rebirth. After the international success and optimism of Cinema Novo came deep pessimism as military rule was followed by a free-market president so corrupt he was impeached. Film production dried up to almost nothing: in 1992 just 36,000 tickets were sold within Brazil to watch domestic pictures. Now 25 titles are made each year and there was a home audience of six million for Brazilian-made films in 1999.

The new films are pulling in both international awards and foreign actors, like Alan Arkin in Four Days in September and Amy Irving in Bossa Nova.

The revival is also a broader one. The traditional film production centres of Rio and Sao Paulo have been joined by new production companies in cities of greater African influence, such as Fortaleza, and in mountainous Minas Gerais. City governments have often been catalysts, offering tax breaks and that uniquely Brazilian way of helping overcome problems known as jeito .

Salles, sitting astride a stack of Golden Globes, Baftas and plaudits from Berlin and Cannes (50 awards for Central Station alone), is surely the patron saint of this renaissance. Helpfully, given his spokesman role, he is as articulate in French and English as in Portuguese; the man is friendly, generous, funny and on top has to suffer film-star good looks.

But like all supposed saints, underneath he is human. A privileged background and a period working in the advertising game might both charge his progressive role now with the impetus of guilt (though perhaps that itself brings more understanding of the human condition).

So good luck to the plucky, crusading Brazilians and the films they are bringing us. Here, under grey clouds, and armed with consummate skill at put-downs and indifference, we Brits may prove too tough a quarry for redemptive cinema. This summer offers a chance to find out.

World cinema's other recent hotspots

Denmark

The reasoning behind the Dogme 95 group's back-to-basics manifesto was debatable but it produced a flurry of impressive movies including Festen and Mifune from last year. However, it seems leading light Lars von Trier has renounced the group's ethos with his new musical, Dancer in the Dark .

Iran

Despite artistic restrictions imposed by the autocratic regime, Iranian cinema has recently enjoyed a boom period. Directors such as Abbas Kiarostami (Taste of Cherry), Mohsen Makhmalbaf (Bread and Flower) and his daughter Samira Makhmalbaf The Apple), who made her debut as a teenager, have led the advance.

Hong Kong

The universal appeal of so-called chop-socky movies propelled Hong Kong martial arts movies into cult viewing internationally and influenced Hollywood. The likes of filmmaker John Woo (Bullet in the Head) and actors Chow Yun-Fat, Jackie Chan and Michelle Yeoh have subsequently had success in America.

China

According to Martin Scorsese, Chinese films were at the forefront of world cinema in the Nineties. Wary of the censors, the stirring films of directors such as Zhang Yimou and Chen Kaige used star Gong Li (Farewell My Concubine) and historical settings to critique contemporary society.
