Love stories of the wealthy, like Baretto's seductive Ipanema-set Bossa Nova , or of the poor, like veteran director Carlos Diegues's tragic Orfeu , will be shown alongside tense tales of the southern badlands, like Beto Brant's acclaimed debut Belly Up . There are takes on what it means to be black (Macunaima), or of Japanese (Gaijin) or Italian (O Quadrilho) origin in perhaps the world's most successful melting pot. And also a generous helping from the Cinema Novo of the 1960s, when Brazilian directors kept pace with Italian neo-realists like Fellini. This month sees the National Film Theatre showing 24 Brazilian films while the Barbican runs another dozen, all from the 1990s. Then, in September, the indefatigable Eva Tarr will launch her 11th annual Latin American Film Festival, first at her Metro cinema in W1 then around the UK, again with a focus on Brazil. 'You leave a Brazilian film feeling alive,' says Tarr. Away from the screen, an unprecedented wave of Brazilian rhythms, photography, theatre and dance will also serve as background throughout the summer. The excuse is the country's 500th birthday, which has seen big Brazilian companies overjoyed to score PR points by sponsoring international cultural tours. Back in South America's largest country, some of the reflection is darker, focusing on a society that produces the world's largest gap between rich and poor and enough real-life violence that no local director feels the urge to glamorise it as Western gangster chic. But while their country's enormous problems are treated with unfailing realism, Brazilian films do emanate a steady faith in the prospect of redemption. Salles sees it as the idealism of youth in a nation still preoccupied with discovering its identity: 'How can you be cynical in a moment like this?' And he sees film as a means to change things, even though 'the targets are not so easily identifiable' as they were in the clear-cut military dictatorship years of the 1970s and 80s. 'The day I start to believe that there are no inter-relations between art and society, I will stop making films,' he declares. Salles is not alone. Brazilian films, whatever their overt theme, do tend to focus on changing the way people see each other. John King, author of a forthcoming book on Latin American cinema, Magical Reels, and one of the organisers of the NFT series, points out how the focus has shifted from the overtly political message of Cinema Novo to a more psychological and complex approach today. Yet still most films from Brazil are moral fables, saccharine-free. Here in Britain the idea of moral progress through film (especially subtitled ones!) sounds fatally worthy, and dull to watch, especially to the distributors and TV execs who control what is on offer to us on any given evening. They have proved that Hollywood, celebrities, a steady ratcheting-up of violence and only the most pre-tested plot formulas can be converted into steady cash. Yet history shows audience tastes are mobile, while many people do seem to want something more from their movies. And the thing about most of these current Brazilian directors is that they do have a way with cinema: a 'way' in that even though budgets are small and subtitles do need reading, your emotional engagement is turned on like a switch and then held. Inventive disrespect for genres is combined with characterisations and narratives that pull you in. The likes of Barreto, Salles and Lima make it all seem so easy on the screen, just as Pelé did on the football field. Film is a serious business to Brazilians - and they are seriously good at it. The directors are helped by strong, occasionally breathtaking, cinematography - witness the work of Affonso Beatto in Orfeu or Pedro Farkas in the haunting Oyster and the Wind , unfortunately absent from the Barbican series. A lot of Brazilian camerawork is influenced by years when their film industry hibernated and wages were earned, just as by our own Ridley Scott, in advertising. This overlap is still alive - Salles's own studio still earns some handy money that way. It's with these companion qualities that intelligent cinema becomes a pleasure. That sense of leaving the cinema feeling quite different about something, even if it takes a few days to define what, can happen easily with good Brazilian films (though with Helena Solberg's biopic Carmen Miranda - Bananas is my Business I think you just need to love samba and fruit-topped hats). In this they share something with current output from China and Iran, but perhaps a narrower cultural gulf means less is lost to European viewers in translation. But where does this faith come from? The 'young country' argument doesn't fully convince. US culture is more youthful, yet most Hollywood pictures are cynical in how they treat their audiences. Perhaps a more likely reason is the innate religiosity of Brazilian culture, whether those roots are Amerindian, African, Catholic or (as with several directors) Jewish. Belief just seems to make more sense in Brazil, whether you are between the Sugar Loaf mountain and Atlantic breakers or on the edge of the world's last major rainforest. Some sort of providence did seem to guide the making of Central Station . Salles says: 'We looked for the boy who could play Josué's role for a whole year, and interviewed over 1,500 children.' Yet Vinicius de Oliveira, the nine-year-old actor whose relationship with Fernanda Montenegro is the backbone of the film, found Salles. Vinicius was shining shoes at the airport and was guided to Salles's footwear as a likely prospect. 'He chose me before I could choose him.' Even before Central Station , the 'second chance' theme was prominent in Salles's oeuvre. In Socorro Nobre he presents the true story of how a 36-year term female prisoner began a relationship with a Polish-Jewish sculptor who carves wood he finds in the Amazonian jungle (giving those branches their own second chance in life). In the suspenseful Midnight a prisoner is allowed to escape on millennium eve on condition he carry out a murder. Most famously, the Oscar-nominated and magical Central Station gave us Montenegro at her best as the epitome of a cynical character given an opportunity for self-reform. Brazilian cinema itself is going through a rebirth. After the international success and optimism of Cinema Novo came deep pessimism as military rule was followed by a free-market president so corrupt he was impeached. Film production dried up to almost nothing: in 1992 just 36,000 tickets were sold within Brazil to watch domestic pictures. Now 25 titles are made each year and there was a home audience of six million for Brazilian-made films in 1999. The new films are pulling in both international awards and foreign actors, like Alan Arkin in Four Days in September and Amy Irving in Bossa Nova. The revival is also a broader one. The traditional film production centres of Rio and Sao Paulo have been joined by new production companies in cities of greater African influence, such as Fortaleza, and in mountainous Minas Gerais. City governments have often been catalysts, offering tax breaks and that uniquely Brazilian way of helping overcome problems known as jeito . Salles, sitting astride a stack of Golden Globes, Baftas and plaudits from Berlin and Cannes (50 awards for Central Station alone), is surely the patron saint of this renaissance. Helpfully, given his spokesman role, he is as articulate in French and English as in Portuguese; the man is friendly, generous, funny and on top has to suffer film-star good looks. But like all supposed saints, underneath he is human. A privileged background and a period working in the advertising game might both charge his progressive role now with the impetus of guilt (though perhaps that itself brings more understanding of the human condition). So good luck to the plucky, crusading Brazilians and the films they are bringing us. Here, under grey clouds, and armed with consummate skill at put-downs and indifference, we Brits may prove too tough a quarry for redemptive cinema. This summer offers a chance to find out. World cinema's other recent hotspots Denmark The reasoning behind the Dogme 95 group's back-to-basics manifesto was debatable but it produced a flurry of impressive movies including Festen and Mifune from last year. However, it seems leading light Lars von Trier has renounced the group's ethos with his new musical, Dancer in the Dark . Iran Despite artistic restrictions imposed by the autocratic regime, Iranian cinema has recently enjoyed a boom period. Directors such as Abbas Kiarostami (Taste of Cherry), Mohsen Makhmalbaf (Bread and Flower) and his daughter Samira Makhmalbaf The Apple), who made her debut as a teenager, have led the advance. Hong Kong The universal appeal of so-called chop-socky movies propelled Hong Kong martial arts movies into cult viewing internationally and influenced Hollywood. The likes of filmmaker John Woo (Bullet in the Head) and actors Chow Yun-Fat, Jackie Chan and Michelle Yeoh have subsequently had success in America. China According to Martin Scorsese, Chinese films were at the forefront of world cinema in the Nineties. Wary of the censors, the stirring films of directors such as Zhang Yimou and Chen Kaige used star Gong Li (Farewell My Concubine) and historical settings to critique contemporary society.  NFT: 020 7928 3232; www.bfi.org.uk/nft Barbican: 020 7638 8891; www.barbican-org.uk Brazil500 Festival Hotline: 020 7399 9265 Latin American Film Festival (in September): www.metrocinema.co.uk

fields.headline: Rachel Griffiths
fields.standfirst: ...spiky, outspoken and up for a bit of everything
fields.trailText: ...spiky, outspoken and up for a bit of everything
fields.body:
When Muriel's Wedding was charming international audiences a few years back, it was difficult to know which actress was destined for bigger things. As the awkward, plump heroine, Toni Collete was the star, but Rachel Griffiths left an indelible impression. Playing her tomboyish best friend, Rhonda, she blazed across the screen, inspiring guffaws and eventually pathos.

Since then Griffiths has often been cast as the 'other woman', not in the romantic sense, but the spiky, outspoken counterpart to the lead role. In fact, when director Anand Turner wanted to cast her as Jacqueline Du Pré's retiring sister in Hilary and Jackie , he met some resistance. 'We both had to convince quite a few people that I was right for it,' she says. 'That character was the shadow behind the genius, and people don't remember me as the shadow in Muriel's Wedding.'

Still, her controlled performance as the selfless sister complemented Emily Watson's more mannered one as the flamboyant genius. Both actresses were nominated for Oscars. Neither won, but the industry recognition has helped the Australian actress.

Her first major starring role in Me, Myself and I was probably the result of her enhanced profile. In the film she takes on the dual role of a lovelorn media high-flyer. Her idea of a romantic evening is to open a bottle of wine, gaze at photos of vintage boyfriends and say wistfully: 'Why did I let you go?'

She subsequently falls into a parallel universe in which she married her teenage sweetheart and had three children. The grass, as she finds out, is not greener, just a different hue. Basically, the film revisits Sliding Doors territory with more humour and insight.

Griffiths could also rival Gywneth Paltrow in the adopted Brit stakes. She probably didn't want it, but she could have been Bridget Jones if Renee Zellwegger hadn't got there first. Apart from Hilary and Jackie , she's pulled off convincing English accents in Jude and My Son the Fanatic . Both films were well received, and the latter was one of those underrated domestic films which fail to reach an audience. Griffiths was superb playing that most clichéd of roles, the prostitute with a heart of gold.

The problem with Griffiths's career to date has been that she has been memorable in films that often aren't. She hasn't had the sort of Breaking the Waves role which elevated Watson from virtual unknown to art-house poster girl.

Such roles are rare, and when it comes to mainstream success Griffiths is unwilling to play by Holly wood's rules. She took a small role in the Julia Roberts comedy My Best Friend's Wedding, but she didn't bother to chose a suitable follow-up project. Instead she crossed the Atlantic to take supporting roles in Divorcing Jack and Among Giants . The former was interesting, the latter wasn't.

Me, Myself and I probably won't emerge as the pivotal film in Griffiths's CV, not least because this summer moviegoers may confuse it with the Farrelly brothers' blockbuster comedy Me, Myself and Irene , starring Jim Carrey and Zellwegger. Griffiths's versatility doesn't match Carrey's facial elasticity, but she refuses to limit her range. 'I'm like a decathlete really. I want to do a bit of everything. I've yet to meet a human being who doesn't make me laugh, even if I'm laughing at them.'

Five things you should know about Rachel Griffiths

1 Her first acting job was in the community theatre group Woolly Jumpers Inc.

2 She is a staunch supporter of Oxfam's campaign for the Global Charter of Basic Rights.

3 She wrote and performed in the one-woman show, 'Barbie Gets Hip'.

4 Toronto is her least favourite city.

5 She didn't meet the real Hilary before filming Hilary and Jackie because she 'didn't want to feel like I was depicting some literal truth'.

fields.headline: Work, jest and play
fields.standfirst: What does a star do when he's off duty? If he's George Clooney, he swills beer, hangs out with 'The Boys' and plays practical jokes. But with his matinee idol charisma and a new blockbuster,  The Perfect Storm , about to hit our screens, the self- deprecating, former  ER  doc is on the brink of the becoming  the leading man of the new decade, says  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: What does a star do when he's off duty? If he's George Clooney, he swills beer, hangs out with 'The Boys' and plays practical jokes. But with his matinee idol charisma and a new blockbuster, The Perfect Storm , about to hit our screens, the self- deprecating, former ER doc is on the brink of the becoming the leading man of the new decade, says Mark Morris
fields.body:
George Clooney's friends have a favourite story about him. Richard Kind - the bulky actor who plays Paulie, the naive, hapless, panicky press secretary in Spin City - was staying over at Clooney's house for a while. This happens a lot: Clooney has eight spare bedrooms so his mates can hide out if they've been thrown out by their wives.

This time Kind brought a tiny kitten with him and started growing worried because there was nothing in the litter tray when he returned from work each day. He was so concerned he started feeding the poor kitten laxatives, but the tray was still empty.

One day he walked into the bathroom to find a massive - you might say human-sized - deposit in the tray. Kind screamed: 'Oh, my god Kitty!' loud enough to be heard halfway across LA. Just before he could take the cat to the vet and ask for an explanation of this freak of nature, Clooney owned up...

There are several ways to react to this story. One is disgust that Clooney could be so puerile. Another is bemusement at the idea of a suave, millionaire film star sneaking around, clearing up after a cat and then defecating in a litter tray. But Clooney's friends prefer to see it this way: it demonstrates the dedication to the point of absurdity that distinguishes the true practical joker.

What Clooney's friends think matters because his life seems to be built around them. He calls them The Boys, his core group of eight. They've each got a bedroom in his house, sometimes just so they can stay after all-night poker, or when they've got some more serious crisis. And while they're there they can shoot hoops on his basketball court, watch movies in the screening room and drink Guinness on draught.

And when none of them is around, Clooney shares his space with his potbellied pig, Max, and his two dogs. Sometimes a woman manages to negotiate this male enclave for a while, but not at the moment. And Clooney, a divorced man, swears he'll never get married again.

Adam Sandler, the master of idiot comedy and just about as far as you can get from Clooney on screen, has a similar set-up. The difference is that there's something reclusive about Sandler's life, which seems to be conducted solely with his close friends. Sandler doesn't even speak to the press. Clooney, on the other hand, is happy to let journalists - that is the non-tabloid variety - hang out with him in his house. And if they don't do the interview there, he'll go out drinking with them: he's a beer man. And consequently the press love him. Stars these days tend to be prickly and oversensitive, or therapised and unnervingly confessional. Clooney's different: he's just relaxed, good copy. Ask him about the rumours that he's having an affair with Mark Wahlberg and he'll say: 'That must be my longest Hollywood relationship.'

It's not all quips and practical jokes. He's got a serious side, including the interest in politics he inherited from his fiercely liberal father Nick, who Clooney claims used to tell him off for not going out with black girls. He thinks Jimmy Carter was a much underrated president. And he got involved in a campaign against a Chicago TV station that hired Jerry Springer to comment on the news. Clooney, who has known Springer all his life, was deeply concerned by this dip in journalistic ethics, and let everyone know.

These strongly held opinions come coated in the famous charm. You could see it at Cannes this year. Ever since President Reagan's Libya obsession had Sylvester Stallone running scared from the festival in fear of a terrorist attack there have been mutterings about the end of the affair between Cannes and Hollywood. But Cannes allowed Clooney to sweep it off its feet. The French like their Hollywood stars in the classic mould, and Clooney certainly has a touch of Cary Grant and Humphrey Bogart about him.

In direct contrast to Bruce Willis, scowling as critics jeered at a rough cut of Armageddon, Clooney had the wisdom to come to Cannes with a festival sure thing, the Coen brothers' O Brother, Where Art Thou? But then, that's Clooney all over. These days he is the perfect film star in almost every way. The only thing he can't always do is the one that counts most - get punters into the cinema. His films tend to be medium-size hits at best. Conventionally, his new film, The Perfect Storm, would be seen to be the great test. Based on a true story about a doomed fishing boat, it has ambitious special effects and a summer opening: all the elements that show that the studio is expecting a hit. But in a typical move Clooney has suggested that it doesn't stand a chance in the early summer box office clash with Mel Gibson in The Patriot .

Gibson, as it happens, was the first choice to play the skipper in The Perfect Storm , a fact that Clooney's all too willing to discuss - just as he told everyone that his role in Three Kings was intended for Clint Eastwood. Asked once whether he was a big star, he said: 'Don't kid yourself. I'm the guy following Clint's horse with a shovel.'

George Clooney was five and dressed as a leprechaun when he first appeared on the local TV variety show that his father hosted. 'We were like this vaudeville family,' he always says. His aunt is Rosemary Clooney and her husband was actor Jose Ferrer. But George didn't grow up intending to be an actor: that was all happening in faraway LA. He grew up in Kentucky and Ohio and wanted to play baseball for the Cincinnati Reds. It was a dream that got as far as a try-out, but as soon as he stood on the field with the pros, Clooney knew he would never be a ballplayer.

Instead, after hanging out on set with his cousin, actor Miguel Ferrer, he decided to head to LA and stay with Aunt Rosemary. It was 1982. Clooney credits the next 12 years with giving him some perspective. He did a year on the dreadful sitcom The Facts Of Life , and the first season of Roseanne . He was in The Revenge Of The Killer Tomatoes . He appeared as 'Lip-synching trannie' in one movie. And that was also the era when he got married and divorced. By the time the part of womanising, bullheaded paediatrician Doug Ross came along, Clooney looked like a man rather than a Hollywood pretty boy.

Even now - at 39 - Perfect Storm director Wolfgang Petersen reckons 'he's too young' for the parts that suit him best. ER made him a huge TV star, even if Clooney was eager to credit the show rather than take all the praise himself, given that the show has survived pretty well without him. But he was also quick to criticise the producers when they started to turn the doctors into social workers. His own rule was that Ross could only grieve for a patient a couple of times a season: any doctor affected more often than that would crack up soon enough.

But his TV stardom was slow to transfer to the big screen. This mystified people. It's no great puzzle why most of the Friends stars have struggled to convince on the big screen, but Clooney looked like an old-fashioned movie star. So he succeeded Val Kilmer in the rubber suit for Batman & Robin (1997), the movie that seems to have killed off the series. He was paired with Michelle Pfeiffer in One Fine Day (1996) a romantic comedy that on paper looked like a certain hit, but wasn't. And he was matched with Nicole Kidman for The Peacemaker (1997), directed by ER veteran Mimi Leder. That failed to do much either.

For all the goodwill, Clooney looked like he was going to have to stick to TV. At which point Steven Soderbergh, a director who seemed to have completely self-destructed, came to the rescue. Although it wasn't a big hit, Out Of Sight showed that Clooney - especially in his scenes with Jennifer Lopez - really did have that mysterious quality that stars used to have in the Forties.

By the time Three Kings came out, Clooney had left ER. Again, the film was only a middling success, but, again, the reviews were great, Clooney was excellent and was very proud of the film's political complexity, even if he did get in a punch-up with director David O. Russell. As Clooney's friends tell it, the tension came because, as usual, Clooney had made friends with the crew. And Russell, who had never made an action movie before, started getting panicked by all the helicopters and noise and was taking it out on the crew and the extras. Clooney stepped in, and Russell head-butted him. But he still thinks that Russell did a good job.

So film crews like him, the Coen brothers like him and magazines such as People like him. The South Park guys love him too: he played Sparky the Gay Dog. So maybe The Perfect Storm will finally justify that $12 million pay cheque. And if not, then he's busy producing Wahlberg's next movie, Metal God . And he'll probably do some more live TV following Failsafe, the Cold War drama he organised and starred in that was screened in the US in April.

And then there's Ocean's Eleven, a remake of the legendary but actually rather dismal rat-pack movie. Soderbergh will direct, while Clooney is producing and playing Danny Ocean, the Sinatra role. He has also roped in Julia Roberts, Michael Douglas, Bill Murray and possibly Bruce Willis to do the other parts for peanuts. How did he manage that? Because he's George Clooney, and while the cinema-going public are taking their time to cotton on, the stars know he's a star.

Six decades of male icons

Forties: Cary Grant - The Charmer
Bristol-born Archibald Leach epitomised the debonair Hollywood male until his screen retirement in the Sixties. Adept at high-speed comedy and drama, he made acting look effortless - but underneath the suave exterior was a tough centre, frequently utilised in the films of Hitchcock.

Fifties: Marlon Brando - The Rebel
The birth of the teenager facilitated the iconic status of Brando's outsider. Along with Montgomery Clift and James Dean he spoke to an alienated generation that could relate to his sulky anti-establishment stance in The Wild One and A Streetcar Named Desire , which belied the myth of the idyllic and innocent Fifties.

Sixties: Paul Newman - The Outlaw
A successor to Brando, Newman was a more palatable dissenter, often in trouble with the law in his finest roles (Cool Hand Luke, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid), but rarely unappealing. His famous blue eyes proved a powerful charm. Too square to be a genuine counter-culture figure - see Easy Rider - but nevertheless symptomatic of the times.

Seventies: Robert de Niro - The Loner
Traumatised by Vietnam (The Deer Hunter, Taxi Driver), or devastatingly wilful (Mean Streets, New York, New York) De Niro embodied urban dislocation and often played the anti-hero. The man least likely to play a romantic lead or enjoy a happy ending, the actor's actor instead gave startlingly naturalistic performances in unflattering roles.

Eighties: Sly Stallone -The Indestructible
In his two long-running franchises, Rocky and Rambo, the pugnacious actor seemed invincible and the subsequent box office receipts were huge. In hindsight that may seem laughable, but contemporary critics saw parallels between the star's appeal and that of Reagan's muscular politics.

Nineties: Tom Hanks - The Everyman
After an uninspiring early career as a comic leading man, this decade he re-emerged as an All-American moralist reminiscent of Jimmy Stewart. Unlike Stallone he preferred to battle prejudice (Philadelphia) and made sure everyone played by the rules in World War II (Saving Private Ryan). His favourite co-star is the similarly inoffensive Meg Ryan.

 The Perfect Storm opens in Britain on 28 July and O Brother, Where Art Thou? opens on 15 September

In direct contrast to Bruce Willis, scowling as critics jeered at a rough cut of Armageddon, Clooney had the wisdom to come to Cannes with a festival sure thing, the Coen brothers' O Brother, Where Art Thou? But then, that's Clooney all over. These days he is the perfect film star in almost every way. The only thing he can't always do is the one that counts most - get punters into the cinema. His films tend to be medium-size hits at best. Conventionally, his new film, The Perfect Storm, would be seen to be the great test. Based on a true story about a doomed fishing boat, it has ambitious special effects and a summer opening: all the elements that show that the studio is expecting a hit. But in a typical move Clooney has suggested that it doesn't stand a chance in the early summer box office clash with Mel Gibson in The Patriot . Gibson, as it happens, was the first choice to play the skipper in The Perfect Storm , a fact that Clooney's all too willing to discuss - just as he told everyone that his role in Three Kings was intended for Clint Eastwood. Asked once whether he was a big star, he said: 'Don't kid yourself. I'm the guy following Clint's horse with a shovel.' George Clooney was five and dressed as a leprechaun when he first appeared on the local TV variety show that his father hosted. 'We were like this vaudeville family,' he always says. His aunt is Rosemary Clooney and her husband was actor Jose Ferrer. But George didn't grow up intending to be an actor: that was all happening in faraway LA. He grew up in Kentucky and Ohio and wanted to play baseball for the Cincinnati Reds. It was a dream that got as far as a try-out, but as soon as he stood on the field with the pros, Clooney knew he would never be a ballplayer. Instead, after hanging out on set with his cousin, actor Miguel Ferrer, he decided to head to LA and stay with Aunt Rosemary. It was 1982. Clooney credits the next 12 years with giving him some perspective. He did a year on the dreadful sitcom The Facts Of Life , and the first season of Roseanne . He was in The Revenge Of The Killer Tomatoes . He appeared as 'Lip-synching trannie' in one movie. And that was also the era when he got married and divorced. By the time the part of womanising, bullheaded paediatrician Doug Ross came along, Clooney looked like a man rather than a Hollywood pretty boy. Even now - at 39 - Perfect Storm director Wolfgang Petersen reckons 'he's too young' for the parts that suit him best. ER made him a huge TV star, even if Clooney was eager to credit the show rather than take all the praise himself, given that the show has survived pretty well without him. But he was also quick to criticise the producers when they started to turn the doctors into social workers. His own rule was that Ross could only grieve for a patient a couple of times a season: any doctor affected more often than that would crack up soon enough. But his TV stardom was slow to transfer to the big screen. This mystified people. It's no great puzzle why most of the Friends stars have struggled to convince on the big screen, but Clooney looked like an old-fashioned movie star. So he succeeded Val Kilmer in the rubber suit for Batman & Robin (1997), the movie that seems to have killed off the series. He was paired with Michelle Pfeiffer in One Fine Day (1996) a romantic comedy that on paper looked like a certain hit, but wasn't. And he was matched with Nicole Kidman for The Peacemaker (1997), directed by ER veteran Mimi Leder. That failed to do much either. For all the goodwill, Clooney looked like he was going to have to stick to TV. At which point Steven Soderbergh, a director who seemed to have completely self-destructed, came to the rescue. Although it wasn't a big hit, Out Of Sight showed that Clooney - especially in his scenes with Jennifer Lopez - really did have that mysterious quality that stars used to have in the Forties. By the time Three Kings came out, Clooney had left ER. Again, the film was only a middling success, but, again, the reviews were great, Clooney was excellent and was very proud of the film's political complexity, even if he did get in a punch-up with director David O. Russell. As Clooney's friends tell it, the tension came because, as usual, Clooney had made friends with the crew. And Russell, who had never made an action movie before, started getting panicked by all the helicopters and noise and was taking it out on the crew and the extras. Clooney stepped in, and Russell head-butted him. But he still thinks that Russell did a good job. So film crews like him, the Coen brothers like him and magazines such as People like him. The South Park guys love him too: he played Sparky the Gay Dog. So maybe The Perfect Storm will finally justify that $12 million pay cheque. And if not, then he's busy producing Wahlberg's next movie, Metal God . And he'll probably do some more live TV following Failsafe, the Cold War drama he organised and starred in that was screened in the US in April. And then there's Ocean's Eleven, a remake of the legendary but actually rather dismal rat-pack movie. Soderbergh will direct, while Clooney is producing and playing Danny Ocean, the Sinatra role. He has also roped in Julia Roberts, Michael Douglas, Bill Murray and possibly Bruce Willis to do the other parts for peanuts. How did he manage that? Because he's George Clooney, and while the cinema-going public are taking their time to cotton on, the stars know he's a star. Six decades of male icons Forties: Cary Grant - The Charmer Bristol-born Archibald Leach epitomised the debonair Hollywood male until his screen retirement in the Sixties. Adept at high-speed comedy and drama, he made acting look effortless - but underneath the suave exterior was a tough centre, frequently utilised in the films of Hitchcock. Fifties: Marlon Brando - The Rebel The birth of the teenager facilitated the iconic status of Brando's outsider. Along with Montgomery Clift and James Dean he spoke to an alienated generation that could relate to his sulky anti-establishment stance in The Wild One and A Streetcar Named Desire , which belied the myth of the idyllic and innocent Fifties. Sixties: Paul Newman - The Outlaw A successor to Brando, Newman was a more palatable dissenter, often in trouble with the law in his finest roles (Cool Hand Luke, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid), but rarely unappealing. His famous blue eyes proved a powerful charm. Too square to be a genuine counter-culture figure - see Easy Rider - but nevertheless symptomatic of the times. Seventies: Robert de Niro - The Loner Traumatised by Vietnam (The Deer Hunter, Taxi Driver), or devastatingly wilful (Mean Streets, New York, New York) De Niro embodied urban dislocation and often played the anti-hero. The man least likely to play a romantic lead or enjoy a happy ending, the actor's actor instead gave startlingly naturalistic performances in unflattering roles. Eighties: Sly Stallone -The Indestructible In his two long-running franchises, Rocky and Rambo, the pugnacious actor seemed invincible and the subsequent box office receipts were huge. In hindsight that may seem laughable, but contemporary critics saw parallels between the star's appeal and that of Reagan's muscular politics. Nineties: Tom Hanks - The Everyman After an uninspiring early career as a comic leading man, this decade he re-emerged as an All-American moralist reminiscent of Jimmy Stewart. Unlike Stallone he preferred to battle prejudice (Philadelphia) and made sure everyone played by the rules in World War II (Saving Private Ryan). His favourite co-star is the similarly inoffensive Meg Ryan.  The Perfect Storm opens in Britain on 28 July and O Brother, Where Art Thou? opens on 15 September

fields.headline: Super drug
fields.standfirst: Honey's healing powers help take the sting out of conventional medicines
fields.trailText: Honey's healing powers help take the sting out of conventional medicines.
fields.body:
Since the discovery of the bacterium Helicobacter pylori, the treatment of stomach ulcers has changed significantly. This bug can embed itself in the walls of the stomach, exposing the stomach lining to acid attacks and causing gastritis, which, when this occurs frequently enough, can provide the ideal conditions for a stomach ulcer to develop. Many gastroenterologists believe that Helicobacter pylori is responsible for the majority of stomach ulcers, which in most cases can be countered with the appropriate antibiotics. A patient of mine had been suffering from indigestion for two years before she finally admitted to herself that the root of her problem had to be something other than her erratic eating habits and stress, although these certainly didn't help. A visit to the GP resulted in a stomach ulcer being diagnosed.

Although many people are worried about taking antibiotics, a single course can eradicate the majority of stomach ulcers without increasing the risk of developing a resistance to antibiotics in the longer term. However, as a practitioner, I am well aware that there are those who just don't like, or are unable to stomach, antibiotics. There are also some people who simply don't respond to the antibiotics. But thankfully, some new scientific research appears to offer an alternative to taking medication for stomach problems.

Dr Peter Molan MBE, an associate professor in biochemistry at the University of Waikato, New Zealand, has been researching the healing properties of honey. He has found that when honey comes into contact with bodily moisture, the glucose oxidase enzyme (which is introduced into the honey by bees) slowly releases hydrogen peroxide. Although we more commonly associate hydrogen peroxide with bleaching hair, in this instance it acts as an antiseptic agent. Dr Molan and his research team also recently discovered that some, but not all, types of Manuka honey contain a second natural antibacterial component. This component, which is referred to as UMF, has been proved to be an effective antidote to such 'superbugs' as Staphylococcus aureus and Helicobacter pylori.

New Zealand bees produce Manuka honey from the flowers of the Manuka tree, which has long been used in traditional Maori folk medicine. In laboratory tests, UMF Active Manuka honey has been shown to inhibit the growth of Helicobacter pylori . It has to be said, however, that not all gastroenterologists are convinced that honey destroys Helicobacter pylori completely, but at present it seems that people who are suffering from stomach ulcers caused by this bacterium and others blighted with indigestion or digestive complaints may experience some relief after taking it.

The message that honey is good for your health is hardly new: we all know how soothing hot water laced with honey and lemon can be if we have sore throats, and I always recommend that children recovering from surgical throat procedures eat ice cream with a dollop of honey on it. You may be surprised to read that some doctors report successfully enlisting the aid of honey for treating serious skin conditions such as burns. The scientific explanation lies with honey's antibacterial, tissue-nourishing and growth-stimulating properties. Honey's osmotic effect draws a thin film of moisture from the body to the surface of the skin, thereby creating a barrier between the wound and any dressing. The honey also acts as a natural and gentle catalyst that speeds up the healing process and minimises scarring.

I do have a few caveats, however. Firstly, the popular belief that honey is more natural and therefore healthier than table sugar, sucrose or glucose isn't entirely true. Like all foods, honey can be healthy when eaten in moderation, but may also have some downsides. Dieters should know that honey contains the same number of calories as other types of sugar, which means that biscuits and other foods made with honey can cause weight gain. Because honey can cause blood-sugar levels to rise quickly, diabetics should regard honey as cautiously as any other natural sweetener, while many of the children I treat for energy-level disturbances can become just as irritable after eating a honey sandwich as a bar of chocolate. Eating too much honey on an empty stomach tends to aggravate the systems of sugar-sensitive individuals, so it's best to cushion your stomach with some fibre first, perhaps by following a main meal consisting of vegetables, wholegrains or fresh fruit with a dessert that incorporates honey. Finally, honey can erode tooth enamel. The practice of dipping a dummy in honey to keep a baby sweet is a real no-no: not only can it encourage babies to develop an overly sweet tooth and rot their teeth before they appear, the bacterial content of honey is far too challenging for a baby's immune system, if they're under one year old.

On the plus side, honey's concentrated sugar content makes it a very useful food for people who are trying to gain weight, perhaps while recuperating from a major illness. Whether added to a milky drink, dribbled over rice pudding or spread on hot toast, honey can provide a much-needed calorie boost, along with mouthwatering sweetness. Use honey carefully - with medical guidance if necessary - either to help to relieve indigestion or simply as an indulgent treat. But watch this space: there's a great deal more that bees can offer us than their stings.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: Tortured PoWs win millions
fields.standfirst: Britain set to pay victims of Japan's camps
fields.trailText: Britain is set to agree a multi-million pound compensation package for thousands of ex-servicemen who faced years of torture and barbaric treatment as Japanese prisoners of war.
fields.body:
Britain is set to agree a multi-million pound compensation package for thousands of ex-servicemen who faced years of torture and barbaric treatment as Japanese prisoners of war.

Campaigners for the 7,000 PoWs were jubilant last night after being informed that the Prime Minister and Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon are 'very sympathetic' to their claims, which could cost the Government £70 million.

Senior Downing Street sources last night admitted it it would be 'political suicide' to turn down the veterans' demands. Many of them live in poor conditions and feel that their suffering has never been recognised.

In the 1950s, the PoWs were paid £76 compensation even as part of the Second World War peace treaties. Prisoners from other countries were paid up to £2,000.

The Government's hand has been forced by a series of agreements around the world. Canada and the Isle of Man both recently agreed to payouts of £10,000 to PoWs.

British veterans are making a similar claim for £10,000 each. There are also connected claims from about 1,000 servicemen's widows.

'It is not a question of hatred or revenge, it is a question of justice,' said Arthur Titherington, aged 79, who served more than three years as a prisoner in the notorious Kinkasaki copper mine, in what is now Taiwan.

'This has been a battle spanning more than 50 years. We were the forgotten victims and it is about time that was recognised,' he said.

Civil servants at the Ministry of Defence are now poring over details of the claim and an announcement is expected in the next few weeks. Sources stressed that although a final decision has not been taken, the Prime Minister has made it clear that he wants to see something done.

The action follows repeated refusals by the Japanese to compensate PoWs. Recent attempts to press the issue through the courts have failed. British PoWs have now appealed, although they admit that a successful outcome is unlikely.

Officials at the MoD are now trying to define exactly who should get the money. They are worried that if they agree to too broad a definition it will open the floodgates to claims from people who suffered in other conflicts. They have also pointed out that unless they get more funds from the Treasury it will be difficult to find the money from overstretched budgets.

The Royal British Legion, which is helping the PoWs' campaign, has now made a significant concession which it is said has made the Government's next move easier.

Jeremy Lillies, the legion's head of communications, said it would not support claims from other PoWs who feel they have been badly treated by Germany or have suffered in other conflicts such as Korea or the Gulf war.

The MoD is now liaising with the Departments of Social Security and Health to ensure that servicemen who receive the pay-out will not lose out on other benefits.

David Winnick, the Labour MP for Walsall North, who is leading the parliamentary campaign for the PoWs, said that he hoped the agreement would not be scuppered by intransigent Ministers at the MoD. 'That would be a sorry state of affairs,' he said.

The settlement will bring to a close one of the most brutal chapters in British military history. When Japan successfully invaded Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore in 1942, thousands of British servicemen were captured and sent to PoW camps.

Many of them worked on the Burma-Siam railway, an experience described by veterans as close to a living hell and immortalised by the film The Bridge On the River Kwai.

Many veterans believe that the few hundred prisoners who were sent to the Kinkasaki mine faced greater hardship. They were hit with hammers, served three small bowls of rice a day and expected to work for 15 hours in temperatures topping 40C.

Titherington said that when the war was over he weighed 5 stone, down from 11st when he was first sent there. Many of his friends and colleagues died.

fields.headline: Walter Matthau dies at 79
fields.standfirst:
Philip French pays tribute to Hollywood's greatest grump
Walter Matthau in his own words
fields.trailText: Walter Matthau, arguably the funniest man in the world and both Grand Duke and jester at the court of film acting, died in a California hospital yesterday.
fields.body:
Walter Matthau, arguably the funniest man in the world and both Grand Duke and jester at the court of film acting, died in a California hospital yesterday.

Matthau, the wise grump both in life and on screen who rose from poverty as a son of Russian immigrants to stardom, was 79 and died of a heart attack at St John's hospital in Santa Monica.

Matthau made more than 45 films, most famously The Odd Couple , in which he played a loutish sports writer. Matthau told Time magazine in 1971: ' The Odd Couple was the plutonium I needed. It all started happening after that.'

He is also best remembered for the movie more revered by journalists than any other: the side-splitting The Front Page. In both, he played opposite the actor from whom Matthau's memory is inseparable, Jack Lemmon. But Matthau's Oscar was for neither of these; he won the Academy Award for best supporting actor for Billy Wilder's 1966 comedy The Fortune Cookie .

Matthau had been battling heart difficulties for decades, having had his first cardiac arrest in 1966. Ten years later, he had heart bypass surgery and on another occasion was hospitalised for double pneumonia.

But Matthau's attitude towards his health problems was that of both a grumpy old man and a stoic with that irresistible, slow smile. He blamed his successive ordeals on his eating habits: 'If you eat only celery and lettuce,' he grunted, 'you won't get sick. I like celery and lettuce, but I like it with pickles, relish, corned beef, potatoes, peas. And I like Eskimo Pies, vanilla ice cream with chocolate covering.'

webTitle: Interest rates set to stand still as inflation eases

fields.headline: Interest rates set to stand still as inflation eases
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) is set to leave interest rates unchanged again at its monthly meeting this week.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) is set to leave interest rates unchanged again at its monthly meeting this week.

New statistics have shown an easing of inflationary pressures since the MPC voted 6-3 in favour of leaving rates at 6 per cent last month. Last week the US Federal Reserve also held its rate at 6.5 per cent, which is still its highest level for nine years.

While Bank Governor Eddie George has made no secret of the fact that rates may have to rise if the pound falls sharply, sterling has stabilised in recent weeks after dropping from the heights reached in May. Meanwhile the domestic inflation figure that most concerns the MPC, the index for average earnings, has slowed. This confirms the MPC view that earlier alarmist figures were inflated by one-off wage bonuses.

Stephen Lewis, analyst at Monument Derivatives, said: 'Unfortunately for the hawks, economic data released since the June MPC meeting has militated against their case for tightening credit. Average earnings are running so far below the path that seems to have been assumed in the Bank's May Inflation Report as to call for major adjustments to the forecasts presented therein.'

Average earnings in April showed a drop in the headline rate from 5.7 to 5.1 per cent. Economists at Barclays Capital, David Hillier and Adam Law, say that the underlying growth in earnings, 4.4 per cent, is consistent with the inflation target for the first time in nine months.

Latest official estimates confirm earlier calculations that the economy's growth rate slowed in the first quarter.

fields.headline: Accentuating the positive
fields.standfirst: Employer pension funds will have to come clean on ethics, says  Simon Birch
fields.trailText: Occupational pension holders are to gain a real say in their pension funds' environmental and ethical policies as a result of new legislation that comes into force tomorrow.
fields.body:
Occupational pension holders are to gain a real say in their pension funds' environmental and ethical policies as a result of new legislation that comes into force tomorrow.

The regulation, an amendment to the 1995 Pensions Act, will for the first time force trustees of occupational pension funds to state the extent to which they have taken environmental and ethical considerations into account in fund managing.

With assets of over £800 billion, the British pension fund industry in effect owns a third of the UK's public companies and has great potential to influence boardroom policies on environmental and ethical issues. And while the new regulation will not mean that pension funds are obliged to operate an ethical investment policy, many fund managers are waking up to the fact good environmental management is in their own financial interests.

The Prudential is adopting an ethical policy for the management of its £71bn UK portfolio - not because of any moral crusade about the environment, says the company's Andrew Collis, 'but because we believe that... an appropriate environmental policy is a good indication of how well managed that company is'.

Already three of the biggest funds, BT, British Coal and the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS), have declared their intention to operate an ethical investment policy. With assets of nearly £20bn, the USS is the third biggest pension fund in the country and invests in more than 2,000 British companies, including controversial names such as BAe, Rio Tinto and British American Tobacco.

This has resulted in the USS being the subject of a campaign by some of the scheme's members, who have formed Ethics For USS to lobby the USS to adopt a more stringent ethical policy. Their campaigning paid off late last year when the USS announced that it was to adopt an ethical investment policy that was to be run by new staff.

However, six months on Jess Worth, from Ethics For USS, is disappointed at the lack of action from the fund: 'While we're really encouraged that the USS has decided to take its social and environmental responsibilities seriously, it seems to be making slow progress, and therefore we remain to be convinced that this new policy will have a major impact.'

In practice, the regulation will probably result in fund managers operating a policy of engagement with companies in their portfolios. This means that, as a major shareholder in a company, an institution will look to encourage it to act in a more ethically responsible way through active dialogue. This would involve a great many things, such as producing comprehensive social and environmental reports and the introduction of environmental management systems.

The policy of engagement is in direct contrast to the ethical investment policy of negative screening, which involves disinvesting from those companies that don't live up to certain ethical and environmental criteria. Negative screening, which characterised ethical investing in the 1980s - largely as a result of the anti-apartheid campaign - was the reason behind the pension fund industry's initial hostility to the Government's new regulation. Pension fund managers were opposed to the idea of having to disinvest from companies.

However, the Government has bent over backwards to reassure the industry that negative screening was Old Labour thinking, and that positive engagement is the order of the day.

Rob Harrison from Corporate Critic, the business ethics website, is sceptical, however, about the long-term impact that an engagement-only policy is likely to have. 'When the regulation was first being discussed with both a negative screening and engagement component, the pension industry was predicting, among other things, the collapse of both the arms and tobacco industries. Since negative screening was dropped, the industry now supports it, as clearly it no longer believes that engagement alone will change anything.'

Despite this, Harrison concedes that the fact that the Government is regulating the pension fund industry at all is a useful first step towards overhauling corporate ethical behaviour.

Apart from the fact that the regulation could lack any real teeth, the other fear is of a tidal wave of greenwash from the pension fund industry. 'It is going to be a bit of a mess to begin with,' accepts Peter Webster from Eiris, the ethical investment research group. 'There will be more words than action to begin with, but then the industry will begin to regulate itself by introducing proper standards to measure these words against actions.'

Jess Worth is in no doubt, though, about the campaigning opportunities that the regulation presents. 'Major institutional shareholders such as pension funds have a direct line of influence right into the boardrooms of huge corporations in a way that other types of campaigns don't, and it's an area where there's real potential.'

webTitle: Kick off the tired old team dream

fields.headline: Kick off the tired old team dream
fields.standfirst: We may score more goals by playing offside, suggests  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: We may score more goals by playing offside, suggests Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
In a fortnight during which England's football and cricket teams fared dismally against international competition while its rugby side triumphed over one of its toughest rivals, we don't need reminding of the importance of teamwork. Or do we?

Teams, says Dr David Butcher of Cranfield Management School, are 'overhyped, overrated - yet under-utilised'. The paradox derives from the very unassailability of teamwork: in many organisations it is so ingrained in management that it is impossible to criticise or even discuss rationally.

This has devastating consequences. Most fashionable management concepts follow a well-defined life cycle: they burst on the world, are enthusiastically embraced as a panacea, rejected in disillusion when they fail to live up to expectations and finally find their true place as small incremental additions to the sum of management knowledge as their advantages and limitations are charted.

The concept of teams, on the other hand, seems stuck in eternal infancy. Thinking on the subject has never matured. The best we get, says Butcher, is an ever-growing array of techniques for 'improving' teamwork. 'But they usually don't,' he says, 'especially if their starting point is bettering the quality of interpersonal relationships - that's to say bonding.'

According to Butcher, the research evidence is that where enhancing working relationships is the main focus of team development, there is no improvement in overall performance - in fact it sometimes suffers because people spend more time enjoying being together than they do working.

According to conventional argument, teams are the means of coordinating individual effort so that the result is more than the sum of the individual parts. In reality, research from Cranfield and other sources shows that far from being universally applicable, teams can only work in certain narrowly defined conditions - and even then, ideal teamwork is hard to achieve.

Witness the England football team. Football clearly needs teamwork: winning requires a (literally) goal-driven group of players to blend their organisational roles tightly and simultaneously. Performance depends on the co-operation of all the participants. Yet even though English commitment was never in doubt, the side lacked appropriate leadership on the pitch and the right balance between process and task. With two or three players who couldn't be relied to deliver their parts, hard work, as the manager conceded afterwards, was not enough.

So if teams don't always deliver, even when such a lot hangs on it, how much less likely is it to happen in less favourable conditions - such as at the top of companies?

Top managers, almost by definition, are fierce supporters of the team ethos, yet they have usually reached the top by playing extremely well to the completely different rules of individual accountability in the snakes-and-ladders game of formal hierarchies and structures. Typically, top managers are far too busy, far too independent and have too many different interests, views and goals for 'team' and 'teamwork' to be useful descriptions of what they are and do.

'They are supposed to represent the highest-level integration and coordination in the company, but everyone knows they don't,' says Butcher. 'And the tragedy is that the force of the inappropriate team metaphor makes the possibility of developing simpler, more productive ways of getting things done impossible to discuss.

Boards and senior teams are often paralysed by this contradiction. 'Too many managements spend far too much of their time sorting out car park spaces rather than key business problems,' notes Butcher. 'There's much more improvement to be gained from simple things like focusing on terms of reference - what are we here for, what are we trying to achieve - than rowing across Lake Windermere on a team-constructed raft to improve personal relationships.'

There's another paradox here: where real teams come into their own as 'pockets of good practice', in the Cranfield terminology, they are often not deliberately constructed but self-generating, as groups of self-selecting, motivated people coalesce around an energising idea. Often these are unofficial and unsanctioned, even illegal in management terms - a good example is the breakaway grouplets by which advertising agencies propagate.

Dotcoms are classic team 'pockets', sustaining themselves on adrenalin and an Alamo-like siege mentality. Yet in time the very success of the group often destroys it by dilution, expansion and the growth of vested interests - a process which is harder to resist because no one is allowed to question it.

The substantial challenge for top management is how to systematise such an elusive concept. A first step is to be more discriminating about what teams can and can't be used for. Frustratingly, teamwork can't be imposed on a whole company by diktat; instead, pockets can only be given a framework in which to emerge, as in Disney's 'internal market for new ideas' or 3M's ring-fencing of time for individuals to build their pet projects.

This often requires a wrenching change in management attitudes, abandoning implicit reliance on hierarchy and status and admitting the reality of informal, 'political' structures.

This goes for existing teams, too. Take the fortunes of the fractious Dutch team at Euro 2000 - living proof that teamwork is not about being best mates off the pitch, but about bending the collective intelligence towards getting the ball between the opposing posts.

The Dutch, until they were knocked out, were improving. But you still have to be able to convert penalties. At the end of the day, reader, scoring goals is what teams are all about.

scaulkin@easynet.co.uk

fields.headline: Content to quit the Continent?
fields.standfirst: Dome boss Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is one of a happy band of economic migrants in Britain, says Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Dome boss Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is one of a happy band of economic migrants in Britain, says Jim Pollard
fields.body:
You can say what you like about economic migrants - and Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe have said a lot recently - but at least they will do the jobs no Briton is prepared to do.

Take Pierre-Yves Gerbeau. Chalices do not come much more poisoned than the Millennium Dome but the French former vice-president of EuroDisney seized the post of chief executive with relish.

Another is Belgian Luc Vandevelde. He left the largest supermarket group in Europe, the French chain Promodes, to give succour to the UK's wounded giant, Marks & Spencer. Perhaps British business management is going the way of British football management in its zeal for foreign bosses, preferably with a bit of Gallic flair. But why do they come? It can't be the food or the quality of the football. It does not appear to be primarily the money.

With a salary of £100,000 (and little prospect of a bonus), Gerbeau says the Dome job was by far the poorest paid of seven he considered after finishing his MBA. It has a lot to do with our attitudes to work.

'Throughout Europe the UK has the image of being conservative and conventional but in business it's not true,' says Gerbeau.

'None of my job options were with French companies because although I had the profile, CV and experience, I was only 34. You need a little more grey hair to be a chief executive at home. Here age was never mentioned.'

Gerbeau was impressed by how the Dome's 5,000 staff responded to him. 'I've never felt so supported,' he says.

'There's a different attitude. Staff here would die to make a success of this business. I have an open, informal, upfront management style which wouldn't have been so well received in more hierarchical working cultures. It works here. I enjoy the sense of humour, the company of people who take the work seriously but not themselves.'

Gerbeau's honesty extends to calling the Dome's original business plan (estimating 12 million visitors) 'completely wrong' and the original management style 'arrogant'. 'You can only be arro gant after you succeed,' he says. 'I learnt that at EuroDisney when we were very arrogant when we opened. It was like, "We Americans are going to teach you Europeans how to do business." It took three years to turn it round.'

He understands the media's interest in the Dome but has been surprised by its intensity. 'The French media criticised EuroDisney over our business decisions but they weren't interested in my love life.' he says. Within days of moving here, he was 'calling my mum to check that I hadn't robbed a boulangerie when I was seven because I knew the press would find out about it if I had.'

Despite Gerbeau's high profile, he is still a rarity. Foreign workers make up only 3 per cent of the UK workforce. More than half are from other European Union countries, mainly the Irish Republic (around 220,000) and France, Germany and Italy (around 40,000 each).

'Mobility is actually less than you think,' says Professor Kevin Doogan, who researches European labour market policy at Bristol University's School for Policy Studies. 'There's a strong attraction to one's own country. Migrants tend to be of particular types - young executives without families - or in particular industries like construction.'

Peter de Oude, an employment consultant from the Netherlands, was attracted to this country for a different reason: he has a disability. 'The social benefits for disabled people are better in Holland,' he says, 'but attitudes to work are different.

'There's still a fear of employing people with disabilities at home. Here employers are more aware. Just look in the newspaper and you see the two-ticks symbol, indicating equal opportunities for disabled people, and there's the Disability Discrimination Act too.'

Gerbeau says that turning the Dome into the UK's most popular tourist attraction (which it now is, despite its problems) involves him working 20-hour days. But the UK's long-hours culture is less attractive to other Europeans. Isabelle Martin, a catering company administrator who is also French, says: 'The assumption is that you'll be more productive if you work longer hours but I doubt that.

'People in France put work in a different place in their lives. It's important, but not central. We take our lunch breaks, for example, and even at a business lunch nobody talks business. You talk about the food because food is also an important part of life.'

De Oude says: 'Work is a bit more relaxed in Holland. I needed to buy a couple of suits when I moved here. But I enjoy working hard and as I come from a small town I love the feeling of making it in a big city like London where it's so competitive.'

More than half of the UK's workers from abroad are based in London and most of the remainder are elsewhere in south-east England. Sally Marullo, who edits Employment Europe , which monitors the labour market, questions the assumption that these numbers will increase. 'The internet will cut both ways,' she says. 'The traditional idea of upping sticks and moving for work will go. There will be easier ways to achieve the same result.' Gerbeau says the UK's employment laws helped him take prompt action to lessen the Dome's losses, but Marullo believes the attraction of low regulation can be overestimated.

'I'm sure it's a factor for some types of business. It's cheaper and easier to set up business here than in most other parts of Europe. But equally, once you're used to work ing in a more regulated environment you just get on with it. France is currently the most popular country for inward investment, particularly from Japan.'

Gerbeau is proud to be French - he represented his country as a professional ice hockey player - but he is glad that globalisation is blurring the line between nations over business. 'The idea of a 100 per cent French company will go,' he says. 'France Telecom, a very French company, has just taken over Orange, and this sort of thing is going to change French corporate culture for the better.'

Isabelle Martin, at the catering company, is less sure. 'I don't feel labour is valued in UK,' she says. 'Clients often complain about our four-hour minimum charge for waiters; but would they give up their weekends to travel miles and work into the small hours for just £30, let alone less?' Probably not, and not one of the firm's waiters is British.

webTitle: Tesco to bring its banking services to the checkouts

fields.headline: Tesco to bring its banking services to the checkouts
fields.trailText: Customers of Tesco's bank will soon be able to pay money and cheques into their accounts at the supermarket checkout while doing the weekly shop.
fields.body:
Customers of Tesco's bank will soon be able to pay money and cheques into their accounts at the supermarket checkout while doing the weekly shop.

Tomorrow, Britain's biggest supermarket group will finally unveil its expected move to take personal finance transactions at the till.

The measure will be seen as an important weapon to counter the growing number of high street bank branch closures. It also comes as the Government plans to allow the Post Office to operate a banking service for the financially excluded.

Tesco will be the first supermarket to offer a 'banking' checkout service. This will be seen as a huge boost to its savings business. It is thought that Individual Savings Account revenues in particular will benefit.

But hard on the heels of Tesco's new checkout plan will come speculation that it will shortly offer customers a current account.

Tesco Financial Services, a joint venture between the supermarket and Royal Bank of Scotland, currently offers loans, mortgages, Isas and various insurance products.

Tesco sees personal finance as a huge growth area. It has more than 1.5 million personal finance customers and aims to double that in the next few years. Its personal finance division has moved into month-by-month profit.

In March it became the first supermarket chain to sell motor insurance at all its 633 shops and 326 petrol stations nationwide. Last February, Tesco launched an online service for its instant access savings customers.

Sainsbury's said it has no plans at present to offer a similar scheme.

Tesco sees personal finance as a huge growth area. It has more than 1.5 million personal finance customers and aims to double that in the next few years. Its personal finance division has moved into month-by-month profit. In March it became the first supermarket chain to sell motor insurance at all its 633 shops and 326 petrol stations nationwide. Last February, Tesco launched an online service for its instant access savings customers. Sainsbury's said it has no plans at present to offer a similar scheme.

webTitle: How to save an arm and a leg

fields.headline: How to save an arm and a leg
fields.standfirst: The right insurance cover can help to ease the pain of buying private medical care, says  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: The right insurance cover can help to ease the pain of buying private medical care, says Helen Pridham
fields.body:
Rather than join one of the National Health Service's waiting lists, many people are paying for private medical treatment out of their own pocket. Last year 160,000 people took this option, and more are likely to do so in the future.

Private hospitals such as those run by Nuffield or Bupa report a growing number of patients opting to pay privately for operations such as cataract removal and hip replacements. But if you have a more serious illness, such as cancer, the cost of paying for your own treatment can be prohibitive.

Although the insurance industry offers a variety of policies to cover the cost of private medical care, no two policies are the same and it is important to be aware of pitfalls. This type of protection does not come cheap, so it's worth doing your homework.

The obvious attraction of private medical insurance is that you don't have to wait more than a few days for many types of treatment. Other advantages are convenience - you can choose when to go into hospital - and better accommodation. But don't expect the insurance company to foot the bill for every type of treatment. This type of insurance is designed to cover only acute or curable conditions. Treatment of chronic conditions, such as asthma or diabetes, will not be paid for.

When choosing a policy, cost is a key factor for may people. This will depend on factors such as your age and whether cover is required for provincial or London hospitals. More than 20 companies currently offer medical insurance, ranging from Bupa to smaller companies such as CS Healthcare and Secure Health.

There are three main options: standard policies, which provide comprehensive cover for outpatient and inpatient treatment; budget plans, which pay for inpatient treatment but give limited outpatient cover; and deluxe plans, which pay for extras such as dental and optical treatment, and all in- and outpatient treatment.

If you are thinking of opting for a budget plan to keep costs down, you will need to weigh up the cost of outpatient treatment against the savings in premiums. Fees for consultations and tests can run into hundreds of pounds and will normally be refunded only if they are linked to inpatient treatment. A budget plan may also be more restrictive than a standard policy in cover for, say, psychiatric conditions.

An alternative way to keep costs down is to accept an excess on your policy. In return for agreeing to pay up to £500 a person a year towards the cost of any claims, you will receive a discount. But the practicality of large discounts will depend on your age and how many people are insured under your policy. If you have a family policy or are over retirement age, the likelihood that you will make a claim increases. If you have to pay the excess too often, you can end up paying more than if you had paid the full premium all along.

Other considerations include the age and number of your children. Some companies charge for the first two children only - subsequent siblings go free; others charge for each child. The maximum age also varies - some insurers will cover children until they are 17 or 18; others include them until they are 21, or older if they remain in education.

When comparing premiums, note how much a pol icy might cost you in future. Premiums often increase as you get older, as well as being driven up by inflation in the cost of medical procedures. The increases can get particularly steep as you reach retirement age. Two insurers that do not put up their premiums with age are OHRA and Exeter Friendly Society. The premiums they set when you take out a policy increase with inflation only.

Another option is a fixed-premium policy from Bupa. Premiums are guaranteed for either five or 10 years and can be paid monthly or by lump sum. The only disadvantage here is the potential jump in cost at the end of the fixed-premium period.

Private medical insurance will not normally cover existing health problems, although there are moratorium policies that may cover them if they don't recur within a certain period of a policy being taken out.

Many insurance advisers argue, though, that it is better to have a policy that takes your health into account. If you have health problems, it is a good idea to ask a specialist health insurance adviser to help you find the right insurer.

webTitle: Cracking up is hard to do

fields.headline: Cracking up is hard to do
fields.standfirst: News of subsidence brings images of doom, but  Jacqui MacDermott survived
fields.trailText: News of subsidence brings images of doom, but Jacqui MacDermott survived
fields.body:
'Don't worry,' I told my partner. 'I read somewhere it has to be big enough to stick a pencil into.' Moments later I was sitting dejected on the carpet holding a yellow HB2, which had just fitted comfortably into a crack in our living room wall. Damn. We had subsidence.

The very mention of the word has a similar effect on homeowners as 'taxman', or even 'alimony'. It certainly scared the hell out of us. But almost three years after finding the dreaded evidence, I can claim to be a survivor. And the good news is that if you stay calm and informed, it needn't be as traumatic as you might think. Golden rule one is don't panic.

Golden rule two is know your enemy. Basically, subsidence is damage to a property's foundations caused by ground movement as a result of a change in soil moisture levels. It is most likely to happen in areas with clay soil, and it is most likely to strike in London and the South East. According to insurer Direct Line, one in 50 houses in these areas has suffered in the 25 years since insurance companies began keeping records, and 75 per cent of claims are for properties built on clay.

We live on the ground floor of a Victorian house with mature gardens in north London, on a great big hill of clay. Perfect.

So how do you tell the difference between the real monster and a bit of natural movement soon remedied with a tube of Polyfilla and a lick of paint? Well, there's the pencil trick, but there are other clues. Cracks may be:

 Small, diagonal and numerous - we had five in the first set;

 In weak points such as around doors and windows - ours were in the bay;

 Wider at the top than the bottom - ours were.

The first thing to do was to ring the buildings insurer, Commercial Union, with our grim suspicions. It wasted little time in arranging for a loss adjuster to visit. We expected a rough ride - loss adjusters coming just behind traffic wardens in the unpopular professions top 10 - but were pleasantly surprised.

He was courteous, sympathetic and informative and didn't quibble when we showed him the new cracks that had developed - in the hall, dining room and bedroom. It seemed our house was sliding down the hill so fast it would soon be propping up the local bar.

The following week a young chap stopped by and vigorously hammered monitoring studs on either side of every crack. He measured the width between them, rubbed his chin, and went away. He came again to measure them six weeks later - and every six weeks for almost 18 months. Golden rule three: develop the patience of a saint - you're going to need it.

Our situation was complicated by the fact that we, and the owners of the other two flats in the house, are leaseholders. This meant no decision, however minor, could be made without the freeholder being consulted. He was, he said, determined to 'protect his interests'. Our policy had a £1,000 excess, shared between the flats. So we each paid £330 in advance - to the freeholder - before anything could proceed.

He appointed a firm of consulting engineers and quantity surveyors who were to be the project managers. Investigations proper began slowly in autumn 1998.

Damaged drains can often be contributors to subsidence (Direct Line estimates that one in five claims are a result of leaks causing soil erosion). So exploratory bore holes were drilled to the front and back of our property. Yes, the drains were worn; yes, there was evidence of root invasion; no, our policy would not cover the cost because it came under that stalwart clause, 'wear and tear'. This would involve stumping up another £435 per flat. Golden rule four: Even if you are fully insured, accept it's going to cost you.

I began to fret about the garden, whether we would lose the ivy, the jasmine, and the virginia creeper on the back of the house that turns a spectacular scarlet in autumn.

And what about the remedial work? A woman from the quantity surveyor, who specialises in the repair of old houses, had talked worryingly at one stage of dismantling the bay, complete with sash windows and stained glass. It might have to be underpinned and rebuilt.

Luckily, these turned out to be worst-case scenarios. The understanding and treatment of subsidence have improved in leaps and bounds over the past few years, and underpinning, as well as destroying gardens, is now accepted as the absolute extreme - sometimes exacerbating the situation. Golden rule 5: don't despair until the final verdict is in.

An arboriculturalist was sent for. He identified the trouble-making shrubs and trees and, much to our relief, recommended pruning by between a third and a half, depending how close to the house they grew. Cutting more might cause heave - where moisture no longer needed by roots would swell the soil under the house, causing more problems.

After that it was simply a case of getting quotes and agreeing one. Our freeholder insisted on making the final decision and, irritatingly, picked one that was not the first choice of any of the occupants. The insurer will pick up a bill for more than £11,000.

Do we think it's all over? Now there's just the prospect of almost every room being torn apart for repair - and the crack-of-dawn arrival of cheery builders, gardeners and drain experts. Golden rule 6? Keep a stiff upper lip.

How a pruning in time can save your property
If you do buy a home in an at-risk area, there are some simple and sensible precautions you can take to reduce the risk of subsidence:

 Keep an eye on your drains. If you suspect they may be blocked or leaking, call a professional.

 Prune trees and shrubs regularly, especially those close to the house (roses are regarded as particularly aggressive). It's a good idea to call in an expert in the first instance to set you a guide, which you can then maintain. A list is available though the Arboricultural Society (01794 368717).

 Avoid planting thirsty varieties of tree, such as oak, elm, willow or poplar. Any new trees should be planted as far away from the house as their expected mature height.

 Never cut down a mature tree without professional advice.

 Check gutters and pipes for any sign of splitting.
