webTitle: Sacked without chance of a hearing

fields.headline: Sacked without chance of a hearing
fields.standfirst: I have just been fired from my job as a designer after 10 months service. The company told me that their major client was not happy with my performance. I was not given any warnings. A solicitor says I can do little to challenge the action because I have been there less than 12 months. Is this so?
fields.trailText: Agony aunt
fields.body:
The solicitor's advice is probably right. If, however, your notice period would take you beyond the 12-month threshhold, you could sue for breach of contract for your notice period and for being denied the opportunity to bring an unfair dismissal claim. This is a way of bringing an unfair dismissal claim - for which you need a year's service - by the back door. The maximum you could get in an employment tribunal for breach of contract is £25,000.

The other possibility would be to bring a claim on sex, race or disability grounds if one of those elements was involved in the complaint. Workers get immediate rights to claim unfair dismissal if they are are discriminated against, if they are whistleblowers, because of union membership or if a health and safety issue is involved.

So, in short, you are probably best off looking for another job and putting the issue behind you. Under the law, employers can fire you for totally unfair reasons during your first year.

 Legal advice from Lewis Silkin

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Standard 'needs to talk to its members'

fields.headline: Standard 'needs to talk to its members'
fields.trailText: A new Standard Life members' organisation linked to the life insurer itself is needed to keep it safe from carpetbaggers, according to the leader of the campaign that last week defeated a plan for a stock market flotation.
fields.body:
A new Standard Life members' organisation linked to the life insurer itself is needed to keep it safe from carpetbaggers, according to the leader of the campaign that last week defeated a plan for a stock market flotation.

Stewart Stevenson, who masterminded the Standard Life Independent Members' Organisation, said that the new body would improve the company's communications with its savers and borrowers, and promote the benefits of mutuality.

It could also channel the views of members to the board. 'Members may feel more confident if they knew they had others with like minds around them,' Stevenson said. He added that it could also help the directors to gauge members' opinions.

Stevenson is to meet senior Standard Life executives this week to discuss the views of the people who contacted him during the demutualisation campaign.

'A large number of people contacted me, and I think I have some useful suggestions to make on how they could improve communications,' he said. 'That is at the heart of building a bond of trust between members of the board.'

Standard Life has already accepted that it needs better channels of communication with members. It will spend the next few weeks working out how to respond to the issues raised by the campaign.

The insurer won the ballot, but 46 per cent of its members voted in favour of flotation. Standard Life was criticised for failing to make a convincing case for its mutual status.

But the insurer is not convinced that a members' organisation is the best way to improve communication. 'Ours is a complex business to get typical members involved in,' said spokesman Gordon Arthur. 'They may not understand the complexity. But if we handpick members, they could be accused on being stooges of the board.

'The simple things to do are sometimes the things which do not contribute a lot.'

Arthur added that the group was considering 'benchmarking' itself against other mutual organisations, in this country and abroad, which were good at communicating with their members. That could include building societies, such as Nationwide and Britannia, which had fought off challenges to their mutual status, as well as non-financial organisations such as the RAC in Australia which, Arthur said, could have interesting ideas.

Among the other issues the company will tackle are ways to attract more members to its annual meetings. More than 700 attended for last week's vote, but previous ones have been lucky to attract 10 people.

Fred Woollard, who led the campaign for demutualisation, has now stood down. There is no sign of anyone else to replace him, but that could alter if Standard Life does not make changes.

webTitle: How to make your entente extra cordiale

fields.headline: How to make your entente extra cordiale
fields.standfirst: Here  are five tips for cementing Anglo-European relations
fields.trailText: Here are five tips for cementing Anglo-European relations
fields.body:
Here are five tips for cementing Anglo-European relations

 Most Europeans are more direct than the British. Do not be offended if you get a blunt 'no' rather than an 'I hear what you say'. Likewise, be direct about what you want done and when. 'When you feel like it' may be taken literally.

 Do not mistake formality for coldness. Many European working cultures are more formal, with first names used far less. English does not distinguish between a formal and informal 'you', which can create misunderstandings.

 Don't misinterpret touching. Most Europeans do it more than we do. It doesn't mean he or she fancies you.

 Check that people understand how business is being done. What can be agreed by phone in the UK may require a formal letter in France.

 Use other Europeans' language skills. Their English grammar may be better than yours: asking their help could make you a friend for life.

webTitle: Cork sees England home in Lord's thriller

fields.headline: Cork sees England home in Lord's thriller
fields.standfirst: England have beaten West Indies by two wickets in a tense Test match at Lord's
fields.trailText: England may be eighth in the Wisden World Championship, but their Test matches are consistently top of the entertainment league. After three gripping days of cricket, England squeezed home by two wickets in fading light at Lord's to square the five-match series with three to play.
fields.body:
England may be eighth in the Wisden World Championship, but their Test matches are consistently top of the entertainment league. After three gripping days of cricket, England squeezed home by two wickets in fading light at Lord's to square the five-match series with three to play.

Dominic Cork, whose bowling shone on Thursday, was England's unlikely hero with an unbeaten 33 in a nerve-jangling finish. He came in at 140 for 6 after Walsh had taken two wickets in an over to send back Alec Stewart and Craig White. Cork struck four fours and one mighty six and, with able support from Andy Caddick (7) and Darren Gough (4*), saw England home to their target of 188.

In the end it was like a one-day match, but there was no artificial deadline to offer one side a get-out clause at the death.

Courtney Walsh, who took eight wickets in the First Test at Edgbaston, had struggled manfully to put West Indies into the driving seat after tea. They were for a while - he bagged the first six wickets of the innings on the way to match figures of 10-113 (his third ten-for in Tests) and his record wicket tally now stands at 467.

In the past England might have folded in the face of such bowling; today they almost did. But Dominic Cork - returning to the side from the wilderness - showed just the required mettle. What a way to celebrate the 100th Test at Lord's.

A full house at headquarters was racked with tension throughout. England had battled to 109 for 2 at tea, with Atherton making a solid 44, but things fell apart soon after as 119 for 2 became 120 for 4 in the 45th over. Graeme Hick made a now-typical cameo of 15 before he steered Walsh into Lara's hands at first slip. Later in the over Atherton was conquered - a quicker ball jagged back into his pads and umpire Venkataraghavan pointed him on his way. Hick had played positively enough, but when push came to shove he was found wanting.

Thus Nick Knight and Alec Stewart were thrown into the thick of it. Stewart had top-scored in the first innings and he came out in the same vein, belting Walsh for three through mid-wicket in his next over to set the tone.

Rose replaced the luckless Ambrose and again proved the weak link. Stewart's two fours - both clattered through the leg side - edged England closer, but Walsh's 19th over changed the complexion of the match yet again. He trapped Stewart plumb leg before to end a quick-fire 18 from 24 balls.

Next ball Walsh steamed in to White and immediately found an edge. Lara snaffled it and appealed for the catch without knowing if it was fair or not, but White survived the trial by television. Enter Dominic Cork. The hero of two days ago took two successive fours off Walsh's next over - one all-run - but then Knight edged a ball from Rose that went across him into the gloves of Jacobs. 149 for 7. It was redoubled for Caddick's exquisite cut through cover point for four. The pair took England within 28 before the return of Ambrose signalled Caddick's demise, leg before. Runs came chiefly on the leg side as the Roses partnership put on 92 for the second wicket - England's first fifty-partnership of the series.

After a morning session when runs were few and far between, the afternoon was positively bountiful. Walsh's first ball went for four leg-byes, then Atherton edged between slip and gully. Vaughan, still on 0, survived a big appeal for caught behind but John Hampshire wasn't convinced. It was a Snickometer job - and even then it was hard to say if the noise was ball on bat or bat on pad. Vaughan was fortunate to survive; it was that sort of day. The arrival of the support bowlers confidence started to ooze through the Michaels as they moved past 50 in the 22nd over. On 53 they registered England's first fifty-partnership of the series; on 55 they sailed smugly past West Indies' second-innings total.

King replaced Curtly and another battle was won, but even though the weather and the scoreboard were improving in tandem, there was still a sense that England might yet throw it away with the loss of a wicket or two. Walsh came back and with his third ball he duly found Vaughan's (41) outside edge to give Jacobs an easy catch. England were half way home at 95 for 2.

fields.standfirst: West Indies shot out for smallest test total against England :   6-1 :   6-2 :   10-3 :   24-4 :   24-5 :   39-6 :   39-7 :   39-8 :   41-9 :   54-10
fields.trailText: Andy Caddick stirred from his torpor, stretched and bowled his side back into the second test at a time when all but the most unhinged English optimist would have deemed the match beyond redemption.
fields.body:
Andy Caddick stirred from his torpor, stretched and bowled his side back into the second test at a time when all but the most unhinged English optimist would have deemed the match beyond redemption.

Thirteen overs on the reel, each and every one packed with snarling, animal aggression brought him five prime West Indian wickets for 16, all wickets coming for seven runs in a one ball fewer than 10 of the overs. What had he had for tea? Rocket fuel?

For someone who recently would not have felt inclined to say boo to Julian Clary for fear of a poke in the eye, the transformation from the insipid character of the first innings was startling.

Once he followed through down the pitch to stand eyeball to eyeball with the great Ambrose - one of the few able to do so without recourse to a step-ladder - and so far has lived to tell the tale although it would have been wise to get his affairs in order last night.

Caddick's marvellous effort and similar response from Darren Gough and Dominic Cork saw West Indies, in their second innings, humbled in a fraction over two hours and inside 27 overs for just 54, the lowest score they have ever made against England and only two more than their lowest ever in Tests, the 51 made against Glenn McGrath and Jason Gillespie in Port of Spain fifteen months ago.

Only Ridley Jacobs, with 12, reached double figures yesterday. It left England eight overs to negotiate in pursuit of 188 to complete what would be an astounding win, and Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash duly negotiated seven balls before the light closed in and a remarkable day that had seen 21 wickets fall came to a conclusion.

Today, then, is as big as it gets, with not just the match but the entire series hanging in the balance. For two decades and more it has been the absolute belief within the West Indies side that no matter how few runs their own batsmen score the bowlers can always dismiss the opposition for fewer.

But to pull this one round the Twin Tormentors, Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh together with the young pretenders Reon King and Franklyn Rose will need to pull out all the stops. Perhaps they will draw strength from other matches in Trinidad. Against Zimbabwe earlier in the year they successfully defended 99 in the final innings but more pertinently, when they sent England packing for 46 when Atherton's 1994 tourists required 193 to win.

The latter is too much etched on the England psyche and too close in context to this game for comfort and badly needs exorcising.

Against that, Alec Stewart would be missing a trick if he did not bring to his teams attention the West Indies travails in New Zealand last winter when in Hamilton, in the very first innings of the series, Sherwin Campbell and and Adrian Griffith added 276 for the first wicket only to see the Kiwis triumph by nine wickets.

For West Indies to lose here, from 161 for one, given that memory, could set them back to where they were, while England know that the chance is now there for someone to make their name.

The same number of wickets as fell yesterday did so in a days' play against New Zealand at Edgbaston last year, but that was a different pitch.

This sort of batting carnage is less readily explained although the Lord's groundsman Mick Hunt will have been biting his fingernails to the quick. He need not worry. The surface was as dry as it could be on the first day and the although it has quickened up noticeably, the bounce has re mained true and the lateral movement from the seam certainly not excessive.

A contributory factor has been the blanket of haze, which has lent encouragement to the swing bowlers and kept the pitch fresher than it might have been under sunlight. Techniques on both sides, against the ball moving even minimal amounts at pace have been exposed, however, and West Indies towards evening yesterday were unable to cope with Caddick's rib-tickling bounce.

Not for a long time has an England short leg become such a predatory fielder and today it will be the high bounce of Walsh and Ambrose that will test the resolve of the England batsmen. Already, Campbell's 82 and Wavell Hinds' 59 made before tea on the first day, may prove to be the decisive innings of the match with no one else since reaching 30. Indeed apart from Nick Knight, who made 34 in the second innings at Edgbaston, no England batsman has reached even that in three innings this series.

Knight, should he bat today, will do so encumbered by a right index finger damaged when attempting to catch a screamer of a catch at third slip off Gough. While the evening carnage was unfolding he was in the casualty unit having an Xray which revealed " no major fracture" whatever that means.

The West Indies bowlers may well have felt they had done enough with the ball to put the game beyond reach.

At the outset, Ambrose was irresistible, probing, giving nothing away, and making inroads as Ramprakash, Michael Vaughan and Graeme Hick were drawn into error, the latter bowled leaden footed after a calculated assault on Rose's opening over that brought him four boundaries at a time when runs were like gold dust.

Untypically too, Atherton was drawn into some inept bathanging at Walsh and was caught at the wicket. Hick's riposte and a later partnership of 35 between Stewart (28) and Craig White (25) provided the only respite from the torture.

Walsh and Ambrose finished with four wickets apiece and if Ambrose deserved more then his superb partner, conceded little until Gough, premeditating, swung him lustily over the square leg fence.

The last-wicket stand Gough shared with a remarkably composed and organised Matthew Hoggard was just sufficient in the circumstances to come into the irritating category.

fields.headline: Actor Walter Matthau dies at 79
fields.standfirst: Walter Matthau, the foghorn-voiced movie villain who became a master of crotchety comedy in The Odd Couple, has died of a heart attack at 79
fields.trailText: Walter Matthau, the foghorn-voiced movie villain who became a master of crotchety comedy in The Odd Couple, has died of a heart attack at 79
fields.body:
Walter Matthau, the foghorn-voiced movie villain who became a master of crotchety comedy with his Oscar-winning The Fortune Cookie and followed with The Odd Couple, Grumpy Old Men and many other hits, died Saturday morning of a heart attack. He was 79.

Matthau was pronounced dead at 1:42am, shortly after being brought into St. John's Health Center in Santa Monica, said hospital spokeswoman Lindi Funston.

Often cast as a would-be con man foiled by life's travails, Matthau bellowed complaints against his tormentors and moved his lean, 6-foot-3 frame in surprising ways.

Said his frequent costar, Jack Lemmon: "Walter walks like a child's windup toy."

Matthau's performance as the shyster brother-in-law of Lemmon in The Fortune Cookie won him the Academy Award as best supporting actor of 1966. He was twice nominated for best actor: as the cantankerous oldster in Kotch, 1971 (directed by Lemmon); and as the feuding vaudeville partner of George Burns in The Sunshine Boys, 1975.

The Odd Couple provided the role that established Matthau's stardom. In 1965 he appeared in New York as the slobby sportswriter Oscar Madison in Neil Simon's play. Art Carney was the fastidious photographer, Felix Unger, who shared an apartment with Madison after both had been divorced.

Matthau repeated the role in the 1968 film, with Lemmon as Felix. They reprised their roles 30 years later in the 1998 film Odd Couple II.

"Every actor looks all his life for a part that will combine his talents with his personality,'' Matthau told Time magazine in 1971. "The Odd Couple was mine. That was the plutonium I needed. It all started happening after that.''

The actor could be as whimsically eccentric in interviews as he was on the screen. Reporters had to exercise caution in separating fact from his flights of fancy.

In responding to a form for current biography, he reported that his father had been an Eastern Orthodox priest in czarist Russia who ran afoul with church authorities by preaching the infallibility of the pope. His father was actually a Kiev pedlar.

Matthau declared that he had married the former Carol Wellington-Smythe Marcus. His wife was really Carol Marcus, who had been twice married to playwright William Saroyan.

"That's my defense mechanism against pompous and ludicrous questions,'' Matthau explained. When he filled out his Social Security form in 1937, he listed his middle name as Foghorn. He never corrected it.

Some of the facts about the actor's early life seem accurate. He was born Walter Matuchanskayasky on October 1, 1920, in New York City to impoverished Russian-Jewish immigrants.

The father left home when Walter was three. Walter and his older brother, Henry, lived with their mother, a garment worker, in a series of cold-water flats on the lower East Side.

Young Walter showed a dramatic bent early, reading Shakespeare at 7 and reciting poems in school assemblies at 8. He was introduced to Yiddish plays at 11, when he sold soft drinks at 2nd Avenue theaters. He made occasional appearances onstage at 50 cents a performance.

He was already 6-feet tall at 10 and weighed 90 pounds. "When I drank cherry soda, I looked like a thermometer,'' he once cracked.

Graduating from Seward Park High School during the Depression, he took government jobs - as a forester in Montana, gym instructor for the WPA, boxing coach for policemen. In the second world war he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and served as radio cryptographer in a heavy bomber unit in Europe.

Matthau ended the war a sergeant with six battle stars and a fistful of money from poker winnings. Legends of his gambling followed him throughout his life. While making a TV series in Florida before his movie stardom, he lost $183,000 betting on spring-training baseball games.

The actor himself made no effort to quash the legends and even contributed to them. In middle age he estimated his lifetime gambling losses at $5m.

After release from the Air Corps in October 1945, Matthau enrolled in the dramatic workshop at New York's New School. Among his fellow students: Gene Saks, Rod Steiger, Harry Guardino, Tony Curtis. He stayed three years, living on the GI Bill and playing in regional stock during the summer.

Matthau's first Broadway role came at the age of 28 when he was hired as understudy for the role of an 83-year-old English bishop in Anne of the Thousand Days, starring Rex Harrison.

When the aged English actor playing the role became ill, Matthau went onstage without a rehearsal. He liked to tell the story of how the surprised Harrison looked at him and uttered an expletive. Matthau related: "People in the audience began muttering to each other: 'Did he say Oh, spit!?"'

A series of flop plays followed, then Matthau hit a lucky streak with Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?, Once More with Feeling and A Shot in the Dark. Hollywood took notice.

His first film, The Kentuckian starring and directed by Burt Lancaster in 1955, cast him as a villain, and more heavy roles followed. Among the early films: King Creole (Elvis Presley), A Face in the Crowd (Andy Griffith), Lonely Are the Brave (Kirk Douglas), Charade (Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn).

The Odd Couple and The Fortune Cookie elevated Matthau to stardom, and he enjoyed a wide variety of roles for more than 30 years. He appeared in action thrillers such as The Taking of Pelham One Two Three and The Laughing Policeman, and portrayed a US Supreme Court justice in First Monday in October. He even did a musical, Hello Dolly! costarring with Barbra Streisand, with whom he publicly feuded.

He was always identified with comedy, something that rankled him.

"When people come up to me and say, 'Aren't you that comedian who's in the movies?' I want to throw up,'' he once complained. "I throw up a lot.''

Matthau was often teamed with Lemmon, always as adversaries though they were best friends offscreen. Their films included: The Front Page, Buddy Buddy, Grumpier Old Men, Out to Sea.'

He was most recently on screen with Meg Ryan, Diane Keaton and Lisa Kudrow in Hanging Up, which was released in the UK in April.

Matthau was married to Grace Geraldine Johnson from 1948 until their divorce in 1958. They had two children, David and Jenny. He married Carol Marcus in 1959, and they had one son, Charles, who became a film-maker, and directed his father in The Grass Harp in 1996.

The actor survived several serious health setbacks during his career. While making The Fortune Cookie in 1966, he suffered a serious heart attack. His doctor attributed it to smoking three packs a day and constant worry about gambling, and told him to give up both. Matthau stopped smoking.

In 1976, he underwent heart bypass surgery. After working in freezing Minnesota weather for Grumpy Old Men in 1993, he was hospitalized for double pneumonia. In December 1995 he had a colon tumor removed; it tested benign.

He was also hospitalized in May 1999 for more than two months after another bout with pneumonia.

Matthau attributed his various illnesses to his eating habits: "If you eat only celery and lettuce, you won't get sick.... I like celery and lettuce, but I like it with pickles, relish, corned beef, potatoes, peas. And I like Eskimo Pies, vanilla ice cream with chocolate covering.''

Related articles

 Films of Walter Matthau
 The greatest grump Philip French pays tribute to Hollywood's ultimate nonconformist
 The mordant wit and melancholy wisdom of Walter Matthau

The Odd Couple and The Fortune Cookie elevated Matthau to stardom, and he enjoyed a wide variety of roles for more than 30 years. He appeared in action thrillers such as The Taking of Pelham One Two Three and The Laughing Policeman, and portrayed a US Supreme Court justice in First Monday in October. He even did a musical, Hello Dolly! costarring with Barbra Streisand, with whom he publicly feuded. He was always identified with comedy, something that rankled him. "When people come up to me and say, 'Aren't you that comedian who's in the movies?' I want to throw up,'' he once complained. "I throw up a lot.'' Matthau was often teamed with Lemmon, always as adversaries though they were best friends offscreen. Their films included: The Front Page, Buddy Buddy, Grumpier Old Men, Out to Sea.' He was most recently on screen with Meg Ryan, Diane Keaton and Lisa Kudrow in Hanging Up, which was released in the UK in April. Matthau was married to Grace Geraldine Johnson from 1948 until their divorce in 1958. They had two children, David and Jenny. He married Carol Marcus in 1959, and they had one son, Charles, who became a film-maker, and directed his father in The Grass Harp in 1996. The actor survived several serious health setbacks during his career. While making The Fortune Cookie in 1966, he suffered a serious heart attack. His doctor attributed it to smoking three packs a day and constant worry about gambling, and told him to give up both. Matthau stopped smoking. In 1976, he underwent heart bypass surgery. After working in freezing Minnesota weather for Grumpy Old Men in 1993, he was hospitalized for double pneumonia. In December 1995 he had a colon tumor removed; it tested benign. He was also hospitalized in May 1999 for more than two months after another bout with pneumonia. Matthau attributed his various illnesses to his eating habits: "If you eat only celery and lettuce, you won't get sick.... I like celery and lettuce, but I like it with pickles, relish, corned beef, potatoes, peas. And I like Eskimo Pies, vanilla ice cream with chocolate covering.'' fields.headline: Top rung/ Bottom rung
fields.standfirst: Miles Moorhouse and Dominic Bovington give their view from both ends of the motro marketing career ladder
fields.trailText: Miles Moorhouse and Dominic Bovington give their view from both ends of the motro marketing career ladder
fields.body:
Top rung

Miles Moorhouse Aged 30 Marketing & comms manager CarLand
Motor mad is something Miles Moorhouse happily admits to being. "I was always motor industry-orientated and have a huge enthusiasm for all things automotive. I now work with cars and race Caterham 7 sports cars as a hobby."

His first job was with an ad agency handling the Mazda MX5 account. He later worked with other agencies and in-house for an import firm.

Since taking up his present post, Miles has been actively re-branding the group which sells cars from nearly new to five-years old - mostly ex-lease and rentals - at "supermarket" sites around the country.

CarLand logbook: Originally the Concept group; employs 880 staff; 22,000 cars; £170m turnover; sites at Lakeside, Chertsey, Enfield, Cannock, Manchester and Glasgow with four more planned.

"It's very much a weekend business with most sales done on Saturdays and Sundays. We are a one-stop shop with finance and after-sales services and we adopt a 'drive away today' approach."

Must-have qualities: "CarLand as a company and the motor trade in general are fast-moving businesses which produce real pressure but offer the chance to progress quickly."

Bottom rung

Dominic Bovington Aged 27 Marketing executive CarLand

Bottom rung

A temp job with CarLand led to a staff post for former history and English student Dominic Bovington.

"When I left Exeter University I had no idea of what I wanted to do," he says. He thought about journalism but started work with a computer company - staying five years and becoming its transport co-ordinator.

"After that, I joined a recruitment agency but went temping again and found myself in CarLand's marketing section. This became permanent in May."

Current role: Dominic collects the stats which form a weekly report on the performance of CarLand's ad campaigns in the press, magazines, TV and direct marketing. He is also computerising the marketing section's operations.

Likes most? "You can have an idea one day and see it in action the next."

Dominic sees his next move in terms of consolidation. "I want to build on the enormous learning curve I'm on."

Tip for entrants: "Graduates lacking a focused plan, but interested in areas such as the law or accountancy, will find lots of business opportunities with companies like CarLand."

Useful links
www.carland.co.uk

fields.headline: Solving age-old problems
fields.standfirst: Mature graduates seeking grown-up bosses
fields.trailText: Mature graduates seeking grown-up bosses
fields.body:
Remember the mature students on your course? The bloke with the beard and thick jumpers who had a wife half his age? The woman who'd lived in Kenya and could speak Swahili? The twice-married bus driver who wrote poetry? They may not have been exactly like this but chances are, they were just as diverse.

But whatever their background and interests, mature students had one thing in common - they had done a bit more than just leaving school with a couple of A levels. They'd usually had jobs and sometimes they'd even got kids. As a result, they tended to be, well, more mature. What's more, while the other students were living it up on pints of wine in the college bar, older students were usually genuinely interested in getting an education.

It's precisely these 'university-of-life' credentials which make older graduates such an asset in the workplace says Carl Gilleard, chief executive with the Association of Graduate Recruiters. "Mature graduates will usually have more experience of life than graduates in their early 20s," he says. "This is a great benefit, especially in careers where you're dealing with different kinds of people.

"They may also have many years of work experience and as a result, more transferable skills," he continues. "Often, they've made enormous personal sacrifice in terms of partnerships or financial security to pursue their studies, which shows a great deal of commitment and self- motivation. We know this is something that employers look for."

However, employers are often wary of taking on older graduates, says Gilleard, which is surprising when you consider that more than a quarter of this year's graduates will be over the age of 25. The problem, he believes, is that older people in general are more difficult to pigeonhole. "A lot of companies haven't quite found a way of assessing mature candidates," he explains. "It's partly ageism. There are often misconceptions about older people fitting in and if the person is looking for a complete career change after their degree, employers can find it hard to believe that they're willing to start again from scratch."

Graduate recruitment schemes and even application forms, he points out, also tend to be designed with younger graduates in mind. "It's all very well asking someone in their 20s what they like to do in their spare time but if you ask a single mother of three who's just completed a degree part-time, she'll say, 'What spare time?' Some careers literature is also very obviously aimed at younger people," he adds. "They use words like 'dynamic' and 'energetic' which people associate with youth. It sends out messages to older graduates that they're not suitable."

Mike Atterbury is a training resources officer with a large telecommunications company where he has worked for more than 20 years. He began a part-time degree with the Open University in the early 90s and two years ago, in his mid-forties, graduated with a 2:1 in politics and social policy. He too, has found it difficult to fit in as a mature graduate.

"I'd always wanted to go to university, but my mum died when I was fifteen and I went straight out to work," he explains. "But in a way it's worked out for the best. I wouldn't have had the same discipline to study when I was younger and because I'm older, I've actually lived through some of the things we studied on the course. It's given me greater understanding."

Despite his qualification and length of service, Atterbury still hasn't been promoted to management level. "I'm disappointed," he says, "especially as the company sponsored my degree. I think ageism comes into it but to be honest, I think they just don't know what to do with a middle-aged graduate. I couldn't join their graduate recruitment programme because that would mean moving to a different part of the country. I'm settled here and I've got a mortgage. Also, I'm a lot older than most graduates and I wouldn't really fit in."

Many mature graduates find themselves similarly disillusioned when their new qualification fails to land them a dream job, says Gilleard. "Unfortunately having a degree isn't a guarantee of anything these days. A lot of large companies don't have a hierarchical structure any more, so there are fewer management positions available. And some companies have early retirement policies which get in the way of hiring older people.

"Things are changing but it's a slow process," he continues. "Employers are beginning to realise that we need a more tailored approach to accommodate more diverse applicants. But the most important thing is for people to take responsibility for their own career. There's nothing to be gained from bleating about your situation or you become a victim."

Mature graduates, he advises, need to be doubly pushy to overcome people's preconceptions. "You've got to market yourself properly. Identify what you've got to offer. Get out there and tell employers, 'Look! I've got a degree, and I've got all this experience. I've brought up children and I've worked for 20 years. You can't afford not to hire me!'"

Mike Atterbury is resigned to his situation but doesn't regret his studies. "It's been my main achievement and it's really enhanced my life," he says. "It's changed my way of looking at things. I'm a different person now. I would advise older graduates not to expect too much from their degree. If you look on it as a step forward in your career, you might be disappointed. You've got to do it for yourself."

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to adding a touch of originality to the office
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to adding a touch of originality to the office
fields.body:
A. Idea fatigue

When, for the ninth time in a week, you're asked to provide a vibrantly refreshing approach to yet another dull old problem, you could be forgiven for feeling all used up. But you may not be forgiven for proclaiming it.

In a knowledge-based economy, to be without ideas is to be without added-value. Whenever you feel originality deserting you, console yourself with the fact that completely new ideas are as rare as meaningful clichés and relieve the strain on your brain by harnessing the efforts of others.

B. Transplant technology

Develop the technique of dressing up old inspirations in new clothes. They don't even need to have been yours in the first place - the world is full of solutions waiting to be adapted to new situations. An idea only has value if it works. The advantage of transplanting rather than creating is you can see the concept in action first. The danger is it might not function as well when moved. Assess its match potential, then do the necessary preparation and alteration to make sure it looks fresh and fit for your purpose.

C. Fair shares

Find someone to talk to; ideas don't grow well in isolation. Seek out new people, new places and unexpected happenings in order to sharpen your

senses. This sort of change can be as good as a rest for curing idea fatigue. People only part with their best ideas if they can trust you to credit them due credit. To steal the inspirations of others is counter-productive. Do it once and you're on your own.

webTitle: How to... cope with information overload

fields.headline: How to... cope with information overload
fields.standfirst: Honing your data handling skills
fields.trailText: Honing your data handling skills
fields.body:
Oscar Wilde said of the late 19th century: "We live in an age that reads too much to be wise and thinks too much to be beautiful." At the start of the 21st century we are reading even more. As for thinking - well, opinion is divided. But the fact remains that we are exposed to more information than any other generation.

According to Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial

Society, this newspaper alone contains more data than the average 17th century person would have encountered during their entire lifetime.

And it doesn't stop there. We are constantly being bombarded (and bombarding others) with all manner of multimedia messages. There are voicemails, emails, pagers, faxes, and any number of phone calls received from any number of fixed-line, analogue, digital - and now the ubiquitous Wap phone.

There's internal post, external post, trade journals, specialist magazines and unlimited news services - available all day, every day if you are not into sleeping. Oh, and there's the internet as well.

Gallup and the Institute For The Future recently calculated the number of communications an average British worker receives in an ordinary week. It numbers well over a 1,000.

It is no wonder that in its annual Messaging Study, corporate mail specialists Pitney Bowes found that by the time some professions have responded to all of this information the best part of their day has already gone, with the "real work"being pushed into evenings and weekends.

Medical research suggests the impact of all this is unhealthy. Information fatigue syndrome, as it has been called, can affect us physically and emotionally. Occupational psychologist professor Cary Cooper says it can cause eye strain, increased stress and RSI and can bring about tensions in our home life and personal relationships.

According to David Lewis, author of Information Overload , the situation is not going to go away. So it is vital, he says, that we become better at managing it.

So where do you start? It sounds basic, but learn to identify what really is important. Some items will scream out their relevance. Others will mumble their irrelevance. But distinguishing the vital from the marginal is not always obvious or easy. "It helps, though, if you can be clear about the key responsibilities and objectives of your job", says John Caunt in his book 30 Minutes To Manage Information Overload . "Use them as a mental checklist against which you can match whatever information comes your way." You won't always make the right decision. But at least you'll be filtering out some of the "data smog", as David Shenk puts it in a book of the same name.

Once you do clear a path for yourself, you need to move swiftly through what is still in front of you. So, be ruthless and systematic with each piece of information that you have decided to keep. Assign one of these four actions to it:

1. Deal with immediately

2. Deal with on a designated date

3. Delegate to another person

4. Deposit into some sort of logical retrieval system.

To speed this process up further, look at developing improved information handling skills. These include scanning, speed reading, summarising, maximising your concentration span and expanding your memory capacity. The authors of Handling Information Overload In a Week point out that you should apply these skills to all sources of printed material - from company memos to annual reports to social emails.

However efficient you become at managing information overload, whether the stuff is tangible or not, it will never stop coming at you if you don't block off some of the sources. Remove your name from mailing lists that have not yielded anything worthwhile. Cancel subscriptions to periodicals that have not produced much value in the past six months.

Be discriminating with your details; don't just give them away to organisations or individuals who may just end up sending you junk. When sending emails, set an example as to how you'd like to be treated by 'cc-ing' only those people who actually need to be included. Also, if a reply is not required, indicate as much. This, says John Caunt, avoids the cycle of receiving unnecessary returns that you can then feel obliged to respond to, and on it goes.

But addressing all this only goes part way to solving the problem. To completely deal with your information overload, you have to master that most overloaded of all information sources: the internet. We're all guilty of surfing, getting distracted by intriguing links and curious search results. Half an hour later we've led ourselves to an interesting but rather irrelevant destination.

To get the most out of the web - at least when it comes to work related inquiries - you need to be focused and disciplined. It's boring, I know. But then so is working late because you didn't manage your time properly. It's best to keep your searches narrow and specific. It's best, too, to know when to stop looking. Remember the 80:20 rule where you get 80% of your results from 20% of your efforts.

Now, more than ever, we live in an information age. And Wilde would probably maintain that we have still not become any wiser for it. Perhaps the most we can do is become wise about how we manage it.

Still buried under a pile of email?

If you still find yourself deluged with information, it may be that you simply have far too much to do. If so, talk to your boss. To ensure the discussion goes well, author John Caunt suggests these dos and don'ts:

Do raise the issue at an appropriate time - that is, when you are not up against it

Do show that you understand your job's objectives

Do show that you have already tried to overcome the problem

Don't give the impression that you're just trying to get out of doing

something

Don't come across as either combative or apologetic

Don't be bullish; be ready to reach a compromise

webTitle: Help: I just want to doss around for a bit!

fields.headline: Help: I just want to doss around for a bit!
fields.standfirst: I'm just finishing my degree, am not fixed up with a job and feel like spending a year doing nothing. Will that damage my future career prospects?  DL, law student, Manchester
fields.trailText: Not if you phrase it correctly. Avoid saying your plans are "to do nothing". Present it instead as a period of reflection and discovery. In fact, if you approach it as that, you'll get much more from it than sitting around and letting the world pass you by.
fields.body:
Not if you phrase it correctly. Avoid saying your plans are "to do nothing". Present it instead as a period of reflection and discovery. In fact, if you approach it as that, you'll get much more from it than sitting around and letting the world pass you by.

Make use of the chance to think about what you want without the pressure of deadlines and exams. It should save you from hurtling into a mistake of a career.

In order to maintain employability you need to look at how you're going to sell your time-out to future employers. It's not difficult. Most see a gap between finishing education and starting work as a positive thing. They just want to be convinced you used it constructively. So for example, any travel you do shows what a good planner you are, how adaptable you can be and provides examples that highlight your resilience during difficult times.

The danger with intending to do nothing is that this is what will happen. A year of sitting around is not easy to portray as constructive, because it's not.

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 36 WGSN
fields.trailText: No 36 WGSN
fields.body:
Less than three years ago brothers Julian and Marc Worth were running Heatseal Textiles, a small niche business making badges and transfers for the fashion industry.

Since then, they have embraced the internet and turned their traditional business into Worth Global Style Network - WGSN.com - the world's first online news and information service for the fashion, style and interiors industries.

WGSN may not be a household name yet, but ask anyone in the rag trade whether they could manage without its service and it becomes clear that the brothers Worth have come up with a very valuable internet business.

The fashion industry is a glutton for up-to-the minute news and information on a variety of subjects. But how do you go about delivering this material to a worldwide and fragmented industry?

The Worth brothers started with a very simple premise in 1998. They sussed out that many of their potential clients were spending thousands of pounds travelling across the world every season, spotting new trends, taking photographs of shop windows. A website providing this kind of information, delivered directly to their desktops could save the industry a fortune - and provide a nice little earner for the brothers.

But unlike many other internet start-ups, they decided to invest a small sum of their own money in a test site to prove the concept before going all out to woo venture capitalists. The Worth Global Style Network Ltd prototype attracted interest from all corners of the industry not to mention a wealth of talent anxious to get involved in a project that combined fashion with the allure of the internet.

After a slow start, in internet terms, WGSN has built up its London-based team to around 150 staff. It has also opened offices in New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo, Melbourne, Madrid, Paris and Frankfurt.

Globally - if you add in all the freelances and stringers - it has a worldwide workforce of around 300 people. It's a headcount that would be the envy of most daily newspapers.

WGSN has some 1,200 subscribers around the world and its current client list, which includes major players such as Calvin Klein, Giorgio Armani, Donna Karan, Tommy Hilfiger and Hugo Boss, reads like a who's who of the fashion industry.

In the UK alone, WGSN gives more than 50,000 fashion and design students free access to www.wgsn-edu.com where they can browse around 300,000 pages of the same up-to-the-minute, industry-specific information used by designers and manufacturers.

 For details of current vacancies and application details, write to Collette Sinclair, WGSN, Winchester House, 259-269 Old Marylebone Road, London NW1.

fields.headline: Still buried under a pile of email?
fields.trailText: If you still find yourself deluged with information, it may be that you simply have far too much to do. If so, talk to your boss. To ensure the discussion goes well, author John Caunt suggests these dos and don'ts:
fields.body:
If you still find yourself deluged with information, it may be that you simply have far too much to do. If so, talk to your boss. To ensure the discussion goes well, author John Caunt suggests these dos and don'ts:

Do raise the issue at an appropriate time - that is, when you are not up against it

Do show that you understand your job's objectives

Do show that you have already tried to overcome the problem

Don't give the impression that you're just trying to get out of doing something

Don't come across as either combative or apologetic

Don't be bullish; be ready to reach a compromise

webTitle: The only way is up if you're at the bottom

fields.headline: The only way is up if you're at the bottom
fields.standfirst: Concluding part of our graduate starter guide
fields.trailText: Concluding part of our graduate starter guide
fields.body:
The carefree campus life is over. Twenty-somethings are entering the workforce with high hopes and dreams of six-figure salaries, big offices, and perks galore. And every year most, like the rookies before them, are disappointed to find themselves in low-level jobs that offer salaries little more than the minimum wage. And benefits? Do me a favour.

It's a rude welcome to the real world. Skipping the 9.15 is no longer an option and days filled with tedious tasks - sorting post, filing papers, answering phones, doing research for a boss who will get all the glory - are the norm.

But it can also be a great opportunity to learn the nuts and bolts of your chosen career, to hone your networking skills, and to prove that you are an ambitious, creative, and competent professional. No, really!

The first thing you'll need to develop - and particularly if you find yourself in a so-called 'McJob' - is a good attitude.

Most employers value high expectations in their employees, but few will appreciate or reward the "world-owes-me-a-job attitude".

You can learn much about workplace reality in the "I-need-some-money" jobs that you take before finding a plum spot in your chosen trade. Most entry-level jobs, and particularly reception and post-room positions, offer a unique opportunity to learn everything about a company and its people.

Make sure to leave your student union bar attitudes behind. You may have been able to survive university by deciding you only needed to pass certain classes, but that mindset could doom you to a longer stay at the bottom of the career ladder once you are in the workforce.

First jobs provide a chance to develop a personal skill set that will be valuable in pretty much any job and any career. You can learn, for example, how to use a PC and essential software like Microsoft Word and Excel, how to type faster, take shorthand, or sell a product. These are the skills that will make you marketable as an applicant.

But the advantages of doing your time in jobs that many people would consider menial go beyond the chance to develop concrete skills. It can also hone your softer skills, like the ability to communicate, to demonstrate initiative and self-discipline, and to work well with others.

One way to convince your superiors that you take your work at any level seriously is to commit time to your career outside working hours. Be willing to train after hours, take classes on the weekends, learn a second language and make yourself more marketable. And go home when the job is done, not at 5pm with work unfinished.

As far as networking goes, there is no better place to start than at the bottom. Forging alliances with established mentors may be the quickest way to advance your career. Try to meet as many people as you can. Go out for coffee with them, take lunch with them and get to know them outside work.

Above all else, remember that life at the bottom of the career ladder may not be glamorous, but neither is it necessarily a refuge for people in dead-end jobs.

From the bottom, the only way to move in your career is upward.

webTitle: Handing out honours as the graduate fair season ends

fields.headline: Handing out honours as the graduate fair season ends
fields.standfirst: No more window shopping - now it's time to get a job
fields.trailText: No more window shopping - now it's time to get a job
fields.body:
For some, at least, it is all over now, bar the signing on the dotted line and wondering if they have made the right career decision. But at least they've got themselves a job.

The graduate fair season is well underway, having started as far back as June 7 at Nottingham, and early reports suggest that for most graduates going to a fair has proved a successful move.

Manchester, which this year had the largest number of exhibitors of all the fairs, says its event was considered a great success. More than 160 companies went on the head hunt at the Armitage Centre and all of them had jobs on offer - in fact, it was one of the conditions of entry.

Graduates had even greater choice this year because the organisers arranged for different companies to set out their stalls on the two days. Manchester University Careers Service's Jan Hewitt says: "We were extremely pleased. We had lots of wonderful comments from the exhibitors about the quality of students who attended."

Organisers of graduate fairs are always concerned that the events will attract late-comers and no-hopers but with the change in the structure of the academic year, more of the 'high-flyers' are waiting until their second set of exams is over before they start on the serious business of finding a job.

With more than 6,000 students going through the doors on the two days, number crunching is still going on but Hewitt says the feeling from students who turned up was positive.

"They believed it was a very useful format for meeting companies face to face."

The average number of students that companies saw on the two days was 35 each and last week the first round of interviews for candidates was well under way.

Birmingham, which ran its fair on June 21 and 22 also reports good feedback with an estimated 8,000 students turning up to a show which boasted more than 100 exhibitors.

The fair is a joint enterprise between Birmingham and Aston universities and attracts specialist employers like pharmaceutical companies because of the range of courses studied in the city.

Organisers Venture Marketing's Donald Nell says: "There was a free coach service from around the country and at least 2,000 people made use of that this year."

Like other fairs, Birmingham is open to all graduates and Nell estimates that at least half of the hopefuls through the doors at the NEC were from universities outside the city.

As well as the exhibitors there were added-value attractions like the CV clinic which Birmingham University's careers service adviser Richard Maynard says was very popular. He sees graduate fairs as a chance for students who are uncertain about what career to pick to do some window shopping.

"People are using fairs for a variety of purposes and to test things out a bit," says Maynard. "They like the chance to have a discussion with someone on how to present themselves.

"Employers felt it was worthwhile. They saw a reasonable number of people of good quality."

Unusually, Birmingham is organised so that first interviews can take place on the spot.

This year the six interview rooms were fully booked by companies which found enough good prospects to carry on with the hiring process.

"Some of the second-round interviews were taking place last week." says Nell.

Julie Ingham, of the Career Services Unit, notes that graduate fairs are growing in popularity both with students and employers.

"Employers are more willing to take on students who have left and got work experience or taken a year out to travel," she says. "Whereas the milk round was more dominant there is a move towards less structured job hunting."

Carl Gilleard from the Association of Graduate Recruiters also sees change on the way.

"The most dynamic change in a very short period of time is that a lot of the process is being done online, but whether this will impact on graduate fairs remains to be seen. The jury's still out on virtual fairs and the vast majority of employers don't do the whole process online," he says.

"It's useful for students to make enquiries and gain an insight into the company and sometimes they deselect themselves.

"Fairs still play an important part. They are a superb opportunity to meet employers face to face and there can be upwards of 100 under one roof. There are many more graduates now and the competition for the best ones can be quite intense."

The graduate fair season continues until July 7 with the last one at Surrey University. If you missed out on the merry-go-round this time there are still lots of other avenues to explore.

For example, the CSU website, www.prospects.csu.ac.uk has a quick search facility for you to evaluate yourself for your career choice, or you can get copies of the unit's job listings in Prospects Today by calling 0161 277 5271.

A six-month subscription costs £9.99. The current issue has 72 pages packed with possibilities.

Julie Ingham reminds graduates that they can visit any university careers unit for advice, even if it's not their own.

Anne-Marie Martin, director of the University of London Careers Service says last Wednesday - the first day of its fair - saw something in the region of 8,000 students through the door at the Business Design Centre, Islington. She says this is on track to match last year's 14,000 attenders.

"The first day's numbers were significantly up on last year's and we didn't expect to be up," she adds.

The major change this year was a vastly increased interest in IT companies and dot.coms while the other companies to pprove popular were the big blue chips which had something different to offer. Among these were PricewaterhouseCoopers, Bloomberg and Glaxo Wellcome.

"Some of the employers were packed out," says Martin, "and everybody was busy. The seminars proved popular too."

Traditionally, only around 20% of graduates who attend the London Fair are graduates from London universities and this year that trend appears to have been repeated.

"It seems that this is a stopping off point for graduates on their way back to their homes in London and the south-east."

But this year also marked the return of Europeans with a group of students visiting from Paris, says Martin.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Wake up call | Keep your eyes open
fields.body:
Writer of the week: Our very own Adeline Iziren has picked up an award at the Industrial Society 'Oscars' for her work as a contributor to Rise. Adeline's work was considered to be so far ahead of the competition that the judges decided against awarding a commendation to any of the other nominees. Mmm... she'll be asking for a pay rise next.

Eyes wide shut: Coming to an office near you - the meditation room. As workplaces abandon private offices for more open, collegial environments, employees have noticed the lack of space for quiet and mediatation. In the US, the pendulum is swinging back to allow for break rooms with couches and lounge chairs, as well as screens for visual privacy.

Wake up call: But maybe power naps between meetings aren't such a good idea. A study of Costa Rican snoozers has found that a daily siesta increased their risk of heart attack by 50% compared with people who rarely or never dozed in the afternoon. However the researchers say regular siestas may simply indicate a lifestyle that is too sedentary.

Keep your eyes open: Signing up with a start-up needn't end in tears says author Daniel Rippy who quit a blue-chip job to join a dot.com in Seattle. Look for an assurance that you'll gain valuable experience, he tells Fast Company magazine. "Since many start-ups have fewer employees and less management hierarchy to claw through than more established companies, the chance to shoulder new tasks should be a given. But make sure you'll be gaining experience that will be useful in the future. Will you become an expert in ways that all companies, regardless of their particular market or focus, value? Will you be making decisions and striking deals that you weren't involved in at your previous job? It may look good on your business card, but there's no point in having a glamorous new title if you're doing the same work that you were doing at your last job."

webTitle: Get in line for online chances

fields.headline: Get in line for online chances
fields.standfirst: Eileen Sheridan meets the creative teams putting together pages on the internet
fields.trailText: Eileen Sheridan meets the creative teams putting together pages on the internet
fields.body:
There can't be many areas of employment left where you can get a job if you can do the job - no qualifications necessarily required. But website design is, for the moment, one of them.

That is not to say that most website designers are without qualifications. Far from it. The really good ones are trained up to the eyeballs and say they are still and always will be learning.

It just happens that many working website designers are self taught and their knowledge and skill is enough to get them employment. The internet is still the new frontier and therefore the province of anyone and everyone, amateurs, geeks and backwoodsmen.

The profession of website designer is still an entirely unregulated one and designers come into it by many different routes which can make it confusing for people who want to investigate a career in the business.

Everybody's heard of the talented self-taught HTML-ers who now pull down huge pay packages for their skills, or the whizzy kids who learned a bit of software and used it to launch a career, but they, like successful dotcoms are fewer on the ground than you might think.

Companies are looking for people who have been trained and can prove it - no contest. The real debate is over what sort of training to get. Do you need to be a total techie or is it enough to be a creative design type with a bit of software knowledge stashed away.

Rae Lonsdale, owner of Swindon-based Global Data, a company which produces websites for a series of business clients says she sees the profession as having two distinct areas, techies and designers.

"But lately people have skills in both areas because they are being taught them in colleges and designers have an appreciation of the back end," she says. "Anyway, the likelihood is that if you are design-orientated and fancy a career in website work, you will be an internet surfer already."

The main decision to make, says Lonsdale, is whether you want to be directly involved with the client, or quietly churning out websites or working in a big company on corporate id stuff.

"Have you got good interpersonal skills and do you want to use them," she says. "Can you handle the stress side of dealing with clients or do you want to be tucked away and let someone else do that?"

Her own company provides websites for small to medium sized businesses to run their administration and is part of designer Duncan Gilbert's (see below) role to deal with clients. Good people skills is an issue which website designers and managers all point to as necessary for the job. Websites are a team effort, especially as they grow more sophisticated.

Serious websites are produced with teams of techies and teams of designers with website developers or managers holding the ring. So as well as dealing with clients, designers need to be able to work in a team, often to short deadlines and under immense pressure.

And, as chief executive of Replicanation, Nigel Hunt, points out a website on the scale of his company's involves other providers. He is hiring in database people, Sequel Solutions as well as building his own team.

"It is not one company doing everything now. It's a collaborative effort," he explains.

And quality people are very much in demand. Hunt cites the former boo.com staff, 90 per cent of whom were offered jobs by other companies as they picked up their P45s and headed through the door.

John Higgins, director general of the Computing Services and Software Association with 700 IT companies in its membership agrees that there is a shortage of good people and therefore a huge demand.

Website designers need more than one set of skills, he advises. "It is an excellent career for people who have knowledge and interest in the application of technology to solve problems in business or any other field, who have graphic and designs skills and systems knowledge.

"There is a huge shortage of people with the depths of technical skills," says Higgins.

They are not, however, interested in graphic designers who have mugged up on one software package and want to wing it. But although website designers are in demand, the money is not spectacular. In the provinces companies pay young designers between £17,000 and £20,000.

A top-flight designer in London might get up to £40,000 but this is exceptional. The big bucks still go to the techies, with softwear developers averaging £30,000 and freelance web programmers charging £1,200 a day.
fields.bodyText: There can't be many areas of employment left where you can get a job if you can do the job - no qualifications necessarily required. But website design is, for the moment, one of them. That is not to say that most website designers are without qualifications. Far from it. The really good ones are trained up to the eyeballs and say they are still and always will be learning. It just happens that many working website designers are self taught and their knowledge and skill is enough to get them employment. The internet is still the new frontier and therefore the province of anyone and everyone, amateurs, geeks and backwoodsmen. The profession of website designer is still an entirely unregulated one and designers come into it by many different routes which can make it confusing for people who want to investigate a career in the business. Everybody's heard of the talented self-taught HTML-ers who now pull down huge pay packages for their skills, or the whizzy kids who learned a bit of software and used it to launch a career, but they, like successful dotcoms are fewer on the ground than you might think. Companies are looking for people who have been trained and can prove it - no contest. The real debate is over what sort of training to get. Do you need to be a total techie or is it enough to be a creative design type with a bit of software knowledge stashed away. Rae Lonsdale, owner of Swindon-based Global Data, a company which produces websites for a series of business clients says she sees the profession as having two distinct areas, techies and designers. "But lately people have skills in both areas because they are being taught them in colleges and designers have an appreciation of the back end," she says. "Anyway, the likelihood is that if you are design-orientated and fancy a career in website work, you will be an internet surfer already." The main decision to make, says Lonsdale, is whether you want to be directly involved with the client, or quietly churning out websites or working in a big company on corporate id stuff. "Have you got good interpersonal skills and do you want to use them," she says. "Can you handle the stress side of dealing with clients or do you want to be tucked away and let someone else do that?" Her own company provides websites for small to medium sized businesses to run their administration and is part of designer Duncan Gilbert's (see below) role to deal with clients. Good people skills is an issue which website designers and managers all point to as necessary for the job. Websites are a team effort, especially as they grow more sophisticated. Serious websites are produced with teams of techies and teams of designers with website developers or managers holding the ring. So as well as dealing with clients, designers need to be able to work in a team, often to short deadlines and under immense pressure. And, as chief executive of Replicanation, Nigel Hunt, points out a website on the scale of his company's involves other providers. He is hiring in database people, Sequel Solutions as well as building his own team. "It is not one company doing everything now. It's a collaborative effort," he explains. And quality people are very much in demand. Hunt cites the former boo.com staff, 90 per cent of whom were offered jobs by other companies as they picked up their P45s and headed through the door. fields.headline: Ebooker prize
fields.standfirst: www.ebookers.com
fields.trailText: www.ebookers.com
fields.body:
Another newcomer?
No - ebookers has been around for a long time; before a reincarnation in September last year, it was called flightbookers.com. It claims to have been the first ever interactive travel booking site when it originally launched in 1996. Until quite recently, though, it could be painfully slow.

No signs of ageing?
On the contrary, it's actually speeded up as it's got older. ebookers has some exciting little features that will intrigue fans of text messaging (SMS) on mobile phones. The Flight Watch service sends regular SMS messages updating you on the status of a particular flight. At the moment this service is only available on certain major airlines, but as a charter from Malaga is unlikely to be on time anyway this is not a major oversight.

I assume you can book flights, too?
The booking procedure is unusually intelligent. (Mysteriously, however, its own "negotiated" fares can be higher than the public fare.) Visitors will find a familiar flight search, but can also try an idea pioneered in the US a couple of years ago, but which has been slow to catch on here: a 24-hour Bid & Go service. This allows you to set your own maximum price for an international return flight and leave your credit card details with the site. ebookers then tries to find an airline that will accept it, and book immediately on your behalf. Unfortunately, the service only applies to adult fares.

What's missing?
ebookers needs a bigger selection of hotels, although those it does feature are of a high quality.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... The Wirral

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... The Wirral
fields.standfirst: Chris Boardman
fields.trailText: Chris Boardman
fields.body:
Why: I spend so much time away that I love being at home. I live a 500 metres from the beach on the end of the Wirral peninsular, near the mouth of the River Dee and a mile away from Hilbre island, which is linked to the mainland by a tidal causeway. I have wanted to take my kids there for ages, but I simply don't get the chance because in summer, when you should do that kind of thing, I'm away working. Although I have cycled around the Wirral ever since I was 13 and still train there, I never tire of it because it is a world away from my professional life. For me, a beach is somewhere where you can stretch the eye and, sadly, when I'm cycling, the main thing I see is Tarmac, hotels and the team vehicle.

What's the best thing: It's an overlooked part of the country between North Wales and the Lake District. When people think of the Wirral Peninsular, they imagine oil terminals, chemical plants and discarded industrial areas. But on one side of the peninsular is Liverpool, on the other is Chester - both of which are ancient ports, so there is a tremendous amount of history in the area as well as a wealth of natural beauty. The water is surprisingly clean: for example, a colony of seals live behind Hilbre island.

My advice: The Wirral peninsular is about contrast. Chester has Roman and medieval history, Liverpool its industrial areas as well as the restored docks area, and North Wales has its sheer beauty. You can go and get lost in the back streets of Chester, where there is so much to discover; or relax in the Cheshire or North Wales countryside.

How do I get there? Virgin Trains run daily services to both Liverpool and Chester; then take local train services to the Wirral. National rail enquiries: 0845 748 4950.

 The Complete Book of Cycling by Chris Boardman is published by Partridge at £17.99.

fields.trailText: Brain power | Busy, busy, busy... | Go green
fields.body:
Brain power
A retractable footbridge links visitors to The Big Idea, the world's first inventor centre, where such boffins as Fleming, Baird and McAdam are waiting.

 Open daily 10am-6pm. £7/£5, family £16/£20/£24. Irvine, nr Troon, Ayrshire (0870 840 4030).

Busy, busy, busy...
Costume-making, clay-sculpture, circus and theatre shows are all free to under-16s at Bolsover Castle Children's Festival.

 Sun, 11am-5pm; adults £4.50. Bolsover, nr Chesterfield, Derbyshire (01246 822844).

Go green
Hampton Court Palace Flower Show is the place to begin mentally re-designing your garden.

 July 6-9, 10am-7.30pm (Sun 5.30). £19 or £10 from 3pm. Children 5-15 £5, under 5s free. East Molesey, Surrey (0870 9063791).

Summer fests on
The Cookson Country Festival begins today with a street procession from South Shields town hall to the seafront summer fair. Tomorrow's Tribute Show in Bents Park features Oasisn't, The Vengi Boys and Spiceish Girls.

 Until Aug 6. Procession 1.30pm. Tribute Show 2pm-46.30pm. All free. 0191-424 7985.

Kitchen bygones
Food historian Ivan Day explains a Heath Robinson-ish array of ancient cooking apparatus in Kenwood House, north London.

 The Eat, Drink and Be Merry exhibition runs until September 24. Sunday, demonstrations 2pm and 4pm. Kenwood House, Hampstead, London NW3 (020-8348 1286).

Eat your heart out
The Food & Drink Fair at Wrest Park Gardens has demos, wine tastings and organic produce.

 Sat/Sun, 10am-5pm. £4/£2.50. Wrest Park Gardens, Silsoe, Bedfordshire (01525 860152).

Having a boule
Derek Fowlds and Miles Kington head the celebrity teams bowling and rolling against locals in the 10th Bath Boules tournament. French food and wine available.

 July 1 and 2, 10.30am-dusk both days. Free. Queen Square, Bath, Avon.

Hot air
Get a new perspective on Leeds Castle and the Kent countryside from the castle's own hot-air balloon, launched today.

 Weekend champagne flight £150pp, midweek £135 (Airborne Balloons 01732 462179). Leeds Castle, Maidstone, Kent (01622 765400).

Steam dreams
The Cathedrals Express, the first regular steam-hauled train from London for 33 years, is running to Canterbury and Salisbury every Wednesday until Sept 20.

 Return tickets: premier dining £129, 1st non-dining £90; standard return £39.50. Luxury picnic hampers £45 for two. Steam Dreams (01483 209888).
