fields.headline: Hugh Grant, Karen Kilimnik (1997)
fields.trailText: Portrait of the week No 12
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Karen Kilimnik, born 1955 in Philadelphia, a painter often called "gothic" in her choice of recherché subject matter: Russian ballet, living dolls, teen horror films and Hugh Grant.

Subject: The actor Hugh John Mungo Grant, born 1960, recently dumped boyfriend of Liz Hurley, star of Notting Hill, Four Weddings and A Funeral and the photographic archives of the Los Angeles Police Department.

Distinguishing features: You can see the strain in the smile and the wrinkles in this painting. Grant is not being celebrated so much as commiserated with. This is the Hugh Grant arrested on Hollywood Boulevard in 1995 and held up to public ridicule, his police mugshot flashed around the world, after he was caught in a car with Divine Brown - a Hugh Grant who looks disconcertingly older than in his films, and very tired. His air of hangdog Englishness is familiar, but here it makes him look not the resilient underdog of Notting Hill but a confused, post-colonial Englishman lost in America.

This is a nice example of a relatively new genre of painting, which we might call the iconic portrait, not commissioned by its sitter but based on photographs, magazine cuttings, film clips. The painter puts a famous face on canvas, translating the voyeuristic look we fix on celebrity into art. Its history can be tracked through the 19th and early 20th centuries in painters like Degas and Sickert, who painted royalty glimpsed in the street and copied their faces from photographs. Later in the 20th century royalty mutated into celebrity and the most famous exponent of the iconic portrait was Andy Warhol, who helped to shape fame as we know it.

Kilimnik has also painted Leonardo DiCaprio and Diana, always with the same yellow, even golden, light of fame. Yet she has more in common with Warhol than portraiture in which the subtle light of the studio is blasted away by the camera flash. Kilimnik and Warhol are both American artists with eastern European affinities: Warhol's parents were Belarussian and Kilimnik says that hers were Russian, although much of her background is unclear. For both, the idea of an icon has more than casual significance. Kilimnik's portraits, like Warhol's, look as if they belong in a private shrine. They capture the madness of fandom - the illusion that we know this person - by tapping into the devotional use of icons in orthodox Christianity.

This portrait is painted in what appears to be a naive, amateur style, as if Kilimnik were an untrained, obsessive fan of Grant. You could say this was too knowing: like a lot of contemporary painters, Kilimnik has been visibly influenced by the Los Angeles artist Jim Shaw's collection of Thrift Store Paintings, an archive of anonymous, insane-looking pictures found in charity shops.

But this painting doesn't seem glib or ironic. The down-at-heel aesthetic matches Kilimnik's reading of Grant as someone who, though wealthy outside, is massively overdrawn inside. Our perception of Grant - at least until the Grant-Hurley breakup, in which she gets her portrait with a big snake done by glamour photographer David LaChapelle while he gets this melancholy tribute - has long been at odds with his image in America, which is irrevocably, tragicomically, tied to his arrest on Hollywood Boulevard and subsequent chatshow apologies. Kilimnik's art is about cultural displacement, Russian memories in high school, Europe transplanted across the Atlantic, and she empathetically seems to recognise the same displacement in Hugh Grant. She has painted him as an Englishman too far from home.

Where is it? South London Gallery, 65 Peckham Road, London SE5 (020-7703 9799) till July 23.

fields.headline: Tories attack Labour's underspending
fields.standfirst:
Schools, roads and hospitals 'worse off than under Major'

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Opposition parties last night sought to exploit Labour's admission that spending on Britain's crumbling infrastructure is running at only half the level it was when John Major left office more than three years ago.
fields.body:
Opposition parties last night sought to exploit Labour's admission that spending on Britain's crumbling infrastructure is running at only half the level it was when John Major left office more than three years ago.

Conservatives and Liberal Democrats were quick to seize on evidence of the lack of spending on schools, hospitals, roads, railways and the Tube at a time when the Treasury's coffers are overflowing.

With the state of public services causing discontent among Labour voters and likely to be an issue at the forthcoming election, the Conservatives said the under-shoot in capital spending was "another classic example of Labour saying one thing, and doing another".

Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor, said: "After lecturing us all about the importance of public sector investment, we find that the amount of public investment has actually fallen in every year since Labour came to power.

"This government seems incapable of spending taxpayers' money well. With hospital waiting lists up, crime rising and roads in their worst state for over 25 years, public money is being wasted on welfare fraud, new bureaucracies and spin doctors, and Labour's plans to scrap the pound. They are taxing more and delivering less."

Official government figures show that net capital spending - the money directly spent by the government on infrastructure projects - fell by 32% in the last financial year (1999-2000), from £3.8bn to £2.6bn. The Treasury had sanctioned an increase to £5.5bn, but found that the money went unspent in Whitehall's big spending departments. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is expecting further big rises in capital spending, to £11bn by 2001-02 and an eightfold increase on current levels to £20bn by 2003-04.

Treasury teams are now working with other ministries to find ways of speeding up work on infrastructure projects. Labour spent much of its 18 years in opposition complaining about the lack of spending by the four Conservative administrations, but the latest figures show that net capital investment is now running at a quarter of its level of the early 1990s. Some extra investment is coming from the private finance initiative (PFI), but the amounts are lower than envisaged. In the last Conservative budget in November 1996, Kenneth Clarke anticipated PFI spending of £4.3bn in 1999-2000, but the latest forecast in this year's budget was £1.4bn.

Matthew Taylor, Treasury spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, who have persistently demanded higher levels of public investment, said: "It's mismanagement. There's a huge log jam of things waiting for approval by ministers. PFI schemes are also running into the same problems, months or even years behind schedule. This is about incompetence."

But Lib Dem strategists believe that Mr Brown's comprehensive spending review - now expected on July 18 - will give large increases to capital projects to put this right. "Whether they are capable of spending it, whether they have the staff and the systems in place, remains to be seen," said Mr Taylor.

Treasury officials say that money for projects is available and that Mr Brown - who stuck by inherited Conservative spending totals for his first two years - is not refusing to loosen purse strings. fields.bodyText: Opposition parties last night sought to exploit Labour's admission that spending on Britain's crumbling infrastructure is running at only half the level it was when John Major left office more than three years ago. Conservatives and Liberal Democrats were quick to seize on evidence of the lack of spending on schools, hospitals, roads, railways and the Tube at a time when the Treasury's coffers are overflowing. With the state of public services causing discontent among Labour voters and likely to be an issue at the forthcoming election, the Conservatives said the under-shoot in capital spending was "another classic example of Labour saying one thing, and doing another". Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor, said: "After lecturing us all about the importance of public sector investment, we find that the amount of public investment has actually fallen in every year since Labour came to power. "This government seems incapable of spending taxpayers' money well. With hospital waiting lists up, crime rising and roads in their worst state for over 25 years, public money is being wasted on welfare fraud, new bureaucracies and spin doctors, and Labour's plans to scrap the pound. They are taxing more and delivering less." Official government figures show that net capital spending - the money directly spent by the government on infrastructure projects - fell by 32% in the last financial year (1999-2000), from £3.8bn to £2.6bn. The Treasury had sanctioned an increase to £5.5bn, but found that the money went unspent in Whitehall's big spending departments. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is expecting further big rises in capital spending, to £11bn by 2001-02 and an eightfold increase on current levels to £20bn by 2003-04. Treasury teams are now working with other ministries to find ways of speeding up work on infrastructure projects. Labour spent much of its 18 years in opposition complaining about the lack of spending by the four Conservative administrations, but the latest figures show that net capital investment is now running at a quarter of its level of the early 1990s. Some extra investment is coming from the private finance initiative (PFI), but the amounts are lower than envisaged. In the last Conservative budget in November 1996, Kenneth Clarke anticipated PFI spending of £4.3bn in 1999-2000, but the latest forecast in this year's budget was £1.4bn. Matthew Taylor, Treasury spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, who have persistently demanded higher levels of public investment, said: "It's mismanagement. There's a huge log jam of things waiting for approval by ministers. PFI schemes are also running into the same problems, months or even years behind schedule. This is about incompetence." fields.headline: Good sport
fields.standfirst: Omar Epps promises that Love & Basketball will be his last sporting role. Fortunately, gangster maestro Takeshi Kitano has other plans for him
fields.trailText: Omar Epps promises that Love & Basketball will be his last sporting role. Fortunately, gangster maestro Takeshi Kitano has other plans for him
fields.body:
Omar Epps comes from a family of New York educators, has written stories since childhood, reads voraciously and attended a high school for performing arts. So how come, whenever the bedroom-eyed, tattoo-friendly actor isn't making crime dramas, he's doing football (The Program), baseball (Major League 2), track (Higher Learning) or something or other sporty? Now Epps is co-starring with newcomer Sanaa Lathan in Love & Basketball, the tale of two childhood friends who follow their passions for the game, and one another, through troubled collegiate and professional careers.

You a hoops fan?

I was like, The Fan, like De Niro. I go to the Laker games, they hate me. They're like, "Security, get him outta here."

Is there a favourite player you're stalking?

I ride Shaq [O'Neal] a lot. He's so phenomenal; I like to push him.

Love & Basketball's title sets a new standard for truth in advertising. What do you think the film has to say about each subject?

With the love, first of all, the film offers so many lessons to learn: about selfishness; about conditional versus unconditional love; and about passion, something that's beyond your mind or your body, something that's just inside of you that you feel for someone else. As for the basketball, especially with regard to Sanaa's character, it just shows that no matter what they'll tell you, you can do it. For my character, though, the message was: don't rely on your so-called God-given talent, because God didn't make up the game of basketball. Don't put all of your eggs in that basket, whatever it is. Whatever you want to be, you've got to deal a little bit in reality.

You come from an academic background. How did you become the go-to guy for athlete roles?

I don't know how I ended up in all of these sports movies. When Love & Basketball came around I just figured, OK, might as well go 360 with it. But these movies were all decent ones, save for Major League 2. The films spoke more than the sports to me. But I've retired from them now.

So what's next?

I just wrapped Brother. That's gonna be hot, Takeshi Kitano's first American movie. Everything they talk about him? He's all that, he's bringin' it.

He only speaks Japanese, though. How did the two of you communicate?

Through the eyes. We hung out a bunch of times and he'd be talking to me in Japanese and I wouldn't know what he was talking about, and that would run the same the other way. But that was a fun experience; I think you guys are gonna like it.

You've recently become a first-time father too.

Parenthood humbled me. I was never cocky or arrogant because of some insecurity, which a lot of people are. I was truly confident in me. But my daughter really made me want to learn about the man that I think I want to be. I think about what to add and take out if I really want to be him. It's not for me, it's for her now.

And her mom?

We were together for about seven years, but we're not any more. We're still like family, though; we have a great relationship and I'm thankful for that.

And I guess female companionship isn't too hard for you to find when you want it.

Well, I never thought of myself as some supermodel dude. But you know, I think that anybody in a movie looks good, and that's how people react. I figure I might as well enjoy these years, because they won't last forever. I appreciate it, but I've gotta have some depth to me, too.

fields.headline: Mission: Implausible
fields.standfirst: John Woo's new action blockbuster has ludicrously daft villains and a plot riddled with holes. But it does finally give Tom Cruise a role to sink his teeth into, says Joe Queenan
fields.trailText: John Woo's new action blockbuster has ludicrously daft villains and a plot riddled with holes. But it does finally give Tom Cruise a role to sink his teeth into, says Joe Queenan
fields.body:
Shortly before Mission: Impossible 2 opened in the United States, the Wall Street Journal ran a front-page story about an editing genius who was called in at the 11th hour to reorganise the film. Seemingly, the producers were concerned that John Woo's highly anticipated sequel to Brian de Palma's unbelievably complicated but hugely entertaining Mission: Impossible was a bit hard to follow. Now that the finished product has been released, it's possible to report that the sequel, at the very least, has a story line that makes sense. It's klunky, it's goofy, it's repetitive and it has holes big enough to drive the entire United States Marine Corps through, but at least it can be followed. Thank heavens for small mercies. And industrious editors.

M:I2 is the kind of movie that intelligent, self-respecting critics (there are seven of us, globally) hate to review. Because it is a summer blockbuster, because it is already a mammoth hit in the United States, and because, despite its faults, it is generally quite an engaging film, it seems almost churlish to say anything negative about it. Thus, let me preface my remarks by stating that while M:I2 is not nearly as good as the original, it is not a dud like last year's Wild, Wild West or The Phantom Menace. But it's no Gladiator.

This time out, Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) is forced to abbreviate a rock-climbing vacation in order to save the world in general and Australia in particular from a lethal virus that has fallen into the hands of fiendish villains.

Well, in fact, the fiendish villains, though very, very cruel, are such ninnies that they have only secured one half of the virus, and need the other half in order to bring the world to its knees. In exchange for returning their half of the virus, or all of the virus, or some combination thereof, the villains are demanding the nice round sum of £37 million.

Well, at first they are. But then they decide that they don't really want the £37 million per se, so much as they want the right to buy £37 million worth of stock options in the corporation that has manufactured the virus, so that they can seize control of the company and become fabulously wealthy and even more dangerous and unpleasant. Throughout the film, the villains always seem a bit on edge, perhaps because their fiendish plot is so complicated that they themselves cannot keep the details straight. Fortunately, Hunt can, which is one reason he is so likeable.

As in Mission: Impossible and John Woo's own Face/Off, both Cruise and his adversaries are constantly using clever disguises to switch identities. As a result, one can never tell whether Cruise is really Ethan Hunt, or whether the man who gets beaten to a pulp is in fact Tom Cruise or a henchdude disguised as Tom Cruise, or whether anybody in the film is the person that they claim to be.

This is one of the gaping holes in the plot. Since the villains are trying to blackmail the head of the virus-making corporation into turning over the half of the virus that they don't have, it is not entirely clear why one of them doesn't simply put on a fake face and pretend to be the beleaguered CEO and walk right into company headquarters and stick the virus into his attache case and walk back out again. It is also unclear why the unspeakable forces of pure, unadulterated evil are asking for a measly £37 million when £3 billion and complete dominion of New South Wales seems a more appropriate asking price. But never mind.

In Mission: Impossible, Cruise was constantly seen interacting with other members of his team, and this gave the film a certain pacing and variety and humour. In M:I2, his colleagues have a much smaller, less interesting role, basically manning computers and piloting helicopters and not adding anything special to the film. The love interest this time out is Thandie Newton, here cast as a fantastically gifted pickpocket and safe-cracker who was once romantically involved with Dougray Scott but who is now romantically involved with Cruise.

Newton doesn't have a whole lot to do; she mostly staggers around Australia waiting to die, which is about par for the course for actresses in John Woo movies. The film never really explains how the same woman could fall in love with a man as debonair and clever and virtuous as Cruise and as seedy and sadistic and inept as Scott. Nor why a law enforcement official (Cruise) would get so emotionally involved with a world-class thief who probably cannot be trusted, as criminals often have defective moral character and many other personality flaws. But never mind.

Because Mission: Impossible was a thriller and M:I2 is an action film, it's a great relief when the tangled threads of the plot finally coalesce and Cruise can start killing people. In a way, it's almost a shame that Woo had to even bother with a plot, because all anybody really wants to see in John Woo movies is some good-looking guy - or John Travolta - cavorting on a motorcycle, plunging through plate-glass windows, just generally raising hell.

As with Face/Off, the last half-hour of the film is infinitely more entertaining than the huge build-up that precedes it, particularly if you enjoy highly stylised violence as much as I do. M:I2 has no scene as memorable as the sequence where a suspended Cruise sneaks into CIA headquarters to hack into the agency's computers, and as a villain, Scott is certainly no Jon Voight. Still, after the disaster of Eyes Wide Shut and his curious second banana work in Magnolia, it's nice to see Tom Cruise back doing what he does best. Nobody does better teeth work than Tom Cruise. Nobody's even close.

 Mission:Impossible 2 is out on Friday

fields.headline: Baby, you're a star
fields.standfirst: Iman, Catherine Zeta Jones and Madonna are all expecting babies this summer. But star quality is not just in the genes - it helps if  you play the Hollywood name game, says Rebecca  Taylor
fields.trailText: Iman, Catherine Zeta Jones and Madonna are all expecting babies this summer. But star quality is not just in the genes - it helps if you play the Hollywood name game, says Rebecca Taylor
fields.body:
With Madonna in the family way again, the bets are on as to what suitably kooky concoction the lucky offspring will get for a name. Perhaps mum will be tempted to continue with a religion-themed moniker to complete the Holy Trinity: Madonna, Lourdes and baby Epiphany (for a girl), or Eucharist (for a boy), perhaps? Whatever the new child's name, one thing is for sure: a unique handle can be a definite plus, especially if you want to make your mark in Hollywood.

"A distinctive name can make the celebrity seem interesting, even before you know anything about them," says Pamela Redmond Satran, author of the bestselling American baby-naming book Beyond Jennifer And Jason, Madison And Montana. "It seems as if the cult of the personality has made a huge comeback in Hollywood, with stars selling everything from designer fashion to soap. A celebrity named Leonardo (DiCaprio) or Charlize (Theron) is automatically more exotic and fascinating than a Jimmy (Stewart) or a Katharine (Hepburn)."

When studio titans such as Louis B Mayer and Harry Cohen ruled Hollywood back in the 20s and 30s, it was routine to change a newcomer's name to something a bit more stardust (and, in many cases, a little less Semitic). Theodosia Goodman became Theda Bara, Emmanuel Goldenberg became Edward G Robinson, and the manifestly unglamorous Frances Gumm became Judy Garland.

But times have changed: individuality, diversity and ethnicity are the new Hollywood buzz words, and for an MTV generation of Ionas and Zacharys, anything goes in the name game.

"A lot of the young stars today who have unusual names are children of counterculture parents," says Satran. "It was an enormous trend in America in the 70s to give kids nature names such as River and Sky, as well as place names and ethnic names such as Winona. It represented a break with the old Anglo-Saxon establishment. Parents who chose these names raised their kids in an unconventional, creative manner, and many of those kids grew up to be creative people."

The legacy of 70s parents with hippie inclinations has left Hollywood with more than its fair smattering of colourful names: Rain and (the late) River (Phoenix), Winona (Ryder) and Roma (Downey) to name but a few. Ryder, (born Winona Horowitz) was named after a town in Minnesota, and the word Winona is taken from Winona Siouan, a Native American girl's name meaning first-born daughter.

Other stars have monikers that reflect exotic origins or connections. Uma Thurman, whose father is a renowned Buddhist scholar, takes her name from the Hindi word for "flax". Increased global and cross-cultural influences also mean that names such as Neve (Campbell, whose first name is an anglicised spelling of the Irish "Niamh", which means brightness) no longer sound as unusual as they did 20 years ago. It's an interesting sign of the times that Emilio Estevez goes by his birth name, but his father, Ramon Estevez, changed his name to the distinctly un-Hispanic Martin Sheen in the 60s.

These days, stars are only likely to change their name if it isn't distinctive enough in the first place. The actor formerly known as Brian Ulrich is now the much hipper Skeet, a nickname acquired because of his mosquito-like qualities on the field in Little League.Ving Rhames contracted his first name from the less exotic Irving.

"There's a much more active tradition in the US of inventing or modifying names," says Professor Richard Coates of the University of Sussex. "Names such as Calista (Flockhart) have been remodelled on classical names. Callisto was the name of a nymph who was changed into a bear by Zeus. It comes from the Greek, kallistos, meaning most beautiful and it has been given the typical feminine Ôa' suffix." Jada (Pinkett) has similarly added the -a suffix to a pre-existing name, Jade, while another bizarre combination, Charlize (Theron), is simply a fancy spelling for a blend of Charlotte and Lisa, explains Coates.

Kwami Nyamidie, editor of the US-based Babynamer.com, believes the modification of existing names is an ongoing trend. "This is the way parents are resolving the difficult conflict between the need for a unique name, and the equally important concern for a popular and acceptable one." Using a different spelling for an established name has also long been an African-American tendency, says Nyamidie.

A name such as Halle (Berry) for instance, is an unusual spelling of Hayley, which has been a favourite in the States for decades, inspired by the popularity of Hayley Mills.

In fact, American naming trends often respond dramatically to social and political changes and the naming of stars is not immune to this. "For women, an androgynous name such as Parker (Posey) conveys some kind of feminist cache," says Satran. (Although, ironically, Posey was named after Suzy Parker, a 60s model). But the erosion of boundaries between the genders in many areas of life could account for a growing trend: giving boys' names to girls. Drew Barrymore and Reese Witherspoon are famous examples, but stars are increasingly bestowing their female offspring with male monikers: Diane Keaton's daughter is Dexter Dean, Spike Lee's girl is called Satchel Lewis and Steven Spielberg has a daughter named Destry Allyn.

Satran says the movement towards more idiosyncratic names will continue: "One of the strangest future trends we'll undoubtedly see in Hollywood in 20 years' time is word names such as Discovery, Spruce, Dancer and Camera. We already have Sailor (Christie Brinkley's daughter) and Indigo (Robert Downey Jr's son). This is the new wave of 70s nature names."

As with most Hollywood fads, names regarded as quirky now could soon sound as frumpy as Doris and Humphrey seem to today's stars. But just think: if John Wayne had been born a few decades later, we might still be using his original name: Marion Michael Morrison.

webTitle: Fear and loathing in the lowlands

fields.headline: Fear and loathing in the lowlands
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: There is great excitement in the street. Brandon Ludlow, 22-year-old soccer fan, is due home this afternoon from Charleroi, Belgium
fields.body:
Thursday, June 22, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

There is great excitement in the street. Brandon Ludlow, 22-year-old soccer fan, is due home this afternoon from Charleroi, Belgium. A banner has been erected outside the Ludlows' house. It says Welcome Home Our Hero.

Brandon was arrested before the England Romania match. Apparently, he was having a quiet meal at a pavement cafe and was talking about Jane Austen with his friend, "Mad Dog" Jackson, when a brutal Belgian policeman in riot gear thrashed him unmercifully with a baton.

Mad Dog Jackson escaped, but Brandon was restrained with a cable tie and thrown into the back of a police van where he lay, face down, only inches from a pool of urine. When the van was full, it was driven to a police station. Brandon was pushed towards a holding cell, where he and 40 others stood until daybreak. Brandon was not allowed to phone the Ludlows, his family (and anyway, it would have been a futile exercise since the Ludlows' phone had been cut off by BT for non-payment).

Peggy Ludlow is threatening to sue the Belgian prime minister as soon as she finds out who he is. As she was preparing the party food, she said, "Adrian, our Brandon is the only one of my kids who ain't a hooligan. Our Brandon's always been a strange kid, you know, reading books for pleasure and talking about things that none of the rest of us are interested in."

She told me that Brandon only went to the match for research purposes. He is writing an essay about David Beckham, entitled God Or Idiot Savant? He is hoping to see it published in the London Review Of Books.

4pm

I can tell from the noise outside - car horns blaring, whistles blowing, Dobermans barking - that Brandon has arrived home. We have all been invited to the party. Glenn and William are very excited, as they have been watching the rioting in Charleroi avidly.

In fact, they have shown more interest in the fighting on the streets than they have shown in the football on the pitch. Mrs Wormington talked to me as I ironed one of her vast, full-skirted summer frocks. According to her, certain sections of young Englishmen have always behaved like Barbarians when they have travelled abroad as a group. She said, "How do you think we managed to capture all them foreign countries. It weren't the limp-wristed brigade what done it and coloured the map pink."

She insisted on wearing a hat to the Ludlows' party, seemingly under the impression that it was Ludlow Castle she was going to rather than the front room of a council house. I had a very interesting talk to Brandon, who is indeed a sensitive, intelligent, young man. He reminded me of my younger self, before I became trapped in single fatherhood and the endless round of domestic duties (which now includes caring for a nonagenarian). Over Mother's Pride and Kraft processed cheese sandwiches, we discussed his ordeal. Brandon said that his night in the cells was only made tolerable by the fact that a barrister had also been arrested and had happened to have a copy of last week's Spectator magazine on him. This same barrister kept trying to get his fellow hooligans to chant Boris Johnson's name, but few joined in and eventually he gave up and went to sleep, but only after confessing to Brandon a particularly lurid sexual fantasy that included Petronella Wyatt and Bruce Anderson.

After a heated discussion with Vince Ludlow about Mrs Worthington's habit of banging on the party wall with an orthopaedic shoe every time the Ludlows enjoyed sexual congress, I took my family home.

Sunday, June 25

Brandon came round as promised to read my manuscript of Sty! I dare not let it out of my sight. A lot of work has gone into the first three chapters. Brandon looked up after the first few pages and said that he thought it was a mistake to call my pig hero Lucifer, as it set up false Mephistophelean expectations in the reader. I could have done without such stinging criticism but I have to concede that Brandon has a point. While waiting for the washing machine to finish its cycle, I re-christened Lucifer and call him Peter. It is amazing what a difference this has made to the tone. It now reads like a children's book. I may subtitle it A Farm Yard Allegory. Watch out, Harry Potter. Peter Pig is on the way!

fields.headline: Diverse panel to award book prize
fields.trailText: Three novelists will join an eminent geneticist and a TV newscaster as judges for this year's Guardian First Book Award.
fields.body:
Three novelists will join an eminent geneticist and a TV newscaster as judges for this year's Guardian First Book Award.

The £10,000 award aims to recognise an author's first book, whether it is fiction, non-fiction or poetry. The winner also receives an advertising package in the Guardian and Observer and an endowment of £1,000 worth of books to a school of their choice.

The diversity of books it attracts is reflected by the judging panel. Outside judges are the novelists Julian Barnes, David Baddiel and Toby Litt; Steve Jones, winner of the Royal Society Faraday medal for the public understanding of science; and Kirsty Young, co-presenter of the ITV Lunchtime News, named newscaster of the year.

Barnes is author of eight novels, ranging from Flaubert's Parrot to Love, Etc, to be published this year. Baddiel's highly successful first novel, Time for Bed, is now being filmed. Litt is author of Beatniks, about two Englishmen who try to reenact Jack Kerouac's beat epic On the Road in Bedford bedrooms.

On the panel, chaired by the Guardian literary editor Claire Armitstead, they join the paper's editor Alan Rusbridger, and Louise Collinge, marketing manager of Borders Books.

Borders is running reading groups in stores in London, Glasgow, Cheshire Oaks and York to help choose the shortlist.

fields.headline: Being John Cusack
fields.standfirst: John Cusack is a man with a conscience, but as a film actor he specialises in morally ambiguous characters. By now, he's successful enough not to worry too much whether he's a 'star', but self-aware enough to recognise the temptations and pitfalls of being a movie darling. Suzie Mackenzie finds him something of a tease.
fields.trailText: John Cusack is a man with a conscience, but as a film actor he specialises in morally ambiguous characters. By now, he's successful enough not to worry too much whether he's a 'star', but self-aware enough to recognise the temptations and pitfalls of being a movie darling. Suzie Mackenzie finds him something of a tease.
fields.body:
One pithy definition of the difference between comedy and tragedy, sometimes attributed to that gangster of the comic, Mel Brooks, goes like this. "Tragedy is if I cut my finger; comedy is if you walk into an open sewer and die." Tragedy is subjective; comedy is objective, it requires distance. The comic is no less serious, indeed it can deal with the darkest stuff of life. But, for the spectator, the ethics are different. We suffer with the tragic hero and we laugh at the comic fool. Somewhere between the two lies irony - which requires the self-immersion of tragedy and the detachment of comedy. Irony, you could say, is conscience. But first and foremost, it is an attitude - the attitude of the clown who has no narrative of his own. All Shakespeare's fools are ironists, but even he didn't always know what to do with them - what do you do with the person who has no narrative? Lear's fool, for example, disappears unaccountably half way through the play.

All of which is a way of saying that the actor, John Cusack, is our latterday Fool, our ironist - the closest thing we have to the Shakespearian clown: odd, edgy, inexpressibly funny, wry, charming, sweetly evasive. And tall - six foot three. He wasn't tall as a kid. As a kid he was short. "The ages two to 15 I spent at different stages of shortness. I didn't become a tall person until I was 16." The same age, incidentally, that he became an actor. In the ensuing 17 years, he has made 44 films. That's a hell of a lot of films. "But I only like eight of them." He talks like this, in these kind of abrupt, eccentric rhythms, arms swinging loosely by his side, eyes fixed in a wide-eyed glare. Even sitting he is tall. How would he describe the kind of characters he likes to play. "Er. Confused. Morally ambiguous." Well, I say to him, at least you are clear about that. "Am I?" he says. "I don't know."

And that's it. The end of the interview. I don't mean the end of the conversation but the end of these roles we are playing - interviewer and interviewee. Journalist and film star. He doesn't like it; more than this, he declines it. It's his choice. Wading through a mound of opaque cuttings about him, I came across a story from 1992 in the Los Angeles Herald, where he was interviewed with his close mate Tim Robbins, soon after Robbins made his political satire Bob Roberts. Cusack has a cameo role in the film - playing a sort of satirical jester, in fact. The idea, the journalist's idea, was that they were going to talk about their friendship, the films they have made together, going way back to 1985 when, both unknowns, they made the slight but charming romantic comedy The Sure Thing. Except that Robbins and Cusack had a different idea. They wanted to talk about "the importance of wearing good shoes". The indignant journalist laid into them both in print for refusing to talk about movies. For being unprofessional. For refusing, in other words, to play the parts he had assigned them.

Of course, what they were up to was a piss take. He does the same thing to me when he asks me about my marriage. "Do you cheat on each other?" But he is also making a serious point. Actors, of course, play roles for a living. But all of us, and all the time, play roles in life and we have choices about how we play and what we play. Unthinkingly to play a part - to say this is not me, this is just what I do for a job, is morally irresponsible. This sounds a bit heavy. Cusack put it better, that is, more lightly, in the film he co-wrote, Grosse Point Blank, which deals hysterically with exactly this subject. (You could make the case that all his films since GPB are about this. Is this me, or is this an alias? Who am I?)

In Grosse Point Blank he plays the morally-numbed professional killer, Martin Blank, who undergoes a spiritual crisis when he returns to his childhood town to kill someone and, while there, to attend his high-school reunion with his erstwhile love, played by Minnie Driver. It could have been merely elegant, arch, a film that evoked precisely the emotional blankness that it set out to satirise. To work it required a performance of outsize eccentricity from Cusack - and it got it. And not just from John, but also from his sister Joan Cusack, who plays his secretary in the film with an explosive battiness rarely seen. It's extremely funny and, as he says, serious. "I grew up fascinated by people in the Reagan administration, their ethics, their mercenary values. People who plan wars and then go home to their wives and their kids. How do they live? I thought one way of looking at this was to play around with the killer genre. Some people got it. For some it worked just as entertainment."

For Cusack, the moral aspect and the creative aspect of film making are the same thing - visible in the choices he makes about the kind of films he wants to do. Some are overtly political, such as Bob Roberts and the more recent The Cradle Will Rock, in which he played Nelson Rockefeller. But the majority, and probably the best, of his work, consists of comparatively small-scale portraits of guys - often loners, certainly misfits - people with a jumble of identities trying to figure out who they are: Being John Malkovich is the apotheosis of this. "The most original piece of writing I have ever read, brilliant." Closely followed by High Fidelity, his latest film, adapted from the novel by Nick Hornby and about a bunch of guys who put on attitudes as easily as they put on their beloved records, and then wonder why love doesn't linger.

High Fidelity is the perfect film for what Cusack is trying to do with his acting - which is lightheartedly, easily, in his friendly, nervy way, to explore what it is in each of us that inhibits us from being ourselves. Nick Hornby must be delighted with it, it's better than the book because the movie can do what the novel couldn't and play the songs. Cusack again co-wrote the screenplay with his Grosse Point Blank mates DeVincentis and Steve Pink. "I liked the book and thought it would make a good film because it seemed to me it captured something that no one had done in movies, which is to show how people experience music autobiographically. How, over the years, songs become markers of experience." As he says, how we use music to interpret a situation, a particular song, a particular mood. Change the song and you change the mood. Put the song on and you put on the mood. Then take it off.

"It's something we, guys, have all done. Made tapes for girls, trying to impress them, to meet them on a shared plane of aesthetics. Read them someone else's poetry because they do poetry better than you could do it, because you're too awkward to do it. It seemed to me that Nick just nailed how men's minds work when we're trying to sort out what we do with women. And, of course, it's funny." It's not about anything very much, except what's going on in the characters' minds. There's no great plot, not a lot of narrative. But then, as he says, "There are lots of people who don't have extraordinary things happen to them and who still live quite intense lives."

Maybe he is not a star. Or not a star in the Tom Cruise mould. "People are always telling me, 'You should do more of this, more of that. Why aren't you more of a star. You could be more successful?' But it's all relative. It all depends on your definition of success. Is High Fidelity or Being John Malkovich a success? Both films will probably make money for the people who made them. But neither of them, in total, will make what Con Air made in its opening weekend - $200 million." Con Air was a dreadful action movie, featuring Nicolas Cage, that Cusack did for the money. Not again. "I am rich enough." He knows what he is doing. And in the process of doing it, he has invented a new screen character - a guy equivocal, screwed up and yet decent. "The man with question marks in his eyes", as Pauline Kael once wrote of him, the man who is prepared to admit, "I don't know." An Everyman for our time.

His decency he gets from his parents - his mum a teacher, his dad a documentary film-maker, both Irish by descent and Catholic. Cusack went to church until he was 16, then gave it up. "A recovering Catholic, yes." He grew up, the fourth of five, in Evanston, an upper-middle-class suburb of Chicago - and now has his own place in Chicago as well as in Los Angeles. Don't know where he gets the screwiness from, probably his parents again, a kind of madcap wildness runs in the family - you see it, too, in his sister Joanie, also a wonderful actor. They have worked together in a number of movies, including High Fidelity. Does he help her out? "Don't be ridiculous. She helps me out." How? "By being in the movies. She's so great." (His older sister, Ann, and his brother, Bill, also act. Only his little sister Suzy doesn't.)

His dad, he says, was hysterically funny. "Still is. Very silly." Very silly and very committed - to his marriage, which has lasted 40 years, and to his faith, which, though I can't pretend to know what form this takes, can be inferred from his long-standing friendship with Daniel and Philip Berrigan: Philip, a former Jesuit priest, Daniel, a practising Jesuit who now works in an Aids hostel in New York. Both the brothers are devout pacifists, with long histories of peace protests, and have been imprisoned many times. In 1968, when John Cusack would have been two, they caused a national furore, inspiring nationwide demonstrations, when they broke into army offices and burned draft papers in protest against the Vietnam war.

Cusack says he remembers in his childhood, around the family dinner table, stories of their activism, their incarcerations. "Their commitment is mind boggling. I think Phil is in prison again, he got six years for ripping apart a warhead, which, when you're in your 70s, is not so good." So, a family of good people, used to thinking about issues. Parents who encouraged their children to think for themselves, not to accept what they were told. In the model of the Berrigans, it was shown to them that there is no external authority, not even the moral authority of the church, which should not be questioned. The Catholic Church renounced Philip Berrigan and he was excommunicated when he married a former nun.

A definition of good faith is making choices and accepting responsibility for those choices. So Cusack chose what to keep of Catholicism, "I like that some of it has stayed with me. That it's given me a conscience." The rest, "the mindless ritual", he chucked away. Too much Catholicism? "I don't think so, no. I don't tend to think in terms of a moral authority - be a good boy, do good things - more in terms of what feels right." Which means that you have to watch yourself, he says: "I don't want to be buffeted by the foul, exploitative winds blowing around." And: "A lot about this life I lead is crazy. Having this emperor's card, being able to get in anywhere, meet anyone. Knowing that just about any girl you can think of you can probably get on the phone. Because you have a sort of name." It's very tempting, he says, and quite frightening. And the way to resist it? "Well," he says, "that's what High Fidelity is all about."

When he was small, and short, he wanted to be an athlete, "a boxer" - not as unlike acting as it may appear, similar dedication to discipline, though a more fanatical subordination of the self. And a sense of brotherhood. He enjoys this. In England he is travelling with two mates, one of them Jeremy Piven, also an actor, whom he has known since childhood and whose parents ran The Piven Theatre Workshop, where he first started to act, aged eight. (Piven gives the cameo as the estate agent in Grosse Point Blank.)

By the age of 10, he'd given up wanting to be an athlete, "and decided to do what I was best at, acting". Pragmatic, too. He was always like this. "At school, I'd get into trouble, but I was smart about the trouble I got into. I liked to stir things up, but I always kept an escape hatch." His dad put him in a couple of commercials. And then, from the age of 16 in 1982 up until 1988 - when he was in John Sayles's political allegory Eight Men Out, based on the 1919 World Series baseball scandal - Cusack played little and then bigger parts in an assortment of teen movies.

Of that generation of "brat-pack" actors, River Phoenix is dead; Rob Lowe's career was ruined by a sex scandal; Ditto Charlie Sheen. Cusack didn't make those sorts of mistakes. No sex scandals, unless you count Minnie Driver saying he was mean to her. "Minnie gets cross with everyone. Anyway, I wasn't mean, I was very nice to her. We're good pals. Then he stopped. "I figured I needed other ways to be wild that weren't so physically taxing." fields.bodyText: One pithy definition of the difference between comedy and tragedy, sometimes attributed to that gangster of the comic, Mel Brooks, goes like this. "Tragedy is if I cut my finger; comedy is if you walk into an open sewer and die." Tragedy is subjective; comedy is objective, it requires distance. The comic is no less serious, indeed it can deal with the darkest stuff of life. But, for the spectator, the ethics are different. We suffer with the tragic hero and we laugh at the comic fool. Somewhere between the two lies irony - which requires the self-immersion of tragedy and the detachment of comedy. Irony, you could say, is conscience. But first and foremost, it is an attitude - the attitude of the clown who has no narrative of his own. All Shakespeare's fools are ironists, but even he didn't always know what to do with them - what do you do with the person who has no narrative? Lear's fool, for example, disappears unaccountably half way through the play. All of which is a way of saying that the actor, John Cusack, is our latterday Fool, our ironist - the closest thing we have to the Shakespearian clown: odd, edgy, inexpressibly funny, wry, charming, sweetly evasive. And tall - six foot three. He wasn't tall as a kid. As a kid he was short. "The ages two to 15 I spent at different stages of shortness. I didn't become a tall person until I was 16." The same age, incidentally, that he became an actor. In the ensuing 17 years, he has made 44 films. That's a hell of a lot of films. "But I only like eight of them." He talks like this, in these kind of abrupt, eccentric rhythms, arms swinging loosely by his side, eyes fixed in a wide-eyed glare. Even sitting he is tall. How would he describe the kind of characters he likes to play. "Er. Confused. Morally ambiguous." Well, I say to him, at least you are clear about that. "Am I?" he says. "I don't know." And that's it. The end of the interview. I don't mean the end of the conversation but the end of these roles we are playing - interviewer and interviewee. Journalist and film star. He doesn't like it; more than this, he declines it. It's his choice. Wading through a mound of opaque cuttings about him, I came across a story from 1992 in the Los Angeles Herald, where he was interviewed with his close mate Tim Robbins, soon after Robbins made his political satire Bob Roberts. Cusack has a cameo role in the film - playing a sort of satirical jester, in fact. The idea, the journalist's idea, was that they were going to talk about their friendship, the films they have made together, going way back to 1985 when, both unknowns, they made the slight but charming romantic comedy The Sure Thing. Except that Robbins and Cusack had a different idea. They wanted to talk about "the importance of wearing good shoes". The indignant journalist laid into them both in print for refusing to talk about movies. For being unprofessional. For refusing, in other words, to play the parts he had assigned them. Of course, what they were up to was a piss take. He does the same thing to me when he asks me about my marriage. "Do you cheat on each other?" But he is also making a serious point. Actors, of course, play roles for a living. But all of us, and all the time, play roles in life and we have choices about how we play and what we play. Unthinkingly to play a part - to say this is not me, this is just what I do for a job, is morally irresponsible. This sounds a bit heavy. Cusack put it better, that is, more lightly, in the film he co-wrote, Grosse Point Blank, which deals hysterically with exactly this subject. (You could make the case that all his films since GPB are about this. Is this me, or is this an alias? Who am I?) In Grosse Point Blank he plays the morally-numbed professional killer, Martin Blank, who undergoes a spiritual crisis when he returns to his childhood town to kill someone and, while there, to attend his high-school reunion with his erstwhile love, played by Minnie Driver. It could have been merely elegant, arch, a film that evoked precisely the emotional blankness that it set out to satirise. To work it required a performance of outsize eccentricity from Cusack - and it got it. And not just from John, but also from his sister Joan Cusack, who plays his secretary in the film with an explosive battiness rarely seen. It's extremely funny and, as he says, serious. "I grew up fascinated by people in the Reagan administration, their ethics, their mercenary values. People who plan wars and then go home to their wives and their kids. How do they live? I thought one way of looking at this was to play around with the killer genre. Some people got it. For some it worked just as entertainment." fields.headline: Horns of grace
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  gets into the ring with AL Kennedy's On Bullfighting
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard gets into the ring with AL Kennedy's On Bullfighting
fields.body:
On Bullfighting
AL Kennedy
(Yellow Jersey Press, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

One morning, acclaimed novelist and short story writer AL Kennedy, blocked, a writer no longer a writer, looks out of her study window and internally prepares herself to jump to her death. What stops her are the strains of a particularly irritating song - Mhairi's Wedding - to which it would be absurd to commit a felo de se .

So, to get over her block and her weariness of life, she writes a book about bullfighting. Obvious, really: strange it didn't occur to her earlier. How the book happened in quotidian terms she is coy about, but that doesn't matter as she has written a blinder.

Kennedy, you might think, is not the obvious choice for the subject, or vice versa; there is little of the macho about her, unless you stretch a point to distortion and say that the clenched-teeth steeliness of her prose is in itself masculine. There is little of Hemingway in her; and, thankfully in my opinion, none in this book.

If there is another writer in here, it's Lorca. (Read his Lament for Ignacio Sánchez Mejías, his epitaph on a friend who died in the ring, before you read this, if you can.) Questions of particularly male bravery do not interest her; but bravery itself does, and grace, and destiny. (She points out, with examples, that when a matador kills a bull in the ring who has killed another man, that matador will himself be killed by a bull one day.) It is worth remembering that when Spanish newspapers write up bullfights, the reports go in the Culture section of the paper, not the sports section.

Bullfighting, the corrida, is a crux: it makes us wonder about the human capacity for cruelty and blood. It is gladiatorial, primitive, appalling; an affront to our modern pieties, and had Kennedy not approached the subject from the edge of her own oblivion, she might have been freighted with the kind of attitudes that prompt our own unease.

It has to be said, though, and this book makes its own eloquent case to this effect, that to compare bullfighting and fox-hunting, to bracket them under the term "blood sports", is almost to make a category error. Fox-hunting comes off, by comparison, as pathetically sadistic, and one strange side-effect of this book will be to make you look on it with even more contempt than I suspect you already do. When foxes have curved, sharp horns two or more feet long, weigh half a ton, and can move like lightning, well, maybe then hunters can talk about their ludicrous pastime as something noble and courageous.

As well as the facts, the details and the terms, Kennedy puts much that is autobiographical in, as she did in her other non-fiction work, her study of The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp; this works here, as it did there. It galvanizes her as a writer; and it also shows that if you want a great non-fiction book written, you get a fictionalist to write it.

You may think that the spectacle she is describing is obscene, and that to write beautiful, haunting prose, with a linear direction that makes the book more or less impossible not to read at a sitting (only complaint: it's too short), is in itself a transgression; but you can tell she is poised between possibilities of fascination and disgust. Hers is an honest response to a difficult problem. It is perhaps inevitable that for a mind as responsive as Kennedy's to take it in is to come to the conclusion she does: that it is a religious mystery.

(She points out, with examples, that when a matador kills a bull in the ring who has killed another man, that matador will himself be killed by a bull one day.) It is worth remembering that when Spanish newspapers write up bullfights, the reports go in the Culture section of the paper, not the sports section. Bullfighting, the corrida, is a crux: it makes us wonder about the human capacity for cruelty and blood. It is gladiatorial, primitive, appalling; an affront to our modern pieties, and had Kennedy not approached the subject from the edge of her own oblivion, she might have been freighted with the kind of attitudes that prompt our own unease. It has to be said, though, and this book makes its own eloquent case to this effect, that to compare bullfighting and fox-hunting, to bracket them under the term "blood sports", is almost to make a category error. Fox-hunting comes off, by comparison, as pathetically sadistic, and one strange side-effect of this book will be to make you look on it with even more contempt than I suspect you already do. When foxes have curved, sharp horns two or more feet long, weigh half a ton, and can move like lightning, well, maybe then hunters can talk about their ludicrous pastime as something noble and courageous. As well as the facts, the details and the terms, Kennedy puts much that is autobiographical in, as she did in her other non-fiction work, her study of The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp; this works here, as it did there. It galvanizes her as a writer; and it also shows that if you want a great non-fiction book written, you get a fictionalist to write it. You may think that the spectacle she is describing is obscene, and that to write beautiful, haunting prose, with a linear direction that makes the book more or less impossible not to read at a sitting (only complaint: it's too short), is in itself a transgression; but you can tell she is poised between possibilities of fascination and disgust. Hers is an honest response to a difficult problem. It is perhaps inevitable that for a mind as responsive as Kennedy's to take it in is to come to the conclusion she does: that it is a religious mystery.

webTitle: Blair wants on-the-spot fines for louts

fields.headline: Blair wants on-the-spot fines for louts
fields.standfirst:
Crime: special report
Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair provoked a mixture of scorn, anger and scepticism last night after he proposed on-the-spot fines for Saturday night hooligans - who could be marched to their cashpoints by police and forced to hand over up to £100.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Tübingen and  Michael White
fields.body:
Tony Blair provoked a mixture of scorn, anger and scepticism last night after he proposed on-the-spot fines for Saturday night hooligans - who could be marched to their cashpoints by police and forced to hand over up to £100.

The prime minister chose the unlikely forum of a debate on ethics in one of Germany's most eminent seats of learning to argue that police should be given an unprecedentedly free hand to deal with "nuisance crime" caused by what frustrated Tory ministers once dubbed lager louts.

He said he wanted on-the-spot fines for "drunken, noisy, loutish and anti-social behaviour" - much in the way that errant cyclists, parking offenders and pavement-fouling dogs attract instant fixed penalties that are also subject to legal appeal and court cases if defendants so choose.

The proposal, mooted initially by Home Office ministers, drew a wary response from senior policemen, some of whom will meet Mr Blair for discussions at No 10 on Monday. Blair aides later stressed it was only an idea for wider debate.

Addressing an audience of students at Tübingen, the prime minister explained: "A thug might think twice about kicking in your gate, throwing traffic cones around your street or hurling abuse into the night sky if he thought he might get picked up by the police, taken to a cashpoint and asked to pay an on-the-spot fine of, for example, £100."

Mr Blair added: "If the police want that power - and I believe they will, and the public will support it - they should get that power."

Ann Widdecombe, the Tories' home affairs spokesman, dismissed the proposal as "just another headline-grabbing gimmick".

Simon Hughes, for the Liberal Democrats, said: "There is a basic principle of justice: if you commit a crime you are punished. But punishing people who are not charged and not found guilty is fundamentally against civil liberties."

The radical QC Michael Mansfield said he was "very concerned" because it suggested that ministers "can't be bothered to take this through the courts and want police to act as judge and jury to fine people on the spot".

Police were cautious about the idea. The Police Federation, which represents the kind of beat policemen who would be empowered to fine drunks and other miscreants, said the move might be welcome in principle. But a spokesman warned that it might also breach the European convention on human rights, which will come into domestic operation on October 1.

The Association of Chief Police Officers said it shared Mr Blair's concerns that "loutish behaviour should be firmly dealt with", adding: "We would wish to give further thought on how it could work in practice at street level."

Blair aides said afterwards that £100 would probably be the limit. The reference to cashpoints had been intended to stress that "affluent people" were as much in the government's sights as poorer offenders. Powers would not be introduced without consultation.

Mr Blair, who was addressing the inaugural session of the Global Ethics Foundation, a body set up by the writer and priest Hans Küng, said: "It is perfectly legal for a private company to put a clamp on a car wheel and demand £100 to get it released. Yet no comparable power exists for our public police force. I believe that should change."

webTitle: A gimmick, maybe, but it fits into Blair's vision

fields.headline: A gimmick, maybe, but it fits into Blair's vision
fields.standfirst:
Crime: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What did Tony Blair think he was up to, dropping a controversial but distinctly parochial law-and-order proposal into a wide-ranging speech about "values and the power of community" before a religious audience in Germany?
fields.body:
What did Tony Blair think he was up to, dropping a controversial but distinctly parochial law-and-order proposal into a wide-ranging speech about "values and the power of community" before a religious audience in Germany?

Labour MPs were startled to hear of the "£100 spot penalty" for Saturday night hooligans - and not just on civil liberty grounds.

This speech was meant to be about interdependence in a globalised world, about what Mr Blair called "the grammar of togetherness" and "reciprocal altruism" between rich and poor. It will be remembered for coppers being told to drag drunks to cashpoint machines.

"He did it because Alastair Campbell told him the speech had to have something for the bloody tabloids," one fair-minded Labour MP explained last night.

Another obvious explanation, the MP conceded, was that the prime minister is embarrassed about the appalling reputation abroad of English football hooligans during Euro 2000 - he mentioned them in Tübingen yesterday - and wanted to show he is taking the problem seriously at home.

There is also the little matter of William Hague, who has been running off with the law- and-order headlines lately. The prime minister and home secretary want to regain control of that agenda.

Here was a tough solution to appeal to the Daily Mail and Sun, even if it sounded half-baked and unworkable. The problem has been made more urgent by the looming rise in crime figures, after three years of falling ones, further highlighted by the much-publicised claim on US television this week that Britain is a very violent place.

But this was a speech with an avowed vision far grander than all that. The private Mr Blair takes his religion seriously, but nowadays he is wise enough to avoid making public theological pronouncements even when he succumbs to an invitation from the dissident Catholic theologist Hans Küng.

He was also mindful of the pitfalls of overtly partisan speeches to non-political audiences and must have wondered whether Tubingen might turn nasty - another Women's Institute fiasco. So he devoted just two paragraphs to Europe and one reference to the Tories.

Mr Blair explained his vision of how communities - local, national and international - can mitigate the "breakneck speed and continuous change" that globalisation creates and most people find hard to cope with. He spoke of education, drugs, the daily grind of two-job families, of elderly parents and divorce. Acknowledging the price of growing affluence, he said: "It is a world with a paradox at ther heart of it: greater individual freedom, yet greater interdependence."

Part of his aim was to persuade the wider audience in Europe that the Blairite third way can reconcile tradition and modernisation, the heresies of left and right, one hostile to capitalism and family values, the other fearful of immigrants, yet slaves to market forces.

At the heart of his philosophy, Mr Blair explained, was "the modern idea of community" and his belief in the equality of individual worth - "not equality of income or outcome, or simply equality of opportunity, rather it affirms our equal right to dignity, liberty, freedom from discrimination as well as economic opportunity".

That is a short step from emphasising both what Labour is doing on public services and what it expects by way of responsibility from individuals themselves, "the covenant at the heart of modern civil society", he called it.

The main thrust is enough to enrage his critics on both left and right, too bland and consensual for their tastes, too prone to avoid real differences of interest that will not be easily reconciled.

The fact that No 10 saw fit to drop a gimmicky idea for fining Saturday night drunks into such a speech suggests that his promise to the WI - not to over-spin stories or "fight for every headline" -has already been discarded. We suspected it might be.

webTitle: Is Ofsted right to attack local education authorities?

fields.headline: Is Ofsted right to attack local education authorities?
fields.standfirst: Education is just too important to be left to organisations whose performances have been found to be in some cases execrable, says Ofstead's David Singleton. But Graham Lane of the LGA argues that the elected status of local government brings it a legitimacy and accountability that could never be achieved by private companies. Read the debate and have your say here.
fields.trailText: Education is just too important to be left to organisations whose performances have been found to be in some cases execrable, says Ofstead's David Singleton. But Graham Lane of the LGA argues that the elected status of local government brings it a legitimacy and accountability that could never be achieved by private companies. Read the debate and have your say here.
fields.body:
Dear Graham,

The role of local education authorities is under discussion. It is right that it should be. No institution - including Ofsted - has any divine right to exist. None is immune to change. The main questions that need asking of any aspect of government - local or national - are: "Does it do its job well?" and "Is the job the right one?"

We have now reported on 75 education authorities, and it is clear that the answer to the first question is sometimes yes and sometimes no. Their performance varies from excellent to execrable and encompasses every point on that spectrum. That variability is too great; the government is working hard to reduce it. There's rather less sign of education authorities working collectively to raise the performance of the least effective.

There is little doubt that education authorities are improving as institutions, but that's not in itself a sufficient answer to my second question. Their key role is to support schools in raising standards. To date, inspection evidence does not convincingly demonstrate that they have a major impact. They may - they almost certainly do - have some impact, but it*s not clear that they have enough. As long as the answer to my first question is "yes and no", and to my second question "not proven", the debate is likely to continue.

Yours sincerely,

David Singleton Head of LEA inspection Office for Standards in Education

Dear David,

First of all, local education authorities are not institutions; they are democratically elected and the people can dismiss those who run them at the ballot box. They cannot do that to Ofsted.

It is not their only role to support schools in raising standards, vital as that is. They have a key role to play in pre-school provision and post-school education and training. Moreover, they don't stand alone; they are part of local government, playing a key role in delivering other strategies, such as economic regeneration. The Local Government Association is committed to improving these authorities, and is about to launch a major initiative dealing with local authorities that are ineffective in supporting schools in raising standards. But the present privatisation agenda is a distraction. What is needed is effective strategic political leadership.

The lessons learned from many successful authorities, which you identified, need to be quickly applied where authorities are being less effective. They play a vital role; raising standards is too important to be left to schools alone.

Yours sincerely,

Graham Lane Chair, Education Committee Local Government Association

Dear Graham,

Quite. Education authorities are democratically elected institutions. As such, they are ejectable by the electorate. They can also legitimately be reformed: for example, as the end result of national policy formulated on the basis of evidence collected by an independent inspectorate, which is itself subject to reform, or dissolution, by a democratically elected government.

You're right to say that supporting schools in raising standards is not the only role of the education authorities, but as a realist you surely know as well as I do that it is by their success in that role that they will, in the end, stand or fall.

It's good to hear that you are about to launch a major offensive to deal with ineffective local authorities. Not before time. You're right that effective leadership at the local level is essential. Where it is not there, as our inspections have shown is sometimes the case, what do you suggest?

It is unreasonable to think that 150 local education authorities can manage improvement in every one of 24,000 schools. Most schools, fortunately, can be, if not "left alone", then trusted to manage their own improvement - with help, if they want it, from the education authority, or from elsewhere. Those that can't need more, and more effective, support than they often get. Can't we agree on that?

Yours sincerely,

David

Dear David,

LEAs have changed since their creation in 1902, pioneering all the major educational reforms, from ending selection at the age of 11 to abolishing corporal punishment. Raising standards was, quite rightly, added to their duties in 1998 - and challenging failing schools is a key role that must be carried out. Authorities must now allow any school in its area to continue to fail its students; how that school improves is not the issue, but the LEA must make sure it does. We want schools to take control of their own destiny and that is why local government pioneered local management of schools.

But privatising these services only deals with symptoms, not the political leadership. The causes of failure need to be identified before the solution is found. That can be poor senior staff, weak governors, lack of resources, an inadequate curriculum or even too few permanent, experienced staff. Authorities can use other agencies - but they have to make sure the problems are solved quickly.

We are quite willing to work with Ofsted, but removing the LEA from the scene is no way for a democratic society to behave. The ultimate solution in a democracy is to remove the people responsible for the failure, and that has to include politicians. Private companies can have a role, but since they are not accountable to the electorate, it must be a carefully considered one.

Yours sincerely,

Graham

Dear Graham,

I agree with most of what you're saying - I hope that doesn't make you feel inclined to revise your position! If you*re saying the crucial job for education authorities is to insist on a minimum acceptable level of provision, and to ensure that children - often the most vulnerable children - aren't let down by a minority of schools, then you won't find anyone at Ofsted disagreeing with you. But our inspections have found that too many authorities don't concentrate sufficiently on that central task.

Dealing with symptoms is not necessarily a bad thing; after all, it's often the symptoms that kill the patient. But you evade the issue. You yourself have said that poor political leadership is often the root cause. Our findings bear you out. In that event, what is to be done? It*s too easy to resort, as I think you may be doing, to blaming the teachers.

I know you*re willing to work with Ofsted, but your last paragraph is a bit apocalyptic. Privatisation doesn't "remove the LEA from the scene", as you well know: all the statutory functions of the authority remain with the elected members. No one, incidentally, is arguing for their abolition. But are you really saying there could be no democracy without LEAs? What a recipe for ossification! Change, reform, evolution, and flexibility in response to changing needs are surely touchstones of the effective functioning of democracy. This is not to deny the need for local accountability - but the forms that accountability may take are as subject to change as anything else in this imperfect world.

Best wishes,

David

Dear David,

I'm worried! I seem to be convincing Ofsted that local education authorities need to exist. I'm not blaming teachers for failing schools - but if Ofsted identifies weak senior management or poor teaching, then it is local government, as the employers, that must step in to ensure that students receive high-quality education.

LEAs have constantly changed and, in the end, can be dismissed by the electorate. If an individual authority is failing, then the local government association, working with partners, needs to intervene as well. The political parties need to make sure that education leaders can do the job they have been elected to do. Failure in any school has to be tackled so that it can succeed for all its students. I am not concerned about who actually runs the support services for schools: best value shall be the guiding principle.

Local government, however, is needed to coordinate a complex network of strategies to promote higher standards. Being elected gives local authorities legitimacy, especially over difficult decisions. Elected members remain accountable to the electorate - unlike a private company, whose duty is to its shareholders.

Yours sincerely,

Graham

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Readers share their expertise on fear of flying
fields.body:
Jennifer Stuart asked for advice on how to conquer her aversion to flying so she could visit the Caribbean.

First, buy your ticket to the Caribbean. Now you're committed. Next, learn a relaxation technique: I learnt this at ante-natal classes, though there are numerous books and tapes available.This should relax you physically during the flight, but there may still be terror in your head, so fill your head with something else; find a really good book, ie one that you have been meaning to read for years, or one that has been strongly recommended by friends who know what you like. Start reading as soon as you have heard the safety announcement. Ensure, at check-in, that you are very close to an emergency exit point. Carry a hip flask. The difficult times are take-off and touch-down; in between, you realise after a while that you're still alive, and the anxiety recedes.Tell yourself it is not irrational to have an aversion to flying. These strategies worked for me, after years of avoiding flying.

Morag Williamson

The only way to conquer a fear is by confronting it - the more you avoid it the worse it gets. The trouble with flying is you don't have many chances to "get used to it" by building up your confidence and having small practise runs. I believe there are special training trips on offer, try one of the airports or airlines. My experience is that when you actually get on the plane, while you might not actually enjoy it, it doesn't seem half so bad as when you were lying in bed anticipating how awful it was going to be. David John

• One-day Fear of Flying courses are organised by Aviatours, Pinewoods, Eglinton Road, Tilford, Surrey GU10 2DH (01252 793250) and cost £189.

This week's question

fields.bodyText: Jennifer Stuart asked for advice on how to conquer her aversion to flying so she could visit the Caribbean. First, buy your ticket to the Caribbean. Now you're committed. Next, learn a relaxation technique: I learnt this at ante-natal classes, though there are numerous books and tapes available.This should relax you physically during the flight, but there may still be terror in your head, so fill your head with something else; find a really good book, ie one that you have been meaning to read for years, or one that has been strongly recommended by friends who know what you like. Start reading as soon as you have heard the safety announcement. Ensure, at check-in, that you are very close to an emergency exit point. Carry a hip flask. The difficult times are take-off and touch-down; in between, you realise after a while that you're still alive, and the anxiety recedes.Tell yourself it is not irrational to have an aversion to flying. These strategies worked for me, after years of avoiding flying. Morag Williamson The only way to conquer a fear is by confronting it - the more you avoid it the worse it gets. The trouble with flying is you don't have many chances to "get used to it" by building up your confidence and having small practise runs. I believe there are special training trips on offer, try one of the airports or airlines. My experience is that when you actually get on the plane, while you might not actually enjoy it, it doesn't seem half so bad as when you were lying in bed anticipating how awful it was going to be. webTitle: Virtual video's inventor faces web fadeout

fields.headline: Virtual video's inventor faces web fadeout
fields.standfirst: Film industry's $10m target talks surrender
fields.trailText: The inventor of the "virtual video recorder" yesterday said he wanted to settle with the entertainment industry after his start-up company received a $10m writ for copyright infringement.
fields.body:
The inventor of the "virtual video recorder" yesterday said he wanted to settle with the entertainment industry after his start-up company received a $10m writ for copyright infringement.

David Simon, 40, a software programmer, closed down his website RecordTV.com, which allowed users to record television shows and watch later at their convenience, after lawyers for a dozen media groups, including Time Warner and Disney, alleged that he was stealing their shows.

"I don't want to be the figurehead or a martyr," Mr Simon told the Guardian. "I am a guy with two kids, a mortgage and a regular job. I just want to settle."

He has become the latest target of a media and entertainment industry keen to destroy all web-based "attacks" on its legal rights. Earlier this month, the US recording industry asked the federal court to shut down online music-sharing service Napster.

This time it is the Motion Picture Association of America which has trained its sights on RecordTV.com.

"David Simon, willingly and knowingly, has built a business based on offering its customers access to valuable, stolen property," said Jack Valenti, president and chief executive of the MPAA.

Last November, Mr Simon used not much more than a cable feed and a few computers equipped with television tuner cards in his Los Angeles home to record episodes of Pokemon on his PC for his daughter.

A few months later, RecordTV.com was born - and by March was attracting some 100,000 users and up to 2m hits a day.

The ease with which Mr Simon produced his website contradicted the industry view that the quality of the internet was not up to "video streaming" popular programmes. However good the technology, it may not be enough to save Mr Simon.

"We have no funding and are just trying to reach a settlement," he said.

The future of the website, which sports a picture of the founder as well as a biography mentioning his love of running 15 miles a day, is based as much on raising some money as pacifying the media moguls.
