webTitle: Atlantic fish stocks in peril, survey reveals

fields.headline: Atlantic fish stocks in peril, survey reveals
fields.trailText: Two thirds of the fish stocks in the north-east Atlantic and all of the commercial species in the North Sea are over-exploited and in danger of disappearing, according to a report released yesterday in Copenhagan.
fields.body:
Two thirds of the fish stocks in the north-east Atlantic and all of the commercial species in the North Sea are over-exploited and in danger of disappearing, according to a report released yesterday in Copenhagan.

In the first comprehensive look at the state of the seas along the European coastline, the depletion of fish stocks was the main concern but pollution from the oil industry and other human sources was also serious.

There have been regional reports of some coastal areas, Irish and North seas before by the Ospar commission, a 15 nation treaty organisation which deals with pollution in European waters and the health of the seas, but never one covering the whole region.

The report reviews evidence from the Arctic to the straits of Gibraltar and from Greenland to the Kattegat, concluding that in some areas pollution had been reduced but overall, the seas faced many threats.

Apart from overfishing, trawls were causing serious damage to the sea bed, destroying many species including rare corals which were being smashed. Anti-fouling paints used on the bottom of ships were continuing to cause serious problems, with shellfish changing sex and colonies being destroyed. For the first time, there were serious concerns about the effect of global warming on the seas - on fish spawning, the disappearance of wetlands and potential for flooding low lying areas.

Among the other findings was the threat to wild salmon stocks of escapes from fish farms resulting in interbreeding and parasites; serious damage to sea bed and marine life by large scale dredging for sand and gravel; litter from ships strangling and drowning birds, turtles and dolphins, and the discharge of oily waste and bilges from ships which has led to 100 exotic species being released and breeding in European waters.

Although heavy metals like cadmium, mercury and lead had reduced, PCB pollution was still a serious problem. Stored in body fat PCBs could make some birds and mammals sterile. North sea flatfish were developing tumours because of contamination. Oil and gas installations were causing pollution and marine life was reduced within two miles of platforms.

The report was launched in Copenhagen by the Danish environment minister, Svend Auken, the host of the five-day meeting of Ospar nations. He said it was a hopeful sign that the combined efforts of 15 countries had managed to reduce pollution in many areas but despite this there were many serious areas of concern.

According to the report, 40 of the 60 main commercial fish stocks were "outside safe biological limits". This meant too many adults were being killed to leave viable breeding stock. All nine species listed from the North sea, including cod and haddock, came into this category despite EU efforts to limit catches.

Of special concern were the deepwater fish, not previously caught, but now trawled to replace overfished species. The scabbard, roundnose grenadier and argentine found along the continental shelf edge are now regularly found in British supermarkets.

Euan Dunn, RSPB marine police officer, said: "Knowledge of these deep water species is in its infancy. With their slow growth and low breeding rate they are highly vulnerable to over-exploitation." Dr Dunn said the report was "a wake-up call to the EU."

The World Wide Fund for Nature said in a statement that global warming was potentially the most serious threat to species in the north-east Atlantic. It said the report showed the seas were severely degraded and a greater sense of urgency was required.

fields.headline: Let's mention the war
fields.standfirst: Some current vehement rows show that the past is still a problem for Germany
fields.trailText: Since 1945, one word has been a talisman in Germany: Vergangenheitsbewältigung. To watch our horrible football fans a fortnight ago as they assaulted Germans, or screamed "If it wasn't for the English you'd be Krauts" at bemused Belgians, was to wonder which country had more successfully accomplished this "coming to terms with the past". In Germany, the truth about what had happened under the Third Reich - and what the nation had done - was confronted with excruciating honesty.
fields.body:
Since 1945, one word has been a talisman in Germany: Vergangenheitsbewältigung. To watch our horrible football fans a fortnight ago as they assaulted Germans, or screamed "If it wasn't for the English you'd be Krauts" at bemused Belgians, was to wonder which country had more successfully accomplished this "coming to terms with the past". In Germany, the truth about what had happened under the Third Reich - and what the nation had done - was confronted with excruciating honesty.

But just when you think the ghosts of the past are laid, they have a way of coming back to haunt you again. Several vehement rows, small and large, have just erupted around Gunther Ottinger, Helmut Kohl and Ernst Nolte. Together they show that the past remains a problem in Germany. The least serious concerns Ottinger, leader of the Christian Democrats in south-west Germany. At a reunion dinner with his old student duelling club at Tübingen university (happy days!), he sang the first verse of the national anthem.

That is, instead of the postwar, politically sanitised version, "Unity and law and freedom", he sang " Deutschland, Deutschland über Alles . . .", August von Fallersleben's original lines written in the high noon of German nationalism: "Germany, Germany above all others . . . from the Maas to the Memel, from the Etsch to the Belt." These are sensitive place names today for some of Germany's neighbours. The Etsch (Adige in Italian) is in the South Tyrol, removed from Austria after 1918 as a prize of war of Italy. And the river Memel (Klaipedia in Lithuanian) is now more than 300 miles from German territory. It was once the northern frontier of East Prussia, part of the vast territories in the east taken as a prize of war in 1945 when more that 12m people were driven out of lands east and south of the Oder which had been German since the middle ages.

Very few Germans now expect a revision of frontiers, and so what Ottinger sang could be dismissed as a convivial and trivial gaffe. Germany no longer stretches from Etsch to Memel. But then Britannia no longer rules the waves, and the bounds of land of hope and glory are no longer wider and wider set, whatever may be sung at the last night of the Proms. Antique patriotic songs can be harmless enough.

There is less of an excuse for Kohl, not long retired as the longest-serving postwar chancellor but now mired in scandal. He was proved to have accepted clandestine political donations when in office, was very heavily fined, and has been trying to raise money to pay the fine. When one Social Democrat suggested this fundraising should be shunned, Kohl said he was reminded of the boycott of Jewish shops in the 30s: "I have already experienced this as a child." As Michel Friedman of the Central Council of Jews in Germany said, this grotesquely thick-skinned comparison "trivialises the persecution of the Jewish community in the Third Reich".

Still, even Kohl's vulgar outburst was not significant: unlike the award of the important Konrad Adenauer prize to Nolte. The most conspicuous of rightwing nationalist historians, he was at the centre of the Historikerstreit of the 80s. In that "battle of historians", he argued that the German army in 1945 had been defending civilisation, and that the Germans at that time should be seen as victims rather than unique villains, as they had so often been portrayed.

He has also claimed that Hitler's anti-semitism had a "rational core", since Nazism was "the strongest of all counter-forces" to Bolshevism, which had wide Jewish support. It was the communists who pioneered mass murder, Nolte argues, and Hitler was a mere novice at the feet of Lenin and Stalin. Awarding the prize seemed intended to show that these are now mainstream views. It was presented to him by another well-known historian, Horst Moller, director of the Institute for Contemporary History, who defended Nolte against what he called "hate-filled and defamatory attacks". Something is going on here.

What is going on is partly a reaction to that earlier exercise in coming to terms, which sometimes took the form of national self-flagellation and international denunciation, or what Nolte calls the "collective accusation" against Germany ever since Hitler. It would have been surprising if there had been no form of revisionism at all, and not everything Nolte says is totally wrong. For too long there was a double standard in historical judgment - what has been called an asymmetry of indulgence between crimes of right and left. Hitler's murder of millions was intolerably and incomparably wicked, Stalin's murder of even more millions was just one of those things.

But Nolte doesn't leave it at that. He insists on making claims which are ever more extreme, not to say insulting. Some go beyond polemical exaggeration, and when you read him you might wonder whether, as his compatriots would say, Professor Nolte has all the cups in his cupboard.

At the least, he is eccentric with chronology. Hitler's Jew-hatred was fermented in Vienna before the first world war, and could scarcely have been a reaction to the October revolution of 1917, a revolution which would not have taken place without a war which Germany wanted and Russia didn't. And, although there plainly was a vicious circle of violence in the 20th century, the idea that Hitler needed to take lessons in genocide from anyone is frankly bizarre.

Even when Nolte says, truly enough, that the German people suffered terribly in the last years of the war, from bombing, hunger and ethnic cleansing, not only hate-filled defamers may be inclined to ask who's talking. If Germany hadn't taken Europe into two terrible wars, her borders would indeed still stretch " bis an die Memel " and millions of Germans would today still live in East Prussia and Silesia.

Tabloid Hun-bashers say that the Germans are eternal barbarians and aggressors. As someone who knows and likes the country, I would gently suggest that the true German problem - not fully come to terms with, if Nolte and Kohl are anything to go by - isn't self-aggrandisement or self-assertion but self-pity.

fields.headline: The real American gothic
fields.standfirst: In 1968 Michael Lesy 'tumbled into a holocaust without Jews, buried in the history of the heartland of the United                                 States'. It was a history in photographs and newspaper reports of Wisconsin in the 1890s. Lesy made it into a book -                                 Wisconsin Death Trip - an extraordinary account of death, epidemics, arson, madness, poverty, and other daily events.                                 Now it is a film by James Marsh. Here Lesy explains the story of the book.
fields.trailText: In 1968 Michael Lesy found a history in photographs and newspaper reports of Wisconsin in the 1890s. Lesy made it into a book - Wisconsin Death Trip - an extraordinary account of death, epidemics, arson, madness, poverty, and other daily events. Now it is a film by James Marsh. Here Lesy explains the story of the book.
fields.body:
The first publisher of Wisconsin Death Trip was an underground newspaper called Take Over. I worked there - if you choose to call what I did work - as a political collage maker while I studied American history in graduate school at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. Take Over had made a name for itself by publishing a fabricated story about a murder committed at a huge meat processing plant, downwind from the state capital, across the highway from the city's sewage treatment plant.

The paper claimed that the dead man's body had been disposed of by blending it with the other meat that left the plant's renowned hot-dog production line. The plant called a news conference to deny the story but since the worker - who had never existed - had vanished, the plant found it difficult to prove a negative and the paper's reputation was made, and so followed that first fabrication with something even less plausible: "Nixon Invades Cambodia" was the 12 inch headline.

Unfortunately, two weeks after we reported it, President Nixon actually did send US troops across the border. No-one would print the paper, let alone advertise in it. Eventually we found printer 60 miles away who would print the thing after hours - as long as no-one found out. A coalition of wholesale marijuana dealers, known as the Midwest Dealers Association, tithed themselves to pay for printing costs. The paper's politics, combined with its funding sources, provided the police with sufficient cause to spy on it, paid informants, installed wiretaps, and infiltrated agents to keep watch over our daily lives.

The result was that one day, when a fellow I barely knew finished laying out a page and got in his car to drive off to firebomb an insurance company, he was followed by an unmarked convoy of Red Squad detectives. They didn't even give him a chance to light a match before they tried to arrest him. The boy ran. The police ran after him - all the way to his apart ment where he pulled a gun and shot and wounded a police officer.

The cops probably would have killed him, except he was white and his mother taught at the university. I ended up at the University of Wisconsin because I thought I wanted to study European social history. I'd graduated from Columbia College in New York City in 1967, one year before the anti-Vietnam student demonstrators occupied its buildings. When I first told my friends I was leaving to study in Wisconsin, a few asked me where Wisconsin was.

I answered that, to the best of my knowledge, it was near Wyoming since, as everyone knew, the states were arranged alphabetically, east to west, from A to Z. It felt like the end of the alphabet once I arrived in Madison, the state capital. The place was beautiful; the women were stunning, but the New York Times arrived two days late, and it was impossible to see more than one new movie a week, let alone the three a day I was used to in New York.

Worse than that, my professor was a mincing little man with a dachshund who insisted that for starters, we read and translated Martin Luther's letters to the German princes. I had one book of photographs with me - an anthology of black and white images called The Photographer's Eye, published by the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Several images in it - one in particular, of an old lady standing by a fence - had captions which identified them as coming from the State Historical Society of Wisconsin.

I was so bored that I went looking for them; what I blundered into changed my life. The society kept all its photographs in something called the department of iconography whose offices were up a flight of marble stairs, down a dim, chilly corridor, off a foyer that overlooked the carved plaster columns and Palladian windows of the society's main reading room.

As I opened the door, I heard the music: Janis Joplin, soft, sweet, low and desperate, thrumming like a cat. There was one light on in the whole place, a buttermilk saucer of it, pooled on the secretary's desk. She lay across it, head cradled in her arms. "Take it. Take another little piece of my heart," Janis sang.

The curator of the place - its founder and director - was an old man named Paul Vanderbilt. He had a little bit of white hair and a scraggly white beard, but his lips and eyes were as sweet and soft as a boy's. "Yes, yes", he said. "We have those pictures. But we have quite a few others, too. Marsha," he said, "would you mind turning on the lights, please?"

When Marsha did, I realised how much I didn't know. The room was lined with filing cabinets; bank after bank of steel shelves in parallel lines ran into the depths of the space. I had walked into my first photographic archive. That afternoon, Paul and I began a conversation that continued, one day to the next, for four years. Some days, I thought he was Prospero; some days, Polonius; some days, Lear.

In fact, he was Hess's Master of the Glass Bead Game. He knew about tacit meanings and the language of things; he understood the syntax of juxtapositions, inferences, and ambiguities; he could recite 1,000 word sentences coiled inside a single, frozen moment.

Outside, in what passed for the real world, people, well known and otherwise, were getting shot to death in their beds, or in hotel kitchens, or in the backseats of convertibles, or on their way to their motel rooms. Half a world away, we were turning a whole country into a cratered charnel house. I told the professor with the dachshund that I had other things to do.

I declared myself a student of American history, settled into my conversations with Paul, and began to read everything and anything my professors wanted me to know about US foreign and domestic policy. One day, Paul asked me if I'd ever heard of August Sander or seen any of his work.

"Of course", I said. "Not as much as I'd like, though." Sander had been a portrait photographer in Cologne. After the first world war, he'd decided to systematically photograph the entire human race, type by type, trade by trade, class and caste. He'd printed his portraits on photographic paper engineered to reproduce everything he saw in fine grained, flawless detail.

Unfortunately, the Nazis had their own ideas of what constituted the human race and destroyed the printing plates of Sanders' book. Twenty five years after the second world war, Sanders' great images were just being printed and published again.

"Well," said Paul, "if you like Sanders, you might want to look at these."

"These" were 3,000 images made at the very end of the 19th century by a man named Charles Van Schaick, the town photographer of a Wisconsin county seat called Black River Falls. Those images eventually became the images of Wisconsin Death Trip.

It was the eyes of the people in the pictures that did it to me. Their gaze; their long, slow, steady gaze. Since I was an earnest young historian, I began to investigate the history of the town where Van Schaick worked.

As I began to list the data sources - diaries, newspaper on microfilm, state statistics - I asked Paul if I could make slides of some of the images.

"And why?" he asked.

I'd started a film society, I told him. We were showing things like Bunuel's Le Chien Andalou, but it was all on 16mm, and in between reels, we needed something to entertain the audience. I thought the slides would amuse people.

"Fine", he said. So, in between eyeballs being slit and men with movie cameras riding trollies, I showed slide sequences of Van Schaick's portraits. I read as many farm diaries from the area around Black River Falls as I could stand. "Rain today. Too wet to plant," was all that happened.

I made my notes and went on to the town's newspaper. I spooled the first reel of microfilm that had been made of it, and began to read the state and local news columns. In between the church supper announcements and the birth and betrothal notices, the murders and suicides and the ghosts began to appear. I looked up and away from the screen.

The microfilm reading room was a cold, dark, low-ceiling vault, quiet except for the sound of chairs shifting across its marble floor, and the whine of motor- drives winding microfilm.

"Jesus!" I whispered.

"No-one ever told me about this stuff."

The "stuff" kept coming, issue after issue. Arsons, epidemics, infanticides, suicides, bankruptcies.

"Ah, my God," I thought, "I've stumbled into a madhouse." Not so, though. The state statistics showed the place had normal rates for everything - mental and physical health; infant mortality, commercial activity and crop production. Worse yet, the craziness was being reported from all across the region.

I settled into a rhythm: I attended lectures, spoke up at seminars, talked with Paul - and read microfilm. Reel after reel of it. Flat, uninflected chronicles of suffering, suffering everywhere. At the end of the day, I'd stagger out into the light, go home, get loaded, and read Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse-Five.

"So it goes," said Vonnegut's Billy Pilgrim.

"So it goes." I'd stumbled into a holocaust without Jews, buried in the history of the heartland of the United States, at the end of an era that everyone kept calling the Gay Nineties.

Half my friends were academics; half were artists, subversives, and outcasts. Every one of us knew that something had gone wrong with our country. The academics sat in classrooms and libraries, poring over documents like medical researchers, trying to discover the origins of the outbreak that was killing everyone.

The outcasts and revolutionaries I knew - the dope dealers and ideologues and outlaw bikers, the larcenous poets and whole-earth farmers and hermit-girl truck drivers - were evenly divided between those who wanted to bring down the walls, and those who wanted to head for the hills before anyone lit the first match. And me? All I wanted to do was make a movie.

Back in New York, I'd spent a quarter of my life in the dark, in theatres like the New Yorker, and the Thalia, and the Carnegie Hall Cinema. I'd read and re-read Eisenstein and Poduvkin. I'd even worked as an assistant when my best buddy - a cinematographer who'd learned his craft in the porn industry - began making 16mm, short, dramatic films of his own.

It would take too long to tell you exactly how it happened, but two years after I saw the first faces from Black River Falls, I met a young guy in New York who worked as an apprentice film editor for a production company. He and his uncles were all that were left of a big family of Dutch diamond cutters who'd been rubbed out by the Nazis. Since a lot of my relatives had gone up the chimney too, we had something to talk about.

He introduced me to a guy who was getting rich making commercials that panned across packs of cigarettes and soda bottles as if they were as big as trees or buildings. For the price of three file clerks' annual salaries, the guy said he'd make a five-minute movie of all Van Schaick's pictures. I didn't have the money.

Even if I'd had it, I wasn't sure that five minutes of fluid-mounted macro zooms would do the trick. That's why I made a book. Please understand, though: the book I made, I made as if it were a movie. A strange kind of movie, of course, more like a perpetual motion machine with no moving parts than a John Ford western.

The book was made to move rhythmically and incrementally, like a Gamelan concert; it relied on the viewer/reader to decipher - and participate in - its coded progressions as if they were elements of a collage built like a raga.

John Cage and William Burroughs were as much its godfathers as Max Ernst and John Heartfield. Minor White and Ralph Gibson's photo sequences had as much an influence as Bob Dylan's Blonde On Blonde and John Wesley Harding. James Marsh is an artist. He found the book and the book found him. He made Wisconsin Death Trip into the movie it was.

 James Marsh's Arena film Wisconsin Death Trip, adapted form Michael Lesy's book (University of New Mexico Press, $29.95), will be shown tomorrow night at 10.10pm

fields.headline: 10 Manchester St, London
fields.trailText:
Address: 10 Manchester Street, London, W1M 5PG.
Tel: 020-7486 6669
Web address: www.10Manchesterstreet.com
fields.body:
Address: 10 Manchester Street, London, W1M 5PG.
Tel: 020-7486 6669
Web address: www.10Manchesterstreet.com

First impressions Middle market. Located in a swanky area but the place itself is not overly plush. The reception area looks like the secretary's office at a decent comprehensive.

What are the rooms like? Delightful. Very spacious and tastefully decorated. Decent air conditioning would help for the rare flashes of British summer, but otherwise there is a very helpful side room if the whirring fan gets too much.

The bed test Big enough, comfy enough.

The bathroom test Nothing glamorous, everything functioning. The Marks & Spencer of bathrooms.

The restaurant Understated. An identical number of notches up from Blackpool B&B as it is down from Claridge's.

The lounge Full of people and papers and chat - exactly as it should be.

What is there to see within walking distance? Most of central London, particularly Oxford Street and Tottenham Court Road.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? All of central London, although central London being what it is you'd be better walking.

How much a night? Small doubles £120; double/ twin £150; suite £195.

Would you go back? Yes, if I lived out of town and was feeling flush.

fields.headline: Alwaha, London
fields.standfirst: An incantation to Lebanese indulgence leaves Matthew Fort with a gleam in his eye
fields.trailText: An incantation to Lebanese indulgence leaves Matthew Fort with a gleam in his eye
fields.body:
Address: Alwaha, London

I heard it through the grapevine. Alwaha is producing some really interesting Lebanese food. Lebanese food! The very phrase has rung like a clarion for me ever since I fell in love with it at the great Chez Marcelle.

Chez Marcelle was a restaurant of such unappealing aspect that I nearly didn't go in. Having gone in, I nearly never came out again. The cooking was a revelation - clean flavours, oomphy spicing, dead sexy in every department. It left the mouth and the man feeling fresh and fizzing. Since then ... well, let's just say, as with most things in life, there is more disappointment than there is fulfilment, so you can understand why I responded to the siren call of Alwaha, dragging Daphnis and Chloë in my wake.

Alwaha lies on the corner of Westbourne Grove and one of its side streets. Westbourne Grove is a curiosity. It manages to combine a scruffy, exotic loucheness with a series of restaurants unparalleled in London for their range and oddity. Greek, Chinese, caff and Malaysian, Indian and Austrian, Iranian and modern British (sic), all jostle hugger-mugger for custom.

Alwaha is at the respectable end of the spectrum. While perhaps not in the forefront of contemporary restaurant design, it certainly has greater appeal than Chez Marcelle. It shares the latter's taste for pine, but keeps it a modest, natural shade, rather than Marcelle's Day-glo orange. There's quite a lot of greenery, but the overall impression is smart, decent, serious, an impression confirmed by the prices.

Not that Alwaha is expensive. It's not dirt-cheap, certainly, but given the general price range in London these days there's not much to click your teeth at. I zeroed in on the set lunch at £18, which promised a range of hot and cold dishes for a first course, a mixed grill and a pudding. You might say that £18 for three courses doesn't strike you as being bargain-basement stuff. Nor is it, but there is enough food to eat yourself to a standstill, and of a standard that shames many places that charge twice as much.

The bill for the three of us was a princely £73.75, including a modest bottle of Chteau Kefraya - a Lebanese rosé of impeccable cut - coffees, waters, orange juices and cover charge, plus a kingly array of tabbouleh, warak inab, hummus shawarma, moutabal, fattoush, foul moukala, moussakat batinjan, batata harra, jawaneh meshwiyh, kibbah maklieh, kallaj bil jiben, not to mention my kebab and the exquisite, pistachio-stuffed, syrup-sodden pastries for pudding.

Don't the very names send drifts of the flavours of spices and herbs wafting through the brain? They are an incantation to indulgence. Somehow, vine leaves stuffed with rice, herbs and spices, fried aubergine with chickpeas, onions, aubergines and spices, and grilled chicken wings in garlic sauce don't have quite the same evocative magic.

Of course, names aren't everything. There's many a menu that seduces the eye and imagination, only to prove a severe disappointment when you get around to eating the dishes of choice. That does not apply to Alwaha. The place wasn't exactly full to bursting that lunch-time - there was only one other table occupied - but the kitchen wasn't sending out any tired old rubbish. Each dish carried the authentic hallmark of proper middle-eastern cooking - peppy spices, singing herbs, shining flavours, health and happiness in every mouthful, not a stale note, not a sloppy detail in evidence, even in the standard items. The hummus had an unctuous, velvet texture to it, and a subtle, slightly piquant flavour that slithered around the mouth. The tabbouleh sparkled, the proportion of parsley to burghul about 1,000,000:1, as it should be. The kallaj bin jiben is a kind of Lebanese pizza, small but packing a punch through the use of melted halloumi cheese. The kebabs were models of grilled meats. And so on and so on. Each dish had a list of virtues enough for an entire review.

That's why £73.85 - £44.75, if you strip out the non-food items - seems a reasonable sum to to me. So, instead of wishing that I was heading for a quick nap (my normal form, post-lunch), there was a spring in my step and a lively gleam about my eye. I was ready for anything, including second helpings.

Of course, names aren't everything. There's many a menu that seduces the eye and imagination, only to prove a severe disappointment when you get around to eating the dishes of choice. That does not apply to Alwaha. The place wasn't exactly full to bursting that lunch-time - there was only one other table occupied - but the kitchen wasn't sending out any tired old rubbish. Each dish carried the authentic hallmark of proper middle-eastern cooking - peppy spices, singing herbs, shining flavours, health and happiness in every mouthful, not a stale note, not a sloppy detail in evidence, even in the standard items. The hummus had an unctuous, velvet texture to it, and a subtle, slightly piquant flavour that slithered around the mouth. The tabbouleh sparkled, the proportion of parsley to burghul about 1,000,000:1, as it should be. The kallaj bin jiben is a kind of Lebanese pizza, small but packing a punch through the use of melted halloumi cheese. The kebabs were models of grilled meats. And so on and so on. Each dish had a list of virtues enough for an entire review. That's why £73.85 - £44.75, if you strip out the non-food items - seems a reasonable sum to to me. So, instead of wishing that I was heading for a quick nap (my normal form, post-lunch), there was a spring in my step and a lively gleam about my eye. I was ready for anything, including second helpings.

webTitle: England's heroes show the right mettle

fields.headline: England's heroes show the right mettle
fields.trailText: Nerve-jangling, spine-tingling, nail-biting? You'd better believe it. Watching today's play was like sitting in front of seven-and-a-half hours of golden-goal extra-time. And for once England won without paying the penalty.
fields.body:
Nerve-jangling, spine-tingling, nail-biting? You'd better believe it. Watching today's play was like sitting in front of seven-and-a-half hours of golden-goal extra-time. And for once England won without paying the penalty.

This wasn't a typical Lord's Saturday and it wasn't the typical Scotch-egg-scoffing crowd. It was alive and transfixed to every ball of completely compelling cricket. Every run was cheered; every no-ball applauded; every play-and-miss oohed-and-ahhed and each cracking shot - England weren't in their shells today - roared. They lapped up Hick's Botham-esque eyes-off-the-ball hook just before tea, Cork's six into the Grand Stand and much much more.

England seem to have found a proper opening partnership. Michael Atherton and Michael Vaughan may be mirror images of each other but, when they bat as calmly and authoritatively as they did today, who cares? And it wasn't as if they were slow or cowed. Atherton, hit on the hip bone by a 91mph missile from Franklyn Rose, responded with a beautiful back-foot square-drive next ball. Vaughan confidently drove Reon King for four in his first over and hit six boundaries in his 41. As he walked back to the pavilion Lord's stood to him - if he needed a reminder of what the future could hold, that was it. But he won't need much luck, he is the most natural-looking Test player England have produced since Graham Thorpe. And then there was Cork and Gough. Courtney and Curtly might be better eyeballers but Darren and Dominic are champions at getting up people's noses. They love the big occasion and each seems to thrive on the adrenaline the other produces.

And as Cork hit the final runs off Walsh (a desperately unfair end for a man who had taken 6-74 and bowled like the God he is) the sun came out. Is summer really here? Now that England have won two Lord's Tests in as many months, anything is possible.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: How can Wisden deal with the match-fixers?

fields.headline: How can Wisden deal with the match-fixers?
fields.trailText: I am sure that there are many people like me of all nationalities who follow cricket avidly. We play and love the game; perhaps some of us are not too good at it, but a thirty, three wickets or a catch can make a memorable match.
fields.body:
I am sure that there are many people like me of all nationalities who follow cricket avidly. We play and love the game; perhaps some of us are not too good at it, but a thirty, three wickets or a catch can make a memorable match.

Some of us will be starting to play, or are in the middle of our playing careers, or are eking out our last few seasons permanently at second slip with a youngster next to us who will chase the balls we nearly stop. Some of us, like myself, will have dozens of Wisdens taking away space from other books on our shelves. They are not stored away in the attic because they are a constant source of reference, pleasure and memories.

Now we find that we have been cheated and insulted, and the game we love has been sullied. Fortunately the game will survive - it is too good to be brought down by the despicable actions of the likes of Salim Malik and Hansie Cronje. There is no excuse - they have betrayed all of us and the game we love. In the case of Cronje he has also disgraced his religion. He is continuing to lie for his own ends, as the others will. They deserve not only a prison sentence but our acrimony for the period of their natural lives and beyond. I cannot find any forgiveness for them.

One of our beloved game's biggest appeals is its ability to create interesting statistics - a fundamental raison d'etre for Wisden's wonderful Almanacks. None of us like the contrived situations - such as declaration bowling - which muddy the waters of these fascinating figures and comparisons, but Wisden does the best it can to register and footnote the contrived circumstances. However the current circumstances are far-reaching in this regard and the full truth will probably never be known. I do not believe we can eliminate suspected "fixed" matches from Test and ODI records. It would also be unfair on the competing players who had no knowledge of the activities of these odious people.

Perhaps Wisden will consider extracting proven or implicated persons (I cannot use the word cricketer or even player - they have forfeited the right to be referred to as such) from any lists in which they appear and re-inserting their names in a section at the foot with a relevant comment such as "found guilty of match-fixing and accepting bribes" or "fined $XXX for withholding testimony re: match-fixing" - an appropriate and lasting testament to their evil. This is easily done in the cases of Malik and Cronje, but there are borderline situations such as Shane Warne and Mark Waugh who should perhaps be included in a new section of the Almanack called Cricket's Hall of Shame.

On a positive note, there are some people who emerge very well - both the Pakistani judge and Rashid Latif immediately spring to mind - people who have risked much for their moral convictions. Perhaps in the next Wisden a Personality of the Year could be selected; rewarding the person who has contributed most to the well-being of cricket. To be fair this could also be matched with another regular Historical Personality, enabling Wisden over time to give due recognition to those characters that have served the game so well, but in a different capacity to those who enrich the game with their cricketing feats and qualify as the Five Cricketers of the Year.

As a final note, forget any political correctness about wholesomeness of forgiveness. For this kind of calculated evil you need a necklace of garlic, a cross, a very sharp stake and the sun shining on the village green. Drastic measures are needed to stop the spread of this disease.

Bill Gregory, 55, was born in Yorkshire. He is currently living in Sydney, where he works for a software company that covers Australasia and South East Asia.

fields.headline: No 10 savages Eurosceptic press
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair gave unambiguously enthusiastic backing to the European Union yesterday while Labour accused newspapers of "distortion and misrepresentation" over Europe.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Tübingen, Germany, and  Michael White
fields.body:
Tony Blair gave unambiguously enthusiastic backing to the European Union yesterday while Labour accused newspapers of "distortion and misrepresentation" over Europe.

As he announced a landmark speech in the autumn in which he will set his own vision of the continent's future alongside that of the leaders of France and Germany, the prime minister called the EU "the most obvious manifestation around us of the need for nations to cooperate together". He said: "Europe is not a conspiracy against Britain. Europe is an opportunity for Britain."

His words were the latest of several hints during a two-day visit to Germany that the government is ready to take a more proactive stance on the euro and Europe in general.

In a significant indication that Downing Street may finally be prepared to take on the Eurosceptic media it posted a highly critical memo on the No 10 website. In it Mr Blair's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, took the rare step of lambasting yesterday's coverage of the Potsdam session.

Attacking named newspapers, including the Sun and Daily Mail, for "distortion and misrepresentation", he said most coverage had been a joke. The Times, the Independent and the Daily Telegraph were also singled out.

"More serious, he believes, is the way that the press bias and misrepresentation sets the agenda for broadcasters who endlessly repeat the cliches of isolation, division and international conflict," said Mr Campbell in an official statement. That amounted to a warning shot at the BBC.

William Hague accused the prime minister of cowardice and ducking key European policy issues in Germany, but pro-European Labour MPs declared that the prime minister's rhetoric - and actions - are starting to move their way.

On Thursday, Mr Blair shrugged off President Jacques Chirac's proposal earlier this week for a "pioneer group" of nations within the EU. Yesterday, his spokesman said he was equally unruffled by Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's earlier demands for the EU to hold a lengthy round of inter-governmental talks to talk what his officials called "the big issues".

Britain's only concern was if the proposed talks stalled the enlargement of the union, officials said.

Mr Schröder's plan was for an inter-governmental conference (IGC) to start in 2004 or thereabouts, as soon as the latest reform process is completed. Issues on the agenda would include how to carve up power between the regions, the states and the various institutions of the EU.

British officials have chosen to see Mr Schröder's initiative as a response to specifically German concerns that relate to the powers of its regional administrations. That is so, but the chancellor's proposals went much further and were clearly designed to dovetail with the even more ambitious scheme set out by his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer.

In a speech last month, Mr Fischer called for the EU to commit itself to an eventual federation of nation states.

Mr Blair said yesterday: "I will be setting out the British view as to Europe's future in a speech in the autumn. I have no doubt that it is important for Great Britain to be a full and leading partner in Europe."

International cooperation and interdependence were the key themes of the prime minister's speech yesterday at Tübingen in south-west Germany. He depicted them as the projection on to the global plain of his frequently stated belief in the need for an idea of community in which rights are balanced with duties. Indeed, his address, which he wrote himself, was entitled Values and the power of community.

"None of the big issues facing us all - trade, finance, the environment, nuclear proliferation, organised crime and drugs - can be tackled today by nations acting alone," Mr Blair asserted. "The history of the last 100 years and more shows the vital importance of renewing the institutions of international cooperation and of building alliances between the main players."

"We will only succeed if we start to develop a doctrine international community based on the principal of enlightened self interest. As within countries, so between countries."

It was a speech that provided him with the intellectual underpinnings to a new argument as to why Britain should be more closely involved in the EU. Because of globalisation, he appeared to say, there was no alternative to collaboration.

webTitle: Media's coverage is a joke, says Blair

fields.headline: Media's coverage is a joke, says Blair
fields.standfirst:
Statement from the prime minister's official spokesman posted on No 10 website yesterday

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Statement from the prime minister's official spokesman posted on No 10 website yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday the prime minister urged the British media to "grow up" on the subject of Europe. Today's press suggests it will take some time before this happens. Given the scale of the distortion and misrepresentation on the subject, on an almost daily basis, people may be interested to know that today for example:

When the Telegraph front page lead says "Blair comes off fence to back euro", the prime minister repeated the well-known policy yesterday - that we support the principle of joining a single currency.

When the Sun says "Blair flies to Berlin for crisis talks" the prime minister flew to Berlin for a long-arranged dinner with Chancellor Schröder, because the prime minister was in Germany to make a speech today, as the media has known for some time.

When the Independent says "Blair urges Germans to spurn Chirac's EU policy", the prime minister urged no such thing. He said, privately and publicly, that he was totally relaxed about the contents of President Chirac's speech.

When the Daily Mail says: "In his speech in Tübingen this morning, Mr Blair will hammer home the message that Britain opposes a two-tier Europe", the press has been told ever since this event was announced that this would not be a speech about Europe.

When the Sun says that "British government yesterday insisted Britain will scrap the pound - in a two- fingered salute to Gordon Brown", the foreign secretary again restated the policy laid out by the chancellor in 1997.

When the Times reports a "last push for early euro poll" and suggests the foreign secretary is urging on the prime minister a faster timetable than the chancellor, that is not true. No such view has been communicated to the prime minister.

When the Express says that the prime minister and the foreign secretary "gave a remarkable tutorial" to the cabinet, this is called ministers discussing important policies.

The media is constantly calling for a real debate on Europe. The prime minister believes that the way the media covers Europe makes a real, sensible and mature debate very difficult. The politicians want a real debate. Many in the media do not.

As a high profile public figure in the 24 hour media age, the prime minister is used to distortion and misrepresentation by the media but on Europe, he believes much of the media's coverage to be a joke. More serious, he believes, is the way that the press bias and misrepresentation sets the agenda for broadcasters who endlessly repeat the cliches of isolation, division and international conflict.

 Number-10.gov.uk

webTitle: Still stuck in the world of Jim Hacker

fields.headline: Still stuck in the world of Jim Hacker
fields.standfirst:
French and Germans consider serious issues as the British worry about their sausages
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The debate: French and Germans consider serious issues as the British worry about their sausages
fields.byline: Jon Henley  in Paris and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
It will be business as usual today at one French factory in Pessac, near Bordeaux. The national mint will be striking coins, but they will not be francs. The last franc was produced in May. The demise of the currency - which was born the day Jean Le Bon was ransomed from his English captors in 1360 for three million gold crowns and declared "franc des Anglais", or free of the English - has barely been remarked upon in France: not a single headline, not a single outraged column.

Here, the euro appears to have been universally accepted, if not embraced. Shops, restaurants and cafes print their prices in francs and euros. Shoppers can pay with a euro chequebook from a euro bank account.

But where the French, and for that matter the Germans, have taken a pragmatic approach to their currencies, most in Britain seem horrified at the mere prospect of the Queen's head being removed from their banknotes.

Tony Blair may privately accept that Britain will weaken itself politically and economically if it remains outside the single currency. But in public, overwhelming hostility to the euro means the prime minister will say only that he plans a referendum after the next election if a series of economic tests have been met.

As France takes up the six-month rotating presidency of the EU today, two very different popular interpretations of the European project will clash once more. On one side of the Channel, mistrust and a visceral rejection of all that Brussels represents; on the other, a population revealed by a new survey this week to be generally enthusiastic about Europe (59%), and overwhelmingly in favour of further and faster integration (70%).

Yet even as that poll was being published in Paris, a family butcher in the Essex town of Leigh-on-Sea was setting out to become the latest martyr of the Eurosceptic cause, being jailed for resisting new European regulations on metrication. David Stephens, whose Mandy's Chop Shop is decked out with union flags, is leading an "imperial revolution" of Great Britain. "Napoleon said England is a nation of shopkeepers - well the shopkeepers are revolting," warned the butcher, who continues to sell his meat in pounds and ounces in defiance of EU regulations.

His lone campaign highlights a deep distrust of the role Brussels plays in the lives of British people. Regulations that cause barely a ripple in continental Europe lead to endless scare stories as anti-Europeans follow the example of Jim Hacker, who rose to the top job in Yes, Prime Minister after fighting to prevent Brussels renaming the British sausage the emulsified high-fat offal tube.

Much of the damage is done by the press. Mr Blair, who says he wants to work at the heart of Europe and who has engaged more positively with his continental partners than any other recent British prime minister, issued a plea on Thursday night for the media to stop seeing the EU as a "conspiracy against Britain".

A speech to the Reichstag earlier this week by the French president, Jacques Chirac, in which he floated the idea of a "pioneering group" of EU nations, led to predictable howls of protest. "Blair isolated as Berlin and Paris press for EU fast track," the Daily Mail screamed - although the proposals would, in reality, quite possibly create a club Britain could join.

In France, Mr Chirac's speech was carefully analysed and variously declared "important", "a positive contribution to a vital debate", and "a much-needed breadth of vision from a traditional pillar of European construction". Even if it quite seriously embarrassed the more cautious Socialist-led government of Lionel Jospin, the point was that Europe deserved, and needed, big ideas.

This is despite reservations about Europe expressed on either side of the political divide in Franc. Wary of too many "big ideas", Mr Jospin's government wants to use the presidency to make progress on some concrete, practical issues designed to appeal to the average citizen.

"It's true France used to be Europe's idealist, but in many ways it's now much more pragmatic - it wants practical and positive advantages, things that will make Europe work, things the people will appreciate," said Pascal Boniface, the director of the Institute for International and Strategic Relations, a Paris thinktank.

So France will be putting greater welfare protection and social justice high up on the agenda, as well as food safety, doping in sport, a more effective European immigration policy in the wake of the Dover tragedy last week, in which 58 illegal Chinese immigrants died, and stricter controls on shipping in European waters after the sinking of the oil tanker Erika off the Brittany coast.

Many of those issues, the French public indicated in this week's survey, are ones they feel European institutions may be able to deal with more effectively than national governments. With its fears fanned by scare stories splashed all over the press, the British public may never even contemplate that possibility.

British scare stories about Europe tend to have two themes: our isolation in the face of hostile Europeans, or our triumphs over hostile Europeans. Hence the reporting of the prime minister's management of the recent EU summit in Portugal.

It was, the British were told, a triumph for Mr Blair. "Britain has defeated demands by Brussels for a European savings tax," the Mail reported after Gordon Brown hammered out a compromise with his European partners on the withholding tax. In fact, for the French the hard-won compromise was the result not of the British prime minister's negotiating skills, but of Austrian blackmail in an attempt to return to the European fold.

As it enters this presidency, the French government knows it will have popular support for almost any fast-track measure it pursues. It is actually more interested in not rocking the boat and in completing the intergovernmental conference on schedule. There is little on that agenda to cause serious friction with Britain. Yet the British press and public opinion, through a combination of what Mr Boniface calls "ignorance and misrepresentation", will want to see the next six months as a battle.

They are not the first to think that way. "When was the last time we got our way with France?" Jim Hacker once asked his cabinet secretary, Sir Humphrey Appleby. "Battle of Waterloo, 1815," came the reply.

But in public, overwhelming hostility to the euro means the prime minister will say only that he plans a referendum after the next election if a series of economic tests have been met. As France takes up the six-month rotating presidency of the EU today, two very different popular interpretations of the European project will clash once more. On one side of the Channel, mistrust and a visceral rejection of all that Brussels represents; on the other, a population revealed by a new survey this week to be generally enthusiastic about Europe (59%), and overwhelmingly in favour of further and faster integration (70%). Yet even as that poll was being published in Paris, a family butcher in the Essex town of Leigh-on-Sea was setting out to become the latest martyr of the Eurosceptic cause, being jailed for resisting new European regulations on metrication. David Stephens, whose Mandy's Chop Shop is decked out with union flags, is leading an "imperial revolution" of Great Britain. "Napoleon said England is a nation of shopkeepers - well the shopkeepers are revolting," warned the butcher, who continues to sell his meat in pounds and ounces in defiance of EU regulations. His lone campaign highlights a deep distrust of the role Brussels plays in the lives of British people. Regulations that cause barely a ripple in continental Europe lead to endless scare stories as anti-Europeans follow the example of Jim Hacker, who rose to the top job in Yes, Prime Minister after fighting to prevent Brussels renaming the British sausage the emulsified high-fat offal tube. Much of the damage is done by the press. Mr Blair, who says he wants to work at the heart of Europe and who has engaged more positively with his continental partners than any other recent British prime minister, issued a plea on Thursday night for the media to stop seeing the EU as a "conspiracy against Britain". A speech to the Reichstag earlier this week by the French president, Jacques Chirac, in which he floated the idea of a "pioneering group" of EU nations, led to predictable howls of protest. "Blair isolated as Berlin and Paris press for EU fast track," the Daily Mail screamed - although the proposals would, in reality, quite possibly create a club Britain could join. In France, Mr Chirac's speech was carefully analysed and variously declared "important", "a positive contribution to a vital debate", and "a much-needed breadth of vision from a traditional pillar of European construction". Even if it quite seriously embarrassed the more cautious Socialist-led government of Lionel Jospin, the point was that Europe deserved, and needed, big ideas. This is despite reservations about Europe expressed on either side of the political divide in Franc. Wary of too many "big ideas", Mr Jospin's government wants to use the presidency to make progress on some concrete, practical issues designed to appeal to the average citizen. "It's true France used to be Europe's idealist, but in many ways it's now much more pragmatic - it wants practical and positive advantages, things that will make Europe work, things the people will appreciate," said Pascal Boniface, the director of the Institute for International and Strategic Relations, a Paris thinktank. So France will be putting greater welfare protection and social justice high up on the agenda, as well as food safety, doping in sport, a more effective European immigration policy in the wake of the Dover tragedy last week, in which 58 illegal Chinese immigrants died, and stricter controls on shipping in European waters after the sinking of the oil tanker Erika off the Brittany coast. Many of those issues, the French public indicated in this week's survey, are ones they feel European institutions may be able to deal with more effectively than national governments. With its fears fanned by scare stories splashed all over the press, the British public may never even contemplate that possibility. British scare stories about Europe tend to have two themes: our isolation in the face of hostile Europeans, or our triumphs over hostile Europeans. Hence the reporting of the prime minister's management of the recent EU summit in Portugal. It was, the British were told, a triumph for Mr Blair. "Britain has defeated demands by Brussels for a European savings tax," the Mail reported after Gordon Brown hammered out a compromise with his European partners on the withholding tax. In fact, for the French the hard-won compromise was the result not of the British prime minister's negotiating skills, but of Austrian blackmail in an attempt to return to the European fold. As it enters this presidency, the French government knows it will have popular support for almost any fast-track measure it pursues. It is actually more interested in not rocking the boat and in completing the intergovernmental conference on schedule. There is little on that agenda to cause serious friction with Britain. Yet the British press and public opinion, through a combination of what Mr Boniface calls "ignorance and misrepresentation", will want to see the next six months as a battle. They are not the first to think that way. "When was the last time we got our way with France?" Jim Hacker once asked his cabinet secretary, Sir Humphrey Appleby. "Battle of Waterloo, 1815," came the reply.

webTitle: Ian Black on the French presidency's agenda

fields.headline: It's a tough job but France has to do it
fields.standfirst:
An overhaul of the European machinery is well overdue
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: France faces a hard grind and little glory when it assumes the presidency of the EU today at a time of deepening controversy surrounding the character and direction of the entire European project.
fields.body:
France faces a hard grind and little glory when it assumes the presidency of the EU today at a time of deepening controversy surrounding the character and direction of the entire European project.

The main task facing the French is vital but not glamourous: to push through the reforms needed to ensure that creaking decision-making machinery will work when new members from the emerging democracies of eastern Europe join in coming years.

Between now and the Nice summit in December, French ministers must persuade, cajole and bargain with their EU partners on a narrow but extremely difficult agenda.

The key items contrast starkly with the ambitious vision of a Europe led by a bold Franco-German "pioneer group" sketched out by President Jacques Chirac in Berlin on Tuesday.

True, the new treaty that enshrines the latest changes will not match the scope of the Maastricht agreement of 1992, which launched the single currency project. But without success in Nice, paralysis will surely set in.

French officials know this is not a moment for grandstanding: there is already embarrassment in Paris at the glaring difference between their Gaullist president - keen to ally with Germany - and his centre-left prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

"If the 15 [member states] do not meet this challenge, all the other speculations, proposals, reflections and orientations will not have a leg to stand on," the foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, warned.

At stake is the inter-governmental conference (IGC), a rolling negotiation on issues left over from the 1997 Amsterdam treaty because they were just too tricky. Portugal made virtually no progress during its presidency, which ended last night.

The basic problem is as simple as the details are complex: institutions created for the EEC in 1957 are close to breakdown. And with 12 countries lining up to join from 2003, the machinery must be modernised.

Even though the enlargement timetable is slipping and enthusiasm waning, the need is urgent. Treaties require time-consuming ratification by national parliaments while anxious Poles, Hungarians and Cypriots need reassuring that existing member states are serious.

France's insistence that enlargement is as high a priority as the IGC reforms underlines the way in which the two issues are intertwined.

The weight of each member's vote needs to be readjusted: Germany has no more votes now than before reunification. Are 80m Germans "equal" only to 57-60m Britons, Frenchmen or Italians?

Larger states want to redress a balance which favours smaller ones, fearing that in an expanded union they could be blocked by the tiddlers. Spain wants more votes. Experts say this is a mathematical problem, but it is highly sensitive politically.

Most states accept the need to reduce the use of the national veto and increase majority voting to avoid deadlock in an EU with up to 27 members. Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, calls the veto a ball and chain.

At the recent summit in Portugal, Austria was able to hold up agreements on a withholding tax on savings. Britain insists on retaining the veto for tax, defence, social security, treaty changes and border controls. Minor changes are likely.

As regards the 20-strong European commission, it is a supranational body. But having a national bum on a seat is a right that no member state is prepared to forego. Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Spain are ready to give up one of their current two jobs. Future commissioners from Cyprus and Estonia are likely to find themselves in the de facto role of junior or deputy commissioners.

There is a plan to let some states integrate faster than others, so-called reinforced cooperation. In the British political debate this is about a "two-speed" Europe, with Britain in the slow lane.

London's greatest but largely unspoken fear is that if closer cooperation is made easier, the 11 euro zone countries may move to formalise their role and harmonise taxation and budgetary policies, making a British decision on the single currency even tougher than it is. Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, who is worried by the weakness of the euro in the global currency markets, is a key figure here.

Diplomats predict that the outcome at Nice will be just enough for the French to be able to claim success. "It has to work," says one veteran Brussels negotiator. "Failure is unthinkable. And it's better to have a bad treaty than no treaty at all."

Other big issues seem likely to be put off. Divisive plans for an EU charter of fundamental rights may be boiled down to a declaration, with a promise to take it up again in future, probably in the new IGC that Germany is already demanding.

The same is true of plans to look at the hot potato that is a future EU constitution.

France is certain to mount a big push on defence, where Mr Chirac has forged a powerful alliance with Mr Blair. Progress has already been made on institutional mechanisms, although the US and Turkey are nervous about Nato's interests.

Neutrals such as Ireland and Finland are worried about their role in plans to field an EU rapid reaction force with 60,000 soldiers. A November conference on troop numbers will be a key fixture of the French presidency, as will a Balkan summit and initiatives to reinforce links with the Mediterranean.

The hot seat presidential points

 European Union presidencies last for six months, from January to June or July to December, and rotate between the 15 member states

 Portugal was last at the helm. Sweden and Belgium respectively are next in line

 France will chair nearly 200 meetings including an informal summit in Biarritz in October and one at Nice in December.

President Chirac will also preside over a meeting of Balkan leaders

 Lenotre, France's biggest delicatessen chain, has been commissioned to provide gourmet catering at both summits. Nice will include a grand fireworks display over the bay

 Presidencies manage the business of the European council. They convene meetings, set the agenda, draft compromises and call votes. They represent the council and member states in dealings with third countries

 Large states such as France try to have defined ambitions for their presidencies. Smaller ones make do with being "good presidents"

 France has designed its own cubist- inspired logo in the form of a red, white and blue face combining the colours of the national flag with the 12 golden stars of Europe. It says the image represents "a homo Europeus" as well as "dialogue and France's resolutely European outlook"

webTitle: Divided village damps hope for Cyprus unity

fields.headline: Divided village damps hope for Cyprus unity
fields.trailText: Ahmet Sakali hoots with laughter when he is reminded that some people see his village as an example of how Greeks and Turks can live together in Cyprus.
fields.body:
Ahmet Sakali hoots with laughter when he is reminded that some people see his village as an example of how Greeks and Turks can live together in Cyprus.

"We have so many problems here," he said, "we can't agree on anything. If this was a model for the future of Cyprus the whole island would be a disaster."

Mr Sakali, the Turkish mukhtar - a locally elected official - is sitting in his office in the only genuinely shared village on the island. The Greeks call it Pyla, the Turks insist on Pile, and the United Nations tries to make sense of it all.

The village is in the UN buffer zone which has divided the Turkish- and Greek-controlled sectors of the island for more than a quarter of a century. The UN has a small air-conditioned office in the corner of the village square, where Australian and Irish policemen do their best to liaise with both communities.

Even here, however, Greeks and Turks rarely mix. There are activities organised by bi-communal enthusiasts, but day-to-day life goes on in different worlds. They shop at their own shops, teach at their own schools, and mind their own business. The Greeks never visit the Turkish coffee house, and the Turks don't go to the Greek restaurant a few yards across the square.

"We sit over here, and they sit over there", Mr Sakali said. "We've got used to living separate lives. Maybe it's sad, but this is the best way."

Many Turks in their breakaway northern state share that belief. They argue that the Cyprus problem was solved in 1974, when the mainland Turkish army intervened to help its Cypriot brethren. It occupied the northern third of Cyprus, and its been there ever since.

"There is no going back as if nothing has happened," said Tahsin Ertugruloglu, the foreign minister in a Turkish Cypriot government which is recognised only by Turkey. "Why does anyone expect us to give up what we have for something that is not better."

That is the central problem the UN faces as it prepares to host another round of proximity talks in Geneva next week.

The Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders will both talk to the UN, but they will not meet face-to-face.

The Greek Cypriots still claim the whole island, and describe the hated Turkish military as an army of occupation.

The Turks, meanwhile, demand some form of recognition of their de facto independence, which the rest of the world refuses to accept.

So northern Cyprus continues to forge its own path. Economic embargoes mean it is far less wealthy than the Greek Cypriot south, and desperately dependent on massive financial aid from the Turkish mainland. But it is at peace, and for many people that is the most important thing.

Metin Sahinoglu sees a vivid reminder of past conflict every day. He runs the Palm Beach Hotel on the island's eastern coast, overlooking a ghost town of barbed wire and abandoned buildings.

"People talk about the Cyprus conflict as if there is a war going on," he said. "But no one is being killed any more, no villages are being destroyed on either side. Let's not forget that."

After more than a quarter of a century, it is sometimes difficult to see change coming to Cyprus. The Turks argue that a loose confederation of two states which run most of their own affairs is the answer, but they have not been able to convince anyone else.

In fact, critics of the veteran Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, wonder whether he is really ready for a deal at all. He already has most of what he wants, and for some of his compatriots he is far too close to mainland Turkey for comfort.

"Mr Denktash doesn't care about Turkish Cypriots," said opposition politician Mehmet Ali Talat, who is an outspoken critic. "He is more keen on defending the rights and interests of Turkey."

The trouble is that everyone in Cyprus has become entrenched in their own positions. Mr Denktas and his Greek Cypriot sparring partner Glafkos Clerides have known each other for decades. They can repeat each other's arguments word for word.

Stalemate, however, may no longer be an option. The Greek Cypriot government is a candidate for membership of the European Union, and it could complete the process of membership negotiations as early as next year.

If the UN-sponsored talks get nowhere, and Greeks and Turks continue to live on opposite sides of the barbed wire, the EU will have to decide whether to admit a divided country.

That, in turn, would push the Turkish Cypriots into closer integration with the Turkish mainland and cement the division of the island.

"The EU dimension means this issue will have to be solved one way or another," said Mustafa Akinci, the Turkish Cypriots' deputy prime minister. "I hope we can all be flexible. The clock is ticking."

webTitle: Fatal crush at rock festival in Denmark

fields.headline: Fatal crush at rock festival in Denmark
fields.trailText: At least one person died and 20 people were injured late last night at one of Europe's largest rock festivals, police said
fields.body:
At least one person died and 20 people were injured late last night at one of Europe's largest rock festivals, police said.

The Norwegian news agency NTB, which had a reporter at the Roskilde festival, said there were four dead and 20 injured. But police, who said they were swamped with calls from worried parents, could only confirm one dead and 20 injured.

Details were still sketchy early this morning but the casualties occurred while American rockers Pearl Jam were playing on the festival's main Orange stage. According to early unconfirmed reports, spectators near the stage were injured when they were pressed by those behind.

The Roskilde festival, first held in 1971, was inspired by the 1969 Woodstock festival in the US. It is held annually on a farm 25 miles west of Copenhagen.

fields.headline: UN officer killed in ambush
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: A unit of UN peacekeepers from Jordan was ambushed yesterday in Sierra Leone and a soldier was killed, UN officials said.
fields.body:
A unit of UN peacekeepers from Jordan was ambushed yesterday in Sierra Leone and a soldier was killed, UN officials said.

The peacekeepers were on their way from the western town of Masiaka to join a UN convoy at nearby Mile 91 when they were attacked with guns and a rocket-propelled grenade, UN force commander Major-General Vijay Kumar Jetley said.

It was not immediately clear who had launched the attack, about 80 miles from the capital, Freetown. The peacekeepers returned fire. One Jordanian was killed and four injured, Gen Jetley said.

UN peacekeepers from Nigeria were moving yesterday to reinforce Mile 91, where about 50,000 people have gathered after fleeing rebel attacks on surrounding villages, said a UN spokesman, Manoel de Almeida de Silva, in New York.

The attack came as 21 Indian UN troops returned to Freetown after being held for weeks at an eastern base of the Revolutionary United Front.

webTitle: Guatemala executes kidnappers on breakfast TV

fields.headline: Guatemala executes kidnappers on breakfast TV
fields.trailText: Two convicted kidnappers were put to death by lethal injection in an execution shown live on Guatemalan television.
fields.body:
Two convicted kidnappers were put to death by lethal injection in an execution shown live on Guatemalan television.

Viewers making breakfast watched on Thursday as Amilcar Cetino Perez, 35, said his last words, which appeared to be a prayer.

Cetino and Tomas Cerrate Hernandez, 39, were sentenced to death for their part in the kidnapping in January 1997 of Bonifassi de Botran, 80, an heir to the Botran liquor distillery fortune, who was found dead after her family paid the ransom. The two men died proclaiming their innocence.

"It's not the kind of thing you want to watch, but you can't stop yourself," said Nerry Rinales, who saw the execution with three employees while opening his car repair shop in Quatemala City. Every channel focused on the executions.

Cetino was strapped down and at 6.05am drugs flowed into his arm from a wall-mounted bag. Over 11 minutes, as he died, the programme showed the line of a heart monitor start to flatten, then it cut back to Cetino's hand as it quivered, then lay still.

"You start to feel sorry for a guy like that when he's lying there and he's dying," said Ana Pinada, who watched both executions as she made breakfast. "But then you think about what he did and you think, 'I'm glad this is happening to him."

The executions, which were rebroadcast continually for hours, caused such a stir here that the Guatemala City newspaper Nuestro Diario said it will publish 220,000 copies - a Guatemalan record.

But the grim show was not for everyone."I turned off the television when I saw what was going on," said Sara de Leon, 49, who did not want her children to watch. "What kind of message can a child learn from that?"

The executions took place after weeks of often wild speculation about possible jailbreaks allegedly planned by the kidnap gang to rescue their condemned associates.

"Everything here has been extremely quiet," said Luis Rivas, a spokesman for the Guatemala City fire department, outside the Pavon rehabilitation work farm, 20 miles south-east of Guatemala City, where the executions took place. "There was no reason for us all to be so nervous."

The gang is also believed to have issued death threats against the family of President Alfonso Portillo, prompting Mr Portillo to send his mother, sister, brother-in-law and two nephews to Canada. Members of the dead woman's family also left Guatemala for the United States this week.

The second execution began at 7.15am. Cerrate was shown being led, shaking, to the death chamber and prison doctors said he had had "a complete nervous breakdown".

The men were the second and third Guatemalans to be executed by lethal injection. The 52 other Guatemalan executions in the last 100 years were by firing squad, the last of which was televised live in September 1996.

Viewers making breakfast watched on Thursday as Amilcar Cetino Perez, 35, said his last words, which appeared to be a prayer. Cetino and Tomas Cerrate Hernandez, 39, were sentenced to death for their part in the kidnapping in January 1997 of Bonifassi de Botran, 80, an heir to the Botran liquor distillery fortune, who was found dead after her family paid the ransom. The two men died proclaiming their innocence. "It's not the kind of thing you want to watch, but you can't stop yourself," said Nerry Rinales, who saw the execution with three employees while opening his car repair shop in Quatemala City. Every channel focused on the executions. Cetino was strapped down and at 6.05am drugs flowed into his arm from a wall-mounted bag. Over 11 minutes, as he died, the programme showed the line of a heart monitor start to flatten, then it cut back to Cetino's hand as it quivered, then lay still. "You start to feel sorry for a guy like that when he's lying there and he's dying," said Ana Pinada, who watched both executions as she made breakfast. "But then you think about what he did and you think, 'I'm glad this is happening to him." The executions, which were rebroadcast continually for hours, caused such a stir here that the Guatemala City newspaper Nuestro Diario said it will publish 220,000 copies - a Guatemalan record. But the grim show was not for everyone."I turned off the television when I saw what was going on," said Sara de Leon, 49, who did not want her children to watch. "What kind of message can a child learn from that?" The executions took place after weeks of often wild speculation about possible jailbreaks allegedly planned by the kidnap gang to rescue their condemned associates. "Everything here has been extremely quiet," said Luis Rivas, a spokesman for the Guatemala City fire department, outside the Pavon rehabilitation work farm, 20 miles south-east of Guatemala City, where the executions took place. "There was no reason for us all to be so nervous." The gang is also believed to have issued death threats against the family of President Alfonso Portillo, prompting Mr Portillo to send his mother, sister, brother-in-law and two nephews to Canada. Members of the dead woman's family also left Guatemala for the United States this week. The second execution began at 7.15am. Cerrate was shown being led, shaking, to the death chamber and prison doctors said he had had "a complete nervous breakdown". The men were the second and third Guatemalans to be executed by lethal injection. The 52 other Guatemalan executions in the last 100 years were by firing squad, the last of which was televised live in September 1996.

webTitle: Panorama editor gets top BBC post

fields.headline: Panorama editor gets top BBC post
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's embattled flagship documentary series, Panorama, was given the strongest possible vote of confidence last night when its editor was appointed head of the corporation's current affairs department.
fields.body:
The BBC's embattled flagship documentary series, Panorama, was given the strongest possible vote of confidence last night when its editor was appointed head of the corporation's current affairs department.

Peter Horrocks, a former editor of Newsnight, beat off stiff competition from within and outside the BBC for the prestigious post. His appointment guarantees the series a strong voice at the highest levels of the BBC.

The appointment ends months of speculation, following the promotion of the previous head of current affairs, Helen Boaden, to the controller's post at Radio 4. Staff on Panorama were delighted.

The programme has come in for sustained criticism from some sections in the BBC, who believed it was not performing well. The BBC recently increased its budget by £300,000, and cut the length of the series to concentrate resources on a smaller number of programmes.

Greg Dyke, director general, has signalled his intention to transfer some of BBC1's more serious programmes - which some believe to include Panorama - onto BBC2.

Mr Horrocks said he was delighted at the appointment. BBC current affairs should now concentrate on "making an impact", with "original and aggressive journalism", he said.
