fields.headline: Wariness and weariness at Drumcree
fields.standfirst:
Orangemen, police, and 2,000 extra troops prepare for first of two parades

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orangemen, police, and 2,000 extra troops prepare for first of two parades
fields.body:
Like old prizefighters whose days of triumph are long gone, Orangemen and the RUC were circling each other warily yesterday, ready for the latest battle over the most contentious stretch of Tarmac in western Europe. Only this time, even Portadown is jaded at the prospect of annual farce, and it seemed unlikely Drumcree 6 would prove a blockbuster.

More than 2,000 extra troops have been drafted in to help the police as the Co Armagh town prepares for the first of two parades in consecutive weeks, and plans to seal off the hill around the Church of Ascension are there to be quickly implemented. But the police were yesterday taking it easy, and the landscape remains relatively unscarred.

One businessman sighed as he faced up to another yearly slump in trade. He said: "I wish the whole thing would just go away. Most people are sick of the whole thing. They should put the lot of them on a boat and push it out into the middle of the Atlantic."

Scant chance. Portadown Orangemen believe Tony Blair reneged on a tacit promise to allow them to march last autumn if they walked away from confrontation, as they did. So they intend to step up their two-year protest, with marches tomorrow and next Sunday.

No walking away

One Orangeman outside the Church of Ascension at Drumcree said: "I'll tell you what - there will be no walking away from the police lines this year. We were on a promise from Tony Blair last year that if it was peaceful we would get down at some point, but he sold us out. I know it's not a very nice thing to say about your own prime minister, but he lied to us."

Portadown lodge will march tomorrow in an apparent effort to stretch the security forces until the annual July 12 celebrations throughout Northern Ireland, when Orangemen celebrate the victory of King William III over the Catholic forces of James II at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690. They will march again to Drumcree tomorrow week, and the signs yesterday were that it will represent the more likely flashpoint.

But Portadown lodge likes to spring surprises. It astonished everyone last year when it disbursed, so no one is confident in predictions about what might happen.

One elderly woman stocking up with provisions yesterday said : "We're just all waiting and seeing. It's an awful predicament to be in. I just lock up the front door and stay inside for the whole time. But you don't know what will happen. You never do."

A handful of Orangemen, led by Harold Gracey, 65, has held a picket on Drumcree hill, just outside the town, where the Orange Order was founded, since July 1998, when the parades commission banned it from its traditional route, the infamous Garvaghy Road. It first paraded there in 1807.

Three decades ago the thoroughfare was a country lane. It became a concrete jungle of a 60s housing estate and, over the years as Portadown became ghettoised, it became an overwhelmingly nationalist one.

Five years ago residents decided they no longer wanted what they saw as Protestant triumphalism close to their front doors, although the Orangemen detect Sinn Fein's influence behind the scenes. They say no one much opposed the march until republican leaders seized on the issue to wallow for political advantage in its preferred condition of victimhood.

Nonsense, says councillor Breandan MacCionnaith, of the Garvaghy Road residents' coalition. He believes Catholics are increasingly confident of asserting their rights and refuse to be treated as second-class citizens any longer.

The worst violence came in 1996, when the RUC agreed to the banned parade going ahead as leading loyalist Billy Wright, since assassinated, threatened to drive a digger filled with drums of petrol at police lines, and set them alight. His then fledgling group, the Loyalist Volunteer Force, also murdered a Catholic taxi-driver, Michael McGoldrick, 31.

There was mayhem in 1998, with crowds of 25,000 gathering nightly in the first week after the Orangemen were stopped, and 30 police officers injured in bomb attacks, four seriously. Violence spread throughout Northern Ireland, as it had done two years earlier.

Just as up to 100,000 Orangemen were expected to converge on Drumcree after their own lodges' July 12 celebrations, three boys died in a petrol-bombing incident in Ballymoney, Co Antrim. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, within three or so hours of the Quinn children's murder, was on television linking the attack to the dispute at Drumcree, and a potentially lethal confrontation was lanced as protesters stayed away.

Although there had already been 137 petrol bomb attacks on Catholic homes that week, Orangemen denied any Drumcree link to the Quinn tragedy. They were largely exonerated when a subsequent trial indicated the attack was more to do with a personal vendetta, than that the boys' mother was Catholic.

Relaxed residents

The Orange Order may wish to mount a strong protest this year, but it appears unlikely it can pull out the support of two years ago. The Portadown lodge is in dispute with the ruling Grand Lodge of Ireland, which refused it even permission to talk to the Parades Commission, a move which could have paved the way for a limited march.

Sir Ronnie warned yesterday that dissident loyalists may become involved. The LVF was key, both in 1996 and 1998, but loyalist sources suggest it is unlikely to play such a major role this time. The Ulster Volunteer Force, which is at loggerheads in Portadown with the LVF, is also keen to prevent violence.

On the Garvaghy Road, residents appear more relaxed than ever. Mr MacCionnaith, a hate figure to the Portadown lodge because he was jailed 18 years ago over a bomb attack on the British Legion in the town, detects weariness among the Orangemen.

He said: "A week ago they put adverts in the press all over the north calling for a massive march. But only 500 turned up. If the same thing happens this time we might not need to see the massive security operations that we have in the past."

But Mr MacCionnaith believes in time a solution can be found. "How many people in the north in 1995 would have believed that in 2000 there would be a devolved government with David Trimble as first minister and Martin McGuinness as minister of education? People would have laughed, but all that was achieved through dialogue."

The Portadown lodge is in dispute with the ruling Grand Lodge of Ireland, which refused it even permission to talk to the Parades Commission, a move which could have paved the way for a limited march. Sir Ronnie warned yesterday that dissident loyalists may become involved. The LVF was key, both in 1996 and 1998, but loyalist sources suggest it is unlikely to play such a major role this time. The Ulster Volunteer Force, which is at loggerheads in Portadown with the LVF, is also keen to prevent violence. On the Garvaghy Road, residents appear more relaxed than ever. Mr MacCionnaith, a hate figure to the Portadown lodge because he was jailed 18 years ago over a bomb attack on the British Legion in the town, detects weariness among the Orangemen. He said: "A week ago they put adverts in the press all over the north calling for a massive march. But only 500 turned up. If the same thing happens this time we might not need to see the massive security operations that we have in the past." But Mr MacCionnaith believes in time a solution can be found. "How many people in the north in 1995 would have believed that in 2000 there would be a devolved government with David Trimble as first minister and Martin McGuinness as minister of education? People would have laughed, but all that was achieved through dialogue."

webTitle: Briton gets 13 years for smuggling £3m of heroin

fields.headline: Briton gets 13 years for smuggling £3m of heroin
fields.trailText: A British backpacker caught smuggling £3m worth of heroin into Australia was jailed for 13 years yesterday, Australian police said.
fields.body:
A British backpacker caught smuggling £3m worth of heroin into Australia was jailed for 13 years yesterday, Australian police said.

Paul Burchill, 22, from Leigh-on-Sea, Essex, had earlier pleaded guilty at Brisbane supreme court to importing and possessing heroin.

He was told that, with parole, he would have to serve six and a half years of the sentence.

The drugs, weighing 13.4kg (29.5lb) and hidden in the frames of paintings, were seized at Brisbane airport in January last year, after Burchill had flown in from Bangkok.

Stephen Jakobi, of Fair Trials Abroad, was contacted by representatives for Burchill to assist with the case but he declined. He said: "He could not explain why he was carrying all these paintings. It's the usual case of a courier who got caught."

fields.headline: Rogers heads for showdownover cities
fields.trailText: The fashionable architect who led a government inquiry into England's declining cities was last night heading for a confrontation with senior ministers after bitterly accusing Whitehall of stifling his key recommendations.
fields.body:
The fashionable architect who led a government inquiry into England's declining cities was last night heading for a confrontation with senior ministers after bitterly accusing Whitehall of stifling his key recommendations.

Lord Rogers of Riverside, once applauded by Downing Street for adding style to Tony Blair's vision of a new Britain, raised ministerial hackles by describing some English cities as the "worst in Europe" - and calling for a multi-billion pound spending boost to halt further decay.

The patience of the Labour peer, who chaired an urban task force which made a string of recommendations a year ago, finally snapped when he was told this week that the Treasury was preparing to reject his proposals for a US-style package of tax incentives to revive cities.

One senior minister dismissed his onslaught as "unfair", others were said to be fuming, and John Prescott's Department of the Environment hit back with a claim - contested by other members of the 13-strong taskforce - that many of Lord Rogers's proposals were being implemented.

Next week the government's urban policy will face a further hammering from the Commons environment committee in a hard-hitting report. The Guardian has learned that it will accuse the Treasury of kicking Lord Rogers's recommendations "into the long grass".

Following a lengthy inquiry into the state of cities, one committee source said last night: "There is absolutely no evidence from the witnesses we questioned - civil servants, ministers from all departments - that there is any direction or corporate planning in Whitehall to push the taskforce report forward. There is deep dismay about the attitude of the Treasury."

With English cities outside London towards the bottom of the European wealth league, Lord Rogers's report called for a national crusade to improve the quality of life, create more jobs - inner-city unemployment is twice the national average - and recycle an estimated 1.3m urban buildings (houses, warehouses, factories) lying empty.

Crucially, ministers were urged to provide a range of low-tax incentives for developers and local councils in special urban priority areas to encourage regeneration - and it appears that Mr Prescott has now lost that battle with the Treasury. The deputy prime minister and the architect are due to meet shortly.

In an unexpected, shorter and punchier report recently, Lord Rogers made clear the government had to move "faster and further". More controversially, he urged ministers to divert funds from rich parts of England to poorer cities in order to relieve "stressed out" urban areas. The report warned: "There is no ducking this highly contentious issue."

Yesterday, interviewed by the BBC, Lord Rogers said there had been too little effort across Whitehall to put his recommendations into practice.

He added: "We would have liked to have had more funding. I have to say that whereas John Prescott, I think, is doing his best, there is no real realisation of the problems across [Whitehall] departments. We are calling on the prime minister to say it is cross-departmental. It is no good putting money into education and hospitals if you can't get to the area and everybody wants to leave."

He further raised the temperature of the debate by indicating that time was running out for some cities. "We do live in some of the worst cities in Europe and unfortunately we really are at the bottom of the ladder even though we are very wealthy," he added.

Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, defended the government's record, saying that Lord Rogers's report required coordinated action by several departments. "I think Lord Rogers is being a little bit unfair because some of the recommendations have been implemented," he added.

In fact, new planning guidelines recently issued by Mr Raynsford have been widely welcomed as a move towards encouraging city rebuilding. These tell developers to exam ine recycled, or "brownfield" land, before considering "greenfield" building.

But the House Builders' Federation, representing the big builders, defended Lord Rogers last night. "Many 'brownfield' sites are expensive to buy and even more expensive to clean up," it said. "The government must understand that public subsidy is the only way of making these sites viable."

webTitle: Manager in the frame as book trade hits crisis

fields.headline: Manager in the frame as book trade hits crisis
fields.standfirst:
All eyes are on appeal by sacked Waterstone's veteran as concern over spread of 'bestsellers only' attitude comes to a head
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Quality booksellers and publishers all over Britain are waiting, with foreboding, for the outcome of an appeal by a shop manager who has been sacked by Waterstone's for stocking too many good books.
fields.body:
Quality booksellers and publishers all over Britain are waiting, with foreboding, for the outcome of an appeal by a shop manager who has been sacked by Waterstone's for stocking too many good books.

Robert Topping is the man who said: "Any bookshop can sell the fourth Harry Potter. It's the bookshop which sells the first Harry Potter which matters."

Now - with marketing displays for the fourth Harry Potter to bloom in his old store next Saturday and less glamorous titles cleared from the shelves - one of the most admired booksellers in the trade is struggling to get his job back.

This week Mr Topping, manager of Waterstone's in Manchester for 16 years, tabled an internal appeal against his dismissal. His offence is to refuse to obey a head office order to reduce drastically the number of books in his shop and to put a high focus on bestsellers.

Nationally, he is one of five Waterstone's managers who are defying this edict and one of 20 who are under most pressure to conform to it, according to the trade magazine The Bookseller. Yesterday the magazine said it had received more than 300 reactions to the sacking. Most of them were critical.

The cash-strapped chain, the largest in the country, has been deluged with complaints from publishers, including Manchester and Yale university presses. Publishers, in turn, are being deluged with books returned by Waterstone's under the new policy.

The novelist Will Self warned this policy would lead to "cultural impoverishment" and to "wall to wall pulp".

Normally less outspoken publishers have set aside professional reticence to defend Mr Topping. "Generally the feeling in the literary world and in the city is that it is an outrageous thing to happen," Vanessa Graham, editorial director of Manchester University Press, said yesterday.

"Waterstone's policy is a very important indicator. If they won't commit to keeping a stock range, you will end up with shops just selling the top 100 titles.

"There is nothing on the internet that can compete with a bookshop like Waterstone's in Manchester. It is a cultural centre in a sense that the internet can never be. But, if you won't let a bookseller like Robert Topping work, what sort of bookseller are you going to become?"

In a letter in The Bookseller, she added: "Forget the threat of electronic sales. Forget e-books. When Waterstone's ... cannot recognise that they are getting rid of one of the most talented people in the business - who has probably made more money for them than any other manager in the country - then we really do have something to fear".

Michael Schmidt, managing director of the literary publisher Carcanet, said he was "shocked and outraged" by Mr Topping's dismissal. Since it occurred, he said, displays of local and quality books had been squeezed out of the branch by "huge dump bins of Ann Widdecombe, Harry Potter and Bridget Jones". Waterstone's had begun charging authors hundreds of pounds for window displays.

"Robert kept a devoted and stable staff. You knew them all - and you knew a lot of the customers as well", said Mr Schmidt.

Kate Pocock, head of marketing at Yale University Press London office, said: "I think everyone is very shocked and saddened. A company like Waterstone's should be able to stretch itself to accommodate a character like Robert.

"I hope they will be able to reach a way of dealing with it. We are getting substantially higher numbers of returned books from Waterstone's than at this time last year."

Mr Topping is noted for the 300 events he ran at the store every year, making the Deansgate branch "a unique gig on the reading circuit". He followed the "browser-friendly" policy of the firm's founder, Tim Waterstone, but was once warned by Mr Waterstone not to carry this too far.

After being sacked a fortnight ago, he picketed the chain's yearly managers' conference in London with a placard urging Save Waterstone's From the Mekon - a reference to Private Eye's nickname for its managing director, David Kneale.

"When it comes to books, marketing is too important to be left to the marketing people, just as selling them is too important to be left to the grey suits in sales", he declared.

After lodging his appeal, however, Mr Topping said from his Manchester home: "I can't talk. I do want good relations with them in future."

A Waterstone's spokeswoman declined to comment because of the appeal. She added that the charge for window displays was introduced before Mr Topping's departure.

Waterstone's, once known for the independence of its local managers, has never been thrivingly profitable, Last year pressure on margins and internet investment costs pushed earnings down 16% to £21.4m.

Its parent company, HMV Media, carries £550m in debt. Last week three potential buyers, reportedly the German group Bertelsmann, the US group Borders and Tim Waterstone, tabled bids for the chain which are understood to have been rejected as too low.

Yesterday one book trade observer said, though Mr Topping's case had been mishandled, Waterstone's was genuinely in trouble. During a flat period for trading, its stores were overstocked and not selling enough bestsellers.

Mr Kneale was unrepentant. He told his managers' conference: "Publishers will squeal from time to time ... For some people, it has been too easy to get stock into Waterstone's."

webTitle: Prize claim scratched out by court

fields.headline: Prize claim scratched out by court
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday turned down a claim for £50,000 in damages from a former postman who alleged a national newspaper had failed to pay him his winnings from a telephone scratchcard game.
fields.body:
A judge yesterday turned down a claim for £50,000 in damages from a former postman who alleged a national newspaper had failed to pay him his winnings from a telephone scratchcard game.

Lee O'Brien, 33, from Bolton, Greater Manchester, claimed the cash plus £20,000 in interest after failing to scoop an expected jackpot.

During a two-day hearing, the high court in Liverpool was told that because of an error by the company hired to design and operate the "instant scratch" game, Mr O'Brien and 1,471 other players thought they had each won £50,000. They called the bonus hotline on July 3, 1995, but were told their cards were void.

The Mirror successfully argued it was covered by a rule which said if more prizes were claimed than were available there would be a prize draw.

Judge Brendan Hegarty said: "I have come to the conclusion on the facts and the law that [the paper's decision] was fair."

He said Mr O'Brien could have seen the rules on the day the game was introduced in April 1995 and other occasions.

webTitle: Rail blast blamed on Real IRA

fields.headline: Rail blast blamed on Real IRA
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, yesterday blamed dissident republicans for a small explosion on the Belfast to Dublin railway in south Armagh, and warned of further attacks.
fields.body:
The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, yesterday blamed dissident republicans for a small explosion on the Belfast to Dublin railway in south Armagh, and warned of further attacks.

Sir Ronnie believed the small device, expected to disrupt cross-border train services, was the work of the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bomb two years ago which claimed 29 lives.

He believed it might be planning more attacks in Britain after the explosion at Hammersmith Bridge in west London last month.

But he emphasised that he had received no specific intelligence about an imminent operation.

The dissident republican attack on the railway line was the first such act of sabotage in several years.

The attack appeared to be designed to anger the IRA. It occured three miles outside Newry, Co Down, in south Aramgh.

Sir Ronnie, launching the annual police report, warned he had intelligence that dissident loyalists would try to cause trouble at this year's Orange Order marches at Drumcree.

Sir Ronnie said: "We have some indications there will be small elements that intend to hijack protests.

"At this stage we don't have indications to the same level as in past years. I'm not talking about organised loyalist paramilitarism, but dissidents."

He said the drain on policing resources would be considerable as the security forces struggle to cope with the increased risk of disorder in the run up to the Orange Order's July 12 celebrations.

He refused to discuss deployment at Drumcree.

webTitle: England fury at 'insult' over World Cup bid

fields.headline: England fury at 'insult' over World Cup bid
fields.standfirst: Fifa report claims football facilities fall far below those of rivals
fields.trailText: England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup appeared on the brink of collapse yesterday following a controversial report by Fifa, world football's governing body, showing that English football facilities are way below those of two rival countries hoping to stage the tournament.
fields.body:
England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup appeared on the brink of collapse yesterday following a controversial report by Fifa, world football's governing body, showing that English football facilities are way below those of two rival countries hoping to stage the tournament.

The report comes just five days before Fifa chooses the country to host the tournament and was drawn up by an inspection team which visited English football grounds late last year.

The report claims that facilities in England are below those of Germany and South Africa, the two countries considered favourties for the tournament, leading to accusations from organisers of England's bid that there is a political agenda behind Fifa's criticisms.

Former sports minister Tony Banks, who has been working on England's bid, which has cost almost £10m and involved travel around the world, said the report was an insult to football in this country and that Fifa was actively working to promote the Germans.

The English bid has been headed by former World Cup winners Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst.

Brazil and Morocco also hope to stage the tournament but their facilities have been ranked below England's.

Mr Banks said: "Yes, I have seen that report. We have very reliable information that ... they have rated South Africa as being superior in terms of football facilities to England.

"Now quite frankly I don't believe even in South Africa that they believe that, and certainly the rest of the world won't believe that.

"It's all par for the course for the Fifa inspection team, but if this is true of course, they probably believe that Elvis Presley is alive and living on the moon."

England's officials are in Luxembourg addressing delegates from Uefa, European football's governing body, who have eight votes on the 24-member Fifa executive, which will decide the host country for 2006.

Mr Banks added: "We've got some problems on our hands because we have clearly got the Uefa machine working for Germany and the Fifa machine working for South Africa."

Ironically, the damning report on English football facilities comes as a Guardian/ICM poll shows that barely a majority of the British public backs the 2006 bid.

The survey also found that the staging of football's premier event is still very much a male passion.

While a clear majority of men - 56% to 37% - want to see England stage the World Cup, more women - 47% to 42% - want it staged elsewhere.

The poll shows that those most enthusiastic for the game remain overwhelmingly the skilled working class who quite strongly want to see the tournament staged in England.

C1 voters - broadly the lower middle class and skilled working class - split 57% to 37% in favour of staging the tournament.

Support for the bid is weakest among upper middle class voters - in the AB social class - who are 48% to 42% against.

The poll found little support for the government's handling of violence by England fans during Euro 2000. Only 11% felt ministers had handled the problem "well" or "about right". Some 45% felt the government had handled it "poorly".

However, 39% believe the trouble would have happened whatever the government had tried to do.

Some 44% support the current legal position under which the passports of hooligans who have been convicted of football-related offences can be confiscated to stop them travelling abroad to international matches.

But 48% of those polled say ministers should go further and allow the police to confiscate the passports of those who are only suspected of being involved in football-related violence, even if they have not been convicted of any offence.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,061 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between June 23 and June 26. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

The poll found little support for the government's handling of violence by England fans during Euro 2000. Only 11% felt ministers had handled the problem "well" or "about right". Some 45% felt the government had handled it "poorly". However, 39% believe the trouble would have happened whatever the government had tried to do. Some 44% support the current legal position under which the passports of hooligans who have been convicted of football-related offences can be confiscated to stop them travelling abroad to international matches. But 48% of those polled say ministers should go further and allow the police to confiscate the passports of those who are only suspected of being involved in football-related violence, even if they have not been convicted of any offence.  ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,061 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between June 23 and June 26. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Rock queen bows out  Tina Turner to retire

fields.headline: Rock queen bows out  Tina Turner to retire
fields.trailText: Tina Turner, the queen of stadium rock, told her fans last night that she will grace the cavernous arenas of the world no more.
fields.body:
Tina Turner, the queen of stadium rock, told her fans last night that she will grace the cavernous arenas of the world no more.

Turner, who is 60, has decided to retire from live performances after a career that spanned more than four decades.

She will settle down in a house overlooking Lake Zurich, shared with boyfriend Erwin Bach, 42.

Last night she told 75,000 fans in Zurich of her decision, on the first date of her world tour.

Turner's first hit, A Fool of Love, was in 1960. Together with husband Ike she had a string of hits including Nutbush City Limits, and River Deep, Mountain High. But their violent marriage, depicted in the movie What's Love Got To Do With It, ended with Turner walking out in 1976, and into a pop wilderness.

The 1984 album Private Dancer revitalised her career, as she became the queen of adult-orientated rock.

Her spray-on leather outfits, rasping voice and extravagant stage shows saw her become one of the best selling female artists, with album sales of 60m.

Explaining her decision to stop touring Turner, a grandmother, said: "I've done enough. I've been performing for 44 years, I really should hang up my dancing shoes. I can't sing without jumping around and I admit it's getting harder. I can't keep up with Janet Jackson. I'm not a diva like Diana Ross, I'm rock'n'roll, but I'm happy I can do it one last time so people can remember me at my best."

Her last tour will see her play in London, Cardiff, Glasgow and Sheffield in July. Her last live performance will be in San Francisco in November.

webTitle: Suicide policeman's widow may sue force

fields.headline: Suicide policeman's widow may sue force
fields.trailText: The widow of a twice-commended policeman who hanged himself after being forced to resign because of a drink-driving conviction is considering taking his former employers to court after alleging they had "applied double standards" in their treatment of him.
fields.body:
The widow of a twice-commended policeman who hanged himself after being forced to resign because of a drink-driving conviction is considering taking his former employers to court after alleging they had "applied double standards" in their treatment of him.

Carrie Ellis, 26, said she felt her husband, Richard, had been unfairly treated by senior officers within Hertfordshire police who had allowed six other officers convicted of drink-driving in the past four years to keep their jobs.

Speaking after a coroner yesterday ruled that Mr Ellis, 32, of Ware, Hertfordshire, had committed suicide, she said: "Richard seems to have been the only one who was required to resign.

"We are considering legal action. Had he been alive, we could have been looking at a case for unfair dismissal. We can't do that because he is dead, but we will be looking at the options with a lawyer."

Her criticisms followed an unusual decision by the coroner, Andrew Haigh, to write to the chief constable of Hertfordshire asking him to ensure the likely consequences of disciplinary action were made "as clear as possible to officers". Stressing he was not criticising the force, he added: "There does appear to be a perception of unfairness in this process."

Hertfordshire police admitted that another officer - who like Mr Ellis had been convicted of drink-driving and was also twice over the limit - was last month allowed to keep his job.

In the past 10 years, seven officers convicted of drink-driving have been allowed to continue with the force, with one other dismissed, a spokeswoman said.

But the chief constable, Paul Acres, said: "We have made it clear that we take a very serious view of drink-drivers and officers know their job is in jeopardy if they are convicted of such an offence.

"However, the constabulary has to judge each case presented to an internal tribunal on its own merits."

The inquest at Hertford coroner's court heard Mr Ellis hanged himself in his garage on February 27 - seven months after his conviction and four months after being ordered to resign after nine years' service.

He had worked as a security guard for Tesco but "absolutely hated" it, said his widow, and "felt incredibly guilty".

"Richie felt that he had lost a job that nobody could lose and as a result he felt a failure to me, his family and friends and himself," she told the inquest.

"If he couldn't be a police officer, he said he didn't want to live. He said his job was his life and when he couldn't get that job back then he wanted to die."

The court heard the PC was convicted after being involved in a minor collision after leaving a wedding reception, while off-duty, at Hertford police station.

He immediately reported the crash, and was found to be twice over the drink-drive limit.

fields.headline: Russia's pirate kings of e-commerce
fields.standfirst:
Capital letters: Ian Traynor in Moscow

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Capital letters: Ian Traynor in Moscow
fields.body:
The sweet smell of grilled meat and charcoal is wafting into the birch trees. The cold Baltika beer has the young Muscovites snoozing in the afternoon heat. On the stage in the middle of the park, Marimba Plus, a virtuoso combo of students from the Moscow conservatory, are bashing out an intriguing world music mix on cello, clarinet, flute, and the eponymous marimba.

And the paths of the park are heaving with the Moscow young crowd, snapping up the latest movies, CDs, Walkmen, cellphone gadgetry, and software. All, more or less, for the price of a pint.

The latest Moloko CD - a snip at £1.50. The new Gladiator film, in English or dubbed into Russian, on video or DVD. Take your pick. Yours for £3.50. Or the five-CD Encarta encyclopaedia - eight quid. Perhaps Microsoft Office 2000? Four CDs of the latest software. £6.50. Or an empty CD case - six pence.

Welcome to Gorbushka, a maze of hundreds of little red and white tents in a park in western Moscow and Russia's biggest bazaar for the entertainment and electronic era. There are more pirates here than in the South Seas.

It's the kind of place that makes American trade delegations and Hollywood moguls see red, muttering about intellectual property, copyright, thievery, and slashed profit margins.

"For the films," explains Sergei, a stall-holder, "we take a new DVD, that's the best quality, and copy it on to video." By the hundred thousand.

The streets of central Moscow, the metro stations, the underpasses are one big bazaar, with the trade particularly brisk in pirated music, film, and computer software. But Gorbushka is the Mecca.

And the stall-holders don't miss a trick. Forged barcode labels lend a specious aura of legality. Mock hologram stickers on the CDs look like authentic imprints aimed at thwarting counterfeiters. Many stalls display bogus street-trading licences. Other young men offer to "chip" your playstation, Nintendo, CD player, or whatever to beat any anti-piracy devices installed by the Japanese or Americans.

On any Saturday or Sunday, thousands of people make their way through the warren in the park, contributing substantially to making Russia the biggest market in the world for pirated software and making Gorbushka the biggest emporium of its type in Europe.

It is estimated that only one in 10 videos, music CDs, or software discs in any Russian home is not counterfeit. No Russian would dream of paying the full western whack for a CD, even if they could afford to.

An industry survey on global software piracy recently put losses from piracy at £8bn worldwide last year alone. The results, released in Washington last month, put Russia at the top of the international league of offenders, with a piracy rate of 89%.

The authorities occasionally go through the motions of clamping down, usually when western industry raises a hue and cry. The Ukrainian government, for example, last year made a bonfire of pirated discs and tape.

The Moscow mayor's office regularly threatens to close Gorbushka down. But it would only migrate somewhere else and it's generally believed that the police and the mayor's office are getting their cut of the proceeds.

In any case, where western capitalists see black market, Russian hawkers see free market. We'll call it e-commerce.

webTitle: Royals stay away as Diana memorial opens

fields.headline: Royals stay away as Diana memorial opens
fields.trailText: In Kensington Gardens yesterday it was the regrets rather than the acceptances which were noted: the Prince of Wales was busy in Dorset, his sons had considered it carefully and decided not to come, and Buckingham Palace man aged to give the impression that the other royals had been too polite to attend the opening of a spectacular new playground - the first public memorial to Diana, Princess of Wales - in case they were gatecrashing.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
In Kensington Gardens yesterday it was the regrets rather than the acceptances which were noted: the Prince of Wales was busy in Dorset, his sons had considered it carefully and decided not to come, and Buckingham Palace man aged to give the impression that the other royals had been too polite to attend the opening of a spectacular new playground - the first public memorial to Diana, Princess of Wales - in case they were gatecrashing.

The young princes presumably decided to stay away for fear their mother's life would be commemorated much as it was lived, in an unlovely media circus.

In the event it was a day of good behaviour and polite words through clenched teeth from the grown-ups, and whoops of glee from the children who had not realised there was anything sensitive about the opening of the playground.

Earl Spencer, who memorably vowed at his sister's funeral to keep her spirit alive in the princes, first turned down the invitation, and then apparently agreed to come only when he realised he would not be meeting any of her former in-laws.

Yesterday he stood with his arms around his four children throughout the speeches on the eve of what would have been Diana's 39th birthday, praising her playfulness, kindness, and love of children. Speaking to reporters afterwards, he said: "Honestly, I think anyone who wanted to attend could attend, and that's fine."

Also present was the chancellor, Gordon Brown, chairman of the Diana memorial committee which steered the £1.7m playground and £1.3m memorial walk in the royal parks through endless disputes with supporters who wanted more, opponents who wanted less, and local residents who wanted nothing at all in their park. He said: "This is a day for talking to the children, and that's what I'm going to do."

Rosa Monckton, one of the princess's closest friends, said: "I don't want anything written to detract from this day, and I am sure that members of the royal family will visit in private now that it is open."

Her five-year-old daughter Domenica, the princess's last goddaughter, performed the opening ceremony. She has Down's syndrome and has had years of speech training. Her mother repeated her words to the crowd, but there was no need. Her "I open this garden for godmother Diana" was perfectly clear. The microphone clipped to the front of her dress just picked up the warm "Well done!" whispered by the chancellor.

It was left to the arts minister, Alan Howarth, to say passionately: "This is something which seems to me very pri vate, very sensitive, and perhaps painful, inevitably provoking memories of [the princes'] mother. I think her sons are entitled to grieve in their own manner. The Prince of Wales had long-standing engagements. He is a wonderful servant of his country, employed today on public duties. I would very strongly suggest that no one should venture any criticism of him."

As the stilted interviews went on and on, Emily Weldon, seven, looking longingly at the rocks, the fountains, the golden sand and the pirate galleon, lost her temper. "Tell those cameras to go away and let us play!" she shouted, and eventually they did.

fields.headline: Act must ensure safeguards
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair's proposal to give police the power to impose on-the-spot fines for hooliganism is to succeed, safeguards must ensure that it does not conflict with the forthcoming Human Rights Act, set to come into force in October.
fields.body:
If Tony Blair's proposal to give police the power to impose on-the-spot fines for hooliganism is to succeed, safeguards must ensure that it does not conflict with the forthcoming Human Rights Act, set to come into force in October.

The act incorporates into law the European convention on human rights. Article 6 of the convention says: "Everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law." It also lays down that everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing before an independent tribunal.

John Wadham, the director of Liberty, believes there would need to be a process of appeals, and alleged hooligans would have to be given the right to opt for a court hearing instead of an on-the-spot fine.

"The trouble with this kind of rough justice, where police are expected to act as judge and jury, is that the traditional safeguards are absent and there's a risk of getting the wrong people - especially in a crowd situation," said Mr Wadham. "I assume that the pro posals will contain the kind of protections which would be needed to comply with the European convention on human rights. Without this, there would be a risk that these proposals would sweep up the innocent as well as the guilty."

Putting the plan into effect will not be easy, as the police acknowledged yesterday when they gave it only a guarded welcome. A spokesman for the Police Federation, representing rank and file officers, said: "The proposals would have to be carefully considered in the light of the European convention on human rights."

webTitle: Hong Kong restive under China's rule sours on Tung's reign

fields.headline: Hong Kong restive under China's rule sours on Tung's reign
fields.trailText: Three years after Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive who was hand picked by Beijing to lead the region, faces a crisis in public confidence.
fields.body:
Three years after Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive who was hand picked by Beijing to lead the region, faces a crisis in public confidence.

Fewer than one in four Hongkongers said that they were satisfied with the performance of Mr Tung's government in a poll published yesterday, the eve of the handover's anniversary.

Ironically, Mr Tung received a huge pat on the back only last week from Beijing when top Chinese leaders told a visiting delegation of Hong Kong tycoons that he was doing a good job. The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, said that Mr Tung had shown "wisdom and capability to govern under a complicated situation" and urged the territory's business community to support him.

But testimonials of this type have not impressed the Hong Kong public who have taken to the streets to draw attention to a wide range of complaints, while the legislative council (LegCo) defied Mr Tung by passing a vote of no confidence in two senior housing officials earlier this week.

Wednesday's censure vote followed a series of scandals about faulty construction work in public projects, and anxiety about depressed property prices and a shortage of low-income housing. One of the officials, the housing authority chairwoman, Rosanna Wong, resigned in spite of an earlier vow by Mr Tung that she would remain at her post.

Five separate rallies last weekend brought out demonstrators in a wave of anger against government policies on doctors' salaries, social welfare restructuring, urban renewal policies and the right of some mainland Chinese to live in Hong Kong, as well as on housing.

In short, as the political temperature starts to rise ahead of September's LegCo elections, Mr Tung is beginning to pay a heavy price for Hong Kong's lack of public accountability.

"I hoped the government would not be so reluctant to face a new political culture," commented Tsang Yok-sing, leader of the pro-government Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, who surprisingly voted for the censure. "Whether you like it or not, it has already arrived."

Critics say that the appointed housing officials were scapegoats, sacrificed to quell the disquiet caused by Mr Tung's reluctance to introduce a ministerial system which would take responsibility for the government's mistakes.

The region has inherited from Britain a government system where the chief executive (formerly the governor) is approved by the parent country and rules through an appointed executive council answerable to no one.

Attempts by the last British governor, Chris Patten, to make LegCo a fully elected body were frustrated by Beijing. Its powers, as under the British, are strictly limited; Mr Tung's administration is only obliged to give an annual policy address, answer questions from legislators and seek their approval for spending plans.

The legislators - of whom only a third are directly elected - cannot legislate except with government consent.

The voting system has been devised to make it impossible for a private member's bill to succeed without the approval of the mainly pro-government legislators, chosen by special-interest "functional constituencies". But in the censure vote the traditionally docile Liberal party swung the balance.

The Liberal party chief, James Tien, said his party favoured a ministerial system and demanded a "culture of accountability".

In this September's LegCo elections, the number of directly elected members will rise modestly, to 24 from 20, out of the 60 seats. The functional constituencies will continue to hold 30 seats, with the remaining six chosen by an election committee.

In some ways fears that Hong Kong might lose interest in politics have been dispelled by the current storm.

It appears to show that even though the pro-reform Democratic party has been losing ground, public concern about Hong Kong's political future has become widespread.

The functional constituencies will continue to hold 30 seats, with the remaining six chosen by an election committee. In some ways fears that Hong Kong might lose interest in politics have been dispelled by the current storm. It appears to show that even though the pro-reform Democratic party has been losing ground, public concern about Hong Kong's political future has become widespread.

webTitle: Nuclear waste site fire is out

fields.headline: Nuclear waste site fire is out
fields.trailText: The fire which scorched nearly half the Hanford nuclear waste site in Washington state, coming within two miles of some of the most lethal waste on earth, was virtually out yesterday, the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, said.
fields.body:
The fire which scorched nearly half the Hanford nuclear waste site in Washington state, coming within two miles of some of the most lethal waste on earth, was virtually out yesterday, the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, said.

There was no known air or soil contamination, he added.

The fire, begun by a fatal car crash on Tuesday, injured 15 people and destroyed more than 70 buildings, including 20 houses outside the 560 sq mile reserve.

Roads were closed and thousands of people were evacuated as the fire swept through the arid sagebush.

The reserve, originally set up under the second world war Manhattan Project to make plutonium for atomic weapons, contains the US's biggest volume of radioactive waste.

The fire crossed three old disposal sites - a trench and two dried out ponds - but officials said that initial surveys showed no increased radiation.

Firefighters stopped its advance before it reached some excavated drums of uranium waste.

webTitle: Bridge unites Norse in mutual banter

fields.headline: Bridge unites Norse in mutual banter
fields.standfirst: Concrete, steel and irony link Sweden and Denmark
fields.trailText: Two identical trains - one Swedish, one Danish - will speed towards each other today and stop 30 metres apart on an artificial island in the middle of the Baltic Sea.
fields.body:
Two identical trains - one Swedish, one Danish - will speed towards each other today and stop 30 metres apart on an artificial island in the middle of the Baltic Sea.

In four minutes they will be coupled together on this symbolic patch of land, and in that time Sweden will be directly joined to Denmark and continental Europe for the first time in 7,000 years.

Road traffic will begin to trundle across the £1.8bn bridge which stitches the two countries together later this evening.

The Oresundsbron is quietly impressive in a typically Scandinavian way: a model of understated Nordic elegance. It carries a four-lane motorway and double track railway from the centre of the Danish capital Copenhagen to the heart of Sweden's third city, Malmo.

Deceptively low-slung, and reminiscent of an expensive Bang & Olufsen stereo, the bridge spans most of the 10 miles which separate the two coastlines.

A specially built island and a road and rail tunnel do the rest. The best views of the bridge are to be had by driving from the Swedish side. Small white sailing boats bob around in the Baltic Sea and cross-channel ferries, which will now have to compete for customers, ply the Oresund.

Planes taking off and landing at Kastrup, Copenhagen's busy airport, fly close by and the piercing blueness of the Baltic shimmers beneath the bridge's concrete and steel.

The Oresundsbron, built in four years to last 100, is expected to carry up to 13,000 vehicles a day - 3m a year. It is jointly owned by the Danish and Swedish governments, who will recoup the building costs over 30 years from road tolls and rail charges.

A one-way crossing in a car will cost £20, a single rail ticket just over £5.

The project, it is said, will regenerate southern Sweden, create a dynamic economic area of 3.5m people to rival other European powerhouses, and bring together 11 universities and 130,000 students.

"The Swedes need a metropolis since their own capital is 600km [375 miles] away," said Henrik Koster, manager of the bridge exhibition centre on the Danish side.

"We want to be good competitors with Hamburg and Amsterdam, and if we link the two together we can have something good. It's funny that we are one of the smallest countries in the world and that we have built this.

"People ask me how how we can afford to spend so much money on a bridge, and I say because we can, because we're stinking rich," he jokes.

Enthusiasm for the project has so far been much greater on the Swedish side. Pensioners and tourists are already flocking to a visitor centre in Lernacken where they can drink cold beer and gaze at the bridge as it dips gently towards Denmark.

The proud Danes, used to seeing hoards of Swedes make the 45-minute ferry crossing to stock up on cheap beer in Copenhagen, believe that the traffic will all be one way.

It is already a bit like the Calais booze cruises, with alcohol-starved Swedes loading cheap Danish beer into wheelbarrows, one said.

"Until now we haven't had much to do with them, apart from selling them cheap beer," a sceptical Copenhagen resident said.

"The Swedes have a stiff upper lip like the Brits. Why would we want to go over there? Everything is expensive in Sweden, you can't drink, the Swedes are boring and there's nothing to do."

But Sven-Eric Soder of the Swedish foreign ministry says the bridge will bring benefits to both countries.

"The consumer will be the winner, because it will be easier to travel. Clothes and shoes are cheaper in Denmark and it's cheaper to buy a car there. But it's cheaper to go to the dentist's in Sweden.

"Fifty years ago it took three hours to cross Oresund. Today it takes three quarters of an hour, and now it will take just 10 minutes. I think the bridge is wonderful and beautiful. It looks like it has always been there."

Erik Pedersen, a Swedish pensioner, who lives near the bridge, agreed. "We love it and we really need it. Slowly we will become nearer to each other. I will take the train to visit Copenhagen to relax and shop."

But Lizbet Nielson, a Swedish pensioner at the Lernacken visitor centre, regretted that the journey to Copenhagen would now be so short that she would not have enough time to drink a beer. "It will be okay with the train but you won't be able to enjoy a beer.

But detractors are few. "The people living here are really proud of it: 99% of people are in favour," a Dane visiting Sweden said.

Bengt Falk, a Swedish pensioner, gazing at the bridge through his binoculars, saw it as an important indicator of the growing importance of Europe's regions.

"They've been talking about this bridge for almost a hundred years, but it's better late than never. It's incredibly important for the regions. Regions are becoming more important than countries."

There is a certain irony in the project, which has not been lost on the Danes. Southern Sweden, or Scania, once belonged to Denmark and only became part of Sweden in 1658 after a bloody battle.

This, said Mette Kragholm, who works at the bridge exhibition centre, was making the otherwise apathetic Danish public more interested in making the crossing.

"There is an idea that we're taking back Scania, but we're going to do it peacefully this time."

But the Swedes, she said, still had more to gain from the bridge than the Danes.

"Sweden will be empty on Sunday, because they'll all be over here."

fields.headline: Volcano chief quits stricken island
fields.trailText: The British director of the Montserrat volcano observatory has resigned, adding to Britain's difficulties in handling the Caribbean island's protracted crisis.
fields.body:
The British director of the Montserrat volcano observatory has resigned, adding to Britain's difficulties in handling the Caribbean island's protracted crisis.

Simon Young has refused a new contract because his recently born daughter is barred for health reasons from living on the island, partly devastated by the active Soufriere Hills volcano.

Since Zoe was born three months ago he has commuted by helicopter from the nearby island of Antigua.

He told Radio Montserrat that he had been unable to reach agreement on a new contract with the British Geological Survey, which takes over the management of the observatory from the Department for International Development (DfID) today.

"They will not allow my baby to even spend one evening on Montserrat, because they believe that the volcanic ash may pose some long-term threat to her health," he said.

He was "very disappointed" to be leaving, especially since the volcano was expected to become more active.

The 5,000 or so Montserratians who remain on the island live in the safe north; two thirds of the island remains an "exclusion zone", including the capital, Plymouth, which has been virtually destroyed by volcanic activity.

A spokesman for the DfID, which funds the observatory, said the rule that expatriates' children under the age of 12 must not live on the island was introduced in late 1997, at the height of the crisis, because there was no paediatrician on the island, and no facilities for night flying.

In March the island's chief medical officer, Dr Colin Avery, suggested to the DfID that it might be advisable to seek a second opinion about the ban.

"If expatriate babies and children under 12 are not allowed on island," he wrote in a letter leaked to the Montserrat Reporter in April, "why are we not advising the government of Montserrat to evacuate all children under 12 years?"

A mission due to visit the island in August will reassess standards of health care, especially paediatric provision. The heliport is being improved, but the work does not seem to have any priority.

David Ovadia, head of British Geological Survey International, denied that the observatory would not be fully staffed.

webTitle: Girls confess to killing nun 'for sport'

fields.headline: Girls confess to killing nun 'for sport'
fields.trailText: Italy was in shock yesterday after three teenage girls confessed to luring a nun from her convent and stabbing her to death "for a game". The girls allegedly ambushed Sister Maria Laura Mainetti, 61, on June 6 and took turns stabbing her 19 times in a crime initially blamed on drug addicts or pimps.
fields.body:
Italy was in shock yesterday after three teenage girls confessed to luring a nun from her convent and stabbing her to death "for a game". The girls allegedly ambushed Sister Maria Laura Mainetti, 61, on June 6 and took turns stabbing her 19 times in a crime initially blamed on drug addicts or pimps.

The three girls, aged 17, 17 and 16, had been taught catechism by Sr Mainetti at their school in Chiavenna, a prosperous town near Lake Como on the Swiss border. They have been arrested and will be charged with the murder, police said.

The daughters of middle-class parents, with no record of violence, they turned against the Catholic church and decided to punish it, according to transcripts of confessions leaked to the media.

What started as a playful enterprise escalated. "We wanted to kill the parish priest, Father Ambrogio. But he was too fat, we would never have been able. So we thought of the nun. We prepared a trap," one is reported as saying.

Sr Mainetti was known in the town for her work with prostitutes and drug addicts. She often left her convent for night-time tours of parks and streets. Three days before the killing one of the girls allegedly phoned her and said she had been raped and was pregnant. She said she was considering an abortion.

The girl phoned again on June 6 to say she had fled home and begged the nun to meet her at Piazza del Castello.

Sr Mainetti is believed to have left the convent at 9.30pm and met her former student, who is reported to have claimed she had a suitcase hidden in Marmitte dei Giganti, a tourist attraction of pot-holes formed by glaciation, where her accomplices waited. Emerging from bushes, one allegedly smashed a stone against the back of the nun's neck. She fell but fought back as a knife was produced.

An early morning stroller discovered the body the next day. Clutched in Sr Mainetti's fist were clumps of an attacker's hair.

The girls appeared calm after returning home, telling parents they had been to a restaurant. A witness who saw one girl and intercepted mobile phone calls led police to the three.

Motive remains a mystery. Alessandro Maggiolini, the bishop of Como and Sondrio, played down rumours that the three had been influenced by satanism.

"It was the triumph of emptiness. It appears they wanted to strike against mercy. Maria Laura signified welcome, repentance, humil ity." Representations of the church as an oppressive all-powerful institution fed such mentalities, said the bishop.

In May the body of a defrocked priest, Juan Granados, 53, was found naked and bound in his Rome apartment. He had been beaten around the head in an apparent sex crime. Earlier this week a crude bomb was placed in a crypt under the altar of a Milan church. Anarchists are suspected.

fields.headline: Mongolia heads for shakeup
fields.trailText: Campaigning for Mongolia's parliamentary elections, which may return to power the country's former communist rulers, ended yesterday amid accusations of vote-rigging and corruption.
fields.body:
Campaigning for Mongolia's parliamentary elections, which may return to power the country's former communist rulers, ended yesterday amid accusations of vote-rigging and corruption.

The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (MPRP), which ruled for 75 years until 1996, may make a comeback when 1.2m voters go to the poll on Sunday, riding a wave of disillusionment.

After a decade of reforms, a third of Mongolia's 2.4m population still lives in poverty, on less than $10 (about £6.30) a month, and thousands lost their livelihoods last winter, the worst for 30 years.

Many are fed up with bickering within the ruling coalition. However, there are fears that MPRP hardliners will stall economic reforms.

The MPRP has been accused of using its wide membership within the bureaucracy to rally votes. It counter-accuses the coalition government of blocking its television time. American observers say they have found no evidence of systematic corruption.However, it is unclear how several parties are funding their expensive media campaigns.

webTitle: Carnival greets French farmer who took on McDonald's

fields.headline: Carnival greets French farmer who took on McDonald's
fields.trailText: Amid scenes resembling an old-fashioned country fair, José Bové, the pipesmoking French activist, sheep farmer and icon of the modern anti-globalisation movement, arrived at his trial yesterday in an open wagon towed by a tractor.
fields.body:
Amid scenes resembling an old-fashioned country fair, José Bové, the pipesmoking French activist, sheep farmer and icon of the modern anti-globalisation movement, arrived at his trial yesterday in an open wagon towed by a tractor.

On trial for ransacking a half-built McDonald's restaurant in the southern French town of Millau last August, Mr Bové and nine fellow members of his Confédération Paysanne small farmers' union could face five years in prison and fines of up to £50,000.

But that did not seem the main concern of the estimated 30,000 protesters crammed into the small town, more than doubling its population.

"Even if it rains, we'll carry on partying," one small crowd of demonstrators chanted to the rhythm of a bass drum.

Others outside the courthouse carried large banners saying "The World is Not for Sale" - the title of Mr Bové's book, which has become a bestseller in France.

He has turned his trial into a huge anti-globalisation party, featuring concerts by French rock bands, a feast to promote traditional French food and more than a dozen public debates led by intellectuals and activists.

But justice officials insisted that the happy gathering would not influence the outcome of the two-day trial.

"There is no question of taking French justice hostage," said the court president, François Mallet. "What happens in the street does not interest this court."

Mr Bové and his friends trashed the McDonald's restaurant as part of a symbolic protest against America's decision to impose crippling import duties on a variety of emblematic French goods including Roquefort cheese, for which Millau is famous, Dijon mustard and foie gras.

The US move, itself a retaliation for the European Union's decision to ban imports of hormone-treated beef, sparked anger among France's traditional farmers and provided a focus for growing Gallic misgivings about the power of American multinationals, the inequality of world trade, and the dangers of industrialised food.

The moustachioed activist, a veteran of protests in the Pacific against French nuclear testing, has become almost as well known in America as he is in France after leading protests against November's world trade talks in Seattle.

The US magazine Business Week recently named him one of the top 50 people helping to shape the new Europe.

His popularity is due in part to his capacity to boil complex issues down to pithy protest statements. Asked once why he didn't resolve his differences by having McDonald's put Roquefort on cheeseburgers, he replied: "That would be like selling holy water in a sex shop."

In front of the McDonald's restaurant they dismantled almost a year ago, a small group of sheep farmers set up a stand where visitors could buy a slice of pungent Roquefort cheese, a glass of wine and a sticker denouncing globalisation, all for £1. The restaurant itself was closed.

Mr Bové, 47, has said he hopes the trial will be the start of a vast campaign coinciding with the start of France's presidency of the EU tomorrow.

"Any sentence would be unacceptable," he said yesterday. "At any rate, the verdict will be political. We are fighting for the dismissal of this case."

fields.headline: Ex-PM laundered millions
fields.trailText: Pavlo Lazarenko, Ukraine's former prime minister, has been found guilty of laundering millions of dollars through Swiss banks, making him the most senior foreign political figure convicted on corruption charges in Switzerland.
fields.body:
Pavlo Lazarenko, Ukraine's former prime minister, has been found guilty of laundering millions of dollars through Swiss banks, making him the most senior foreign political figure convicted on corruption charges in Switzerland.

Lazarenko, who is currently detained in the US on further money-laundering charges, was given a suspended 18-month sentence yesterday following a one-day trial in his absence this week. The outcome was the result of a deal between the Geneva prosecu tor's office and Mr Lazarenko's lawyers. In return, Switzerland is expected to drop its extradition request to the US.

Lazarenko's lawyers had pleaded guiltyon his behalf to charges relating to several million dollars received from a state farm and commissions paid in return for export permits while he was regional governor of Dnepropetrovsk in 1994.

The police court ordered the confiscation of $6.6m (£4.1) - the amount frozen in Swiss bank accounts - which is likely to be returned to Ukraine.

Lazarenko, who is currently detained in the US on further money-laundering charges, was given a suspended 18-month sentence yesterday following a one-day trial in his absence this week. The outcome was the result of a deal between the Geneva prosecu tor's office and Mr Lazarenko's lawyers. In return, Switzerland is expected to drop its extradition request to the US. Lazarenko's lawyers had pleaded guiltyon his behalf to charges relating to several million dollars received from a state farm and commissions paid in return for export permits while he was regional governor of Dnepropetrovsk in 1994. fields.headline: Slick action
fields.standfirst: South African penguin rescue under way
fields.trailText: Thousands of penguins were herded into wire enclosures on the South African nature reserve of Dassen Island yesterday to prevent them swimming   into the oil slick from the sunken tanker Treasure, which has already soaked the feathers of 11,000 penguins on Robben Island .
fields.body:
Thousands of penguins were herded into wire enclosures on the South African nature reserve of Dassen Island yesterday to prevent them swimming into the oil slick from the sunken tanker Treasure, which has already soaked the feathers of 11,000 penguins on Robben Island .

The Western Cape nature conservation board hopes a recent change in the weather will keep the spill away from the island and save them from the nightmare of having to evacuate the penguins.

So far only small patches of oil have washed up on the southern shore of the 220-hectare (550-acre) island, six miles off the coast, which normally has a population of 55,000 adult penguins and six humans.

About 1,300 oily penguins have been rescued and sent to the mainland for rehabilitation and there are thought to be at least 1,000 more contaminated birds, according to the reserve manager, Anton Wolfaardt.
AP

webTitle: British phone groups win Japan licence

fields.headline: British phone groups win Japan licence
fields.trailText: The stakes were raised in the race to dominate the world's hi-tech mobile market yesterday when Britain's biggest telecoms companies clinched a "3G" phone licence in Japan.
fields.body:
The stakes were raised in the race to dominate the world's hi-tech mobile market yesterday when Britain's biggest telecoms companies clinched a "3G" phone licence in Japan.

J-Phone, in which BT, Vodafone and local operator Japan Telecom have equity stakes, will launch a network with internet-style services by December 2001. J-Phone will be Japan's third-largest mobile service provider, with 8m of Japan's 50m mobile users.

BT owns 20% of J-Phone and Vodafone 26%. BT and AT&T jointly hold 30% in Japan Telecom. J-Phone will be able to call upon a £4.2bn cash reserve to build the network.

BT said it would strive to win third-generation licences across Europe and in Asia.

The deal coincided with an announcement from the German government that it is sticking with plans to auction between four and six 3G mobile phone licences which are expected to raise about £6.7bn.

The British government raised £22.48bn from the auction of five licences. US group WorldCom said it was in talks with Vodafone, BT, Orange, One2One and TIW, which each won a licence, to become a "virtual" network operator of a 3G British licence.

WorldCom pulled out of British licence bidding, saying prices were too high and dropped out of Germany's auction this week.

Peter Bonfield, BT chief executive, said of the company's win in Japan: "The partnership between us offers unique global capabilities and reach."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
MEPC sells Centre Point

Property investment firm MEPC, which this month agreed a deal to be taken private, said yesterday it had agreed an offer for Oldham Estate, a portfolio which includes London landmark Centre Point.

Blackmoor Portfolio, a development consortium which includes funds Apollo Real Estate Advisers and Pelham Partners, is to pay £392m for MEPC's 99.9% stake in Oldham. Blackmoor will also assume debts taking the total payment to MEPC to around £495m.

BBC seeks property allies

The BBC said yesterday it was in talks with five potential partners for revamping its £500m property portfolio, comprising 522 buildings.

"We are starting to create the tailor-made partnership which will provide a modern property infrastructure across London, the nations and regions, meeting the BBC's needs for at least the next 30 years," said the BBC's director of property, Ian Robertson.

The state broadcaster spends around £173m, 6% of its annual budget, on its estate, and streamlining the portfolio is part of director general Greg Dyke's strategy of focusing on programme making.

The BBC said it would announce a shortlist in the autumn and create the partnership by February 2001.

Faith invested in advertising

Financial TV operator Money Channel said yesterday its revenues would come from advertising because the cost of supplying free set-top boxes means digital broadcasters are reluctant to pay for content.

The company, founded by 60s pop star Adam Faith, said it aimed to raise £10m from a placing to fund development of digital interactive services, production of programming and provide working capital.

It predicted that the introduction of interactive commercials in the autumn would draw advertisers which were traditionally wary of television.

Paramount offloads estate

Paramount, the Chester-based pub company, is selling its entire estate of 145 houses to Royal Bank of Scotland for £19.6m.

Chief executive Paul Davies and finance director John Dangerfield are going to work for the new owner of the pubs, which are in the north-west of England, north Wales and Shropshire.

They said Paramount was too small to survive alone. Its annual pre-tax profits rose 10% to £615,000. The company will look for fresh businesses in which to invest.

Clinton's sign of the times

President Clinton went to Philadelphia, where America's founding fathers signed the Declaration of Independence, to "e-sign" a bill yesterday that makes electronic signatures as valid as ink counterparts.

He used a smartcard encoded with numbersto sign the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.

fields.headline: Tomkins triggers sale of gunmaker
fields.trailText: Tomkins is trying to erase its image as as an unfashionable stock market conglomerate by removing Greg Hutchings as chairman and trying to get shot of its gun arm, Smith & Wesson.
fields.body:
Tomkins is trying to erase its image as as an unfashionable stock market conglomerate by removing Greg Hutchings as chairman and trying to get shot of its gun arm, Smith & Wesson.

The decision to move Mr Hutchings, a veteran financier who built up the company through a series of daring acquisitions in the 1980s, is said to have followed complaints by shareholders about corporate governance standards.

Mr Hutchings, who is staying on as chief executive, could provide beleaguered shareholders with some much-wanted relief as soon as next week by making a "substantial return", estimated by analysts to be as much as £1bn, from the sale of foods unit Ranks Hovis McDougall to the Doughty Hanson venture capital group.

While Mr Hutchings steps down as chairman, Tomkins is selling many of the companies he bought to focus on two areas - industrial and automotive engineering and construction components.

As a result, a large part of the remaining businesses will be based in the US, although Mr Hutchings insisted yesterday that the group, which has fallen out of the FTSE 100, would retain its stock market listing in London.

Its shares made further progress off some of their lowest levels for 10 years yesterday, rising more than 6% to 214.75p as the group reported a 4% fall in pre-tax profits of £478m for the year to the end of April. It will pay total dividend of 17.45p.

David Newlands, the former General Electric finance director who is becoming non-executive chairman of Tomkins, insisted that the decision to split Mr Hutchings' role had not been forced upon the company by weary shareholders. "Greg's talents were spread too thinly. I have agreed to take on responsibility to run the board ... leaving Greg time to provide leadership and grow Tomkins."

Mr Newlands also described the Smith & Wesson gun unit as non-core and said the group was looking for ways to resolve that. The group, which sold more guns than it expected, has been ostracised by the rest of the industry after it signed a clean-up guns code in the US.

The gun unit has also brought unwelcome attention in the US. Earlier this month, New York City filed a suit against a Smith &Wesson subsidiary alleging negligent sales practices and deceptive advertising.

Mr Hutchings indicated that further acquisitions were in prospect once the wave of non-core disposals was completed. Part of the proceeds of the delayed sale of Ranks Hovis McDougall would be kept as "fire power" but would also be used to make a "substantial return" to shareholders.

The group has already sold its US food business, Red Wing, for £88m. Garden centre group Murray is up for sale.

webTitle: 'Le cost killer' happy to live up to soubriquet

fields.headline: 'Le cost killer' happy to live up to soubriquet
fields.trailText: Carlos Ghosn has a reputation as a corporate hard man. Even before his appointment last year as Renault's choice to run Nissan - surely the toughest job in the motor industry - he was known as "le cost killer".
fields.body:
Carlos Ghosn has a reputation as a corporate hard man. Even before his appointment last year as Renault's choice to run Nissan - surely the toughest job in the motor industry - he was known as "le cost killer".

Mr Ghosn has already shown the Japanese his mettle. At a shareholders meeting this month he confronted a group of sokaiya - racketeers who try to drag out shareholder meetings in the hope management will pay them off-head on.

Mr Ghosn will face tougher battles as he tries to change Nissan's corporate culture and bring the car company back into black.

He was born in Brazil and educated in France at the Ecole Polytechnique and then at the Ecole des Mines de Paris.

He joined Michelin in 1978 and held posts in manufacturing and research and development in France before he ran the tyre maker's business in Brazil and then in North America.

In 1996 he joined Renault as an executive vice-president where his approach quickly brought him the soubriquet "le cost killer". "He has a reputation for being ruthless in the way in which he carries out tasks," said one industry executive.

In 1999 Renault bought a 36.8% stake in Nissan and sent Mr Ghosn to Japan to turn the business round. Initially he was appointed chief operating officer but was appointed president this month.
