fields.headline: Nissan fuels euro row
fields.standfirst: Ghosn drops Micra bombshell, then flies out before talks with ministers
fields.trailText: The row over whether Britain should sign up for the single currency burst into new life yesterday after Nissan's most senior executive said the company's Sunderland car plant was facing its biggest threat since it was built in 1986 because of the strength of the pound.
fields.body:
The row over whether Britain should sign up for the single currency burst into new life yesterday after Nissan's most senior executive said the company's Sunderland car plant was facing its biggest threat since it was built in 1986 because of the strength of the pound.

Nissan president Carlos Ghosn said the plant's prospects of being chosen to build the new Micra were being undermined by the level of sterling against the euro.

Adding to the government's embarrassment, Nissan's widely trailed "top level talks" with senior ministers are on hold. Although Tony Blair is said to be ready to talk to Nissan executives, a spokeswoman for Mr Ghosn said a meeting was unlikely to be "within days or weeks".

Mr Ghosn flew to Japan yesterday and was not scheduled to be back in Europe until the Paris motor show in September.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers immediately seized on Mr Ghosn's comments, made in an interview with the Financial Times, as a demonstration of the dangers of staying out of the single currency if the economic conditions were right for entry.

"As we know, there are those who would refuse to join the euro on principle or to rule it out for the whole of the next parliament even if it was in the economic interest of the UK to join," Mr Byers said.

Mr Ghosn's statement "shows how dangerous that approach is. It is an approach which puts at risk investment in the UK and the loss of jobs as a result."

However, union sources claimed Renault, the French car group which owns 36.8% of Nissan, was secretly manoeuvring to transfer production of the new Micra to France and fill spare capacity among its own plants.

Pointing out that the new Micra would share the same platform as Renault's best-selling Clio model, they said the French group was using the political excuse of the strong pound and Britain's exclusion from the euro to dump Sunderland, Europe's most productive - but loss-making -car plant.

A British car industry insider said: "Renault wants to build the car in France. Nissan and it have gained nothing from their alliance so far and we know from our own dealings that Renault would dearly like to have something to show. This could be just a taste of things to come."

However, other sources doubted that a single Renault plant would be able to build both the Micra and the Clio, or that a new plant was likely at a time when there was already too much capacity in Europe.

Mr Ghosn said that, although Sunderland was the most logical place for the new Micra to be built, currency factors could jeopardise its position. "How much we rely on Sunderland is at stake. We could be interested in limiting output at Sunderland and increasing output at other European plants."

Mr Ghosn said that Nissan would not close the Sunderland plant, even if it was not awarded the new Micro production and the estimated £150m investment entailed in that project. The plant already produces the Primera and Almeira models.

Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU which has a single-union agreement covering all 5,000 employees at Sunderland, has arranged a series of meetings with Nissan-Renault executives to discuss the issue and at Downing Street on Monday warned Mr Blair about the new threat to Britain's shrinking manufacturing base. Sir Ken said yesterday: "The workforce has delivered on productivity but exchange rate variation has wiped out all the gains."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The mere 134 scored by England in their first innings against the West Indies, and another round of gripping matches at Wimbledon, provided the main source of excitement for City dealers yesterday, even though the FTSE 100 struggled out of its losing streak.
fields.body:
The mere 134 scored by England in their first innings against the West Indies, and another round of gripping matches at Wimbledon, provided the main source of excitement for City dealers yesterday, even though the FTSE 100 struggled out of its losing streak.

However, share trading volumes waned to low levels which gave dealers little heart about the durability of the 73 point rise in the blue-chip index to 6,312.

Amid the sporting-induced torpor, Royal & Sun Alliance found itself in the unusual position of topping the league table for gains on the day. Its shares rose almost 31.5p to 429p as a result of an upgrade by Cazenove brokers.

While Cazenove moved the rating from hold to buy and set a target of 538p, a few sceptics in the City could not help but muse that perhaps something was afoot at the insurer, which has found few friends on the stock market since it was formed by a merger three years ago.

Another insurer, CGNU , the named of the married CGU and Norwich Union, also gained. The shares closed at a new high of £11, up 55p.

Among the banks, Lloyds TSB , once the doyenne of the sector, suffered another downgrade - also ending down 16p at 624p - this time by its own brokers at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. The analysts were responsible for a number of gyrations among the financials, although their cut in Barclays to neutral from outperform corresponded with a 41p rise to £16.43.

The generally warmer mood in the market was inspired by a stronger feel to the bruised Nasdaq technology market in the US, which also helped major telecoms stocks gain ground.

Cable & Wireless climbed 73p to £11.19, while Vodafone AirTouch gained 3p to 267p but, because of its size, was responsible for eight points of the FTSE's gains on the day.

It was sorrier story for British Telecom , however, which scored a low of 815p before eventually ending 6p lower at 854p.

Outside the main index, a few eyebrows were raised by a sudden 9% rise just before the close in the shares of Rank , which ended at 153p.

Pubs operator Paramount was little moved by news of the sale of its pubs to a Royal Bank of Scotland-backed venture which left it as a cash shell in search of "corporate transaction".

webTitle: Bank's review tells tales of doom

fields.headline: Bank's review tells tales of doom
fields.trailText: The stock market is no place for the faint of heart. Risk is an inherent part of its infrastructure. It creates opportunities, but it also poses threats. This week the Bank of England published an assessment of current threats that - if they cared to read it - would frighten any novice investors.
fields.body:
The stock market is no place for the faint of heart. Risk is an inherent part of its infrastructure. It creates opportunities, but it also poses threats. This week the Bank of England published an assessment of current threats that - if they cared to read it - would frighten any novice investors.

The Bank's semi-annual Financial Stability Review is not the dry read that its title might suggest - a testimony to the stewardship of deputy governor David Clementi. Its purpose is to warn of impending disaster. Its delivery sharpens the senses without resorting to sensationalism.

In the chaotic world we occupy it would be foolish to look for order and structure where it does not - or indeed can never - exist. Too much analysis of financial markets assumes an unrealistic collective rationality of market participants. Consequently conclusions and prescriptions are delivered with an "authority" that is spurious.

The FSR avoids this pitfall by focusing on possible economic scenarios and analysing what could be done to enhance at the margin the stability of the financial system. Vigilance is its watchword.

But investors should not assume that the Bank of England is doing everybody's worrying for them. The range and scale of possible threats to stability is too great, and the power of the authorities to head off each and every possible crisis is too slim. If you'd like to spook yourself, pull up the FSR on the Bank of England's website, www.bankofengland.co.uk one level the review is reassuring - in being identifiable and measurable, risks must surely be controllable and to some extent already priced into markets. But digging deeper one is struck by the veiled references to the apparent irrationality evident in the recent behaviour of equity markets in particular.

The arguments employed to challenge current equity valuations are not novel, and as such have been dismissed by bulls repeatedly over recent years. What gives them piquancy, however, is the recent collapse in telecoms, media and technology (TMT) sectors. A risk remains only a risk until it becomes a reality.

The Bank's analysis has understandably been some time in the making for it focuses on the negative impact of the failure of Boo.com in May, an event that has already disappeared to the back of the memory banks. But only to be replaced by new spectres, with Amazon's share price woes top of the spookometer.

Highlighting the fallout from the Boo.com affair, the Bank wryly observes: "That poses a question about how well prospectuses are studied by investors." This query borders on the rhetorical. No one doubts that institutional investors comb the claims of floating companies, but the marginal price maker is often the carefree private punter following the herd.

This week I was privileged to share a media platform with Brent Hoberman, one of Lastminute.com's co-founders. Raking over the coals of his cou I was struck once again by the staggering mismatch between the reality of the company's fundamentals and the fantasies that accompanied its launch.

The occasional ignominious IPO can be absorbed by equity markets accustomed to risk, so long as it doesn't pull the rug from under investor confidence altogether. More concerning would be the failure of a dot.com Goliath. Step forward Amazon?

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee spends the majority of its time weighing risks. Specifically inflation risk, but of necessity also broader economic and financial risks. One does not envy it its task. Economic growth in the western world teeters on the knife-edge of investor confidence in TMT stocks.

The policy watchers agree that interest rate decisions now rest between unchanged and higher rates. I'm not so sure. The tech stock bubble has burst and the disappearance of technology euphoria could trigger a deceleration of economic growth in the second half of the year - in the US and Europe.

If this came to pass then the balance of policy debate could shift rapidly towards easing rather than tightening. The dot.com entrepreneur could go the way of the 1980s estate agent. Only the leanest and meanest will survive to enjoy the next upswing.

Lest you think this all spells disaster, it is conceivable that this scenario would be great for bonds and equities. Slower growth, equals lower inflation risk, spells falling interest rates. Unfortunately, though, the dislocation involved could destroy investor confidence.

This is just a scenario. But one to be aware of. There are many others. Take time out to read the FSR. If it sharpens your senses you'll have done yourself a favour.

The Bank's semi-annual Financial Stability Review is not the dry read that its title might suggest - a testimony to the stewardship of deputy governor David Clementi. Its purpose is to warn of impending disaster. Its delivery sharpens the senses without resorting to sensationalism. fields.headline: Zetters goes into City bets
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Zetters is planning to reinvent itself as an international online financial spread-betting operation after a decline in its core football pools business.
fields.body:
Zetters is planning to reinvent itself as an international online financial spread-betting operation after a decline in its core football pools business.

The company is understood to have applied to the financial services authority for regulatory clearance to compete with bookies IG Index and City Index by offering punters the chance to bet on a range of stock market prices. Chief executive Tony Wollenberg said Zetters was also talking to potential partners in the US and Far East about tapping "vast" overseas gaming markets.

He hopes that making Zetters available through the internet, digital television and handheld web access devices will attract people who do not use betting shops.

Bets placed on share price changes, interest rate moves and index levels are among the fastest-growing areas of the bookmaking industry. That has led IG Index to seek a £115m flotation next month.

However, Mr Wollenberg warned that Zetters might relocate to an offshore tax haven if the government refused to reduce the betting levy.

The declining popularity of football pools was reflected in full-year results to March 31. Turnover fell by £5m to £10.42m, pre-tax profit slipped from £1.54m to £1.14m.

fields.headline: Attacks force out biotech guru
fields.trailText: One of the most influential financiers behind Britain's biotech industry, Jeremy Curnock Cook, has resigned as head of Rothschild's International Biotechnology Trust amid a growing storm over his personal interest in some of the fund's investments.
fields.body:
One of the most influential financiers behind Britain's biotech industry, Jeremy Curnock Cook, has resigned as head of Rothschild's International Biotechnology Trust amid a growing storm over his personal interest in some of the fund's investments.

Mr Curnock Cook, 50, left yesterday "on medical advice" in the middle of a battle for control with a US firm, Millennium Partners. He said that he was "irritated" at "specious personal attacks" from the American company, which he believes have aggravated his long-term heart condition.

"There is nothing hidden here - it is a simple issue," said Mr Curnock Cook. "They are choosing to personalise matters with an attack which I think is unneccessary."

Millennium, a 10% shareholder, wants to liquidate the £290m fund and distribute the proceeds to investors. It wrote to shareholders last week accusing Mr Curnock Cook of a conflict of interests, after discovering that he held share options worth more than $750,000 in two of the biotech companies in which IBT has invested.

IBT said that after a review of the situation, Mr Curnock Cook had agreed to give any profits from his options back to the trust. Mr Curnock Cook said: "It was always my view that the value of the share options would go through to the trust. This was never, for me, an issue. "

The options, in the US firms Sugen and Cell Therapeutics, have exploded in value amid a resurgence in the performance of the drug development sector.

Mr Curnock Cook was granted the options because he is a non-executive director of the two companies. Corporate governance guidelines in the US - unlike those in Britain - permit such awards to independent directors.

Mr Curnock Cook's options have never been disclosed to IBT's shareholders. According to filings with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, he holds options in several other firms in which IBT has invested, including Targeted Genetics and Ribozyme - but their value is unclear.

Mr Curnock Cook insisted his resignation from IBT had nothing to do with these disclosures: "My health has been troubling me for a while. One eventually listens to the very good advice one's been given. If you continue to roar around the place, you risk bits falling off."

Millennium wants to break up IBT because its share price, which fell 3.5p to 254p yesterday, is well below the total value of its investments - 313p a share. IBT argues that this is because some of its stakes are in early stage, unquoted companies, which cannot easily be cashed in.

Mr Curnock Cook said: "Fairly predictably, if an arbitrageur wishes to undermine an investment trust, its first approach has to be to attack the management."

A qualified microbiologist, Mr Curnock Cook is an ubiquitous figure in the drug development industry. He is the chairman of Biocompatibles, deputy chairman of Vernalis and also a director of Cantab Pharmaceuticals.

Millennium has asked how he can devote attention to IBT when he sits on the board of 23 different companies. Mr Curnock Cook says that some are dormant, and that the true figure is in the "mid-teens".

Shareholders will vote on whether to break up IBT at a meeting next Friday. AstraZeneca is one of the biggest investors, with 7%.

webTitle: Wilkinson nets another fortune in Akers deal

fields.headline: Wilkinson nets another fortune in Akers deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Wilkinson, the entrepreneur and architect of Freeserve, realised another fortune yesterday through a £165m reverse takeover of his companies VData and Storm.
fields.body:
Peter Wilkinson, the entrepreneur and architect of Freeserve, realised another fortune yesterday through a £165m reverse takeover of his companies VData and Storm.

The agreed bid was made by AIM-listed InTechnology, the latest vehicle for dealmaker Chris Akers.

The move was a repeat of the process which saw Mr Wilkinson's Planetfootball website company bought by Mr Akers' Sports Internet group for £24m a little over a year ago. BSkyB has since agreed to buy Sports Internet for £301m.

The management team behind VData and Storm is the same one that built up Planetfootball and PlanetOnline, an internet services company Mr Wilkinson sold to Energis for £85m two years ago.

The new company will be chaired by former Conservative party chairman Lord Parkinson. Mr Wilkinson will be chief executive and own 57% of the shares in InTechnology.

VData hopes to tap burgeoning demand among large companies that do not yet back up their systems. It provides automatic off-site back-up to online applications in case they crash or are accidentally damaged.

In the period to December 31 - its start-up phase - it recorded a turnover of £28,000 and a pre-tax loss of £1.6m.

Storm is a 17-year-old data storage company with an annual turnover of £102m and pre-tax profits of £5.4m. Mr Wilkinson hopes Storm customers such as IBM, Compaq and Sun Microsystems will also buy services from VData.

Mr Wilkinson said: "The global demand for data storage has increased by 80% in the last two years. Our significant investment in developing our own network and data storage facilities has placed Storm and VData in a leading position to take advantage of this phenomenal growth."

InTechnology plans to pay Mr Wilkinson £9.7m cash and the balance of £65m in shares. It is also raising £33m through the placement of new shares at 150p each to fund its European expansion.

InTechnology shares, which were suspended at 257.5p in early May, are due to start trading again on Monday.

Mr Wilkinson met Mr Akers through Leeds United, the football club they both support and where the latter was once chief executive.

webTitle: Old flame tries to set sports market alight

fields.headline: Old flame tries to set sports market alight
fields.standfirst: Sports memorabilia have seen wild price swings and Sotheby's is now testing the water with Olympic items. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: Sports memorabilia have seen wild price swings and Sotheby's is now testing the water with Olympic items. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.body:
Elegant: Mucha poster, 1904, estimate £6,000-£8,000

Heroic: Berlin 1936: Lithograph, estimate £1,500-£2,000

Golf memorabilia is now described as a "steady market". But in the late 80s, when the Japanese were buying, golf clubs and trophies fetched ridiculous prices - tens of thousands of pounds.

And collecting football ephemera, even though England does not seem able to win very much, has become almost a craze, with national caps and football shirts as well as medals, cups and even programmes selling for thousands of pounds compared with hundreds a few years ago.

But what of Olympic Games items? Strange to relate, there does not seem to have been a sale by any of the big auction houses devoted entirely to Olympics collectibles, although items do come up at general sports sales.

As this is an Olympic year (the Games start in Sydney in September) and because a collection of Olympic memorabilia has come its way, Christie's, South Kensington, has decided to have a dedicated sale at 2pm next Thursday (July 6) almost, one feels, to test the water and see what interest there is.

The Games were started by the Greeks in 776 BC at Olympia in north-western Peloponnese and included running, pentathlon and chariot racing events. They were held every four years until they were abolished in 393 AD by the Roman Emperor Theodosius I.

In 1892 29-year-old Baron Pierre de Coubertin, a member of a French aristocratic family, sought to revive the Games. Two years later a congress of Athletic Associations unanimously endorsed his proposals and the first Olympic Games of the modern era took place in Athens in 1896. There were more than 280 participants from 13 nations, although no women competed. The events were open to everyone - there were no national teams - and silver medals were awarded to the winner of each event.

The next three Olympics, in Paris (1900), St Louis (1904) and London (1908) saw the Games revert to little more than a side-show and all three were staged as part of larger trade exhibitions. Because of the first world war no Games were staged from 1912 to 1920, but from 1924 on, apart from another gap because of the second world war, the Games were held every four years, growing in strength, sophistication and, often, controversy.

Although there are few precedents for this sale in the UK, there are some guidelines. Nicolette White, who is organising the sale for Christie's, says: "Each year Ingrid O'Neil holds an Olympic memorabilia sale in Colorado. There are known to be a number of collectors and the centrepiece of this sale comes from a collector who advised us on prices."

The collection included in the 100 lots comprises memorabilia and sporting ephemera relating to the British athlete Harold Maurice Abrahams, CBE (1899-1978). Abrahams's experiences in the 1924 Olympic Games in Paris were captured in the award-winning film Chariots of Fire, released in 1981.

Abrahams was famous for his victory in the 100-metre sprint, winning the gold medal. But he was also a member of a silver medal winning four by 100 metres relay team, which was run in 42 seconds, a British record which stood for 28 years.

The collection includes his silver medal, along with other medals awarded to Abrahams, including a participation medal for the 1948 London Olympics and an Academie des Sports gold medal awarded in 1925 in recognition of his athletic achievements.

Although Abrahams' career was tragically cut short when he broke a leg as a result of a long-jump accident in 1925, he maintained life-long links with the sport as an administrator and patron. His collection is estimated to realise £8,000 to £12,000, which would compare favourably with mementoes of a footballer of similar stature.

There is probably nothing in football, cricket or golf to match the Olympic flame. The continual burning of the flame throughout the Games was introduced at the Amsterdam Games in 1928, and the torch relay from Olympia in Greece to the host city was introduced at the Berlin Games in 1936. A number of Olympic torches are on offer at the sale. One, from the Berlin Olympics, is estimated to fetch £1,500 and another, from the London 1948 Games, is priced at £2,500.

With posters the sale is on firmer ground. Sports posters in general and skiing posters in particular have become very popular in the past two or three years. The third Games, in St Louis 1904, were held in conjunction with the Louisiana Purchase Exhibition. An Alphonse Mucha poster advertising the Exhibition is offered at the sale for £6,000 to £8,000. Mucha was, of course, a well-known lithographer and this is about the right price range.

Trawling through the catalogue you will find some wonderful lithographs and silk-screen prints from the 1964 Tokyo Olympiad, starting at around £500. I suspect that if there is a market for Olympic memorabilia it will centre on posters and prints.

For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington: 020-7321-3120; www.christies.com

webTitle: The world will not stand still for Labour

fields.headline: The world will not stand still for Labour
fields.standfirst: Danes can confuse issue even more
fields.trailText: First things first. The strength of the pound against the euro and the debate over whether or not Britain should sign up for the single currency are not the same thing. Entwined, perhaps inextricably, they may be. Identical they are not.
fields.body:
First things first. The strength of the pound against the euro and the debate over whether or not Britain should sign up for the single currency are not the same thing. Entwined, perhaps inextricably, they may be. Identical they are not.

Membership of the single currency would remove the risk of adverse exchange rate movements between the pound and the currency of a leading trading partner. But signing up for the euro is not the only solution to the strength of the pound. Indeed, at the current euro-sterling exchange rate, it is not a solution at all. It would lock in the existing competitiveness problem.

Yet every time the question of sterling's strength is raised by a manufacturer hard pressed by the exchange rate the question of whether or not Britain should join the euro comes rushing to the fore. This is not entirely surprising.

Some of those complaining about the level of sterling would like to see Britain in the single currency zone. They would like the removal of one uncertainty which does complicate investment decisions and so are not averse to seeing one question blur into the other.

There is little doubt that the warning from Nissan president Carlos Ghosn about the threat to the company's Sunderland plant getting the job of building the new Micra from sterling's strength against the euro will be seized on by those pressing the case for British membership of the single currency.

The government has known about the risk of the new Micra not coming to Sunderland for some while now. But the timing of Mr Ghosn's remarks could have been better from Downing Street's point of view coming, as it did, when France and Germany are talking of a two-speed Europe - with Britain among those likely to be in the slow lane on a number of key issues.

There is a broader, related single currency question for the government. It is true enough that ruling out British membership of the euro in the foreseeable future could be a high risk option. So could rushing into membership without passing Gordon Brown's economic tests. But, despite Stephen Byers comments yesterday, the government appears to be proceeding as if doing nothing is a zero risk option. It isn't. The world will not stand still simply because the government would like it to.

Whereever the new Micra ends up being made, some high profile investment decisions will be made on the basis of where sterling is likely to be against the euro over a given period. They may well be influenced by the likelihood or otherwise of Britain joining the euro zone. In other cases the non-membership issue may well provide a convenient excuse for decisions taken on, shall we say, more Machiavellian grounds.

The exchange rate is not the only mechanism by which the euro will have an impact. If and when (okay, a fair-sized if and a tricky when) the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges finally manage to link up, a substantial slice of the trading down in London will be in euros.

Initially that will be in dealings in the big German stocks which will migrate to the City under the terms of the deal to create the new iX exchange. UK companies will continue to have the option to list in sterling. But it is inconceivable that the likes of Vodafone, the biggest constituent of the FTSE 100 share index, will not come under pressure to adopt the euro - not just from shareholders in the euro zone but also from American investors looking to limit their currency exposures.

There is a considerable risk that the euro - for all its travails since its launch at the beginning of 1999 - will become the de facto currency in the City, whatever this government, or another, chooses.

Nor will the issue slip off the political radar. It will come into particularly sharp focus in September when Denmark will go to the polls over the single currency issue. Danish voters can create merry havoc for the sterling exchange rate. It was their decision in the summer of 1992 to reject the Maastricht treaty that set the scene for that summer's currency turbulence, which culminated in the September crisis that saw the pound forced out of the exchange rate mechanism.

This time round, as the investment bank JP Morgan noted yesterday: "A 'yes' vote could leave the UK isolated as the only one of the 15 European Union members without a clear timetable for entry."

Then again a "no" vote might provide both Britain and Sweden - the other members of the EU's awkward squad when it comes to single currency matters - with the justification for their own procrastination.

As the JP Morgan analysis notes, if that happened: "Investors are unlikely to react positively to the rejection of the single currency by a country that has been a member of the EU for 27 years, with a fixed exchange rate for 18 years."

webTitle: Getting net results in the tennis racket

fields.headline: Getting net results in the tennis racket
fields.standfirst: The Lawn Tennis Association has a new scheme to accommodate post-Wimbledon enthusiasm. Eileen Sheridan dons her whites
fields.trailText: The Lawn Tennis Association has a new scheme to accommodate post-Wimbledon enthusiasm. Eileen Sheridan dons her whites
fields.body:
Because of our weather, we Brits live in a strange contradictory world which sees us stripped off and active for one part of the year and swaddled and slothful in the other.

So now we're in summer we can start telling ourselves that life is full of sunshine, strawberries, tans and healthy outdoor activity. And since this lasts not much longer than three months, we had better be quick about making the most of it.

Once Wimbledon is over and we have peeled ourselves away from the television set, hordes of us, according to the Lawn Tennis Association, rush down to the local tennis club and sign up for a bit of coaching.

"It's a great sport for all ages and sexes. And it can be played as an individual as well as a team sport," says the LTA's Richard Lewis. So in response to the seasonal post-Wimbledon demand, the LTA has this year launched Play Tennis 2000, which offers free taster sessions to all comers at 1,100 clubs around Britain.

On the weekend of July 15 and 16 anyone can pitch up and meet the club coach to have an introduction to the sport. "Racquets will be available free and all you need is suitable shoes - most people wear trainers - and clothes you can run around and play tennis in," says Mr Lewis.

As tennis has shed its English middle-class image and become a glamorous world sport, the number and quality of clubs where you can play, not to mention local authority courts, has multiplied.

Membership of a club at the snob end of things might cost in the region of £2,000 a year, but that would be at a centre which offers a gym, swimming, saunas, beauty rooms and other sports.

To join a good average local club costs around £50 a year and will probably buy you into a more cosy atmosphere. "In rural areas the tennis club is often the centre of the community," Mr Lewis points out.

The LTA has built 40 specialist tennis centres where you do not have to be a member but can just turn up and play and the cost is very reasonable. At off-peak times a hour on a court will cost around £2.50 per person and at peak times £5 per person.

But if you have to learn, or want to improve your game from school knockabout level, you need a proper coach. And what you have to look out for is someone who is LTA qualified and licensed. The licence part of it is most important. This guarantees that the coach has maintained his/her knowledge by undertaking LTA courses; that they have undergone proper police checks - a must if they are teaching children - and carry insurance for personal injury.

"There are 2,000 licensed coaches in the country," says Mr Lewis. "You are quality assured with them." A licensed coach will have gained a development coach award which is taken over 14 days in a five-month period and is a pass or fail qualification.

Expect to pay around £2 for a group beginners' lesson, and anything from £20 to £30 for an individual coaching lesson. The LTA says individual coaching is only necessary for people who are taking the game up seriously.

At David Lloyd Leisure centres members can have individual coaching from a starting price of £17 and the coaches are all LTA qualified. There are 43 David Lloyd Leisure clubs in the UK and the majority have both outdoor and indoor courts with an average of 10 indoor and six outdoor per club. Fees to join a David Lloyd Club cost from £130, with average monthly subscriptions for an individual member of £48.50. The group says that prices are higher in the London area.

The clubs have a host of other facilities such as saunas, steam rooms, health and beauty salons and creches and all of them have swimming pools. And most of them have sports shops for all the equipment you will need.

Tennis racquets are much cheaper than they used to be and you can get a very good one for £25 to £30.

"They are made from graphite or carbon, which is easy to mass produce," says Mr Lewis. "And they make the sport easier because the racquets are lighter and the heads bigger."

Makes to look out for are Slazenger, Dunlop and Wilson Prince. And as for tennisshoes, most people have trainers anyway which are fine for the game, although manufacturers like Nike and Adidas make special tennis variations of the trainer if you want them. These days you will find yourself playing tennis on all kinds of different surfaces. The majority are tarmacadam. "They give a very good ball bounce, a true bounce," says Mr Lewis. "There are also acrylic courts and about 100 clay courts in the UK, but these are mainly used by performance play ers." David Lloyd Clubs have carpet and playtex indoor courts.

The other new development in the game is "short tennis", a variation usually played by children in the 5 to 8 age bracket. "Short tennis came to this country from Sweden about 10 years ago and is played with a lighter racquet and foam ball on a smaller court. Adults can start this way too. The idea is to introduce you to hand - eye co-ordination, but no-one should play it for too long," advises Mr Lewis.

webTitle: The game's over for pools dynasty

fields.headline: The game's over for pools dynasty
fields.standfirst: Brand values Littlewoods
fields.trailText: Spare a thought for the descendants of Harry Askham this week as more than thirty members of the Moores family share out the proceeds from the sale of the Littlewoods football pools business.
fields.body:
Spare a thought for the descendants of Harry Askham this week as more than thirty members of the Moores family share out the proceeds from the sale of the Littlewoods football pools business.

Trevor Hemmings, the entrepreneur who owns Blackpool Tower, is paying £161m for the group's leisure operations: pools, spot-the-ball and scratchcards.

Harry Askham worked as a telegraphist in Manchester with John Moores in 1923 when the pair were setting up the pools business. They decided not to use their own names for fear of losing their day jobs and agreed to call the company Littlewoods. The business had an unpromising beginning: the first dividend was just £2.12s and the operation lost money. Harry Askham lost heart and sold out - the business equivalent of filling in a winning combination and then not bothering to post the coupon.

Cecil Moores then joined his brother and by the end of the 1928 football season, the company had begun to turn in the kind of profits that made its founder a millionaire by the late 1930s. It was a brilliant business: counting the money and checking coupons was left to local collectors. Littlewoods hardly had to do a thing, so operating costs were minimal; owning the pools was a licence to print money.

But the pools have suffered since the National Lottery was launched - with the group losing 70% of its pools turnover in the past five years. Last year it accounted for only £300m of Littlewoods' £2.3bn turnover, and the group recently reported a 60% fall in pre-tax profits.

Until the lottery came along Littlewoods' pools business pulled in more than six million punters every week. For two and a half hours - from kickoff to classified re sults - every Saturday they were on tentherhooks. As Tony Hancock said in one of his sketches: "Two and a half hours time! I can't wait that long without knowing! I'd be a quivering mass of disintegrated nerve tissue, lying on the floor twitching away in a pile of fag-ends and finger nails!"

Selling the pools leaves Littlewoods free to concentrate on home shopping and high street stores, and the company is interested in acquiring up to 20 sites from C&A, which is pulling out of the UK after years of heavy losses.

Barry Gibson, chief executive, said the strategy of combining retail and catalogue stores had been working "extremely well" and the company was looking for sites in towns where it was not represented. Two years ago Littlewoods sold 19 stores to Marks & Spencer - which has since admitted that many of its problems stemmed from ill-timed expansion.

New strategy

Last November, the company launched its new strategy, which will re-establish the Littlewoods name as the core brand. Market research findings highlighted many strengths associated with the name, customers trusting it to deliver quality at an affordable price. The Index catalogue shopping brand will move under the Littlewoods banner and trials of store fascias combining the two are already underway. The aim is to broaden its appeal to a newer, younger audience while building on relationships with existing customers.

Shares in the company - still privately held - are spread among 30 family members: socialites and socialists, family loyalists and self-styled realists. Their boardroom connections have faded in recent years. Only one member of the clan remains on the board: James Suenson Taylor, son of Sir John's daughter, Lady Grantchester.

But the business has had more than its share of dramas. The search for Sir John's successor had the hallmarks of the US television soap opera Dynasty - even down to a granddaughter named Alexis. One son, John junior, opted instead for cattle breeding; a nephew, Nigel, widely tipped as his successor, was killed in a car crash.

Another son, Peter, who had worked in the arts before joining the business, took over as chairman in 1977. He was ousted when profits dived - and Sir John returned to the helm at the age of 84. But the founder's brilliance had its drawbacks: so much of the company's managerial talent and power was concentrated in himself. For almost 60 years John Moores man aged Littlewoods in his own autocratic way. Staff were left in no doubt as to who controlled the company. Even senior executives had to clock on. Members of his family were treated the same way: he fired his nephew Timothy, aged 19, for eloping with a window dresser.

The Moores stretched their corporate brand and enhanced the family's philanthropic reputation by pouring millions into Merseyside charities, football and other sports, education and the arts. When Liverpool polytechnic made the leap to university status, few quibbled when it took the name of John Moores University - acknowledging his status as Merseyside's greatest post-war benefactor.

The fax

In the high street Littlewoods sales are £2.5bn a year from 5m sq ft of selling space. It is Britain's third-largest clothing retailer and fifth-largest non-food retailer

The stores More than 280, under three fascias: Littlewoods, Littlewoods Catalogue Discount Stores and Index, the catalogue store. Not many people know Index is part of Littlewoods, so the stores are being rebranded Littlewoods Index; 54 have been opened within larger Littlewoods stores

By mail order Be an agent for Janet Fraser, Burlington, Peter Craig and John Moores. Oh, and Littlewoods. If your back doesn't collapse under the weight of the catalogues. Index Extra cuts out the agent and is now Britain's largest direct home shopping catalogue

Treble chance The first pools coupons were handed out in 1923. Of 4,000 distributed, only 35 were returned, with bets totalling £4 7s 6d. The payout was £2 12s 0d and the season brought losses of £600. By 1954, the pools were the seventh-largest business in Britain, employing 23,000 people

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.body:
National Savings cuts fixed rates

National Savings, the government bank, has cut interest rates on its fixed-rate savings accounts. Two-year pensioners' bonds with a minimum investment of £5,000 drop to 6% from 6.2% while investors who opt for its five-year version lose 0.25 points to 5.75%. The bonds pay gross interest but may be liable to tax.

The new rates on its Capital bonds with a minimum investment of £100 have been cut even further, dropping from 6.15% to 5.65%, while rates on six-month savings bonds now range from 6.2% for more than £50,000 to 5.8% on £500.

Its fixed-interest savings certificates are still worth considering, but only for higher rate taxpayers. Its five-year certificate pays 4.15% tax free, which works out as 6.92% for higher rate taxpayers and 5.18% for basic rate taxpayers.

This is lucrative for top rate taxpayers, pretty average for those on the basic rate and poor value for non-taxpayers.

Despite the copper-bottomed security of investing in the the state controlled bank many disillusioned savers are voting with their wallets after their bonds mature.

Savers pulled £1 billion more out of National Savings products than they invested over the year ended April 2000, according to figures just out. The net outflow - the first for 10 years - shows that National Savings is struggling to hold on to investors' cash in an increasingly competitive market.

Mortgage deals to tempt buyers

People thinking of investing in bricks and mortar have several lenders chasing them with new fixed-rate mortgage packages. Mortgage broker Chase De Vere is offering housebuyers with a 10% deposit homeloans at 5.41% fixed until July 1, 2002.

For borrowers who prefer lower rates over the next two years it will lend at 3.96% but they are tied to its deal for a further three years at the then prevailing mortgage rates, or pay hefty early redemption penalties.

For borrowers with the typical 5% deposit, the West Bromwich Building Society is offering mortgages at 4.39% fixed until August 31, 2002. But borrowers have to pay an early redemption penalty costing 3% of the mortgage for switching lenders in the first five years.

Independent Mortgage Collection (0800 731 0 137) has secured a two-year fixed rate deal at 5.49% with no early redemption penalties.

Cashcard part of student account

Royal Bank of Scotland has launched its Student account ahead of the next academic year, beginning in September. The account comes with a cashcard which gives free access to virtually every cash dispenser in Britain.

And it pays 3.04% on credit balances but more importantly for indebted students it offers interest-free overdrafts staring from £1,000 in the first year and rising on a sliding scale to £2,000 in the fifth year for graduates who stay on to take their postgrad qualifications.

Sir Paul backs affinity card

To mark this year's National Vegetarian Week, People's Bank has launched an affinity card that triggers a donation of £10 for every new card issued follow up donations of 35p per £100 spent on the card. The new Visa card, which is backed by Sir Paul McCartney, comes with a carrot of low APR 7.9 fixed for six months.

Watchdog guide to power switch

Gas and electricity consumers can now get an unbiased guide to facts and figures form energy regulator Ofgem to enable them to make more informed choices when switching suppliers.

The information pack, includes a guide to price comparisons, factsheets covering a range of issues surrounding switching and complaints statistics which are an important indicator of a company performance.

For copies of the Ofgem pack tel 0800 88 77 77.

For copies of the Ofgem pack tel 0800 88 77 77.

fields.headline: Adding insult to injury claim
fields.standfirst: No-win, no-fee claims handlers charge up to 39% of damages, but approaching a solicitor direct offers a better deal, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: No-win, no-fee claims handlers charge up to 39% of damages, but approaching a solicitor direct offers a better deal, says Richard Colbey
fields.body:
Lawyers may, with some satisfaction, cite as a cautionary tale the case of the Lancashire woman who was injured in a taxi.

Her experiences might suggest that those who want to make claims after being injured are much better off approaching a solicitor directly, rather than going to one of the growing number of claims handlers, who provide legal representation in exchange for a share of the damages.

The injured passenger, who does not wish to be identified, contacted Somerford Claims, a part of the Claims Direct (CD) group. They referred her case to Blackburn solicitors, Farleys. Eventually the drivers' insurers agreed to pay her £7,105. Farleys' bill was also met in full by the insurers.

Had she gone to that firm in the first place she would have been able to walk away with the entire sum. However, her agreement with Somerford entitled it to take £2,764 - nearly 39% of her damages.

CD, which aims to float on the Stock Exchange later this year, was approached by the Solicitors' Journal about the case. Its first reaction was to deny any responsibility on the basis that Somerford was an independent company, although admitting "there have been shareholders common to both companies". Later, though, it emerged that a cheque for the shortfall had been sent to Stephen Tranter, the Manchester solicitor now acting for the woman, by CD in an attempt to settle the matter.

However, a spokesman for the company claimed that this cheque had been sent as the result of an error by a "middle manager". Sending it was at odds with CD's official position that it is the solicitor responsible for advising the client about the best way of paying for the action.

This woman, undoubtedly, should have been told by the solicitors if she was eligible for legal aid. The Law Society's Practice Rules specifically require solicitors to advise clients about various funding options. The passenger has now sued Farleys, alleging that they failed to advise her properly in respect of this and a number of other options.

If a CD client actually commences proceedings, the company ceases to be entitled to a share of the damages. Farleys should have advised her to commence proceedings for that reason alone.

However, they and other solicitors on CD's panel may fear that if they consistently advised clients to do this, CD would stop sending them cases. CD's spokesman insisted, however, that this conflict was more illusory than real. None of the solicitors removed from its panel had so far been removed for that reason. CD does give a form mentioning other funding options to clients, but few will understand it.

Tranter and the woman's barrister have also alleged that Farleys should have advised that the agreement with CD was "potentially" champertous (a legal term for an illegal agreement) and hence unenforceable. If that view is correct, the basis for much of CD's business would be ruled illegal.

Legal aid has not, since April, been available for new personal injury cases, but there are still different fund ing options that need to be considered. Anyone with a strong case will be able to find solicitors willing to take it on a contingency no-win, no-fee basis. The solicitors get more than their usual rates if the case does succeed, but this will all be paid by the other side. Solicitors, unlike referral agencies, may not in any circumstances take a proportion of the damages.

Where an agency like CD charges on that basis, the agency's proportion, inevitably, has to come out of damages. The advantage of using such agencies is that there is no need for the claimant to pay extra costs, such as medical reports and court fees. Although these are recoverable at the end of the case, they have to be paid by the claimant initially if a solicitor is instructed directly.

Partly because of the difficulties identified in the taxi passenger's case, CD clients no longer have to pay a proportion of their damages, but instead must pay £1,312, described as an insurance premium. Sixteen per cent interest is charged to those unable to pay it all immediately.

There has not yet been any court ruling on whether premiums can be recovered from the other side if a case succeeds. At best, a reasonable premium will be recoverable but interest above 8% cannot possibly be. Only if the claim exceeds £15,000 is such a premium even arguably reasonable. Comparable insurance is available for around £200.

A CD spokesman accepted that although the £1,312 is paid to insurance underwriters, a fair amount is returned to CD "for services". This sum is probably the main basis for CD's profits, which last year were more than £10m.

Stephen Tranter sums the position up by saying: "Many agencies promise accident victims that if they lose their case it won't cost them anything. However, what is not properly understood by many claimants is the position if they win. While my firm, and many others, still guarantee it won't cost our clients anything, claims agencies like CD make deductions, leaving clients substantially worse off."

Tranter's concerns are heightened by the fact that claims companies are completely unregulated. CD may well be correct in asserting that it was under no obligation to advise the Lancashire woman about funding options, but if it does not even perceive itself as under a duty to act in this way, then it is not just lawyers who will feel it has no business dabbling in litigation.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Time for tax cheats to confess

fields.headline: Time for tax cheats to confess
fields.standfirst: Tough new legislation is on the way, reports David Brodie
fields.trailText: Tough new legislation is on the way, reports David Brodie
fields.body:
Crackdown: Gordon Brown is targeting tax and benefits fraud

If you have any dark secrets from the taxman you may now be drinking at the last chance saloon, as this week the government announced tough new measures to tackle the black economy.

From January 1 2001, anyone with untaxed income - from the odd bit of moonlighting to a full-time job paid in cash - could face up to seven years' imprisonment and an unlimited fine.

Legislation has been presented to Parliament in Gordon Brown's mounting drive to clamp down on tax and benefits cheats, although there is a chance to "come clean" in the six months before the new measures take effect.

These moves follow a report by Lord Grabiner QC which concluded that billions of pounds are being lost through dishonesty. The Revenue finds it difficult to prosecute tax evasion under the existing common law, and only a few dozen cases are tried each year.

Normally the taxman must be content with a financial settlement, typically involving payment of six years' tax plus interest and a penalty, which has done little to stem the tide of evasion.

Grabiner ruled out a tax amnesty, saying it would be unfair to those who have paid their taxes and would not necessarily work; thousands might volunteer to benefit from the amnesty, but then go back to their previous bad habits. But he did suggest a "carrot and stick" approach, which is now being implemented.

A new hotline has been set up, offering confidential advice to anyone who would like to put their affairs in order before the new law bites. If you phone 0845-608-6000 (lines are open from 8am-8pm weekdays, 8am-5pm at weekends) and give details of the income you have not reported, you will receive guidance on how much tax and National Insurance contributions you will be expected to pay.

The hotline will also explain how to register with Revenue offices and whether you might qualify for the working families' tax credit; many callers will have failed to claim this generous benefit for fear of a tax investigation.

The hotline can also tell you whether you have been claiming benefits illegally and, if so, what to do about this. There is no blanket immunity from prosecution if you report your offence, but a spokesman says that "consideration will be given to the fact that claimants will have voluntarily let the Benefits Agency know what they have been doing".

The government says that the hotline is completely confidential; you do not have to give your name and calls will not be traced. You will be given a reference number and password, enabling you to call back for further information should you wish to.

And if, having spoken to the hotline, you feel ready to approach your tax office, it will offer to send you a letter confirming the advice given on the phone. We are told that "so long as callers have been frank with the advice line", that advice will be followed by the tax office.

The new hotline offers a welcome new route for anyone wanting to get on to the Revenue's books. However, it cannot offer expert guidance on the financial penalty the Revenue will want to add to the tax and interest due, which can by law be as much as the tax unpaid but is usually mitigated to reflect your disclosure and cooperation.

Also, if you want a letter confirming the advice you have received, you will need to give your name and address. However, this loss of confidentiality may not matter because the draconian powers to be introduced next January should persuade anyone who owes tax that now is the time to come clean.

From January, the Revenue will be deploying an extra 50 officers in the prosecution of cases in the Magistrates' Courts - where you could face a fine of up to £5,000 and six months in prison - while more serious cases will be tried in the Crown Courts, which can impose unlimited fines and up to seven years' imprisonment.

David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 020-7624-3768 between 10am and noon, Mondays to Thursdays, or go to www.taxaid.org.uk.

webTitle: Cowboy builders head for Boot Hill

fields.headline: Cowboy builders head for Boot Hill
fields.standfirst: A number of new schemes and online vetting services are being launched to help consumers find honest, reliable tradesmen, writes Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: A number of new schemes and online vetting services are being launched to help consumers find honest, reliable tradesmen, writes Elizabeth Langton
fields.body:
British consumers' love affair with DIY is due in part to their loathing and suspicion of builders. Everyone, but everyone, has dealt with a rogue builder at some point in their homeowning life. The cowboys' reputation for drinking endless cups of tea, wearing low-slung trousers and never turning up when they should is second to none.

Government figures say 300 people a day complain about the level of service they receive from contractors. In response, a number of initiatives have sprung up that marry up skilled, honest tradesman with desperate customers, offering different levels of protection.

The two main internet-based services, www.improveline.com and www.homepro.com, which put consumers in touch with vetted builders, claim they are growing at a rate of knots.

Homepro was started after the founders were victims of shoddy building practices and saw a gap in the market for a vetting service, says Dan Cobley, its head of marketing. Homepro checks whether builders who want to join the scheme have any outstanding county court judgments against them, have a good credit rating and are carrying the relevant liability insurance, he adds.

"The next step is to visit their place of work and rifle through their invoice files to randomly select customers who are then contacted and asked about the service they received," says Mr Cobley.

For the customer, the matching service is free. Builders pay a subscription fee to join Homepro and a commission fee for any job they secure via the service. About 5,000 contractors have signed up since it was launched in February and the site has submitted £25m worth of work for builders' perusal. So far only a small number of jobs have come to fruition, says Mr Cobley.

Improveline.com also checks builders' county court judgments and credit rating and puts details of jobs worth more than £1,000 out to suitable traders.

They take out five invoices at random and phone two previous customers. Improveline also contacts the customer after the contractor visits for a quotation. Customers are asked whether they turned up on time, were polite and helpful or walked mud through the house, says Charles Pearce, business development manager. "This way customers can report back before the contractor even starts the job," he says.

Improveline says it has signed up 90,000 contractors since its launch in October last year and has seen about 500 jobs completed. Meanwhile, Quality Mark, the government-driven scheme to chase cowboy builders out of the industry, is being piloted in Birmingham and Somerset. The scheme, which aims to identify "quality marked" builders backed by a warranty, has been more than two years in development and the pilots are still in the process of recruiting builders.

However, Martin Fisher of the Institute of Trading Standards Administration says: "Most of the jobs consumers want done around the home are very small and are often carried out by the smallest businesses which will be the slowest to sign up."

In the past, bad publicity about trade associations that neither vet their members nor expel them when they've been found guilty of wrongdoing has shattered public confidence in the system. The Federation of Master Builders (FMB) has been working to raise its profile as a bona fide organisation that consumers can trust. To join the FMB, contractors need to produce one year's accounts and two customer references.

Last month, the Federation joined forces with local council building inspectors to launch a scheme that goes further and offers the chance to insure against faulty workmanship. Anyone who contacts a council's building control service, the office charged with ensuring building regulations are properly adhered to, will be told about MasterBond Warranty.

Consumers who purchase the warranty, which costs 1.5% of the total contract value including VAT, are covered against faulty workmanship and materials for two years and against structural defects for a further eight years. Builders must have been trading for at least three years, to have passed independent financial and other checks, and been vetted by the FMB and the local authority's building control department.

In the meantime, consumers can make the most of good tradesman schemes endorsed by local trading standards officers. Some local authorities also hold lists of contractors they use to carry out work in their area.

Relying on membership of some trade associations can be as risky as putting a pin in the Yellow Pages. Mr Fisher says consumers need to check out the schemes and what membership entails.

Once consumers have a shortlist of tradesmen, they might want to contact their local trading standards officers for advice. Although officers have to be careful about defaming local tradesmen for no good reason, they can often give you a nudge and a wink, he says.

When it comes to digging deep into their pockets, even the experts rely on recommendation. If Mr Fisher had to look for a builder, he says he would start by talking to neighbours who have had similar work carried out.

fields.headline: Strawberries and the service game
fields.standfirst: Outdoor catering has grown from a seasonal affair to an all-year-round industry employing thousands, from designers to chefs. Sandra Deeble gets a flavour
fields.trailText: Outdoor catering has grown from a seasonal affair to an all-year-round industry employing thousands, from designers to chefs. Sandra Deeble gets a flavour
fields.body:
Gilt and red plush chairs, a ruffly tent, sparkly chandeliers and a little something masquerading as champagne to wash down insipid coronation chicken. Yes, it's that time of year again.

For people working in events catering summer is their busiest time. Yet it's far from being just a seasonal thing. Throughout the year, corporate hospitality is a £750m industry firing on all cylinders.

"It's such a booming area," says florist Victoria Sullivan. "Ten years ago I was busy in the summer. Now there's no let up all year round." Ms Sullivan has been working with Silwood Park Nurseries to prepare and maintain the flowers for Wimbledon fort night. Before the tournament started, Silwood ordered 20,000 stems of flowers, including roses, delphiniums, scabious and lilies to adorn public areas and corporate marquees.

"More and more companies are using freelances," she says. "When you're working on something like Ascot or Wimbledon you can do 16- or 17-hour days. If any of the roses droop at Wimbledon they have to be replaced at three in the morning."

Being freelance can be precarious at times, although Ms Sullivan has had her moments of glory: she arranged the flowers for Diana Ross's wedding on Lake Geneva. She trained with Constance Spry 20 years ago but says that floristry has changed a lot since she started out.

"You used to have to work your way up. Nowadays, you can be at art college and it's enough just to like flowers. Colour sense is much more important than formal training."

Yet many people are still getting into the bucks' fizz and canape business through the college route. "Up to 60% of our graduates are going into event catering," says Angela Maguire, programme director at the School of Hospitality, Leisure and Tourism at Westminster College, famous for training the likes of Jamie Oliver, Ainsley Harriot and Anthony Worrall Thompson. "The work is so interesting and varied and the big companies are offering competitive salaries and training."

By big companies, Ms Maguire is referring to the likes of Sodexho or Compass - huge multi-tasking machines which are not only in the business of corporate hospitality, but also cater for hospitals, schools and year-round corporate contracts.

"It isn't about food anymore," admits Lynne Morrison, director of training at Sodexho UK. "Our heritage is in being a food provider, but we're in so many other things now."

As a catering graduate, you could join the "executive" training programme at Sodexho, perhaps becoming a district manager responsible for up to 15 corporate contracts, although, as Ms Morrison explains, as companies acquire and merge, the market can shrink, as two clients often become one.

But one recent graduate of the Westminster College School of Hospitality, Anne Nielsen, whose final dissertation was based on predicting the future of events catering, thinks that she would prefer to work for a smaller company. "There are so many opportunities," she admits. "Catering brands are growing: there are really good companies like Mosimann's and Rhubarb." And, she points out: "The bigger companies are driven by cost cutting."

One person who found the cost-cutting too much to bear was motivated to start his own company. Frank McCartney used to work for Sodexho and had been responsible for running the entire catering operation at Wimbledon for many years. In January 1999, together with Martin Joyce and Colin Botting, he set up the company FMC. They were able to retain the much-coveted All England Club as a client by virtue of the fact that if the Wimbledon contract were taken over and run by people who hadn't done it before, it might have been a recipe for strawberry hell.

During Wimbledon fortnight, Mr McCartney takes on 1,500 staff (during the rest of the year he has a core staff of 32) all of whom are employed by FMC directly: they never use agencies. It's a logistical mindbender, but Frank McCartney, who is calm and softly spoken, has it all under control.

Three days before the start of the tournament, as lorries deliver their loads of Pimms to the labyrinth under court number one, Mr McCartney has time to stop for a chat with former star Christine Trueman before explaining how the 1,500 FMC uniforms - complete with discreet logo and strawberry motif - get washed every day. A night shift has been set up to deal with the hulling of 27,000 kilos of strawberries, and, as he explains, things have changed since he started out with Lyons in 1968.

"People are much more discerning now," he says, "Although I'm still surprised when some people ask for coronation chicken." A passion for food and an interest in people should come before an interest in finances; a desire to have fun is what attracts so many people to working with FMC during Wimbledon fortnight.

Frank McCartney has stories about how, for many of the students he employs, it's an opportunity to find love under the canvas; other perks include the opportunity to watch tennis on the outside courts during breaks and a two-week binge of star spotting.

Some companies, such as Purvis in Edinburgh, do still supply traditional tents, but to demonstrate how the market has no limits, you can now get your mitts on a pukka Mongolian yurt (available for hire from an office in Islington), which has a chestnut and hazel coppice frame and can squeeze in up to 500.

Founded four years ago by Lucy Gemmell and Martin Clare, Rhubarb caters for high-profile clients such as the Princes Trust, John Cleese, David Linley Furniture and the Elton John Aids Foundation.

"You don't have to have bog standard white plates and it doesn't have to be the same old thing," says Ms Gemmell, who has an Aladdin's cave of brightly coloured, starry crockery, goblets and cutlery to choose from.

"In what we do, qualifications are not important," she adds, admitting that she only has one O-level (Religious Education) to her name. fields.bodyText: Gilt and red plush chairs, a ruffly tent, sparkly chandeliers and a little something masquerading as champagne to wash down insipid coronation chicken. Yes, it's that time of year again. For people working in events catering summer is their busiest time. Yet it's far from being just a seasonal thing. Throughout the year, corporate hospitality is a £750m industry firing on all cylinders. "It's such a booming area," says florist Victoria Sullivan. "Ten years ago I was busy in the summer. Now there's no let up all year round." Ms Sullivan has been working with Silwood Park Nurseries to prepare and maintain the flowers for Wimbledon fort night. Before the tournament started, Silwood ordered 20,000 stems of flowers, including roses, delphiniums, scabious and lilies to adorn public areas and corporate marquees. "More and more companies are using freelances," she says. "When you're working on something like Ascot or Wimbledon you can do 16- or 17-hour days. If any of the roses droop at Wimbledon they have to be replaced at three in the morning." Being freelance can be precarious at times, although Ms Sullivan has had her moments of glory: she arranged the flowers for Diana Ross's wedding on Lake Geneva. fields.headline: Cheers & jeers
fields.trailText: They're going potty in the Potteries following news that the government is spending £1.5m to help stem job losses and improve productivity in the ceramics industry. The move will help firms across the area, but mainly in Staffordshire where 20,000 workers are employed in ceramics.
fields.body:
They're going potty in the Potteries following news that the government is spending £1.5m to help stem job losses and improve productivity in the ceramics industry. The move will help firms across the area, but mainly in Staffordshire where 20,000 workers are employed in ceramics.

The crack is good in Belfast, too, where up to 250 jobs are on their way thanks to the Insurance Advisory Service which plans to set up a call centre.

The TUC is in good cheer after reading a survey which shows union membership has increased for the first time in a decade, with new recruits from service firms more than making up for losses in traditional areas such as manufacturing.

A ripple of applause is due to employment minister Tessa Jowell who has launched a reading, writing and numeracy initiative among young people joining the New Deal.

And finally, let's give Ted Taylor the day off for completing an astonishing 86 years at work without a single sickie. Ted, 98, has been working at a farm in the Cambridgeshire Fens growing cereals and vegetables since the age of 12. "It was bloody hard work," he says.

Thumbs down for the "boomerang" job market - a new study from the Institute for Social and Economic Research at Essex University reveals that one in five unemployed people are jobless again within a year of finding work. It also found that those who leave the dole queue to get a job are four times more likely to be laid off than those who move from another company.

A ticking-off, too, for ageist employers - another report, this time by the Employers Forum on Age says younger workers are held back because of ageism as much as older people. One in four said that despite having the right qualifications, they were not considered for some jobs because they weren't old enough.

A coughing, wheezing jeer to nasty old tobacco companies. A Euromonitor survey claims fag-makers are keeping cigarettes sales stable by targeting successful young career women with high-stress jobs.

And a final first class frown in the direction of Post Office bosses who sacked two postmen for not delivering junk mail during a stormy April day. Alan Arthur and David Hopkins only delivered letters and packages during heavy rain and left a firm's promotional circulars for another day. The result of an appeal is expected next week.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.standfirst: John Elkington
fields.trailText: Young people often ask what qualifications they need to succeed in the environmental and sustainable development fields
fields.body:
Young people often ask what qualifications they need to succeed in the environmental and sustainable development fields. Those who see environmentalists as doommongers must be surprised to find optimism topping the list. The reasons: pessimism is self-fulfilling and few professions so routinely expose practitioners to gloomy reality.

Economists, for example, once predicted that globalisation would bring economic convergence, with wealth cascading from rich to poor. Fat chance. In 1960, the income gap between the fifth of the world's population living in the richest countries and the fifth living in the poorest countries was 30 to 1. By 1990, that gap was 60 to 1. By 1998, it had reached 74 to 1.

Some 80% of the world's population live in the developing countries and 95% per cent of the next generation's children will be born to women living there. And 70% of those women live on less than $1 per day. The World Bank reports that three billion now live on less than $2 a day. It predicts that unless this problem is solved five billion will live on less than $2 a day by 2030.

The divide between haves and have-nots is dramatically illustrated by the fact that if you combine the wealth of just three billionaires - Microsoft co-founders Bill Gates and Paul Allen and Berkshire Hathaway's Warren Buffet - their net worth (before recent market falls) equalled the combined GDP of the 41 poorest nations and their 550 million people. Whether or not Microsoft is broken up, Gates is predicted to become a trillionaire by 2005, with his holdings topping $1 quadrillion (or one million billion dollars) by 2020.

Happily, another Gates is on the case. In Democracy at Risk (Perseus, $25.00), Jeff Gates of the Shared Capitalism Institute notes that "it's simply not true that the benefits of development are trickling down when it's clear that they're gushing upward at a fast-accelerating pace". He quotes the UN Development Program's sobering conclusion: "Development that perpetuates today's inequalities is neither sustainable nor worth sustaining."

Yet the bill for sustainable development could be remarkably cheap. Gates estimates the cost at just one-seventh of 1% of world GDP. Worryingly, however, financial experts warn that the wealthy are escaping the taxes that might pay for progress: at least $8 trillion has been hidden in tax havens in an estimated 1.5 million offshore corporations, up from just 200,000 in the late 80s.

Compare that to the $300 billion which environmental experts believe is needed each year to put the planet on a more sustainable footing.

The good news, Jeff Gates says, is that markets and democracies are learning systems. If we really want sustainable development, it's within reach. But a key to progress will be the widespread adoption of more inclusive property ownership patterns. Among the solu tions he proposes are "ownership impact reports" to ensure that his namesake Bill and his ilk are held more accountable, and a number of schemes by the major financial markets to channel funds to developing countries.

Of the current US presidential candidates, only Ralph Nader is paying attention. But Bush and Gore be warned: if Gates were standing for global office, it could be a landslide.

John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (website: www.sustainability.co.uk.) Jeff Gates is president of the US-based Shared Capitalism Institute (www.sharedcapitalism.org).

webTitle: Finding out what you have in mind

fields.headline: Finding out what you have in mind
fields.standfirst: As Oxford Professor Alan Ryan calls for psychometrics to be used to end the admissions row Wendy Smith talks to Robert McHenry; a fellow don who has made his fortune from the technique
fields.trailText: As Oxford Professor Alan Ryan calls for psychometrics to be used to end the admissions row Wendy Smith talks to Robert McHenry; a fellow don who has made his fortune from the technique
fields.body:
If you've been for a job interview recently and had to do a tricky psychometric test, the chap to blame is Dr Robert McHenry - he probably had a hand in dreaming up the questions and juggling the boxes which, depending on how you perform, will determine that job offer.

Dr McHenry, a former don at Oriel College Oxford, has made a tidy living out of testing the mind. He is chairman and owner of Oxford Psychologists Press (OPP) which in the past 13 years has grown from three people working in a room of his house to an establishment of 70 staff based in downtown Oxford.

OPP not only provides psychometric tests to industry (they reckon to have worked with two-thirds of FTSE100 companies) but has developed and introduced new tests.

These include the ABLE series, which test the ability to learn and adapt rather than just measure intellect. The company also has a consultancy arm, Sigma, which provides business psychology advice in the UK and overseas.

Psychometric tests are all the rage as human resources departments try to sort the wheat from the chaff. OPP has certainly flourished in this environment. Turnover has shot up and is forecast to exceed £7m. Today it may be Oxford and new offices; tomorrow, more collaborations and even more business.

Back in the 80s, when psychometric tests were seen as new-fangled and daunting and "something that they did in personnel", it was just the graduates and senior managers who had to go through their mental paces. Now, reckons Mr McHenry, many companies are keen to refine their recruitment processes and to get it right will test up to 70% of the workforce before any job offer or internal promotion.

Successful as all this sounds, one might wonder what it was that drove him from the dreaming spires of academia to the rough and tumble of being owner-manager of a start-up company. Possibly age. "I got to 40 and I thought: 'If I don't do it now and leave all this behind I never will.' " He started his academic career as a psychologist at Oxford in 1975, looking at the measurement of differences in people which was then tested by IQ tests, mainly in school. He wanted to apply this system to industry but it was not regarded as a trendy enough area and money was in short supply.

But by the 80s, with the increase in numbers of graduates and a falling off of matching jobs, organisations began to see the value of psychometric testing: it became the in thing. Mr McHenry had a solid base of consultancy work and money behind him to bankroll him through the first year.

But in going it alone it also helps if you have a partner to share some of the burdens of a brave new venture. A near bicycle crash provided a big break for Mr McHenry's fledgling business. "Just as I was planning the leap, I literally bumped into a former psychology student of mine, Betsy Kendall," he says. She was working as a journalist on a local newspaper and possessed the IT skills that he desperately needed. "She understood and could apply my tests and she wasn't frightened of the IT."

They began by distributing the best quality tests they could find. Their best-seller was their adaptation of the Myers Briggs personality test. "We spent at least £500,000 rejigging it to suit the UK market," Mr McHenry says. Initially he acted as a consultant, but in 1988 he approached an American test publisher to see if he could adapt and sell one of its tests. Permission was granted to sell all of its tests, and that's how he got into test publishing.

Not even the recession of the early 90s could stop his Oxford Psychologists Press juggernaut. Between 1991 and 1997, while practically every other industry (apart from loss adjusters) was suffering, the market for psychometric testing, paradoxically, grew by 15% a year. OPP grew at an even faster rate. It started getting a bite at both ends of the personnel department's cherry, with employers using psychometric tests for both recruitment and outplacement activities.

Mr McHenry doesn't believe that demand for psychometric tests will slacken off and retains an almost evangelical approach to his chosen field. "My deep knowledge of the theory of testing has given me the desire to make a difference in the workplace," he says. "We are getting a lot of interest in our work from the US. The UK has the most advanced testing published that we have seen but we can't be complacent. There's still a lot more work to be done."

So next time you go for a job, watch out for the new improved brain measurers - and remember who's responsible.
