fields.headline: Talking heads: Rowan Gormley
fields.standfirst: Managing director of Virgin Wines, which hit the web this week
fields.trailText: Managing director of Virgin Wines, which hit the web this week
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

Five years ago, the day we set up Virgin Direct. Prior to that I had always worked in collegiate organisations.

What has been your best moment in management?

The day I realised that you don't have to be good at it to be a good leader.

What was your greatest mistake?

Not investing in a small start-up company run by an American college kid selling PCs direct over the phone. The company is now called Dell Computers.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Bought into Dell at the start.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Lack of self-belief - it amazes me how many talented people who have delivered time and time again always need to be told that they can do it.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

Absolutely not! The only glass structures we have hold our wines.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

The value of experience over enthusiasm and energy.

What one lesson would you pass on to young managers?

Have a small team of very good people.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Jim Collins and Jerry Poras - the authors of Built to Last.

Who is your management hero?

The late Akio Morita, founder of Sony.

Who is your favourite politician?

Nelson Mandela.

How much were you paid last year?

£250,000.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"I have an idea."

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Closing a deal where both sides get something.

What annoys you most?

The way that Britain lets the rest of the world get ahead while ignoring talented people. And working practices that look backwards.

How do you relax?

Tennis - and letting my three kids beat me up!

What was your last cultural experience?

Opening a bottle of Villa Maria Sauvignon blanc for Sunday lunch.

What is your favourite city?

Cape Town.

What is your greatest regret?

Don't have one.

What is your biggest fear?

My assistant, Helen, leaving me!

webTitle: A wider approach brings out the best

fields.headline: A wider approach brings out the best
fields.standfirst: Eileen Sheridan reports on the winning entries as the recruitment advertising industry saluted its top talent this week at a Millennium Dome gala evening
fields.trailText: Eileen Sheridan reports on the winning entries as the recruitment advertising industry saluted its top talent this week at a Millennium Dome gala evening
fields.body:
Readers of the British Medical Journal and Nursing Times must have drawn more than one breath when they found a page shot with bullet holes and scorch marks inside their professional publications.

And medics were the target. The black and white battle-scarred page was a punchy recruitment ad for medical professionals to join the Territorial Army. Saatchi and Saatchi's ground-breaking advertisement for the TA and the Central Office of Information was a winner in every way.

This week it carried off the Grand Prix d'Or at the Institute of Personnel and Development Recruitment Advertisement Awards which The Guardian has sponsored for the past six years.

The advert also succeeded in generating more than 1,000 professional skills matches with 200 enlistments to the Territorial Army.

This was the first time the TA had looked to enlist people with medical skills and it reports that many highly qualified and motivated people are still in the pipeline as a result of the advert.

Helen Rosethorn, managing director of Bernard Hodes and chair of the 42-strong panel of IPD Awards judges, says: "It was nice and simple, but very clever and showed attention to detail."

The line of the advert was to punch home the message that medics working out in the field for the TA might face the challenge of being under fire in the same way as the people they were helping.

"It was black and white so it was cost effective," comments Rosethorn. "It gives you great heart that pieces of work like that are coming through."

The aim behind the IPD Recruitment Awards is to encourage agencies and their clients to be aware of wider audiences when they recruit, take diversity into account and make an effective pitch in the ever more competitive field of finding good people.

"Recruitment ads and awards for them are clearly valuable," says Rosethorn, whose own agency also captured two this year. "Agencies and consultants exist to meet their clients' requirements and in the war for talent today being able to recruit better than the next is pivotal."

Awards also convey recognition for good work and the client gets a buzz from the process, too.

Rosethorn says she is particularly pleased that this year saw a wide spread of agencies among the winners, a contrast to last year when Saatchi's and the Army dominated. Outstanding for Rosethorn was Stafford Long's "The management is not responsible" internal recruitment campaign for amazon.co.uk

"It was very innovative and it was particularly refreshing to see an internal recruitment scheme win," she says. "It really demonstrated tremendous lateral thinking and reflected the culture of amazon. The judges clearly warmed to this."

This year the awards covered 15 categories and saw some changes reflecting developments in recruitment, says the IPD committee chair, Anne Riley.

The campaign category was split into two - single campaign and multi-media - to enable fairer comparisons to be made between similar media.

"Other changes are that the broadcast media now stands alone and a revised category covering recruitment brochures, direct mail and support material has been introduced," she adds.

The shortlisted entries for this year's Diversity Awareness Award showed that organisations are now moving away from mere tokenism and are coming up with some effective solutions to recruiting a diverse workforce.

"Having seen a number of awards ceremonies I have to say it is getting better all the time," says the IPD's adviser on equal opportunities, Dianah Worman. "Work shortlisted for the diversity categoriy is showing increasing creativity and what comes across is that organisations are working hard to reach people they have not reached before. The entries did not trivialise and there was an absence of tokenism."

TMP's work for the Metropolitan Police and Saatchi's for the COI and Army were very imaginative, Worman adds.

She was also struck by work done for Pret a Manger by an agency new to the IPD awards this year - And Advertising. It won two categories and two finalist nominations.

"Pret a Manger were very humorous and reflected the culture of the company."

Worman notes that ads are more real in their approach and says in the current economy the challenge of attracting good people is greater. "The entries had the ability to attract and hold attention."

The judging panel was drawn from representatives from all parts of the industry. Personnel practitioners, creative directors and agency heads were picked to ensure they reflected views from the client and the agency side of the business.

"There has been a lot of work by the Guardian and the IPD to make the exercise of selecting the best and we have seen the fruits of that work come through," says Helen Rosethorn.

Charter marks new era for the Institute

Today sees the Institute of Personnel and Development enter the premier league as the first professional body in the 21st century to gain chartered status.

Six years ago when the Institute of Training and Development and the Institute of Personnel Management joined to become the IPD one of the new body's main aims was to gain chartered status, explains spokesman Nick Isles.

"Receiving Charter status means we are a 'must consult' body now," he adds.

The process of gaining a charter is an arcane one in which an institute must prove to the Privy Council and the Charity Commisssion that it holds a distinct body of knowledge and leads in its professional field. Its standards and qualifications must also have been tested and proved to be of high quality.

Director general Geoff Armstrong says: "Gaining chartered status means recognition at the highest level of the standing and status of the CIPD and its members."

The CIPD, says Armstrong, is committed to improving the quality of life through helping its members to do their jobs better and working closely with Governments at national and European level to help their economies grow.

"The profession must grab the opportunities presented by the knowledge economy," he says. "It means being the eyes and ears of the customer inside the organisation, constantly translating into action what will delight customers.

"It means listening to people and building cultures that respect their diverse needs and contributions and not just treating them as disposable resources."

Armstrong emphasises that the key to success for companies lies in creating cultures that attract and retain talented people. The CIPD, he says, represents the people profession which will design the architecture and build the practices which will deliver this.

"The world of work has become more turbulent. Taking advantage of uncertainty, looking for opportunities to wrong foot comeptitors by transforming again and again the way things are done is central to business strategy," says Amrstrong. "That requires capacities that go far beyond traditional approaches to managing and developing people. 'Can do' people at all levels are essential. But so are supportive organisational learning and development cultures which need to be led and managed."

The CIPD has more than 100,000 members who specialise in the management and development of people. It organises the recruitment advertisement awards with The Guardian to encourage agencies to be creative and aware of appealing to a diverse audience in their work, as well as promoting even higher levels of professionalism.

fields.headline: Season's greetings go into cyberspace
fields.standfirst: Christmas charity Cards for Good Causes won the Management Consultancies award last year for its first online campaign. Will White reports
fields.trailText: Christmas charity Cards for Good Causes won the Management Consultancies award last year for its first online campaign. Will White reports
fields.body:
Each year the Management Consultancies Association holds an awards ceremony to highlight the best consultancy projects by member firms in the UK in the previous 12 months.

The 1999 winner in the category of e-consulting was a unique partnership from Horwath Consulting and the charity Cards for Good Causes. Not only was it the first time that an e-consulting award had been made, but it was also the first time in the history of the competition that a prize had been given to a consultancy working with a client in the not-for-profit sector.

The client, Cards for Good Causes, founded in 1959, is owned by 28 well-known charities. In 1998 it sold more than £5m worth of Christmas cards via traditional outlets of churches and church halls.

As with every other sector, the marketplace for charities selling their products online is becoming very competitive. By the summer of 1999 US-based organisations were already offering Christmas cards for sale on the internet. It was crucial for Cards for Good Causes to stay ahead of its competitors and be market leader in this field.

At the same time, Horwath Consulting was keen to add value to its existing clients, many of whom are in the not-for-profit sector, by promoting original web-based consulting solutions. Both parties agreed in September 1999 that a new website co-ordinating the 28 suppliers of cards and connecting them directly with their customers had to be in place by November.

People buying online products, even Christmas cards, are usually pressed for time and the site had to reflect this. Michael Caudrey, managing director at Horwath, says: "It was essential that the selection and purchase of cards should take no more than two clicks of the mouse".

Nor was there any point in using expensive technology which would put off average customers by excessive download times. Design had to be crisp and individual cards easily viewable. As Cards for Good Causes points out, 90% of card purchase decisions are made on the basis of what individual cards look like. Fewer than 10% of customers are loyal to a particular charity.

Clearly, as the demand for Christmas cards is seasonal, the design, implementation and success of the project were time-critical. Horwath was able to keep to the deadline and the site was functional from early November.

Traditionally, cards have only been sold for cash. Over the web, credit card payments had to be practical. But because of the time pressures and the fact that banks have traditionally been slow in setting up credit card payment facilities it was decided to outsource the payment system to a third-party bureau service. The charity plans to deal directly with the banks next year and save on the transaction costs associated with outsourcing.

Having a well-designed, operative and effective website is not enough. As Mike Caudrey explains: "There are two popular misconceptions about the internet: the first is that if you build a website, people will come and visit it; the second is that search engines are effective." Unfortunately, there are around 60m websites in cyberspace and many of the leading search engines are either simply not able to keep pace with the exponential growth of the Net or will only accept money to move the site to the top of any search list.

Having a modest budget, Horwath turned down the more expensive internet advertising route. Instead it relied on a PR hook by inviting media celebrities associated with the various charities involved to the official launch of the site, as well as arranging an online auction on lastminute.com of a Christmas card signed by rock group Queen.

A number of related addresses to www.cardsforcharity.co.uk were also registered so that users were automatically re-directed from a number of sites like www. cardsforgoodcauses.com and several others. Clearly this helps with the flow of visitors who are trying to guess the proper site address.

Cards for Good Causes was delighted with the effective and rapid response of Horwath to the original proposition. Horwath believes that the site is a good model for a future trend: charities working together to provide a single point of contact to the public. It was a good experience for the consultants too, as Caudrey explains: "It was great to work on a project where we had to deliver very tangible results and, at the same time, help so many good causes."

The feeling of win-win permeates the project as Judith Rich, CEO of Cards for Good Causes sees: "Against enormous time pressures and with a seemingly endless list of things to bring together, I was delighted with Horwath's expertise and their pragmatic, let's-make-it-happen approach."

Last year the number of cards sold by the group was up by more than 10%. Horwath believes the vast majority of that was due to sales over the internet. This year, at the first Christmas of the new millennium, both charity and consultancy believe this success will be built on from a market leading position. In its 40th anniversary year Cards for Good Causes is in good shape to face up to the e-economy.

Will White is deputy director of the Management Consultancies Association. More information on the Best Management Practice Awards and the MCA itself can be found on its website www.mca.org.uk

webTitle: Diplomats deny back-room talks with Philippine rebels

fields.headline: Diplomats deny back-room talks with Philippine rebels
fields.trailText: European and Malaysian diplomats yesterday strongly denied mounting accusations that they have given up on Manila's negotiators in favour of dealing directly with the Islamic rebels who have been holding 20 mostly foreign hostages in the southern Philippines for 10 weeks.
fields.body:
European and Malaysian diplomats yesterday strongly denied mounting accusations that they have given up on Manila's negotiators in favour of dealing directly with the Islamic rebels who have been holding 20 mostly foreign hostages in the southern Philippines for 10 weeks.

But they said there seemed little prospect of a speedy resolution to the crisis that began on April 23 when members of the Abu Sayyaf Muslim separatist group seized the holiday-makers from the Malaysian resort island of Sipadan and took them to the remote Philippine island of Jolo.

Amid all the bickering, the health of some of the hostages continues to deteriorate; Abu Sayyaf's commander, Galib Andang, said yesterday that one of the two South African hostages, Monica Strydom, had suffered a miscarriage two days ago. The others were said to be "not in good condition".

The captives have been split up and the non-Asians have not seen a doctor for more than two weeks.

The Malaysian foreign minister, Syed Hamid Albar, said yesterday that his government was still supporting the efforts of the Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, to free the South Africans, eight Malaysians, three Germans, two French, two Finns, two Filipinos and one Lebanese.

"You can't simply negotiate outside of the ambit of the Philippine government because it is in the Philippines' territory," the foreign minister said. "So at the end of the day, it is the Philippines that has to be involved."

Germany's ambassador to the Philippines, Wolfgang Goettelmann, said he had "assured the Philippine government we have full confidence in them and their efforts".

Speculation about back-room deals and multi-track negotiations began at the weekend when Abu Sayyaf suddenly released one Malaysian "as a sign of good faith", amid reports that Malaysian businessmen and diplomats had been involved.

On Wednesday the Philippine vice-president, Gloria Arroyo, issued a controversial statement after meeting the French, German and Finnish foreign ministers in Poland. She said the ministers told her that the Malaysian's release "has put pressure on their governments to likewise effect the release of their nationals using back channels".

Mr Goettelmann admitted that in the past few days "many people have been offering their services to us as negotiators". But he said his government "could not take them seriously as they are mainly businessmen who just want to make a profit".

"The problem is that the [kidnappers'] key leaders cannot agree among themselves. The bottom line for the actual kidnappers is a ransom. But so many other, more ideologically motivated, people have joined in. This means the outlook is not good."

fields.headline: The common touch
fields.standfirst: Clacton comes over all coy
fields.trailText: The Clacton Common shopping centre, Essex, it was reported this week, is changing its name. It is getting rid of the Common - a word, it has been decided, which tends to deter middle-class shoppers. Suggesting as it does a hopeless confusion between common defined as vulgar and common defined as belonging to more than one, this represents a deplorable surrender to prejudice, which may even be counter-productive.
fields.body:
The Clacton Common shopping centre, Essex, it was reported this week, is changing its name. It is getting rid of the Common - a word, it has been decided, which tends to deter middle-class shoppers. Suggesting as it does a hopeless confusion between common defined as vulgar and common defined as belonging to more than one, this represents a deplorable surrender to prejudice, which may even be counter-productive. Many people in Essex would tell you that the kind of middle-class people deterred by the word Common would probably find the word Clacton even more alienating. That will certainly be the view not far up the coast at Frinton.

Nor is it the case that the designation Common is commonly found affronting by middle-class people. Ask estate agents in south London. Which is the better address: Wandsworth, or Wandsworth Common? Clapham Common, or Clapham generally? Estate agents sometimes balk at apparently awkward names, digging something more picturesque out of the archives and slapping an Old in front of it. But most residents of all classes who live in places with mildly unfortunate names seem ready to stick with them. Mucking, which is also in Essex, seems happy enough with Mucking. No image consultant would ever have chosen a name like Grimethorpe for a mining village just outside Barnsley, yet no one yet has suggested changing it to Belle Vue. And Pratts Bottom, Kent, has clung to its name in spite of knockers and mockers.

Much the best course in these matters is that adopted by a 19th-century prime minister when the people of Rugeley, Staffordshire, petitioned to change its name on the ground that the place had become indelibly blighted by being so closely identified with the notorious poisoner, Palmer. By all means go ahead, he replied: but on this condition - that you change the name to mine. The prime minister's name was Palmerston.

fields.headline: Mr Blair aims off (again)
fields.standfirst: An unusual treat for German theologians
fields.trailText: In politics, as in other spheres of professional life, thinking on one's feet is a cherished skill. We like a politician who can ad lib a clever response. But our admiration for instant thinking does have its limits
fields.body:
In politics, as in other spheres of professional life, thinking on one's feet is a cherished skill. We like a politician who can ad lib a clever response. But our admiration for instant thinking does have its limits. We would prefer the prime minister, for example, to come up with considered solutions to serious problems like street crime, ideas whose consequences have been thought through - not to make policy on the hoof.

Yet that is exactly what the PM seemed to be doing when he unveiled his latest brainwave yesterday. Standing before an audience of German theologians at Tübingen University, Mr Blair launched into a bizarrely inappropriate tangent on the loutish behaviour scarring Britain's streets, suggesting a new power for police to fine troublemakers on the spot - even frogmarching them to the cashpoint to pay the £100 penalty. It was a move so ill-judged that any one watching would have been tempted to reach an instant verdict of his own - concluding that Mr Blair had done "another WI," and made a grotesque error of judgement.

His first mistake was the same he made at the Women's Institute meeting: he misread his audience. The scholars and clerics of Tübingen can only have scratched their heads as they tried to connect the gospels with the car-clamping policies of British towns. Mr Blair was insulting them by hijacking what was meant to be a serious event in order to grab a headline on the evening news.

The second blunder lies in the initiative itself. The prime minister dismissed in advance any "left libertarian shock" at his wheeze - but that shock is legitimate. The idea of summary justice being exercised by police officers, able to punish citizens without a trial or defence is appalling. As Michael Mansfield noted yesterday, there is something Orwellian about police officers acting as monitors of social behaviour. Besides, police forces are already stretched and few have the numbers on the beat required to take on this extra task.

But the greatest error is that Mr Blair once again looks rattled. Whether he was trying to distract attention from his latest shift toward Europe or, more likely, seeking to match the Tories' ever more draconian responses to crime, the PM looked like a man unable to set his own agenda. Voters don't like governments that look panicky: they prefer a steady line. Mr Blair needs better speechwriters, better advice - and better instincts.

fields.headline: Bad reviews
fields.trailText: I read Michael Billington's article about Donald Sutherland's reaction to bad notices (We will not be muzzled, June 28) and I am on Mr Billington's side; a critic should call it as he sees it.
fields.body:
I read Michael Billington's article about Donald Sutherland's reaction to bad notices (We will not be muzzled, June 28) and I am on Mr Billington's side; a critic should call it as he sees it.

I have had my share of bad notices and have never replied to one. Often I have learned from them. I remember one in Paris which asked "Why allow this American barbarian to desecrate our sacred French heritage?" I hadn't yet given my recital and I did think it would have been more sporting to have put me on trial before leading me to the execution block.

I admire Mr Sutherland and his previous performances, especially in the film, The Day of the Locust, are what drew me to the theatre. But I found this simply a bad play. Had it not been for my respect for the actor I would have left at the interval. We who put ourselves before the public take risks every time we do so. We should be able to accept the penalties that accompany risk-taking.
Larry Adler
London

fields.headline: Britain's path to violence
fields.trailText: As a New Zealander who has spent time living in America and England, I agree with the US report which describes Britain as a violent society (Outrage as US TV brands Britain violent, June 29).
fields.body:
As a New Zealander who has spent time living in America and England, I agree with the US report which describes Britain as a violent society (Outrage as US TV brands Britain violent, June 29). Sure, most US cities have their violent quarter, where the underprivileged vent their frustration upon one another. But the British are without doubt the most aggressively inclined people I have encountered since leaving my homeland.

Take, for example, the ordinary activity of walking along the footpath. In Spain, France, Scandinavia and other places I have visited, people are courteous and considerate. In Britain people steamroll their way along the footpath with a fixed expression which says, quite clearly, "Get outa my way, cos I'm not getting outa yours!" If you're not quick enough to react, they will ram right into you. Occasionally, they will get all snarly-faced and say something threatening, like, "Wunna go, do ya mate!"

There is an incredible level of small-minded immaturity and spitefulness among British people. To do something which annoys the hell out of someone you have never even met is deemed an achievement. It is a cultural thing I have witnessed nowhere else except New Zealand. The major contrast appears to be the average level of education. There is an abysmal lack of emphasis on education in Britain and New Zealand. This creates a society of an ignorant, resentful majority and an arrogant, manipulative minority. It is taken as perfectly acceptable for people to drop out of school in their mid-to-late teens.

I found in America it was deemed important not only to have a university education, but to gain as many qualifications as possible in order to further broaden career options. Sure, America's gun laws are ludicrous. But most of America is a far more pleasant place to be. The people make it that way.
Quentin Poulsen
Rugby, Warks

 I would like to thank CBS News anchorman, Dan Rather, as his comments will reduce the number of American tourists this summer. I know our tourist industry relies on the dollar, but most are spent in American hotels and American-type restaurants anyway. Now, does anyone know a Japanese anchorman?
Kimball J Ormond
Keston, Kent KimballO@hotmail.com

 Charlie Whelan accused me, ITN and our counterparts at BBC News, of distorted reporting of the Euro 2000 violence (Twisted vision, Media, June 26). To take a lecture from a former spin doctor on objective journalism is a bit rich. Especially when it contains inaccuracies.

After a night's violence in Brussels between Belgian and Turkish fans, he claimed our editors in London were uninterested because they only wanted pictures of the English causing trouble. That simply isn't true - a fact Charlie would have realised had he watched my reports the next day. For all three bulletins on ITV, I made extensive use of the pictures of the violence in Brussels.

Charlie suggests only Radio 5 Live called the violence correctly. I agree with their judgment, this was not a riot - and if Charlie had watched my reports he would have heard me make exactly that point repeatedly. He clearly knows little of my output for ITN. He dismisses me as a correspondent "more used to covering diplomatic summits than football thugs". I refer him to my RTS award for covering the Marseilles riots during the last World Cup, and my reports from Copenhagen before last month's Uefa cup final.
Bill Neely
ITN Europe Correspondent

fields.headline: In the time of cholera
fields.trailText: What a snotty misrepresentation of a wonderful event (Creative Britons, June 28).
fields.body:
What a snotty misrepresentation of a wonderful event (Creative Britons, June 28). The six of us award-winners spontaneously came up with a creative idea - that is after all why we were being celebrated - and the Prudential honoured the gesture, magnificent. And as far as my company, Northern Broadsides lacking subtlety, so what! We won £100,000. Your reporting was as subtle as cholera.
Barrie Rutter
Northern Broadsides Theatre

 It is great to see Matthew Norman taking an interest in Mick Pugh (Diary, June 29), by far the funniest English comedian not on TV at the moment. No decent person would have the Guardian in the house, but I will pass your concern on to Michael. In the meantime, perhaps Matthew might care to take a look at some other fine but unfashionable turns such as Mick Miller, Keith O'Keefe, Johnnie Casson, Adrian Walsh and Blackpool's Buddy Lee.
Garry Bushell
The Sun

 I applaud the actions of motorists refusing to buy petrol for one day per week (Pump prices boycott, June 30). But I feel that to really make the point they should refuse to buy petrol seven days a week and get the bus instead.
Karen Leach
Birmingham
Karenish@excite.co.uk

 Perhaps William Hague should ask the Nissan workers if they would prefer their wages paid in euros or their unemployment benefit paid in pounds (Letters, June 30).
Margaret Jones
Ludlow, Salop
campbell@flaxford.freeserve.co.uk

 It was good to see the Dutch and Italian football teams playing a better class of rubbish than England ever could (Holland pay the penalties, June 30).
David Rainford
Manchester

fields.headline: Laddism in middle age
fields.trailText: Jim White's argument (They think it's all over, G2, June 29) is not only simplistic, relying as it does on icons who lost their talent a long time ago, but is also inaccurate in its attack on David Baddiel and Frank Skinner.
fields.body:
Jim White's argument (They think it's all over, G2, June 29) is not only simplistic, relying as it does on icons who lost their talent a long time ago, but is also inaccurate in its attack on David Baddiel and Frank Skinner. Both comedians became famous because they were talented. Their Fantasy Football series was hardly a hotbed of "laddism", as it took its subject seriously, while managing to make a football-hating female like myself laugh. Also, where is his evidence that Baddiel & Skinner Unplanned bombed? Everyone I know who watched the show thought it worked very well.

Next time you comment on a media construct -some young men will always act like morons - hopefully you will be more convincing.
Tanya Jones
Honiton, Devon

 Jim White overlooks a key factor about the promoters of the lad culture. Many working-class youth go through a passing phase of getting drunk on lager and acting in a noisy and occasionally anti-social manner, before adopting a more mature attitude towards life. The secret of the "lad" phenomenon is that it rests upon a bunch of middle-class men moving towards middle age trying to recreate the youthful times they never experienced. It's the modern version of slumming. There's a limit to the amusing ways that this can be palmed off as entertainment, which is why today's professional "lads" are finding their audience slipping away.
Paul Flewers
London

webTitle: Still life at the other Tate

fields.headline: Still life at the other Tate
fields.trailText: Your article on Tate Britain (Arts, G2, June 28) was intelligent and thought provoking, but misleading on two counts.
fields.body:
Your article on Tate Britain (Arts, G2, June 28) was intelligent and thought provoking, but misleading on two counts. First, the opening of Tate Modern does not lead to any uncertainty about the new role of Tate Britain - quite the reverse. Our remit to focus on the history of British art from c1500 to the present day is wonderfully sharp as well as properly inclusive. It will enable us to present in depth the works of acknowledged masters such as Gainsborough, Turner and Spencer, as well as on occasion to explore some outer realms - such as caricature or folk art - as part of our commitment to uncover art's place in wider aspects of British culture.

Second, while visitor numbers have dropped in June, this is hardly surprising - there has been immense interest in Tate Modern and Tate Britain's successful Ruskin, Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites exhibition closed on May 31, having comfortably exceeded our attendance expectations. We always experience a lull between exhibitions, and are thus delighted to be opening Intelligence: New British Art 2000 next week, and, just announced, a major William Blake exhibition this autumn.
Dr Stephen Deuchar
Director, Tate Britain

fields.headline: Discordant note on Glock
fields.trailText: I suppose we are now to be regaled with endless obituaries lauding the contribution of William Glock (Obituary, June 29).
fields.body:
I suppose we are now to be regaled with endless obituaries lauding the contribution of William Glock (Obituary, June 29). In fact it was Glock who instituted the regime which has killed off so many fine composers in this country. Great, he invited Nadia Boulanger over. I went to her as one of her star students and subsequently won the Lili Boulanger Memorial award for "composers of exceptional talent and integrity".

But, despite my array of awards (Royal Philharmonic Prize, Mendelssohn Scholarship), he did nothing for me. Nor, in the 14 years of his directorship of the Proms, did he once include a work by Benjamin Frankel, one of our finest postwar composers, Berthold Goldschmidt, Matyas Seiber, Franz Reisenstein, and other first-class composers.

Unless one adopts the right affectations and employs the right trendy gimmicks, one is persona non grata with the BBC - which is a tragedy because, in this little island, the corporation is the sole custodian of contemporary music. Even foreign artists who rave about one's work abroad get cold feet when they discover one's status with the Beeb.

Robert Simpson, that fine composer who was employed in the BBC music department for 28 years, said in The Proms And Natural Justice that under Glock it became possible for anyone to call themselves a composer, though having no musical talent of any sort. This country, which had such a wonderful reputation for music from the time of Purcell on, has been denigrated to an also-ran since Glock took over. So much of what we hear on the air is written by people who obviously have no idea of the principles of musical composition or the nature of musical material.
James Stevens
London

fields.headline: No access
fields.trailText: Richard Norton-Taylor has documented the Ministry of Defence's lack of frankness (Chinook cover-up continues, June 30).
fields.body:
Richard Norton-Taylor has documented the Ministry of Defence's lack of frankness (Chinook cover-up continues, June 30). Many people will assume the freedom of information bill will throw light on such issues in future. Unfortunately, all information obtained in connection with statutory inquiries, including military boards of inquiry, will be wholly exempt from the new right of access.

In many areas the information commissioner will be able to order disclosure of exempt information on public interest grounds, though ministers will be able to veto such orders. Even this limited provision is expressly excluded in relation to statutory inquiries. This is one of a series of defects which peers should address when the bill's long-delayed Lords committee stage eventually begins.
Maurice Frankel
Director, Campaign for Freedom of Information

 Richard Norton-Taylor does not state the reasons for not reopening the inquiry, but they are as valid as all the spurious reasons put forward to try to exonerate the two pilots. The relatives of the passengers have every right to be angry and Geoff Hoon is quite correct in dismissing calls for the inquiry to be reopened.
David Vernon
Southport

fields.headline: Chris Wagner
fields.standfirst: His groundbreaking research linked asbestos with cancer and changed the world of work for millions
fields.trailText: Chris Wagner, who has died aged 77, was an outstanding international authority on asbestos-related cancer. In 1956, while working at the South African Pneumoconiosis Research Unit, he conducted an autopsy on a black African miner thought to have died from tuberculosis. He later wrote: "On opening the thoracic cavity, I was amazed to find a huge gelatinous tumour." The tumour was a mesothelioma, and further examination of the lung revealed clumps of asbestos bodies. It was a finding that influenced the rest of his life.

Wagner was born in Pretoria, the elder child of Percy Wagner, one of South Africas's most distinguished economic geologists. Chris was six years old when his father died, and, perhaps not surprisingly, spent his early years in his shadow. He was educated at Michaelhouse, Natal, and, in 1941, went up to the University of Natal. In 1942, he joined the South African army, fighting in North Africa and Italy. His memory of that time was indelible - in particular of the events surrounding the battle for Monte Cassino. Back home again, he returned to Witwatersrand medical school, from where he graduated in 1951.

After Chris diagnosed his first mesothelioma, he conferred with colleagues and discovered that a group of similar cases had occurred at a tuberculosis hospital in Kimberley. He hypothesised that asbestos could be involved, and soon made a link with exposure to blue asbestos (crocidolite). This required some detective work, as many of the patients had never worked with asbestos but lived near the asbestos fields; others had left the areas while they were still children.

In 1959, Chris presented his findings to the pneumoconiosis conference in Johannesburg, where the audience included John Gilson, then director of the Medical Research Council's pneumoconiosis research unit (PRU) in Penarth, south Wales. Chris took Gilson to visit the mines and deposits in South Africa, and Gilson recognised Chris's exceptional knowledge of the asbestos then being imported into Britain.

The publication, in 1960, of his seminal paper, Diffuse Pleural Mesothelioma And Asbestos Exposure In North-Western Cape Province (written with CA Sleggs and P Marchand) became the most cited work in the field of industrial medicine, and put Chris firmly on the asbestos research map. It also led to his doctorate from the University of Witwatersrand in 1962.

That same year, at the invitation of Gilson, Chris moved to the PRU, and together they set about stirring up interest in the asbestos problem, an activity that culminated in a ground-breaking conference on the biological effects of asbestos, convened by the New York Academy of Sciences in 1964. Contrary to expectations, the British asbestos industry co-operated fully.

Chris was the first person to emphasise the association between blue asbestos and mesothelioma, and to set up a programme of research to investigate asbestos-related cancer. There were a few earlier case reports suggesting a possible link, but no one had attempted further investigations or considered the type of asbestos involved. Indeed, Chris had to work hard to persuade his colleagues that his research would be worthwhile. He succeeded and went on to prove that different fibre types, in different doses, have different effects on lung tissue. This research was pivotal in the introduction of safety standards and the banning of blue asbestos in Britain.

Chris liked nothing better than to collaborate with colleagues. His research workers were very proud of him, and he, in turn, was fiercely loyal to them. At the PRU, he contributed to projects in other fields and made original observations on the pathology of coalworkers' pneumoconiosis. He was a dominant, if unconventional, figure at research meetings, where he delighted in discussing his research with the international academic community.

Despite dyslexia, Chris had 85 original research articles published, along with many book chapters and reviews - though notwithstanding his success, he had dark moments of despair. Fortunately, he was widely read, and had both a prodigious memory and a talent for making lifelong friends, qualities which helped him to retain his equilibrium.

He received numerous accolades, including, in 1985, the Charles S Mott prize of the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation for "the most outstanding recent contribution related to the causes and ultimate prevention of cancer".

In 1985, Chris and his wife, Margaret, retired to Dorset, where he indulged his love of old stones, becoming a respected member of the Dorset Archaeological Society. He had a logical mind, a brilliant sense of humour and a zest for life. More than that, he left the world a safer place for the rest of us.

He is survived by Margaret, a son, two daughters and two granddaughters.

fields.headline: Frederic Cassidy
fields.standfirst: A life spent exploring the folk idioms of America and Jamaica
fields.trailText: The lexicographer Frederic Cassidy, who has died aged 92, described himself as a lexicolator or "word worshipper". He adored words and phrases - or folk idioms - made up by ordinary people to describe events around them. He specialised in finding the most exotic, and delighted in the strange sounds and often onomatopoeic quality of expressions rarely found in orthodox dictionaries.
fields.body:
The lexicographer Frederic Cassidy, who has died aged 92, described himself as a lexicolator or "word worshipper". He adored words and phrases - or folk idioms - made up by ordinary people to describe events around them. He specialised in finding the most exotic, and delighted in the strange sounds and often onomatopoeic quality of expressions rarely found in orthodox dictionaries. Two favourites were "honeyfuggle", a Kentucky word for flattering sweet talk, and a "flang dang", a Texan description of a loud party with music.

A white Jamaican, who moved to the United States as a child, Cassidy was as highly regarded as James Murray, the Scottish philologist who edited what became the Oxford English Dictionary. He spent decades collecting and investigating words and phrases in regional America for what was to become a five-volume work, the Dictionary of American Regional English, of which he became editor in the 1960s.

He expected to complete it by the end of the century, but, by last year, had only produced three volumes. Lexicography, he noted, "is not a rapid science". Volume IV is now expected in 2002 under the editorship of his successor, Joan Houston Hall, and Volume V in 2007. It will have covered 70,000 words and meanings with annotations on their origins and history.

Cassidy began with a list of 40,000 words, amassed over the decades by members of the American Dialect Society. He then spread the search to all 50 states, with researchers interviewing 2,752 people in 1,002 communities over five years, asking each one a list of 1,874 questions. These were required because the team found that people were not always aware that words or phrases they used were local and specialised.

A typical question would be: "What is a term used around here for a very slow person?" That brought 302 ways to described a "slow coach", or to use the more general Americanism, a "slowpoke". Similes were encouraged and these included "like coal tar running uphill", or "slow as fleas falling off a dead dog", and "slow as cream a-rising".

For something as ordinary as a household dust ball, Cassidy's researchers found "dust bunnies", "dust puppies", "dust tigers" and "collywobbles". In Knoxville, Tennessee, they discovered speakers referring to the jitters as the "fum-fidgets" and "hoo-daddles".

A personal favourite of Cassidy's appeared in a suburban Philadelphia newspaper, in an article about police troubles with "hoofties". The lexicolator traced its origins to the area's German community, and the word in German, hufte, which means hip. He concluded that "hoofties" were "hippies".

Cassidy rejected arguments that his folk idioms were not real words - because they were not standard - as little more than snobbery. "If a meaning is communicated," he wrote, "the word is real." And if he ever encountered a word with curious origins, he would say with relish: "Let's look it up."

The son of an accountant father and university professor mother, Cassidy grew up in Kingston, speaking two languages, standard English at home and Jamaican Creole in the community. When he was 11, the family moved to Akron, Ohio, and he gained a bachelor's degree in 1930, and a master's in 1932, from Oberlin College. In 1938, he received a PhD from the University of Michigan.

He began teaching English literature in 1939 at the Unniversity of Wisconsin and, although he retired a decade ago, he retained an office and directed work on the dictionary with 13 staffers. He returned frequently to Jamaica, and, in 1967, completed his first work, the Dictionary of Jamaican English. It had taken 16 years to finish.

His wife, Helene Lucile Monod, whom he met as a fellow student in Michigan, died in 1980. The couple had four children.

fields.headline: My word
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... plagiarism and just borrowing
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... plagiarism and just borrowing
fields.body:
Naturally, we are all against plagiarism, the most tainting of journalistic sins. The Oxford Dictionary definition of the verb, to plagiarise, is accompanied by the following cautionary quotation from Hazlitt, "If an author is once detected in borrowing, he will be suspected of plagiarism ever after." It is something lived down with difficulty. It leaves its mark not only on the plagiarist but also, unfairly perhaps (or perhaps not, we shall come to that), on the publication that provides the platform for it.

The OED definition itself is, "plagiarise: [to] take over and use as one's own (the thoughts, writings, inventions etc, of another person), [to] copy improperly or without acknowledgement." Journalists reserve the word only for major unacknowledged rifling of another's original work and refrain from using it for the minor uncredited borrowings that go on in journalism all the time. That would bring it too close to home. The two things, however, are at opposite ends of the same scale, a fact that should discourage feelings of self-righteousness when plagiarism is exposed, usually but not always because the author of the original work has complained.

Plagiarists, at their worst, are distinguished from their colleagues by their greed (some would say by their carelessness in failing to cover their tracks). When they raid the fridge they scoop up more than they can carry or eat, with a cry of "Mine." The others snack lightly and depart, taking care to sweep up the crumbs.

The situation is clearly set out in an American publication, Media Law by Ralph L Holsinger (2nd edition, McGraw-Hill), where he says, "Every reporter borrows from the work of other reporters. Reporters working on newspapers in areas served by more than one paper are asked by their editors to follow up stories clipped from competing publications... It's part of the game, and as long as a reporter doesn't take too much, too often, all is well."

It is my impression, however, that the media are developing in a way and at a pace which make plagiarism more, rather than less, likely to occur. It would be interesting to poll journalists with the question: do you think the amount of original journalism has grown in proportion to the increased space available to it? Has it been able to keep up with the physical expansion of newspapers? Or is the main growth taking place in the area of the quick cuttings job?

Journalists at the Guardian (I do not know that it is any different elsewhere) are often put under pressure to follow up a story, or to produce a piece, with no opportunity to make any inquiries of their own. Over-reliance on cuttings and now, even more to the point, the ease of electronically cutting and pasting from the internet, may be not simply attractive options, but the only options open to hard-pressed journalists in certain circumstances. Sometimes another day on a story that might have waited would have been a better option, and certainly better for the journalist's self-esteem.

One experienced journalist with whom I was discussing this suggested that instinct should tell us when we have crossed the line. The alarm bells do not always ring. One journalist had plagiarism thrust upon her in the form of a conspicuous passage from another newspaper written into her own by-lined story by an editor without consulting her and with no acknowledgement to the other newspaper. Despite the fact that we owned up to it immediately, it took a little effort to free the writer whose byline appeared on the printed piece from the unwarranted slur on her reputation.

To put it in perspective, in the two and a half years that I have been the readers' editor of the Guardian, I can recall only three or four complaints about the kind of excessive and unacknowledged borrowing that we might reasonably call plagiarism.

Journalists have to ask themselves not only whether what they are doing actually infringes copyright law but whether it is ethical; to put it another way, whether they are being fair to the author of the original work, whether they would be happy if someone else were making similar unacknowledged use of their work. The question the journalist is too often encouraged to ask is, "Can we get away with it?"

This is not journalism but anti-journalism. If you create a climate in which the cuttings job flourishes, then you have prepared fertile ground for plagiarism. A good thing for us all to remember, perhaps, is that if the availability of the internet makes it easier to appropriate the result of someone else's labours, it also makes it much more likely that we shall be found out. We do not want a journalist browsing the Guardian's website to discover passages of his own embedded in a piece of ours.

Journalists are theoretically independent inquirers dispatched on behalf of the rest of us to find out what is going on. We trust them to tell us in their own words.

webTitle: Put up, or put a cork in it

fields.headline: Put up, or put a cork in it
fields.trailText: I write to comment on your articles concerning corks (Pulling the plug, Society; Cork farmers attack supermarket 'lies'; June 28 ).
fields.body:
I write to comment on your articles concerning corks (Pulling the plug, Society; Cork farmers attack supermarket 'lies'; June 28 ). I have been drinking wine for 35 years and making it for 10 years and we at Camel Valley Vineyard in Cornwall have won many awards, both in national and international competitions. I have tasted "corked" wine on less than a dozen occasions. The so-called wine experts tell us that 10% of wines are "corked". This is, in my opinion, nonsense and in the only objective test of which I am aware 70% of so-called experts were unable to detect cork taint.

How can anyone in this day and age be conned in to believing that (cheap profit-friendly) plastic is preferable to natural sustainable cork? So, if any so-called wine expert would like to step forward to taste a random number of wines from any well known supermarket and put their reputation to the test with Corkwise, then the issue could be very quickly resolved.
Bob Lindo
Camel Valley Vineyard Bodmin, Cornwall

 Your article on the threat to the cork oak forests from the move towards plastic stoppers was welcome, but one of the loudest proponents of plastic has been your own Malcolm Gluck. You could make a real contribution to the preservation of a threatened ecosystem by persuading him of the error of his ways, if necessary by appropriate use of a plastic stopper.
Colin Campbell
Basingstoke, Hants
colin@campbell.datanet.co.uk

fields.headline: Sacred monster, national treasure
fields.standfirst: He is the most influential critic of the past 50 years and a champion of modern art. But he hates his own writing, would rather set up exhibitions and wishes the public would stay away from galleries.  Nicholas Wroe on the iconoclast who is an unashamed elitist
fields.trailText: He is the most influential critic of the past 50 years and a champion of modern art. But he hates his own writing, would rather set up exhibitions and wishes the public would stay away from galleries. Nicholas Wroe on the iconoclast who is an unashamed elitist
fields.body:
David Sylvester's influence on the post-war British art world is unparalleled, as art critic, installer and curator of exhibitions, and as an administrator. He wrote his first article about drawing for Tribune in 1942 when he was only 18. Now aged 75 - think Orson Welles for both his profile and effortless projection of rumbling gravitas - he has just published the definitive account of his friend Francis Bacon's career and staged an exhibition of his work in Dublin.

In the intervening years his role as confidant, adviser, interpreter and arbiter of taste has made Sylvester's contribution to shaping the artistic landscape unique. Because of his efforts the Tate has in its collection whole swathes of work that it could not possibly afford to buy today. It was he who almost singlehandedly alerted a hostile British artistic establishment to the importance of post-war American artists. He has sat for Alberto Giacometti and Francis Bacon and worked for Henry Moore. If anyone prepared the ground for the explosion of interest in contemporary art over the last decade it was David Sylvester.

"David is the only sacred monster that has ever existed in the English art world," says the artist Howard Hodgkin. "He has that kind of grandeur." Tate director Nicholas Serota first met him in the early 70s and says they have remained close. "He was a powerful influence in making me think internationally and has been enormously encouraging in terms of trying to acquire work for the collection. He is an incredible treasure for Britain."

The usually tight-lipped collector and gallery owner Charles Saatchi makes an exception for Sylvester and throws the dictionary at him. "David Sylvester is charming, crotchety, effusive, enigmatic, opinionated, receptive, vivacious, languid, sharp, romantic, perceptive and cuddly. He is the finest installer of art exhibitions in the land and his writing is so delicious he should be doing cook books."

With the recent opening of Tate Modern - categorised as Britain at last making its peace with modern art - this should be Sylvester's moment. For long periods his has been a lonely voice speaking up for the merits of modern and contemporary art. Now is his vindication. But far from celebrating the acceptance of contemporary art into the mainstream of British cultural life, Sylvester finds himself made gloomy by the prospect. "One really doesn't want to be in a gallery with more than a few people. This is the great problem with art. A big audience is no good for it."

His friends speak of an Eeyore-like temperament, edging towards melancholy. Added to this, in recent years his health has not been good. He had a heart attack in the early 90s and was diagnosed with cancer of the colon in 1998, for which he has recently undergone surgery. He also has diabetes.

But his glomy outlook and objections to the ongoing art boom come from neither physical nor psychological motivations. Sylvester's vision of what art is for, and its place in the culture, simply has nothing to do with latterday notions of Cool Britannia, people's art galleries or the veneration of "access". Last month he launched a devastating attack on the recent thematic hanging of the collection in Tate Britain - "like serving up a dish in which roast beef is side by side with grilled sole" - and he is appalled at the thought of the one-out-one-in admission system recently needed to regulate the massive crowds at the 19,000-capacity Tate Modern on London's Bankside.

"At these huge exhibitions, like the Monet in London, or the Vermeer in the Hague, they are so packed there is no pleasure in going to them." The idea of turning the other cheek as given in the Sermon on the Mount still seems a notion of extraordinary beauty."

His first school was Vernon House prep in Brondesbury, London. At 13 he went on to University College School in Hampstead whose alumni include four-minute miler Roger Bannister, former Tate director Alan Bowness, and Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail . "Vernon House was where I received all my education," he says. "UCS was just masturbation." At 15 he was asked to leave, before he had taken his school certificate. He spent a year buying and selling gold and silver to jewellers. "I made more money than I ever have since."

Coming from a family that dictated if he wasn't top of the class it was a disgrace, he cultivated his ambitions elsewhere. First he wanted to be a cricketer. When he realised he wouldn't be good enough he turned to jazz. "I wanted to be a composer and arranger. I listened to records in school, starting in 1934. I missed Duke Ellington at the London Palladium but did see Coleman Hawkins at the Phoenix Theatre." His introduction to art came at 17 when he saw a black and white reproduction of Matisse's La Danse. Jazz was put to one side as he painted 10 hours a day for a year before he realised, "I was no good at it".

Then, at 18, he submitted on spec an article on drawing to Tribune. It was published and soon after they asked him to review a French painting on loan to the National Gallery. He began to write regularly for the magazine under the mentorship of the literary editor George Orwell, although the editor, Aneurin Bevan, found his style too "heavy with Latinisms".

He had now embarked on a writing career, but it was war-time and the services called. He failed a medical for the army and became a teacher instead. "It was absolutely 'Decline and Fall'. I didn't even have the school certificate but they were desperate for masters. I loved teaching. I knew the mistakes made by people who taught me so I tried to be more understanding."

He started writing a book about the psychology of art and after the war nearly reactivated his academic career when he won a scholarship to Trinity College Cambridge to read moral sciences - philosophy and psychology. He chose the college because Wittgenstein was still teaching there, but before Sylvester even started he knew it was another career that was beyond him, and he didn't take up his place. He did think he could write about art, however. He is the only non-artist to be awarded the Golden Lion at the Venice Biennale but still admits to a lack of confidence about writing.

His friend Grey Gowrie, the former arts minister, says he can spend hours on the phone agonising over a single word or phrase. "If I didn't know better I would think I had a heavy breather," says Gowrie. "There can be what seems like 20 minute silence before he declares, 'it's David'. You assume he is going to announce imminent bankruptcy or news of a death, but it's usually a prelude to a fascinating discussion."

Sylvester has had two abortive sessions of analysis and says he has "wept on the couch at things that have been done to my writing by American editors. They have totally destroyed the rhythm of the prose and changed the meaning." Precise meaning is everything in a critical approach that is based on a scrupulous, obsessive attention to the work at hand. The art historian Frances Spalding has noted his, "dogged examination of his own sensations in front of art. Though he is often acute on the relationship between a work and the period in which it was made, he is less interested in history than physical presence; it is the impact a painting or sculpture makes on us that he tries to catch - how it affects the head, heart and guts."

Sylvester says his "fate was sealed" after watching Arsenal ver sus West Bromwich Albion in 1935. Arsenal won 4-1 and he went home and wrote a report on it. "That's been my life; seeing aesthetic experiences, other people doing the work, and then completing the experience by writing about it. The way I write is a bit like St Teresa of Avila writing about being fucked by God. I do try to describe the actual experience of looking at the work. "

A piece written about an installation by the American minimalist sculptor Richard Serra at the Tate in 1992 typifies this approach. The work consisted of two large steel blocks and Sylvester describes his experience as he approaches the work. He first thinks that the blocks are the same height and then, as he gets closer, he realises that this is an illusion. But how many other critics would then point out that what he had described only applied to people between five foot six and six feet tall? This is not mere pedantry but part of an intriguing observation about the subjectivity of our response to art. Serra says Sylvester has the ability to ask questions that other people don't.

Sylvester has maintained close links with artists ever since he visited Paris in 1948, where he met Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler, Picasso's dealer. Kahnweiler secured him an introduction to Giacometti whose work was then, "the one thing that seemed to matter". Sylvester became close to Giacometti and started writing about him. It is a sign of his assiduousness/prevarication that a book did not actually appear until 1994.

He briefly toyed with the idea of becoming a dealer himself because he so much admired Kahnweiler, but abandoned it when he realised that when a dealer sells something to a customer for a profit, "he genuinely feels he has done the customer a favour. I, on the other hand, felt as if I was somehow taking advantage of the buyer. But I suppose my primary emotion about every thing is guilt." He says he really would have liked to work for a rich person with a small private museum where he could do all the buying and installing. "I love using my eye to choose things and to install things. And I think it would have been rather good for anyone who asked me to do it as well."

In 1950 he met his wife-to-be, Pamela Briddon, a schoolteacher who was then a student at London University. They had three daughters, Catherine, who has two children and who Sylvester describes as, "a very good potter"; Naomi, who works as a publicist for a publisher; and Xanthe, who has one child and is a freelance sub-editor who worked for many years for Time Out. Pamela enjoyed art but was not as keen on contemporary work as her husband. They lived in a flat in Putney where Sylvester was a keen gardener, cultivating roses particularly. The three girls had to share a bedroom and Pamela, increasingly fed up with the lack of space, would take the children off on month-long camping holidays to Spain. When Sylvester bought a larger house in Wandsworth he kept the flat as his office. The marriage gradually came to an end over a period of years, with minimal trauma, say his children, as he spent more and more time at the flat and less in the new house. They eventually divorced in the early 80s.

He also has a daughter from a relationship with the novelist Shena Mackay, conducted while she was married to someone else. Cecily Brown was born in 1969 and now lives in New York where she is an acclaimed artist.

Sylvester says he is "neurotically preoccupied" with his daughters and is proud that he has good relationships with them. He had first met Mackay when she worked in his parents' shop. Cecily didn't know he was her father until she was 22. She used to see a lot of him but when they started going to art galleries together and she called him her best friend he began to feel uncomfortable. "I went to an analyst with Shena to discuss how to tell the family. We didn't want it to be too much of a shock to her sisters or to my daughters. I do most things wrong in my life but with regard to the timing of telling Cecily I think I did quite well."

From the mid 80s until late 90s his partner was the art historian Sarah Whitfield. He is still close to Whitfield and says he was virtually a step-father to her daughters Saskia and Sophie. "But now I'm just a lonely old bachelor," he says. "Sarah says it suits me."

His career as installer of exhibitions came about because of his relationship with Henry Moore, about whom he had written a couple of articles for the Burlington magazine. Moore asked to meet him and Sylvester became his secretary, but says, "it didn't work too well because while there was a pile of letters to be answered we would get involved in some aesthetic discussion". In 1951 the Tate staged a Moore exhibition which he was invited to curate. He had visited Wakefield with Moore, who had shared some ideas as to how sculpture should be shown. "Choosing and installing that exhibition excited me more than anything and it remains to this day the thing I like doing best." Sylvester's reputation as an installer extends beyond painting and sculpture. He has also been acclaimed for exhibiting Islamic carpets. "I don't feel I have a talent for writing, but when installing I feel at home in the way that someone who drives racing cars feels at home behind the wheel."

His approach hasn't changed much over 50 years. He likes to provide lots of space around works and acknowledges a tendency towards symmetry. It was once pointed out to him that at two separate sculpture shows he had, unconsciously, used exactly the same configuration. "This was my natural rhythm. I don't like my prose style but I do like my installations. If you're writing you see your own personality crystallised on paper and it is a horrible sight. But with an installation there is somebody else's great work and you don't look at the installation but at the work itself. But that work is combined with your rhythms."

He made his name as a writer in the 1950s and says one of his prime motivations was to counter the influence of John Berger, who was then setting the art critical agenda in the New Statesman.

"He was a brilliant writer, a compelling personality and a great force. I always envied his writing but I felt he was wrong," says Sylvester. Berger says now that they were "very fierce opponents", but while Sylvester didn't have an artist's eye, "he did have a collector's eye, and was one of the first people to realise what was new about very many artists and to explain it".

Sylvester objected to what he saw as Berger's promotion of a popular but "retrogressive" movement by some painters and sculptors as "back to the figure". In a satirical article Sylvester postulated a "Kitchen Sink School" of painters, noting that "the graveyard of artistic reputations is littered with the ruins of expressionistic painters whose youthful outpourings once took the world by storm." The label was almost instantly co-opted to describe the groundbreaking drama and fiction of the period.

Speaking up for modern art then was hazardous. Sylvester faced editorial pressure but says what sustained him was the force of his own physical experiences with art. "It was as if people were attacking fucking but you knew you enjoyed fucking. It was as simple as that. I got the most tremendous physical excitement from looking at modern art."

His habitual self-criticism and insistence on treating work on its merits as he sees it has meant he has never become boxed into critical positions. It was only in the 1980s that he changed his mind and decided that Picasso was a greater artist than Matisse. Howard Hodgkin once recalls him writing about a sculptor in the early 60s. "David said he was 'probably a very great artist'. A little while later he wrote about his next exhibition saying 'I thought he was the greatest English sculptor under 35 with red hair, but I was wrong'. The man's career never recovered. It might be completely apocryphal but it's still true somehow."

Alongside Sylvester's distaste for what he sees as recent populist developments in art he retains a faith in strong centralised institutions. "The BBC was a very enlightened patron of modern art. My talks with American artists in the 60s are invaluable documents. The interviews with Francis Bacon came from the BBC. We even did an interview with Giacometti in French. The treatment of art on television is now at a much lower intellectual level than it was in the 1950s." He dismisses anti-elitist arguments and complains that delegating power to the Arts Council regions has weakened arts administration. "There is an elite. But it is not rooted in class or wealth or privilege. At any one time there are only five or six people who can really spend public money well, be they right, left or centre."

Sylvester's politics were formed in the aftermath of the second world war. "I was to the left of the Labour Party but that changed after Czechoslovakia in 1948 [when the communists took control]. I didn't even wait for Hungary in '56. I saw that you can't get into bed with the communists without getting clap." He has since voted Labour, Liberal and Conservative, and briefly even had high hopes for the SDP. He says he is probably still a Gaitskellite because he maintains a belief in nationalisation, but Grey Gowrie sees him as a singular sort of floating voter.

"At the last election he said, 'I'm in an absolute rage. They've redrawn the boundaries and I don't want to vote Tory but I suppose I'm going to have to vote for Al Clark.' I said to him that it was a human right not to vote for Al Clark but David said, 'the problem is he is such a fucking good writer.' He might not have done it in the end but he did make me laugh."

Sylvester admits to voting Conservative in the 60s, when he lived in Putney, just to stop a man who would have been arts minister in a Labour government. But his politics and artistic leanings had been exploited some years earlier when he had been invited on a State Department-sponsored trip to America in 1960. In an odd sideshow to the cold war the CIA was covertly sponsoring the cultural magazine Encounter and promoting abstract expressionism as an example of western freedom. Sylvester is untroubled that he might have been used. "Jolly good for them. But no-one ever told me what to write or say."

His introduction to the American art scene coincided with his arrival in Paris. After going to a jazz club to see Charlie Mingus he was introduced to Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and Philip Guston. He later made contact with Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns. He says that, broadly speaking, over the last 40 years his primary interest has been contemporary American art.

He is currently editing his interviews with artists over this period. He has at the same time managed to produce, with Sarah Whitfield, the definitive five-volume catalogue raisonné of Magritte, not an artist you would normally associate him with. It was a monumental project and while he says he does love the work, "the fact remains that I spent years of my life, like Swann, on someone who was not my type".

Someone who very much was his type was Francis Bacon. Sylvester first wrote about Bacon in the late 1940s and they soon became friends. Sylvester was his self-appointed Boswell and undertook a series of landmark interviews in the 50s and 60s. The show currently on in Dublin is the fifth he has staged of Bacon's work. His new book about Bacon is dedicated to the composer Harrison Birtwistle who says that Sylvester's conversations with Bacon are among the most interesting things written on creativity. Birtwistle has dedicated a piece of music to Sylvester and says he is having a, "sort of intellectual love affair with David. Dedicating a piece to him was a way of describing our friendship." Sylvester has asked Birtwistle to read the cricket poem "At Lords" by Francis Thompson at his funeral.

Although he never staged a Bacon show during the artist's lifetime, every show since has taught Sylvester something new about the artist. The biggest revelation has been in Dublin. "I think the pictures look like 18th-century portraits in English country houses. And that is very true to Bacon's background. He had a typical upper-class background and grew up in Irish country houses. In Dublin, in these neo-classical rooms, the pictures look wonderful, they look like their true selves. Seeing them there it as if he has come home."

In his 1996 collection of critical essays, About Modern Art, Sylvester regretted the exclusion of artists born after 1945 on the same basis that he regrets, "becoming useless at tennis". But this is no slight to the BritArt generation. He says there are, "some seriously talented artists. I think Damien Hirst is pretty hot. Rachel Whiteread is a very good artist. Jenny Saville [who is painting him for the National Portrait Gallery] is very good, as is Douglas Gordon."

But whatever their strengths, Sylvester is adamant that encouraging queues of people to see their work is not the way forward. "Of course it is nice to see artists making some money," he explains. "So many of the artists from my generation struggled. But I think there is a price to be paid for it. I'm a bit ashamed of being the subject of a piece like this. It's a symptom of a bad state of affairs. You are only coming to see me because art is so popular but I wish there was less interest. Perhaps the answer is for art to become unfashionable and un-loved again."

 Francis Bacon in Dublin is at the Hugh Lane Municipal Gallery of Modern Art, Dublin, until August 31 Looking Back At Francis Bacon is published by Thames & Hudson at £29.95
