fields.headline: How to take a photograph
fields.trailText: Photography is the essential barrier that comes between us and our holidays. It gives us something to do when we're there and something to talk about when we get back.
fields.body:
Photography is the essential barrier that comes between us and our holidays. It gives us something to do when we're there and something to talk about when we get back. Taking a photograph frees us from the burden of having to experience anything. This is especially useful at sites of great natural or architectural beauty, as cameras have all sorts of filters, lenses and devices to make sure you're protected from any kind of direct aesthetic uplift.

To lessen the impact of these moments even further, it's best to get your friend Brian to stand in front of them and smile. In this way, you can go halfway around the world and come back with a fine collection of pictures of Brian. This is probably a good thing, as the people you show the photos to are generally more interested in what Brian is wearing than in the World Heritage Site he's obscuring.

Photos of groups looking happy are a favourite. Sadly, the quickest way of making a group look unhappy is by trying to take a spontaneous photo of them, especially if you take half-an-hour reorganising everyone, changing the film, etc. In group photos, it's vital that you have someone with his fingers raised behind someone else's head in an incredibly funny way; someone totally blocked by someone else, so that only their hair shows; the back of a stranger's head at the next table; and someone with blazing red eyes (NB, people who always have red eyes in photos are probably vampires).

Cameras are idiot-proof these days, except no one has found a way of keeping the idiot out of the picture itself.

There is a handful of people who look thin, radiant and gorgeous in all pictures - the technical term is photogenital. At the other end of the spectrum, you get the person who always looks like the photo has been taken with a special bad-hair, red-eye, squinting-doofer lens.

With modern cameras, a telephoto lens can make it look as if you're standing right next to a grizzly bear. The only way you can tell it's a telephoto shot is because you haven't got Brian in it smiling like an idiot.

Another useful innovation has been the disposable camera. These are cheap little cameras that you can use and then throw away without ever bothering to develop the 24 shots of Brian. Top-of-the-range digital cameras allow you to manipulate the image after you've taken it, so if you accidentally take a beautiful, well-composed, crystal-clear shot of something wonderful, you can always superimpose Brian later.

fields.headline: A sad hurrah
fields.standfirst: Sarah Kane's first play, Blasted, provoked outrage, but in the years before her suicide in  1999 she came to be recognised as an agonised, brilliantly poetic voice. All who knew  her are adamant that her work and life should not be confused, yet the parallels are hard to avoid
fields.trailText:
Sarah Kane's first play, Blasted, provoked outrage, but in the years before her suicide in
1999 she came to be recognised as an agonised, brilliantly poetic voice. All who knew
her are adamant that her work and life should not be confused, yet the parallels are hard to avoid.
fields.body:
When Mel Kenyon stood up to give a little speech at Sarah Kane's memorial, the words wouldn't come. She tried two or three times, before being defeated by her tears. In the end, she asked the crowd of friends and relatives at London's Royal Court to listen to a song for Sarah. Kane had killed herself just a couple of months before, and the raw sore of grief wept through the whole theatre. In a way, You Get What You Give, by the New Radicals, was crazily inappropriate. The song is an impassioned attempt to shake someone out of despair, to prove there is a reason to live. Sarah had done exactly the opposite - she had let go, she had given up. Yet the ecstatic tune - a rebuttal of all that was bleak and cruel and shitty in life, an affirmation of love and purpose against the odds - was somehow perfect.

Kane's death at 28 was big news. Just like her first play, Blasted, had been. The obituaries talked about the controversial nature of her work, stretched for their Roget's, and lasciviously listed, as journalists always had done, the shock elements - the fellatio and frottage, the micturition and defecation, the rapes and hangings, the eye-gouging and cannibalism. They also quoted the infamous headline, "The Disgusting Feast Of Filth", that accompanied Jack Tinker's review in the Daily Mail.

But this time the tone was different. The reports acknowledged the poetry, the tenderness, the classical traditions at play in her work. Many said that the world had lost the great dramatist of the 90s. In death, Kane's work (five plays in all, four of them staged during her lifetime) was finally being contextualised. There was a sudden posthumous consensus - the work wasn't hateful, nor was it about hate; it was about love. The impossibility of pure love. The newspapers even quoted Roland Barthes to help us understand the plays: "When one is in love one is in Dachau."

Blasted was first performed in January 1995, at the tiny Royal Court Upstairs theatre. It is set in a fancy hotel bedroom in Leeds. Ian, a middle-aged tabloid hack, seems to be dying and invites a trusting, retarded child-girl to make his last hours happier. She agrees to visit out of love, her desire to comfort him. He rapes her, taunts her, humiliates her. Halfway through the play, an armed soldier breaks into the room, wreaks his sickening destruction and turns the scene into a Bosnian battlefield.

Kane was subject to the most bilious of attacks. She was accused of "abject puerility", of subjecting an audience to the theatrical equivalent of "having your whole head held down in a bucket of offal". Charles Spencer, in the Telegraph, called Blasted a work "devoid of intellectual and artistic merit", and later suggested that Kane was mad. Michael Billington, in the Guardian, wrote, "I was simply left wondering how such naive tosh managed to scrape past the Court's normally judicious play-selection committee." Overnight, Blasted had become the Royal Court's biggest controversy since Edward Bond's Saved 30 years earlier, in which a baby was stoned to death. Even more astonishing was the reaction of established dramatists such as Harold Pinter and Bond himself, who rounded on the critics and told them they were out of their depth; Blasted was too new, too complex, too good for them.

Kane was notorious, a cause célèbre. In all, the play was performed in front of barely more than 1,000 people, and there has never been another production in Britain. But, like the first Sex Pistols concert, it has caused a strange form of false-memory syndrome. Many people believe they were there, and confidently tell the stories to prove it.

The playwright David Greig shared a flat with Kane at university in Bristol. He had already enjoyed some success in his early 20s, but he certainly hadn't made the news pages. "I saw her when the reviews were coming out, and said, 'You must be really pleased everyone's talking about you', but she really didn't feel that. Perhaps if it had been me, I would have revelled in it - maybe I'm a shallower person - but she felt devastated by the reviews. She found it really difficult that they were not taking her artistically seriously. In some way, Sarah was very arrogant. She knew Blasted was a very great work, and she found it devastating that that was not recognised."

Devastated. So many people use that word when talking about Kane. They talk about her love of Manchester United and of clubbing and chatting and laughing, but invariably they return to the word devastated. Some friends and family still don't want to talk about her in public. Eventually, more than a year after her death, some would - including her brother Simon and her agent Mel Kenyon, both of whom feel they owe a very special duty to Kane. Nothing was to be published until the first production of her final play, 4.48 Psychosis, had opened and the reviews had appeared. The danger, Kenyon and Simon Kane stress, is that we use the work to explain the life, regard it as a serialised suicide note. Or, even worse, we use the life to explain the work. Sarah Kane (and Kenyon and Simon, who finally decided to stage the play) could not be more exposed. 4.48 Psychosis was finished just before she died, and is about suicidal depression. If you know anything about her life, it is impossible to de-personalise the play.

I meet Simon Kane at the Royal Court, where 4.48 Psychosis is being rehearsed. He blanches at the suggestion that I might watch rehearsals, or read the play. He refuses to explain what the title means, and says he's going to leave it to the director, James Macdonald, who also directed the premieres of Blasted and Cleansed, to tell me about it.

Simon is 30, Sarah's older brother and the executor of her estate. Before I have a chance to sit, he lays down the law. "One of the things Sarah said in her last instructions was 'no biographies'." He also makes clear his own distrust of journalists, and explains it away as a family thing. Their parents were both journalists. While their mother gave up work to look after the children, Peter Kane went on to be area manager of the Daily Mirror for East Anglia. He had known how to invade privacy with a smile. "What she wanted to leave behind was her work. That's all Sarah was interested in people seeing, rather than a fairly uninteresting story of her life. Growing up with a journalist, you pretty soon realise you have to be careful what you say to people . . . Sarah was a very private person."

Simon Kane looks like his sister. But whereas she was handsome, boyish, he is pretty, girlish. He often blushes. He talks about how they grew up in Essex, how both of them were good pupils, keen learners. There was only a year between them, and in the early days they were competitive in a friendly way. After A-levels, Simon went off to study maths; a year later, Sarah began her drama degree. He says it would be easy to polarise the two, the artist and the scientist, but it would be wrong.

As children, they used to talk a lot, about love, about their hopes, about God. Especially about God. Throughout their early teens, God dominated the household. The four of them went along to an evangelical church every Sunday. In the few interviews Sarah gave, she described it as "the full spirit-filled, born-again lunacy", and railed against the naivety of her religious years.

Simon winces, and says the news reports gave the wrong impression. "At the time of her death, it came across in the papers as if Mum and Dad had forced this mad, cultish religion on us. It really wasn't like that. Of all of us, I'd say Sarah was the most fervent." He says their Christianity was one of compassion, love thy neighbour as thyself, rather than vengeance is mine. "If people had problems, Sarah would always listen and do whatever she could to help them out. I was aware of it as a child because I wasn't so much like that. I got to a point where I'd say, 'I'm sorry, I just can't deal with this,' and I don't remember Sarah ever doing that."

He says the religion was normal, just part of growing up, then seems to change his mind mid-sentence. "We went along to this church, and there were some peculiar people there. They did become quite extreme. They started reading the Bible very literally, and when you do that you're going to end up with some bizarre opinions. There are bits in the Bible that are atrocious - you know, like the treatment of female prisoners of war in Deuteronomy . . . 'If you want to take the woman rip her fingernails out and shave all her hair off'." He looks appalled.

Sarah became an atheist, her writing fired by the cruelties carried out in the name of God. "God, the bastard," was one of her favourite Beckett quotes. "I think she looked at the world around her, and thought it was unsustainable to think there is an all-powerful, all-caring God who made the world as it is," says Simon. By the time she was studying for A-levels, she was also busy directing Chekhov and Shakespeare at school.

Vince O'Connell, who went on to direct Kane's short film Skin, met her when she was 17 and acting in his play at a local drama group in Basildon. "She was very obviously exceptional," he says. A few months later, she was bunking off school, working as an assistant director in a production at Soho Poly. "She knew theatre, understood how it worked. It was instinctive. She had the ability to create a crackle in a room. She had that same ability as a person. Funny, empathetic, huge-hearted. She was gifted at living, more than anyone I've known. She had a massive appetite for life . . ." He lurches to a stop. "I know it's a paradox."

O'Connell tells me a story about Skin that somehow sums up Kane. The film is about a black woman who kidnaps a leery racist abuser and beats him into an adoring, submissive love. Ewan Bremner played the man, Marcia Rose the woman. The two had never met each other before Skin. They fell in love while making the film, and now have a child together.

Sarah Kane went to university wanting to be an actress. She then realised that actors were powerless, so she decided to direct. She then realised that there was hardly anything she wanted to direct, so she began to write. It's funny, says Simon, in some ways she was so unambitious, in others she knew exactly what she wanted and how to get it. "She was very determined and uncompromising.

She only ever produced work she was completely happy with."

Everyone who knew Sarah Kane has an anecdote. The world is full of Sarah Kane anecdotes. She was such a wild child, she savaged the drink, said what she wanted to, did what she wanted to. The strange thing is that all the stories ultimately boil down to one incident, when she was accused of writing pornography and threw a pile of porn mags at the feet of her tutor and told him that if he wanted to wank he should do it to these instead. Everyone tells the story a little differently. In some versions, she accuses the tutor of writing porn, in others he accuses her, and in some they both accuse each other. "It makes her sound very aggressive," says David Greig. "But it was done very sardonically, actually. Sarah was really very gentle. Really, really gentle. Very kind. You hear a story and conjure up a picture, but the reality of the way she'd be when you met her was so huge. The aggression wasn't an act, but there was a degree of playfulness about it."

Both Sarah and Greig were influenced by Howard Barker's modern Jacobean dramas - the extreme violence, the muscular language, the poetry, and dark black humour. At Bristol, they acted in the same production of Barker's Victory. Like Kane, Barker celebrated the perversity of love, embraced the terrible entwining of violence and tenderness. Greig says there is a quote in Barker's play, a definition of love, that best explains the ambiguities of Sarah's work. "I would crawl across four miles of broken glass just to take a piss in her bathwater." Obsession, sacrifice, love, pain, humiliation, loathing, all in the one act. Greig says they used to joke about how the names of their favourite writers all began with B - Bond, Beckett, Brecht, Berkoff, Barker. "All of them people who don't set their plays in the front room, who don't like kitchen sinks. And if they do have a kitchen sink, it will be filled with blood."

At Bristol, Kane stood out as an actor and director. Not yet as a writer. Her first substantial written work, a series of three monologues under the umbrella title Sick, was performed in Edinburgh. One was about rape, one about a woman questioning her sexual identity, and another about eating disorders. They were all performed in the first person, confrontational, and felt as if you were listening to first-hand experience. Greig, who performed his own monologue in the same pub that year, says, "It was very, very raw. It unsettled the audience. It didn't come across as particularly crafted." Greig thinks that this blurring of boundaries was intentional, a means of unsettling audiences, and that we should be wary of reading too much into the tantalising clues in her work. Kane later withdrew the monologues - disowned them, in effect - because she thought audiences regarded them as confessional.

Greig and Kane were part of an intimate circle of gothic miserablists. Student clichés, really, says Greig, laughing. They listened to Joy Division, dressed in black, raged against the slaughter in the Balkans. "We both shared a slightly depressive outlook, a whole group of us, who shared an enjoyment of the darker things - a post-adolescent dwelling on the question of life, if you like." Kane never lost her love for Joy Division, nor her fiery despair about the civil war in former Yugoslavia, but Greig believes the depression of later years was very different from the earlier angst.

There were many Sarahs, he says, with many different types of friends. She hated labels, especially those that defined her by gender or sexuality. Greig reminds me of an article she wrote for this paper, in which she discussed the 10 best shows she'd seen. Number two was a visit to a live sex show featuring a witch sucking the Grim Reaper's cock in Amsterdam: "Perhaps the power of that sex show in Amsterdam was more to do with the grass I was smoking than the stark images thrown together as an excuse to watch people fuck," she wrote. Old Trafford was her favourite theatre.

The director James Macdonald, who is now putting the finishing touches to 4.48 Psychosis, finally returns my call. He's apologetic, embarrassed. "I just feel talked out about Sarah. I feel rather boring on the subject." He's not very good at dissembling, and within seconds the truth is out: "I suppose I'm wary of her death creating the possibility of people looking at her work in the wrong way." He compares her to Sylvia Plath, and says just look at the way that her life is always refracted through the prism of her suicide. Not surprisingly, Macdonald feels vulnerable. Kane graduated with a first from Bristol and went straight on to David Edgar's playwriting MA at Birmingham University. Vince O'Connell says she hated the course, felt stymied by it. Her ideas were being squashed. She considered giving up, and completed the course only to please her mother - the enfant terrible of British theatre didn't like upsetting her family. fields.bodyText: When Mel Kenyon stood up to give a little speech at Sarah Kane's memorial, the words wouldn't come. She tried two or three times, before being defeated by her tears. In the end, she asked the crowd of friends and relatives at London's Royal Court to listen to a song for Sarah. Kane had killed herself just a couple of months before, and the raw sore of grief wept through the whole theatre. In a way, You Get What You Give, by the New Radicals, was crazily inappropriate. The song is an impassioned attempt to shake someone out of despair, to prove there is a reason to live. Sarah had done exactly the opposite - she had let go, she had given up. Yet the ecstatic tune - a rebuttal of all that was bleak and cruel and shitty in life, an affirmation of love and purpose against the odds - was somehow perfect. Kane's death at 28 was big news. Just like her first play, Blasted, had been. The obituaries talked about the controversial nature of her work, stretched for their Roget's, and lasciviously listed, as journalists always had done, the shock elements - the fellatio and frottage, the micturition and defecation, the rapes and hangings, the eye-gouging and cannibalism. They also quoted the infamous headline, "The Disgusting Feast Of Filth", that accompanied Jack Tinker's review in the Daily Mail. But this time the tone was different. The reports acknowledged the poetry, the tenderness, the classical traditions at play in her work. Many said that the world had lost the great dramatist of the 90s. In death, Kane's work (five plays in all, four of them staged during her lifetime) was finally being contextualised. There was a sudden posthumous consensus - the work wasn't hateful, nor was it about hate; it was about love. The impossibility of pure love. The newspapers even quoted Roland Barthes to help us understand the plays: "When one is in love one is in Dachau." Blasted was first performed in January 1995, at the tiny Royal Court Upstairs theatre. It is set in a fancy hotel bedroom in Leeds. Ian, a middle-aged tabloid hack, seems to be dying and invites a trusting, retarded child-girl to make his last hours happier. She agrees to visit out of love, her desire to comfort him. He rapes her, taunts her, humiliates her. Halfway through the play, an armed soldier breaks into the room, wreaks his sickening destruction and turns the scene into a Bosnian battlefield. Kane was subject to the most bilious of attacks. She was accused of "abject puerility", of subjecting an audience to the theatrical equivalent of "having your whole head held down in a bucket of offal". Charles Spencer, in the Telegraph, called Blasted a work "devoid of intellectual and artistic merit", and later suggested that Kane was mad. Michael Billington, in the Guardian, wrote, "I was simply left wondering how such naive tosh managed to scrape past the Court's normally judicious play-selection committee." Overnight, Blasted had become the Royal Court's biggest controversy since Edward Bond's Saved 30 years earlier, in which a baby was stoned to death. Even more astonishing was the reaction of established dramatists such as Harold Pinter and Bond himself, who rounded on the critics and told them they were out of their depth; Blasted was too new, too complex, too good for them. Kane was notorious, a cause célèbre. In all, the play was performed in front of barely more than 1,000 people, and there has never been another production in Britain. But, like the first Sex Pistols concert, it has caused a strange form of false-memory syndrome. Many people believe they were there, and confidently tell the stories to prove it. The playwright David Greig shared a flat with Kane at university in Bristol. He had already enjoyed some success in his early 20s, but he certainly hadn't made the news pages. "I saw her when the reviews were coming out, and said, 'You must be really pleased everyone's talking about you', but she really didn't feel that. Perhaps if it had been me, I would have revelled in it - maybe I'm a shallower person - but she felt devastated by the reviews. She found it really difficult that they were not taking her artistically seriously. In some way, Sarah was very arrogant. She knew Blasted was a very great work, and she found it devastating that that was not recognised." Devastated. So many people use that word when talking about Kane. They talk about her love of Manchester United and of clubbing and chatting and laughing, but invariably they return to the word devastated. Some friends and family still don't want to talk about her in public. Eventually, more than a year after her death, some would - including her brother Simon and her agent Mel Kenyon, both of whom feel they owe a very special duty to Kane. Nothing was to be published until the first production of her final play, 4.48 Psychosis, had opened and the reviews had appeared. The danger, Kenyon and Simon Kane stress, is that we use the work to explain the life, regard it as a serialised suicide note. Or, even worse, we use the life to explain the work. Sarah Kane (and Kenyon and Simon, who finally decided to stage the play) could not be more exposed. 4.48 Psychosis was finished just before she died, and is about suicidal depression. If you know anything about her life, it is impossible to de-personalise the play. I meet Simon Kane at the Royal Court, where 4.48 Psychosis is being rehearsed. He blanches at the suggestion that I might watch rehearsals, or read the play. He refuses to explain what the title means, and says he's going to leave it to the director, James Macdonald, who also directed the premieres of Blasted and Cleansed, to tell me about it. Simon is 30, Sarah's older brother and the executor of her estate. Before I have a chance to sit, he lays down the law. "One of the things Sarah said in her last instructions was 'no biographies'." He also makes clear his own distrust of journalists, and explains it away as a family thing. Their parents were both journalists. While their mother gave up work to look after the children, Peter Kane went on to be area manager of the Daily Mirror for East Anglia. He had known how to invade privacy with a smile. "What she wanted to leave behind was her work. That's all Sarah was interested in people seeing, rather than a fairly uninteresting story of her life. Growing up with a journalist, you pretty soon realise you have to be careful what you say to people . . . Sarah was a very private person." Simon Kane looks like his sister. But whereas she was handsome, boyish, he is pretty, girlish. He often blushes. He talks about how they grew up in Essex, how both of them were good pupils, keen learners. There was only a year between them, and in the early days they were competitive in a friendly way. After A-levels, Simon went off to study maths; a year later, Sarah began her drama degree. He says it would be easy to polarise the two, the artist and the scientist, but it would be wrong. As children, they used to talk a lot, about love, about their hopes, about God. Simon winces, and says the news reports gave the wrong impression. "At the time of her death, it came across in the papers as if Mum and Dad had forced this mad, cultish religion on us. "If people had problems, Sarah would always listen and do whatever she could to help them out. I was aware of it as a child because I wasn't so much like that. I got to a point where I'd say, 'I'm sorry, I just can't deal with this,' and I don't remember Sarah ever doing that." He says the religion was normal, just part of growing up, then seems to change his mind mid-sentence. "We went along to this church, and there were some peculiar people there. They did become quite extreme. They started reading the Bible very literally, and when you do that you're going to end up with some bizarre opinions. The two had never met each other before Skin. They fell in love while making the film, and now have a child together. Sarah Kane went to university wanting to be an actress. She then realised that actors were powerless, so she decided to direct. She then realised that there was hardly anything she wanted to direct, so she began to write. It's funny, says Simon, in some ways she was so unambitious, in others she knew exactly what she wanted and how to get it. "She was very determined and uncompromising. She only ever produced work she was completely happy with." Everyone who knew Sarah Kane has an anecdote. The world is full of Sarah Kane anecdotes. She was such a wild child, she savaged the drink, said what she wanted to, did what she wanted to. The strange thing is that all the stories ultimately boil down to one incident, when she was accused of writing pornography and threw a pile of porn mags at the feet of her tutor and told him that if he wanted to wank he should do it to these instead. Everyone tells the story a little differently. In some versions, she accuses the tutor of writing porn, in others he accuses her, and in some they both accuse each other. "It makes her sound very aggressive," says David Greig. "But it was done very sardonically, actually. Sarah was really very gentle. Really, really gentle. Very kind. You hear a story and conjure up a picture, but the reality of the way she'd be when you met her was so huge. The aggression wasn't an act, but there was a degree of playfulness about it." Both Sarah and Greig were influenced by Howard Barker's modern Jacobean dramas - the extreme violence, the muscular language, the poetry, and dark black humour. At Bristol, they acted in the same production of Barker's Victory. Like Kane, Barker celebrated the perversity of love, embraced the terrible entwining of violence and tenderness. Greig says there is a quote in Barker's play, a definition of love, that best explains the ambiguities of Sarah's work. "I would crawl across four miles of broken glass just to take a piss in her bathwater." Obsession, sacrifice, love, pain, humiliation, loathing, all in the one act. Greig says they used to joke about how the names of their favourite writers all began with B - Bond, Beckett, Brecht, Berkoff, Barker. "All of them people who don't set their plays in the front room, who don't like kitchen sinks. And if they do have a kitchen sink, it will be filled with blood." At Bristol, Kane stood out as an actor and director. Not yet as a writer. Her first substantial written work, a series of three monologues under the umbrella title Sick, was performed in Edinburgh. One was about rape, one about a woman questioning her sexual identity, and another about eating disorders. They were all performed in the first person, confrontational, and felt as if you were listening to first-hand experience. Greig, who performed his own monologue in the same pub that year, says, "It was very, very raw. It unsettled the audience. It didn't come across as particularly crafted." Greig thinks that this blurring of boundaries was intentional, a means of unsettling audiences, and that we should be wary of reading too much into the tantalising clues in her work. Kane later withdrew the monologues - disowned them, in effect - because she thought audiences regarded them as confessional. Greig and Kane were part of an intimate circle of gothic miserablists. Student clichés, really, says Greig, laughing. They listened to Joy Division, dressed in black, raged against the slaughter in the Balkans. "We both shared a slightly depressive outlook, a whole group of us, who shared an enjoyment of the darker things - a post-adolescent dwelling on the question of life, if you like." Kane never lost her love for Joy Division, nor her fiery despair about the civil war in former Yugoslavia, but Greig believes the depression of later years was very different from the earlier angst. There were many Sarahs, he says, with many different types of friends. She hated labels, especially those that defined her by gender or sexuality. Greig reminds me of an article she wrote for this paper, in which she discussed the 10 best shows she'd seen. Number two was a visit to a live sex show featuring a witch sucking the Grim Reaper's cock in Amsterdam: "Perhaps the power of that sex show in Amsterdam was more to do with the grass I was smoking than the stark images thrown together as an excuse to watch people fuck," she wrote. Old Trafford was her favourite theatre. The director James Macdonald, who is now putting the finishing touches to 4.48 Psychosis, finally returns my call. He's apologetic, embarrassed. fields.headline: Life on fast forward
fields.standfirst: Pico Iyer investigates the life of the modern-day nomad in The Global Soul
fields.trailText: Pico Iyer investigates the life of the modern-day nomad in The Global Soul
fields.body:
The Global Soul: Jet Lag, Shopping Malls and the Search for Home
Pico Iyer
Bloomsbury, £15.99, 303pp
Buy it at BOL

Early in this appropriately restless book, before it finally settles into an argument of some originality about the way many people live today, the author visits an old schoolfriend in Hong Kong. Richard is a management consultant, "by no means extravagantly rich" and, Iyer insists fondly, "one of the least ambitious and acquisitive people I know". He is generous and contentedly married; self-aware and considerate. And, within a few paragraphs, he is almost impossible to bear.

Richard's whole being has been colonised by work and travel. His flat is a suitcase depot. There are computer disks in the guest room, incoming faxes all night, conversations about nothing but air miles. His apartment block is really a kind of hotel: serviced by maids, silent with jet lag, "do not disturb" warnings sulking red-eyed in doorways. Most of the time Richard is not there at all, but somewhere in the air or in Asia or Europe or America, juggling his projects and plane tickets and fistfuls of telephone calling cards.

Yet this strange, accelerated existence prompts few reflections on his part. Instead he talks like a robot: "I really don't need to exist in real time or real place at all," he tells Iyer. "When I'm sitting right here, and [my wife] Sharon's over there... I leave a message for her by calling her voicemail in Boston." The author asks him why. "She can listen to the message repeatedly, and take down a lot of concrete information."

Richard is what Iyer calls "a global soul": a modern-day nomad in the service of the international economy, no longer loyal to any place or culture. And all of us, Iyer claims, are living a little like that these days. Travel and technology have burst our horizons. We eat Thai and email America and feel less and less attached to a single identity. This can be stimulating, liberating - the first few chapters dazzle with anecdotes from abroad and lists of foreign delicacies - but what is it doing to our psyches? Does near-infinite choice lead to enrichment or exhaustion? And is the global soul, attractive or otherwise, an entirely new sort of person?

Before we meet Richard, Iyer has already presented himself as an example. He is a journalist for middle-brow magazines, but also a serious writer. He is Indian, but was born in Britain. He moved to urban America as an adult, but now lives in rural Japan. Initially, his pride in all this hybridity is rather cloying: "My parents named me after a 15th-century Italian neo-Platonist" he writes, before letting us know just how many airports he has visited. His research here is of the gentlemanly sort; experts and hard evidence are largely absent, in favour of visits to Iyer's far-flung acquaintances, episodes from his itinerant life and trips to literary festivals and cricket matches. A book about asylum seekers this is not.

It begins at Los Angeles airport. Such places, Iyer persuasively argues, are increasingly where the pivotal moments in people's lives are played out. Emigration and immigration, marriage-saving holidays and crucial trips for work - all of these are centred on the long, cool halls where international commerce displays its latest wares and ways of selling. Iyer wanders the glassy corridors, sharp-eyed, looking for telling modern moments. But for all his tracking of baffled incomers and eavesdropping on the clashing tongues, his observations are not quite fresh enough; airports are over-charted territory for amateur sociologists.

Hong Kong proves more rewarding. Iyer gets dizzy then disillusioned at the sheer weight of cultural options on offer: "Wasabi Mousse Caviar and Crème Brlée flavoured with lychee... Matins in Mandarin... Holy Eucharist in Filipino... I felt, sometimes, as if I were in a city whose local tongue was Esperanto." For expatriates like Richard, Iyer tartly concludes, Hong Kong offers a passingly exhilarating "mishmash". For the Chinese majority, multiculturalism often just means red-faced Westerners stumbling out of bars, singing rugby songs.

A mixed-together world, Iyer suggests, can mean greater friction and misunderstanding. He quotes a character in Paul Auster and Wayne Wang's film about New York, Blue in the Face: "Best thing about Brooklyn? All the countries of the world are here. Worst thing about Brooklyn? None of us get along." In Atlanta for the Olympics, Iyer happens upon a choice example. Three Iraqi tourists are being shown around the headquarters of CNN, the international television news network, where they unintentionally terrify the other visitors by revealing their nationality.

If Hong Kong represents the global soul at its most unthinkingly excited, in Atlanta it is at its most calculating. Iyer's elegant but precious writing turns more cutting in response. He depicts a city almost entirely given over to self-promotion, every civic amenity and business straining to establish the international status of a few square miles of convention centres and sticky Georgian asphalt. Iyer drily sums up his visit as "like walking through a curriculum vitae".

Atlanta's very diversity and internationalism seem to make it keener to become a corporate cheerleader. Being globally aware, it appears, means knowing how competitive the world is and smilingly adapting. When he is in Japan, Iyer himself gets up at five on weekday mornings in order to fit in with his editors in America. And as the book saunters around the globe, the glances it casts are as much approving as disapproving. A trip to Toronto leaves Iyer thrilled by the more benign possibilities of a planet full of migrants: "The 'most cosmopolitan city on earth', as a local columnist called it, was also, statistically, the safest city in north America."

With his travel-writer's eye for bustle and symbolism, Iyer does make Toronto sound an enticing place, full of refugees from harsher cities making their lives afresh, with writers and artists stirring the froth like their sweet pavement cappuccinos. But Toronto, with its carnivals and constant discussions of multiculturalism, self-promotes just as much as Atlanta does. Another aspect of the global soul, Iyer inadvertently suggests, is a certain earnestness and smugness.

For his conclusion, he returns to his own life. Japan is good for him, he says. He relishes the cornershop treats; he charms his partner in pidgin Japanese; he writes and visits local shrines in the cocoon of silence that envelops the unknowing expatriate. Feeling foreign but fairly at home, he argues, is more relaxing than being a native in the place where you live. You escape the gossip, the hang-ups, the consumer crazes, the need to keep up - much of the noise, in fact, of the globalised world that enabled you to move abroad in the first place.

It's a clever paradox to end with. This is a bright and timely book, a vivid shading-in of the outline of a changed world currently visible on newspaper business pages and in economics texts. What is missing here, though, is proof that today's ambitious global citizens are fundamentally different from those - Viking traders, Indian merchants - who went before. There is also no sense of the global soul of the poor. They are glimpsed at the edges of chapters, like hitchhiking migrant farmworkers. But Iyer is travelling too fast and too interestingly to stop and talk to them for very long.

And all of us, Iyer claims, are living a little like that these days. Travel and technology have burst our horizons. We eat Thai and email America and feel less and less attached to a single identity. This can be stimulating, liberating - the first few chapters dazzle with anecdotes from abroad and lists of foreign delicacies - but what is it doing to our psyches? Does near-infinite choice lead to enrichment or exhaustion? And is the global soul, attractive or otherwise, an entirely new sort of person? Before we meet Richard, Iyer has already presented himself as an example. He is a journalist for middle-brow magazines, but also a serious writer. He is Indian, but was born in Britain. He moved to urban America as an adult, but now lives in rural Japan. Initially, his pride in all this hybridity is rather cloying: "My parents named me after a 15th-century Italian neo-Platonist" he writes, before letting us know just how many airports he has visited. His research here is of the gentlemanly sort; experts and hard evidence are largely absent, in favour of visits to Iyer's far-flung acquaintances, episodes from his itinerant life and trips to literary festivals and cricket matches. A book about asylum seekers this is not. It begins at Los Angeles airport. Such places, Iyer persuasively argues, are increasingly where the pivotal moments in people's lives are played out. Emigration and immigration, marriage-saving holidays and crucial trips for work - all of these are centred on the long, cool halls where international commerce displays its latest wares and ways of selling. Iyer wanders the glassy corridors, sharp-eyed, looking for telling modern moments. But for all his tracking of baffled incomers and eavesdropping on the clashing tongues, his observations are not quite fresh enough; airports are over-charted territory for amateur sociologists. Hong Kong proves more rewarding. Iyer gets dizzy then disillusioned at the sheer weight of cultural options on offer: "Wasabi Mousse Caviar and Crème Brlée flavoured with lychee... Matins in Mandarin... Holy Eucharist in Filipino... I felt, sometimes, as if I were in a city whose local tongue was Esperanto." For expatriates like Richard, Iyer tartly concludes, Hong Kong offers a passingly exhilarating "mishmash". For the Chinese majority, multiculturalism often just means red-faced Westerners stumbling out of bars, singing rugby songs. A mixed-together world, Iyer suggests, can mean greater friction and misunderstanding. He quotes a character in Paul Auster and Wayne Wang's film about New York, Blue in the Face: "Best thing about Brooklyn? All the countries of the world are here. Worst thing about Brooklyn? None of us get along." In Atlanta for the Olympics, Iyer happens upon a choice example. Three Iraqi tourists are being shown around the headquarters of CNN, the international television news network, where they unintentionally terrify the other visitors by revealing their nationality. If Hong Kong represents the global soul at its most unthinkingly excited, in Atlanta it is at its most calculating. Iyer's elegant but precious writing turns more cutting in response. He depicts a city almost entirely given over to self-promotion, every civic amenity and business straining to establish the international status of a few square miles of convention centres and sticky Georgian asphalt. Iyer drily sums up his visit as "like walking through a curriculum vitae". Atlanta's very diversity and internationalism seem to make it keener to become a corporate cheerleader. Being globally aware, it appears, means knowing how competitive the world is and smilingly adapting. When he is in Japan, Iyer himself gets up at five on weekday mornings in order to fit in with his editors in America. And as the book saunters around the globe, the glances it casts are as much approving as disapproving. A trip to Toronto leaves Iyer thrilled by the more benign possibilities of a planet full of migrants: "The 'most cosmopolitan city on earth', as a local columnist called it, was also, statistically, the safest city in north America." With his travel-writer's eye for bustle and symbolism, Iyer does make Toronto sound an enticing place, full of refugees from harsher cities making their lives afresh, with writers and artists stirring the froth like their sweet pavement cappuccinos. But Toronto, with its carnivals and constant discussions of multiculturalism, self-promotes just as much as Atlanta does. Another aspect of the global soul, Iyer inadvertently suggests, is a certain earnestness and smugness. For his conclusion, he returns to his own life. Japan is good for him, he says. He relishes the cornershop treats; he charms his partner in pidgin Japanese; he writes and visits local shrines in the cocoon of silence that envelops the unknowing expatriate. Feeling foreign but fairly at home, he argues, is more relaxing than being a native in the place where you live. You escape the gossip, the hang-ups, the consumer crazes, the need to keep up - much of the noise, in fact, of the globalised world that enabled you to move abroad in the first place. It's a clever paradox to end with. This is a bright and timely book, a vivid shading-in of the outline of a changed world currently visible on newspaper business pages and in economics texts. What is missing here, though, is proof that today's ambitious global citizens are fundamentally different from those - Viking traders, Indian merchants - who went before. There is also no sense of the global soul of the poor. They are glimpsed at the edges of chapters, like hitchhiking migrant farmworkers. But Iyer is travelling too fast and too interestingly to stop and talk to them for very long.

webTitle: Judging panel announced for Guardian First Book Award 2000

fields.headline: Judging panel announced for Guardian First Book Award 2000
fields.trailText: Novelists David Baddiel, Toby Litt and Julian Barnes join Professor Steve Jones and broadcaster Kirsty Young to judge this years Guardian First Book Award. Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, and Louise Collinge, marketing manager of Borders, will also be on the judging panel, which will be chaired by Claire Armitstead, literary editor of the Guardian.
fields.body:
Novelists David Baddiel, Toby Litt and Julian Barnes join Professor Steve Jones and broadcaster Kirsty Young to judge this years Guardian First Book Award. Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, and Louise Collinge, marketing manager of Borders, will also be on the judging panel, which will be chaired by Claire Armitstead, literary editor of the Guardian.

The Guardian First Book Award panel reflects the diversity of the award, which aims to recognise an authors first book, whether it is fiction, non-fiction or poetry. The winner will receive a prize of £10,000, an advertising package in the Guardian and Observer and an endowment of £1,000 worth of books to a school of their choice.

Julian Barnes is the internationally acclaimed author of eight novels including Flauberts Parrot, A History of The World in 10 Chapters and England, England. His new novel, Love, Etc, is published later this year. Writer and comedian David Baddiels hugely successful first novel, Time for Bed, is currently being filmed and has been published in over seven countries worldwide. Toby Litt has published two novels, Beatniks and Corpsing, both to great critical acclaim. His debut collection of short stories, Adventures in Capitalism, won the Curtis Brown Award for most promising student of his year on the Creative Writing course at the University of East Anglia.

Steve Jones, Professor of Genetics at UCL, won the Royal Society Faraday Medal for the Public Understanding of Science in 1998. Kirsty Young, co-presenter of the ITV Lunchtime News, was named Newscaster of the Year for her work on Channel 5 News and has also won the Sir James Carreras Award for Outstanding New Talent.

Alongside the selected judging panel, Borders are running reading groups in their stores in London, Glasgow, Cheshire Oaks and York who will help choose the shortlist from the designated longlist.

The longlist will be announced in August and the shortlist in October.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Stephen Calloway's survey of the baroque is a period piece itself, plus Tokyo: A Certain Style
fields.body:
Baroque
Stephen Calloway
(Phaidon, £19.95)

Buy it at BOL

At last in paperback after six years, and now a period piece itself: own up, what loony reproduced a Piranesi engraving at postage-stamp size, with matching caption, while allowing Calloway to do the aesthetic equivalent of mouthing off in at least 20pt type and moreover in gold? Ooh, the preciousness of it all, in quite the wrong sense: several hundred years of "me and the friends of Cecil Beaton pose in fancy dress at a fête champêtre"... But you have to forgive, because Calloway really does make connections between Cocteau, Michael Powell movies and Brighton Pavilion, etc. If only he'd also understood that baroque also provided the energy of British popular arts.

Tokyo, a Certain Style
Kyoichi Tsuzuki
(Chronicle, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Antidote to surfeiting on pictures of grand interiors, and not because it shows zen teahouses in trad austere mode. No, these are real hutch homes in the Tokkaido megapolis: muddles of books, CDs and kawaii (cute) cuddly-toy kitsch - the true spirit of modern Japan, a student bedsit with top-class electronics. The honesty shocks - a condo-dweller ablutes in the local bathhouse to reclaim her bathroom as storage space. Like that iodine-and-miso restaurant smell, this is instant transport to a wholly likeable Tokyo where nobody puts life on hold until they can achieve perfection. We were going to send minimal-master John Pawson a copy as a reality check.

webTitle: Leviathan and Getting Out of Hand

fields.headline: Leviathan and Getting Out of Hand
fields.trailText: Something has grown too big for the pond...
fields.body:
Leviathan

Something has grown too big for the pond: first the moorhens disappeared
then the ducks (corner-of-the-eye stuff,
nothing strictly attributable).
The Canada Geese stayed, but looked as if they knew
something they'd rather not think about.

A goat on the village green went mad overnight.
Then pensioners living nearby
started to peg out: heart attacks mostly
and always at Meals-on-Wheels time
(the body on the rug, the cartons emptied).
Alice Weevil went missing altogether.

A builder up a ladder, on his mobile,
didn't at first hear the flub of something
working its way up the rungs behind him.
'Quick Reg,' were his last words -
'get the pond drained - don't wait
for the Council - there's a huge, unbelievable -'

Getting Out of Hand

Experimenting with virtual reality
she calls up a good-sized house, and in it she pops
Rupert Brooke, who comes out of his study
muttering octosyllabics and twisting
his inky fingers through his famous hair.

Remembering his penchant for anguished passion
she summons Charlotte Brontë - but something goes wrong
and it is Branwell who turns up, though it doesn't seem
to matter, and he falls into conversation with Rupert
about the rail service to Lulworth Cove.

They settle down for tea, and here comes Jane Austen
handing round the bread and butter. Cup in hand, she
leafs through a volume of diaries
found on the coffee table. Her eyes widen
and she drops the book with a nervous glance

over her shoulder, but there is no sign
of the author, for Joe Orton (if on the premises)
is engaged elsewhere. More figures
materialise, and surely someone will have to wash
the cups - though that doesn't look like a butler

limping in through the French windows, saturnine
and patrician, with a dangerous-looking hound in tow.
Someone who understands these animals is needed a.s.a.p.
and Conan Doyle springs to mind - being also qualified
to advise about the foot - but no, surely that's GBS

cycling bossily up through the garden
ready to sort everyone out, if he can make himself heard
above the shouting and barking. Now they're all
comparing something, and fragments of speech surface:
Missolonghi... mosquito... my best apple tree.

Then pensioners living nearby started to peg out: heart attacks mostly and always at Meals-on-Wheels time (the body on the rug, the cartons emptied). Alice Weevil went missing altogether. A builder up a ladder, on his mobile, didn't at first hear the flub of something working its way up the rungs behind him. 'Quick Reg,' were his last words - 'get the pond drained - don't wait for the Council - there's a huge, unbelievable -' Getting Out of Hand Experimenting with virtual reality she calls up a good-sized house, and in it she pops Rupert Brooke, who comes out of his study muttering octosyllabics and twisting his inky fingers through his famous hair. Remembering his penchant for anguished passion she summons Charlotte Brontë - but something goes wrong and it is Branwell who turns up, though it doesn't seem to matter, and he falls into conversation with Rupert about the rail service to Lulworth Cove. They settle down for tea, and here comes Jane Austen handing round the bread and butter. Cup in hand, she leafs through a volume of diaries found on the coffee table. Her eyes widen and she drops the book with a nervous glance over her shoulder, but there is no sign of the author, for Joe Orton (if on the premises) is engaged elsewhere. More figures materialise, and surely someone will have to wash the cups - though that doesn't look like a butler limping in through the French windows, saturnine and patrician, with a dangerous-looking hound in tow. Someone who understands these animals is needed a.s.a.p. and Conan Doyle springs to mind - being also qualified to advise about the foot - but no, surely that's GBS cycling bossily up through the garden ready to sort everyone out, if he can make himself heard above the shouting and barking. Now they're all comparing something, and fragments of speech surface: Missolonghi... mosquito... my best apple tree.

fields.headline: A sad hurrah (part 2)
fields.standfirst: Sarah Kane's first play, Blasted, provoked outrage, but in the years before her suicide in  1999 she came to be recognised as an agonised, brilliantly poetic voice. All who knew  her are adamant that her work and life should not be confused, yet the parallels are hard to avoid
fields.trailText: Harold Pinter was at the Royal Court the night after the first reviews came out. He says that he had never heard a voice like Kane's, that she hardly knew where it was coming from herself. "It was a very startling and tender voice, but she was appalled by the world in which she lived and the world within herself." Many of the critics "were way out of their league", says Pinter. "Oddly enough, the night I went she happened to be there. She was extremely upset. I was able to tell her, for what it was worth, that it was terrific. She then dropped me a line, and we met up. It just seemed, when I met her that night, that she needed a friend. I'm sure she had plenty of friends, young friends, but I thought she might need an older friend. And I benefited from our friendship very much." A Pinteresque pause follows. "I just found her very, very . . . I liked her very much." Whereas closer friends are reluctant to talk about her life and simply direct me towards the text, Pinter says the two are inseparable. "Some playwrights take on a different personality, and you say, 'How can that fellow have written that?' But she was her work. It was one thing. And, as such, it could be extremely uncomfortable. One play of hers, Phaedra's Love, just frightened the shit out of me. I told her, and we used to laugh about it. She said, 'There's some things you just can't take, Harold,' and I'd say you're dead right." Why did it terrify him? "Well, the violence was, what's the word? It jumped right out of the page. The page itself was violent. The act of turning the page was violent. She was so naked, and her work was evidently so naked. She had no protective skins at all.

"Oddly enough, the night I went she happened to be there. She was extremely upset. I was able to tell her, for what it was worth, that it was terrific. She then dropped me a line, and we met up. It just seemed, when I met her that night, that she needed a friend. I'm sure she had plenty of friends, young friends, but I thought she might need an older friend. And I benefited from our friendship very much." A Pinteresque pause follows. "I just found her very, very . . . I liked her very much." Whereas closer friends are reluctant to talk about her life and simply direct me towards the text, Pinter says the two are inseparable. "Some playwrights take on a different personality, and you say, 'How can that fellow have written that?' But she was her work. It was one thing. And, as such, it could be extremely uncomfortable. One play of hers, Phaedra's Love, just frightened the shit out of me. I told her, and we used to laugh about it. She said, 'There's some things you just can't take, Harold,' and I'd say you're dead right." Why did it terrify him? "Well, the violence was, what's the word? It jumped right out of the page. The page itself was violent. The act of turning the page was violent. She was so naked, and her work was evidently so naked. She had no protective skins at all.

"What frightened me was the depth of her horror and anguish. Everyone's aware, to varying degrees, of the cruelty of mankind, but we manage to compromise with it, put it on the shelf and not think about it for a good part of the day. But I don't think she could do that. I think she had a vision of the world that was extremely accurate, and therefore horrific. Because the world is a fucking awful place. It's a very beautiful place, but this species mankind is an absolute bloody disaster. The elements of sadism are astonishing. She wasn't simply observing mankind; she was part of it. It seems to me she was talking about the violence within herself, the hatred within herself, and the depths of misery that she also suffered."

Like Greig, Pinter jollies himself out of his misery. "Anyway, I would like to tell you she was a girl of tremendous spirit. Despite everything I've said, she was a lot of fun." What made her happy? "I think she seemed to be in love most of the time. When her love life was going well, she was happy." But it rarely did go well. "As far as I could glean, she had a very unhappy love life. About a year before her death, she came here and a relationship with a woman had just finished. She was very distressed about it - who wouldn't be? - but again the depth of her suffering was her own, very singular. Her antennae were very sharp for every bloody thing, including love."

It's tempting to apply a conventional narrative to Kane's life. The playwright Edward Bond already has done, arguing that the theatre and its critics killed her: a depressed girl wrote a wonderful play that was slated and everything went downhill from there. But it didn't. Kane wrote four more plays in a four-year period.

Cleansed was about love, death and drug addiction in a concentration camp. Again, it was fuelled by her revulsion of Serb atrocities. Again, it was minimalist and elliptical. Kane was a political writer, but she never thought plays should tell you how to vote. During the run of Cleansed, the actress Suzan Sylvester pulled her back. Kane had always said she would never ask an actress to do something that she wouldn't do herself, so she learned a dance routine within an hour, and then prepared to whip off her clothes and teeter on to the stage in stilettos. She was terrified - she'd never worn stilettos before. As with Blasted, the critics suggested the violence in Cleansed was gratuitous and exaggerated. In fact, every violent incident in her plays was closely fashioned on real incidents. (The sucking out of an eye in Blasted, for example, comes from Bill Buford's account of football thugs' retribution against a policeman who had infiltrated their gang; the pole inserted up the arse and released through the shoulder was a Serb method of crucifixion; while the prisoner in Cleansed who learns how to count, discovers how much time he has left to serve and then hangs himself, is based on a man who was jailed on Robben Island with Nelson Mandela.)

Crave was widely reviewed as Kane's best, most mature piece of writing. In this play, she dispensed with plot - four nameless voices, different characters or warring factions of one person's consciousness, sit around and discuss love, desire, abuse and the ultimate desire: death. Kane wrote Crave under a pseudonym for the theatre company Paines Plough, where she was working as writer-in-residence. The director, Vicky Featherstone, says it all started as bit of a joke: "We used to do a workshop, in which new plays would be read. And one of the writers dropped out with three days to go. I said to Sarah, 'Why don't you write one?' I knew it takes her years to write anything. The thing about Sarah is that she hated letting people down, so she'd agree to things and regret it later."

Kane disappeared. Every time Featherstone rang her house, the answerphone was on. "I thought, Christ what have I done. Then, three days later, she turned up and said, 'I hate you for having made me do this.' She stood in the corridor, jiggling her leg, having a fag, and made me read it while she waited. It was just the most simple, perfect piece of writing." Kane then spent another year-and-a-half completing Crave.

Why did she write it under the pseudonym, Marie Kelvedon? "In one way, she thought it was funny. Marie was her middle name, Kelvedon was a town near where she was born. But, in another way, it was deadly serious. She had spent a lot of time shaking off the negative effects of Blasted. She really wanted to write something that could be judged for what it was, rather than for the fact that it had been written by Sarah Kane." The beginnings of Crave were read out, in front of Sarah, to the workshop, and the writers decided Marie Kelvedon was a great talent.

Featherstone tells me how much she misses her friend - the pub talk, the pontificating, the raging sense of injustice. "She was like a child with a massive brain, the biggest theatre brain I've ever known. I've never seen someone with their eyes so open to the world, as if seeing it for the first time. And yet she was very cynical in some ways." Like so many people who were close to Kane, Featherstone uses the word "paradox". The paradoxes of Crave - the barren mother, the caring abuser - and the paradoxes within Kane herself. Kane's work may have seemed anarchic, she herself may have seemed anarchic, but she had an amazing grasp of the mechanics and the history of theatre.

Kane spent much of the last four years of her life travelling through Europe, doing workshops with students by day and writing by night. While Britain remained at best ambivalent to her, she became a huge star in France and especially in Germany. "They saw her as something new and uncompromising," says her German translator, Nils Tabert. He says the students always had an image in their head of how Sarah would look and act. "But she didn't turn up tattooed and pierced like people expected. Instead, here was a very young, very frail, very charming woman."

Tabert says Kane was one of the best-read people he's met. "She knew everything." They would spend hours searching out, and deleting, a single word. "Forever, she was cutting away the superfluous words. The plays are so precise and, as a translator, that's a huge challenge." They also represent a huge challenge in that (as with Artaud's theatre of cruelty) the odd stage instruction is unperformable. "When someone falls from the roof to the floor, you can't do it. Artaud once said this nice thing, that his plays require acting without a safety net, and Sarah's plays require that, too. Emotionally." But the difference is, says Tabert, Kane didn't want her instructions taken literally. She was surprisingly prudish about her work. She didn't want the audience to see blow jobs and mutilation; she regarded them as images. "She thought the production of Blasted in Berlin was cynical. She found it offensive, cool and stylised, like Tarantino, whom she detested. They took the play very literally, there was a lot of nudity. It was true to the text, but it lacked the metaphorical quality, the poetry, and that's what she hated."

Depression tends to be cyclical. For Kane, it was always there, sometimes simmering, sometimes raging. After writing Crave, she went into a vicious depression and admitted herself to the Maudsley Hospital in south London. She took anti-depressants, reluctantly. "She hated them," says her agent, Mel Kenyon. "She just told me she didn't like taking pills because they numbed her response to the world, which is, of course, what they're supposed to do. But as an artist, it's extraordinarily difficult if your responsive level is made less intense. What do you do? Take pills and take away the despair? But despair also engenders knowledge in some way, and that knowledge fuels your understanding of the world and therefore your writing, but at the same time you want to exorcise the despair. She tried to weigh it up all the time."

Did Kenyon worry that Kane's writing might harm her? "The only thing I ever wondered about was whether the connection made with the outer world was becoming less and less, and therefore she was having to dig deeper and deeper to create. There were times when I wanted her to embrace doing an adaptation or something, just so that she'd relieve herself of the need to go further inside."

Did they talk about it? "Yeah, we did, but I wasn't worried. I didn't think she was endangering her psyche, I just thought it may . . . I didn't want her world to shrink. Maybe I was dumb. I wanted to say you can use other things if you need a break from doing intense, personal statements."

Kane came out of the Maudsley to triumph with Crave. Critics called it a dramatic poem, and compared it to TS Eliot's The Wasteland. Mel Kenyon says, "It's not a mistake that the last play but one was called Crave - that's actually what it is. She had this incredible yearning, this desire." The language is so fragile, so spare, so beautiful, so romantic, that many reviewers suggested it showed a new optimism. This made Kane laugh.

The only hope in this play, she said, lies in the possibility of death. She believed that Cleansed, possibly the most savage of her plays, was her most optimistic - every time the two boy lovers have another limb chopped off, they keep going, convinced that they can overcome if they love enough.

Many friends say they remember her at her happiest when Crave was being premiered in Edinburgh. It was a huge success, she felt she was coming out of the depression, and she was surrounded by friends. "It was just like the old Saz," says Vince O'Connell. "She made such an effort to get back to herself, and for a time it worked." But she hadn't beaten the depression.

The Actors Touring Company asked Kane to write a play based on Goethe's The Sorrows Of Young Werther. Werther was a fictional hero who killed himself for love. He became the ultimate romantic icon, and after Goethe published the story a spate of copycat suicides followed. Kane said that she was already working on 4.48 Psychosis, - and that there were parallels. The title refers to the time of morning when the urge to kill oneself is at its highest. In January 1999, a few months after the triumph of Crave and just after completing 4.48 Psychosis, she took 150 anti-depressants and 50 sleeping pills. Her flatmate discovered her unconscious at their Brixton flat, and drove her to King's College Hospital. The hospital received notes from the Maudsley, saying that she was "preoccupied with morbid thoughts and suicide".

Mel Kenyon says that Sarah had never talked to her about killing herself. "I knew she had this despair. We talked about that a great deal, and I knew taking her life was an option. However, she didn't threaten suicide ever. You know, you'll feel differently about me when I'm dead, we never had that conversation. Never. I felt, as other people did, strangely protective of her. You just want her to be as happy and as safe as possible." She visited her in hospital when she regained consciousness. Kenyon says she was calm and comfortable. But she still talked about wanting to die. Kenyon recalls Sarah saying she was annoyed she had eaten pizza - if she hadn't, she would not have survived. "We both laughed about it. Not that we shrugged it off. We just spoke about it so openly that it seemed almost funny. I think people think it's a frenzied act, and I don't think it is."

fields.bodyText: Harold Pinter was at the Royal Court the night after the first reviews came out. He says that he had never heard a voice like Kane's, that she hardly knew where it was coming from herself. "It was a very startling and tender voice, but she was appalled by the world in which she lived and the world within herself." Many of the critics "were way out of their league", says Pinter. "Oddly enough, the night I went she happened to be there. She was extremely upset. I was able to tell her, for what it was worth, that it was terrific. She then dropped me a line, and we met up. It just seemed, when I met her that night, that she needed a friend. I'm sure she had plenty of friends, young friends, but I thought she might need an older friend. And I benefited from our friendship very much." A Pinteresque pause follows. "I just found her very, very . . . I liked her very much." Whereas closer friends are reluctant to talk about her life and simply direct me towards the text, Pinter says the two are inseparable. "Some playwrights take on a different personality, and you say, 'How can that fellow have written that?' But she was her work. It was one thing. And, as such, it could be extremely uncomfortable. One play of hers, Phaedra's Love, just frightened the shit out of me. I told her, and we used to laugh about it. She said, 'There's some things you just can't take, Harold,' and I'd say you're dead right." Why did it terrify him? "Well, the violence was, what's the word? It jumped right out of the page. The page itself was violent. The act of turning the page was violent. She was so naked, and her work was evidently so naked. She had no protective skins at all. "What frightened me was the depth of her horror and anguish. Everyone's aware, to varying degrees, of the cruelty of mankind, but we manage to compromise with it, put it on the shelf and not think about it for a good part of the day. But I don't think she could do that. I think she had a vision of the world that was extremely accurate, and therefore horrific. Because the world is a fucking awful place. It's a very beautiful place, but this species mankind is an absolute bloody disaster. The elements of sadism are astonishing. She wasn't simply observing mankind; she was part of it. It seems to me she was talking about the violence within herself, the hatred within herself, and the depths of misery that she also suffered." Like Greig, Pinter jollies himself out of his misery. "Anyway, I would like to tell you she was a girl of tremendous spirit. Despite everything I've said, she was a lot of fun." What made her happy? "I think she seemed to be in love most of the time. When her love life was going well, she was happy." But it rarely did go well. "As far as I could glean, she had a very unhappy love life. About a year before her death, she came here and a relationship with a woman had just finished. She was very distressed about it - who wouldn't be? - but again the depth of her suffering was her own, very singular. Her antennae were very sharp for every bloody thing, including love." It's tempting to apply a conventional narrative to Kane's life. The playwright Edward Bond already has done, arguing that the theatre and its critics killed her: a depressed girl wrote a wonderful play that was slated and everything went downhill from there. But it didn't. Kane wrote four more plays in a four-year period. Cleansed was about love, death and drug addiction in a concentration camp. Again, it was fuelled by her revulsion of Serb atrocities. Again, it was minimalist and elliptical. Kane was a political writer, but she never thought plays should tell you how to vote. During the run of Cleansed, the actress Suzan Sylvester pulled her back. Kane had always said she would never ask an actress to do something that she wouldn't do herself, so she learned a dance routine within an hour, and then prepared to whip off her clothes and teeter on to the stage in stilettos. She was terrified - she'd never worn stilettos before. As with Blasted, the critics suggested the violence in Cleansed was gratuitous and exaggerated. In fact, every violent incident in her plays was closely fashioned on real incidents. (The sucking out of an eye in Blasted, for example, comes from Bill Buford's account of football thugs' retribution against a policeman who had infiltrated their gang; the pole inserted up the arse and released through the shoulder was a Serb method of crucifixion; while the prisoner in Cleansed who learns how to count, discovers how much time he has left to serve and then hangs himself, is based on a man who was jailed on Robben Island with Nelson Mandela.) Crave was widely reviewed as Kane's best, most mature piece of writing. In this play, she dispensed with plot - four nameless voices, different characters or warring factions of one person's consciousness, sit around and discuss love, desire, abuse and the ultimate desire: death. Kane wrote Crave under a pseudonym for the theatre company Paines Plough, where she was working as writer-in-residence. The director, Vicky Featherstone, says it all started as bit of a joke: "We used to do a workshop, in which new plays would be read. And one of the writers dropped out with three days to go. I said to Sarah, 'Why don't you write one?' I knew it takes her years to write anything. The thing about Sarah is that she hated letting people down, so she'd agree to things and regret it later." Kane disappeared. Every time Featherstone rang her house, the answerphone was on. "I thought, Christ what have I done. Then, three days later, she turned up and said, 'I hate you for having made me do this.' She stood in the corridor, jiggling her leg, having a fag, and made me read it while she waited. It was just the most simple, perfect piece of writing." Kane then spent another year-and-a-half completing Crave. Why did she write it under the pseudonym, Marie Kelvedon? "In one way, she thought it was funny. Marie was her middle name, Kelvedon was a town near where she was born. But, in another way, it was deadly serious. She had spent a lot of time shaking off the negative effects of Blasted. She really wanted to write something that could be judged for what it was, rather than for the fact that it had been written by Sarah Kane." The beginnings of Crave were read out, in front of Sarah, to the workshop, and the writers decided Marie Kelvedon was a great talent. "She was like a child with a massive brain, the biggest theatre brain I've ever known. I've never seen someone with their eyes so open to the world, as if seeing it for the first time. And yet she was very cynical in some ways." Like so many people who were close to Kane, Featherstone uses the word "paradox". Kane spent much of the last four years of her life travelling through Europe, doing workshops with students by day and writing by night. While Britain remained at best ambivalent to her, she became a huge star in France and especially in Germany. "They saw her as something new and uncompromising," says her German translator, Nils Tabert. He says the students always had an image in their head of how Sarah would look and act. "But she didn't turn up tattooed and pierced like people expected. Instead, here was a very young, very frail, very charming woman." Tabert says Kane was one of the best-read people he's met. "She knew everything." They would spend hours searching out, and deleting, a single word. "Forever, she was cutting away the superfluous words. "When someone falls from the roof to the floor, you can't do it. Artaud once said this nice thing, that his plays require acting without a safety net, and Sarah's plays require that, too. Emotionally." But the difference is, says Tabert, Kane didn't want her instructions taken literally. She was surprisingly prudish about her work. She didn't want the audience to see blow jobs and mutilation; she regarded them as images. "She thought the production of Blasted in Berlin was cynical. She found it offensive, cool and stylised, like Tarantino, whom she detested. They took the play very literally, there was a lot of nudity. It was true to the text, but it lacked the metaphorical quality, the poetry, and that's what she hated." Depression tends to be cyclical. For Kane, it was always there, sometimes simmering, sometimes raging. After writing Crave, she went into a vicious depression and admitted herself to the Maudsley Hospital in south London. She took anti-depressants, reluctantly. "She hated them," says her agent, Mel Kenyon. "She just told me she didn't like taking pills because they numbed her response to the world, which is, of course, what they're supposed to do. But as an artist, it's extraordinarily difficult if your responsive level is made less intense. What do you do? Take pills and take away the despair? But despair also engenders knowledge in some way, and that knowledge fuels your understanding of the world and therefore your writing, but at the same time you want to exorcise the despair. She tried to weigh it up all the time." Did Kenyon worry that Kane's writing might harm her? "The only thing I ever wondered about was whether the connection made with the outer world was becoming less and less, and therefore she was having to dig deeper and deeper to create. There were times when I wanted her to embrace doing an adaptation or something, just so that she'd relieve herself of the need to go further inside." Did they talk about it? "Yeah, we did, but I wasn't worried. I didn't think she was endangering her psyche, I just thought it may . . . I didn't want her world to shrink. Maybe I was dumb. I wanted to say you can use other things if you need a break from doing intense, personal statements." Kane came out of the Maudsley to triumph with Crave. Critics called it a dramatic poem, and compared it to TS Eliot's The Wasteland. Mel Kenyon says, "It's not a mistake that the last play but one was called Crave - that's actually what it is. She had this incredible yearning, this desire." The language is so fragile, so spare, so beautiful, so romantic, that many reviewers suggested it showed a new optimism. This made Kane laugh. The only hope in this play, she said, lies in the possibility of death. She believed that Cleansed, possibly the most savage of her plays, was her most optimistic - every time the two boy lovers have another limb chopped off, they keep going, convinced that they can overcome if they love enough. Many friends say they remember her at her happiest when Crave was being premiered in Edinburgh. It was a huge success, she felt she was coming out of the depression, and she was surrounded by friends. "It was just like the old Saz," says Vince O'Connell. "She made such an effort to get back to herself, and for a time it worked." But she hadn't beaten the depression. The Actors Touring Company asked Kane to write a play based on Goethe's The Sorrows Of Young Werther. Werther was a fictional hero who killed himself for love. He became the ultimate romantic icon, and after Goethe published the story a spate of copycat suicides followed. Kane said that she was already working on 4.48 Psychosis, - and that there were parallels. The title refers to the time of morning when the urge to kill oneself is at its highest. fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: Stein's weird reworking of the family-saga genre is, in the words of one critic, "horribly flawed, and a joy to read if you just give up and drown in it".
fields.body:
The Making of Americans
Gertrude Stein
(Dalkey Archive, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Stein's weird reworking of the family-saga genre is, in the words of one critic, "horribly flawed, and a joy to read if you just give up and drown in it". This should give you an idea of her prose style: "He could do something. He could completely understand doing that thing. He was understanding any one doing that thing. He was understanding what any one was doing in doing that thing." As the Dallas News sweetly said: "cannot be comprehended with one eye on the baby".
