fields.headline: Celebrity behind the counter
fields.standfirst: Abdullah Hussein tells Maya Jaggi how he wrote while running an off-licence
fields.trailText: Abdullah Hussein tells Maya Jaggi how he wrote while running an off-licence
fields.body:
Few of the celebrities who patronised Abdullah Hussein's Clapham off-licence in the 1980s would have twigged they were being served by the world's greatest living Urdu novelist. "Vanessa Redgrave, Vivienne Westwood, John Pilger used to come in," he recalls. "But no one ever knew I had any other life than being a shopkeeper."

A film director, Udayan Prasad, was more curious. "He said, 'you're always scribbling - what is it?' " The inquiry led to Prasad's BBC feature film Brothers in Trouble (1996), based on Hussein's short story "The Return Journey". Set in 1960s Birmingham among Punjabi newcomers with high ambitions, it was part of a sparkling oeuvre published in Urdu to acclaim in Pakistan, even though Hussein had lived in England since the mid-1960s.

Now 69, he has written his first novel in English. Emigré Journeys builds on the story of a houseful of pioneering male migrants of dubious legal status, battling dicey jobs, slum landlords and sexual frustration. But it looks back from the 1990s, splicing in alternate chapters in the "second generation" voice of one of their daughters.

"Very few of the second generation read Urdu, their parents' language," says Hussein, explaining why he switched languages. "I wanted to give them a knowledge of their history and the accident - economic migration from east to west - by which they find themselves in a foreign society, in which they have to seek their own cultural identity; to strive more than others to make a place for themselves."

The novel recalls a time before chicken tikka masala became Britain's national dish, when locals ostentatiously covered their noses at the smell of Indian food. Yet Hussein says: "I didn't want to focus on racism. I thought the Asian community had grown up enough to look at larger discrimination: against the poor by the rich, women by men."

The conflict between Amir and his rebellious daughter Parvin uncannily echoes Hanif Kureishi's My Son the Fanatic and Ayub Khan-Din's East is East. Yet the skeleton story was written 20 years ago. And while Hussein modelled Parvin on his two children and their friends, the elders are based on his own contemporaries.

A graduate, he arrived in Britain in 1966 as a chemical engineer. "I was the chief chemist in a large cement factory [in Pakistan], but I wanted to travel. The British government had a scheme to attract qualified people - though I started all over again as an apprentice; 15 years' professional life wiped out."

Born in 1931 in Rawalpindi, in what became Pakistan, he had begun to write aged 25 while recovering from a nervous breakdown after the death of his father, a customs inspector. "I had a very close relationship with my father because my mother died when I was six months old; he never married again. He was a great reader, one of few of his generation who read and spoke English."

Hussein's first novel, Udas Naslain (The Weary Generations, 1963), won Pakistan's highest literary award, the Adamji prize. "I became famous overnight," he says. A 700-page saga on Indian independence, from the 1857 "mutiny" to partition, it was later made a Unesco classic and translated into English. But the muse fled after he migrated, working for 10 years for the Gas Board in Birmingham. Following redundancy and spells in Pakistan and Libya, where his wife worked as a doctor, he bought the off-licence by Clapham Common. "Now I can live on my Urdu royalties, but then, the shop seemed a nice idea: I could drink on the cheap and have enjoyable chats with customers."

Keeping shop, he took up the pen again. "I'd spent 17 years drinking and enjoying myself, wasting my time. Then suddenly I sat down and wrote three books in a row." The collected short stories of Nasheb (Downfall by Degrees, 1981) - set in Pakistan, Canada, Libya and Britain - were followed by the novels Bhag (The Tiger, 1982) and Qaid (Captivity, 1989). Later came the novel Nadar Loge (The Dispossessed, 1997). His reputation crossed borders, with translations into Indian languages, Chinese and English.

"I'm not very popular with governments," he says. "My first novel was about to be banned for obscenity before it won the award. My second, The Tiger, was about Kashmir: Pakistan said India imposed the war on us, but my stand was that Pakistan infiltrated Kashmir with agents provocateurs; that the responsibility for the war was half ours."

Emigré Journeys is a subtle morality tale on the follies and pathos of two generations. Amir recalls a crime of passion after a fellow lodger inveigled his white girlfriend, Mary, into marrying his nephew to bring him into the country. Thirty years on, as Amir seeks a Pakistani suitor for his wayward daughter, the violence - for which Amir blames Mary - revisits them with the fury of Greek tragedy.

"Everyone is a prisoner of their background, so you can't condemn people; hypocrisy invariably comes into it," says Hussein. "Amir falls back on a system of inherited values; he thinks every white woman is a prostitute. The irony is that he tells of a disaster resulting from a marriage of convenience, but he can't help wanting to do the same thing to his daughter - bring a man from Pakistan to marry her."

Since selling his off-licence in the late 1980s, Hussein has moved between England and his birthplace. But his next novel, about the US proxy war in Afghanistan, will again be in English. "I don't think in Urdu and translate; I think in whatever language I'm writing in."

"Everyone is a prisoner of their background, so you can't condemn people; hypocrisy invariably comes into it," says Hussein. "Amir falls back on a system of inherited values; he thinks every white woman is a prostitute. The irony is that he tells of a disaster resulting from a marriage of convenience, but he can't help wanting to do the same thing to his daughter - bring a man from Pakistan to marry her." Since selling his off-licence in the late 1980s, Hussein has moved between England and his birthplace. But his next novel, about the US proxy war in Afghanistan, will again be in English. "I don't think in Urdu and translate; I think in whatever language I'm writing in."

fields.headline: God of small things
fields.standfirst: Amit Chaudhuri's family drama, A New World, focuses on the details of life that hold back
fields.trailText: Amit Chaudhuri's family drama, A New World, focuses on the details of life that hold back
fields.body:
A New World
Amit Chaudhuri
Picador £12.99, 200pp
Buy it at BOL

Jayojit chooses his mother a sari. It is off-white, with orange embroidery. He is attracted to it "not because it stood out but because it had held back; there had been an understated quality about it that had caught his attention". This sari selection could serve to describe Amit Chaudhuri's imagination. He prefers, in this haunting but withdrawn novel, the details of life that "hold back". He is intent on the innocent, the shy and the incidental. "Life goes on", sometimes inconspicuously - and Chaudhuri follows it keenly.

The novel is a gamble because it is quite astonishingly lacking in incident. The drama for Jayojit - Joy for short - is over before the book begins. He is a Bengali economist working in the American mid-west whose wife has left him for her gynaecologist (an insulting choice). There has been a harrowing custody suit in two countries over their seven-year-old son Bonny, which has secured only limited victory for Joy. The novel spans a summer spent with Joy's parents in their flat in Calcutta.

We first meet father and son in transit. Chaudhuri writes as if he were a curious fellow traveller searching for clues, and he finds them everywhere. Bonny's gait, for instance, is a giveaway: he walks with "the mournful, loping air of a miniature expeditioner".

Pretty soon, the reader is moving in with the ageing Chatterjees and getting to know their flat; inspecting the lentils, the fresh bar of Lux soap, the fish heads - all the textures of life that persist no matter how gaping the holes in the emotional fabric. Home, for everyone in it, seems to be somewhere between a haven and limbo. Even the cooking participates in this: "Home food was safe and insipid and had a tranquillity about it." Joy is in a similarly savourless state. He can not cope with the idea of a strong taste, a second wife.

There were points in the novel when I almost laughed at the extent to which Chaudhuri is resolved to show life in uncooperative mood. Romance is not on the horizon; even the unpleasant diversion of ill health does not arise. People lie in the lap of their lives, waiting to be rocked. At the end of one chapter, Bonny might have caught a fever, but the last line reads: "The boy had no temperature." At the close of the novel, Joy finds himself making pleasant conversation with a young, unattached American woman on the plane home. But no new start is hinted at: "He felt not the slightest attraction towards her, and was reassured to sense that she probably felt none towards him."

There is charm in this, and it is convincing, too. Joy has every reason to be sad, but A New World is not a depressing book. Chaudhuri is witty, in his mournful fashion; his description of Joy's parents is funny, respectful and memorable. But the most striking moments involve looking beyond family - at strangers or passing acquaintances. A street vendor's eyes are "brown-grey, as if they held a little of the twilight of another town in them". A neighbour looks "distracted, as if life had turned out in some way a minor, uninteresting affair".

In Chaudhuri's hands, life may be minor but it is never uninteresting. By the time we witness Joy's understated farewells to his parents, we understand far more than we have been explicitly told about life in Calcutta, and about what Joy, his parents and son may be feeling. And the wrench at the end of the book is surprisingly like not wanting to say goodbye.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Michael Frayn's bittersweet portrait of a 1960s newspaper office is finally reissued, plus Home Truths, The Great Ideas and The Wonder
fields.body:
Towards The End Of The Morning
Michael Frayn
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Recommended more often than Scoop by one generation of hacks to another, Frayn's Fleet Street novel has at last been reissued. Unlike Waugh, Frayn is bitter-sweet rather than utterly satirical about journalism. John Dyson runs the nature notes and crossword section of a failing newspaper together past-it friends Bob and Eddy. Television, rather than Murdoch or web-mastery, is the spectre haunting their lunchtimes and when Dyson gets his chance at late-night punditry he blows it. Though Frayn's portrait of a 1960s newspaper office may seem like fanciful ancient history to today's content providers, much will be instantly familiar.

Home Truths
David Lodge
(Penguin, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Novels are always being turned into scripts, but as Lodge points out in his introduction, the process is rarely reversed. Reading Home Truths, which began life as a play that never made it to the West End, you can see why. The lives of a once-successful novelist, his wife and their old university friend, now a pompous Hollywood screenwriter, are overturned by a personality interviewer for a Sunday paper - a premise that does not cut it on the page. Lodge fills in the spaces between dialogue with elaborate description rather than giving his characters emotional hinterlands, and the deus ex machina which brings the curtain down is hopelessly contrived.

The Great Ideas
Suzanne Cleminshaw
(Fourth Estate, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

This coming-of-age novel is jazzed up with touches of American Gothic and philosophy borrowed from Jostein Gaarder. Its first few pages seem far too cleverly wrought for their own good, but Cleminshaw pulls off her narrative trick with humour and a good old-fashioned skeletons in the cupboard mystery. Heroine Haddie, aged 13, is accompanied in her search for the reason why her sister fell from the balcony of a neighbouring house by Louis Lewis, an irrepressibly precocious, half-French kleptomaniac. Cleminshaw adeptly portrays the knowingness and naivety of adolescence; what's disappointing is the banality of the solution to Haddie's quest.

The Wonder
JD Beresford
(Bison, £8.95)
Buy it at BOL

There is an admirable Edwardian solidity to Beresford's classic of "speculative fiction" that carries a good yarn, sometimes woodenly written, along. Our first-person narrator, naturally educated but at ease with landowners and the working class, tells of the strange progeny of an English cricketer he once knew. "The Wonder", an intellectual freak, is both a throwback to 19th-century monsters and a precursor to existentialist loners. His gift and his burden is his ability to understand instantaneously, to be deprived of mystery. Long unavailable, The Wonder is a minor work, but an enjoyable, old-fashioned discovery nonetheless.

fields.headline: Candid camera
fields.standfirst: Alfred Hickling  on two novels from Peter Everett and Helen Humphreys, both born of photography
fields.trailText: Alfred Hickling on two novels from Peter Everett and Helen Humphreys, both born of photography
fields.body:
Bellocq's Women
Peter Everett
Jonathan Cape, £15.99, 250pp
Buy it at BOL

Afterimage
Helen Humphreys
Bloomsbury, £15.99, 248pp
Buy it at BOL

The Victorians faced the camera as if awaiting execution; a visit to the photographer was a traumatic event. You placed your trust in an alchemist with silver nitrate-stained fingers, who promised that one's image had the power to outlast oneself. Photography brought with it the concept of the freeze frame. A photograph is an attempt to hold on to something long after it has already departed. Those early portraits have the air of an embalming procedure: subjects held as stiff against flock-wallpaper backgrounds as they would inevitably appear on a mortuary slab.

Beryl Bainbridge's novel Master Georgie opens with a sequence in which such a grouping is arranged: "Master Georgie ordered me to stand stock still and not to blink," relates Myrtle, the narrator. "He had me rest my hand on Mr Hardy's shoulder. Mr Hardy didn't have to be told to keep still because he was dead." Bainbridge may have started a trend. Master Georgie is conceived in photographic frames, in which everyone - except the photographer - has a point of view. The photographer records what he sees, not what he thinks. For novelists this is fertile territory, given that their job is to think on everyone's behalf.

Both Bellocq's Women by Peter Everett and Afterimage by Helen Humphreys began life as photographic sequences. Humphreys found her inspiration in a group of prints by an aristocratic female pioneer, while Everett took his from the dramatis personae of the brothels of New Orleans. Both take the collodion plate as evidence of a significant moment and sluice it in words to fill the imaginative gaps.

The outcomes are as diverse as the techniques are similar. Humphreys's novel will appeal to Pre-Raphaelite sensibilities excited by the frisson of lesbian intrigue; Everett's to anyone with a stomach strong enough to cope with a description of a child prostitute fished from the Mississippi disfigured by catfish.

But if a picture is worth a thousand words, are a couple of photographic collections worth two medium-length novels? Prudently, perhaps, both steer clear of illustrating their sources of inspiration. The late 19th-century studies which Julia Margaret Cameron took of her favourite housemaid in various allegorical disguises are not particularly well known, but have a generic pathos typical of Victorian "art" photography.

Everett is on less stable ground, in that the images he has chosen to work with have become iconic. His saving grace is that no one knows anything concrete about the man who created them. EJ Bellocq died in 1949 leaving little of note, but a drawer full of secrets. He had worked as a commercial photographer for the Foundation Shipping Company, making documentary assessments of damaged steam paddlers. On his death, however, 80-odd glass plates were discovered among his papers, featuring the women who worked in the brothels of the Storyville district in New Orleans. The plates were eventually purchased by the distinguished photographer Lee Friedlander, who printed up the images and arranged for their display at the New York Museum of Modern Art in 1970.

Friedlander's prints confirmed what he had suspected - Bellocq had, without anybody realising, built up a body of some of the most psychologically perceptive portraits in American photographic history. The fact that the photographer had later scratched away some of the women's faces to preserve their anonymity merely added to their poignant, mysterious power.

Although slightly prurient at first sight - the camera maintains the viewpoint of the prospective client - Bellocq's oeuvre is not pornographic, nor even particularly erotic. Often it veers closer to surrealism: a naked prostitute with her back towards us, unaccountably drawing a butterfly on the wall; dispassionate studies of the bizarre things women wear to please men; a Storyville whore splayed on a chair, covered in a bodystocking that reveals all her contours while erasing her nipples.

These strange twilight goddesses could be floating in one of the feverish, sensual visions of Belgian surrealist Paul Delvaux. They were, however, real women whom Bellocq clearly knew and cared about. He seemed to have been adopted by the flophouses as a kind of mascot or benevolent father figure (the women used to refer to him as "Papa").

Peter Everett has made something of a speciality of imagining himself inside other artists' skins. His previous novel, The Voyages of Alfred Wallis, inhabited the salty hide of the celebrated Cornish fisherman-painter, while Matisse's War, the one before that, took the rather more sophisticated Frenchman as its subject.

Everett chooses to explain Bellocq by casting him as a serial obsessive. First it's his mother, then his landlady's daughter; later a self-destructive 10-year-old nymphette. All of this sounds desperately unhealthy, but Everett suggests that Bellocq, who remained single all his life, gained in the blowsy, high-spirited enclaves of the brothels a sense of familial, domestic security that he failed to find elsewhere.

Everett particularly relishes the over-scented atmosphere of these curiously homely vice dens. In fact, the whole novel reeks. No sooner does Everett conjure a comparison with Degas's ballet dancers than he draws attention to the sweat under their armpits, tenderly evoked elsewhere in the novel as a "rank odour of wet rusty iron": his pungent prose plays everywhere upon the senses.

Afterimage, by comparison, is a breath of fresh air. This is the kind of novel in which the heroine enjoys the leisure to experience an erotic encounter with an apple tree and then floats indoors to enquire of her husband whether she will ever be taken seriously. Humphreys arranges a tidy story around three principal characters: Eldon, who wishes he were a great explorer; Isabelle, who wishes she were a great photographer; and Annie, her new maid, muse and model, who wishes being in service were more like Jane Eyre. Though Humphreys is certainly adept at teasing out a compelling tale, plot-wise this is fairly predictable, triangular stuff. The characters are far more preoccupied with exploring their individual fantasies than exploring each other.

Ultimately, however, what goes on in the mind of the photographer is pure speculation. The image is the only statement that matters. It is a point which eludes both these novels, but which Bainbridge dealt with brilliantly in Master Georgie. In Bainbridge's novel, the man behind the camera doesn't have a voice; Georgie never speaks. All we hear are the accounts of his motley caravan of admirers as the whole crew becomes sucked into the maelstrom of the Crimean War. As the situations and scenery become ever more harrowing, the camera goes on impassively recording. Bainbridge demonstrates that the camera never lies, it simply remains impeccably silent.

fields.headline: Big in first novels
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell rounds up the latest releases
fields.body:
"Why do saints come down to the world of the living, give us a couple of signs, and leave in a hurry?" asks the heroine of Maria Escandon's delightful Esperanza's Box of Saints (Picador, £9.99). While Esperanza prepares for her recently deceased daughter's funeral, San Judas Tadeo, saint of desperate causes, appears in the grease spots on her oven window.

Esperanza takes this as a sign that Blanca is not dead, but has in fact been kidnapped and forced into prostitution. Determined to save her, she journeys from her Mexican village to the brothels of Tijuana. Aided by a confessor priest, a pot-smoking judge, a cross-dressing pimp and the clutch of saintly icons she carries everywhere, the unassailable Esperanza is transformed from spiritual naif into woman of the world. And, like the characters she drags along on her quest, the reader is richer for it.

Rajeev Balasubramanyam's In Beautiful Disguises (Bloomsbury, £14.99) deals with a similar metamorphosis. The lazy days of Arjuna's south Indian childhood are spent dreaming of becoming a film star. These end abruptly when she is told she must marry.

Luckily, her brother-in law's father is on hand with a contact in the city, a few thousand rupees, and the sage advice to "experience life". Alas, Arjuna's world-view is mostly informed by the character of Holly Golightly in Breakfast at Tiffany's. Surely, all a woman needs is "an apartment, diamonds, a friend in Sing Sing, a cat"? But what if she's picked the wrong movie? What if in fact, Sabrina is a more appropriate allegory? Colourful, spirited and crackling with charm: it's easy to see why Balasubramanyam has already won a Betty Trask prize.

In the Alaskan wilderness of Kimberly Kafka's True North (Macmillan, £9.99), the bears are so hungry they eat rubber seats off snowmobiles. This desolation suits bush pilot Bailey Lockhart, who prefers to minimise human contact. However, her log cabin sits in the middle of indigenous territory, and her attraction to Ingalik activist Kash draws her into an angry debate over land rights. Wise in her handling of delicate issues, Kafka expertly balances arresting physical description and suspenseful prose.

Felix Campbell "grew up in a glen with a glen-shaped soul, and baptism in his heart". Still a virgin at 43 and oblivious to the designs of Ballymully's single women, he falls hook, line and sinker for a Catholic widow from the other side of the glen. In The Biggest Baby in Ireland after the Famine (Virago, £9.99), Anne Barnett picks up the torch from her storytelling ancestors as once again Protestant meets Catholic and traditional values conflict with the proclivities of the human heart. However, Barnett's contribution to the genre lacks energy: thin on plot and stylistic dynamism, she still has a lot to learn from Edna O'Brien's wry and moving representations of rural Irish community.

It's conventional to blame creative-writing programmes for slick prose and first-line shockers. Set in redneck rural Pennsylvania, the opening sequence of Maureen Gibbon's Swimming Green Arrow (Sceptre, £10) certainly conforms to stereotype. "When I was 18, I went parking with my boyfriend Del, my best friend June, and her boyfriend Ray. What I mean is that June fucked Ray and I fucked Del in the same car, at the same time."

However, this tale of female friendship and first love is surprisingly compelling. The graphic sex scenes are not for the squeamish, but though brutal, they are never gratuitous. Rather, Gibbon's craft is to force the reader to acknowledge how easily addictive sex can be mistaken for love, with all the grisly consequences that ensue. This she does with almost effortless assurance.

Alas, Arjuna's world-view is mostly informed by the character of Holly Golightly in Breakfast at Tiffany's. Surely, all a woman needs is "an apartment, diamonds, a friend in Sing Sing, a cat"? But what if she's picked the wrong movie? What if in fact, Sabrina is a more appropriate allegory? Colourful, spirited and crackling with charm: it's easy to see why Balasubramanyam has already won a Betty Trask prize. In the Alaskan wilderness of Kimberly Kafka's True North (Macmillan, £9.99), the bears are so hungry they eat rubber seats off snowmobiles. This desolation suits bush pilot Bailey Lockhart, who prefers to minimise human contact. However, her log cabin sits in the middle of indigenous territory, and her attraction to Ingalik activist Kash draws her into an angry debate over land rights. Wise in her handling of delicate issues, Kafka expertly balances arresting physical description and suspenseful prose. Felix Campbell "grew up in a glen with a glen-shaped soul, and baptism in his heart". Still a virgin at 43 and oblivious to the designs of Ballymully's single women, he falls hook, line and sinker for a Catholic widow from the other side of the glen. In The Biggest Baby in Ireland after the Famine (Virago, £9.99), Anne Barnett picks up the torch from her storytelling ancestors as once again Protestant meets Catholic and traditional values conflict with the proclivities of the human heart. However, Barnett's contribution to the genre lacks energy: thin on plot and stylistic dynamism, she still has a lot to learn from Edna O'Brien's wry and moving representations of rural Irish community. It's conventional to blame creative-writing programmes for slick prose and first-line shockers. Set in redneck rural Pennsylvania, the opening sequence of Maureen Gibbon's Swimming Green Arrow (Sceptre, £10) certainly conforms to stereotype. "When I was 18, I went parking with my boyfriend Del, my best friend June, and her boyfriend Ray. What I mean is that June fucked Ray and I fucked Del in the same car, at the same time." However, this tale of female friendship and first love is surprisingly compelling. The graphic sex scenes are not for the squeamish, but though brutal, they are never gratuitous. Rather, Gibbon's craft is to force the reader to acknowledge how easily addictive sex can be mistaken for love, with all the grisly consequences that ensue. This she does with almost effortless assurance. Buy Esperanza's Box of Saints at BOL Buy In Beautiful Disguises at BOL Buy True North at BOL Buy The Biggest Baby in Ireland after the Famine at BOL

fields.headline: Schoolboy in the wars
fields.standfirst: Richard Norton-Taylor  on Max Hastings' Going to The Wars
fields.trailText: Richard Norton-Taylor on Max Hastings' Going to The Wars
fields.body:
Going to The Wars
Max Hastings
Macmillan, £20, 400pp

Buy it at BOL

While Max Hastings was, as he puts it, bobbing about in the China Sea after fleeing Saigon in 1975, his mother wrote a letter to Charles Wintour, then editor of the London Evening Standard. It was high time, she said, that Max got on to the executive circuit. "I know that Max himself thinks he could not be happy without the constant stimulus of excitement and danger, but one cannot be a schoolboy for ever."

But the self-confessed romantic, now in Wintour's editorial seat, could not resist what became the apogee of his career as a war correspondent, indulging again what he calls his "lifelong love and admiration for the British army". This was the 1982 Falklands conflict, accounting for more than a quarter of this book. "If the unbelievable was to happen," he writes, "if we were to fight, I had to be there." He told his wife he felt it was for this moment he was born: "I feel I don't want to go on living if I'm left behind on this one." ("I really said that," he confesses here.)

Hastings triumphed through a mixture of luck, wit and guile. He shared a language with the senior officers, though not all admired him. Nor did he endear himself to some his journalistic colleagues, least of all when he walked alone into the Falklands capital, prompting the Standard front-page headline "The first man into Stanley". He comments: "It was the happiest moment of my career."

Hastings, in many ways a warrior manqué, revelled in the company of soldiers. He is the son of Macdonald Hastings, the celebrated wartime Picture Post correspondent, and Anne Scott-James, and his autobiography is a racy account - revealing both boyish self-indulgence and self-doubt - of his picaresque career. He makes no bones about where he is coming from. In Vietnam, he writes, the communists won the propaganda struggle at home and abroad by "cloaking their own military and political operations in obscurity, even invisibility, while the Americans bared their follies and misjudgments to the gaze of the world".

He adds: "We know that Stalin and Mao killed more people than Hitler. Yet most people today unequivocally regard Hitler as more evil." On the following page, he confesses: "I have always enjoyed teasing lefties, who seldom fail to rise to the fly."

Well, I was reminded in this case of a review Hastings wrote in 1982 of a book I had written on land ownership, a subject as neglected then as it is now. It included a deliberately provocative coda: "Every once in a while," he wrote, "walking up Fleet Street, you may glimpse a flurry of activity, a sympathetic little knot of onlookers gathered round a struggling figure. And, of course, you know that yet another writer from the Guardian has run screaming from that hothouse of dotty idealism, and must now be led gently away to his or her padded cell."

Hastings has an element of the showman about him: he is not all he appears to be. Some of his observations here seem surprising only because of an image he has created for himself, consciously or otherwise."What has befallen Ireland since 1968," he writes, "is the fruit of British indifference for 47 years after the 1912 Partition Treaty."

In a graphic description of clashes between Catholics and Protestants at the start of the "troubles" in August 1969, he observes: "Never an admirer of the Unionist government of Ulster, that night I became its committed foe... the Catholics were victims not only of institutionalised injustice, but also of clumsy and brutal efforts by the Stormont government and the RUC to put them down." Perversely, he says, he has felt ever since 1982 that it was right to fight the Falklands war to show that Britain was still capable of taking on aggression, but wrong not to negotiate a settlement with Argentina on sovereignty.

On journalism, he makes acute and forceful comments. "Forget the pack," he says. "Do your own thing." He recalls the late Nicholas Tomalin of the Sunday Times advising "They lie. They lie. They lie", and David English, late editor of the Daily Mail, saying "All the best journalists are obsessives". But he also derides what he calls a school of modern journalism "which holds that a reporter is failing in his duty if he speaks well of those in charge of anything". This is an entertaining book. But somehow I still do not know enough about the author.

fields.headline: Unknown travails
fields.trailText: First-time novelist Jason Cowley bemoans his hard luck, plus Harry Potter for Amazon and strange goings on in the bushes at the Faber party
fields.body:
 Oops. We seem to have offended New Statesman literary editor and first-time novelist Jason Cowley with our review of his book Unknown Pleasures the Saturday before last. In the Statesman's Diary column, Cowley bemoans the lot of the reviewer-turned-novelist, noting glumly that "I was forewarned by my wife and others that I wouldn't have it easy if I ever published a book myself."

In particular, he takes exception to a Times profile that painted him as an habitué of strip clubs and dodgy bars, and to these pages, in which "a career reviewer of first novels" had the temerity to dub his prose "portentous and cliché-ridden". More obscure debutant scribblers might well think that having your first work published by Faber, seeing it extensively reviewed and then writing about it in a magazine column is not the worst luck in the world, but there we are.

 Shrugging off the great share-price slide, Amazon is putting plenty of marketing muscle behind the new Harry Potter. Customers are invited to order before midnight on July 6, thus taking advantage of a 40 per cent discount and the chance to win tickets for a trip to LA, to be concealed in a golden envelope in one of the despatched books. With the great Dorling Kindersley Star Wars debacle still fresh in the memory, one can only hope that Harry works the same magic for the online bookseller as he has for Bloomsbury, and that readers are not suddenly infected with, in Amazon chief Jeff Bezos's words, "an irrational under-exuberance".

 To the annual Faber summer garden party, where Julian Barnes's patience was sorely tested by an eager diarist who asked him if he had seen much of Martin Amis since the publication of the latter's memoirs. The hapless correspondent was given short shrift, but praised Barnes's "extensive vocabulary": he can tell you to get lost with extraordinary eloquence.

Meanwhile, man of the moment Harland Miller moved coolly among the crowd, perhaps comparing the rather sedate gathering with his own star-studded bash, at which Jarvis Cocker played DJ, and publishing folk found themselves rubbing shoulders with supermodels and Young British Artists. Had he, as the gossips suggested, taken a peek into the bushes, he might have found a certain amount of bad behaviour to goggle at: details are hazy, but as usual, there were poets involved.

fields.headline: Blue remembered thrills
fields.standfirst: Christopher Isherwood only recalls the sex in his Lost Years, as  Ian Sansom discovers
fields.trailText: Christopher Isherwood only recalls the sex in his Lost Years, as Ian Sansom discovers
fields.body:
Lost Years: A Memoir 1945-51
Christopher Isherwood, edited by Katherine Bucknell
Chatto & Windus, £25, 388pp

This shows Christopher Isherwood at his worst: solipsistic, trivial, self-obsessed, bitchy, manipulative, immature, self-indulgent, guilt-ridden, filthy-minded, stupid with drink, spiritually flushed and morally bankrupt. For six years, and for almost 300 pages, almost nothing seems to happen: Isherwood works on crappy film scripts in Hollywood during the day, goes to parties with celebrities at night, gets half drunk and has sex a lot.

Sometimes he wrestles; he lies on the floor looking up at the ceiling; occasionally he pops in to see his guru. He drinks to "blood brotherhood" with Montgomery Clift. There are orgies. Norman Mailer visits, and Marlon Brando gets to make sandwiches in Isherwood's kitchen. It is therefore a book both unreadable and unputdownable.

Lost Years is Isherwood's reconstructed diary, composed between 1971 and 1977, about the period 1945-51, when he was in his early forties, living in Santa Monica with the photographer Bill Caksey. It fills in the gaping hole at the centre of the first volume of Isherwood's Diaries, published back in 1996, or at least it would if a hole can be said to be filled with a void. The title Lost Years is hardly subtle, but it is at least appropriate.

Isherwood had to go back and reconstruct the material because during the late 1940s he abandoned his habit of keeping the detailed diaries that provided him with material for many of his novels and autobiographical works - he was too lazy, or too busy, depending on how you look at it. Even by Isherwood's own uneven standards, Lost Years is therefore something of an oddity: an unpolished and unfinished memoir based on virtually non-existent diaries and edited by someone else, the dutiful Katherine Bucknell, who also edited the Diaries.

The reconstruction is at times a little wobbly, to say the least. The entries eventually peter out as Isherwood's attention begins to focus on various other writing projects, such as Christopher and His Kind, but even when he's concentrating on the job in hand his memory is unreliable and his efforts at recall half-hearted. Thinking back to his relationship with the artist Bill Harris, he wonders, "Why did he suddenly decide on this boyish elopement? Was he trying to prove to Bill how young he still was?... I simply cannot remember." If he can't remember, why should we care?

Isherwood's was always a style built around limitations, but in Lost Years the limitations become an irritation. History completely passes him by, as he reports himself in the third person: "The next month passed without any remarkable incidents, as far as I can judge from the day-to-day diary. It sounds crazy to say this, when, in fact, Mussolini and his mistress were killed on April 28, Hitler's death was announced on May 1, Berlin fell on May 2 and the Nazis surrendered on the 7th! The day-to-day diary merely records that, on the 28th, he took a taxi to the beach and spent the night at Denny's," etcetera.

Everything passes him by, then, except sex, of which he can't get enough: "Christopher was ready to have sex with most males within reasonable age limits." His sexual liaisons are about the only thing Isherwood seems to remember with any real clarity, purpose or pleasure. A large part of the book is therefore taken up with a lusty retelling of his adventures, or what he refers to as "stickings-in and pullings-out". There is sex in courtyards, in cars, with friends and casual pick-ups, plus an attempt at an underwater Pacific blowjob, which might provide a useful metaphor for the book as a whole: an attempt to bring froth out of foam.

At one point Isherwood announces, casually but authoritatively, like a cigar snob or a connoisseur of fine wines, that he prefers rimming to other sexual practices "because of its grossness". Grossness of various kinds is on display throughout the book. Isherwood recalls, for example, that the first time he slept with Stephen Spender's ex Tony Hyndman ("Jimmy Younger" in Spender's World Within World ), "he found the act so delicious that he was unwilling to wash Tony's shit off his cock".

This is frank, but not nearly so shocking as a throwaway phrase such as "When Christopher got cured of his guilt, several years later", which makes guilt sound like a cast-off sweatshirt. There are depths, however, to which Isherwood does not sink. He does not, for example, and thank God - would we ever have heard the last of it, from either of them? - have sex with Gore Vidal.

Even for Isherwood enthusiasts - for those of us who admire and marvel at his persistent attempts at honesty - there are passages in Lost Years that will unsettle and shock. Describing his relationship with the composer Barry Taxman, for example, Isherwood writes that "he had that Jewish tactlessness, argumentativeness and aggressiveness which always aroused Christopher's anti-semitic feelings. Only, in Barry's case, Christopher's anti-semitism quickly became erotic. It made him hot to mate Barry's aggressiveness with his own, in wrestling duels which were both sexual and racial, Briton against Jew. Barry's aggressiveness became beautiful and lovable when it was expressed physically by his strong lithe body grappling naked with Christopher's. As they struggled, Christopher loved him because he was a pushy arrogant Jewboy." Not despite, note, but because. So that's all right then.

The book ends abruptly in 1951 with the Broadway success of I Am A Camera - which saved Isherwood's career, and pulled him out of his downward spiral into sloth and self-pity - just out of sight and around the corner. I Am a Camera, adapted from Isherwood's novel Goodbye to Berlin, was later made into the film Cabaret by Bob Fosse, and although Isherwood undoubtedly deserves to be remembered as more than the man responsible for Liza Minnelli perched on a chair in black boots and stockings with her legs apart, it will not be for his Lost Years.

fields.headline: The sorcerers' apprentice
fields.standfirst: Where did Harry learn his trade?  Giles Foden  conjures up a short history of wizards in literature
fields.trailText: Where did Harry learn his trade? Giles Foden conjures up a short history of wizards in literature
fields.body:
"He stumbled, but everything still seemed to be working, and wasting no more time, Harry pointed his wand straight at Malfoy and shouted, 'Rictusempra!' "

Yes, everything does still seem to be working. As you may know by now, the latest book in the Harry Potter series is published next week. Part of the mystique is that the title, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, was until recently kept secret. Nearly 2m in advance sales adds something else to the aura. And then there is the author, no less mysterious than some of her own creations.

Lately she has been the subject of a piece of smear journalism in the Sunday Mirror, which tracked down her estranged husband Jorge in Portugal, alleging him to be a drug addict. Still, there must be compensations. Already among Britain's richest women, with her new book JK Rowling is likely to net a fortune in worldwide merchandising - £600m, according to one estimate.

But there is much more to her tales of the young wizard than money, hype and gossip. There is a back story to all this: wizards have long been part of literary culture, both as subjects and as personae adopted by writers. Rowling is not the only bestselling children's author to put the occult at the centre of her writing. Philip Pullman, whose Northern Lights has won him great acclaim and large sales, is another writer alert to the expansive power of magic in children's literature. Both are drawing on a tradition that stretches back to Tolkien and further, into the mist-shrouded origins of northern European literature.

In a schema that now has more general currency among Hollywood scriptwriters through the influence of mythographer Joseph Campbell, the hero or apprentice of a magical narrative will leave his or her "ordinary world" - the world of the Muggles, in Potter-speak - and face a journey, literal or metaphorical. On one level the attraction is clear: pure escapism and the fantasy of power denied in the ordinary world. On another it is more mysterious, posing the question of why magical narratives have proved so popular with children and young adults. Is there something freakish in the appeal of stories such as Rowling's, or should she be commended for a valuable contribution not just to children's books, but to literature in general?

Witches probably make more regular appearances in such stories (no doubt a function of a sexism that runs deep in the veins of the culture), but boy, are the wizards more interesting. They are more finely grained, with a moral hinterland that leaves witches gasping. In Lord of the Rings - a book which constantly tops best-ever lists - Gandalf, the longbeard wizard who guides the hobbits in their search for the Ring, is just such a cross-hatched figure.

He is knowing, but not all-knowing; powerful but, at the same time, fatally flawed. His transformative abilities are predicated on their not being over-used or abused; as if magical ability were a car that stopped working altogether if you drove it to the wrong places or at excessive speed. This is a common feature of the cultural presentation of "white" magic and also, one supposes, a submerged version of the parable of the talents: don't waste your wizardry. Hogwarts in the Potter stories flags up this aspect of sorcery simply by being a school.

Writers of the past have not been slow to show what happens when supernatural powers are squandered, and not just in children's books. Building on Malory's Morte d'Arthur and its precursors, Tennyson created what is perhaps the greatest wizard in literature in his long sequence of Arthurian poems, Idylls of the King. The genius of Malory's and Tennyson's Merlin is that as well as being an iconic figure - the guardian of national purity - he is also a three-dimensional character with ordinary hopes and desires and fears. Rowling has developed a similar approach in the Potter books, as have the writers of the cult television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

In Buffy, sex and magic are inextricably entangled, with the confusing world of adolescence finding symbolic equivalents in the arcana of demonology. These work on numerous levels. Buffy kills vampires, but her boyfriend is a good vampire, though unreliable and difficult to integrate into ordinary society; all the while, she has an Oedipal relationship with her tutor in magic, the likeable but absent-minded Giles.

Many of the Buffy characters are shape-shifters. The dry ice swirls, and friends show themselves to be monsters. This doesn't work only on a dramatic level; it also serves to exemplify how easily, in the confusion of teenage hormonal torment, an innocent or cosy sexual encounter can turn into something threatening. Shape-shifters are part of the Rowling universe too: in The Prisoner of Azkhaban, affable Professor Lupin turns out to be Master of the Dark Arts, and then a werewolf; finally we learn that he is a good werewolf.

The Goblet of Fire is rumoured to be the first of the Potter books in which sex makes an appearance. As Harry, Hermione and friends enter adolescence, it will be interesting to see how Rowling stacks up the multivalent layers of sexual and magical identity. Perhaps Harry will go to the bad. It can happen to the best of them. Look what happened to Anakin Skywalker. Or Edmund in CS Lewis's Narnia stories, who succumbed to the lures of the White Witch, with Turkish delight standing in for forbidden sexual territory. It's more likely Harry will flirt with danger, seem to fall, and come out all the stronger.

The test has long been a feature of magical narratives. In the Arthurian corpus of tales, both Sir Galahad and Sir Percival abdicate sexual power for military invulnerability, and variously fail or succeed the tests that are set them, according to which version you read. Lancelot becomes the Hugh Grant of Camelot, a figure in sexual disgrace; correspondingly, the magic stops working for him. It doesn't always work for the wizards, either. The key moment in Tennyson's Idylls comes when Merlin falls victim to sexual predations and is frozen in a tree, thereby losing his powers.

This is a reversal of the usual pattern. The figure of the male bad enchanter (as in Spenser's Faerie Queene) is a common one. He usually ends up cornering a virgin: Milton's Comus, using semen-like glues, sticks his to a chair. Sometimes, however, the wizard gives up his powers willingly, breaking his rod like Prospero or Millroy, the faith healer in Paul Theroux's Millroy the Magician. This generally happens when some kind of cycle is thought to be complete (although in Theroux's case it is to enable the magician to fulfill an ordinary sexual relationship).

If, as has been intimated, the Potter books continue into young adulthood - with three more said to be on their way, Harry looks as though he will get to his 18th birthday - can we expect our hero to retire in such a manner? Or, as with that wizard of the rational, Sherlock Holmes, will the public demand a comeback?

It has often been argued that for Shakespeare, Prospero's role in The Tempest offered a way of encoding the climax of his own career; it's certainly true that for centuries writers have drawn parallels between the magical and literary arts. And there is without doubt something nocturnal and glamorously spectral about many writers in person. In the past, the wizard look ran to their property too. Some, holed up in their grand, gothic houses, have seemed the very image of the necromancer: Walter Scott, for instance, the "White Wizard" of Abbotsford, consciously drew on a tradition of Scottish magick that included recorded figures such as Pale Kenneth and Major Weir.

Other authors, such as Yeats, have sought a necromantic agency in language, as though putting the right words in the right order might provide a channel to the nether world. In his memoirs, former Daily Chronicle and Guardian journalist HW Nevinson remembers visiting Yeats in his chambers at Woburn Place and listening to him harking on Leo Africanus, his 16th-century attendant spirit. Today, a quasi-magical correspondence with the past is at the heart of the work of authors such as Peter Ackroyd and Iain Sinclair. This correspondence is rooted in the London landscape, particularly the reaches of the Thames, the City and Clerkenwell.

The latter affords the setting of The House of Doctor Dee, Ackroyd's novel about the Elizabethan alchemist - another area in which literature and the spirit world have touched each other. Even a poet as sober as Geoffrey Hill has not been averse to the notion that writing is, to borrow a phrase of Freddie Mercury's, "a kind of magic": Hill's poems are full of images of gold, and constantly press the idea that words, properly used, have an alchemical, transformative power.

Writers such as these affect the image of the magus (think of John Fowles's novel), the wizard of an eastern, hermetic tradition in European literature that, through various byways, eventually winds itself back to the scholars of the Jewish Kabbalah; for these and their antecedents, secret knowledge is like a kind of drug.

If all this makes you think of Getafix, the wizard in the Asterix stories, and then of Will Self (this kind of free-associating rough magic is central to some theories of literary mysticism), the return takes you round to the spell itself - to the very words. It was through the words themselves that Baudelaire and Rimbaud, through other systems of mystic correspondences and vocalisations, sought to break and remake their worlds.

In this the dissolute French poets made common cause with authors of one of the most ancient forms of writing, runes. These archaic symbols appeared in Nordic and Germanic inscriptions from the second century AD until the Viking era, and latterly in Anglo-Saxon derivations. Used in systems of divination, they suggest that magic was central to the earliest forms of written communication.

Northern European writers today constantly hark back to this tradition, raiding the "word-hoard", as Seamus Heaney called it, in attempts to bring magic to their work. While some of the appeal of the Potter stories lies in the way they offer, like Middle Earth, Narnia and Gormenghast before them, a parallel world in which young people can test the boundaries of their nascent identities, they are also firmly in this mainstream of northern European literature. And perhaps not just northern European; if the writers whose forebears came out of the forested, frozen north can be called wizards, can the storytellers and wisdom-keepers of other cultures not be wizards too - the shaman of the Native Americans, the trickster of the Caribbean?

One thing is certain. When The Goblet of Fire comes out next week, JK Rowling will once again cast her spell over the minds of young children, the cash registers of bookshops - and, indeed, the keyboards of journalists driven to write that she is "casting her spell" over this and that. Afterwards, who knows? Maybe the craze will tail off, or maybe she will go from strength to strength. The wizards are out of the bag, in any case. Seamus Deane, Heaney's old schoolfriend, is rumoured to be writing a novel about one. Expect many more. But don't worry about wizards planning to take over the world. We have no plans of that nature.

 Giles Foden is the author of two novels, Ladysmith and The Last King of Scotland.

Part of the mystique is that the title, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, was until recently kept secret. Nearly 2m in advance sales adds something else to the aura. And then there is the author, no less mysterious than some of her own creations. Lately she has been the subject of a piece of smear journalism in the Sunday Mirror, which tracked down her estranged husband Jorge in Portugal, alleging him to be a drug addict. Rowling is not the only bestselling children's author to put the occult at the centre of her writing. Philip Pullman, whose Northern Lights has won him great acclaim and large sales, is another writer alert to the expansive power of magic in children's literature. fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The SAS are on Peter Kingston's tail, plus Wisden Cricketer's Almanac
fields.body:
The Hit List
Chris Ryan
(Random House, £8.99, 180mn)
Buy it at BOL
Hear an extract

These ex-SAS scribes are pumping yarns out faster than rounds from their old Heckler and Kochs. Bored after leaving his old regiment, Neil Slater signs up for a British assassination squad to rub out awkward foreigners. Christian Rodska licks it along in a suitably slim, tough NCO-ish voice. Alas, I don't know the final tally of the fatally clubbed and stabbed because the tape broke at the start of side 3. Accident or foul play? Who can sa-aaargh!

Wisden Cricketers' Almanack: three vols
(Mr Punch Audio, £9.99 each, 20 mn)
Buy Overseas Tour at BOL
Buy Tea in the Pavilion at BOL
Hear an extract

England won by an innings and 140 runs. But then, it was 1872 and they were playing Canada. These three titles - 137 Not Out, Tea in the Pavilion and Overseas Tour - boast more than a dozen voices and a jaunty muscial score, and the pickings are fascinating for anyone with a mild interest in the game.

fields.headline: Don't shoot the gatekeeper
fields.standfirst: Anthony Daniels  is unconvinced by Jeremy Harding's polemic on asylum seekers, The Uninvited
fields.trailText: Anthony Daniels is unconvinced by Jeremy Harding's polemic on asylum seekers, The Uninvited
fields.body:
The Uninvited: Refugees at the Rich Man's Gate
Jeremy Harding
Profile, £5.99, 128pp
Buy it at BOL

The discovery in Dover of the bodies of 58 Chinese who suffocated to death in the container in which they were being smuggled into this country is unlikely to deter anyone from making a similar effort in the future. The urge to migrate in search of a better life has always been a strong one, but it has never been stronger than it is today.

Thanks to television, the poor are in daily imaginative contact with the rich, and the unprecedented movement of goods and people across frontiers has given the poor more opportunities to migrate than ever before. Moreover, oppressive political regimes are by no means consigned to history, and probably never will be. Both push and pull, therefore, favour mass migration.

The rich countries of the world are far from delighted by such a prospect, however, and all try to erect barriers to limit the influx of political refugees and economic migrants. The author of this short book, which is part reportage and part analytical essay, believes that "fortress Europe" is neither desirable nor practicable. His sympathies are all with the migrants, and not with the mean-spirited authorities who try to keep them out. No one loves an immigration officer.

Jeremy Harding is at his best when describing individual cases. Only someone who was invincibly hard-hearted would not be moved by the dignified plight of individuals who have often risked hardship and even death in the hope of bettering themselves and their families. And migrants who succeed in evading the many obstacles put in their path are more than likely to prove resourceful and productive citizens of their new lands of residence.

When Harding moves from the particular to the general, however, he becomes convoluted, vague and evasive. One is never quite sure what he is proposing, if indeed he is proposing anything definite at all. His desire to appear more compassionate than thou always prevents him from getting down to brass tacks: and there is nothing quite like a brass tack to deflate a moral balloon full of hot air.

The essential dilemma of the situation is this: should everyone who wishes it be permitted entry into western Europe or not? After all, the pool of potential immigrants is vast. Harding's answer - neither yes nor no - reminds me rather of what Father Divine, a charlatan evangelist, used to tell his followers on the vexed question of his own divinity. "I'm not saying I'm God," he would declare. "But I'm not saying I'm not."

Most people would agree that there has to be some limit to immigration: that a world without frontiers is not really a possibility in the foreseeable future. Upon what basis, then, are immigrants to be allowed or refused entry and residence? Is the determining factor to be our need of their labour or their need of our succour? Is the fact that some immigrant groups are more easily assimilated into our culture than others to be taken into account? Is it really true that one immigrant is as good as another? And how many immigrants should be accepted annually into a country like Britain? 700? 7,000? 70,000? 700,000? 7m?

These are hard questions, and can't really be avoided. Moreover, Harding's desire to dissolve boundaries, not only between countries and continents but between different kinds of human suffering, so that anyone who has suffered anything in his or her life can plausibly claim to be a refugee, hardly helps: for if everyone is a refugee, no one is. And if there are no undeserving cases, there can be no specially deserving ones either. The book reads as if its author wants the glory of appearing generous, broadminded and warm-hearted, without the trouble of descending to tedious administrative detail that might so easily give one the opposite impression.

Harding's writing does not so much convey a meaning as a mood: one of intense self-satisfaction. The warm glow of self-righteousness radiates from almost every page, as from an electric heater. Here he is on the Macedonian treatment of Kosovar refugees during Nato's bombing campaign: "There was much to extenuate the reaction of this little country to the overwhelming influx of refugees - it was no worse than the worst reactions in wealthier countries to the arrival of the Kosovars - but in the end, it looked very much like a version of the same hostility that had driven them from their homes in the first place."

This sentence succeeds in being confused, repulsive and erroneous at the same time, which is a considerable achievement in so short a passage of prose. It conveys no overall moral or empirical point; it is mealy-mouthed about the problems faced by the Macedonians, which were roughly equivalent in scale, pro rata, to those that would have been posed by the arrival within a few weeks of 25m Mexicans in the United States; and it implies that the treatment of the Kosovars in Macedonia was morally equivalent to that they had received in Kosovo. This latter is a disgusting slur, the only possible function of which is to stimulate admiration in the reader for the intensity of the author's compassion.

The refusal to face in any concrete way the real moral and practical dilemmas posed by mass migration is this book's greatest weakness. It also has an exhibitionist, self-important quality. There is a great difference between being open-hearted and wearing one's heart on one's sleeve, though this is a distinction that we seem ever less able to make.

 Anthony Daniels is the author of Monrovia Mon Amour, a book about Liberia.

fields.headline: Bard times
fields.standfirst: John Updike is clearly enjoying himself in his prequel to Hamlet, Gertrude and Claudius
fields.trailText: John Updike is clearly enjoying himself in his prequel to Hamlet, Gertrude and Claudius
fields.body:
Gertrude and Claudius
John Updike
Hamish Hamilton, £16.99, 212pp
Buy it at BOL

If any writer has sufficient bombast to take on the Bard, it is John Updike. He is not quite the grand old man of American letters - that's surely Bellow - nor can he match the machismo of Mailer, the rampant inventiveness of Pynchon and DeLillo, or the urban mythmaking of Roth. Yet he remains important because he's a master craftsman, his characteristically ribald tales of familial tensions and small-town infidelities conveyed, almost too elegantly, within carefully modulated sentences.

Perhaps it's this acute feeling for the lush possibilities of language, combined with an equally sensitive perception of the seedy duplicity and detritus of everyday life, that allows him to approach the Bard, however reverentially.

What Updike offers us in Gertrude and Claudius is a roiling three-part prequel to Shakespeare's Hamlet. The action spans three decades, and in each section Updike signals the various sources of the play by invoking the appropriate spellings.

In part one the names are taken from a 12th-century account of the Hamlet legend. We see Gerutha betrothed to the king, Howendil; she bears a son, Amleth, and is drawn to the king's brother, Feng. In part two, the names come from a 16th-century source: Geruthe commits adultery with Fengon, Horvendile's brother, thus arousing the suspicions of her son, Hamblet. In part three the drama tiptoes into the first two scenes of Shakespeare's version, and the names revert to those he favoured.

By tracing the story's provenance, Updike cleverly undermines the perception of Shakespeare's text as the definitive version of the tale, while also paying homage to his creative appropriation of the original sources.

Updike's endeavour is similarly fluent. He dreams between the lines, making full use of the additional subtleties and depths offered by novelistic discourse. What would be theatrical asides become lengthy interior monologues; motives only suggested or summarised previously are investigated and dramatised. The fraternal rivalries and resentments are well measured and deftly nuanced throughout, so that when Feng finally poisons the king as he sleeps in the orchard, it is less an act of malice than a despairing bid to overcome the loveless dictates of the court.

Our knowledge of the play and its resonances are everywhere brought to bear by Updike's twists and turns. He smuggles in lines and phrases and teases with presentiments, some more subtle than others. Hamlet himself is banished to brood in the wings; he has only one line in the book. His moody presence is communicated by the worried words of others, and he looms all the larger because of it. Just as we are inhabiting the lacunae of Shakespeare's text - spaces now lavishly upholstered by Updike's prose - so, too, do we sense the dark prince stalking the blind spots of our own newly granted perspective. And the terrible foreboding is all ours.

As the novel progresses, the queen's ignorance of her husband's murder piques the reader's conscience, and we flinch at the studied accretion of her niggling doubts and unhappinesses. We are guilty by proxy, the murderer's accomplice, and Updike presses the point with glorious understatement: "She was puzzled. There seemed to be a secret."

In prose bulging with earthy metaphors and canny dialogue, Updike proffers descriptions to prick the senses: a garment has "the secret little greasy stink of sheep in the rain". He excels at the seemingly incidental objects of domestic life, here transposing this skill to the timber-floored chambers and wainscoted rooms of "vast, formal, echoing Elsinore". The brushes, powders and toothpicks on Gertrude's dressing table comprise a sad inventory of a queen never quite at ease with her roles as mother and wife.

Elsewhere, Corambis (Polonius) retains the clumsy punning and pontification that Shakespeare bestowed upon him. And Updike drops in a few anachronisms to give an ahistorical, ironic feel, just in case we are beginning to take it all too seriously. Understandably for such an ambitious project, there are moments in the narrative that don't quite ring true, as well as bucolic passages during which Updike's sentences become fat with self-indulgence: a "gloomy winter morning emanated a coruscating halo of static phosphorence". Occasionally, pronouncements lack humour or insight.

No doubt Updike would defend his stylistic extravagance under the licence of a bawdy Elizabethan excess, and nowhere more so than when writing about sex. As you'd expect from a writer who has fun finding new ways to describe the "brainless rhythm of thrust and counterthrust", here he runs amok. Women are to be "pressed into the mattress and basted like a spitted chicken", while Howendil boasts "enough explosive thrusting to fill a bucket". The queen is supremely submissive: "had he bid her lie down in pigshit she would have squeezed her buttocks together in the clench and rejoiced to be thus befouled".

Clearly, Updike is enjoying himself. Perhaps he believes he can preclude charges of misogyny or chauvinism by entering into the spirit of the times. Others might claim that, as in The Witches of Eastwick, he is at his best when giving his prejudices free rein. Despite its injudicious outbursts, and there are quite a few of them, Gertrude and Claudius is a marvellously enterprising and linguistically joyful footnote to one of the most famous plays in our language. Whether or not such a full and frothy conceit can survive the rigours of a second reading is altogether another matter.

fields.headline: Online help for househunters
fields.standfirst:
There is now a wide choice of property and mortgage websites, Jessica McCallin finds

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: There is now a wide choice of property and mortgage websites, Jessica McCallin finds
fields.body:
Confused about the service you should get from a mortgage provider? Visit the Mortgage Code Compliance Board's new website at www.mortgagecode.com.

The site provides information on how your mortgage should be arranged, what information you should receive before you commit yourself and how your mortgage should be dealt with once it is in place.

Flexible mortgages which allow you to overpay and underpay received a boost this week when online mortgage provider E-Loan announced plans for a database of truly flexible loans which meet stringent criteria.

They will be available from July 4 onwards at www.eloan.com/uk.

Bid for a home over the internet through www.PropWatch.com. The website allows consumers to buy and sell property online using a bidding process where the market rather than an estate agent sets the price of the property. Buyers submit offers online using software that allows sellers to set a defined bidding period, after which they can choose whether to accept the highest bid or not.

Internet home buying can also be done through the television. In a deal with cable company Telewest, digital television viewers will be able to access on-screen Property Internet's residential property website www.08004homes.com. The site has more than 70,000 UK properties and also features property news, house buying advice, area guides, financial services advice and DIY information.

Find a property (www.findaproperty.com) is hoping to lure potential buyers with more detailed information. The website has introduced five new categories: prestige homes, waterside homes, new homes, short let and commercial. It hopes the move will help customers locate their desired property more effectively and with more precision.

Share website MoneyGuru (www.moneyguru.co.uk) is offering refunds to customers who follow its advice but don't see the returns. The site says that if recommendations from its in-house ana lysts don't outperform the FTSE All-Share index average over the year, customers will get a no-quibble refund of their £11.95 subscription.

Fund information site TrustNet (www.trustnet.co.uk) has had a redesign. New features include live news feeds, comparative performance tables and charts and a personal portfolio facility.

fields.headline: Deadly net Terror websites easy to access
fields.standfirst:
Copeland profile
Photo gallery
Special report
Audio from outside the Old Bailey
fields.trailText: For as long as it has been a public network, the internet has offered detailed information on every aspect of bomb-making. But the revelation at Copeland's trial that he learned his deadly techniques from the web was a disturbing confirmation of what is available online.
fields.body:
For as long as it has been a public network, the internet has offered detailed information on every aspect of bomb-making. But the revelation at Copeland's trial that he learned his deadly techniques from the web was a disturbing confirmation of what is available online.

Copeland downloaded The Terrorist's Handbook and How to Make Bombs: Book Two after visiting an internet cafe near Victoria in London.

Both titles are still easily accessible; a search yesterday for the keywords "terrorist" and "handbook" on the Google search engine found nearly 4,000 matches. One site gives instructions on how to acquire ammonium nitrate, Copeland's "first choice" of explosive material.

How to make fuses and timers is also explained, accompanied by what were described at the trial as "facetious" warnings not to experiment. One website begins with the caution: "Don't try anything you find in this document!!!" - followed by an 11-chapter guide to making explosives.

The best-known bomb-making guide, The Anarchist Cookbook, offers instruction on everything from making an atomic bomb to devising a rocket launcher "for under $5". Such sites are, however, a small proportion of the 800m websites on the net, and the material available here can also be found almost as easily in bookshops and libraries.

Roger Darlington, chair of the Internet Watch Foundation, said: "The problem isn't the internet as such, it is ease of access, and anonymity."

Internet access can be traced, however. "Obtaining the information on the internet may betray you more than if you bought it in a bookshop."

The Internet Watch Foundation believes internet service providers, the hosts for websites, should be encouraged to exercise more social responsibility.
